headline: How to Visit Some of Paris’s Finest Museums but Skip the Crowds
text: Paris is home to the finest museums in the world. Unfortunately, they are also some of the most crowded. Nearly four million people head to the Pompidou Center and the Musée d’Orsay each year. The Louvre receives more than twice as many.

headline: Kicking Off the Lunar New Year
text: A firecracker festival in Roosevelt Park in Manhattan’s Chinatown on Friday is one of many events this weekend to mark the beginning of the Year of the Horse.

headline: Amanda Knox, Found Guilty in Italy Killing, Vows to Fight Extradition
text: Appearing stunned and fighting back tears, Amanda Knox said Friday that she “will never go willingly back” to Italy and would fight any effort to extradite her “to the very end.”

headline: Give Malta Your Tired and Huddled, and Rich
text: PARIS — Having been besieged by the Ottomans, and ruled over the centuries by foreign invaders from the Greeks to the Romans to Napoleon, the tiny Mediterranean island nation of Malta has seen plenty of unwelcome interlopers.

text: Donald S. Engel, a lawyer who helped pop stars like Olivia Newton-John, Donna Summer and the Dixie Chicks wrest greater control of their careers from their record companies, died on Jan. 15 in Redwood City, Calif. He was 84.

headline: Child Pornography Charges Against Police Chief Roil a Town in Westchester
text: VALHALLA, N.Y. — Betrayed. That was the word some parishioners used to describe how they felt about the arrest of a longtime member of their congregation who happened to be the police chief of Mount Pleasant.

headline: For Some, Retirement Is Out of Reach. For Others, Boring.
text: IN just a few days, Jay Leno, 63, the host of the “Tonight” show for the last 22 years, will be ceding his comedic throne to the 39-year-old Jimmy Fallon.

headline: France and Britain Agree on Outer Space, but Find No Common Ground on Europe
text: LONDON — Britain and France are stepping up their cooperation in outer space, but in Europe they still move in very different orbits.

headline: A Library for Obama First Needs an Address
text: On election night in 1992, James L. Rutherford, known as Skip, was celebrating with other key Clinton supporters on the streets of Little Rock, Ark., when he felt the hand of Herschel Friday, a prominent Arkansas lawyer and member of the Clinton finance committee, on his back.

headline: Are You Ready for Some ... Nordic Voices?
text: Sunday promises to be a big night for Peyton Manning, the quarterback of the Denver Broncos; for Russell Wilson, his counterpart on the Seattle Seahawks; and for their teammates, competing in a stadium before 80,000 spectators and a television audience of more than 100 million people.

headline: Retailers Ask: Where Did Teenagers Go?
text: Luring young shoppers into traditional teenage clothing stores has become a tough sell.

headline: Theodore Millon, Psychologist and Student of Personality, Dies at 85
text: Theodore Millon, a psychologist whose theories helped define how scientists think about personality and its disorders, and who developed a widely used measure to analyze character traits, died on Wednesday at his home in Greenville Township, N.Y. He was 85.

headline: The Super Bowl and Sex Trafficking
text: TENS of thousands of people have descended upon the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area this week for tomorrow’s Super Bowl, accompanied by the usual media frenzy. A now familiar feature of this coverage, wherever the Super Bowl is held, is an abundance of stories, from Reuters to CNN, reporting that the event will cause a surge in sex trafficking to capitalize on the influx of fans and tourists.

headline: Even Out of Office, a Wielder of Great Power in Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — THE old man still rises at 5:30 a.m., as he did during the three decades he ruled this tumultuous country. He does some physical therapy to help his scarred body recover from the 2011 bomb blast that nearly killed him. He reads the papers. And then, sitting in a gazebo in a high-walled compound that rivals the presidential palace, he begins receiving the endless tide of visitors who still treat him as if he were the most powerful man in Yemen.

headline: In Rinks Beyond Sochi, a Chance for Players Left Behind
text: MINNEAPOLIS — An expansive mural dominates a high corner wall at the University of Minnesota’s Ridder Arena. It depicts the seven Golden Gophers female hockey players who have participated in the Winter Olympics — six for the United States and goalie Noora Raty for Finland. Now, it may have to spill over to another wall. Four more Americans and another Finn have been named to teams for Sochi.

headline: Skyline? Yes. Night Life? Great! Lake to Skate On? No.
text: From Mount Kisco in Westchester County, N.Y., to Fair Haven on the Jersey Shore, ponds and lakes have frozen solid. “There’s something a little magical about it,” said D. J. Breckenridge, the director of parks and recreation for the Borough of Fair Haven, N.J., where a hundred children slipped and glided on McCarter Pond one afternoon this week.

headline: The Sound of a Tree Falling Is Not Ka-ching
text: For each member of a band the question may arise whether to do a solo project. Some bands consist of musicians who’ve already done projects on their own. But some people have known life only in the band, and the prospect of a solo venture can be both exhilarating and scary to ponder. I was of the latter variety.

headline: Harold Shaw, Manager of Major Classical Artists, Dies at 90
text: Harold Shaw, an artist manager whose clients included some of the most famous performers in classical music, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: The Economic Road Ahead
text: Economists, politicians and investors gave the latest economic growth report, released on Thursday, a generally warm reception: The estimated annual growth rate in the fourth quarter of 2013, a decent 3.2 percent, could bode well for further growth this year. But there are, on balance, more reasons for caution than for optimism.

headline: Too Loud, Too Quiet: Those Alluring Seahawks
text: This year’s N.F.L. playoffs have been a study in hypocrisy. Not from the N.F.L. — which is clear about the violence and mayhem it packages and sells — but from those of us who fight our battles with pens and pads, microphones and cameras. We have been pushed by technology — and vanity — to want it both ways: We capitalize on noise, and we capitalize on silence, and yet we complain about both.

headline: Fewer Benefits for Target’s Part-Timers
text: Target has announced that it will no longer provide health insurance for part-time workers but will send them instead to the new health care exchanges established by the Affordable Care Act. The change could help low-income workers who will now have access to subsidized coverage. It might distress middle-income workers ineligible for a big subsidy, and it is likely to be bad news for taxpayers, who will foot the bill for the coverage Target had provided. But the biggest unanswered question is this: Will Target raise wages to make up for the loss of the company contribution? As a matter of fairness, it should.

headline: On 35th Anniversary of Diplomatic Ties With U.S., China Tries to Soften Image
text: With tensions between China and the United States growing over a range of political and economic issues, the Chinese government is using the 35th anniversary of diplomatic relations this year as part of an intensified effort to soften its image.

headline: Aid for Students With a Dream
text: With Congress circling immigration reform ever so slowly, it is up to the states to provide more help to young people who were brought to this country illegally by their families. Some states, like California, have already made it possible for undocumented students who graduate from high school to pay at the in-state tuition rate and get financial aid when they go to state colleges.

headline: Fight Over Effective Teachers Shifts to Courtroom
text: LOS ANGELES — They have tried and failed to loosen tenure rules for teachers in contract talks and state legislatures. So now, a group of rising stars in the movement to overhaul education employment has gone to court.

headline: Detroit Sues to Cancel Some Costly Contracts
text: Detroit filed suit on Friday to invalidate some complex transactions it used to finance its pensions, contending they were illegal from the very beginning.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 31, 2014
Russell Wilson, the Man Behind Center, Could Have Wound Up as a Second Baseman
text: JERSEY CITY — Russell Wilson needed help, and he needed it right then. The next morning, he was to fly to Denver to sign his contract with the Colorado Rockies and work out at his new full-time position of second baseman before shipping off to the minors, and he did not know how to turn a double play.

headline: Obama Is Said to Plan Fence-Mending Trip to Saudi Arabia
text: WASHINGTON — Seeking to mend a frayed relationship with a major American ally in the Middle East, President Obama plans to travel to Saudi Arabia in March for a meeting with King Abdullah, an official with knowledge of the planning said Friday.

headline: Snacks Laced With Marijuana Raise Concerns
text: DENVER — All day long, customers at LoDo Wellness Center, one of Colorado’s new recreational marijuana stores, reach into the refrigerator and pull out tasty ways to get high. They buy sparkling peach and mandarin elixirs, watermelon Dew Drops, and sleek silver bags of chocolate truffles, each one packed with marijuana’s potent punch.

headline: Unionized College Athletes?
text: Kain Colter is a senior at Northwestern University, a pre-med student majoring in psychology with a 3.1 grade-point average. For the last two years, he has also been the starting quarterback for the university’s football team, where he has shown himself to be a real leader and, in the words of his academic adviser, “a wonderful example of a true student-athlete.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 1, 2014
text: “We do not make a pot brownie. It’s a little cliché for us.”

headline: Funds Meant for Charters May Be Diverted to Pre-K
text: New York City’s schools chancellor announced her intention on Friday to shift money away from charter schools to help pay for Mayor Bill de Blasio’s expansion of prekindergarten programs.

headline: Pipeline Opponents’ Hopes Now Rest Largely on Kerry
text: WASHINGTON — Environmental activists have not been shy in their fight against the Keystone XL pipeline. They have wrapped a giant pipeline around the White House fence, marched on Washington in the frigid cold, been arrested, and followed President Obama around the country to press their concerns while raising millions of dollars for the cause.

headline: East Hampton Withdraws From Deer-Culling Program
text: After vigorous opposition to deer culling, both the Village and Town of East Hampton have decided to withdraw from a program to bring in federal sharpshooters to significantly thin the local herd. The developments throw into doubt the future of what had been designed as one of the largest deer removal efforts ever undertaken by the federal government.

headline: The Masculine Mistake
text: If one of the overt Democratic lines of attack against Republicans is that Republicans are conducting a war on women, one of the low-simmering, implicit lines of attack from Republicans is that Democrats are conducting a war on men, or at least traditional views of masculinity.

text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, that was a lot of fun. We haven’t seen Will Nediger’s byline in a year (his last one was published Jan. 30, 2013), and it’s nice to have him back.

headline: $300,000 Robbed From Armored Car
text: Three men in heavy winter clothing robbed an armored-truck guard at gunpoint on Friday around noon, stealing about $300,000 in cash, the authorities said.

headline: As Manchester United Flails, Its New ‘Chosen’ Manager Is Feeling the Strain
text: MANCHESTER, England — After enduring years of industrial decline, the people of this northern city are not new to building, or to rebuilding, and they have experienced things far worse than the loss of a few more soccer matches than usual.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: A move to protect freshly cooked meals in French restaurants, an interest rate increase in Turkey and a video camera maker that wants to become a media company.

headline: Presidential States
text: President Obama’s State of the Union address certainly lacked the raw drama that other presidents around the world generated last week: Viktor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine took “sick leave” as two months of protests sapped his powers; Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was snubbed in Brussels; the love life of France’s François Hollande remained stubbornly in the news; Mohamed Morsi of Egypt was confined to a soundproof cage at his trial; Bashar al-Assad of Syria heard no weakening of calls for his ouster at peace talks in Geneva.

headline: Tech Rides Are Focus of Hostility in Bay Area
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Like huge lumbering beasts, the luxury buses shuffle down Valencia Street.

headline: Israeli Military Strikes Targets in Gaza
text: Israeli warplanes carried out raids against three Palestinian targets in Gaza early Friday, soon after militants fired a rocket from Gaza into southern Israel. The Israeli military said it struck a plant for weapons manufacturing, a weapons storage site and what it called a “terror activity site.” Ashraf al-Qedra, a spokesman for the Hamas-run Health Ministry in Gaza, said that five Palestinians were wounded, including a 6-year-old girl, who lived near one of the targets and was injured by flying glass. Later Friday, Israeli forces fired on Palestinians who had entered a restricted buffer zone in two areas along the fence separating northern Gaza from Israel, wounding seven. The military said that the soldiers opened fire to disperse rioters who were hurling rocks along the fence.

headline: Paul Allen, the Seahawks’ Man in the Shadows, Shows Them the Light
text: As the Seattle Seahawks prepared to play the San Francisco 49ers in the N.F.C. championship game two weeks ago, the anticipation at CenturyLink Field was palpable. The fans roared as the home team was introduced. They chanted fight songs. They booed the visitors.

headline: Texas: Historic Status for Astrodome
text: The Houston Astrodome, which has languished since being shuttered nearly six years ago, has earned a listing in the National Register of Historic Places. But the federal listing, made public on Thursday, may not be enough to save the 48-year-old stadium from the wrecking ball. Officials in Harris County are undecided about its fate after voters last year turned down a $217 million plan to redevelop the site into a convention and event center. A spokesman for Harris County’s top elected official, Judge Ed Emmett, said the dome’s inclusion in the register “would have no practical effect on the county’s ability to either repurpose the Astrodome for future use or to demolish it.”

headline: Callahan Trade Talk Overshadows Victory
text: After the exhilaration of two victories at Yankee Stadium, it was back to reality, and a foreboding one at that, for Rangers fans on Friday. As they sat in Madison Square Garden and watched the Rangers beat the Islanders, 4-1, the fans knew they might be watching Ryan Callahan’s last game with the team.

headline: Bloomberg Picked to Be Climate Envoy
text: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire former mayor of New York City, has a new job: United Nations special envoy for cities and climate change. The United Nations secretary general’s office said Friday that Mr. Bloomberg would be responsible for nudging cities around the world to take steps to combat climate change, helping to “raise political will and mobilize action among cities” in the months before a climate summit meeting that is scheduled to take place in New York in September. The United Nations climate agenda has been entangled in arguments between rich and poor nations over who should more urgently take steps to reduce carbon emissions. As mayor, Mr. Bloomberg set a citywide goal to slash emissions by 30 percent by 2030. He tried to penalize taxi owners who did not use fuel-efficient hybrid cars, but the courts blocked that effort in 2011, calling it a de facto regulation of emissions standards — a power that, under existing laws, belongs to the federal government. Reuters first reported the news of Mr. Bloomberg’s appointment early on Friday. “I can’t think of a person better suited for this important new role,” Secretary of State John Kerry said in a statement.

headline: At Barclays Center, Nothing Can Stop Kevin Durant Except the Bench
text: Seconds before the opening tip on Friday night at Barclays Center, Kevin Durant skipped alone across the baseline — his eyes partly closed, his head tilted backward — and let out a prolonged scream. It was an aggressive posture that did not bode well for the Nets.

headline: Conservative Groups Outpaced in Fund-Raising Stakes
text: A network of outside groups with close ties to Republican Party leaders raised just $7.2 million last year, group spokesmen said on Friday, suggesting some top donors remain on the sidelines as the 2014 campaign season begins.

headline: Video Notebook: Britton Colquitt
text: Britton Colquitt, the punter for the Denver Broncos, talks about what it's like being from a family of punters, three of which have played in the N.F.L.

headline: Making Surveillance a Little Less Opaque
text: One of the most disturbing aspects of the surveillance programs revealed by Edward Snowden is how little we knew about the information federal agencies have collected about millions of people. That is partly because these agencies have put severe limits on how much private telephone and Internet companies can disclose about the data they have been ordered to turn over to the government.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 7:15 P.M. (HBO) EPIC (2013) The spirited 17-year-old daughter (Amanda Seyfried) of an eccentric scientist (Jason Sudeikis), trying to prove the existence of a nearly invisible kingdom, ventures into a lush forest and shrinks to two inches, the better to ride on the backs of hummingbirds, in this animated film inspired by William Joyce’s children’s book “The Leaf Men and the Brave Good Bugs.” There, she meets the leader of the Leafmen (above, voiced by Colin Farrell), an army of ecowarriors committed to saving their environment from the evil Boggans, who want to turn it into a wasteland. Beyoncé Knowles provides the voice for the Leafmen’s ruler, whose 100-year reign will end when a flower pod bursts under a full moon to reveal the new queen; Christoph Waltz is the leader of the Boggans, who cruise on flying rodents; and Steven Tyler is the distracted yellow caterpillar in charge of recording the forest’s history. “The gorgeous 3-D adventure comedy,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, “suggests a warmer, fuzzier ‘Avatar,’ with a green heart. Directed by Chris Wedge, the movie is a hymn to nature rendered in phantasmagoric detail as refined as anything I’ve seen in a computer-animated family film. But as beautiful as it is, ‘Epic’ is fatally lacking in visceral momentum and dramatic edge.” Still, he added, “for what it’s worth, ‘Epic’ is on the side of the angels.”

text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Fund-Raising by G.O.P. Rebels Outpaces Party Establishment
text: Insurgent conservatives seeking to pull the Republican Party to the right raised more money last year than the groups controlled by the party establishment, whose bulging bank accounts and ties to major donors have been their most potent advantage in the running struggle over the party’s future, according to new campaign disclosures and interviews with officials.

headline: Reopening an Employment Door to the Young

headline: True South | New Orleans Dining, High and Low
text: “The past doesn’t pass away so quickly here,” Bob Dylan said about New Orleans. In the debut of True South, a new video series, Sara Ruffin Costello, a T contributing editor, shows how that’s still true about eating out in the Big Easy, visiting two wildly popular new restaurants in the French Quarter that “springboard off the classics” in very different ways. One is Killer Poboys, a delicious sandwich shop in the back of a dive bar; the other is Marti’s, a onetime local institution that has been relaunched as a model for fun, upscale culinary excellence. Each in its own way offers up an essential New Orleans flavor.

headline: When Your App Is in the Cloud
text: The telecommunications services business, worth about $1 trillion in annual, global sales, is starting to feel the effects of cloud computing, one of this era’s most important advances in high tech.

headline: The Work Before the Parachute Jump
Trying to See Apple From a Different Angle
text: The stock market doesn’t know quite what to make of Apple.

headline: Jody Greenstone Miller, on Not Overselling the Job Ahead
text: This interview with  Jody Greenstone Miller, co-founder and C.E.O. of the Business Talent Group, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. The Business Talent Group provides independent professionals for project-based work.

headline: Phoning From Prison, at Prices Through the Roof
text: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: Get Some Sleep, and Wake Up the G.D.P.
text: January is always a good month for behavioral economics: Few things illustrate self-control as vividly as New Year’s resolutions. February is even better, though, because it lets us study why so many of those resolutions are broken.

headline: Vows: Finding Love, Again
text: Anne Tarbell and William Marden III each lost their longtime spouses to cancer in 2010. Starting over again was frightening, but they adopted the mantra "life is for living."

headline: How de Blasio Measures Up on the Court, Field and Ice
text: While Mayor Bill de Blasio towers above most characters on the New York political stage, he would hardly be an outlier among New York’s best known professional athletes, depending on the sport.

headline: 1959: Oslo’s Worry: What Will Tourists Think?
text: OSLO — Oslo is the Little Orphan Annie of the northern capitals. Stockholm is the “Venice of the North,” Copenhagen, we all know, is “wonderful,” but Oslo has no such label — and it feels the lack most bitterly. It is always panting to catch up.

headline: And Now, a Preview From Your Sponsor
text: Advertising columnist Stuart Elliott discusses which Super Bowl commercials have already generated the most buzz.

headline: A Long Fight to Get What Was Theirs, in a 401(k)
text: Five years, two articles in this space, assistance from the Labor Department and the Internal Revenue Service and prodding from one no-nonsense bankruptcy judge — that’s what it took for owners of the 401(k) plan sponsored by Penn Specialty Chemicals to gain access to their money last month.

headline: Chasing Their Star, on YouTube

headline: Heat Are Listing, but Righting Ship Will Not Take Much
text: When they came to New York to face the Knicks on Jan. 9, the Miami Heat were 27-8. Trailing the Indiana Pacers by one game for the best record in the Eastern Conference, the Heat seemed to be coasting through the season in their pursuit of a third consecutive championship.

headline: Variety: Out of Order
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — The man in this photo is Patrick Blindauer. He looks like a nice guy, right? You would never know that beneath that friendly, dapper exterior lurks the heart of a madman, and I say that as someone who is very fond of him. His mother probably says that about him, too.

headline: Major Volcanic Eruption Kills at Least 14 in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — An active volcano on Indonesia’s Sumatra Island unexpectedly erupted again on Saturday, killing at least 14 people and spreading toxic clouds of hot ash that hampered search and rescue teams, officials said.

headline: Gun Battle in Bangkok Escalates Election Protest
text: BANGKOK — At least six people were injured Saturday in a prolonged daylight gun battle between protesters seeking to block the distribution of ballots in Bangkok and would-be voters demanding that protesters cease their attempts to obstruct national elections on Sunday.

headline: Glitches in State Exchanges Give G.O.P. a Cudgel
text: WASHINGTON — With the federal online insurance exchange running more smoothly than ever, the biggest laggards in fixing enrollment problems are now state-run exchanges in several states where the governors and legislative leaders have been among the strongest supporters of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Law Doesn’t End Revolving Door on Capitol Hill
text: A top aide to a Republican congressman from Arizona helped promote a legislative plan to overhaul the nation’s home mortgage finance system. Weeks after leaving his government job, he reappeared on Capitol Hill, now as a lobbyist for a company poised to capitalize on the plan.

headline: As Players’ Agents, Women Face Extra Challenges
text: Women who are agents for N.F.L. players have heard every criticism imaginable — of their credentials, their experience, their negotiating skills. Yet for Kelli Masters, perhaps the low point came when, just as she thought she had persuaded a player from Oklahoma to sign as a client for his first N.F.L. contract, she was stopped short by his mother, of all people.

headline: Macroeconomic Populism Returns
text: Matthew Yglesias says what needs to be said about Argentina: there’s no contradiction at all between saying that Argentina was right to follow heterodox policies in 2002, but it is wrong to be rejecting advice to curb deficits and control inflation now. I know some people find this hard to grasp, but the effects of economic policies, and the appropriate policies to follow, depend on circumstances.

headline: Maturity’s Victories
text: BEAR in mind that what you’re about to read comes from someone whose creaky knees protest any run longer than three miles, whose achy left shoulder just got its first cortisone shot and whose haircuts are more ceremonial than functional, given that nature is doing a barber’s work. I have a vested interest in coming up with an argument that older is somehow better.

headline: Canada May Have to Go to Olympics Without Lightning’s Stamkos
text: The Olympic fate of Canada’s Steven Stamkos, who has not played since breaking his leg in November, could be decided this week.

headline: Denver’s Offense (Unstoppable) vs. Seattle’s Defense (Unmovable)
text: JERSEY CITY — Max Unger, Seattle’s starting center, hails from Hawaii, excelled as a rebounder for his high school basketball team and, about 100 pounds ago, loved to skateboard. None of that would be relevant to the outcome of the Super Bowl except that Unger’s chief adversary, Denver’s 335-pound defensive tackle Terrance Knighton, probably knew all those facts last week.

headline: Before Hitting and Fielding, Young Mets Seek Edge by Running and Stretching
text: PLYMOUTH, Mich. — Thirty minutes west of Detroit, at an indoor sports complex that could otherwise pass as a warehouse, several of the more intriguing members of the Mets gathered to train this off-season.

headline: He’s Pete Carroll’s Guardian Tweeter
text: Ben Malcolmson had a cool, if not totally original, idea. As an enterprising football beat reporter for the student newspaper at Southern California, he decided to try out for Coach Pete Carroll’s powerhouse team even though he had not played the game since the fifth grade back home in Dallas.

headline: Protesters Beat Police Officer in Ukraine, Ministry Says
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Antigovernment protesters here in the capital, who have become angrier and rougher in recent weeks, captured and beat a plainclothes police officer in the part of the city controlled by demonstrators, the authorities said Saturday.

headline: Remembering Nodar
text: The world knows Nodar Kumaritashvili as the luge athlete who died on the eve of the 2010 Winter Olympics, but his sister remembers a brother and a mentor.

headline: A Lethal Luge Accident Still Questioned
text: With a new Olympic competition approaching, friends and family continue to seek answers and action after the 2010 death of the luge athlete Nodar Kumaritashvili.

headline: A Swift and Fatal Luge Plunge, and Then an Abyss of Sorrow
text: BAKURIANI, Georgia — To reach this tiny skiing village, carved into the north side of the Trialeti mountain range, one must weave through a long progression of switchbacks rising more than a mile above sea level. When it is snowing — which is often — the trip from the capital city of Tbilisi can take nearly three hours.

headline: Dylan Farrow’s Story
text: WHEN Woody Allen received a Golden Globe award for lifetime achievement a few weeks ago, there was a lively debate about whether it was appropriate to honor a man who is an artistic giant but also was accused years ago of child molestation.

headline: What G.O.P.-Style Reform Looks Like
text: Three Republican senators — Orrin Hatch of Utah, Tom Coburn of Oklahoma and Richard Burr of North Carolina — have issued an alternative to the health care reforms that they deride as Obamacare. Conservative analysts have hailed their proposals as “an important milestone in the health care debate” and a “reform that has enormous promise.” But the plan, which is hard to parse because it has not been put into precise legislative language, looks inferior in most respects to the existing law.

headline: A Ghastly Injustice in India
text: Yet another horrific gang rape has grabbed headlines in India. This time, a village council in the Indian state of West Bengal ordered the rapes as punishment. The crime: falling in love and planning to marry.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Immigration Delusion
text: THE debate over immigration reform, rekindled last week by House Republican leaders, bears a superficial resemblance to last fall’s debate over the government shutdown.

headline: Phedon Papamichael
text: Phedon Papamichael is a Greek cinematographer whose visual sense has shaped more than 40 feature films including “Nebraska,” which brought him an Oscar nomination this year.

headline: Ashes to Ashes, but First a Nice Pine Box
text: PRAIRIE VILLAGE, Kan. — NOT long ago, my wife and I had a good friend over for a glass of wine. We had drunk just enough to feel pleasantly liberated in thought. Or at least that’s how I felt. Probably that’s why it seemed a good moment to bring it up. So, I calmly announced to my wife: “I’m going to build my own coffin. I just thought you should know.”

headline: A Wonderful Country
text: TEL AVIV — One of the most popular shows on Israeli TV is called “Eretz Nehederet” or “A Wonderful Country.” It’s a comedy show that lives to make fun of Israeli politicians and the absurdities of life here. It recently opened its 2014 season with a cartoon graphic of a beautiful, multicolored, flower-filled garden with a butterfly fluttering across the screen. Then, suddenly, a concrete wall rises up all around the garden, which was an image the producers used last year. But this season not only does the wall emerge but a glass dome rises out of the wall and seals off this Garden of Eden from above as well.

headline: How the Fed Learned to Talk
text: BINGHAMTON, N.Y. — IN his nearly 19 years as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan was notorious for speaking in an elliptical, oracular, even mystifying style. Mindful that a single errant syllable might cause markets to soar — or tumble — Mr. Greenspan mastered a language, “Fed-speak,” so turgid that it made economics textbooks seem like children’s literature by comparison.

headline: Scribbling in the Margins
text: MADISON, N.J. — THE graduate student thrust the library book toward me as though brandishing a sword. “This has got to stop,” she said. “It isn’t fair. How can I work on my dissertation with this mess?” As she marched out of my office, leaving the disfigured volume behind, her words stung — for the code of civility on which libraries depend had been violated. She was the third Ph.D. student in less than a year to bring me a similarly damaged volume, and each had expected me as the library director to turn sleuth, solve the mystery, and end the vandalism.

headline: When Pedestrians Get Mixed Signals

headline: An Open Letter From Dylan Farrow
text: (A note from Nicholas Kristof: In 1993, accusations that Woody Allen had abused his adoptive daughter, Dylan Farrow, filled the headlines, part of a sensational story about the celebrity split between Allen and his girlfriend, Mia Farrow. This is a case that has been written about endlessly, but this is the first time that Dylan Farrow herself has written about it in public. It’s important to note that Woody Allen was never prosecuted in this case and has consistently denied wrongdoing; he deserves the presumption of innocence. So why publish an account of an old case on my blog? Partly because the Golden Globe lifetime achievement award to Allen ignited a debate about the propriety of the award. Partly because the root issue here isn’t celebrity but sex abuse. And partly because countless people on all sides have written passionately about these events, but we haven’t fully heard from the young woman who was at the heart of them. I’ve written a column about this, but it’s time for the world to hear Dylan’s story in her own words.)

headline: An Unconventional Path to Scripting the Broncos’ Offense
text: Between plays on the field, Peyton Manning appears just a bit unhinged. The body language is manic, an eruption of gesticulating arms, twiddling fingers and fidgeting, stamping feet.

headline: Saving More Than Just Snow Leopards
text: THE cold and rugged mountains of Pakistan, Afghanistan, Tajikistan and China seem an unlikely place to find a flourishing combination of new community institutions and international diplomacy. Few people live there. Those who do are mostly desperately impoverished livestock herders. They have been largely isolated from the rest of humanity on these enormous mountains where the Indian subcontinent once crashed into Asia, buckling the earth’s crust and raising peaks over 20,000 feet.

headline: Indians Protest, Saying a Death Was Tied to Bias
text: NEW DELHI — Hundreds of young protesters from India’s far northeast demonstrated outside a New Delhi police station on Saturday, furious over the death last week of an 18-year-old man who was injured in a fight with shopkeepers, and complaining of widespread discrimination against them because of their East Asian features.

headline: A Tradition of Stars With Something to Say
text: Before it was the No Fun League, the N.F.L. had loquacious characters with iconic nicknames. Dandy Don Meredith, Broadway Joe Namath and Deion Sanders, a.k.a. Prime Time, to name a few. They were as memorable off the field as they were on because they had style, a flair for drama and, more often than not, an attention-getting proclamation.

headline: Nocturnalist at the Super Bowl | Pregame With the Stars
text: Standing weak-kneed and quavering, sometime after a kiss on the cheek from the model Tyson Beckford and a bear hug from the actor Ice T on Friday night, we searched for what exactly we were feeling. Our mind reeled and the stately marble columns of Cipriani in Midtown seemed poised to spin.

headline: At the Town in the Middle, Super Bowl Loyalties Are Difficult to Nail Down
text: Halfway between Denver and Seattle, as the crow flies, sits Arco, Idaho, a farming community that is home to about 950 residents, the Pickle’s Place cafe, an airstrip, the Sawtooth Club, some gas stations and not much else.

headline: Stunned by Tragedy, a Village in Rural Quebec Turns Inward
text: L’ISLE-VERTE, Quebec — In the wintry days since a fire swept through the retirement home in this quaint, rambling village along the south shore of the St. Lawrence River, L’Isle-Verte has been overrun by police officers, firefighters, coroners and anthropologists, painstakingly chipping away at the layers of ice encasing the building and digging through the charred ruins.

headline: Political Candidate’s Aides Die in Afghanistan Attack
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two aides to an Afghan presidential candidate were fatally shot in the relatively secure city of Herat in western Afghanistan on Saturday, officials said, raising questions about the prospects of a peaceful election one day before the official start of the campaign.

headline: Relocating Traditions in China
text: Village-based traditions once practiced by close-living families and neighbors are disappearing in an increasingly urban China.

headline: In China, ‘Once the Villages Are Gone, the Culture Is Gone’
text: BEIJING — Once or twice a week, a dozen amateur musicians meet under a highway overpass on the outskirts of Beijing, carting with them drums, cymbals and the collective memory of their destroyed village. They set up quickly, then play music that is almost never heard anymore, not even here, where the steady drone of cars muffles the lyrics of love and betrayal, heroic deeds and kingdoms lost.

headline: F.C.C. Says It Will Double Spending on High-Speed Internet in Schools and Libraries

headline: What’s On Today?
text: 6 P.M. (Fox) SUPER BOWL XLVIII The Denver Broncos face off against the Seattle Seahawks at MetLife Stadium, above, in East Rutherford, N.J. Joe Buck provides play-by-play; Troy Aikman is the analyst. Kickoff is at 6:30. Bruno Mars will take the stage at halftime with the Red Hot Chili Peppers as special guests; Renée Fleming will perform the national anthem; and Queen Latifah and the New Jersey Youth Chorus will sing “America the Beautiful.” “Fox Super Bowl Sunday,” hosted by Terry Bradshaw and Curt Menefee, will offer pregame coverage, starting at 2 in Times Square before moving to the Meadowlands. Segments include a homage to the coach Vince Lombardi, presented by Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York; a reading from the Declaration of Independence by National Football League owners and players; a tribute to the former player and broadcaster Pat Summerall, who died in April; and red-carpet coverage by Michael Strahan and Charissa Thompson. Bill O’Reilly will interview President Obama from the White House at 4:30.

headline: The New Bern Raid

The Union Army could draw on food, clothing and livestock from untouched farms in nearby Maryland and Pennsylvania or shipped from the old Northwest. It was a crisis at the forefront of Gen. Robert E. Lee’s mind. But, he wrote Jefferson Davis on Jan. 2, 1864, there was a chance — right then — to feed, clothe and shod their soldiers for a spring campaign.

headline: Super Bowl Casts Shadow Over Movie Box Office
text: Movie studios may line up to advertise during the Super Bowl, but they typically avoid releasing substantial new movies on game weekend – too much competition from beer and bean dip (and, oh right, football). This year, two studios offered smaller films aimed at audiences considered the least likely to be interested in televised sports: young girls and the intelligentsia. Both fizzled, albeit to differing degrees.

headline: Writers Guild Crowns ‘Her’ and ‘Captain Phillips’

headline: Philip Seymour Hoffman, Actor of Depth, Dies at 46

He was 46.

headline: Pro-Am Tournament Raises $100,000 for Parkinson’s Disease
text: Zeke Jabbour, an eight-time national champion, hosts an annual charity pro-am tournament to benefit the National Parkinson Foundation. Simultaneously, anyone could play the same deals at the Common Game website, which was organized by Jay Whipple. With sponsorship from Netjets, the event raised about $100,000.

headline: Academy President Defends Ruling on Song
text: Cheryl Boone Isaacs, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, defended that organization’s decision to rescind an Oscar nomination for the song “Alone Yet Not Alone,” from the film of same title, in an interview with The Hollywood Reporter on Saturday. The Academy had been criticized by some who said that it was biased because the song had come from a faith-based film. “This is not about the film,” Ms. Isaacs said. “We are adamant about keeping the integrity of our voting process.” She said that it was the appearance of undue influence by the song’s composer, Bruce Broughton, who emailed fellow members of the Academy’s music branch, prompting the decision to rescind the nomination. “Our purpose is to keep a level playing field and to keep it anonymous,” Ms. Isaacs said. “So when one person — in this case, Mr. Broughton — sends out an email driving the voting members to a specific song that’s his, it does break the rules.”

headline: Cataclysm Has Arrived: Man’s Inhumanity to Nature
text: The plight of doomed, extinct or nearly extinct animals is embodied in Elizabeth Kolbert’s arresting new book, “The Sixth Extinction,” by two touching creatures.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Feb. 3
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Ringing in the Chinese Zodiac’s Year of the Horse
text: According to the Chinese zodiac, 2014 is the Year of the Horse. For the New York Philharmonic’s Chinese New Year celebration on Saturday night, two enormous, inflated golden horses were placed on the outer balcony of Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Underworld Notes, in the Homeric Sense
text: The young British choreographer Liam Scarlett still looks cherubic: curly-haired, wide-eyed, with a touch of puckishness. What’s curious is that his mind, by contrast, repeatedly turns to subjects of darkness, death and the dead.

headline: Poor Game Seals Season but Not Debate on Legacy
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Seattle Seahawks ripped out the feel-good ending to Peyton Manning’s storybook season. Tore the final pages to shreds. Burned them in a fire. Left Manning and his Denver Broncos looking like outdated print in a digital world.

headline: Luring With Sound, but Aiming for Something Deeper

And so perhaps with “Nous: A Musical Rite,” a half-airy, half-aggressive three-hour interdisciplinary happening that had its first performance on Saturday night here at Basilica Hudson.

headline: Ethical Concerns Hit Oscar Races

headline: A Modigliani? Who Says So?
text: Three daunting facts confront anyone interested in buying one of Amedeo Modigliani’s distinctive elongated portraits. They tend to have multimillion price tags; they are a favorite of forgers; and despite an abundance of experts, no inventory of his works is considered both trustworthy and complete.

headline: Staying True to Greece While Drawing on Some Wider Influences
text: The Greek singer Eleftheria Arvanitaki, who performed for an adoring crowd on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, is part of an international sorority of musicians who have merged national traditions with pop. She has collaborated with some of them, including Cesária Évora from Cape Verde, Buika from Spain and Dulce Pontes from Portugal, and in Greece Ms. Arvanitaki is so celebrated that she was chosen to sing her hit “Dynata” (“It’s Possible”; the word also means “strong”) at the closing ceremony of the 2004 Olympics in Athens.

headline: Checkout Counter Staple

headline: How Inequality Hollows Out the Soul
text: One of the well-known costs of inequality is that people withdraw from community life and are less likely to feel that they can trust others. This is partly a reflection of the way status anxiety makes us all more worried about how we are valued by others. Now that we can compare robust data for different countries, we can see not only what we knew intuitively — that inequality is divisive and socially corrosive — but that it also damages the individual psyche.

headline: Abortions Declining in U.S., Study Finds
text: The abortion rate among American women declined to its lowest level in more than three decades in 2011, according to a new report released Monday that is widely considered the country’s most definitive examination of abortion trends.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 27-Feb. 2
text: Collisions and precision in a week of action.

headline: Ex-Chicago Mayor Daley Still in Intensive Care
text: Richard M. Daley, the former mayor of Chicago, remained hospitalized in an intensive care unit on Sunday and will most likely stay there for several days as doctors run tests to determine the nature of his ailments, officials said.

headline: The Dangers of Certainty: A Lesson From Auschwitz
text: As a kid in England, I watched a lot of television. There weren’t any books in our house,  not even the Bible. TV was therefore pretty important, omnipresent actually. Of course, most of what it delivered was garbage. But in 1973, the BBC aired an extraordinary documentary series called “The Ascent of Man,” hosted by one Dr. Jacob Bronowski in 13 hour-long episodes. Each episode was what he called an “essay” and involved some exotic and elaborate locations, but the presentation was never flashy and consisted mostly of Dr. Bronowski speaking directly and deliberately to the camera.

headline: U.S. Player Ratings: Wondolowski and Defense Stand Out
text: The United States men’s soccer team opened its 2014 schedule with a 2-0 exhibition win over South Korea on Saturday in Carson, Calif., thanks in part to a fine effort by Chris Wondolowski and a defensive unit that bent but would not break to preserve the shutout.

headline: Building a Better Battery
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The next breakthrough smartphone, or maybe the one after that, might not have a traditional battery as its sole source of power. Instead, it could pull energy from the air or power itself through television, cellular or Wi-Fi signals.

headline: Palestinian Leader Seeks NATO Force in Future State
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Six months into peace talks dominated by discussion about security, President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority has proposed to Secretary of State John Kerry that an American-led NATO force patrol a future Palestinian state indefinitely, with troops positioned throughout the territory, at all crossings, and within Jerusalem.

headline: A New Way to Rein In Fat Cats
text: UNION VALE, N.Y. — PRESIDENT OBAMA’S planned directive to increase the minimum wage for employees of federal government contractors has prompted the usual tiresome reactions in Washington and the media echo chamber we euphemistically call “debate.”

headline: Sudan Tells Red Cross to Halt Work
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — The Sudanese government has ordered the International Committee of the Red Cross, which helps well over a million people in conflict areas in Sudan, to suspend its operations in the country, the organization said Sunday.

headline: We Need G.M.O. Wheat
text: THREE crops — corn, soybeans and wheat — account for a vast majority of the value of America’s agricultural crop output. But wheat is different in one important respect. While more than 90 percent of the nation’s corn and soybean acres are now planted with seeds genetically engineered to resist insects, herbicides or both, there is not a single acre of genetically engineered wheat being grown commercially in the United States.

headline: Give the Data to the People
text: LAST week, Johnson & Johnson announced that it was making all of its clinical trial data available to scientists around the world. It has hired my group, Yale University Open Data Access Project, or YODA, to fully oversee the release of the data. Everything in the company’s clinical research vaults, including unpublished raw data, will be available for independent review.

headline: Abbas’s NATO Proposal
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — At Tel Aviv’s Ben Gurion Airport there is a photo exhibition of great moments in Israeli airline history. One large black-and-white photograph caught my eye. It was a picture of Egypt’s President Anwar Sadat seated with Israel’s Prime Minister Menachem Begin on a flight, with both men laughing — their faces radiating friendship.

headline: Kerry and Iran Minister Confer on Nuclear Issue
text: MUNICH — Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, met for an hour on Sunday with Secretary of State John Kerry, another sign of serious efforts to solve the crisis around Iran’s nuclear program. The two met on the margins of the Munich Security Conference here, and Mr. Zarif later said on a public panel that Iran “will go to those negotiations with the political will and good faith to reach an agreement.”

headline: Texas Republicans Vying for Lieutenant Governor Lean Heavily Right
text: HOUSTON — One candidate has called for the impeachment of President Obama. Another wants the National Guard to help secure the border. Yet another criticized the openly lesbian mayor here for marrying her longtime partner in Palm Springs, Calif., saying it was “part of a larger strategy of hers to turn Texas into California.” And all of the leading contenders want to allow Texans to carry handguns in holsters on their hips.

headline: For Restless Pioneer of Modern Tattoo Art, a Life Beyond Ink
text: Visitors to the cluttered studio inside Thom DeVita’s Victorian house marvel at the artwork that covers the walls, his drawing table, even his hands. The images reflect not just his interests, but his skills, which he honed as a tattoo artist on the Lower East Side for some 30 years; a storied era to aficionados. The accomplishment was all the more remarkable because it was illegal in New York City at the time.

headline: With Renée Fleming, Super Bowl XLVIII Gets an Operatic Opening
text: Renée Fleming became the first opera singer to perform the national anthem at the Super Bowl on Sunday at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., but the word “opera” went unmentioned in her introduction.

headline: Placed on Unpaid Leave, a Pregnant Employee Finds Hope in a New Law
text: Floralba Fernandez Espinal rose at 6:50 that morning. For the first time in weeks she felt no misgivings about going to work, no anxieties about her pregnancy.

headline: Imax Faces a Threat in China
text: LOS ANGELES — “We’ve got the future under control,” contends OmniCorp, the giant technology corporation in “RoboCop,” a blockbuster remake set for release by Sony Pictures and MGM next month.

headline: Philip Seymour Hoffman’s Many Roles
text: A look back at the career of Philip Seymour Hoffman, who was found dead Sunday. He was perhaps the most admired American actor of his generation.

headline: Syria Hits Areas Held by Rebels in Aleppo
text: ISTANBUL — Syrian government aircraft continued to strike rebel-held areas in Aleppo with makeshift bombs on Sunday, killing at least three dozen people, most of them women and children, antigovernment activists said.

headline: The Middle Class Is Steadily Eroding. Just Ask the Business World.
text: In Manhattan, the upscale clothing retailer Barneys will replace the bankrupt discounter Loehmann’s, whose Chelsea store closes in a few weeks. Across the country, Olive Garden and Red Lobster restaurants are struggling, while fine-dining chains like Capital Grille are thriving. And at General Electric, the increase in demand for high-end dishwashers and refrigerators dwarfs sales growth of mass-market models.

headline: Tamils’ Smuggling Journey to U.S. Leads to Longer Ordeal: 3 Years of Detention
text: Five Sri Lankan men left hometowns reeling from the remnants of a ruthless civil war and embarked on a monthslong human-smuggling journey that spanned seven countries.

headline: Halftime Brings a Much-Anticipated ‘Seinfeld’ Reunion

headline: Documents in New Jersey Bridge Scandal Set to Start Pouring In

headline: Delusions of Failure
text: The Republican response to the State of the Union was delivered by Cathy McMorris Rodgers, Republican representative from Washington — and it was remarkable for its lack of content. A bit of uplifting personal biography, a check list of good things her party wants to happen with no hint of how it plans to make them happen.

headline: As Ukraine’s President Returns From Leave, His Options Seem Dismal
text: KIEV, Ukraine — When President Viktor F. Yanukovych returns to work on Monday after a four-day sick leave, he will find that even after that brief absence his options for resolving Ukraine’s political crisis have already narrowed.

headline: In the Forecast, More of the Off-White Stuff
text: The business model for the Atlantic Salt Company on Staten Island basically boils down to passing the salt.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Cleanup Campaign
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo wants to make the fight against corruption in Albany a major theme in his re-election campaign this year. Given the arrests, convictions and accusations of misbehavior involving state legislators in recent years, that makes sense. And to show he’s serious this time, the governor has announced a package of reforms, including public financing of elections, as part of his 2014-15 budget. His task now is to persuade the Legislature to go along. It won’t be easy, but he should be ready to campaign against any lawmaker, Democrat or Republican, who resists these crucial reforms.

headline: Libya’s Cache of Toxic Arms All Destroyed
text: WASHINGTON — Even as the international effort to destroy Syria’s vast chemical weapons stockpile lags behind schedule, a similar American-backed campaign carried out under a cloak of secrecy ended successfully last week in another strife-torn country, Libya.

headline: Not Quite 75 and Sunny, but a Mild Day Dispels the Worries About the Weather
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — John Dalena and his son Mike were prepared for the worst. In the back of their car parked near MetLife Stadium, they had snow pants, extra sweatshirts and other cold-weather gear to keep them warm after kickoff at the Super Bowl still three hours away.

headline: After Burying Thousands, a Gravedigger Retires

headline: A Tiny Glimmer From North Korea
text: North Korea recently reversed itself and accepted South Korea’s proposal to hold long-overdue family reunions between citizens of the two countries.

headline: Battles Loom in Many States Over What to Do With Budget Surpluses
text: In a year when three dozen governors are up for election, unexpectedly robust revenues from taxes and other sources are filling most state coffers, creating surpluses not seen in years and prompting statehouse battles over what to do with the money.

headline: The Capitol’s Spinning Door Accelerates
text: The anonymous congressional staff members who write the nation’s laws generally work hard for fairly modest wages. Increasingly, though, they do so because there is a promise of K-Street riches at the end of their toil.

headline: News Giant in Japan Seen as Being Compromised

headline: ‘Mass-Transit Super Bowl’ Hits Some Rough Patches in Moving Fans
text: About four hours before Sunday’s Super Bowl kickoff, fans of all jersey colors appeared to achieve a moment of angry unity while stuck inside a Secaucus, N.J., rail station. The air was stale, the heat had become blistering, and the ordeal was going on and on, approaching an hour. “A.C.! A.C.!” the fans shouted in a plea for cooler conditions as they strained to get a little closer to the connecting trains to MetLife Stadium.

headline: Method of Study Is Criticized in Group’s Health Policy Tests

headline: El Salvador and Costa Rica Hold Presidential Elections
text: MEXICO CITY — Two Central American countries, El Salvador and Costa Rica, put incumbent parties to the test on Sunday in what were expected to be closely fought presidential elections that focused less on ideology than on unease over unemployment, corruption and crime.

headline: Philip Seymour Hoffman Said to Be Found With Syringe

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Recap: Showdown Between Lady Violet and Isobel

But after a bruising and occasionally ugly battle, it was her longtime rival, Lady Violet, the Dowager Countess, who emerged with the only thing that mattered: a victory.

headline: Unlikely Allies Seek to Check Power of Activist Hedge Funds

headline: Super Bowl Security Breach Comes After Game, in an Interrupted News Conference

headline: After Risqué Years, Super Bowl Commercials Go Warm and Fuzzy
text: ALMOST everyone seemed relieved that the first cold-weather Super Bowl played outdoors was not an ice bowl. As for the advertising extravaganza that took place during the game, it turned out to be a nice bowl.

headline: Petition Seeking to Void Brooklyn Murder Conviction Calls Verdict a ‘Sham’
text: The 2005 conviction of John Giuca for the murder of Mark Fisher, a college football player from New Jersey, was a “sham” built on prosecutorial misconduct, a feeble defense, contradictory evidence, a biased juror and the testimony of witnesses who have since recanted, Mr. Giuca’s lawyer wrote in a scathing petition to be sent to the Brooklyn district attorney on Monday.

headline: Magic Carpets
text: Lina Zedig and Marcus Ahren, the founders of the Stockholm-based design studio Oyyo, have introduced a line of cotton dhurries that stands apart from the ubiquitous stripes and chevrons of flat-weave designs. With their soft pastels and spare patterns, these rugs have a definite Nordic accent, recalling the textiles of the Swedish designer Marta Maas-Fjetterstrom, but a closer look reveals more diverse influences — everything from the Bauhaus textiles of Gunta Stölzl to the tree markings of itinerant laborers in the 1940s.

headline: Men’s Watches that Stop the Hands of Time
text: That age-old obsession with halting the passage of time took a literal turn at the recently concluded Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) watch fair in Geneva. A multitude of styles on view there made use of the chronograph — a feature that enables the rapid starting and stopping of hands on a dial to measure specific segments of time. Primarily used in the world of sports, where fractions of a second can make the difference between winning, losing and shattering records, this function was the must-have add-on at the show.

headline: As Peanut Allergies Rise, Trying to Determine a Cause
text: Peanut allergy has become a nemesis for increasing numbers of children and parents in recent years, forcing them to maintain nut-free households and prompting many schools to ban a childhood staple, peanut butter, from the lunchroom.

(NBC) SPORTS ILLUSTRATED SWIMSUIT: 50 YEARS OF BEAUTIFUL Heidi Klum, right, hosts this 50th-anniversary celebration of the Sports Illustrated swimsuit franchise, featuring behind-the-scenes glimpses of photo shoots, a countdown of top covers and reminiscences by Tyra Banks, Christie Brinkley, Kathy Ireland, Marisa Miller and Kate Upton. Enrique Iglesias, Lady Antebellum, the Fray, John Legend and Tim McGraw serenade them.

headline: Russell Wilson, the Forgotten Quarterback, Coolly Orchestrates ‘a Perfect Football Game’

headline: Percy Harvin Finally Delivers on Seattle’s Investment
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Seattle Seahawks were so certain that Percy Harvin was the game-breaking offensive player they needed to advance to the Super Bowl that they traded first- and third-round draft choices in 2013 and their third-round selection this year to the Minnesota Vikings to obtain him.

headline: U.S. Skates to 6th Place in Bandy Tournament
text: With a 6-3 loss to Norway on Sunday, the United States finished sixth at the annual Bandy World Championship, played this year in Irkutsk, Russia. The American team, made up primarily of players from the Minneapolis-St. Paul and Duluth, Minn., areas, was 3-3 in the tournament, in which 17 countries participated. The matches, lasting 90 minutes apiece, were played outside in the Siberian cold.

headline: Enlisting Dad to Find a First Bra
text: When I was 12, I worried that I might never grow breasts. There I was, all of 80 pounds, nothing but skin and bones, bruised shins, a mouth full of braces, and not a curve in sight. I worried that I would remain forever a little girl with nothing on my chest but bumps — bumps that my busty classmate, Linda, referred to as “pimples in need of Band-Aids.”

headline: Student With Rifles Kills 2 in Standoff at Moscow School

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: January 31, 2014
text: After months of steadily climbing and setting new records in 2013, the Dow Jones alone is down more than 4 percent this month. This downward slide comes even as the economy strengthens. This week on Money Talking, contributors Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine discuss the recent drops, the incoming Federal Reserve chairman Janet Yellen and whether there’s more volatility in store in the coming weeks and months. And the Super Bowl: Just how much of a financial boon is it for the host city?

headline: Finding the Discipline to Say No to Customers

headline: SAC Fashioning a New Identity
text: SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund started by Steven A. Cohen, will soon cease to exist as Wall Street has known it. The firm, whose reputation is now intricately linked to an insider trading scandal, is in the midst of rebranding itself, including changing its name and corporate structure. And recently, a major bank distanced itself from the firm. Together, these developments provide the most vivid illustration yet of SAC’s steep fall from powerful hedge fund to marginalized player,  Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Michael Barrett joined Millennial Media, Baltimore, as chief executive. He succeeds Paul Palmieri, who founded the company; Mr. Palmieri resigned, Millennial Media said, and will join New Enterprise Associates as venture adviser. Mr. Barrett had most recently been chief revenue officer at Yahoo and before that was chief executive at AdMeld.

headline: Officials Scramble to Modify Slopestyle Course After Accident

headline: Bernanke Starts New Role as Yellen Takes Fed Helm

On Monday, he drove himself to a new job as an economic studies fellow at the Brookings Institution, a research group about a mile north of his old office.
