text: Disabled men and women demonstrating at a rally at India Gate in New Delhi.

headline: Study Details Graft in European Union
text: PARIS — Despite its relatively clean image, the European Union is losing at least 120 billion euros a year to corruption, and more than three-quarters of citizens believe that the problem is widespread in their countries, the bloc’s home affairs commissioner said on Monday.

headline: Elliott to Hint at Proxy Fight With Juniper
text: As the networking equipment maker Juniper Networks prepares to announce its turnaround plan, one of the activist investors in its shares is pressing its own case for what the company must do.

headline: Al Qaeda Breaks With Jihadist Group in Syria Involved in Rebel Infighting
text: ISTANBUL — Al Qaeda’s central leadership has officially cut ties with a powerful jihadist group that has flourished in the chaos of the civil war in Syria and that rushed to build an Islamic state on its own terms, antagonizing the wider rebel movement.

headline: In Our Pages: February 4
text: 1939:  French Empire’s ‘Indivisibility’

headline: Unpublished Chaplin Novella to Be Released
text: On Tuesday, the Cineteca di Bologna, an Italian film restoration institute, will release a previously unpublished novella by Charlie Chaplin, which inspired his 1952 film, “Limelight,” widely considered his last great film. The release begins a series of events for the Chaplin centennial, which marks 100 years after the actor and director first appeared on film.

headline: More Bitcoin Regulation Is Inevitable
text: Updated, 6:12 p.m. |

headline: Ask the Author: Economics and Online Dating
text: When Paul Oyer, an economist at Stanford’s Graduate School of Business, plunged into the online dating world a few years ago, he was struck — by the economics involved in his search.

headline: For Seattle, the Fun May Be Just Starting
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — After the Super Bowl, in the concrete corridor connecting the locker rooms of the Seattle Seahawks and the Denver Broncos, players and coaches came and went.

headline: Warburg Pincus to Invest in Cloud-Based Facilities Manager
text: Despite the torrent of money flowing into the technology sector, software to manage building maintenance services seems like an unlikely target for investors.

headline: Makers of Paper App Ask Facebook to Change Its New App Name
text: If you go to Google and type in the word “paper,” the top result doesn’t have anything to do with traditional pulpy vellum. Instead, it links to the well-known app Paper, which allows you to sketch on your iPad just as you can in a traditional notebook.

headline: Going Where 007 Has Gone Before
text: James Bond wasn’t just a legendary fighter of evil. He was a tremendous traveler, equally at home in a Monte Carlo casino as summiting a Swiss peak. Now one bespoke tour operator is offering clients the opportunity to live like 007 at home in England and around the world.

headline: Today in Small Business: GoldieBlox
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: ‘Wolf’s’ Writer Avoids His Own Spoiler Alerts
text: Terence Winter, the screenwriter of “The Wolf of Wall Street,” did not win best adapted screenplay at the Writers Guild Awards on Saturday, but at least he knew better than to check his phone during the ceremony. Despite warnings to the contrary, spoilers are routinely delivered via text and social media throughout the bicoastal event, as awards are announced at different times.

headline: Raymond Weil, Whose Swiss Watches Told More Than Time, Dies at 87
text: Swiss watch companies had dominated the world of precision timekeeping for two centuries by the 1970s, when a technological marvel known as the quartz watch — a cheaper, more accurate work of horology mass-produced in Asia — threatened them with extinction.

headline: New Ads Urge Northerners to Follow the Sun
text: For years, ads during winter have encouraged residents of cold-weather states to visit warm-weather locales. Is there a baby boomer from states like New York or Pennsylvania who does not recall campaigns in which an actor named Jim Dooley proclaimed, “So come on down” to Florida on Northeast Airlines?

headline: Gyora Benedek’s Hidato
text: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Gyora Benedek, the Israeli computer scientist, inventor and adventurer. We first met Dr. Benedek while discussing Robert Torrence’s Lights Out Puzzle last September; Dr. Benedek shared, as one of the original inventors of Lights Out, some of the mathematics behind the game.

headline: Stir-Fried Brown Rice With Red Chard and Carrots
text: A lush bunch of red Swiss chard that I got at the farmers’ market was the inspiration for this stir-fry. The stems, which stay nice and crunchy, are an important ingredient in the stir-fry, so look for chard with nice wide ribs.

headline: Stir-Fried Rice and Black Quinoa With Cabbage, Red Pepper and Greens
text: This is the kind of dish you can make on a whim if you make it a habit to freeze leftover grains. I used a combination of red chard and beet greens for this, but regular chard and kale would also work. I love the texture, flavor and look of the quinoa.

headline: Stir-Fried Rice Noodles With Beets and Beet Greens
text: I like to use golden or Chioggia beets for this stir-fry. Whatever beets you use, slice them very thin; for best results use a mandolin. Use a wok, not a pan, for stir-fried noodles as noodles will spill out of a pan. Tongs are a good tool for stirring and tossing the noodles, but a long-handled spatula will also work.

headline: Heroin Scheme to Support Terrorism Is Foiled, Police in India Say
text: NEW DELHI — The Indian police said Monday that they had intercepted 22 pounds of heroin headed from Pakistan to South India, breaking up a network that included a police officer from Indian-administered Kashmir. The shipment was transported over the heavily militarized, hilly border between Pakistan and India, and was to be carried by train to New Delhi, said S. N. Srivastav, a senior police officer.

headline: Stir-Fried Soba Noodles With Shiitakes and Baby Broccoli
text: Soba noodles are Japanese, not Chinese, but I love using them in Chinese stir-fries. They have a wonderful nutty flavor, and buckwheat has a lot going for it nutritionally – it is a good source of manganese, copper and magnesium, and it is also high in phytonutrients. To make a quick vegetable stock simmer the shiitake mushroom stalks in a small amount of water for about 20 minutes.

headline: Presidential Elections in El Salvador and Costa Rica Are Headed for Runoffs
text: MEXICO CITY — Presidential elections in two Central American countries, El Salvador and Costa Rica, will head to a second round after top contenders in both nations failed to get enough votes on Sunday to win outright, in contests that tested the power of incumbent parties.

headline: Kravis and Gordon Gekko at the Super Bowl
text: One of the more memorable commercials broadcast during the Super Bowl on Sunday night featured a bevy of pop culture icons from the 1980s, including Hulk Hogan and the actor John Ratzenberger.

headline: Stir-Fried Soba Noodles With Turkey and Cabbage
text: Turkey cutlets are a great buy at most supermarkets. These thin medallions of turkey are perfect if you want to add small amounts of meat to a stir-fry. For the best texture, velvet the turkey before stir-frying (Steps 1 and 3).

headline: Catherine Deneuve Film Opens French Cinema Series
text: This year’s Rendez-Vouz With French Cinema will focus on first and second features, including work by directors, like Rebecca Zlotowski, who are considered part of France’s next new wave, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Coca Cola’s Super Bowl Ad
text: Coca Cola’s Super Bowl ad, featuring a multilingual version of “America the Beautiful,” upset some right-wingers who apparently feel that the patriotic song should only be sung in English.

headline: Philip Seymour Hoffman, R.I.P.
text: Sometimes you don’t realize how much an actor has achieved until he’s unexpectedly gone. Reading the tributes to Philip Seymour Hoffman, dead this weekend at forty-six, I have the sense that his passing woke a lot of people up to his true significance, the full measure of his greatness, his distinctive place among his generation’s great performers. Not that he was underappreciated, of course — not with a Best Actor Oscar in his pocket and plenty of other critical garlands as well — but I wonder how many writers would have reached for his name, or at least reached for it quickly, if they had been asked to pick the best English-speaking actor of the last two decades just a week ago. Not as many, I suspect, as are reaching for the “greatest actor” label now, to describe his tragically-truncated career.

headline: Reaction Time May Predict Longevity
text: There are many well established risk factors for cardiovascular death, but researchers may have found one more: slower reaction time.

headline: An Actor Who Made Unhappiness a Joy to Watch
text: It was clear, at least since he won the Oscar in 2006 for “Capote,” that Philip Seymour Hoffman was an unusually fine actor. Really though, it was clear long before that, depending on when and where you started paying attention.

headline: Times Minute | Making Snow for Sochi
text: Also on the Minute, Thailand's political paralysis continues and controversy surrounding Woody Allen's Oscar nomination.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Nascar Announces Sprint Cup Chase Changes
text: Nascar announced on Thursday changes to its end-of-season playoffs, the Sprint Cup Chase for the Championship. The changes, officials said, would place a greater emphasis on winning races. The old format pitted 12 drivers – the top 10 in points and two wild-card entries -- against one another in the final 10 races of the year in a runoff to decide the driving title. Jimmie Johnson, who won six races in 2013, collected his sixth championship, edging out Matt Kenseth, who had seven wins.

headline: Times Minute | Making Snow for Sochi
text: In the Video

headline: ‘Frozen’ Takes Top Prize at Animation Awards
text: Talk about a thaw.

headline: Barclays Chief Declines Annual Bonus
text: Updated, 1:54 p.m. | LONDON — Barclays’ chief executive, Antony Jenkins, said Monday that he would forgo a bonus for 2013 in light of the bank’s continued restructuring costs and litigation expenses.

headline: British Regulator Warns Two of Potential Libor Charges
text: The Wells notice appears to be going global.

headline: Hedge Fund Chief Makes a Lonely Bet Against Portugal’s Debt
text: David Salanic cuts a lonely figure among the Manhattan power brokers eating breakfast at the Loews Regency Hotel restaurant on Park Avenue. Sure, he runs a hedge fund, but with $50 million, his fund may represent a year of commissions for some of the heavy hitters in the room.

headline: Beckham Back, as an Owner of a New Team
text: David Beckham is set to return to Major League Soccer on Wednesday, this time as an owner of a Miami team that will become the league’s 22nd club.

headline: Fiat-Chrysler Merger Spawns New Logo
text: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, the new company created from the merger of Chrysler and Fiat, has introduced a new logo made from the letters F.C.A. and rendered in light blue.

headline: Renée Fleming to Teach Master Class at Juilliard
text: Renée Fleming seems intent on giving Plácido Domingo a run for his money as opera’s busiest star. Apart from singing the title role in the Metropolitan Opera’s current production of “Rusalka,” Ms. Fleming turned up to sing at Marilyn Horne’s birthday concert at Carnegie Hall a couple of weeks ago, and then, of course, there was her performance of “The Star-Spangled Banner” at the Super Bowl on Sunday, and the recent announcement that she will have her first role in a play, at the Williamstown Theater Festival in July. Between now and then, she plans to sing Strauss’s “Arabella” in Salzburg, in April.

headline: Months After Typhoon, Philippine City Suffers From an Exodus of Jobs
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — As Jesse Siozon waited for his grandfather’s funeral to begin, beneath the orange and blue tarps that serve as the roof for the storm-damaged Santo Niño Church, he spoke of a double loss.

headline: Hacker Group Accuses Merkel Government of Helping to Spy
text: MUNICH — The Chaos Computer Club, a leading hacker organization based in Germany, filed a criminal complaint against Chancellor Angela Merkel and members of her government on Monday, accusing them of violating the law by helping intelligence agencies in the United States and Britain to spy on German citizens.

headline: Seeking Views From Your High or Low Perch
text: Good afternoon, City Room.

headline: The Read Around: Barry Werth
text: “Our health care system is broken,” says Barry Werth. In his new book, “The Antidote,” he provides an inside look at one company’s efforts to find innovative ways to treat disease.

headline: Auto Sales for January Held Down by Harsh Winter Weather
text: Automakers reported on Monday sharp declines in United States sales in January as a harsh freeze and winter storms thwarted purchases across much of the country.

headline: Full Picture of Airlines’ Punctuality Is Elusive
text: Travelers on Monday experienced a new round of cancellations and delays as another winter storm grounded planes yet again. But many of those flights won’t be counted as late or canceled in the government’s on-time statistics.

headline: A Souvenir and a Memory
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — As I cleaned out my room before moving to Washington, I found a small piece of red fabric crumpled among some keepsakes. I have stacks of journals that catalog my thoughts, hopes, fears and dreams, as well as anything and everything that reminds me of my various adventures over the years. You could say I’m more than slightly sentimental. Writings, photos, objects and song lyrics all transport me in time.

headline: Changing Circumstances, Graphed
text: One recurrent theme on this blog has been that the effects of shocks to the economy, including policy shocks, depend a lot on circumstances — in particular, on whether short-term interest rates are constrained by the zero lower bound. I was putting together teaching materials, centered around David Romer’s IS-MP exposition, and came up with a graph that I think illustrates this point, um, graphically.

headline: At Canyon Ranch, ‘Sensuality Sessions’ for Valentine’s Day
text: Most hotels tout Valentine’s Day packages with rose petals on the bed and chocolate-dipped strawberries on the nightstand. But Canyon Ranch Hotel and Spa in Miami Beach takes a therapist’s approach to intimacy with a three-day program devoted to sensuality and bond-building.

headline: ‘Gravity’ Cinematographer Wins Peers’ Award
text: Emmanuel Lubezki took the top prize from the American Society of Cinematographers this weekend, for his work creating and photographing outer space in “Gravity.” Mr. Lubezki, known as Chivo (Spanish for “goat”), is longtime friends and collaborators with Alfonso Cuarón, the director of “Gravity”: Mr. Lubezki was previously a winner for their film “Children of Men” in 2007 and is considered a favorite at the Oscars as well, although as the blog Gold Derby notes, the cinematographers’ group has a so-so track record in predicting the eventual Academy Award winner.

headline: The Great Mystery of Chinese New Year
text: The week before the Lunar New Year, which fell this year on Friday, Jan. 31, is an exciting time in China. The streets are full of shoppers looking for last-minute gifts to take back to their relatives, and restaurants are packed with friends celebrating and companies holding their annual parties.

headline: Safety Agency Says 22 Million Vehicles Recalled in 2013
text: For the second year in a row, Toyota led the nation with the most vehicles recalled: nearly 5.3 million in 2013.

headline: Employees Get To Vote, Too?
text: This is kind of funny: Eric Cantor feels the need to explain to his fellow Republican legislators that most Americans not only don’t own their own businesses, they have no desire to own their own businesses. It’s a message he’s apparently having a hard time getting across.

headline: Smith & Nephew Pounces on a Wounded Rival
text: Smith & Nephew, the British medical technology giant, has agreed to buy ArthroCare, an American specialist in sports medicine, for an enterprise value of $1.5 billion.

headline: The Value of Ripeness
text: Q. Do fruits that are ripe have greater vitamin value than those that aren’t? And what about sugar?

headline: As the Latest Christie Story Evolved, The Times Should Have Noted a Change
text: In the digital age, news evolves before our very eyes. A story breaks and goes online with perhaps a few rough paragraphs. Soon after, more details are added, new angles explored and writing is tuned up. Finally — at least in organizations like The Times — a thorough and polished version makes its way onto the web and into both print and the archives.

headline: A Farm’s Lessons in Long-Term Planning
text: When I ask you to think long term, what comes to mind? Ten years from now? One year? One week? In a world where excellence is now measured in milliseconds, it can be incredibly difficult to think past the moment that’s right in front of us.

headline: HP Revises Autonomy Financial Reports, Citing Accounting Errors
text: Hewlett-Packard has disclosed to the authorities that it found what it said were serious accounting errors at Autonomy, the British software maker it acquired in 2011, leading to a number of major revisions in the acquired company’s financial report for 2010.

headline: On the Verge | A Star Is Born
text: The French fashion designer Simon Porte Jacquemus is storming Paris with his superclean designs and rowdy runway shows.

headline: Cutting Straight to the Chase With Dessert
text: Dessert can be excess or antidote, solace or provocation, a stampede of the senses or a tickling of the mind. Rarely is it all at once.

headline: Both Sides Declare P.R. Victory in Skirmish Over SodaStream Super Bowl Ad
text: Updated, 5:10 p.m. | By the time the actress Scarlett Johansson’s critically unacclaimed Super Bowl commercial for SodaStream finally aired Sunday night, both supporters and critics of Israel’s occupation of the West Bank had pronounced themselves satisfied with the new attention her endorsement brought to the company’s factory in a Jewish settlement outside Jerusalem.

headline: First Event of Sochi Olympics: The Hotel Construction Sprint
text: SOCHI, Russia — The official mascots for the Winter Olympics are a polar bear, a hare and a leopard. But walk around the complexes that will stage the Games here, with the opening ceremony Friday, and what seem more apt are a hand drill, a backhoe and a shovel.

headline: Weighing Testosterone’s Benefits and Risks
text: Nearly a decade ago, researchers in Boston decided to see whether older men who were not in very good shape could benefit from daily doses of testosterone.

headline: U.S. and Europe Work on Aid Package for Ukraine
text: BERLIN — Looking to defuse Ukraine’s crisis, the United States and Europe are trying to assemble a financial package that could ease the path for a new government there to guide the country out of its current impasse between Europe and Russia, American and European officials say.

headline: In the End, It All Adds Up to – 1/12
text: This is what happens when you mess with infinity.

headline: Goldman’s Charitable Foundation Chief to Lead Urban Investment Group
text: Dina H. Powell has already made a name for herself as the head of Goldman Sachs’s charitable foundation. Now, she is preparing to add a new revenue-generating role to her list of responsibilities.

headline: A Doctor Bridging Arts and Sciences
text: In history’s long parade of pushy mothers and miserably obedient children, no episode beats Dr. Frank H. Netter’s for a happy ending. Both parties got the last laugh.

headline: Preschool Push Moving Ahead in Many States
text: Preschool is having its moment, as a favored cause for politicians and interest groups who ordinarily have trouble agreeing on the time of day. President Obama devoted part of his State of the Union address to it, while the deeply red states of Oklahoma and Georgia are being hailed as national models of preschool access and quality, with other states and cities also forging ahead on their own.

headline: A Hard Climate for Penguins and Butterflies
text: Adaptation can be tricky. Extreme weather is challenging the survival of certain penguins and butterflies, yet DNA from Neanderthals lives on in modern humans 30,000 years after they went extinct. It’s enough to turn a cave man’s eyes blue.

headline: Chris Christie Returns to High School
text: The investigations into Gov, Chris Christie’s traffic scandal are finally getting serious. The documents subpoenaed by New Jersey legislators are scheduled to start arriving at committee offices this week.

headline: At Work in Subzero Temperatures
text: For this week’s Look column, we asked the photographer Massimo Vitali to visit Harbin, China, to take pictures of the Ice and Snow World there. Long days in the extreme cold — temperatures got as low as minus 40 degrees Fahrenheit — made for difficult work.

headline: On Kristof’s Column About Dylan Farrow and Woody Allen, ‘Only Questions’
text: As I’ve been thinking about Nicholas Kristof’s Sunday column and the related blog post that have caused so much discussion and disagreement, a number of thoughtful emails from readers have arrived.

headline: Super Bowl Slide Show
text: The Seattle Seahawks overwhelmed the Denver Broncos to win their first Super Bowl.

headline: Muti Signs New Contract With Chicago Symphony Orchestra
text: Riccardo Muti’s relationships with American orchestras have been enigmatic: after leading the Philadelphia Orchestra for a dozen years, starting in 1980, he reportedly grew weary of the social responsibilities that an American directorship involves. The New York Philharmonic courted him twice, with no joy, only to see him take up the baton in Chicago in 2010. Mr. Muti seems to have enjoyed his time there so far: On Monday, the Chicago Symphony Orchestra announced that the 72-year-old conductor has signed a second five-year contract, which will extend his tenure through August, 2020.

headline: Alive With a New, Old Liver
text: Five days a week, three hours a day, Jonathan Nuñez works out with a gymnastics coach on bars, rings, pommel horse and floor exercises.

headline: In India, a Pilgrimage to a Feast for Thousands
text: RAYAVARAM, India — Palaniappa Chettiar has always been goal oriented, and when he turned 97 three years ago, he set himself a new one.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 28-Feb. 3, 2014
text: The Super Bowl, a paralyzing ice storm, a new head of the Federal Reserve and more: How many of the 10 questions below can you answer correctly?

headline: Amid the Wreckage of the Broncos, Sports Books Strike Gold
text: It was a good day at the office for Nevada sports books as the Seattle Seahawks’ 43-8 destruction of the Denver Broncos defied the expectations of the square money, representing the general betting public, which wanted to see a storybook ending to the record-breaking season of Denver quarterback Peyton Manning.

headline: Preschool’s Benefits Extend to Parents
text: If preschool is having a moment, it is due in part to its appeal to voters as a program designed to help children: preschool is “the most cost-effective” educational intervention, one that can set children up for greater success not just in reading and math, but in their social and emotional development. Any parent who has raised children in a truly diverse environment has had occasion to grieve how the lives of toddlers who once shared a park sandbox can diverge so dramatically as they grow older. Making preschool available to more children feels like an effort to level that particular playing field.

headline: For Hermione, It Shouldn’t Have Been Ron, Rowling Says
text: Harry Potter fans who were disappointed by the series’ happily-ever-after scenario got an early Valentine’s Day present of sorts, thanks to an interview in which Potter’s creator, J.K. Rowling, said that the wrong guy got the girl in the epilogue of the final volume.

headline: Alvin Ailey to Return to Koch Theater in June
text: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will return to the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center for a 15-performance engagement that will run from June 11 to 22, the company’s artistic director, Robert Battle, announced on Monday. The residency more than doubles the number of performances the company gave at the house last year, in its first appearance there since 2000.

headline: Two Families Battered by a Typhoon
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Shortly before dawn, as Typhoon Haiyan thundered ashore, a man took his wife, son and very pregnant daughter on a motorcycle with a sidecar through rising winds to the hospital.

headline: Former BBC Director Apologizes for Failure of Digital Project
text: LONDON — Mark Thompson, the former director general of the BBC, offered a general apology to a parliamentary committee on Monday for the failure of an expensive digital project, but he insisted that he had never knowingly misled Parliament or the BBC Trust, its oversight board.

headline: As Recovery Looks Weak, Stocks Take a Deep Dive
text: Signs of weakness in the American economy pushed Wall Street to its worst day in an already bad year.

headline: Demography and Employment (Wonkish)
text: A blog post reporting research by Samuel Kapon and Joseph Tracy of the New York Fed is creating a splash in wonkworld today, and it is making an important point. However, the way that point is presented is, I think, likely to mislead, because it mixes two propositions together. One, which is clearly true, is that the aging of the adult population would have meant a considerable decline in the employment-population ratio over the past 7 years even if the economy had remained near full employment.

headline: Dull Super Bowl Made ‘Downton Abbey’ a Thrill, as Nearly 7 Million Watched
text: “Downton Abbey” went once more unto the breach on Sunday night, unafraid, as so many other competitors were, to take on the Super Bowl with an original episode.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: January 31-February 2, 2014
text: In September, Louis DiNatale and his wife, who are from Kentucky, drove over a bridge from New York to Ontario, Canada. They claim they were on their way to Vermont but were misdirected by an unreliable GPS, and when they tried to reenter the United States they were asked by a Canadian border crossing guard whether they had any weapons.

headline: Helping to Build a School for the Poor, by Selling One in a Wealthier Area
text: Ife Lenard, a charter school principal in the South Bronx, could not help but smile as she ran her hand over an architectural model of the school that the Children’s Aid Society plans to build for her young students, and described its future pottery kiln, science labs and library.

headline: Looking Beyond the Canonical Masterpieces
text: Leon Botstein, the conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra, is right. Classical music has far too long been in thrall to the cult of the masterpiece, the idea that the arts exist more or less solely for the purpose of identifying and codifying a canon of great works.

headline: VW Workers in Tennessee to Vote on Union
text: In what will be one of the most closely watched unionization elections in the South in decades, Volkswagen announced on Monday that the 1,600 workers at its assembly plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., will vote next week on whether to join the United Automobile Workers.

headline: Tech Companies Offer Update on Government Data Requests
text: Updated: This post now includes reaction from the American Civil Liberties Union.

headline: How It Happens | Snowmaking
text: Machines make snow the same way nature does – only much more quickly, and a lot closer to the ground.

headline: An Olympian Snow Endeavor in Sochi
text: The people in charge of making snow for the Winter Olympics in Russia caught a break over the past two months, when for two periods of about a week each temperatures dropped enough to make good snow, and lots of it.

headline: Artists Gather for a Spoken-Word Tribute to the Diabolical Wit and Wisdom of John Baldessari
text: WhoA motley crew of L.A.’s artistic elite, including upstarts like Alex Israel, Sam Falls and Dawn Kasper and heavies such as Allen Ruppersberg, Suzanne Lacy, William Leavitt and Jim Shaw, gathered to read writings by John Baldessari, a father figure to the Angeleno art world. They were joined by the unlikely pair of the power curator Hans Ulrich Obrist and the child actor turned TV producer Fred Savage, who has no discernible connection to Baldessari and looks like he’s barely aged since “The Wonder Years.” Savage read Baldessari’s “Advice to Young Artists” (1968). Bettina Korek, founder of the arts organization ForYourArt, hosted.

headline: Brain Science to Beat Mental Disorders, Snow Made by Machine, Obesity Takes an Early Hold
text: Dr. Thomas R. Insel, director of the National Institute of Mental Health, on attacking mental illness by way of brain research; the science of filling Sochi’s slopes with Olympic snow; a new study shows that obesity is established very early in life.

headline: These Two Leap to Judgment (Not That You Should, Too)
text: Christina Masciotti treats her characters with a kindness and patience that are usually accorded to only the very young or the very old. Take the middle-age father and adolescent daughter who make up the entire cast of “Adult,” Ms. Masciotti’s gentle new comedy at the Abrons Arts Center.

headline: China to Ramp Up Military Spending
text: China already spends more on its military than any country in the world except the United States. Now, as defense budgets at the Pentagon and in many NATO countries shrink, China’s People’s Liberation Army is gearing up for a surge in new funding, according to a new report.

headline: Take a Dumpling Detour
text: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: ‘Luminaries’ to Light Up Small Screen
text: Eleanor Catton’s Booker Prize-winning novel, “The Luminaries,” will be turned into a television mini-series, according to New Zealand’s Greymouth Star.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Australia and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Australia, Russia, Central African Republic and Indonesia.

headline: Ethics Questions Arise as Genetic Testing of Embryos Increases
text: Her first thought after she heard the news, after she screamed and made her mother and boyfriend leave the room, was that she would never have children. Amanda Baxley’s doctor had just told her, over a speakerphone in her psychiatrist’s office, that she had the gene for Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease, or GSS, which would inevitably lead to her slow and terrible death.

headline: A Life Full of Dreams That Are Now Coming True
text: The story of Patina Miller, a star of “Pippin,” follows a familiar template. A girl from Pageland, S.C., grows up singing in church under the watchful eye of her grandmother. After studying musical theater, she makes a splash in the London production of “Sister Act.” Eventually she wins a Tony Award for best actress in a musical (the current revival of “Pippin”) and is now planning a June wedding.

headline: ‘Witness Uganda’ Wins Richard Rodgers Award for Musical Theater
text: “Witness Uganda,” a musical by Matt Gould and Griffin Matthews, has won the 2014 Richard Rodgers Production Award for Musical Theater, the American Academy of Arts and Letters announced on Monday.

headline: What’s Behind the Declining Abortion Rate?
text: A new study released on Monday finds that the abortion rate among American women declined to its lowest level in more than three decades in 2011. Prepared by the Guttmacher Institute, the report points to some intriguing trends directly relevant to the current political battle over the contraception mandate.

headline: A Frenchman Finds It’s True. They Really Are Out to Get Him.
text: Robert Harris’s novel “An Officer and a Spy” has a point of high drama when the main character, Col. Georges Picquart, is ushered into a room full of atypical characters: people who will actually listen to him. For the first three-quarters of this book Picquart has operated quietly, trying to piece together the facts of the infamous Dreyfus affair, which culminated in the conviction, humiliation and banishment of Alfred Dreyfus, a French officer convicted on impossibly scanty evidence of being a German spy. Dreyfus is a Jew swept away on a wave of anti-Semitism, but there is also a major element of malfeasance among military officers that brought him to his fate.

headline: ScienceTake: Fight Club for Flies
text: Why are males aggressive? Researchers have found clues in the brains of fruit flies.

headline: A Waiting Game After the Super Bowl: Hours in Line for the Train
text: For months, the organizers of the Super Bowl coaxed fans to ride the rails, urging them to renounce private car travel in the name of the New York region’s famed public transportation system.

headline: New CDs From Broken Bells, Toni Braxton and Babyface
text: BROKEN BELLS

headline: To Study Aggression, a Fight Club for Flies
text: Males’ aggression toward each other is an old story throughout the animal kingdom. It’s not that females aren’t aggressive, but in many species, male-on-male battles are more common.

headline: You’re a Suspect. That’s the Drill.
text: “I Call My Brothers,” by the Swedish playwright Jonas Hassen Khemiri, tracks a fraught 24 hours in the life of young Arab-American man as he runs errands in New York City. The play, mostly narrated by the protagonist, Amor (Damon Owlia), stokes suspense by intimating that the story will take a dark, dramatic turn. Perhaps Amor will be tragically mistaken for a terrorist. Or maybe his anxieties will get the better of him, and that knife in his pocket will come flashing out.

headline: A Master of Percussion, in Its Sounds and Gestures
text: Steven Schick, the percussionist, conductor and San Diego author and educator, turns 60 this year. As he likes to point out, that makes him older than Stockhausen’s “Zyklus” (1959), the first major composition for solo percussion.

headline: Dallas Museum Lands a Rich Trove of Islamic Art
text: While Texas may have the fifth largest Muslim population in the United States by some estimates, its public art collections have only recently begun to reflect the 14-century sweep of Islamic history. But on Friday, with the stroke of a pen — sealing a complex agreement hashed out over months — the Dallas Museum of Art will become the long-term custodian of one of the most important collections of Islamic art in private hands.

headline: A Conductor to Flex and See Through
text: University of Houston researchers say they have developed an electrical conductor that is both highly flexible and transparent, an elusive combination that could help usher in an age of flexible flat-screen televisions and smartphones.

headline: Carly Rae Jepsen Takes a ‘Cinderella’ Risk
text: When you are a newcomer who takes the charts — and auditory nerves — by storm, as Carly Rae Jepsen did with her runaway single “Call Me Maybe,” the pop-music playbook dictates what you’re supposed to do next: Get back into the studio and record another hit before the clock strikes midnight on your good fortune.

headline: How Much Is That Seat? A Travel Site Breaks It Down
text: THE online travel company TripAdvisor will introduce on Tuesday an ambitious redesign of its Flights search feature that will provide detailed information globally on any given flight’s price — including added charges for options like extra legroom — as well as on in-flight amenities like the availability of Wi-Fi and in-seat power ports.

headline: Hollywood Was Just One of His Stages
text: For all his success in Hollywood — hits like “The Hunger Games,” an Academy Award for “Capote,” a promising Showtime series in the works — Philip Seymour Hoffman was the rare star who also worked nonstop in the less glamorous world of Off Broadway. It was his one professional constant during a 23-year career.

headline: New Book on Snowden Revelations From Guardian Writer
text: Only eight months after Edward J. Snowden engineered the release of some of America’s most closely held secrets on electronic surveillance by the government, the first major book on the subject will be published.

headline: A Timeline for the George Washington Bridge Scandal
text: Events in the scandal that has settled around Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey regarding the motives behind the shutdown of some traffic lanes to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: A Proud Daughter Sways to Her Own Beat, While Dancing With Her Past
text: The Brazilian singer Maria Rita’s exquisite concert on Sunday night at City Winery was daringly exposed in more ways than one.

headline: Australian Catch-and-Kill Shark Policy, Meant to Reassure, Horrifies Some
text: SYDNEY, Australia — As Australians flocked to the beaches at the height of a hot Southern Hemisphere summer, a commercial fisherman hired for the task hauled in a 10-foot tiger shark caught on a baited line. The fisherman shot the shark in the head four times with a .22-caliber rifle off the coast of Western Australia and then towed the carcass out to sea, where it was dumped.

headline: Times Minute | A Push for Pre-K
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | A Push for Pre-K
text: State-funded preschool becomes a bipartisan issue. Also on the Minute, genetic testing on embryos and a miracle in Tacloban, the Philippines.

headline: Take the Road Less Traveled; It May Lead to Barbecue
text: I LOVE business travel. I mean, I seriously love it, because every time I leave my home that means I’m doing something to develop my company. I’m the founder and designer for my business, Clothing Arts. We make travel apparel, so I might be meeting with a new buyer or an existing buyer or visiting some place to get inspiration. I’m a former Wall Street trader, and now I’m in the clothing business. I love every second of it. One business trip was five days long, and I was in India for a few of them, then Canada, then back to India, and then home. It was great.

headline: Losing Their Religion, and What’s Next
text: “Breaking Amish,” “Amish Mafia,” “Amish: Out of Order,” “Amish in the City,” “Witness”: What did one small, quiet group of religious orders do to deserve all this?

headline: Intersection: Colorful Style in London
text: In London’s diverse Brixton neighborhood, Michael Donkor, a teacher, describes his style as smart with a playful edge.

headline: Rihanna Joins Viva Glam by MAC to Fight AIDS
text: Slowly, the sales of one lipstick brand have grown so large that the little-known charity it supports, the MAC AIDS Fund, has become the second-largest private donor to AIDS organizations, after the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

headline: A. O. Scott on Philip Seymour Hoffman
text: The Times movie critic A. O. Scott talks about some of his favorite Philip Seymour Hoffman roles, and what defines the actor’s legacy.

headline: Three Views of Philip Seymour Hoffman
text: Moved by the news of Philip Seymour Hoffman’s death, we immediately thought of these photographs, which the magazine had specially commissioned of the notable actor over the years.In the summer of 2002 the magazine asked Gregory Crewdson to create the pictures for the inaugural edition of a photo essay section of the magazine, “Portfolio.” For his setting, he chose an empty house in Rutland, Vt., that had caught his imagination, and for our part we decided to pair him with well-known actors, a departure for Crewdson, whose mysterious, haunting images until then had all featured anonymous subjects. Our hope was to bring a new twist to celebrity portraiture and produce some unusual images. One of the actors cast for the “Dream House” portfolio was Philip Seymour Hoffman. He agreed to go up to Rutland on a Sunday in August. I remember thinking, as we were driving to meet up with him at our rendezvous in a shopping center parking lot, How will we know which car he is in? But there in the big empty lot, in one lone car smack in the middle of it, was a man reading The New York Times. Philip Seymour Hoffman knew how to make an entrance.

headline: Back to Job Hunt After Sharing State of the Union Spotlight
text: WASHINGTON — For a brief moment last week, at the request of the White House, Misty DeMars was the face of long-term unemployment in the United States. The attention has not led to any job offers, not yet at least, but she is hopeful. “I think I can boost my résumé by adding that I wrote part of the State of the Union 2014,” Ms. DeMars, 37, said wryly.

headline: Blazing Trails in Brain Science
text: BETHESDA, Md. — The police arrived at the house just after breakfast, dressed in full riot gear, and set up a perimeter at the front and back. Not long after, animal rights marchers began filling the street: scores of people, young and old, yelling accusations of murder and abuse, invoking Hitler, as neighbors stepped out onto their porches and stared.

headline: Joan Mondale, Who Merged Politics With Art, Dies at 83
text: Joan Mondale, whose promotion and advocacy of painting, sculpture and other fine arts earned her the nickname Joan of Art in Washington during the vice presidency of her husband, Walter F. Mondale, in the late 1970s, died on Monday in Minneapolis. She was 83.

headline: Tax Expert Sees Abuse in a Stream of Private Equity Fees
text: The tax practices of private equity firms have come under scrutiny from the authorities on several fronts. But there is an additional tax strategy that should merit a skeptical look, an academic argues in a new article.

headline: Art Matters | An Outlaw Art Fair Sets up Shop on L.A.’s Frontier
text: Despite its rising profile as an art capital, Los Angeles has never quite mustered an internationally attended art week until, arguably, just now. This year’s festivities, which concluded yesterday with the close of the Art Los Angeles Contemporary fair at the Barker Hangar in Santa Monica and the LA Art Book Fair at The Geffen Contemporary at MOCA in the Downtown area, felt buzzier than in years past — due, in part, to the addition of a newcomer to the circuit.

headline: Iran Giving Food Away to Millions for Relief
text: TEHRAN — The Iranian government has started handing out food packages for millions of its citizens both to help those with low income and to try to lower inflation on food, local news media reported on Monday.

headline: In Switch, Refusal to Testify Wins a Brooklyn Man His Freedom
text: For the last eight months, a Brooklyn man had been held in jail because of his refusal to testify before a grand jury that was believed to be examining a 2008 explosion in Times Square.

headline: Dutch Reporter Is Forced to Flee Egypt as Pursuit of Al Jazeera Journalists Snares More Victims
text: Last Updated, Tuesday, 2:18 a.m. | As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, the Qatari news network Al Jazeera condemned on Monday what it described as “an attempt to demonize” two of its reporters, Peter Greste and Mohamed Fahmy, with the release of video recorded during their arrest in December at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo.

headline: Fast Internet Is Chattanooga’s New Locomotive
text: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — For thousands of years, Native Americans used the river banks here to cross a gap in the Appalachian Mountains, and trains sped through during the Civil War to connect the eastern and western parts of the Confederacy. In the 21st century, it is the Internet that passes through Chattanooga, and at lightning speed.

headline: Catering to the Chinese Shopper’s Grand Tour
text: PARIS — Xiaoyan Mao had not yet collected her luggage after landing at Charles de Gaulle Airport from Shanghai recently. But she and a friend were already mapping out a game plan for the three days they would spend in Paris before continuing a 10-day European blitz with additional stops in Switzerland, Italy and Germany.

headline: Trade Issue Goes Untouched as Obama and Reid Meet
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama met with Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, at the White House on Monday but made no effort to change Mr. Reid’s mind on the trade initiative that has divided them, according to Democrats briefed on the session.

headline: Tacloban Three Months Later
text: Nearly three months after Typhoon Haiyan devastated the Philippines, many still live in tents with little electricity. Keith Bradsher reports from Tacloban.

headline: U.S. Plans Car-to-Car Warning System
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government said on Monday that it planned to require all new cars to broadcast their location, speed, direction and other data, and to receive similar data from other vehicles, to warn drivers of impending collisions. But regulators cautioned that any new rules would be years away.

headline: Boycott Israel? A War of Words
Russia: 3 Jailed in Anti-Gay Case
text: A court in Russia’s Far East on Monday found three men guilty of murdering a man in an attack that prosecutors said was motivated by homophobia. The three men were convicted of stabbing and beating the man, Oleg Serdyuk, to death in a forest near the village of Ust-Bolsheretskii in the Kamchatka region in May, and then burning his body in a car. Prosecutors said the defendants had killed Mr. Serdyuk because they believed he was gay. The men received sentences ranging from nine to 12 and a half years in a labor camp. Advocates for gay rights in Russia have claimed that the number of homophobic attacks has risen since the introduction of a law last year banning “gay propaganda” among children.

headline: Legalizing Immigrants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Britain: French Comic Barred
text: The controversial French comedian Dieudonné M’Bala M’Bala has been barred from entering Britain because of his extreme views, the Home Office said Monday. Mr. M’Bala M’Bala has been repeatedly convicted in France for inciting racial hatred, and his shows have been banned in several French towns. He has been criticized more recently for having invented the quenelle, a gesture that resembles a Nazi salute and carries anti-Semitic overtones, critics say. He says the gesture is social criticism, not aimed at any particular group. A spokeswoman for the Home Office said that Mr. M’Bala M’Bala was subject to an exclusion order, citing “public policy or public security reasons.”

headline: Outdated Missile Policy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Water Quality in High Rises
text: To the Editor:

headline: Advice for a Tall Mayor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chemical Safety: Views From Industry Groups
text: To the Editor:

headline: I.V.F. in Israel, With Unexpected Help From a Stranger
text: Decisions about fertility often come down to what you can change and what you have to accept. Do you accept an infertility diagnosis? Do you detoxify to conceive naturally, as suggested by Julia Indichova (“Inconceivable: A Woman’s Triumph Over Despair and Statistics”) and Sami S. David (“Making Babies: A Proven 3-Month Program for Maximum Fertility”)? Or do you move on to in vitro fertilization?

headline: Maintainer of City Watershed Fatally Shot, Officials Say
text: New Yorkers seldom stop to think that the water they use comes from reservoirs in the forests and wooded hills that stretch from Westchester County to the Catskills, or of the workers who keep it flowing, and safe. But early Monday morning, something happened to remind them.

headline: Finnish Soul Is Reflected in Goalies
text: The duel at 178 feet between Antti Niemi and Tuukka Rask took place last month in California, with the fateful shot heard halfway around the world in Finland, long known for skiing, saunas, sunless winters and cellphones, and increasingly gaining notice for its puck stoppers.

headline: At Four Seasons, Picasso Tapestry Hangs on the Edge of Eviction
text: For more than half a century, it has hung in the hallway of the Four Seasons Restaurant on Park Avenue, an immense work by one of the greatest artists of the 20th century. But Picasso’s curtain is coming down — and that might just destroy it.

headline: When Loud Music Turned Deadly
text: This video tells the story of a black teenager in Florida who was killed by a white man after an argument over loud music. The slain youth’s father shares his loss.

headline: Dissecting a Frog: How to Write a Humor Piece
text: Analyzing humor, as E.B. White famously said, is like dissecting a frog; few people are interested and the frog dies of it. Nonetheless, writing humor is a highly logical exercise — fit idea X into form Y for humorous result Z — and can therefore be broken down in ways that more slippery kinds of prose tend to resist.

headline: Born While Floods Surge
text: Yolando was born during the worst of typhoon Haiyan. He lives with his family in a region devastated by the storm.

headline: Don’t Ask Your Doctor About ‘Low T’
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — A FUNNY thing has happened in the United States over the last few decades. Men’s average testosterone levels have been dropping by at least 1 percent a year, according to a 2006 study in The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism.

headline: Detroit Turns Bankruptcy Into Challenge of Banks
text: Detroit’s bankruptcy is rapidly shaping up as a battle of Wall Street vs. Main Street, at least as far as the city’s creditors are concerned.

headline: Lawmaker Says Colleges Are Misleading on Aid Letter
text: Many top colleges are misleading applicants about the paperwork needed to seek financial aid, possibly violating federal law and costing students extra money, a congressman said on Monday.

headline: Seahawks-Broncos Super Bowl TV Ratings Top 111 Million
text: The game was hardly an edge-of-the-seat thriller, but in the end the pull of the Super Bowl was all that mattered: A record 111.5 million viewers watched Fox’s coverage of the Seattle Seahawks’ dismantling of the Denver Broncos, the Nielsen company reported on Monday.

headline: ‘Puppy Love’ Warms Hearts; Diversity Draws Mixed Response
text: THE annual flood of data after the Super Bowl indicates that the commercials during the game that did best among consumers on television, online and in social media were feel-good spots meant to be uplifting, inspirational, nostalgic or patriotic. And by almost all accounts, the spot that was discussed, liked and shared most was “Puppy Love,” a warm, emotional tale created by the Anomaly agency that Budweiser brought to viewers late in the fourth quarter.

headline: Super Bowl Again Proves Bigger Than the Game Itself
text: The Super Bowl can be a great game or a bad game, a dramatic struggle or a laugher. And viewership hardly wavers.

headline: Closing Arguments in Martoma Trial
text: Mathew Martoma, a former top portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, pursued a “canary in a coal mine” to give him an “illegal sneak preview” of the results of a clinical Alzheimer’s drug trial, a prosecutor said on Monday in closing remarks for the government’s closely watched insider trading case.

headline: Hoffman’s Heroin Points to Surge in Grim Trade
text: Detectives found dozens of small packages in the West Village apartment where Philip Seymour Hoffman, the actor, died on Sunday. Most were branded, some with purple letters spelling out Ace of Spades, others bearing the mark of an ace of hearts. At least five were empty, and in the trash.

headline: Love, Death and Sochi
text: There are few moments sweeter, more humbling or more thrilling than telling someone you love how you feel.

headline: Karzai Arranged Secret Contacts With the Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has been engaged in secret contacts with the Taliban about reaching a peace agreement without the involvement of his American and Western allies, further corroding already strained relations with the United States.

headline: What Machines Can’t Do
text: We’re clearly heading into an age of brilliant technology. Computers are already impressively good at guiding driverless cars and beating humans at chess and Jeopardy. As Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology point out in their book “The Second Machine Age,” computers are increasingly going to be able to perform important parts of even mostly cognitive jobs, like picking stocks, diagnosing diseases and granting parole.

headline: Collegiate Women’s Bowling Gains in Popularity
text: Bowl season has a completely different meaning to Dawn Gugliaro.

headline: Second U.S. Bribery Trial Begins for Brooklyn Assemblyman
text: In October 2010, William F. Boyland Jr., a state assemblyman from Brooklyn, shared fine cuts of meat, wine and whiskey with two businessmen who were trying to buy Mr. Boyland’s political influence.

headline: Olson and Boies, Legal Duo, Seek Role in 2 Cases on Gay Marriage
text: WASHINGTON — Theodore B. Olson and David Boies, the star legal duo who defied skeptics by successfully challenging California’s ban on same-sex marriage, are seeking to play a central role in the next round of marriage cases that appear to be on a fast track to the high court. But in doing so, they have touched off a debate over who gets the coveted job of arguing what could be a landmark gay rights decision.

headline: ‘When Loud Music Turned Deadly’
text: This Op-Doc video tells the story of how a black 17-year-old, Jordan Davis, was killed by a 45-year-old white man, Michael Dunn, now charged with first-degree murder. The shooting took place at a gas station in Jacksonville, Fla., the day after Thanksgiving in 2012. It followed an argument in which Mr. Dunn complained about loud hip-hop music playing in Mr. Davis’s friend’s car. Mr. Dunn has claimed he fired in self-defense after seeing a gun, which the police never found. Two lives, two outcomes, both tragic. Jury selection begins this week.

headline: Too Many Sorry Excuses for Apology
text: It seems that just about every day a chief executive, politician or other prominent figure is apologizing for something.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 4, 2014
text: “Nothing says ‘hard-core’ like being cast out by Al Qaeda.”

headline: The Gun Report, 1 Year Later
text: It has been a year since my assistant, Jennifer Mascia, and I started publishing The Gun Report, an effort to use my blog to aggregate daily gun violence in America. Our methodology is pretty simple: We do a Google News search each weekday morning for the previous day’s shootings and then list them. Most days, we have been finding between 20 and 30 shootings; on Mondays, when we also add the weekend’s violence, the number is usually well over 100.

headline: Bill Would Put Face on Anonymous Attack Ads
text: One campaign advertisement mailed to voters’ homes last fall suggested that a candidate for New York City comptroller deserved to be behind bars. Another highlighted accusations of sexual harassment against a City Council candidate. In a Russian-speaking enclave of Brooklyn, a robocall accused a Council hopeful of having once been an agent for the K.G.B.

headline: Calling for an Apology Cease-Fire
text: In 1976, Elton John sang the memorable phrase “Sorry seems to be the hardest word.” Well, “sorry” has become one of the easiest and most convenient — and therefore least meaningful — words there is.

headline: Firearms’ Toll Among the Young
text: The world at large heard instantly about the school massacre in Newtown, Conn., where 20 youngsters were murdered in 2012 in a terrifying spree of gunfire. Far less noticed but no less horrific is the unending toll from the more routine bursts of gunfire that each day send an average of 20 American children and adolescents to hospitals, many of them for long-term treatment.

headline: A Chill on Speech
text: The New York Legislature is moving to pass a bill that would bar state financing for academic groups that have taken official action to boycott higher-education institutions in Israel. The initiative, which last week passed the State Senate, is now pending before the Assembly. It should be voted down by lawmakers, or, if they prove feckless, Gov. Andrew Cuomo should veto it.

headline: Democracy in Thailand, Interrupted
text: These are dark days in Thailand, where an election on Sunday was disrupted by protesters whose demands for a suspension of democracy could lead to greater chaos. The country’s constitutional monarchy has faced coups and street protests in the past, but it has been a model of relative stability and development in Southeast Asia, a region known for its autocratic and brutal governments. As an American treaty ally, Thailand has been critically important in helping to reduce regional tensions and provided balance to the growing military assertiveness of China by championing trade and economic integration partly through the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. On Sunday, protesters disrupted the vote by blocking the distribution of ballot boxes to polling places in about 11 percent of the country’s electoral districts. Because Thailand’s Constitution requires that 95 percent of parliamentary seats be filled before a new government can be formed, the disruption means the country will remain in limbo for months as election authorities try to conduct elections in those districts where protesters prevented a vote from taking place. A gun battle between protesters and government supporters left seven people injured on Saturday, a day before the elections.

headline: The Mayor and the Unions
text: For Mayor Bill de Blasio, this is the month that the civic conversation shifts from lofty goals and progressive agenda setting — and, let’s hope, snow plowing — to the gloomier and more combative subject of money.

headline: They Often Elicit Blessings
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the things I admire about young David Steinberg (calling him “young” probably grates on his nerves, but I’m old enough to be his mother so I claim that right) is his enthusiasm for pushing the constructing envelope in what I consider to be a very productive way. Many beginning constructors find it enough to develop a simple, relatively tight theme and be done with it. Not Mr. Steinberg. He goes for the tough stuff and then tightens it up even more.

headline: Parks Department Takes a Seat Behind Nonprofit Conservancies
text: Somewhere along the way, New York City lost its faith in its ability to run a parks department.

headline: Move to Red Bulls Gets Convey Close to Home
text: One of the Red Bulls’ new players has a familiarity with the team’s second-year coach, Mike Petke, that comes more from dynamic interchanges on the soccer field than from pedestrian chalk-talks after training.

headline: Immigrant Youth Leaders Signal They May Be Open to a G.O.P. Compromise
text: WASHINGTON — Despite a defiant tone, immigrant youth leaders gathered here on Monday gave signs that they could consider supporting a Republican compromise proposal offering a path to citizenship for young people but not for other immigrants in the country illegally.

headline: The Other Super Bowl Contest: Twitter vs. Facebook
text: From the start of the Super Bowl on Sunday, it was obvious that it was a one-sided match-up: the Seattle Seahawks quickly took the lead, leaving the Denver Broncos further and further behind in every quarter.

headline: A Long Goodbye for a Lost Railroad
text: JIANGMEN, China — It has been decades since a train has passed through the old Beijie train station in southern China. On a recent winter morning, the only sign of activity came from a group of architecture students busy with their sketch pads.

headline: The Casual Couture of the Average American
text: From sweatpants on airplanes to flip flops in the workplace: Have Americans taken casual dressing too far?

headline: Corrections: February 4, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Championship Built in Carroll’s Image
text: Pete Carroll bounded through the front doors of the Sheraton Times Square Hotel a little after 8 a.m. Monday. It was 10 hours after his Seattle Seahawks won Super Bowl XLVIII, so he had ample time to rest. He just didn’t.

headline: De Blasio Says New York Learned From Past Storm Mistakes
text: Grappling with the first of three snowstorms expected to hit New York City in a week, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Monday that his administration had learned from its mistakes and had already made changes to speed snow removal.

headline: In Talk of Economy, Obama Turns to ‘Opportunity’ Over ‘Inequality’
text: WASHINGTON — Like so many political fights, the one between President Obama and Republicans over income inequality has become a battle over language. Is it about inequality of incomes or of opportunity? On this question, the president and his party have moved in Republicans’ — and voters’ — direction.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 3, 2014
With New App, Facebook Aims to Make Its Users’ Feeds Newsier
text: Mark Zuckerberg dreams of a day when Facebook’s computers would know you and your habits so well that it would deliver exactly the information you want to see — what he calls “the best personalized newspaper in the world.”

headline: While Asking for Help, Detroit Sells a Comeback
text: DETROIT — Consider this public relations challenge, perhaps not seen since the Edsel: At the same time that beleaguered Detroit is emphasizing its desperate need for financial support, it is pitching itself as the city of the future.

headline: Video of Journalists’ Arrest in Egypt Seen as Threat to Media
text: CAIRO — A leaked video of the arrest of two journalists offered a cinematic close-up on Monday of the new military-backed government’s crackdown on dissent: slow-moving footage of a hotel room full of telecommunications equipment set to the thumping, sinister score of the recent superhero movie “Thor: The Dark World.”

headline: Dispute Over Italian Marines Prompts Bickering in Indian Court, but No Resolution
text: NEW DELHI — With black-robed lawyers crammed into a courtroom, India’s Supreme Court refused on Monday to resolve a major international dispute that a top Italian diplomat warned could soon damage ties.

headline: De Blasio Takes a Comedic Break on ‘The Daily Show’
text: He bragged about hanging Che Guevara posters in his office, announced plans to flood the Upper East Side with biblical insects, and declared that the horses of Central Park were being waterboarded in their stables.

headline: Toyota Is Reported With Most Recalls in 2013
text: For the second year in a row, Toyota led the nation with the most vehicles recalled: nearly 5.3 million in 2013. The cars and trucks from Toyota and its Lexus brand were among the almost 22 million vehicles recalled last year in 632 recalls, according to figures released by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. That figure compares with nearly 16.4 million vehicles recalled in 2012 and is the highest number since 2004, when recalled vehicles hit 30.8 million. The Chrysler Group ranked second, with almost 4.7 million vehicles recalled in 36 actions; and Honda and its Acura brand were third, with 15 recalls involving almost 2.8 million vehicles.

headline: As Kidd Hits Stride, Nets Keep Improving by Nipping Sixers
text: Nets Coach Jason Kidd walked into a pregame news conference at Barclays Center on Dec. 3 with a sobering bit of information: He was relieving his top assistant, Lawrence Frank, of a majority of his coaching duties.

headline: Former Aide to Christie Invokes Fifth Amendment Right
text: A former top aide to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey revealed Monday that she would not hand over documents in response to a subpoena from a legislative panel investigating the controversial closing of lanes at the George Washington Bridge last fall, citing her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.

headline: Trading Captain Isn’t a Rarity in the N.H.L., and Usually Isn’t a Productive Move
text: The uncertainty over the future of the Rangers’ captain, Ryan Callahan, continued Monday, with fans wondering whether he would be dealt before the trade deadline on March 5 or the Olympic roster freeze on Friday.

headline: Jean Babilée, Rebel of World Ballet, Dies at 90
text: Jean Babilée, who gained instant stardom in French ballet as the violent chair-throwing youth in Roland Petit’s “Le Jeune Homme et la Mort” (“The Young Man and Death”) in 1946, and who remained international dance’s great rebel, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 90.

headline: Falling to Bucks, the Knicks Continue a Pattern of Not Having One
text: MILWAUKEE — The fourth-quarter scenes played out in a way that could only make Knicks Coach Mike Woodson shudder. Amar’e Stoudamire dribbled into a lane crowded with Milwaukee Bucks and lost the ball. Out of the pack came Milwaukee forward Giannis Antetokounmpo, his long limbs churning upcourt on the way to a dunk that pushed the Bucks’ lead to 10.

headline: Potent Pro-Israel Group Finds Its Momentum Blunted
text: WASHINGTON — The last time the nation’s most potent pro-Israel lobbying group lost a major showdown with the White House was when President Ronald Reagan agreed to sell Awacs surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia over the group’s bitter objections.

headline: Study Finds Changes in Brains of Hockey Players Who Had Concussions
text: Hockey players who sustained concussions during a recent season experienced acute microstructural changes in their brains, according to a series of studies published in the Journal of Neurosurgery on Tuesday.

headline: How L.B.J. Pushed Through Kennedy’s Tax Cut
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | carapace
text: carapace•\ˈker-ə-ˌpas, ˈka-rə-\• noun

headline: Study Puts Exonerations at Record Level in U.S.
text: The number of exonerations in the United States of those wrongly convicted of a crime increased to a record 87 during 2013, and of that number, nearly one in five had initially pleaded guilty to charges filed against them, according to a report to be released on Tuesday as part of a project led by two university law schools.

headline: Mets Sign Farnsworth
text: The Mets continued to fill out their bullpen, announcing that they had signed Kyle Farnsworth to a minor league deal, with an invitation to spring training. Farnsworth, 37, had a 4.70 earned run average in 48 games last season, which he split between Pittsburgh and Tampa Bay.

headline: Indian Groups Question Public Child-Welfare Practices
text: DENVER — Several prominent Native American groups on Monday called for the Justice Department to investigate the treatment of Indian children in public child-welfare systems and private adoptions.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) RUST AND BONE (2012) Ali (Matthias Schoenaerts), a former prizefighter fleeing with his young son (Armand Verdure) from a bad situation, arrives in Antibes, on the Côte d’Azur. At a club where he works as a bouncer, he meets Stephanie (Marion Cotillard, above, with Mr. Schoenaerts), a trainer for a Sea World-like amusement park. Then she loses her legs in an accident with a killer whale and calls him, thinking he might help rouse her from her despair. “A plot summary of ‘Rust and Bone’ might suggest a maudlin, therapeutic fable of healing, and in many ways — or, let’s say, in hindsight — the movie is just that,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But its conventional, sentimental essence (which is overtly revealed only at the end) is effectively complicated, indeed almost undone, by the jagged textures of the filmmaking and the naturalistic intensity of the performances.” He added: “The removal of Ms. Cotillard’s legs — including in scenes in which she wears a bathing suit or nothing — is surely one of the most impressive special-effects feats of the year, and a reminder that digital cinema is not all about accessorizing wizards, monsters and superheroes. But the greater marvel is Ms. Cotillard herself, an actress of limitless bravery and supernatural poise, who is both beauty and beast. Mr. Schoenaerts is her perfect foil and complement, as large and coarse as she is small and delicate, and also as tender as she is tough.”

headline: Adult Swim, No. 1 With Younger Adults, Is Expanding
text: The big developments in late-night television are not all happening on NBC this week. Adult Swim, the network that is, in many ways, the new force in late night, has some significant news, too: It is expanding again.

headline: Stevie Nicks, Just Following Her Muse
text: During her 40-year career as a member of Fleetwood Mac and a solo artist, the singer-songwriter Stevie Nicks has made more than 40 Top 50 hits and sold over 140 million albums. “In Your Dreams,” a documentary film about the making of her 2011 album of the same name, was recently released on DVD. Now 65, Ms. Nicks called from a rented house in Phoenix, her hometown. A condensed and edited version of our conversation follows.

headline: A Competition for Converts in Arunachal Pradesh
text: ITANAGAR, Arunachal Pradesh — Though the event they advertised had passed a month earlier, the neon-colored posters remained, clinging to the state capital’s walls, lampposts and storefronts. On them were invitations to Indigenous Faith Day celebrations on Dec. 1, with slogans like “Culture without faith is body without soul,” and, more pointedly, “Imitation of alien faith is slavery.”

headline: Foursquare Checks In With Microsoft and Gets $15 Million to Revitalize Itself
text: On Tuesday, Foursquare, the location-sharing application, announced a data licensing partnership and $15 million investment from Microsoft.

headline: Profit Drops for BP, but Still Beats Analysts’ Forecasts
text: LONDON — BP, the British oil giant, on Tuesday joined other oil companies including Royal Dutch Shell and Exxon Mobil in reporting lower profit for the fourth quarter as production declined and the company’s refineries struggled to make money.

headline: Revamping and Tax Gain Help UBS Beat Estimates
text: Updated, 7:30 p.m. | The Swiss bank UBS reported higher-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday as a far-reaching revamping plan started to pay off and it benefited from a tax gain.

headline: Can Marriage Cure Poverty?
text: Imagine a late-night television commercial aimed at Washington’s wonks: Tired of your same old tax credits and grant proposals? Ever dreamed of a policy tool that improved children’s health, bolstered income and eradicated poverty — all without costing the government a penny? Then, a smash cut to a wedding scene.

headline: If You Were Governor of Your State, How Would You Spend a Budget Surplus?
text: We have become so used to hearing news about layoffs and spending cuts over the past several years that you may not remember what it’s like to have a government surplus — but that’s exactly what’s happening in many states. Politicians now have to figure out what to do with that extra money.

headline: For a Select Few, the Transformative Power of Facebook — for Better or Worse
text: On Tuesday, Facebook turns 10. Over the last decade, it has grown from a website coded in a dorm room to a Silicon Valley giant. It has been at the center of privacy and security backlashes and controversies — some short and others lasting — over new policies and one redesign after another.

headline: Rights Group Releases Video of LGBT Attacks in Russia
text: With just days left until the start on Friday of the Sochi Winter Olympics, Human Rights Watch released a video on Tuesday that highlights the disturbing violence and discrimination that gay, lesbian, transgender and bisexual people face in Russia.

headline: Photographer Shifts from Automotive Espionage to Fine Art
text: CHANDLER, ARIZ. — Brenda Priddy has become known around the world for her automotive spy photography. In her line of work, she stalks heavily camouflaged prototype vehicles being driven in secret — or so the engineers at the wheel have thought.

text: BEIJING — IF you want to understand the current state of self-expression in China, the best indicator must be the line “Sorry, the text has been deleted.”

headline: When Plan A Doesn’t Work
text: Three years ago, I had an idea for a technology company. I noticed that the daily deal sites like Groupon and LivingSocial were starting to wane, and I thought I had a better model. I mocked up some designs, built a PowerPoint deck, and took the concept to investors. After a year of pitching, I raised the money, hired a team, and set about building the product, which we called Posse.

headline: Beating the ‘Curse of the Ninth’
text: LONDON — Two years ago when Peter Maxwell Davies — doyen of British composers and Master of the Queen’s Music — produced a Ninth Symphony he was asked, repeatedly, if he shouldn’t be worried about the “Curse of the Ninth”: a long-cherished myth of classical music claiming that if you manage to write nine symphonies you probably won’t live to complete a 10th.

headline: Venture Capital Firm Focused on the Midwest Raises a $250 Million Fund
text: Mark D. Kvamme, a former partner at the venture capital firm Sequoia Capital, considers himself “a Silicon Valley guy through and through,” having grown up in the region and spent his professional life there.

headline: Veteran Banker to Lead Citigroup’s British Business
text: LONDON – James Bardrick, a veteran banker in London, has been named head of Citigroup’s business in Britain.

text: A slightly unusual word choice can enliven a story. But we should make sure we know what our slightly unusual word actually means.

headline: Where White Means Diversity
text: A FEDERAL COURT DECISION concerning competition between Maryland’s predominantly white public universities and its predominantly black ones has turned the spotlight on diversification of historically black colleges.

headline: Hard Times at Howard U.
text: IT COULD BE SAID that Dr. Wayne A.I. Frederick, acting president of Howard University, was to the manner born. On his birth 42 years ago in Port of Spain, Trinidad, his mother had already determined he would follow in the footsteps of the man she admired most: Eric Williams, who before leading Trinidad and Tobago to independence from Britain had taught at Howard.

headline: Spike Jonze Lives a 5-Year Relationship in 1 Day
text: LOS ANGELES — Spike Jonze, who won the Writers Guild Award for best original screenplay for “Her” over the weekend, has a slightly unusual writer-director process: he spends a long time in the edit room, as much as a year, tweaking the script continually as he goes. But in one way, “Her” appeared on screen as originally written: the flashbacks between Joaquin Phoenix’s character, Theodore Twombly, and his ex-wife, played by Rooney Mara. Those scenes flesh out his romantic life before he falls for his computer operating system, voiced by Scarlett Johansson.

headline: Hold the Apologies
text: “What does saying ‘sorry’ mean when it’s tossed around with the frequency of a Justin Bieber scandal?” asks Andrew Ross Sorkin in the DealBook column. Almost every day, some prominent figure — a chief executive, a politician, an athlete — is apologizing for something — to say nothing of the average person. Are we in the midst of an apology crisis? To hear Dov Seidman talk about it, the answer is an emphatic yes. And in fact, Mr. Seidman is so sure that our mea culpas have become meaningless that he called for an “apology cease-fire” in front of several dozen chief executives and politicians at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Remembering to Pray
text: Sometimes, toward end of day, I jog on a beach nearby on Mobile Bay. As the sun is sinking I look out at the pelicans wheeling in the sky, the fishermen on Fairhope Pier casting their nets, sailboats and channel markers changing to silhouette.

text: There’s a handcrafted earthiness to urban dressing this season.

headline: After 2 Years in Moscow, U.S. Envoy Is Resigning
text: MOSCOW — The United States ambassador to Russia announced Tuesday that he would resign after the Winter Olympics, set to begin in Sochi this week, ending a stormy two-year tenure during which relations between the two countries were at their lowest ebb since the end of the Cold War.

headline: Market for Patents Was Softer in 2013, Firms Say
text: Technology companies have for years been stockpiling patents as an aggressive defense against lawsuits. But patent prices and transfers were down significantly in 2013, according to data from a patent brokerage company and an intellectual property valuation and investment firm.

headline: The Embarrassing Debt Ceiling Ritual
text: Jack Lew, the Treasury secretary, must be tired of this embarrassing ritual by now. Every few months, he has to notify Congress that the entirely unnecessary borrowing limit that lawmakers have insisted on imposing must be raised yet again. Then he has to wait while Republicans contort themselves to keep the government out of default while trying to persuade the hard right that they really hate doing so.

headline: Brisk Business in Big Law Firms Hiring Other Firms’ Partners, Study Finds
text: The country’s biggest law firms are hiring other firms’ partners at a rapid pace, a new study has found. Lawyers specializing in corporate work are the hottest commodities, an annual tally by the legal journal American Lawyer showed.

text: I encourage you to read “How the U.S. Exports Global Warming,” a fine feature by Tim Dickinson in Rolling Stone showing how the United States, flush with coal, oil and the dirty tar sands byproduct petroleum coke, is working hard, from the White House down, to become a big exporter of carbon. Here’s the nut paragraph, which draws an apt parallel to the history of tobacco regulation and trade:

text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Dana Stevens discuss whether the classic marriage plot — desire, courtship, happily ever after — stand up in 2014?

headline: Amid Ethics Inquiry, South Jersey Democrat Is Giving Up House Seat for a New Job
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Robert E. Andrews announced on Tuesday that he would resign from Congress after more than two decades, but said it had nothing to do with a bleak outlook for Democratic chances of retaking the House or with an ethics investigation into alleged misuse of his campaign funds.
