text: WARROAD, Minn. — This time, no royal titles were conferred, like King and Queen of the Frosty Festival, which T. J. Oshie and Gigi Marvin were crowned at Warroad High School in 2005.

headline: Signs of Progress in UBS Investment Bank Overhaul
text: More than a year ago, UBS pledged to overhaul its investment bank after a prominent trading loss and a rate-rigging scandal. Those efforts appeared to be bearing fruit, based on the bank’s latest earnings report released Tuesday.

headline: Sphinx Organization to Join With IMG Artists in Aiding Student Musicians
text: The Sphinx Organization, an organization based in Detroit that offers classical music training to minority students, announced a partnership with the management agency IMG Artists on Tuesday, in which Sphinx’s orchestras would perform at festivals and other events run by IMG, and IMG’s artists would collaborate with Sphinx. Aaron P. Dworkin, the violinist who founded Sphinx in 1996 and has built it into a national program that runs competitions and sends touring ensembles around the country, described the agreement as a relationship unlike the usual arrangement between managers and artists.

headline: Moderate Me Me Me Blogging
text: So Noah Smith has a piece about how moderate yours truly really is. It’s almost completely right, except that I wish Noah would stop saying that my views on monetary policy in a liquidity trap derive from Eggertsson/Woodford; it’s a fine paper, but they were following me, not the other way around. Also, Arcade Fire’s “My body is a cage” isn’t a cover of Peter Gabriel; he was covering them.

text: WASHINGTON — A Congressional Budget Office analysis released Tuesday predicted that the Affordable Care Act would shrink the work force by the equivalent of more than two million full-time positions and recharged the political debate over the health care law, providing Republican opponents fresh lines of attack and putting Democrats on the defensive.

headline: Time Inc. to Cut 500 Jobs Ahead of Spinoff
text: Time Inc., the magazine giant with brands including People, Sports Illustrated and Fortune, began a new round of layoffs on Tuesday as part of a companywide restructuring that will result in the loss of about 500 jobs, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: James J. Gallagher Dies at 87; Educator Focused on Disabled and Gifted
text: James J. Gallagher, an authority on child development whose work expanded educational opportunities for disabled and gifted children nationwide, died on Jan. 17 at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 87.

headline: Evaporating Unemployment
text: Before the recession, in December 2007, about 63 percent of American adults had jobs. Six years later, in December 2013, less than 59 percent of adults had jobs.

text: Hindu devotees offering prayers at Allahabad in Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Britain Says India Did Not Follow Its Advice in 1984 Army Raid
text: LONDON — Britain sent a military officer to advise India before Indian forces stormed the Golden Temple in Amritsar in 1984, leaving hundreds dead, but the advice was largely ignored and had little impact on the bloody outcome, the British government said on Tuesday.

headline: Designer Seed Thought to Be Latest Target by Chinese
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The case of the missing corn seeds first broke in May 2011 when a manager at a DuPont research farm in east-central Iowa noticed a man on his knees, digging up the field. When confronted, the man, Mo Hailong, who was with his colleague Wang Lei, appeared flushed. Mr. Mo told the manager that he worked for the University of Iowa and was traveling to a conference nearby. When the manager paused to answered his cellphone, the two men sped off in a car, racing through a ditch to get away, federal authorities said.

headline: Fraud in Army Recruiting Bonus Program May Cost Nearly $100 Million
text: WASHINGTON — An Army program meant to increase the number of recruits during the Iraq and Afghanistan wars devolved into an illegal free-for-all that could cost taxpayers close to $100 million, military investigators say, describing new details of what they called a long-running scheme among National Guard recruiters that went undetected for years.

headline: Mr. Fremantle’s Adventure
text: In early 1864, printers in New York and Mobile, Ala. began to publish one of the most unusual books of the Civil War: the diary of a British officer, Lt. Colonel Arthur Fremantle, who had spent three months observing the war, on both sides. Though he began his tour with a pro-Union bias on account of his opposition to slavery, Fremantle traveled extensively through the South. Entering through Mexico, he crossed the Rio Grande on April 7, 1863, and left New York to return to Britain 14 weeks later. His insights into the Confederacy, though at times myopic, especially on the question of slavery, offer one of the best single sources on life in the wartime South.

headline: Scenes From Hockeytown USA
text: Images from the tiny town of Warroad, Minn., the home of two indoor ice rinks and eight Olympic hockey players.

headline: California Teacher Accused of Sexual Abuse in YouTube Video Is Arrested
text: A former California teacher and school administrator is expected to be arraigned Thursday on 16 felony charges of sexual assault after a former student confronted her over the telephone and then posted a video recording of the conversation on YouTube, according to a statement from the district attorney’s office in Riverside, Calif.

headline: Bookshelf | Portraits of the Hudson Valley’s Creative Community
text: When Pete Seeger died last week, folk music lost one of its greatest pioneers, but so, too, did the Hudson Valley. Seeger had called the bucolic area just north of New York City home since the late ’40s, when he spent $1,700 for 17 acres in Beacon. It was from his house there that Seeger began, in the ’60s, his crusade to clean up the polluted Hudson River via his environmental nonprofit, the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater. Seeger was inspired artistically throughout his lifetime by the force of the mighty, meandering river, and it was Seeger that the British graphic designer Nick Hand initially had in mind when he decided, in the spring of 2012, to log about 550 miles biking through the region to interview and photograph members of its artisan community. The results are compiled in his new and lovely little book, “Conversations on the Hudson” (Princeton Architectural Press).

headline: In London: Three Plays, Double Standards
text: LONDON — The exorcists’ job is far from over, it seems. More than a century after they were first conjured, the title figures of Ibsen’s “Ghosts,” those remnants of corrosive societal traditions, are still clinging to us like leeches.

headline: Christie’s Cancels Sale of Joan Miro Works Owned by Portugal
text: MADRID — On Tuesday, the auction house Christie’s canceled a London sale of a collection of 85 works by the Catalan artist Joan Miró, owned by Portugal.

headline: A Portable Music Player That May Outdo Some Home Systems
text: Who needs a $2,000 iPod?

headline: At Microsoft, a Step Forward as Founders Step Back
text: Microsoft’s founding fathers are finally receding into the middle distance. Satya Nadella’s experience makes him a solid choice to succeed the longtime chief executive, Steven Ballmer. Better still, he will have greater room to maneuver as Bill Gates steps down as chairman. Mr. Nadella will need to grapple with his predecessors’ bad decisions, like the Nokia deal, and he’s unlikely to pursue a breakup. But he can focus on what the company does best.

headline: Team Harry vs. Team Ron
text: J. K. Rowling’s admission that Hermione Granger should not have ended up with Ron Weasley at the end of the Harry Potter series has sent shock waves through the lives of people heavily invested in the lives of fictional adolescent wizards.

headline: British Insurer Names R.B.S.’s Former Chief as Its C.E.O.
text: LONDON – The British insurer RSA Group said on Tuesday that it had tapped the former chief executive of the Royal Bank of Scotland as its top executive two months after the insurer announced a huge hole in its balance sheet.

headline: Obamacare and the Decline of Work
text: The headlines for the new Congressional Budget Office report on the health care law emphasize the botched roll-out’s potential impact on enrollment, but this strikes me as quite possibly the bigger deal:

headline: Same Old Stadium, Same Winning Approach for the A’s
text: Frustration is useless, so the Oakland Athletics insist they do not feel it. This is hard to believe, but maybe it is part of the reason that, as the game keeps evolving, the A’s remain one step ahead.

headline: Westchester Leader Moves Toward a Bid for Governor
text: ALBANY — Nine months before Election Day, New York Republicans have inched closer to finding a potential candidate for governor, with word that Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, has formed an exploratory committee.

headline: Don’t Look for de Blasio in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio says he won’t be marching in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade because its organizers don’t allow Irish gays and lesbians to march behind banners, signs, flags or other symbols that proclaim gay identity and pride.

headline: Russia Says Syria Will Export Chemicals by March 1
text: Seeking to mollify international officials impatient with Syria for missing deadlines to destroy its chemical weapons, Russia said on Tuesday that the Syrian government planned to send a large shipment out of the country this month and to export its entire stockpile by March 1.

headline: L.A. Dance Project Finds a New Home at Ace Hotel
text: The L.A. Dance Project, started in 2012 by the former New York City Ballet dancer Benjamin Millepied, has a new home. It’s the Theater at Ace Hotel, a 1600-seat space in downtown Los Angeles that occupies the ground floor of a new boutique hotel created in in a 1927 building. The company will have its first performances there on Feb. 20, with Justin Peck’s “Murder Ballads,” a new work by Hiroaki Umeda, and Mr. Millepied’s “Reflections.”

headline: The Seeds of a New Generation
text: John D. Jackson lives in the heart of the Corn Belt, where most of the corn has nothing to do with sweet kernels on the cob. His farm in Southern Illinois typically grows field corn, the high-starch variety that is turned into ethanol and cattle feed. He also works as a logistics manager for Archer Daniels Midland, the agricultural giant that produces the other big artifact of this crop: high fructose corn syrup.

headline: Obama Announces Pledges of $750 Million for Student Technology
text: ADELPHI, Md. — Business leaders have pledged more than $750 million as part of a White House initiative to strengthen access to technology for 99 percent of students within five years, President Obama announced on Tuesday.

headline: Video: Filming ‘Dallas Buyers Club’
text: “Dallas Buyers Club” came away empty-handed from the Writers Guild Awards over the weekend, but the film, including its screenplay, is still very much in contention at the Oscars. The Bagger’s colleague Mekado Murphy spoke with the director, Jean-Marc Vallée, about his filmmaking approach, which could be summed up in a phrase: “let the shots breathe.”

headline: Regulator Compares Currency Investigation to Libor Case
text: LONDON — Expect more bad news from banks about accusations of manipulation in the huge foreign exchange market.

headline: What, Us Worry?
text: Reading the latest Pew Research Center report on global attitudes toward aging made me think of Mad magazine.

headline: The Best Time to Talk to Your Children About the Next National Tragedy? Now
text: The best time to think about how you’ll tackle difficult subjects with your children is before the need arises.

headline: Paying the Rent on Time Can Enhance Your Credit Report
text: If you’re a young person just starting out in the working world, you may not have much of a credit history, especially if you don’t have student loans or have never had a credit card.

text: A day in the life of armed America.

headline: Target Vows to Speed Anti-Fraud Technology
text: WASHINGTON — A top executive of Target told a Senate committee on Tuesday that the company was accelerating plans to adopt a technology widely used in Europe but rare in the United States that reduces potential for credit card fraud, and lawmakers from both parties called on other businesses to do the same.

headline: Food Matters | Hot Dog!
text: From restaurants to bicycle-pushed carts, purveyors all over Paris are embracing the humble hot dog, elevating it to something original and unexpectedly stylish. At both of its 10th Arrondissement locations, Hutch Hotdog House serves all-chicken sausages blanketed with onion jam, homemade pickles and chili sauce. Custom-made franks, flavored mustards and Raclette give “le chien chaud” a gourmet twist at Little Fernand near the Porte Saint-Denis, while the organic all-beef dog entices an otherwise demure crowd at the new cocktail den Glass. Vegetarians can also get in on the action at Le Tricycle, a traveling cart specializing in meat-free dogs named after rappers (the Nate and the Snoop).

headline: Aston Martin Starts Recall Anew After Finding Counterfeit Material in Repair Pedal Assembly
text: After discovering that a supplier in China had used counterfeit material, Aston Martin said it would re-do a 5,000-vehicle recall issued because the accelerator pedal assembly could break. The automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration of the do-over in a report posted on the agency’s website.

headline: Activist Investor Takes Aim at Helen of Troy
text: Updated, 2:07 p.m. |

headline: An Unusual Partnership to Tackle Stubborn Diseases
text: The National Institutes of Health, 10 large drug companies and seven nonprofit organizations announced  an unconventional partnership on Tuesday intended to speed up development of drugs to treat Alzheimer’s disease, Type 2 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

headline: Christie’s Other Congestion Problem
text: Adding to his troubles over the monster traffic jams that his aides deliberately caused at the George Washington Bridge last year, New Jersey’s Governor Chris Christie is now facing more bad press about gridlock in his state. The problem, as more than 33,000 football fans are still grousing about days later, is that New Jersey’s transit system wasn’t really ready for the Super Bowl on Sunday night.

headline: Senate Passes Long-Stalled Farm Bill, With Clear Winners and Losers
text: WASHINGTON — No one was happier than Danny Murphy, a Mississippi soybean farmer with 1,500 acres, when the Senate on Tuesday passed a farm bill that expanded crop insurance and other benefits for agribusiness. “It’s a relief,” Mr. Murphy said.

headline: Navy Opens Inquiry Into Cheating in Reactor Training
text: WASHINGTON — The Navy said Tuesday that it had begun an investigation into whether senior enlisted sailors training on nuclear reactors had been cheating on written tests, adding to the list of recent military cheating scandals.

headline: Familiar Hotel Brands Expand in China
text: Chinese travelers are the biggest spenders when it comes to international tourism, according to the United Nations World Tourism Organization, and American hotels are pulling out all the stops to win them over, putting teakettles in the guest rooms, congee rice porridge on the menus and Mandarin speakers on staff.

headline: Drama League Fellowship to Support Female Writer-Directors
text: The Drama League, a New York organization that provides training and financial support to theater artists, is establishing a new fellowship for female writer-directors who are creating original work, league members announced on Monday night at their annual gala. The fellowship is named for Beatrice Terry, an alumna of the organization’s Directors Project who was an assistant or associate director on several Broadway shows including the Tony Award-winning musicals “Spring Awakening” and “Memphis.” Ms. Terry died in 2012 from cancer at the age of 52.

headline: His-and-Hers Jams, a New Cocktail Menu at the Dead Rabbit and More
text: To Savor: Macarons Arrive in SoHo, With a Little Company

headline: For Motorola Mobility, Third Place Was Far From Enough
text: New data from ComScore, the market research company, makes one thing very clear: In the brutal smartphone market, being No. 3 is not something to brag about.

headline: Easy Sheet Pan Chicken
text: Melissa Clark makes an entire family meal (crunchy chicken with broccoli rabe and sweet potatoes) on two simple sheet pans.

headline: Behold, the Sturdy Sheet Pan
text: Of all the fancy kitchen equipment in my prodigious collection — the copper gratin dishes, the pressurized siphon, the multifunctional immersion blender — it’s the humble sheet pans I reach for most often.

headline: In Yearlong Clash Over Herbalife, Innuendo Trumps Clarity
text: William A. Ackman, the founder of the hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management, announced his “big short” on Herbalife more than a year ago, and many are still unsure whether he’s right or wrong. You might think that is a problem, but for some of Herbalife’s investors, the truth doesn’t appear to matter much as they have been profiting from the wild swings in the stock price.

headline: Christopher Sieber Joins the Cast of ‘Matilda’
text: The Tony-nominated actor Christopher Sieber will return to Broadway to play the evil headmistress Agatha Trunchbull in “Matilda the Musical,” the show’s producers have announced. Mr. Sieber is to make his debut as the character on March 18.

headline: Annisa
text: Anita Lo’s Greenwich Village restaurant earns a third star.

headline: U.S. Spy Chief Says Assad Has Strengthened His Hold on Power
text: WASHINGTON — The country’s top intelligence official said Tuesday that President Bashar al-Assad’s hold on power in Syria had “strengthened” over the past year, and that he had benefited from a deal to abandon his chemical weapons arsenal.

headline: S.&P. Lowers Puerto Rico Debt to Junk Status
text: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | Standard & Poor’s downgraded the debt of Puerto Rico to junk status on Tuesday, intensifying a cash squeeze for the commonwealth, whose financial condition is of outsize importance to the rest of the United States because its debt is widely held by individual investors through mutual funds.

headline: 200 Prompts for Argumentative Writing
text: For a coming student contest in which teenagers are invited to write on an issue they care about, we have gathered a list of 200 writing prompts on a wide range of issues.

headline: Developer From Peru Has Eye on Detroit
text: DETROIT — It was late Friday afternoon before Labor Day weekend when Fernando Palazuelo reached the head of the line at the tax collection window of the treasurer’s office in Wayne County, Mich.

headline: Bodega Negra Opens a Branch in New York
text: Headliner

headline: How Many Non-Combatants Are Killed by Drones?
text: Adam Schiff, a Democratic congressman from California, urged the nation’s intelligence leaders today to get behind an important idea: The Obama administration, he said, should publish an annual report on American drone strikes, showing how many combatants and especially how many non-combatants are killed by unmanned aircraft each year.

headline: Michael Kors Is Now a Billionaire
text: A high-flying stock price has made Michael Kors rich. Just how rich? On Tuesday, the clothing designer became a billionaire.

headline: Hearing Its Own Drummer
text: I THINK THE NEWS is out that Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has become overrun by glassy condos and slapped-up “townhomes” harboring gentlemen with archaic facial hair patterns sustained by 10-course tasting menus festooned with twigs. But it was still jarring, and not in an artisanal-jam kind of way, to glimpse Chanel and Prada placards looming in an optician’s window just outside the Bedford Avenue L stop, that culturally freighted crossroads of the new youthquake. So SoHo, so soon.

headline: Listen Up | Singer-Songwriter Jenny Lewis’s Perfect New Single for ‘Girls’
text: The love-it-or-hate-it HBO series “Girls,” now in its third season, has had its share of memorable musical moments. The buried ’90s treasure “Steal My Sunshine” by Len made a hilarious comeback during a scene in Chris O’Dowd’s character’s luxury condo and Hannah all but launched the Swedish duo Icona Pop’s career when she let loose to their dance-floor anthem “I Love It.” This season, the “Girls” music team commissioned Jenny Lewis, the L.A.-based singer-songwriter and former frontwoman of the defunct L.A. indie band Rilo Kiley, to write a single, “Completely Not Me” — the crown jewel of the show’s new soundtrack album (which also includes tunes from Father John Misty, Lily Allen, Beck, Cat Power and others), out next week from Atlantic Records.

headline: On the Horizon: Bicentenary of Norway’s Constitution Day; New Languages From the Crowd
text: Bicentenary This year marks the 200th anniversary of the signing of the Norwegian Constitution at Eidsvoll, on May 17, 1814. Within Norway, the bicentenary is being celebrated with events throughout the year. In January, Queen Sonja visited the Norwegian Folk Museum to open, “1814-The Game for Denmark and Norway,” an exhibit that details the countries struggles for independence during the “Year of Miracles.” Visitors can also tour Eidsvoll House, which has been restored to look like as it might have when the constitution was signed there. The house opens Feb. 16, and tours run all year.

headline: Rethinking Blogs at The New York Times
text: After we moved our article pages to a new framework and platform, we did the same with our blogs. Scott Taylor, senior software engineer on the Blogs team, wrote about it. Below is an excerpt from a longer post on Scott’s personal blog.

headline: Former Rwandan Intelligence Chief Goes on Trial for 1994 Genocide
text: PARIS — In an unprecedented step, a French court opened a genocide trial on Tuesday against a former Rwandan intelligence chief in the first of what could be several prosecutions of former officials and others who fled Rwanda after the 1994 slaughter there.

headline: L. Stephen Hill
text: Mr. Hill, 50, is a founder and principal of Goldstein, Hill & West Architects, with Alan Goldstein and David West. The firm, which is based in New York and was founded in 2009, has focused mainly on residential design. The partners have worked on numerous projects, including Silver Towers, One Riverside Park and the Aldyn.

headline: Vignettes From a Much-Lauded Career
text: It wasn’t so long ago that the gifted, indefatigably prolific theater composer Michael John LaChiusa was regarded as a theatrical wunderkind destined to be a future king of Broadway. It hasn’t turned out that way. Mr. LaChiusa, 51, has had his successes but no blockbusters. A major impediment has been his refusal (or inability) to write the kind of snugly packaged pop tunes that are Broadway’s bread and butter. To which I say, more power to him; the form needs composers as talented as Mr. LaChiusa, who have the courage to sacrifice commerciality and go their own way.

headline: The Needles in the Monumental N.S.A. Haystack
text: The saga of Edward J. Snowden, the man whose leaked documents revealed the Orwellian dimensions of the National Security Agency, reads like a le Carré novel crossed with something by Kafka — at least it does in Luke Harding’s new book, “The Snowden Files.”

headline: Typing Into PDF Forms
text: Q. Why is it possible to type into some PDF forms and not in others? Is there any way to fill out all PDF forms on the computer without having to print them out?

headline: Japan Is a Land of Rising Hopes for Ski Jumping
text: NAYORO, Japan — The sound of cicadas and the smell of pine trees in the thick summer air were interrupted by the whoosh of ski jumpers in bodysuits hurling themselves off the 90-meter hill here in the northern reaches of Japan.

headline: With Technology’s Aid, Banks Squeeze Their Branches Into Smaller Locations
text: As machines do more, bank branches shrink.

headline: Keeping Her Passport Handy
text: Anita Lo has been the chef of Annisa since it opened almost 14 years ago, and summing up her style has not gotten any easier. Even she, when naming the cookbook she wrote with Charlotte Druckman, defined her style by what it is not. The title is “Cooking Without Borders.”

headline: A Blend of Folk and Filigree, Raucous and Dreamy
text: The Philadelphia Orchestra, led by its music director, Yannick Nézet-Séguin, paid a memorable visit to Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, four months after its scheduled performance at the hall’s opening gala was canceled because of a strike by stagehands. But there were no audible hisses when those stagehands wheeled out the Steinway grand for the program’s piano concerto.

headline: Teaching Just Wasn’t Right for Him, Head of Mexican Drug Cartel Says
text: Last Updated, Wednesday, 2:35 p.m. | In an interview with Britain’s Channel 4 News broadcast last week, Servando Gómez, the head of Mexico’s feared Knights Templar drug cartel, reflected on his transition from schoolteacher to organized crime boss. Teaching, he said, was “an honest job, but for me, with my hyperactive nature and aspirations, it wasn’t satisfying.”

headline: Netflix Signs for a Third Season of ‘House of Cards’
text: Even before the second season becomes available to viewers, producers of the web-streaming series “House of Cards” have completed a deal with Netflix for a third season of 13 episodes.

headline: Colleagues’ Work Part of Alfred Schnittke’s Anniversary Party
text: Many artists have works they disdain later in their careers, pieces created before their mature voice had emerged. For the 82-year-old Russian composer Sofia Gubaidulina, her “Fairytale Poem” is one such score.

headline: Affordability in Kensington, Brooklyn
text: Deirdre Lehn became aware of Kensington’s neighborliness as soon as she attended an open house. “We went to the open houses, and all the neighbors would come by, and folks were chatting with us and inviting us to come by for coffee,” Ms. Lehn said. “These were, like, people we didn’t know.”

headline: MoMA’s Proposal for Sculpture Garden Pleases and Riles
text: Peace and quiet can be hard to come by in the middle of Manhattan. Maybe, if the ice ever melts, you might balance a lunch burrito on your lap in the sunken plaza outside the McGraw-Hill Building. Or park yourself in a hotel lobby and pretend to be a guest.

headline: Philippine Leader Sounds Alarm on China
text: MANILA — President Benigno S. Aquino III called on Tuesday for nations around the world to do more to support the Philippines in resisting China’s assertive claims to the seas near his country, drawing a comparison to the West’s failure to support Czechoslovakia against Hitler’s demands for Czech land in 1938.

headline: New Inquiry on Sri Lanka Points to Possible War Crimes
text: GENEVA — Senior Sri Lankan government officials and military officers may bear criminal responsibility for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed during an offensive near the end of the island’s civil war, according to a new investigation that backs calls for an international inquiry into those events.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Luxe Sweatpants
text: Chalk it up to an increasingly casual workplace culture, the rise of the urban freelancer or the advent of the couch-to-dinner weekend wardrobe. Whatever the case, the old-school sweatpant, made modern with a slim cut and more refined fabrics, is now being heralded as the “new khaki.” Luxe versions of the stretch-waist pants are showing up on runways and in presentations in both Europe and New York, where the men’s shows continue this week. For his fall/winter 2014 collection, Michael Kors explained that he blended “New York City polish with the laid-back attitude of California,” and that he did away almost entirely with structured waistbands and belt loops. Made with double-faced cashmere or a more office-appropriate glen plaid, the newly refined track pant was the linchpin of Kors’s relaxed, elegant wardrobe. Meanwhile, Ralph Lauren introduced more sportswear styles under its Purple Label than ever before. A luxurious cashmere-knit jogging-style pant paired with a matching crew-neck sweater and trim topcoat stood in stark contrast to the nipped-waist suits that are at the heart of the tailored line, yet looked no less natty. And at Bottega Veneta, Tomas Maier paired belted coats, lightly tailored jackets and suede bombers with numerous iterations of the pull-on pant, from corduroy to cashmere, to signify his belief in this new trouser alternative.

headline: More Space for the Living and the Dead
text: A serendipitous juxtaposition of programming on PBS on Wednesday night reminds us just how long humans have been trying to squeeze more space out of urban environments. The ancient Romans knew something we apparently don’t: If you build downward for people who don’t much care about the view rather than upward for billionaires who do, you don’t have to worry about how to wash the windows.

headline: A Dancer’s Rare Grace Survives a Horrible Fate
text: As you watch grainy kinescope footage of dancers in a mirrored studio executing a pas de deux in the documentary biography “Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq,” it is almost as though you are beholding mythological deities who have alighted briefly on the earth. Here today, gone tomorrow, they are like rare birds, seldom glimpsed, who remind us of the evanescence of all things, most of all physical beauty and the casual grace of youth. Therein lies a primal attraction of ballet: its evocation of the ecstatic moment is as fleeting as it is haunting.

headline: Health Law Goals Face Antitrust Hurdles
text: With the midterm elections fast coming into focus, politics in Washington will remain consumed by health care for months to come.

headline: Jay and Dave, With Jerry in the Middle
text: The comic Jerry Seinfeld is a friend to both Jay Leno and David Letterman and has had them both on his web series, "Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee"

headline: AT&T Becomes First Major Advertiser to Protest Russia’s Antigay Law
text: AT&T has become the first major advertiser to come out against a measure outlawing “homosexual propaganda” that has led to protests aimed at the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, as well as the first to urge “others involved with the Olympic Games” to do the same.

headline: Circadian Clocks May Be Tuned to Vibrations, Too
text: In nature, the rising and setting of the sun help set an animal’s circadian clock, a part of the brain that regulates sleep and wakefulness. Fluctuations of light tell the body when to release melatonin, for example, or lower body temperature.

headline: N.E.A. Funds Benefit Both Rich and Poor, Study Finds
text: Ever since the late 1980s, when the performance artist Karen Finley started playing around with yams and chocolate, the National Endowment for the Arts has come under fire from some conservative lawmakers. Back then the agency was castigated for giving grants to provocative artists like Ms. Finley, whom some critics called obscene.

headline: On Silver Screen, a Bit of Gold
text: As the Sochi Olympics will remind the world again, there is a huge amount of human drama in the skiing, skating and snowboarding that seize the world’s attention every four years.

headline: De Blasio to Skip St. Patrick’s Day Parade; Cites Exclusion of Gay Groups
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Tuesday that he would not march in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade in Manhattan next month, citing the event’s longstanding tensions with gay and lesbian groups.

text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Army Recruitment Scam
text: Also on the Minute, a territorial dispute in the South China Sea and the effect of the Affordable Care Act on the full-time work force.

headline: The Ballad of Leno and Letterman, Told by Seinfeld
text: The link between the careers of Jay Leno and David Letterman is long and deep, and their personal relationship has often been fractious, sometimes warm, certainly competitive.

headline: Morgan Stanley Reaches $1.25 Billion Mortgage Settlement
text: Morgan Stanley has agreed to pay $1.25 billion to the Federal Housing Finance Agency to resolve claims that it sold shoddy mortgage securities to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

headline: U.N. Report Details Abuse of Children in Syrian War
text: UNITED NATIONS — United Nations investigators say in a new report that children in Syria have been sexually abused in government detention, recruited to fight with the opposition, tortured and used as civilian shields.

headline: President of BAM Will Leave Next Year
text: When Karen Brooks Hopkins first arrived at the Brooklyn Academy of Music more than three decades ago, it was considered a pioneering outpost for avant-garde theater, music and dance. Housed in a single Beaux-Arts building in what was then a gritty neighborhood, it struggled to attract theatergoers, some of whom would tell Ms. Hopkins they were more likely to travel to London than to Brooklyn to see a play.

headline: Polls Find Security Is Americans’ Top Olympic Concern
text: Just ahead of the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics on Friday, a plurality of Americans say it was a bad decision to hold the Games in Russia, with security concerns the top reason, a new Pew Research Center poll found.

headline: Tanaquil Le Clercq as Muse: Onstage, in Photographs and in a New Film
text: A couple of years ago, the magazine published a photo essay about Mildred and Richard Loving, the couple whose case led to the Supreme Court’s striking down miscegenation laws in 1967. The pictures appeared at the same time as an HBO documentary about the Lovings directed by Nancy Buirski. Now Buirski’s next documentary, “Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq,” is coming out. It opens tomorrow at the Film Society of Lincoln Center; later this month the Berlin International Film Festival will screen it as an Official Selection.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Central African Republic, Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: America’s Team? Yankees May Be Japan’s Team Instead
text: There was a pitcher in Japan in the 1950s and ’60s named Kazuhisa Inao who was so good that the popular saying at the time was God, Buddha, Inao, in deference to the pitcher’s almost otherworldly talent.

headline: With New App, Photos Become a Travel Guide
text: Applying snap judgments to snapshots, the new Jetpac City Guides for iPhones analyzes Instagram photos for commonalities to come up with top-10 lists of things like bars women love and coffee shops with popular latte art in 6,000 cities worldwide.

headline: With New Chief, Microsoft’s New Mantra Is ‘Innovation,’ Over and Over
text: You might remember a now-famous scene with Steven A. Ballmer, then the chief executive of Microsoft, walking on stage at a conference in 2006, sweat staining his armpits and chest while he passionately bellowed, “Developers! Developers! Developers! Developers! Developers!”

text: Recent Sale

headline: 3 Companies Fined for Mislabeling Crude Oil in Rail Transit
text: Federal regulators said on Tuesday that they had fined three companies for mislabeling the type of crude oil they were transporting. The penalties — a total of $93,000 — were the first from surprise inspections begun after since a series of accidents in the last year underscored the hazard of transporting highly flammable oil by rail.

headline: Welcome Relief for Homeowners, Until the Tax Bill Arrives
text: Come tax time, JPMorgan Chase will be able to write off the $1.5 billion in debt relief it must give homeowners to satisfy the terms of a recent settlement.

headline: Pakistani Side Fails to Show Up at Taliban Peace Talks
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani government representatives failed to appear on Tuesday for the scheduled start of peace talks with the Taliban, forcing the postponement of the talks and drawing a sharp rebuke from the militants’ representatives.

text: To the Editor:

headline: A Crusade for the Financially Devastated
text: PROCTER & GAMBLE’S more memorable cause-marketing programs include dispatching a Tide-branded mobile laundromat, a Duracell mobile charging trailer and free-battery distribution center, and Charmin mobile restrooms to areas devastated by hurricanes and wildfires.

headline: Divided Korean Families
text: To the Editor:

headline: More Secure Credit Cards
So Far, Extreme Park Is Proving Extremely Perilous
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — It was a harrowing trip across the finish line, a rag-doll maneuver of somersaults and twisted limbs and a face-plant into the snow. “Finish,” the tall plastic marker read, with the skier’s body wrapped around its base.

headline: Smoking in Jail
text: To the Editor:

headline: Just Say No
text: President Obama indicated in his State of the Union address last week that he will exercise his admittedly limited executive powers in this “year of action.” Though most of the mild proposals he made are welcome, one still wonders why he doesn’t say “no” more often. Two examples where this would be useful are the farm bill and the proposed extension of the Keystone XL pipeline, both of which will reach his office for decisions soon — the farm bill, perhaps, as you read this. (The Senate passed the bill Tuesday afternoon, so its next stop is Obama’s desk.)

headline: WellPoint, a Onetime Critic of Health Law, May Yet Profit
text: INDIANAPOLIS — In the midst of the sweeping transformation taking place in health insurance, the company that served as an illustration of why an overhaul was necessary could end up benefiting most from the new federal health care law.

headline: Tennessee Governor Urges 2 Free Years of Community College and Technical School
text: Public colleges have sharply raised their prices since the 1990s in the face of declining state support, but a plan by Tennessee’s governor to make two years of community college and technical school free for all students represents a striking reversal of that trend.

headline: The Third Intifada
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — For a while now I’ve wondered why there’s been no Third Intifada. That is, no third Palestinian uprising in the West Bank, the first of which helped to spur the Oslo peace process and the second of which — with more live ammunition from the Israeli side and suicide bombings from the Palestinian side — led to the breakdown of Oslo. You get many explanations from Palestinians: they’re too poor, too divided, too tired or that they realize these uprisings, in the end, did them more harm than good, especially the second. But being here, it’s obvious that a Third Intifada is underway. It’s the one that Israel always feared most — not an intifada with stones or suicide bombers, but one propelled by nonviolent resistance and economic boycott.

headline: In Texting Era, Crisis Hotlines Put Help at Youths’ Fingertips
text: The conversation began abruptly, with the anonymous teenager getting straight to the point: She had just told her family that she was really a boy trapped in a female body. “Now my family hates me,” she told a crisis counselor.

headline: Republicans Spar on Leaks and Surveillance, Underscoring Partisan Shake-up
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Tuesday offered sharply divergent views about secret government surveillance programs and the leaks that made them public, underscoring the unsettled nature of a political debate that has scrambled the usual partisan lines.

headline: German Paper Says U.S. Kept Tabs on Leader
text: BERLIN — American intelligence services monitored former Chancellor Gerhard Schröder beginning in 2002 and perhaps earlier, a leading German newspaper reported on Tuesday. Mr. Schröder, a Social Democrat, openly opposed the Bush administration’s developing plans to go to war in Iraq.

headline: Often Overlooked, Mancuso Is Prepared for Her Fourth Olympics
text: Which American woman has won the most Olympic ski racing medals?

headline: From Shadows to Citizenship
text: Does it make sense to impede citizenship to someone who is allowed to live and work in the United States?

headline: Michael Bastian: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: The Road Back: Frost’s Letters Could Soften a Battered Image
text: Few figures in American literature have suffered as strangely divided an afterlife as Robert Frost.

headline: New Boss at Microsoft, With Gates at His Side
text: SEATTLE — Bill Gates is back in the building at Microsoft.

headline: The Two Silicon Valleys: One of Haves, One of Have-Nots
text: Silicon Valley is booming. Job growth is so strong that the recession is a distant memory. Average incomes are up, and the levitation of technology stocks and a pipeline of initial public offerings promise more wealth to come.

headline: Long After Soviet Fall, Russian Pairs Climb Back Up
text: When, as a teenager, Maxim Trankov moved in 1999 from the Ural Mountains to St. Petersburg, he had great ambition as a Russian pairs skater but little money for food or an apartment.

headline: Schools Official Investigating Teacher Exchanged Explicit Texts With Her, Report Finds
text: A detective for the New York City Education Department who was checking into accusations of misconduct by a teacher in Coney Island, Brooklyn, instead engaged in a sexually explicit phone relationship with her, according to a report released on Tuesday.

headline: An Investigation Into a Sexual Text Messaging Relationship in the Education Department
text: The report says a man investigating allegations of misconduct by a teacher had a sexually explicit text messaging relationship with the teacher.

headline: An Aggressive Climate Initiative
text: The Obama administration announced on Monday a proposed Environmental Protection Agency regulation to reduce the nation’s carbon pollution.

headline: Where N.S.A. Kept Watch in Cold War, Artists Now Find Refuge
text: BERLIN — Before Christopher McLarren, a United States Army veteran, takes a tour group up the dark stairs to the highest reaches of the former Field Station Berlin, a crumbling Cold War listening post, he warns the participants to stick together and watch where they step.

headline: On Top of Devil's Mountain
text: Teufelsberg, or Devil’s Mountain, includes an abandoned Cold War N.S.A. listening post in Berlin that has evolved into a de facto art installation.

headline: Google Gives Eric Schmidt $100 Million in Stock
text: Google said on Tuesday that it gave its chairman, Eric E. Schmidt, $100 million in restricted stock units — and for good measure, added $6 million in cash to be awarded on Valentine’s Day.

headline: Saving Ukraine
text: The United States and Europe may finally be ready to put some real emergency aid on the table as part of an effort to resolve the political crisis in Ukraine and to tie the country more closely to the West. Without such an offer of financial support, Russia will continue to have leverage to bully Ukraine into its geopolitical orbit. The standoff over economic policy and whether Ukraine will ally with Europe or Russia is more than two months old and has led to violent protests in which at least six people were killed.

headline: Lawyers in Terrorism Case Seek Access to 9/11 Suspect
text: Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, might not seem like the ideal witness to present at trial.

headline: Overselling Testosterone, Dangerously
text: A large study has found substantial risks in prescribing testosterone to middle-age and older men for a variety of ailments. One part of the study found that testosterone doubled the risk of cardiovascular disease in more than 7,000 men who were 65 years old or older, essentially confirming findings in previous studies. The other part found that testosterone almost tripled the risk of heart attacks in a group of more than 48,000 middle-age men with previous histories of heart disease. The harm in both cases occurred within 90 days of receiving the prescription.

headline: Title for the Seahawks Is a Triumph for the Profile of Yoga
text: The Seahawks’ Super Bowl victory sent happy repercussions through the expected constituencies — namely, Seahawks fans, the anti-Manning crowd, proponents of the color green — but it also lit up a community not usually excited about football: yogis.

headline: Freeing Workers From the Insurance Trap
text: The Congressional Budget Office estimated on Tuesday that the Affordable Care Act will reduce the number of full-time workers by 2.5 million over the next decade. That is mostly a good thing, a liberating result of the law. Of course, Republicans immediately tried to brand the findings as “devastating” and stark evidence of President Obama’s health care reform as a failure and a job killer. It is no such thing.

headline: High School Maniacal
text: WASHINGTON — High school never ends.

headline: On the Luge, Safety Built Into Swerves
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — On the day that the Winter Olympics opened in Vancouver, British Columbia, four years ago, a luger named Nodar Kumaritashvili was killed on a training run. Traveling almost 90 miles per hour at Whistler Sliding Centre, Kumaritashvili, a 21-year-old from the Republic of Georgia, lost control of his sled near the bottom of the course and was thrown from the track. He died after striking a pole.

headline: U.S. Representative to Syrian Opposition Is Retiring
text: WASHINGTON — The United States’ top representative to the Syrian opposition, Robert S. Ford, is planning to retire from the State Department and is expected to leave his post soon, department officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Warming to Women on the Ice
text: On the ice, the teenage hockey player Anna Shokhina is like a grandmaster hunched over a chessboard, able to see several moves ahead through her curtain bangs. Introduced to the sport at 5 by a coach who proffered a stick and a pair of skates and invited her to join his boys’ team, Shokhina was blind in the beginning.

headline: On Connecticut Ice, a Proving Ground for Olympic Hopefuls
text: As ice hockey hotbeds in the United States go, the three M’s — Michigan, Massachusetts and Minnesota — lead the way. Maine, upstate New York and North Dakota also have been prominent feeder spots.

headline: Good Night, John-Boy
text: Administrivial Will Shortz Follow Up! If you missed the Will Shortz interview on MSNBC, you can watch it here.

headline: Terrorism and Tension for Sochi, Not Sports and Joy
text: SOCHI, Russia — One of my neighbors who doesn’t follow the news stopped me a few days before I flew to the Winter Olympics. She was excited to hear that I was going to Russia, and told me how lucky I was.

headline: A British Doctor’s Death in Syria, and His Mother’s Quest for Justice
text: GENEVA — Determined to find her son, Fatima Khan flew to Damascus from Britain last summer, traveling alone for the first time in her 57 years. A surgeon, he had disappeared months before while treating patients in war-ravaged northern Syria.

headline: E.P.A. Staff Struggling to Create Pollution Rule
text: WASHINGTON — In marathon meetings and tense all-day drafting sessions, dozens of lawyers, economists and engineers at the Environmental Protection Agency are struggling to create what is certain to be a divisive but potentially historic centerpiece of President Obama’s climate change legacy.

headline: Amid Trade Rumors, Callahan Propels Rangers
text: The Rangers rolled to their fourth straight victory Tuesday with a smooth 5-1 demolition of the Colorado Avalanche at Madison Square Garden, making it all the more striking that they would consider trading Ryan Callahan.

headline: Government Said to Undervalue Coal Leases
text: DENVER — The federal coal leasing program run by the Bureau of Land Management operates without sufficient oversight or a consistent means of ensuring that fair prices are paid for the leases, a report released on Tuesday said.

headline: Four People Arrested as Part of Inquiry Into Hoffman’s Death
text: Four people were arrested in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday evening with more than 350 bags of heroin as part of the investigation into the death of the actor Philip Seymour Hoffman, a law enforcement official said.

headline: Teachers’ Push for Back Pay May Pinch New York City
text: As New York’s 152 municipal unions line up to press Mayor Bill de Blasio for raises and back pay, his administration and the powerful teachers’ union are reaching the final stages of a largely overlooked, drawn-out battle that could prove enormously expensive to the city — potentially putting at risk its ability to balance the budget.

headline: A Diverse Landscape
text: The crest of the Caucasus divides Europe and Asia. The region is home to dozens of ethnic groups.

headline: Slovene Skier Tries to Shake a Puzzling Cold Spell
text: KRANJSKA GORA, Slovenia — Alpine skiing has long been the sport that best defined tiny Slovenia, whether it was during its years as part of Yugoslavia or in the go-go years after independence in 1991.

headline: Don’t Know These Olympic Athletes? You Will
text: Although the Olympics sometimes crown established stars, they are just as often a coming-out party for athletes who emerge as national heroes with unexpected performances. And the title of breakthrough star of the Games is often judged through a nationalistic lens. In 2002, Americans were thrilled by Sarah Hughes’s unexpected figure skating gold medal; Croatians were stunned by Janica Kostelic’s three Alpine golds; and China celebrated its first Winter Games gold, by the short-track speedskater Yang Yang. Here are some of the candidates to emerge as the darlings of their nations in Sochi, Russia.

headline: California: Officers Faulted in Mistaken Shooting
text: Eight Los Angeles police officers violated Police Department policy when they fired on two unarmed women in a pickup truck last February during the hunt for Christopher Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer accused of killing four people, a civilian oversight board said Tuesday. Police Chief Charlie Beck will determine how to discipline the eight, who have been removed from field duty since the episode. Chief Beck said actions could range “from extensive retraining to termination.” The women were delivering newspapers when officers mistook their truck for Mr. Dorner’s vehicle, and fired more than 100 rounds. Last year the city agreed to pay them $4.2 million. Chief Beck said that although he sympathized with the officers, he could not excuse their decision to open fire. “This was a tragic cascade of circumstance that led to an inaccurate conclusion by the officers,” he said.

headline: Whose Turkey Is It?
text: It is still a marvel to behold Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s self-confidence, even after 11 years of his rule. In recent weeks, a new poster featuring Turkey’s prime minister has appeared throughout Istanbul, on highway billboards and mass transit. Wearing his usual dark suit, Erdogan looks to be in purposeful motion, like an action hero. Two large words in block letters, SAGLAM IRADE, Turkish for “Iron Will,” accompany him. Surely some of his supporters appreciate this evocation of 1930s-era masculinity, but for others, it must feel like an invasion of personal space. The enormous billboards intensify the claustrophobia that many Turks have felt for years: that Erdogan is everywhere, in every tree or open space sacrificed for a building, in every traffic jam, in every newspaper column and pro-government tweet and call to prayer. The poster, which a group of his supporters claims to have put up, begs to be defaced, and Turks have torn at it or covered it with new slogans: “Iron Fascist,” “Iron Corruption,” “Iron Enemy of the People.”

headline: Add a Little Turf to the Surf
text: I don’t subscribe to the belief that everything is better with bacon, but small amounts of meat do often improve many dishes — even those with fish. While there are plenty of classic fish stews that don’t use meat for flavoring, including bouillabaisse, there are also many that do. (Clam chowder, anyone?) Think about it: When you’re making stew, everything is fair game.

headline: The Find | Studio Services
text: After achieving success on the West Coast as one half of the furniture design duo Meier/Ferrer, Charlie Ferrer has branched out on his own and opened a meticulously curated Manhattan showroom that also doubles as his one-bedroom apartment. The 32-year-old has pooled pieces by a number of behind-the-scenes talents, like the sought-after industrial designer Billy Cotton and the lighting expert Kacper Dolatowski, both of whose work had only been available to decorators seeking custom commissions. The handmade designs Ferrer displays, in a range of materials from brass to oak to plaster, feel classic yet current. “I don’t like to call it a showroom, which feels static,” Ferrer says. “It’s really more of a studio, an active place where artists refine, resolve and share their ideas.”

headline: Liberals, Obamacare and Work
text: So far, nearly all of the left-of-center responses to the latest C.B.O. projections on Obamacare and workforce participation have emphasized the upside of the downward trend — the fact that what we’re seeing is just the end of job lock in action, which gives parents the freedom to cut their hours, near-retirees the chance to stop working a job they hate a little early, and so on down a sympathetic list.  “If Obamacare really does cause millions of people to voluntarily leave full-time employment,” Matt Yglesias writes in a representative piece, “that shows us how much avoidable suffering the earlier system was causing,” and you can find roughly similar arguments from Jonathan Cohn, Jonathan Chait, and others too numerous to name.

headline: As Minimum Wages Rise, Businesses Grapple With Consequences
