Even before the increase, Ms. Riley, who owns Gramma’s School House Childcare and Learning Center in Cinnaminson, had been operating on the razor’s edge.

headline: A Domino Theory for Marriage
text: Matchmaking is a dicey endeavor, and not simply because of potential guilt or awkwardness if the pairing doesn’t take. Donald Margulies explored more complex ramifications in his Pulitzer Prize-winning drama “Dinner With Friends,” which is being given a revival by the Roundabout Theater Company. In the play, one couple long ago helped two friends get together and the four were inseparable for years. But one marriage eventually shatters, and Mr. Margulies, instead of focusing on what went wrong, steers our attention to some collateral damage: the surviving couple’s contentment begins to fray in the aftermath.

headline: The Beatles in the U.S., 50 Years On
text: I can still remember the first time I heard a Beatles song. It was the fall of 1964, my second year in an American school after my family moved back from overseas, and I was standing on the corner of 64th street and First Avenue with my friend Larry Campbell. I had a brand new, red, plastic transistor radio, and he tuned it to WABC AM and “Love Me Do” came on the air. The soundtrack of my life changed at that moment, with The Beatles becoming the recurring and dominant theme.

headline: Acrostic
text: Acrostic puzzle for February 9, 2014

headline: Acrostic Answer
text: Acrostic answer for February 9, 2014

headline: Giving Up the Ultimate Bachelor Pad
text: Before he moved to New York two years ago, Brad Chatellier had been living out of a suitcase. For months, he had traveled the world and pursued wildlife photography.

headline: Todd Lodwick to Carry U.S. Flag at Opening Ceremony in Sochi
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Todd Lodwick, who will be competing in his sixth Olympics, was named the United States’ flag-bearer for Friday’s opening ceremony at the Sochi Olympics.

headline: Architect Named to Transform Courtyard at MoMA PS1
text: Every summer, an emerging architect gets the chance to transform the outdoor courtyard at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City and, in the process, gets put on the map as a talent worthy of attention.

headline: Can This Business Survive a Hike in the Minimum Wage?
text: As discussed in an article we have just published, Dolores Riley, along with every other employer in New Jersey, woke up on New Year’s Day to a new minimum wage: $8.25 an hour, up from $7.25.

headline: LEDs Change Thinking About the Light Bulb
text: Lights are no longer just for lighting.

headline: Times May Publish Response From Woody Allen on Dylan Farrow’s Accusations
text: Woody Allen has asked for, and may get, a chance to respond — in an Op-Ed piece in The Times — to a recent column and blog by Nicholas Kristof in which the filmmaker’s adopted daughter detailed her memories of his sexually abusing her.

headline: Subway Strike Hobbles London, Underground and Above
text: LONDON — A strike on the London Underground crippled much of the city’s transportation network on Wednesday, disrupting the plans of millions of travelers and forcing commuters to cram into overcrowded buses and trains or walk or cycle to work.

headline: Russia Blocks Yogurt Bound for U.S. Athletes
text: The relationship between the United States and Russia is deeply strained, with recent disagreements over weighty matters like the Syrian conflict, arms control, human rights and the granting of asylum to Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who has leaked troves of documents detailing the government’s eavesdropping programs.

headline: Gallery | The Stars of New York’s Old Downtown Scene, Like You’ve Never Seen Them Before
text: Three years ago, the French-born, New York-based photographer, stylist and designer Maripol shared a secret box with her assistant, Adèle Jancovici. It was full of intimate Polaroids she’d taken in the ’70s and ’80s of herself, lovers and friends. “Don’t tell anyone,” she said. But when Jancovici founded Le Livre Art Publishing in 2011, she knew she wanted to make those photos the subject of the company’s first release. “I’m not good at keeping secrets,” she admits. “Maripola X,” a collection of approximately 171 Polaroids, 69 of her poems and a bonus CD with two of her songs, will be released in a limited edition of 600 signed and numbered copies on Feb. 7 with a signing at Bookmarc.

headline: And Now For Some Good News
text: Gail Collins: David, I thought we’d go rogue today and talk about things we think President Obama is doing well. Unless, of course, you have a more pressing topic.

headline: App Smart: Finding Love
text: As Valentine’s Day approaches, smartphone apps can play a part in finding love, celebrating love and sharing things love-connected.

headline: Sweet Ways to Romance Your Valentine
text: Valentine’s Day is near and love is in the air. This ancient love fest goes back centuries, but it has gone high tech in recent years. In 2014, this means your smartphone apps can play a part in finding love, celebrating love and sharing things love-connected.

headline: A.I.G. Seeks to Delay Bank of America Mortgage Settlement
text: The American International Group is continuing its quest to upend an $8.5 billion settlement between Bank of America and a group of mortgage securities investors.

headline: Billie Jean King Won’t Join U.S. Olympic Delegation
text: WASHINGTON — Billie Jean King is no longer scheduled to join the presidential delegation to the Olympics in Sochi, Russia, the White House announced Wednesday. King cited the failing health of her mother, Betty Moffitt, who is 91 and lives in Arizona, in her decision to stay behind.

headline: Zell Backs Tom Perkins’s Arguments About Class Warfare
text: The Silicon Valley venture capitalist Tom Perkins drew no small amount of criticism for drawing parallels between attacks on San Francisco’s wealthy class and Kristallnacht, a comparison for which he has since sort of apologized.

headline: An Invisible Message from Jane Austen?
text: Objects associated with Jane Austen tend to draw intense scrutiny, whether it’s the turquoise ring bought at auction by the singer Kelly Clarkson or the proto-paper clips used to attach the manuscript pages of her abandoned novel “The Watsons.”

headline: Commuters Share Woes of Transport Chaos in London
text: Commuters documented the chaos of getting to work on Wednesday, the first day of a strike on the London Underground that disrupted service for millions of people.

headline: Inviting a Picky Eater Into the Kitchen Pays Off
text: So far, changing this family’s picky eating habits has been easier than expected.

headline: ‘Philomena’s’ Audience With the Pope
text: The story of Philomena Lee — which began in the 1950s when she was a teenager forced by nuns to give up her child for adoption and includes an Academy Award-nominated film, “Philomena,” based on her search for her son decades later — can now add one more chapter.

headline: Classical Playlist: Andrew Parrott, Jeroen Van Veen, Ildar Abdrazakov and More
text: MONTEVERDI: ‘L’Orfeo’Taverner Consort and Players; directed by Andrew Parrott(Avie; 2 CDs)There are many fine recordings of Monteverdi’s landmark “L’Orfeo,” the first great opera, composed in 1607. A superb new recording features the distinguished conductor Andrew Parrott, directing the impressive singers and period-instrument performers of the Taverner Consort & Players. This account is exceptional for its fluidity, elegance and tenderness. The cast is headed by the poignant tenor Charles Daniels in the title role. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: What Made Me | Rachel Comey
text: The fashion designer talks about the cool teenagers she observed growing up, her early days in New York City and a very special gift her grandmother gave her over the course of many years.

headline: Pussy Riot Members Take Tour to New York
text: Two young women from the Russian punk group Pussy Riot said Wednesday that their 21-month incarceration in Russia’s penal system for having staged a political protest in a Moscow cathedral had emboldened them to speak out more forcefully against President Vladimir V. Putin, partly because of the global support they received.

headline: Elton John Plans Animated Film of ‘Technicolor Dreamcoat’
text: LOS ANGELES — Elton John on Wednesday said that his movie production company had acquired the film rights to “Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat” and planned to make a feature-length animated musical.

headline: Iraqi Tribes to Take Lead in Falluja Fight, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Iraqi Army is planning to cordon off a key Sunni city now occupied by jihadists so that Sunni tribes can lead the mission to secure it one neighborhood at a time, a senior State Department official told Congress on Wednesday.

headline: French-Canadian Style in Portneuf
text: A three-bedroom French-Canadian-style home, built in 1820, is on the market for $493,993.

headline: House Hunting in ... Quebec
text: A RESTORED FRENCH-CANADIAN-STYLE HOME IN QUEBEC

headline: What Tim Duncan Deserves, but Never Seems to Receive
text: We know what N.B.A. All-Star voting has typically been: a chance for fans to participate in the selection process for a showcase. No registration is required to prove that one knows Kobe Bryant from Krusty the Clown. It’s a popularity contest that cannot be taken seriously.

headline: What Made Me | Rachel Comey, Fashion Designer
text: Over the last 12 years, the designer Rachel Comey has built a cult following for her distinctive prints,  feminine dresses and signature jumpsuits, not to mention the personal relationships she has fostered with some of her most loyal fans. In the first installment of “What Made Me,” a new T video series that explores the influences and life experiences that shape creative figures, Comey talks about the cool teenagers she observed growing up in Connecticut, her early days in New York City and a very special gift her grandmother gave her over the course of many years. Comey, who plans to open her first boutique in SoHo this spring, will show her fall 2014 collection tonight in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: First the Doughnuts, Then the Debates
text: A shout-out to whoever brought the brownies to “Beertown.” They were tasty, as were the butter cookies. I didn’t try the powdered doughnuts or the cake — I was busy getting my souvenir T-shirt — though they looked a bit too sweet.

headline: A Report’s Real Message: It Wasn’t About Health Care
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: New Recordings Made the Old-Fashioned Way
text: It started off as a way to put an unusual acquisition to use. In 2010, Alex Steyermark, a director and music supervisor for films, and Lavinia Jones Wright, a music journalist, found a couple of Presto Model K8 recording machines, and though these 78-r.p.m. direct–to-disc recorders are generally regarded as antiques, of relatively low utility in these days of digital sound, they decided to buy them.

headline: No, ‘Obamacare’ Isn’t Killing 2 Million Jobs
text: Opponents of the Affordable Care Act yesterday seized on a Congressional Budget Office report on the labor market, claiming it indicated that health reform would “kill” 2 million jobs. Actually, as our editorial on the subject explained, the C.B.O. predicted a reduction in the number of full-time workers. That may sound like a distinction without a difference, but it’s not. “Job-killing” implies layoffs; whereas the report found that many workers would choose to leave their positions — because they no longer have to depend on their employers for health insurance.

headline: From ‘Breaking Bad’ to Broadway
text: Bryan Cranston visits the New York Times photo archive in preparation for his role as President Lyndon B. Johnson in the Broadway play “All the Way.”

headline: Presidential Chemistry
text: With his rich baritone hinting of the American West and craggy handsome looks, Bryan Cranston seems custom built to play outsize heartland characters. Where was he, you wonder, when Sam Shepard was writing “Buried Child” and “True West”? Even at his most relaxed, when he leans in and taps your knee to drive home a point, you don’t want to be caught spacing out.

headline: The Gun Report: February 5, 2014
text: Researchers at Chicago’s Cook County Hospital began screening victims of urban trauma—gunshot wounds, stabbings and other violent crimes—for post-traumatic stress disorder in 2011. While they expected to find some cases, they were shocked at just how many: 42 percent of the 307 patients surveyed had signs of the disorder. Patients with gunshot wounds were 13 times as likely as those with falls and twice as likely as those in a car accident to test positive for PTSD.

headline: Lazard Swims With the Big Fish
text: Lazard has put its feet firmly in the big boys’ camp. The advisory and asset management firm didn’t just make progress on financial targets that its chief executive, Kenneth M. Jacobs, set two years ago. Its bankers also goosed revenue in the second half of the year. That makes Lazard look more like Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase than smaller rivals like Evercore Partners and Greenhill.

headline: Citadel Defied a Market Slump in January
text: In a dismal month for the stock market, one big hedge fund company in Chicago managed to record gains.

headline: Orley: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: Hurdles Ahead for Beckham and M.L.S. in Miami
text: MIAMI — The soccer star David Beckham delivered a long-awaited but in many ways provisional commitment to Miami on Wednesday when he confirmed it as the future home of a Major League Soccer expansion team that he will own — alongside partners not yet named — and run.

headline: What’s Happening off the Runway During New York Fashion Week
text: New York Fashion Week begins today, and out-of-towners and locals alike are making their final preparations for another season of back-to-back shows and snow-covered streets. Here, a guide to surviving (and enjoying) the festivities.

headline: CBO: ACA OK
text: What with the fuss over the CBO estimates of employment effects of health reform — Appendix C — everyone seems to have overlooked Appendix B, on the reform’s effects in doing what it was supposed to do: cover the uninsured. How has the disastrous initial rollout affected CBO’s projections about reform’s near future?

headline: Jack Butler, a Top Bankruptcy Lawyer, Will Move to Hilco
text: One of the bankruptcy bar’s biggest names is planning to leave the law to take up a different perch in the world of restructuring.

headline: Economists Sound the Alarm on Deflation in Europe
text: PARIS — Whether or not Mario Draghi and his European Central Bank colleagues plan to do anything about it at the monthly meeting Thursday, many economists are sounding the alarm. It is time, they say, to act defensively against the danger of deflation.

headline: Germany’s Clean-Energy Plan Faces Resistance to Power Lines
text: BERLIN — Germany’s resolve to embrace a clean-energy future may soon face another test of not-in-my-backyard public resistance.

headline: For Seattle’s Celebration, Russell Wilson Is an Unofficial M.V.P.
text: Russell Wilson was the most valuable player on Sunday when Seattle routed Denver to win the Super Bowl. Wilson did not win the actual award — that honor went to one of his teammates, linebacker Malcolm Smith, who returned an interception for a touchdown and also recovered a fumble.

headline: 3 Arrests, but Violin Is Not Recovered
text: Two men and a woman have been arrested in the recent theft of the Stradivarius violin played by the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra, Milwaukee police officials announced Wednesday. But the instrument, which dates from 1715 and is valued at $5 million, is still missing.

headline: Instagram Envy Chain: Sochi Edition
text: This year’s Olympic Games in Sochi, Russia, have come under some criticism for their expense and expansiveness, so I wanted to see how Russian photojournalists were covering Sochi on their Instagram accounts, given that Russian authorities have apparently tried to police the types of images to come out of the area. Time for another Instagram envy chain!

headline: European Official Takes Measured Tone on Ukraine Aid
text: KIEV, Ukraine — On a visit to Ukraine to try to prod the country’s embattled president and his opponents into resolving a volatile standoff, Europe’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, said Wednesday that a package of economic assistance was in the works but dampened hopes of a sudden infusion of cash.

headline: An Italian Hotel Will Be a Guest Star in California
text: Amalfi Coast cuisine and style will merge with those of Los Angeles from Feb. 19 to 26, when Shutters on the Beach in Santa Monica, Calif., will host Le Sirenuse, the hotel in Positano, Italy.

headline: CBS Will Broadcast Thursday Night Games
text: CBS decided that carrying Sunday afternoon N.F.L. games, playoff matchups and, every third year, a Super Bowl was not enough. So it announced Wednesday that it would carry eight Thursday night games in 2014 on a one-year contract that was believed to be worth at least $250 million.

headline: When Love Hits, It Can Really Send You Reeling
text: “Almost, Maine,” that darling of regional theaters, now back in New York, is basically a higher-concept and more clever version of Hollywood hits like “Love Actually“ and “Valentine’s Day.” But this rom-com leans on shrewd writing rather than star power in its nine interlocking love stories, all happening in the same New England town on the same moonless night.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Is the Soundtrack of the Season
text: The Grammy Awards last week brought expected sales gains for some of the night’s big stars, like Lorde and Daft Punk. But the top seller on Billboard’s album chart this week has nothing to do with the Grammys: the soundtrack to “Frozen,” an animated Disney film, earned its fourth No. 1 with 94,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Study of Drug for Blood Clots Caused a Stir, Records Show
text: The makers of the blood-thinning drug Pradaxa were so worried that an internal research paper would damage drug sales that some employees not only pressured the author to revise it, but suggested it should be quashed altogether, according to newly unsealed legal documents.

headline: Below the Line: Scoring ‘Gravity’
text: The previous film scores by the British composer Steven Price have included action comedies like Edgar Wright’s “World’s End” and Joe Cornish’s “Attack the Block.” The music often competed with the busy sounds of action. But his latest composition, for Alfonso Cuarón’s space thriller “Gravity,” is frequently competing with silence, or the voice of its main character Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock).

headline: Clip: 'The Lego Movie'
text: A scene from the film directed by Chris Miller and Phil Lord.

headline: Google Appoints Its Most Senior Woman to Run YouTube
text: The most senior woman at Google, Susan Wojcicki, who has been a senior vice president of advertising and commerce, is changing jobs at the company to run YouTube.

headline: South by Southwest Announces Midnight Slate
text: This year, South by Southwest audiences in Austin, Tex., will witness a frightful forest creature, a killer loose at a musical theater camp and yet one more teenager who has sold her soul to the devil. It’s another installment of the festival’s Midnighters program, which organizers announced Wednesday.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Michael Bastian Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Rebecca Smeyne.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Central African Republic, South Sudan, Pakistan and New York.

headline: Missing Sprite Leaves Only Her Shadow
text: Joyce Carol Oates, now in her mid-70s, is the author of some 140 books — approximately two a year from the moment she was born. I half expect someday to learn that she kept a real-time journal of her eviction from the birth canal.

headline: A Singular Artist Is Staking His Claim
text: At a certain point, it all comes down to voice. The story hip-hop has often told about itself is that it’s a game of lyrical one-upmanship, an ecosystem of artistes looking for words others couldn’t possibly use better. But just as often — more often — it’s a runway show of vocal eccentricity. Words, and how they’re arranged, take a back seat to how they’re delivered, the fresh paint on the tired old car.

headline: Early Start to Upfronts, as ‘The Real’ Cast Meets Advertisers
text: Upfront Nation, rejoice. It is that time again, when purveyors of video programming on television and online woo marketers and agencies to spend advertising dollars on commercial time ahead of the coming season.

headline: Even the Dancers Huddle for Warmth
text: All dancers, but in particular those devoted to ballet, spend their lives in front of mirrors. I’m so glad they can’t see themselves in “Bal de Couture,” a dismal Peter Martins creation that dates to New York City Ballet’s 2012 fall gala, with costumes by Valentino. Sadly, it wasn’t, as Tuesday’s program promised, a “Scenic Delight.”

headline: Coca-Cola to Buy 10% Stake in Green Mountain Coffee
text: Coca-Cola agreed on Wednesday to buy a 10 percent stake in Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, as it seeks to cement ties with the fast-growing coffee company.

headline: User Growth for Twitter Starts to Slow, and Stock Dips
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter has finally acknowledged what any newcomer could have told the company within five minutes of signing up: The messaging service is too hard to use.

headline: Toward a Kingdom Without Kitsch
text: The colorful blocks and cheerful figures of the Lego world have entertained generation after generation of children worldwide and remain a source of artistic expression for adults, too. Now, they’ve been assembled for the first time in a full-length feature film.

headline: Your Best Selfie
text: A test of four top smartphones to find out which forward-facing camera takes the best selfie.

headline: Narcissist’s Dream: Selfie-Friendly Phone
text: “Selfie” was Oxford Dictionaries’ word of the year in 2013. And selfies are powerful business; #me is the third-most-common tag on Instagram, appended to more than 184 million photos, according to the app’s Web viewer, Webstagram. (Numbers 1 and 2 are #love and #instagood.)

headline: You’re Who? Not Even Close
text: With the alighting of fashion’s air-smooching society, this week’s tempest of runway shows, private dinners and after-parties offers endless opportunities for gate crashers seeking social validation and free vodka. But prospective infiltrators beware: the sentinels of such entry points have added new weapons to their defensive arsenal.

headline: Qatari Court Rejects U.S. Couple’s Request to Return Home
text: DOHA, Qatar — An American couple standing trial on charges they starved their 8-year-old adopted African daughter to death in Qatar last year were dealt a setback on Wednesday when a court denied their request for permission to visit their two other adopted children, who are in the United States.

headline: A Last Centennial Tribute to Britten, in Five Songs
text: Benjamin Britten’s centennial year ended on Dec. 31. But 2013 brought few tributes to him lovelier than that delivered on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall by the mezzo-soprano Sasha Cooke.

headline: With El-Erian Leaving, Pimco Says It Is ‘Better’
text: Wall Street was stunned when Mohamed A. El-Erian announced last month that he would step down as chief executive and co-chief investment officer of Pimco, the giant asset manager where he was considered the heir apparent.

headline: Ballads With a Big Dose of Melodrama
text: When a voraciously needy performer stirs up an audience by wringing the last drop of melodrama from a song, it’s known in the trade as schmacting. Audiences tend to embrace such shameless hamming. And on Thursday evening, the Broadway veteran Michele Lee, who is 71 but looks two decades younger and has stamina and enthusiasm to burn, schmacted up a storm at 54 Below, where she appeared with a pop quintet directed by Ron Abel.

headline: Channeling the Style and Emotional Heat of a Tuneful Era
text: Whatever happened to uncomplicated male passion in pop music? That question nagged at me during John Lloyd Young’s nostalgic concert of rock and R&B ballads at Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening.

headline: You Can Run, but Don’t Hide These Shoes
text: Sneakers have never been more chic. At the couture shows in Paris last month, first Dior and then Chanel showed spring confections with sneakers, albeit bedazzled ones. At Chanel, every model strode the runway in sneakers embellished with lace, tweed, python and pearls. It may be a stretch to think that Jennifer Lawrence will wear haute couture trainers with her Dior on the red carpet, but they seem totally reasonable with everything else. The ones here, which include Rick Owens’s architectural wonders designed in collaboration with Adidas, are surely as statement-making as any pair of heels. Expect to see some of them in the front row this week.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Orley Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Pussy Riot at The New York Times
text: Pussy Riot members Maria Alyokhina, 25, and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, 24, visited The New York Times editorial board Wednesday morning. They were on The Colbert Report Tuesday night and will appear at the Barclay’s Center in Brooklyn tonight. This is why they’re getting so much attention.

headline: Simplicity of Movement Translated Into Something Much Larger
text: Some of the dance steps, phrases and constructions by the choreographer Pam Tanowitz are among the finest being made anywhere today. They feature memorable footwork, strikingly elegant and witty combinations of lower- and upper-body movement, and complex, subtle, fascinating uses of stage space. And yet she’s an eccentric. What’s notable — especially in the 50-minute double bill of world premieres that opened at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday — is that her eccentricity is intimately connected to orthodoxy. Much of her dance vocabulary is taken from ballet and from Merce Cunningham technique, both of which she employs in ways that should often impress devotees of either genre.

headline: Disney Reports Strong First-Quarter Earnings, Helped by Animated Film ‘Frozen’
text: LOS ANGELES — A white-hot Walt Disney Company reported a 33 percent increase in quarterly profit on Wednesday, as the animated musical “Frozen” demonstrated why media giants still chase movie hits although investors prefer less risky pursuits.

headline: Louise Brough Clapp, Tennis Champion at Midcentury, Dies at 90
text: Louise Brough Clapp, whose powerful serve-and-volley game propelled her to 35 championships in Grand Slam tennis tournaments of the 1940s and ’50s and made her one of the most brilliant doubles players in the women’s game, died on Monday in Vista, Calif. She was 90.

headline: Jeff Westheimer’s Imaginative Play at Bridge Semifinals
text: Jeff Westheimer made a very imaginative opening bid in the diagramed deal from the semifinals of the 1970 team trials. Westheimer, one of the top players of the game in the 1960s, ’70s and ’80s, died on Monday at 79, in New York City, his hometown.

headline: A Generous Spritz to Set the Mood
text: Of all the things that stood out at Prabal Gurung’s show last year — the clear plastic curtain, the satiny pencil skirts, the mannequin-like models — fashion editors still recall the one thing they couldn’t see: the smell.

headline: Fall 2014 Show Calendar
McConaughey, Savoring the Underdog Role
text: Over his career, Matthew McConaughey has transformed from romantic comedy star to character actor. No matter the role, Mr. McConaughey says that he loves feeling like the underdog.

headline: Potions, Lotions, Emulsions, Decisions
text: The fashion designer Nanette Lepore, 49, who recently dressed New York Mayor Bill de Blasio’s wife, Chirlane McCray, and their daughter, Chiara de Blasio, for his inauguration ceremony, is releasing a line of products for the home this month. Born in Youngstown, Ohio, she lives and works in Manhattan. Her beauty habits, like her fashion, are flirtatious and youthful.

headline: Olympics Spotlight for Russia’s Musical Profile
text: Valery Gergiev is considered a lock to conduct. The Russian diva Anna Netrebko is widely suspected to be singing. And a host of top Russian ballet stars are expected to dance.

headline: Ex-King of Rom-Coms Finds Serious Success
text: There’s a little private thing that Matthew McConaughey likes to do to relax, a sort of call and response with his own body, a chest-thumping, masculine-humming rhythmic trance that he finds centering.

headline: Fortress of Solitude
text: In 1978, the English decorator Charlotte Scott decamped to the remote, semi-mountainous region of Andalusia. Fourteen years and four children later, she opened the doors at Trasierra, a 400-acre Anglo-pastoral guesthouse that she transformed from a crumbling 16th-century olive mill into a sanctuary of whitewashed courtyards, cushioned verandas and resplendent gardens. Starting in April, Scott’s 29-year-old daughter, Amber, who trained in Nepal and London as a yoga teacher and massage therapist, will be offering guests daily yoga classes. There will also be weekly retreats focused on meditation, hiking and massage sessions, combined with a delicious menu created by her sister Gioconda. Though Amber’s full-immersion programs happen in May and October, made-to-measure stays for parties of six or more are welcome year-round.

headline: How Did Your Recent Peace Corps Service Affect Your Life?
text: Serving in the Peace Corps can be both challenging and rewarding. Former Peace Corps volunteers often have good stories to tell — about their experiences in the field, what they learned and how those experiences shaped their lives after their service ended. Times journalists are writing about recent Peace Corps volunteers.

headline: How Eroding the Middle Hits Economic Growth
text: Since my article on Monday about the narrowing of the customer base for midtier restaurants, retailers and other consumer-oriented businesses like hotels and casinos, much of the discussion has focused on what that trend says about whether and how the American middle class is indeed shrinking.

headline: And on Drums, Jazzmen Who Take the Lead
text: The first and last sounds on “303,” Rudy Royston’s sit-up-and-take-notice debut album, involve a tranquil, mysterious, cooled-out funk groove, like an interlude on an early-2000s neo-soul production. Anchored by a soulfully simple bass vamp, with a smoky overlay of horns and guitar, the tune — “Mimi Sunrise,” an opener that resurfaces as a hidden track — calls barely any attention to Mr. Royston’s specific purview, which is drumming. There’ll be time for all that, he seems to imply.

headline: The Fashion Diaspora: Designer Shows Spread Out
text: Driver, thank God you’re here. Take me to ... where again?

headline: Presidio Asks Filmmaker to Try Again
text: National parks are open to everyone, even to the filmmaker George Lucas. That is the message from the Presidio Trust in San Francisco, which this week rejected proposals by Mr. Lucas and two other finalists to build “a cultural institution of distinction” on prized bayside parkland and then turned right around and invited him back.

headline: Small Dreams Set Afire on Marcos-Era Streets
text: Lino Brocka’s “Manila in the Claws of Light” begins with a whisper and ends with a howl. In between, there are grace notes, escalating horrors and the peripatetic journey of a country mouse, Julio (Rafael Roco Jr., later known as Bembol Roco), in the big city. It’s a story of struggle, survival, endurance and defeat that Brocka, perhaps the most celebrated of Filipino directors, filmed down and dirty in Manila when the Philippines was still in the grip of the dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos. Brocka, a political activist as well as a prolific filmmaker, died in a car accident in 1991 at 52, and is ready for rediscovery.

headline: Unsealed Court Documents in Pradaxa Case
text: Unsealed court documents made public by a federal judge who is overseeing thousands of lawsuits filed by patients and their families who say that Pradaxa’s manufacturer failed to properly warn them about the risks of taking the drug.

headline: Times Minute | Vatican Sexual Abuse
text: A U.N. panel assails the Vatican over sexual abuse by priests. Also on the Minute, New York's wintry mess and an international yogurt feud between the United States and Russia.

headline: Times Minute | Vatican Sexual Abuse
text: In the Video

headline: The Life of a Poet Allergic to Endings
text: LYNCHBURG, Va. — It was snowing hard on a recent afternoon, but Anne Spencer’s house glowed like a Vanessa Bell mural, more Bloomsbury than Old Virginia. Though Spencer, an iconoclastic poet and Harlem Renaissance figure, died in 1975, her singular house, with its purple, yellow and green rooms, its boldly patterned wallpapers and upholstery, its sheaves of newspaper clippings, photographs, N.A.A.C.P. ledgers, political fliers and her own copious writings that spill out of notebooks and climb the walls (Spencer was an enthusiastic wall-writer), is so vibrant that you would swear she was still living there.

headline: Like a Strand Within a Strand
text: Fabrics featuring art by Sonia Delaunay, Marc Chagall and Alexander Calder are among the 200 objects in “Artist Textiles: Picasso to Warhol,” at the Fashion and Textile Museum in London. The exhibition, which runs through May 17, also includes a Joan Miró dress and a Salvador Dalí tie.

headline: Breaking From Its Usual Pattern
text: The new Lotta Jansdotter collection for Dansk is a departure for this nearly 60-year-old American company, which routinely hires Scandinavians to design its goods. “We haven’t always been known for pattern,” said Glenn DeStefano, Dansk’s president. “We’ve been about shape and high design, with wood and contrasting materials.” Ms. Jansdotter, who was born on an island between Sweden and Finland, has produced organic forms and whimsical scribbles ever since she started her company in 1996. Here, the imagery floats on plates and repeats on cups and bowls meant to be mixed and matched. Available at Bed Bath & Beyond, the line features five dinnerware patterns and four additional motifs on mugs and bowls only.

headline: Clay Aiken, Able to Carry a Tune but Hoping for a District
text: WASHINGTON — North Carolina has become difficult terrain for Democrats since the Republican-controlled legislature redrew congressional districts in 2011 with the goal of more or less eliminating them from the state’s House delegation.

headline: My Brother’s Bunkmate
text: Caleb and Harper cannot share a bedroom forever. For now, Rachel Goldstein cites a number of not-unconvincing reasons to keep her 7-year-old son and 4-year-old daughter together in the family’s Park Slope brownstone.

headline: Sales at Gretel Home, Love Adorned and Others
text: Gretel Home is discounting many items up to 60 percent, while supplies last (a Folk Stripe tray by Ary Trays, originally $59, is about $35; the Ombre House money box by Ferm Living, originally $39, is about $23); 786-247-9003, gretelhome.com.

headline: Outfitting an Atelier in Mine and Yours
text: Piet Boon, the Dutch architect and designer, recently opened a temporary studio at 404 Park Avenue South (28th Street), in a 1917 building that is being converted into 58 luxury apartments. Mr. Boon led the design team that outfitted the development, called Huys. He has furnished his atelier with his own creations, including Sam chairs upholstered in indigo fabric, shown with an oak Gerrit table. The studio also features other designers’ works, like Roderick Vos’s MaMa vase (on table), Frederik Molenschot’s brass numeral sculptures (on wall) and a Great JJ floor lamp by Centro Stile in Italy (shown in white). Though these items cannot be purchased on site, Mr. Boon’s staff can direct you to a dealer. The ground-floor space will be open until June, and then it will give way to a bank. Information: huys-nyc.com.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Jack Spade Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Creating Effortless Luxury
text: Reed Krakoff’s collection will be his first since leaving Coach.

headline: Flocks, Flecks and Flicks
text: Jennifer Lawrence’s wardrobe in “American Hustle” was one thing, but let’s talk about her kitchen, with its matching blue blinds and phone. Judy Becker, the movie’s production designer, was responsible for the 1970s-inspired décor, every square foot of flocked wallpaper. Now she has her first Oscar nomination (shared with Heather Loeffler, the set decorator). Speaking by phone from Cincinnati, where she is working on the Todd Haynes film “Carol,” Ms. Becker, who said she is in her late 40s, described her immersion in disco-era taste as an education. She even acquired some stuff. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Boutique Sinks for Small Bathrooms
text: As far as most people are concerned, a bathroom is a bathroom, and there are only a couple of things it’s good for. That’s not how John Beckmann sees it.

headline: Plucky Horses, Lucky Year
text: This Lunar New Year is not just the Year of the Horse, but the Year of the Wood Horse. In recognition of the pairing, Lane Crawford, the Chinese luxury department store, commissioned Squint Limited to make a lucky group of rocking horses.

headline: A Place to Park Himself
text: James van der Velden wanted something out of the ordinary in a home. But not in the conventional sense. He wasn’t interested, for example, in any of the beautiful 17th-century townhouses this city is known for.

headline: Behind the Garage Door
text: An architect renovates a 1950s garage, turning it into a home filled with antiques (but not the four-wheeled type).

headline: With Snow Sports, a New Olympic Vocabulary
text: Snowboarders and skiers have an extensive repertoire of spins and flips. Some tricks are named for their technical requirements, others for their flair. Here, some of the best riders describe the joy and fear that come with these jaw-dropping maneuvers.

headline: Making His Name His Own
text: Dana Taylor, a model, stood straight as a maypole as Reed Krakoff circled, paused, then peered intently at his handiwork. Ms. Taylor was wearing Mr. Krakoff’s cobalt-blue sleeveless officer’s coat, a sample from the fall collection he will show on Wednesday, a piece stripped to its essentials: welted seams, slant pockets and a pair of outsize lapels its only embellishment.

Reversing the Drug Crisis
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sorry? Not Really
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bushwick Gang Is Putting Its Brand Back Together
text: Scott Campbell, a tattoo artist to celebrities like Marc Jacobs and Sting who has lately made a name as a fine artist, recalls the shock he felt upon boarding an flight from New York to Los Angeles a few years ago and seeing a passenger wearing a pair of jeans by his go-to denim brand, an obscure label known as Deth Killers of Bushwick.

headline: Video: This Teacher Isn’t Stuffy
text: MICHAEL DONKOR

headline: Jury in SAC Case Requests Documents Related to Defense Witness
text: Deliberating for a second day, jurors in the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma, a former top portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, on Wednesday requested documents supporting the defense’s claim that he is not guilty.

headline: U.S. to Return Painting to Poland That Was Seized by Nazis
text: An 18th-century painting that disappeared from Warsaw’s national museum about 70 years ago during Nazi occupation will be returned to Poland by the United States government on Thursday, officials said.

headline: The Opportunity Society
text: To the Editor:

headline: Klinsmann: ‘The Door Is Still Open’ for World Cup Roster
text: After a monthlong January training camp and an exhibition victory over South Korea, United States national soccer team members have gone their separate ways until the team's next game: an international friendly at Ukraine on March 5.

headline: A Closet Is the Highest Form of Flattery
text: A few weeks ago, the designer Lisa Perry gave a tour of her 300-square-foot closet at her art-saturated Manhattan penthouse on Sutton Place. The closet, built a year ago, is nestled between the kitchen, where there is a Larry Rivers painting, and the bedroom suite, with its entrance demarcated by one of Damien Hirst’s medicine cabinet sculptures.

headline: Apple Takes Down a Bitcoin App
text: Apple has taken down one of the last remaining iPhone mobile applications that allowed users to buy and sell Bitcoin.

headline: The Courtship of Bill de Blasio
text: In the waning days of the Michael R. Bloomberg administration, there was no shortage of tributes to the outgoing mayor as he finished up a 12-year run in City Hall, including a private dinner given at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Dec. 3 by the designers Oscar de la Renta and Diane von Furstenberg.

headline: Heat System Called Door to Target for Hackers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Investigators say they believe they have identified the entry point through which hackers got into Target’s systems, zeroing in on the remote access granted through the retailer’s computerized heating and cooling software, according to two people briefed on the inquiry.

headline: Preserving Routine Amid Rising Violence
text: BAGHDAD — Struggling for a decade against Iraq’s misery, Hani Jari Hattab assembled what passed for an empire in his neighborhood, including a cellphone kiosk, a computer store and a supermarket stocked with goods from abroad.

headline: If the Size Fits, Build a Following
text: At 5 feet 8 inches, with a slender build, Peter Manning says that finding clothes for his proportions has been a challenge his entire adult life.

headline: Skiers Risk Injury to Fuel Progression
text: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind The Line,” professional skiers Dash Longe and Dylan Hood search for new terrain and new tricks in the Selkirk Mountains.

headline: Long-Form Journalism
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Write an Editorial
text: The New York Times’s editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal provides seven tips for writing an effective editorial.

headline: Openings, Events and Sales Starting the Week of Feb. 6
text: Fashion Week

headline: A Solution for Bad Teaching
text: PHILADELPHIA — IT’S no secret that tenured professors cause problems in universities. Some choose to rest on their laurels, allowing their productivity to dwindle. Others develop tunnel vision about research, inflicting misery on students who suffer through their classes.

headline: Video: Skiers Risk Injury to Fuel Progression
text: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: In Spain, Fired for Speaking Out
text: MADRID — FOUR decades ago, I interviewed the New York Times columnist Tom Wicker about the relationship between the government and the press. It was the Watergate era, and journalism appealed to me as a noble calling.

headline: Gloria Leonard, Publisher, Pornography Star and Advocate, Dies at 73
text: Gloria Leonard, who became a pornographic film star in her 30s and then a men’s magazine publisher and a prominent spokeswoman for her industry, died on Monday in Waimea, Hawaii. She was 73.

headline: The Stories We Tell
text: “We tell ourselves stories in order to live,” Joan Didion famously wrote in her essay collection “The White Album.” It’s a haunting line, because it’s so universally applicable. We tell ourselves stories not only for profound reasons but for mundane ones as well: to process the ambiguous and complex events that unfold every day around us, or even to try to understand the issues presented in a major Supreme Court case.

headline: Baby’s All Right
text: As the Williamsburg scene drowns under waves of tourists and condo dwellers, Baby’s All Right has swiftly become a night-life preserver. The expansive bar, restaurant and music space, which opened in October on Broadway, has hosted an event for Opening Ceremony, held a New Year’s party with a performance by Dev Hynes, and booked acts like Smith Westerns. Among Southside insiders, nights now begin or end here.

headline: ‘Williams,’ the Princess and the Gender Pay Gap
text: One day when my twins, a boy and a girl, were about 7 years old, we were out running errands.

headline: Michelle Obama Urges Students to Apply for College Aid
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Michelle Obama told a group of high school students and parents on Wednesday not to let financial concerns stand in the way of a college education as she urged them to apply for federal student aid.

headline: Magic Johnson Steps In to Rescue Los Angeles Sparks
text: LOS ANGELES — More than three decades after guiding the Los Angeles Lakers from mediocrity to excellence, and nearly two years after helping purchase the bankrupt Los Angeles Dodgers, Magic Johnson rescued another local team.

headline: Israel: Final Approval Is Given on East Jerusalem Apartments
text: A city committee on Wednesday gave final approval for more than 500 new apartments in Jewish neighborhoods of East Jerusalem, a routine bureaucratic step that nonetheless could cause ripples in Washington’s efforts to broker a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians. The neighborhoods, in territory Israel captured during the 1967 war and later annexed, are considered illegal settlements by most of the world. Saeb Erekat, the chief Palestinian negotiator, has insisted that such moves undermine the peace process, and on Wednesday was quoted on the Times of Israel, a website, as saying, “The international community must hold Israel accountable for this policy.”

headline: Tech Industry Flexes Muscle in California Race
text: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Here in the land of technology start-ups, Ro Khanna is its political version. Backed by many of Silicon Valley’s top investors and executives at Google, Facebook, Yahoo and other tech companies, Mr. Khanna, a 37-year-old patent lawyer who has never held elected office, has mounted an aggressive campaign for the seat from the 17th Congressional District in the heart of the Valley.

headline: Trading ‘Faces’ and Fashion in Ulta’s New Online Campaign
text: COSMETICS advertising often features celebrities, but even the most optimistic consumers recognize that makeup might not make them look like a starlet or supermodel.

headline: Investors Appear to Shrug Off Puerto Rico’s Debt Downgrade
text: Investors’ faith in Puerto Rico’s debt appeared undaunted on Wednesday after Standard & Poor’s cut the island’s credit rating to junk a day earlier.

headline: At 90, This Doctor Is Still Calling
text: We in journalism tend to cover airplane crashes, corrupt officials and loathsome criminals with gusto, but let’s take a break and applaud a hero.

headline: Doctors Charged in Drug Scheme at Clinic Controlled by Traffickers, Authorities Say
text: It is not an uncommon scene: a waiting room filled with patients hoping to see a doctor. But the crowd of up to 100 people that gathered each day outside the Astramed clinic at 1228 Southern Boulevard in the Bronx, clamoring to get a prescription for the painkiller oxycodone, was a different story, the authorities say.

headline: Calling All Candidates
text: I don’t know if you’ve noticed, but we’re now in an election year.

headline: My Husband’s Things
text: My husband, Stuart, died last June after a decade-long struggle with cancer. He was 77 years old, a former journalist and public relations executive, a marathon runner, and a man beloved and respected by family and friends.

headline: Virtual School on Snow Days
text: Should more schools institute virtual learning on snow days?

headline: Study Suggests Misplaced Fears in Longer Childbirths
text: Epidural anesthesia lengthens the second stage of labor, the one in which women push. But a study published on Wednesday has found that epidurals are associated with an even longer duration in the second stage than is generally recognized, suggesting that some women may be subject to unnecessary interventions by doctors who wrongly fear labor has become prolonged.

headline: A Different Gates Is Returning to Microsoft
text: SEATTLE — The last time Bill Gates played an active role at Microsoft, as chief software architect, he witnessed the company muffing its earliest efforts to become a major player in search, smartphones and tablet computers.

headline: Party Predictions Differ in Texas on Impact of New Voter ID Law
text: DALLAS — Texas is preparing for the first major test of its hotly debated new voter ID law as Democrats and Republicans offer sharply differing assessments of its impact on the state’s March 4 primary.

headline: Jihadist Return Is Said to Drive Attacks in Egypt
text: CAIRO — In just the last two weeks, Islamist militants have detonated a car bomb at the gates of the capital’s security headquarters, gunned down a senior Interior Ministry official in broad daylight and shot down a military helicopter over Sinai with a portable surface-to-air missile.

headline: A Missing Argument on Contraceptives
text: One of the most anticipated showdowns of the Supreme Court’s current term will take place March 25, when the justices are scheduled to hear two cases brought by secular, for-profit corporations whose owners want an exemption, based on their religious beliefs, from the requirement that employers’ health plans cover the full range of contraceptive services without a co-payment.

headline: Knee-Deep in Traffic-Jam Scandal, Christie Keeps Talking
text: He is Oscar quality, this governor, even during this walk across his bridge of sighs.

headline: The U.N. Confronts the Vatican
text: A United Nations report excoriated the Vatican on Wednesday for failing to live up to international commitments to protect children, finding the widespread sexual abuse of children by priests had been compounded by church policies that allowed abusers to continue to prey on youngsters.

headline: Detroit’s Immigration Solution
text: The governor of Michigan, Rick Snyder, wants to fix Detroit with smart immigrants.

headline: Democrats Grab for a Chance to Halt Christie’s Rise
text: Democratic Party operatives have churned out 11 different videos depicting Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey as a revenge-happy gridlock maker who cannot keep his story straight.

headline: A Rough Final Winter for New York’s Sanitation Chief
text: New York City has faced a messy meteorological start to the year, a spate of storms that has sapped the patience of even its most stoic residents.

headline: Despite Revamp, Figure Skating Gets Mixed Marks
text: SOCHI, Russia — A figure skating judge ordered a quick bowl of soup for lunch at the Cup of Nice international competition in France. She did not finish the meal that October day in 2012, putting her spoon down and walking away in shock and anger.

headline: Ukraine Chief Loses Support in Stronghold
text: DNEPROPETROVSK, Ukraine — As violence flared late last month in Kiev after Parliament approved a draconian law against dissent, two of the richest men in this industrial city 300 miles to the east of the Ukrainian capital met in an expensive Italian restaurant that they own and made a fateful decision.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 5, 2014
Who Needs Stopwatches? From the Shadows, Judges Take Starring Roles
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Whether Shaun White wins another gold medal in snowboarding’s halfpipe competition will be determined by a panel of six judges. Their only official criterion is “overall impression.”

headline: Defenders of SodaStream Confuse Boycotts of Israeli Settlements With Movement to Boycott Israel
text: Last Updated, Thursday, 9:10 p.m. | It may be too soon to tell if SodaStream made a wise investment by hiring the actress Scarlett Johansson as a “brand ambassador” for the products it makes in a factory in the occupied West Bank — although its share price has dropped sharply since then, that could be just because the company also missed an earnings target the same week. But one thing is already clear: criticism of the deal from a charity the actress represented for nearly a decade, Oxfam, has been a publicity bonanza for a Palestinian-led movement to counter Israel’s military dominance with a campaign of boycotts, divestment and sanctions.

headline: Bond Hearing Is Held in Killing at Theater
text: DADE CITY, Fla. — After fatally shooting a man after an argument over texting in a movie theater, a retired police captain pushed his glasses back and said, “I can’t believe what I’ve done,” a witness to the shooting testified Wednesday at a bond hearing.

headline: Saving Sochi's Stray Dogs
text: Animal rights workers in Sochi, Russia, are rescuing stray dogs from exterminators hired by the government. They hope athletes and fans visiting the Olympics will adopt them.

headline: New York City Woman Is Charged in Killing of Daughter, 2
text: The mother of a 2-year-old girl has been charged with second-degree murder in what the authorities described as a pattern of abuse that culminated in the toddler’s death this week, the Queens district attorney attorney’s office said on Wednesday.

headline: Racing to Save the Stray Dogs of Sochi
text: SOCHI, Russia — A dog shelter backed by a Russian billionaire is engaged in a frantic last-ditch effort to save hundreds of strays facing a death sentence before the Winter Olympics begin here.

headline: One From Berlin
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — This 15 x 16 puzzle by Joe Krozel grew on me. I don’t always do this, but I started in the northwest and was a bit taken aback by the entries at 1 Across and 4 Down (BANG and GASHED, respectively). With all the news stories of shootings and other types of violence, I personally found the opening of Mr. Krozel’s puzzle disturbing.

headline: Months Later, Sniper Attack at Power Hub Still a Mystery
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A mysterious and sophisticated sniper attack last year on a Silicon Valley power substation has underscored concerns about the vulnerability of the country’s electrical grid and prompted debate over whether it was an act of terrorism.

headline: Veronica Beard: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: In the Breath Between Winter Storms, Officials Scramble to Find More Salt
text: As the latest winter storm bore down on New York City, officials faced with dwindling mounds of salt contacted the state and got an emergency shipment of 2,000 tons. New York State also deployed dozens of trucks to deliver salt from upstate to Long Island towns that are running short. And fielding requests from municipalities, New Jersey’s transportation commissioner called the head of a major supplier, International Salt, to urge the quickest possible delivery.

headline: Live (Streaming) From Russia
text: NBC’s moneyed grip on the Olympics means that it has traveled a technological path that no other network has. It has shown the Games entirely on broadcast television. It has added multiple cable networks. Now, it is live-streaming virtually every event to an ecosystem increasingly populated by tablets and smartphones.

headline: Subdued Send-Off, but Jay Leno Is Exiting on Top
text: When Jack Paar left the “Tonight” show in 1962, he passed through a set of curtains and the camera zoomed in on a card that read: “No More to Come.” Three decades later, Johnny Carson had Bette Midler serenade him on his penultimate show, then sat and spoke directly to his fans in his emotional finale, watched by 42 million viewers.

headline: ‘Chill’ Seattle Savors Its Super Bowl Moment in the Sun
text: SEATTLE — Drivers here often smile and wave at one another for no obvious reason. A study last year found that Washington residents were less likely than people elsewhere to swear at strangers. For many, “Seattle chill” sums up the conflicted local soul: polite but cool.

headline: Time and Luck Run Out as $1 Million Lottery Prize Goes Unclaimed in the Bronx
text: The lottery sign is proudly taped to the window of a discount beauty supply store in the Bronx, reminding customers that one of their own became a millionaire overnight.

headline: VFiles: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: Broadway Dims Lights for Hoffman
text: Broadway theaters dimmed their marquee lights for one minute Wednesday in memory of the acclaimed screen and stage actor Philip Seymour Hoffman, who died on Sunday, apparently of a drug overdose.

headline: A Complicated Actor, Philip Seymour Hoffman, in His Last Days
text: A father with his children in a Greenwich Village playground. A disheveled man hovering around the lone A.T.M. in a grocery store, withdrawing the exact sum of $200, over and over, for an hour. A guy texting his buddy to invite him over to watch the Knicks game at his apartment.

headline: Cycling Study Says Hearts Race With the Riders
text: It should be pretty clear that professional athletes are better at sports than you. It turns out, though, they may be better looking, too.

headline: Corrections: February 6, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Con Ed Asks Harlem to Conserve Power
text: Con Edison has asked electricity customers in Harlem to avoid using nonessential appliances like washers, dryers, dishwashers and extra lights because of problems with electric cables in the area.

headline: With Felton a Step Slow, the Knicks Allow the Blazers to Run Away
text: The Knicks had a third-quarter lead against one of the N.B.A.’s premier teams Wednesday night when Raymond Felton was slowed by a screen along the 3-point arc. He trailed the Portland Trail Blazers’ Damian Lillard for the rest of the play, relegated to the role of spectator as Lillard drove the lane before passing to Nicolas Batum for a layup.

headline: Temporary Insanity
text: For eight days in February and then again in September, more than 100,000 characters descend on New York City for the women’s fashion shows. Traffic grinds to a halt. Requests on Uber, the luxury car-service app, spike 40 percent. It’s harder to get a seat at certain restaurants, like Carbone or NoMad, than it is a front-row perch at Marc Jacobs. And there are enough crazed street-style peacocks clomping around and #NYFW selfies getting snapped to make the whole scene feel like some endless Kardashian nightmare. But it’s also serious business. The shows bring in an estimated $860 million for the city, more than the projected earnings of the U.S. Open, the New York City Marathon or the Super Bowl. Not bad for an event that began in 1941, when the International Ladies’ Garment Workers Union invited 30 journalists to attend a few designers’ showrooms. Here, a brief look into the harrowing and often hysterical week that kicks off every new fashion season.

headline: Shiny Shades of Cerulean
text: A bevy of shiny accessories in steely shades of blue are brightening up winter’s drab look. Monochromatic watches and jewelry, like David Yurman’s classic cable bracelet made anew with icy-blue aluminum, add modest pops of the eye-catching hues. But it’s the highly reflective sunglasses, shoes and bags that really make a statement. Saint Laurent’s teal duffle and sapphire high-tops scream space-age fashion while a pair of ombré Gucci shades are too attention-grabbing to hide behind.

headline: Europeans Undermining Trade Negotiations
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Word of the Day | incursion
text: incursion •\in-ˈkər-zhən\• noun

headline: Jets Hire Assistant
text: The Jets filled the lone remaining vacancy on their coaching staff by hiring Thomas McGaughey as their special-teams coach. McGaughey, 40, spent the last three seasons as the special-teams coach at Louisiana State. McGaughey was the Giants’ assistant special-teams coordinator for four seasons and has also coached in the N.F.L. in Kansas City, Houston and Denver.

headline: Football Fans Fill the Seattle Streets
text: The scene at the Seahawks’ championship parade.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) WINTER OLYMPICS Coverage of the 2014 Games from Sochi, Russia, begins with the men’s and pairs short programs in the inaugural figure skating team contest, which combines results in men’s, women’s, pairs and ice-dancing competition. Of the 10 competing teams, Canada, Russia and the United States are favored. (Above, a member of the Russian team, Yevgeny Plushenko.) Other segments feature women’s moguls in freestyle skiing and men’s and women’s slopestyle snowboarding. Shaun White has announced that he will drop out of the first-time slopestyle event.

headline: ‘An American in Madras’ Traces Career of Unlikely Pioneer in Tamil-Language Films
text: As a college student in what is now known as Mumbai, the Indian filmmaker Karan Bali watched the 1947 Hindi classic “Meera,” a remake of the 1945 Tamil-language film of the same name, and loved it. However, it was not until in 2004, while researching an article for his portal on Indian cinema, Upperstall, that he discovered the director of both films was an American, Ellis R. Dungan.

headline: Legal Costs Hurt Credit Suisse Profit
text: Updated, 7:15 p.m. | Credit Suisse said on Thursday that weakness in its investment bank and money set aside to cover legal costs weighed on its fourth-quarter results, contributing to a small profit increase for the Swiss bank.

headline: After Losses, Yet Another Overhaul for Sony
text: TOKYO — After failing to turn around two of its most troubled consumer electronics businesses, Sony is pushing them aside.

headline: Members of Russian Punk Band Get Warm Greeting in Brooklyn
text: Newly freed by the Russian authorities, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, one of two members of the punk band Pussy Riot jailed for their political activism, had a message for the crowd at a fund-raising concert in Brooklyn on Wednesday.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 6, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | An Olympics in the Shadow of a War Zone
text: In “An Olympics in the Shadow of a War Zone,” Steven Lee Myers writes about the challenges of holding the Winter Games in such a volatile region.

headline: In Jaipur, New Feminists Are Born
text: The women’s rights activists Ruchira Gupta and Gloria Steinem are keeping a diary of their travels throughout India as they meet the country’s young feminists, writers and thought leaders. In this installation for India Ink, Ms. Gupta and Ms. Steinem take part in the Jaipur Literature Festival.

headline: Looted, but Not Lost: An African Artist’s Life Work
text: BANGUI, Central African Republic — Bangui has been a looters’ paradise for weeks now. Despite French and African Union peacekeepers, Christians have gone on a rampage burning Muslim homes and businesses in revenge for almost a year of Muslim Seleka rule of scorched earth and terror. Except now, with no rule of law, the looting has crossed religious boundaries and rampaging mobs sack their own neighborhoods.

headline: Does a More Equal Marriage Mean Less Sex?
text: Not long ago, I was at a dinner party with several couples in their 40s, all married except for my boyfriend and me. The mood was jovial until, over dessert, one guest made an offhand joke about Internet porn.

headline: Will You Be Watching the Sochi Olympics?
text: “Never before has the pre-Olympic chatter been less about the athletes or the sports,” Juliet Macur writes in a piece for Wednesday’s special Sochi 2014  section. Not only are there serious concerns about terrorism, but many are also outraged about Russian legislation that seems to discriminate against gay athletes and visitors.

headline: European Hardship Hurts Vodafone’s Sales
text: LONDON — Vodafone reported weak quarterly sales figures on Thursday, confirming that the British cellphone carrier was still suffering from Europe’s financial problems.

headline: Egypt’s Despair, and Its Hope
text: CAIRO — Last month, on the third anniversary of the revolution of Jan. 25 that led to the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak, millions of Egyptians came out onto the streets carrying Egyptian flags and pictures of Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, the army leader whom they considered their hero for siding with the will of the people and overthrowing the Muslim Brotherhood government in June. At the same time, supporters of the Brotherhood’s deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, continued their confrontations with the police, which resulted in 49 deaths and scores of injuries.

headline: New York Today: Beware of Widespread Black Ice
text: Updated 10:29 a.m.

headline: Times Minute | Saving Sochi's Stray Dogs
text: Also on the Minute, the “American Idol” finalist Clay Aiken announces his bid for Congress and Broadway dims its lights for Philip Seymour Hoffman.

headline: Times Minute | Saving Sochi’s Stray Dogs
text: In the Video

headline: North Korea, Citing U.S. Bomber Training Run, May Cancel Reunions
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Thursday threatened to cancel reunions of families separated by the Korean War, accusing the United States of flying nuclear-capable B-52 bombers on a training mission over the Korean Peninsula.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Return of the Stomach Bug
text: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a 70-year-old woman who has severe gastrointestinal symptoms that return four years later?

headline: As 2 Go Free, Brooklyn Conviction Challenges Keep Pouring In
text: Their wrists uncuffed, their ankles unchained, Antonio Yarbough and Sharrif Wilson walked out of a Brooklyn courtroom Thursday afternoon, free after more than two decades in prison for three murders they did not commit.

headline: Finnish Group Offers to Buy Pohjola Bank for $4.6 Billion
text: The Finnish financial company OP-Pohjola Group said on Thursday that it had offered to buy the shares it does not already own in Pohjola Bank for about 3.4 billion euros, or about $4.6 billion.

headline: In Japan, a Beloved Deaf Composer Appears to Be None of the Above
text: TOKYO — He was celebrated as a prolific musical genius whose compositions appeared in popular video games and the competition routine of a top figure skater in the coming Sochi Olympics. His deafness won him praise as Japan’s modern-day Beethoven.

headline: Democrats Aim for a 2014 More Like 2012 and 2008
text: WASHINGTON — The Democrats’ plan to hold on to their narrow Senate majority goes by the name “Bannock Street project.” It runs through 10 states, includes a $60 million investment and requires more than 4,000 paid staff members. And the effort will need all of that — and perhaps more — to achieve its goal, which is nothing short of changing the character of the electorate in a midterm cycle.

headline: When Identity Theft Hits Home
text: When I first heard about the extensive Target hack in December, I sighed in mild irritation. Sure, the breach’s size and scope was shocking, but these things have become so common I just assumed I’d receive a new card in the mail and that would be the end of it.

headline: A Social Network That’s Just for College Students
text: Start-Up: Blend.

headline: British Rate Still at 0.5% As Growth Stays Slow
text: LONDON — The Bank of England on Thursday decided to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low as Britain’s economic recovery continues at a slow pace.

headline: Downhill Is Already Causing Concern
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The Olympic men’s downhill course begins with a descent so steep that skiers quickly reach 90 miles an hour. A subsequent jump catapults racers almost the length of a football field.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘American Income’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “American Income” by Afaa Michael Weaver and “Reflections on the Road to Yale” by Travis Reginal.

headline: India Looks to Expand Visa-on-Arrival Program to 180 Countries
text: NEW DELHI — India said it would seek to expand its visa-on-arrival program to tourists from 180 countries, including the United States and China, to encourage more people to visit the country.

headline: Glassdoor, a Jobs Website, Hires a Finance Chief
text: Glassdoor, the jobs listings website that lets employees rate their bosses, has hired a chief financial officer, potentially setting up an initial public offering of the company down the line.

headline: Shaun White’s Absence Looms Over Slopestyle Qualifying
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — In snowboarding, it is extremely difficult to be the defending Olympic gold medalist in halfpipe and hold similar expectations in slopestyle. Shaun White knows this better than anyone — almost.

headline: Europe’s Central Bank, Defying Doomsayers, Holds Rate Steady
text: PARIS — The European Central Bank’s president, Mario Draghi, is taking a wait-and-see approach as the threat of deflation hangs over the euro zone and the region’s unemployment remains stubbornly high.

headline: A ‘Doll’ Who Pulls Her Own Strings
text: When Nora Helmer, the heroine of Ibsen’s “A Doll’s House,” left her family, slamming the door as she departed, the sound shook the theater and the world. “People left the theater, night after night, pale with excitement, arguing, quarreling, challenging,” an early critic remarked of that 1879 play. Many theater companies considered the ending so shocking, they changed it.

headline: Toying With Ideas Outside the Manual
text: When I was young I lacked the patience and fine-motor skills to do much with Lego, but I spent a lot of time with friends whose bedrooms and basements bristled with elaborate, snapped-together spaceships and skyscrapers. There was always something of a gap between the care and imagination that went into the constructions and what you did with them after the building was done. Those intricate structures became, like just about everything else, stages for car crashes and action-figure duels. Now and then there would be a pause for an argument about who was the bad guy and what the rules were, and then the battle would resume until it was time for a snack.

headline: Swiss Firm Mercuria in Talks to Buy JPMorgan’s Commodities Unit
text: LONDON – The Mercuria Energy Group, a fast-growing energy and commodities trading company, is in exclusive talks to acquire the physical commodities business of JPMorgan Chase, according to a person familiar with the discussions.

headline: Times Co. Reports Slower Decline in Ads
text: The New York Times Company said on Thursday that it added digital subscribers and slowed its declines in print and digital advertising revenue during the fourth quarter of 2013, a year of transition for the company.

headline: Daily Report: After Years in Philanthropy, a Different Gates Returns to Microsoft
text: The last time Bill Gates played an active role at Microsoft, as chief software architect, he witnessed the company muffing its earliest efforts to become a major player in search, smartphones and tablet computers, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: K.K.R. Profit More Than Doubled in Fourth Quarter
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Thursday that its fourth-quarter earnings more than doubled, as rising markets helped deliver big gains on its investments.

headline: Picking a Flavor of Linux
text: Q. I want to install Linux on an old PC to get a few more years out of it, but I don’t know which version to use. What is the difference between Ubuntu and Mint for a new user and are there any free guides to using either?

headline: Video: Matthew McConaughey, Chest-Thumper
text: Once a big screen heartthrob, Matthew McConaughey doesn’t necessarily want to play the hero anymore.

headline: Seeking an Unbiased Jury
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Fraternity Life, Islamic Style
text: SHORTLY BEFORE SUNUP, a dozen or so students at the University of California, San Diego, stumbled dutifully out of bed. They ironed their collared shirts, knotted their ties and piled into their cars. Their destination was the Islamic Center of San Diego, where they were to be initiated into the country’s first Muslim fraternity, Alpha Lambda Mu, named for three letters that start several chapters of the Quran: Alif Laam Meem.

headline: America’s First Muslim Fraternity
text: A glimpse into the beginnings of Alif Laam Meem on the campus of the University of Texas, Dallas.

headline: A Shrug at Puerto Rico’s Debt Downgrade
text: Standard & Poor’s lowered Puerto Rico’s credit rating to junk status on Tuesday, but on Wednesday, the market responded with barely a flinch. While prices of some of the island’s bonds traded lower, there was nothing close to the kind of mass sell-off that might indicate a panic, Michael Corkery reports in DealBook.

headline: Designing a Dream Daytime Wedding
text: One of the things that has always struck me about weddings, these “very special days,” is how run of the mill they can sometimes feel. When it came time, at 40, to organize my own wedding, I realized that I wanted to do things a little differently, and that I needed to avoid the bridal market in order to keep things personal and on-budget. In the end, this approach to creating a meaningful and memorable day did cost less, and everyone in attendance felt truly spoiled.

headline: Christy Wyatt of Good Technology, on Minding the Details
text: This interview with Christy Wyatt, chief executive of Good Technology, a provider of mobile security solutions, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Jamaican Bobsledders Are Back, With Fans’ Help
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — When Winston Watts put on his helmet to begin Jamaica’s first trip down an Olympic bobsled track in 12 years, he was surprised by what he felt in his eyes. It was not tears of emotion; no, this substance was grittier and chalkier. After a moment, he figured it out: He had protein powder dribbling down his face.

headline: Rise in Profit for G.M., but Europe Unit Falters
text: DETROIT — General Motors on Thursday reported its 16th consecutive profitable quarter — but consistent losses in its troubled European division continued to hurt its results.

headline: Labor Supply and the Meaning of Life
text: I had some fun (for weird econonerd values of “fun”) yesterday thinking through the interesting possibility that our pre-Obamacare health system created a “reverse notch” that induced some people to work too much. But I think I should step back and talk about the broader issue here.

headline: The Start of New York Fashion Week
text: Good morning, New York. Your Fashion Week is here. Today is the first official day of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week, though devoted showgoers have been hoofing through slush and snow for the better part of two days to reach earlier presentations. (As I note in today’s Thursday Styles article on the fashion diaspora, New York Fashion Week is expanding in both time and geography.)

headline: Austerity Memories
text: Ryan Cooper writes about possibilities for a deal that actually does something to boost the economy. He suggests that with the deficit obsession fading, Democrats can go back to the old formula of spending increases in return for tax cuts — the formula that gave us, for example, the Children’s Health Insurance Program in the late 1990s.

headline: In Our Pages: February 7
text: 1939: Ban on Game Called ‘Love’

headline: From a Forgotten Box, a Ray of Light
text: This story begins in 1973 with a man in Wales tidying up the mess in his garage and discovering a box of daguerreotypes. Uncertain whether to throw it out, he waited until his brother-in law asked advice from a friend who was a photographer and documentary filmmaker. The friend, Noel Chanan, strongly advised him to hold tight onto a box that must be brimful of history.

headline: Student Contest | Write an Editorial on an Issue That Matters to You

headline: Rachel Kushner: By the Book
text: The author of “The Flamethrowers” and “Telex From Cuba” steers clear of books with ugly covers. And those that are touted as “sweeping,” “tender” or “universal.”

headline: Stradivarius Is Recovered Unharmed After Theft
text: A Stradivarius violin stolen last month from the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra has been recovered seemingly unharmed, the authorities in Milwaukee announced on Thursday.

headline: Sugary Foods Increase Heart Risks
text: Eating sugary foods, researchers have found, increases the risk of dying from heart disease.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘The Grandmaster’
text: Updated, 12:00 p.m. | “The Grandmaster,” is the director Wong Kar-wai’s combined biopic and action film about the rise of one of kung fu’s masters, Ip Man, who would later go on to train Bruce Lee. The film’s stars, Tony Leung (Ip Man) and Ziyi Zhang (who plays Gong Er, a rival and, of course, love interest), went through several years of intense martial-arts training for the film.

headline: AOL Reports Solid Revenue, but Patch Weighs on Profit
text: AOL, the Internet portal-turned-media company, reported strong revenue for the fourth quarter of 2013 on Thursday, but costs related to Patch, its struggling hyperlocal news service, cut into its profits.

headline: What Does a School Crossing Guard Do?
text: Bring up the subject of school crossing guards in New York City, and plenty of parents will have something spirited to say: “Ours is awesome! She holds my daughter’s hand!” Or perhaps: “Ours is useless! The other day I saw her texting while kids crossed the street alone!”

headline: Concern at Westchester Art House as Heavyweight Rival, Sundance, Plans Theater
text: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y. — Even during film awards season, there have not been many theaters where residents of Westchester County could see quirky independent or foreign contenders like “Nebraska,” “Philomena” or “Inside Llewyn Davis.” Until the last few years, there has often been just one such dependable locale, the 12-year-old nonprofit Jacob Burns Film Center in Pleasantville, the county’s only true art house.

headline: A Vegan-Focused Valentine’s Weekend
text: Not sure what to give your vegan sweetie for Valentine’s? The historic Windward House Bed and Breakfast in Camden, Me., which emphasizes locally sourced food and environmentally friendly products, is offering a weekend getaway free of animal products.

text: A visitor at a defense exhibition in New Delhi checking out a model of a Russian rifle.

headline: Sony Turns to Investment Firm With a Taste for Unloved Assets
