headline: Imagining a New York City Flag for the 21st Century
text: Everyone knows the old joke about what has four wheels and flies. The answer, of course: a garbage truck. But what’s blue, white and orange, festooned with beavers, flour barrels, the blades of a windmill, a sailor, an Indian and an eagle? And flies, too?

headline: Russian Biathlon Coach Had Suspicions, Too
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Wolfgang Pichler, a prominent coach of the Russian biathlon team, said he knew that at least one Russian athlete was doping as far back as November, more than two months before she and another Russian biathlete were suspended for doping violations.

headline: Government Demands for Data About Twitter Users Continue to Grow
text: As Twitter gets bigger, governments around the world are increasingly seeking information about its 241 million users and their accounts, the social networking company said Thursday as it released fourth semiannual transparency report.

headline: ‘Gravity’s’ Score, Playing Soon in Space?

headline: Profit Tumbles at Fox, but Cable Makes Gains
text: LOS ANGELES — Higher costs for sports television, an advertising dip at local TV stations, crumbling ratings for “The X Factor” and lackluster movie releases sent quarterly profit tumbling at 21st Century Fox.

headline: Magazines Gain in Digital Sales but Newsstand Revenue Continues to Fall
text: Magazine circulation declined slightly in the last six months of 2013, according to new figures released Thursday by the Alliance for Audited Media, as big declines in single-copy newsstand sales offset gains in digital editions.

headline: Scholarly Editions of Mozart Librettos Going Online
text: If you’ve always wanted to have the Mozart operas at your fingertips — in scholarly editions, no less — here is a start: the Mozarteum Foundation Salzburg has put the first installment of its Mozart libretto project online, and it turns out that the librettos are only the gateway: as you read along, you can click on a speaker icon, which will not only give you access to an audio recording of the relevant section of the opera but will also put a full orchestral and vocal score on your screen.

headline: Religious Freedom Is a Tenet of Foreign Policy, Obama Says

headline: Caribbean Newcomers Dip Their Toes in the Snow

Boehner conceded that it was unlikely he could pass a bill.

text: What could be more likely to draw international headlines, and jokes on late-night talk shows, than a government report that includes both an alleged waste of Medicare money and erectile dysfunction?

text: LONDON — European Union lawmakers moved on Thursday to support the bloc’s system for trading carbon-emission permits, hoping to revive Europe’s flagging effort to take a market-incentives approach to reducing greenhouse gases.

headline: After Boeing 787 Is Diverted, Air India Looks Into Software Problem
text: MUMBAI, India — In the latest in a string of technical problems involving the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, a “software glitch” has caused an Air India flight to divert from its course and make an emergency landing in Malaysia.

headline: A Triumph for Putin, if Not for the Rest of a Sagging Russia
text: MOSCOW — After President Vladimir V. Putin delivered Russia’s successful pitch to host the Winter Olympic Games in Sochi — in English and a smattering of French, no less — he declared it an international validation of the Russia that had emerged from the ruins of the Soviet Union.

headline: Cooper-Hewitt Museum Gets a $10 Million Donation
text: The Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York has been on a hot streak. In October, it received $5 million from the city to help with its $79 million renovation.  On Thursday, the museum announced a $10 million donation from the Morton and Barbara Mandel Family Foundation — the largest in this arts institution’s history.

headline: Words of Praise for the City’s Sanitation Chief
text: It was always a rather thankless position, but with the addition of social media and tweeted complaints of unplowed streets amplifying New York’s renowned impatience, the position of sanitation commissioner comes with a new job requirement: extra thick skin.

headline: Russia Claims U.S. Is Meddling Over Ukraine
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The tense Russian-American jockeying over the fate of Ukraine escalated on Thursday as a Kremlin official accused Washington of “crudely interfering” in the former Soviet republic, while the Obama administration blamed Moscow for spreading an intercepted private conversation between two American diplomats.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Pity the One Percent
text: In late January, Tom Perkins, a venture capitalist, called attention “to the parallels” between Nazi Germany’s “war on its ‘one percent,’ namely its Jews” and “the progressive war on the American one percent, namely the ‘rich.’”

headline: How to Identify a Stradivarius
text: Christopher Reuning, a rare-instrument dealer in Boston, explained how an expert would identify the Stradivarius stolen in late January from the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Illustrating a Sexless but Equal Marriage
text: This week’s cover story by Lori Gottlieb asks what female empowerment means for the sex lives of modern married couples. While many partnerships these days are so-called peer marriages, in which both spouses work full-time as well as share household and parenting duties, the twist is that those apparently appealing dynamics may have a negative impact on a couple’s sex life.

headline: Green Mountain’s Deal With Coke Fails to Dent SodaStream
text: When Green Mountain Coffee Roasters announced an investment from the Coca-Cola Company on Wednesday, many investors assumed that SodaStream, the D.I.Y.-soft-drink darling, would suffer.

headline: Restaurant Report: Serge et le Phoque in Hong Kong
text: Two stars of the Paris dining scene now have a pied-à-terre in Hong Kong. Last August, Fred Peneau, formerly the business partner of Iñaki Aizpitarte at Le Chateaubriand, and the chef Christophe Pelé joined with the interior designer Charles Pelletier to open Serge et le Phoque, a contemporary French restaurant in the heart of the Wan Chai district. (The restaurant was named both after and by Mr. Peneau’s young son, Serge, who thought that le Phoque, French for “the seal,” would be a good companion to Le Dauphin, or “the dolphin,” another of Mr. Peneau’s ventures.)

headline: In Cambodia’s Capital, an Infusion of Flavor
text: As Phnom Penh’s traffic roared nearby on a recent late afternoon, George and William Norbert-Munns were busy decorating. Amid piles of rubble and cement bags, the brothers mapped their vision for the dark, compact space — solid timber banquette seating, chocolate-hued walls, large windows — that would transform it into a sleek gastro pub.

headline: Hotels With History in Goa, India
text: Half an hour before our plane touched ground in Goa, a crew member announced that we would be turning around and flying back to Mumbai. It was the middle of monsoon season, and the rain and lightning had grown so heavy, the pilot no longer thought it safe to land. I’m not sure what metrics led the flight crew to change their minds, because heavy rain and lightning are exactly what we lurched through when, moments later, our plane began its jarring descent to India’s good-time state.

headline: Ex-SAC Trader Convicted of Securities Fraud
text: Mathew Martoma had been on his way to being another American success story. Today, he is the eighth person who once worked for the hedge fund titan Steven A. Cohen to be convicted of insider trading.

headline: The Gun Report: February 6, 2014
text: Curtis Reeves, the 71-year-old retired police captain who shot and killed a man who was texting in a Florida movie theater on Jan. 13, attended his bail hearing yesterday, and more details about the shooting came to light.

headline: Rules of Style | Edun’s Danielle Sherman on Surviving Fashion Week
text: After under-the-radar stints at the Row (which she co-founded with her childhood friends Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen) and as the head of design for T by Alexander Wang, Danielle Sherman shot into the spotlight when the LVMH brand Edun hired her to take the reins last season. Design is in the L.A. native’s blood: Her grandparents ran the Swinging London label the Dollyrocker, and her father has a soccer-shoe company. Now, she’s reinventing the Africa-focused brand with a modern, easygoing take on luxury — and even shot the spring ad campaign herself (an avid photographer, she also happens to be engaged to the lensman-about-town Todd Selby).

headline: Where Lincoln Sat, Transfixed by Todd
text: An unprepossessing 1830s couch that witnessed the 1840 courtship of Abraham Lincoln and Mary Todd is returning to one of her relatives’ parlors with its chipped mahogany trim and torn upholstery repaired.

headline: A Catalog of Cancer Genes That’s Done, or Just a Start
text: Cancer is a disease of genes gone wrong. When certain genes mutate, they make cells behave in odd ways. The cells divide swiftly, they hide from the immune system that could kill them and they gain the nourishment they need to develop into tumors.

headline: North of Tokyo, Exploring the Sacred and Scenic
text: To the right of the path, a fast-rushing river, blue and white, sped through a secluded gorge, breaking into rapids over dark rocks and tumbling over the occasional waterfall. To the left, a long line of timeworn Buddhist statues sat with their backs to a steep wooded bank, inviting passers-by to share their contemplation.

headline: Answer to Puerto Rico’s Debt Woes? It’s Complicated
text: Puerto Rico is in something of a jam at the moment.

headline: Senate Fails to Pass Three-Month Extension of Jobless Aid
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate failed to move forward on a three-month extension of assistance for the long-term unemployed on Thursday, leaving it unlikely that Congress would approve the measure soon while undercutting a key aspect of President Obama’s economic recovery plan.

text: Range anxiety and limited charging infrastructure are among the reasons some consumers don’t consider buying an electric vehicle. Those two concerns are related, because if there’s no place to charge an E.V., that affects the distance a driver can travel.

headline: Ethics Panel to Review Lawmaker’s Spending

headline: Broadcaster Releases ‘Gay Mountain’ Video for Olympics in Sochi
text: A television broadcaster in Britain is celebrating the opening of the Winter Olympics in Sochi with a change in its corporate logo to rainbow colors, and a promotional advertisement that it will air on Friday to applaud the gay and straight athletes who are taking part.

headline: Syrian City to Receive Aid, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — The Syrian government appeared to take a small step to ease the plight of civilians by agreeing to provide humanitarian access to the city of Homs, which has been under siege for over a year, American and United Nations officials said on Thursday.

headline: Should Doctors Wait Longer Before Intervening in Births?
text: Having a baby — the actual, in-labor, taking-that-baby-from- womb-to-world stage — takes time. As much as many of us feel that the lack of an easy mechanism to complete that process is something of a human design flaw, most women will labor for hours during delivery. How many hours depends on a range of natural factors (first births, for example, tend to take longer). It depends, too, on the willingness of any attending clinicians to let labor continue before intervening with oxytocin, forceps, vacuum or a cesarean.

headline: Romance at Arm’s Length
text: IN Spike Jonze’s mesmerizing new movie “Her,” a man falls in love with a sultry-voiced computer operating system whose presence in the film is so lifelike you have to keep reminding yourself she doesn’t actually exist. To make it easier for the audience to believe that a computer might be able to mimic human thought, emotion and speech so convincingly, Mr. Jonze sets his story in the not-so-distant future.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Bright Eyes at Creatures of the Wind
text: You couldn’t help but notice that flash of electric-blue liner peeking out from under models’ eyes at Creatures of the Wind this morning. But its reason for being there? Not entirely obvious. “It’s actually a lighting effect more than anything else,” revealed the makeup artist James Boehmer. “We pulled colors from the collection and eventually landed on this metallic blue since it gives the eyes a lit-from-within effect, and looks great on everyone.” To achieve the special-effects illusion, Boehmer traced a superfine streak of Nars Larger Than Life Long-Wear Eyeliner in Khao San Road on the waterline — that innermost part of the lower lid — so it would “catch the light,” he explained, and “shock the whites of the eyes so they stood out more.” The finished result was a bit ethereal, a bit punk and definitely pretty, even if that wasn’t the point.

headline: Book Covers: Before and After
text: In the latest installment of “Before and After,” book designers discuss recent examples of their work: early concepts for a cover as well as the final design that ended up on the book.

headline: If Nature’s a Generous Benefactor, a Girl Can’t Help Sharing Her Gifts
text: If it is possible to leer sweetly, then that’s what they’re doing this weekend at City Center, where a likable if long-winded production of “Little Me” is running through Sunday. The Encores! concert revival of this 1962 musical manages to wipe the smirk off the face of a show about the rise and rise of a woman whose greatest assets are her mammary glands.

text: A Check With No Name

headline: Finnish Goalie’s Mask Runs Afoul of I.O.C. Rules
text: SOCHI, Russia — On her Olympic mask, the Finnish goaltender Noora Raty included the words “Hakkaa paalle,” which loosely translates to “Cut them down.” It is a battle cry with roots that go back four centuries, to the Thirty Years’ War, and it has become the national team mantra, something the players recite before every game.

headline: Anatomy: 'The Broken Circle Breakdown'
text: Felix van Groeningen narrates a musical sequence from "The Broken Circle Breakdown."

headline: For ‘Top Chef,’ a New Season of Cruises
text: The Bravo television show “Top Chef” may repeat the basic concept each season, but the actual show is quite different every time nonetheless. It follows, then, that rather than simply reproduce “Top Chef: The Cruise,” a Celebrity Cruises charter that set sail last spring, allowing cruisers to fraternize with former contestants on the competition show, the network and the cruise line have partnered on a new venture in 2014.

headline: Olympic Dreams, Financial Reality
text: The 2014 Olympics in Sochi are estimated to be the most expensive yet. While host cities hope the games will bring in a profit, they have more often than not created long-term economic burdens.

headline: The Olympics: A Costly Feel-Good Moment
text: Even before the Olympic torch reached Sochi on Wednesday — after a 39,000-mile journey, the longest in the history of the Games — another Olympic record had already been shattered: the cost of the Games.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘The Broken Circle Breakdown’
text: The Belgian drama “The Broken Circle Breakdown” follows the relationship that develops between a tattoo artist (Veerle Baetens) and a bluegrass musician (Johan Heldenbergh). The film was nominated for an Academy Award in the foreign-language category and is also available on demand this week. In this video, the director Felix van Groeningen narrates a scene from the film, where the two leads share a musical moment. They perform the song “The Boy Who Wouldn’t Hoe Corn,” first as a couple in their bedroom, then transitioning to a band rehearsal and finally in front of an audience onstage. Mr. Van Groeningen discusses some of his ideas behind the sequence.

headline: Letters: ‘My Life in Middlemarch’
text: Glorious George

headline: Correcting the Film Version of a Sensational Story
text: There is intrinsic power in escape stories; consider films like “Papillon” or “Escape From Alcatraz.” With “Riding the Midnight Express With Billy Hayes,” the writer Billy Hayes tells his own. It’s been presented before: in “Midnight Express,” his 1976 memoir about five years he spent imprisoned in Turkey for trying to smuggle hashish, and in the 1978 movie adaptation. But as he makes clear in this one-man show, the movie omits much of his ordeal, and what it does present has, shall we say, a high degree of historical revisionism.

headline: The Ringing Sounds of ‘Dallas Buyers Club’
text: “Gravity” had a score that had to transcend the soundless void of space. “Dallas Buyers Club,” set in the 1980s in Texas, when there was no shortage of crescendo-ed pop songs and drifting ballads to set the scene, had almost no score at all.

headline: Excerpt: 'Bronx Bombers'
text: A scene from the new Broadway play about the New York Yankees.

headline: Its Space Is No Object
text: The kitchen measures 3 feet by 5 feet and has no oven, only a few induction burners and a sandwich press. There is barely room for the two men in black aprons (the chef, Andrew D’Ambrosi, and his sous-chef, Anthony Mongeluzzi) who toil, heads bowed, behind a long glass case filled with gleaming slabs of raw fish.

headline: Looking Beyond the Canonical Masterpieces
text: Leon Botstein, the conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra, is right. Classical music has far too long been in thrall to the cult of the masterpiece, the idea that the arts exist more or less solely for the purpose of identifying and codifying a canon of great works.

headline: Skating at Home, Plushenko Has Already Won
text: SOCHI, Russia — On Thursday night, the first great Russian star competed at the first Russian Winter Olympics. The eager crowd was disappointingly small at the Iceberg Skating Palace, but Evgeni Plushenko never needed a big audience. He could put on a show in a phone booth.

headline: Coal-Flavored Water
text: The recent waste leak from an old coal-fired power plant in North Carolina should serve as a wakeup call to federal officials who have been far too slow and timid about regulating the disposal of coal ash.

headline: ‘Cordial and Friendly’ Session as Pakistan and Taliban Open Talks
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani government officials and Taliban representatives made their first formal contact on Thursday, each side handing the other a wish list as they began talks to end a debilitating conflict that has ravaged the country for years.

headline: Off-the-Field Fumbles and Passes
text: Traditionally, and in no particular order, Super Bowl Sunday tends to result in hangovers, gambling losses and chatter about the commercials. But what about romance? Can the big game inspire big love? The answer appears to be yes; at least according to the personal ads on Craigslist. The following poems about the erotic possibilities of the Super Bowl were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.com. They are printed verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

headline: A Fashion Meet-and-Greet With the Mayor
text: The fashion industry and New York Mayor Bill de Blasio are officially in the getting-to-know-you phase of their relationship.

headline: A Sentimental Education
text: Recent studies suggest that reading literature may make us smarter and more empathic, even more civic-minded. But what can literature tell us about love? Writers in a variety of genres share the books that taught them about love — and a few that led them memorably astray.

headline: Costello Tagliapietra: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: De Blasio Appoints Chirlane McCray, His Wife, to Lead Nonprofit Group
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio has at times teased his appointees about their diminutive statures, or in one case, an eye patch. But he had not, before Thursday, flirtatiously pinched a prominent official while announcing her new role. Or kissed her twice — on the lips — or given her a high-five.

headline: White Pine Trees Provide Canopy and Carpet
text: There are few places on earth as silent or as fragrant as a grove of white pines. Showering down from above, the trees’ soft needles form a springy, thick carpet suffused with the bracing smell of pine resin. Mature pine groves have been accurately described as cathedral-like, the trees’ spires forming a dense canopy that effectively blocks out direct light and much ambient noise. Tangibly mysterious places, groves of pines frequently shelter wintering wildlife like owls and small mammals. Winter seems to be just a little more forgiving under the pine boughs.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kosovo and Elsewhere
text: Photos form Kosovo, South Africa, Jerusalem and South Sudan.

headline: Classic Lensman, Using Full Palette
text: Perhaps the greatest revelation provided by “Capa in Color” is not that Robert Capa, best known as a war photographer, shot in color film. It is that he shot in color frequently, honing his technical facility and trying to get the work published in magazines that began printing color photographs in the late 1930s. In letters, wall texts and magazine layouts displayed in this exhibition at the International Center of Photography, however, you sense Capa’s enthusiasm for color bumping up against various conventions and commercial demands.

headline: How Ben Horowitz Avoided an Options Backdating Scandal
text: Just by listening to his favorite rappers, Ben Horowitz has absorbed many tales of run-ins and near run-ins with the law. But the prominent Silicon Valley investor also lived one of his own.

headline: Second Shot
text: There comes a moment in every novelist’s career when she sloughs off the weight of the past — the conventions and obsessions, the stylistic fallbacks and linguistic tics, the influence of early masters — and ventures into new territory, breaking free into a marriage of tone and style, of plot and characterization, that’s utterly her own. Anna Quindlen’s marvelous romantic comedy of manners is just such a book.

headline: Seeing the Show With Their Ears
text: “I DON’T know why you people have to go to the movies,” the man had barked. “You won’t get anything out of it anyway.”

headline: Postapocalyptic Survival Stories
text: Like a high-minded “Choose Your Own Adventure” tale or a feature-length scenario from the holodeck of “Star Trek,” the risible “After the Dark” posits a number of postapocalyptic survival stories. Why choose one end of the world when you can safely have several by presenting them as lesson plans in a classroom?

headline: A Martian View of Our Pale Dot
text: Talk about small is beautiful.

headline: Ralph Kiner, Slugger Who Became a Voice of the Mets, Dies at 91
text: Ralph Kiner, baseball’s vastly undersung slugger, who belted more home runs than anyone else over his 10-year career but whose achievements in the batter’s box were obscured by his decades in the broadcast booth, where he was one of the game’s most recognizable personalities, died on Thursday at home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Twitter’s Stock Crashes Back to Reality
text: Twitter’s stock plunged on Thursday, dropping 24 percent to close at $50.05 a share, after a fourth-quarter earnings report on Wednesday showed significant declines in usage and a slowdown in the growth of the new users.

headline: Artists on Artists | Richard Tuttle on Frederic Remington, Purveyor of Wild West Nostalgia
text: The Post-Minimalist sculptor Richard Tuttle is known for transforming humble materials like cloth, wire and plastic bags into something unexpected and new. Whether he’s nailing a bit of frayed rope to a wall or using a doormat, lumber and Kraft paper to build an Arp-like construction on the floor, he always creates work that is anti-monumental and abstract, as evidenced by “Looking for the Map,” at Pace Gallery on East 57th Street (Feb. 7 – March 15), which showcases 11 studies for his installation next October at Tate Modern’s Turbine Hall.

headline: When a Form Is Given Its Room to Play
text: Something old, something new, nothing borrowed and not enough color. A variation on the venerable bridal dress code pretty much sums up the Museum of Modern Art’s latest foray into its photography collection, “A World of Its Own: Photographic Practices in the Studio.” In turn, the title of this fabulous yet irritating survey offers its own variation — on the name of Virginia Woolf’s famous essay about female independence, “A Room of One’s Own” — but the show itself, which opens on Saturday, dazzles but often seems slow and repetitive.

headline: Repaying Home Equity Loans
text: Borrowers who opened home-equity lines of credit at the height of the housing bubble should brace for stiff increases in their monthly payments.

headline: At Wellesley, Debate Over a Statue in Briefs
text: BOSTON — When Sruthi Narayanan, a Wellesley College senior, first saw a nearly naked man who appeared to be stumbling on campus, she assumed he was a drunk, about to be arrested.

headline: One-Acts From Young Playwrights
text: Here in the 21st century, the Miser would have expected the two young gentlemen sharing his abode to be leagues beyond the analog board games that enriched the Miser’s childhood. Yet their Christmas lists included throwbacks like Battleship and Monopoly. There is obviously some lingering appeal to those flat, rectangular-boxed ensembles of cheap cardboard and plastic.

headline: Multiple Exposures, Looking Both Ways
text: PHILADELPHIA — In Michael Snow’s 45-minute film “Wavelength” (1967), the camera gradually zooms in on a wall in his studio. “Wavelength” is a classic of experimental cinema, but it ends with a photograph and might, in a way, be one. That interpretation is encouraged, at any rate, by “Michael Snow: Photo-Centric,” an engaging survey of his photography at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

headline: Mapping Clinton’s Trajectory
text: Many people who worked with Hillary Rodham Clinton, from low-level aides in the State Department up to President Obama, “found themselves liking her more with each interaction, even if they had been worked over,” the authors of “H R C” write. They quote a member of Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates’s inner circle, who somewhat patronizingly describes it as traversing the “stages of Hillary”: “You know, you first dread the prospect of working with her, then you sort of begrudgingly begin to respect her, then you outright respect her and her incredible work ethic. You know, she’s inexhaustible, she’s tough-minded, and then you come to actually start to like her, and you just can’t believe it, but you actually like this person, and she’s charming and she’s funny and she’s interesting and she’s inquisitive and she’s engaging.”

headline: Writing Was on the Wall, and Some Still Remains
text: Some of my most vivid memories from occasional visits to New York in the late 1970s and early ’80s are of the graffiti-covered trains roaring through the city’s subway system. With their giant, pneumatic, spray-painted letters spelling names like Crash and Daze against apocalyptic backgrounds, those unauthorized moving murals amazed me. I thought they were beautiful and inspiring.

headline: A-Team Tracks Nazi Plunder
text: And here we thought that George Clooney was this era’s Cary Grant even if, with his squinty smile and no-sweat insouciance, he’s really closer to Clark Gable. As it turns out, Mr. Clooney seems to have been harboring a desire to tap into his inner Gregory Peck — noble, stolid, dull — as he does in “The Monuments Men,” which he both directed and stars in. It was Peck who led the team of World War II Allied saboteurs in “The Guns of Navarone,” one of those men-on-a-mission movies, a subgenre that includes everything from “The Dirty Dozen” to the “Ocean’s Eleven” trilogy, which starred Mr. Clooney in a fizzier, less sanctimonious mode.

headline: Off the Runway
text: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Senate Confirms One of Its Own as Ambassador to China
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted 96 to 0 on Thursday to confirm Senator Max Baucus as the new ambassador to China.

text: Freestyle skiing, figure skating, and a new sport — slopestyle snowboarding — on the first day of competition at the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics.

headline: Olympic-ish Sport for Tyros Like Us
text: THE Winter Olympic Games are here, which means it’s time once again for couch-dwelling Americans not only to become instant experts in sports they barely knew existed, but also to ponder going out and trying them.

headline: Bryan Greenberg at Richard Chai
text: It was quite the heartthrob lineup at Richard Chai’s fall 2014 show at Lincoln Center on Thursday morning. Seatmates Zachary Quinto, Bryan Greenberg and Joe Jonas (the latter doing “no press”), slid into their front-row assignments a few minutes after 11 a.m. Perhaps Mr. Greenberg, dressed in a dark leather jacket with quilting details, was in familiar territory, having once worked in the fashion industry — well, on screen anyway.

headline: Did Mother, Maybe, Not Know Best?
text: After two decades of saying I would never get married, I did. I changed my mind one Sunday while sitting at my desk in front of my computer, as happily unmarried as ever.

headline: Giving and Forgiving
text: My wife and I are dear friends with a couple we cherish. At our son’s bar mitzvah last October, they approached my wife and told her they had forgotten their gift and would get it to us. When they came to dinner two weeks later, they had forgotten it again. We have seen them several times since, but the topic no longer comes up. We accept that they are never giving a gift; we love them anyway. Still, after every evening together, my wife points out the elephant in the room: “Still no gift.” How do we get past this, so it’s no longer on our minds? Should we say something?

headline: Eichmann’s Rabbi Gazes Backward
text: Perhaps the most haunting and enduring feature of “Shoah,” Claude Lanzmann’s nine-and-a-half-hour documentary — the closest thing to a definitive cinematic work on the Nazis’ mass murder of European Jews we are likely to have — is its dogged commitment to the present tense. Filmed mostly in the 1970s in some of the places where the killing was planned and carried out, “Shoah,” released in 1985, relies on face-to-face, after-the-fact testimony rather than archival footage or dramatic reconstruction. It is thus simultaneously about the imperative to remember and the inadequacy of memory. A masterpiece of historical detective work, the film is also a philosophical exploration of a gap that has only grown wider in the years since its release.

headline: This Is Your Captain Singing
text: Singing careers tend to follow a pattern: early study, conservatory, a young artists’ program, smaller parts, larger ones, little-known companies, famous ones. A soprano who does the Third Norn in Wagner’s “Götterdämmerung” might, if she’s lucky, eventually graduate to Brünnhilde.

text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Ex-Brokerage Executives Charged With Fraud
text: The owner and two executives of the WJB Capital Group were arrested on Thursday and charged with defrauding at least 15 investors out of more than $11 million during the waning days of their now-defunct brokerage company.

headline: Romantic Intensity, Replete With Trills and Flourishes
text: Even by the reliably high standards of the Young Concert Artists series, which has been promoting gifted young musicians since 1961, the performance on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall by the Ukrainian violinist Aleksey Semenenko proved particularly rewarding.

headline: Fashion Sketches and Cartwheel Practice With Betsey Johnson
text: When Betsey Johnson, the celebrated fashion designer who, at 71, still does cartwheels on the runway, has a show in the works, as she does on Feb. 12 for Fashion Week 2014 at Lincoln Center, her Sundays are overwhelmed by casting calls for models and by the sudden need for decorative detail like, say, gold lamé rose petals. “I’m in a total panic, with adrenaline and excitement,” said Ms. Johnson, who filed for bankruptcy in 2012 and was later bought out by her friend and fellow designer Steve Madden. On a more typical Sunday — “my day of nothing” — she is happy to do little more than kick around her neighborhood, the Upper East Side, or look after her granddaughters, Layla, 7, and Ella, 5, who live in her apartment building with Ms. Johnson’s daughter, Lulu.

headline: What I Love | Sarabeth Levine
text: The co-owner of the restaurants that bear her name lives with her husband on the Upper West Side.

headline: Where the Real Sarabeth Dines
text: Be prepared to ditch the brogues or stilettos before setting foot in Sarabeth Levine’s immaculate (and she wants to keep it that way) two-bedroom co-op on the Upper West Side.

headline: Threads in the Tapestry, Dark, Bright and Scratchy
text: In recent years, the Freiburg Baroque Orchestra, which originated as a conductorless period-instrument ensemble in 1987, has ventured beyond its original brief with well-received interpretations of 19th-century works, often in collaboration with noted conductors. Its performance of the complete Brandenburg Concertos by Bach at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday marked a return to its core mission. But the concert had a subdued quality in which fine solos could not make up for the overall lackluster sound and uneven performance.

headline: After a Bad Breakup, Anything Goes
text: Under its contemporary facade of buzzing cellphones and potty-mouthed insults, Bryan Poyser’s “Love & Air Sex” is a traditional romantic comedy that is desperate to please. Although the main characters, in their 20s and early 30s, communicate mostly via text message, often in sexually graphic detail, they are the same vulnerable relationship seekers they have always been but with extra mileage on their pedometers.

text: The most powerful performance at “Bringing Human Rights Home,” a benefit concert for Amnesty International at Barclays Center on Wednesday night, didn’t need drums or electric guitars.

headline: As Seen on TV, a Medical Mystery Involving Hip Implants Is Solved
text: By a strange coincidence, two leading medical journals on Thursday published case studies of the same arcane medical mystery. In one, doctors solved the riddle only after the patient, a middle-aged woman, got so sick she had to have a heart transplant. But in the other, a physician who teaches at the University of Marburg in Germany found the clues in Season 7, Episode 11, of the Fox television show “House.”

headline: Facebook and Football
text: The digital clench has never been stronger. This week, 10 years since the founding of Facebook, some new numbers showed just how much the social network produced in Mark Zuckerberg’s Harvard dorm has changed us all. Can I share?

headline: Veteran Actors To Dress Up For ‘Casa Valentina’
text: An lineup of theater veterans, including Reed Birney (“Picnic”), John Cullum (“The Scottsboro Boys”), Patrick Page (“Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark”), and Larry Pine (“The Designated Mourner”), will be among the ensemble cast in Harvey Fierstein’s new Broadway play “Casa Valentina” this spring, the producers announced on Thursday.

headline: Now They’ll Love Me, a Twin Sister Schemes
text: In “The Pretty One,” Jenée LaMarque’s first feature, Zoe Kazan plays identical twins of contrasting temperament. Audrey, alluded to in the title, has a cute haircut, fashionable clothes and an exciting life in a city that might be Los Angeles. (The film is too coy to be specific about such things.) Her sister, Laurel, mousy and odd, lives with their widowed father (John Carroll Lynch) in a rambling house in a quirky town where she helps him paint copies of famous artworks.

headline: There Can Be Frightening Things in the Canadian Woods
text: The Québécois director Denis Côté throws a tight frame around his characters in “Vic + Flo Saw a Bear,” nearly boxing them in. That makes sense for this funny-eccentric, funny-scary story of two female ex-cons who having once been holed up together in prison are now holed up in a house in the deep woods. There’s a once-upon- a-time feel to both the location and the movie, which had its premiere at the 2013 Berlin International Film Festival, where it won an award. The title may sound like a children’s book and the bear may be metaphoric, but make no mistake: This is a story with surprisingly great, big teeth.

headline: How to Stop Heroin Deaths
text: PHILIP SEYMOUR HOFFMAN, who died of an apparent heroin overdose on Sunday, was just one of hundreds of New Yorkers who fall victim to this drug each year. Heroin-related deaths increased 84 percent from 2010 to 2012 in New York City and occur at a higher rate — 52 percent — than overdose deaths involving any other substance.

headline: Shopping for a Bra With Betsey Johnson
text: “How do I look with breasts?” asked Betsey Johnson, holding a push-up bra clasped over her shirt in a Victoria’s Secret showroom. I took several photos in quick succession, suspecting that it would not be long before security asked me to stop.

headline: West Bank: U.N. Staff Ends Strike
text: The United Nations Relief and Works Agency, the body that provides assistance to Palestinian refugees, announced Thursday that a two-month strike by its 4,500 employees in the West Bank had ended. The strike, over pay and other issues, kept more than 50,000 children out of school, closed down free health services and raised tensions in the volatile refugee camps. The United Nations agency said in a statement that its director of operations in the West Bank and a representative of the area’s staff union had signed a document outlining measures to improve conditions for the staff, without elaborating. The statement praised the government of the Palestinian Authority for its mediation efforts and said the agency was “looking forward to the immediate resumption of all services.”

headline: Italy: Toxic Waste Law Enacted
text: In the first strong legislative response to the dumping crisis in the southern region of Campania, President Giorgio Napolitano signed an emergency law on Thursday to tackle environmental crimes and the damage produced by the illegal dumping or burning of waste. Under the new law, burning garbage without authorization is a crime punishable by up to five years in prison. In the vast area north of Naples where the Camorra mafia has buried toxic waste for decades, health and environmental authorities will have to carry out tests on the agricultural fields to measure the toxicity levels in the soil. Parliament allocated about $676 million for the cleanup, and police officers or soldiers will conduct antidumping patrols. The law includes measures to clean up the environmental damage produced by a steel plant in the southern city of Taranto.

headline: Highlights From Our Social Feeds at NYFW, Day 1
text: New York Times fashion reporters and editors describe day one of New York Fashion Week in 140 characters.

headline: France: Seized Ivory Destroyed
text: In an effort to deter poachers and traffickers, France publicly destroyed a stock of about three tons of confiscated ivory from the tusks of African elephants on Thursday, making it the first European country to take such a step. The ivory was crushed in a large machine at a ceremony at the foot of the Eiffel Tower presided over by Environment Minister Philippe Martin. The impounded ivory included 698 elephant tusks that the police had confiscated and stockpiled since the 1990s. The operation was part of President François Hollande’s plan to “send a clear and precise message” against poachers, traffickers and buyers and “to show the French government’s solidarity to African countries,” the Environment Ministry said. The United States and China, ivory’s biggest market, have also destroyed seized ivory to help stem the illicit trade that endangers the survival of the elephants.

headline: Officers and Office Workers Find an Oasis in National Grid Café
text: It looked like a casting call for “Law & Order: SVU.” Packs of police officers sat at long, white tables, chatting about arrests, ballistic tests and vacation time. Nearby, two fire dispatchers hurriedly ate meatloaf and pastrami while checking their phones. Other diners seemed to be standard-issue office workers, eating brown-bag lunches and drinking cups of coffee.

headline: Muchelney Under Water

headline: Accustomed to Floods, but ‘Nothing Like This,’ in Southern England
text: MUCHELNEY, England — The village of Muchelney has become an island. Cars stand idle; locals canoe across the flooded plain or take a police boat down the road-turned-river connecting them to what they now call the “mainland.” About halfway, a silver sedan bobs in the water, its roof barely protruding. It has been there for five weeks.

headline: Letting the Kids in on the Charitable Giving Conversation
text: Money is one of the most powerful tools we have to teach children the values and virtues we want them to adopt. Given how many of our own values are wrapped up in charitable giving, it makes sense to bring the kids in on some of the decision making.

headline: Why, Yes, This Is Going to Hurt
text: Opens on Friday.

headline: Uterine Surgical Technique Is Linked to Abnormal Growths and Cancer Spread
text: Concerns are increasing among doctors about the safety of a procedure performed on tens of thousands of women a year in the United States who undergo surgery to remove fibroid tumors from the uterus, or to remove the entire uterus.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: This Week's Movies: Feb. 7, 2014
text: The New York Times movie critics on “Vic + Flo Saw a Bear,” “The Lego Movie” and “The Last of the Unjust.”

headline: Iran Delivers Surprise, Money, to Jewish Hospital
text: TEHRAN — The brother of Iran’s president walked into Tehran’s only Jewish hospital on Thursday, delivering a surprise donation along with the message that the Health Ministry would give more attention to hospitals that traditionally serve Christian and Jewish Iranians.

headline: ‘There’s a Dark Cloud Over Our Sport’
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — When Don Catlin, the former head of the U.C.L.A. Olympic Analytical Laboratory, heard that three biathletes had tested positive for a “nonspecific substance” about a week before the Olympics, I could hear him sigh over the phone.

headline: Motion Is Filed to Silence Prosecutor in Sept. 11 Case
text: WASHINGTON — The defense team lawyers for one of the five Guantánamo Bay detainees charged with aiding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks are seeking to muzzle the chief military commissions prosecutor, saying that his comments defending the tribunals system — including in a recent “60 Minutes” interview — are unethical and that they are undermining their client’s right to a fair trial.

headline: Mad Daddy on a Mission
text: Opens on Friday.

headline: Caribbean Islands Agree to Swap Diesel Power for Renewable Sources
text: Several Caribbean nations committed on Thursday to start replacing diesel generators, the most common means of producing electricity on islands, with renewable sources like wind, solar or the earth’s heat.

headline: Richard Hayman, a Pops Concert Figure in St. Louis and Boston, Dies at 93
text: Richard Hayman, who began his career as a harmonica player and went on to become the conductor of pops concerts in St. Louis and the arranger of pops concerts in Boston, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: U.S. Issues Penalties Over Violations of Iran Sanctions
text: The Obama administration penalized nearly three dozen companies and individuals in eight countries on Thursday, accusing them of evading Iranian sanctions. It was the administration’s most extensive enforcement action to target Iran since a temporary international agreement on that country’s disputed nuclear program was completed in November and put into effect last month.

headline: Death in the Afternoon, Then Drinks
text: Between the fetid Gowanus Canal and the South Brooklyn Casket Company lies the Morbid Anatomy Library and Museum. Two thousand books, whose titles include “Corpses, Coffins and Crypts” and “Stuffed Animals and Pickled Heads,” share 200 square feet with inert squirrels, a fetal possum, a human skeleton and about 25 live visitors on any given Saturday afternoon.

text: Nine internationally renowned researchers from various fields will be welcomed on Friday as fellows of the Texas A&M University Institute for Advanced Study, part of a group that administrators have nicknamed the Genius Corps.

headline: Rene Ricard, Art Arbiter With Wildean Wit, Dies at 67
text: “I’ve never worked a day in my life,” Rene Ricard, then 32, wrote in an essay for The New York Times Op-Ed page in 1978. “If I did it would probably ruin my career, which at the moment is something of a cross between a butterfly and a lap dog.”

headline: Fingers Crossed, Marketers Count on Olympic Gold
text: THE many marketers spending an estimated $1 billion to sponsor and advertise during the Olympics in Sochi, Russia, are keeping their fingers crossed that the multiple issues threatening to overshadow the Winter Games — whether security, human rights, stray dogs or ramshackle accommodations — will not repel American consumers.

headline: Health, Work, Lies
text: On Wednesday, Douglas Elmendorf, the director of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, said the obvious: losing your job and choosing to work less aren’t the same thing. If you lose your job, you suffer immense personal and financial hardship. If, on the other hand, you choose to work less and spend more time with your family, “we don’t sympathize. We say congratulations.”

headline: Long-Haul Expansion by a Norwegian Carrier Upsets U.S. Airlines
text: Flying doesn’t come cheaply these days, particularly on long-haul flights across the Atlantic.

headline: ‘Invasion’ Remarks Fuel a Heated Debate in a G.O.P. Race
text: On immigration policy, there are no major differences between the Republican candidates running for lieutenant governor in Texas.

headline: Guatemala Court Rules to Curb Crusader
text: MEXICO CITY — Guatemalan politics were thrown into disarray on Thursday after the country’s highest court ruled that the crusading attorney general, Claudia Paz y Paz, must step down in May, seven months before her four-year term was to end.

headline: F.D.A. Tightens Rules on Infant Formula
text: The Food and Drug Administration updated safety requirements for producers of infant formula. The changes require companies to tighten their quality control procedures and reporting requirements. They also require that the companies meet so-called good manufacturing practices, which include testing for contamination from pathogens like salmonella. Most companies already meet those standards, but the rule will give the agency more control over enforcing them. The rule will also ensure that infant formula contains all federally required nutrients. The changes will be open to public comment for 45 days.

text: New York

headline: Luger’s Name Matches the One on His Waistband
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Bruno Banani is a German men’s underwear company. The brand, which features styles with colorful names like Booty Bass, Rusty Iron and Blockbuster (it can come as a G-string), is well known in Europe for its unusual marketing campaigns. The company has sent its garments underwater to the Bermuda Triangle, and in 1998, Russian astronauts wore the underwear aboard a space station.

headline: Other People’s Views
text: Let’s say you’re turning 40 and you realize you want to leave accounting and become a hip-hop artist. People will say you’re having a pathetic midlife crisis, but should you do it anyway?

headline: In Royal Drama, Spain Sees Its Reality Reflected
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Once upon a time, Spain’s Princess Cristina and her husband lived a life of royal splendor. Ensconced in a hillside mansion with a saltwater swimming pool outside Barcelona, they jaunted off to sailing regattas and charity balls with the Spanish elite.

headline: Events on Long Island for Feb. 9-15
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: A Bellows Painting Moves From Virginia to London
text: In 1920, students at what was then the Randolph-Macon Woman’s College in Lynchburg, Va., raised $2,500 to buy George Bellows’s “Men of the Docks,” a 1912 painting of workers milling around an ocean liner docked at the Brooklyn waterfront. It became the centerpiece of the college’s Maier Museum of Art.

headline: Brain-Dead, a Canadian Woman Remains a Silent Partner Awaiting Birth
text: OTTAWA — Nearly six weeks after a pregnant Canadian woman was declared brain-dead, she remains on life support in Victoria, British Columbia, because of her family’s hope that her fetus will mature enough to be delivered. The decision by Robyn Benson’s family to try to deliver her child has drawn growing attention in Canada, largely because of a series of moving blog posts by her husband, Dylan Benson.

headline: Counting Cars in a Comic Pileup
text: Coming soon to your iPhone (if you’re so inclined): the 70-millimeter Ultra Panavision Hollywood roadshow.

headline: Huge Leak of Coal Ash Slows at North Carolina Power Plant
text: A massive leak of toxic coal ash from a retired North Carolina power plant into a neighboring river dwindled on Thursday, utility officials said, but hundreds of workers had yet to seal the breach in a drainage pipe where the leak was detected more than four days ago.

headline: Three Sensational Deaths and Two Notable Lives
text: The manhunt evoked the Lindbergh kidnapping case; the debate over the insanity defense echoed Harry K. Thaw’s trial for shooting Stanford White; the principal actors included Thomas Dewey and the defense lawyer Samuel Leibowitz. The triple murder on Beekman Place in 1937 by Robert George Irwin has been largely forgotten, but it captivated America for months.

headline: A Moving Glass Box Conquers Uneven Terrain at a Subway Station
text: The first subway line of New York, the No. 1, burst from the ground at a place in Upper Manhattan called Fort George Hill around March 1904, having traveled two miles north, from around 158th Street, through solid rock.

headline: Past Fictions, a Lack of Trust and No Deal in SAC Case
text: The guilty verdict on Thursday against the former SAC trader Mathew Martoma only deepens a mystery about the case: Given the overwhelming evidence against him, why did he fight the charges of insider trading, risking a lengthy prison term, rather than make a deal with the government to cooperate in return for leniency?

headline: The Homogeneous Federal Bench
text: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, in a dissent from a 2007 Supreme Court decision that made it harder for women to sue employers for pay discrimination, suggested that the court’s majority was not in “tune with the realities of the workplace.” Her background as general counsel to the American Civil Liberties Union, where she had co-founded the Women’s Rights Project in 1972, surely informed her thinking. Unfortunately, that kind of experience is both less common and more controversial on the federal bench today. If she were being considered for a seat on the court these days, Justice Ginsburg told an audience in 2011, “my A.C.L.U. connection would probably disqualify me.”

headline: Taking Tobacco Off the Shelves
text: CVS Caremark, the giant drugstore chain, deserves a big round of applause for deciding to phase out the sale of cigarettes and other tobacco products at its more than 7,600 stores by Oct. 1. The decision will cost the company a substantial amount of money but will place CVS where it and other pharmacy chains belong — on the side of customer health and against a product that still kills 480,000 Americans a year.

headline: Taking Stand, Nagin Defends Acts as Mayor in New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS — C. Ray Nagin took the stand in his federal corruption trial on Thursday, and under both the genial guidance of his defense lawyer and the unyielding press of a federal prosecutor, defended his conduct as the onetime mayor of this city and insisted he never received bribes for awarding contracts.

headline: Amid Flow of Leaks, Turkey Moves to Crimp Internet
text: ISTANBUL — Shortly after an audio recording in which Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is said to be heard talking about easing zoning laws for a construction tycoon in exchange for two villas for his family, SoundCloud, the file-sharing site where it was leaked last month, was suddenly unavailable to Internet users in Turkey.

headline: A Spotlight on Mr. Putin’s Russia
text: The Olympic Games that open in Sochi, Russia, on Friday are intended to be the fulfillment of President Vladimir Putin’s quest for prestige and power on the world stage. But the reality of Mr. Putin and the Russia he leads conflicts starkly with Olympic ideals and fundamental human rights. There is no way to ignore the dark side — the soul-crushing repression, the cruel new antigay and blasphemy laws and the corrupt legal system in which political dissidents are sentenced to lengthy terms on false charges.

headline: Malaprops Were Part of the Charm of Kiner, an Enduring Met
text: Ralph Kiner had not called many Mets games in the past few years. He did not want to travel much. He was usually at afternoon games for a few innings, maybe 12 or 15 times a season.

headline: Environmental Groups Denounce Arrests of Ecologists Near Olympic Sites
text: SOCHI, Russia — The initial brunt of a police crackdown on protesters at the Winter Olympics — originally expected to target gay rights groups — has instead fallen on environmental activists.

headline: Behind Retreat on Immigration, a Complicated Political Interplay
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner would sorely like to help engineer an overhaul of immigration policy to bolster his legacy, help his party politically and address a difficult social and economic problem. He just cannot seem to persuade other Republicans, who see the immigration debate as a major threat to their drive to win the Senate and increase their House majority in November.

headline: Mother Pleads Not Guilty in Death of 2-Year-Old
text: On Jan. 23, Ashley Diaz stood in Queens Family Court with her five children, ages 2 to 10, as a judge reviewed her efforts in parenting classes and therapy sessions mandated by the court after an abuse and neglect investigation two years ago.

headline: On Blog, an Ex-Christie Ally Showed Approach to Politics
text: As Wally Edge, political blogger, David Wildstein was so anonymous that when he sold his company, the buyer did not know his real name.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 6, 2014
Designers Carve a Fashion Runway at the Games
text: Beyond the thrilling victories and agonizing defeats, the Olympics are a 16-day fashion show, even for fans blithely unaware that the United States Alpine skiing uniforms are meant to evoke the nation’s flag reflected in the water off Fort McHenry the morning after the British bombardment, 200 years ago, that inspired “The Star-Spangled Banner.”

headline: If You Stage It, They Will Come
text: Talk about your fantasy baseball team. Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, for starters. Plus Mickey Mantle and Joe DiMaggio. Add the catcher Elston Howard, the first black player on the New York Yankees roster, and throw in the team’s current captain, Derek Jeter.

headline: Fourth-Brightest Star in the Sky
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I struggled with this 66-worder by Ned White, but I wound up liking the struggle. I believe that’s why we have Friday puzzles, right? To both stretch your limits and entertain.

headline: Energy Role Is Lifting Democrat in Louisiana
text: Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, is set to become chairwoman next week of the Senate Energy Committee, a powerful position that gives her jurisdiction over the oil and gas industry that fuels her state’s economy — and which will be a major source of contributions to Ms. Landrieu’s tough re-election campaign this fall.

headline: Twitter Q. and A. on Olympic Preparations
text: A day before the 2014 Winter Olympics begin in Sochi, Russia, David Herszenhorn, a Times correspondent based in Moscow, answered readers’ questions via Twitter on preparations for the Games. He discussed the importance of security concerns, current U.S.-Russian relations and how those abroad could help Sochi’s threatened stray dogs.

headline: Bench Empty, the Lakers Are Saved by a Technicality
text: There were 3 minutes 32 seconds remaining in the Lakers’ game against the Cleveland Cavaliers on Wednesday when Los Angeles center Robert Sacre committed his sixth foul. Would the Lakers, who at the time had only five healthy players, be forced to play four on five?

headline: Abundance of Snow, Headache to Many, Is a Boon for Hundreds Without Jobs
text: Nadji Colon never saw snow until he arrived in the Bronx in his late 20s from his homeland, Puerto Rico. He found it slushy and unpleasant to pick his way through.

headline: In Hong Kong, an Unexploded Bomb Forces Evacuations
text: Hong Kong residents have a lot to contend with. Soaring real estate prices. High pollution levels. Political meddling from mainland China. And, in at least one pricey neighborhood famous for its racetrack, unexploded American ordnance from World War II.

headline: Trial Brings New Scrutiny of Self-Defense Laws
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Nearly seven months after a jury acquitted George Zimmerman, whose shooting of an unarmed black teenager made him synonymous with Florida’s so-called Stand Your Ground law, the state’s latest drama involving a fatal burst of gunfire and a claim of self-defense began to play out Thursday in a courtroom here.

headline: The Cohen Connections
text: The top hedge fund SAC Capital agreed to plead guilty to insider trading and pay a record $1.2 billion fine. At least eight current or former SAC employees have been convicted or pleaded guilty to insider trading.

headline: New Hampshire: Deal Reached on Medicaid Expansion
text: State senators said Thursday that they had reached a bipartisan deal on a framework to expand Medicaid to about 50,000 low-income adults. Under the agreement, the state will use federal money to buy private insurance, similar to a method adopted last year in Iowa and Arkansas. Last year, the New Hampshire House passed a bill to expand Medicaid, but the Senate failed to agree on expansion. The House voted again to expand Medicaid in January. The new deal will be drafted into a bill, which will probably be voted on in March. Gov. Maggie Hassan, a Democrat, praised the deal during her State of the State address on Thursday.

headline: Power Failures Are Still Widespread After Storm
text: More than 500,000 people in Pennsylvania and Maryland went a second day without electricity on Thursday as utilities scrambled to restore power after heavy ice felled trees and damaged electrical equipment. Utility companies in Pennsylvania said that about 446,000 customers had no power on Thursday afternoon, a day after a storm knocked out electricity to about 800,000 people. In Maryland, utilities said about 50,000 customers remained in the dark. The companies said most customers would have their lights back by Friday night.

headline: Vasil Bilak, 96, Dies; Czech Communist Encouraged 1968 Soviet Invasion
text: Vasil Bilak, a former Communist leader in Czechoslovakia who in 1968 encouraged the Soviet Union to invade his country to halt efforts for change that he saw as a threat to socialism, died on Thursday in Bratislava, Slovakia’s capital. He was 96.

headline: Streak Over, Rangers’ Focus Turns to Penguins, Then Sochi
text: The Rangers’ drive for a fifth straight victory stalled at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night as they fell to the Edmonton Oilers, 2-1, on Nail Yakupov’s goal with 1 minute 38 seconds to play.

headline: In Trail Blazers, Woodson Sees a Lot to Like
text: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson has had an aggravating season that could soon cost him his job. But amid everything that is going wrong with his team, he has found time to admire how the Portland Trail Blazers go about their business.

headline: Nets Keep Noses in Front Despite Fight From Depleted Spurs
text: The San Antonio Spurs had just 10 players dressed to meet the Nets on Thursday night, and before the evening was done, two of them had blood dripping from their broken noses. They were absurdly depleted, seemingly reduced to a B-list squad. But it hardly mattered.

headline: Past, Future or Alien?
text: “I’m a huge sci-fi nerd,” the curator Ginger Shulick says, “and I’ve been wanting to do an overtly sci-fi-themed show.” So she did. The exhibition, titled “Future/Past,” opens today at the Reverse gallery in Brooklyn and features works by a handful of global artists, some of them clearly speculative-fiction buffs themselves. “You can’t really tell if things are from the past, or if they’re alien or futuristic,” explains Shulick. “I like to present works that raise more questions than leave you with answers.”

headline: California Bill Would Require Antitheft Technology for Cellphones
text: A smartphone is sleek, compact and valuable, which makes it a perfect target for a thief. Californian lawmakers want to require cellphone companies to fix that problem.

headline: The Challenges of Running Responsible Supply Chains
text: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and headed the Council of Economic Advisers and the National Economic Council under President Clinton.

headline: Word of the Day | apolitical
text: apolitical •\ˌa-pə-ˈli-ti-kəl\• adjective

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 9 P.M. (Starz) BEFORE MIDNIGHT (2013) Nine years after rekindling a romance (“Before Sunset”) in Paris that began nine years before that (“Before Sunrise”) in Vienna, Celine (Julie Delpy) and Jesse (Ethan Hawke, above, with Ms. Delpy) are now in Greece, at the end of a summer vacation with their twin daughters (Jennifer and Charlotte Prior) and the son (Seamus Davey-Fitzpatrick) he left behind in Chicago. Jesse wonders if they could move from Paris to the United States to spend more time with his son. Celine sees his question as a demand to make it happen. And so they will fight about this — and the meaning of love, the nature of time and the difference between men and women — throughout the course of a day. “ ‘Before Sunrise,’ ‘Before Sunset’ and ‘Before Midnight’ are modest, charming movies that together add up to the great romantic epic of a generation defined, in the popular mind and our therapists’ offices, by hedged bets, easy ironies and perpetual confusion,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this trilogy from the director Richard Linklater. Celine and Jesse “can get on your nerves almost as much as they get on each other’s,” Mr. Scott added. “We have known them, and they have known each other, for a long time now, but we don’t know, from one moment to the next, what their future will be, or what it is that keeps them going. That kind of uncertainty, a scary fact of life, is something most movies avoid. We prefer the magical thinking of neat endings, tidy plots and clear character arcs. ‘Before Midnight’ is a wonderful paradox: a movie passionately committed to the ideal of imperfection that is itself very close to perfect.”

headline: Mark McMorris on Slopestyle
text: Snowboarding’s slopestyle event has been dominated recently by Mark McMorris, a 20-year-old from the flat plains of Saskatchewan, Canada.

headline: Ban on Liquids for Carry-Ons on Direct U.S.-Russia Flights
text: Passengers on nonstop flights between the United States and Russia have been prohibited from packing liquids, gels, aerosols or powders in their carry-on bags during the Winter Olympic Games in Sochi under a new directive issued by the United States Transportation Security Administration.

headline: Woodson Shows Frustration
text: A day after the Knicks lost their third straight game, Coach Mike Woodson reiterated that he felt the team was capable of making the playoffs. But he also showed some frustration.

headline: Corrections: February 7, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: Report Says North Korea Is Improving Missile Capabilities
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has made progress in expanding its main satellite launch site, apparently to accommodate larger rockets that outside analysts said the country was developing for its intercontinental ballistic missile program, an American research institute reported Thursday.

headline: That ‘Old Guy’? He’s Retired Now, Right?
text: Johnny Carson’s departure from the “Tonight” show in 1992 was an abdication. Jay Leno’s last show, on Thursday, was closer to a retirement party — a bittersweet send-off for a loyal executive pushed out after 22 years.

headline: Amid Raft of Chinese Financial Numbers, One to Watch Carefully
text: China’s slowing growth and sputtering industrial output have helped fuel a global fall in stock prices this year. Economists are divided on whether ballooning debt in the world’s second-biggest economy will trigger a full-blown financial crisis or whether China, as it has time and again, will manage to defy the pessimists and continue to outgrow its neighbors.

headline: A Homegrown Comic Con Highlights Growth in Local Comics Market
text: MUMBAI — In 2011, a group of comic book lovers in Delhi found it was too expensive to travel to the Comic Con fan conventions overseas and decided to hold their own event at home in the Indian capital.

headline: Criticizing the Vatican
text: The United Nations this week released a report sharply critical of the Vatican’s response to child abuse.

headline: Petition to Nullify Thai Election Is Rejected in Setback for Opposition
text: BANGKOK — A petition to nullify Thailand’s general election was rejected Friday on procedural grounds by the country’s ombudsman, a setback for the opposition Democrat Party, which is allied with protesters trying to overthrow the government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.

headline: Stranded Travelers Start ‘Riot’ at Airport
text: Holiday travel stress became too much for some of the 2,000 stranded passengers at an airport in central China, with some passengers smashing computers and causing a “riot,” the Global Times newspaper has reported.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Feb. 7, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Steel Maker ArcelorMittal Narrows Its Net Loss
text: LONDON — Not long after Lakshmi Mittal formed ArcelorMittal through the takeover of Arcelor in 2006, the financial crisis dragged global demand for steel sharply down, hitting the company’s European base particularly hard. ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, has been on the ropes ever since, running losses in some years and struggling with an outsize debt burden.

headline: Indonesia Grants Parole to Australian Woman in Drug Case
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The Indonesian government on Friday granted parole to an Australian woman whose conviction in 2005 for smuggling drugs into the Indonesian resort island of Bali caused a diplomatic row between the two nations and public outrage in her home country.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Teaching Creativity
text: In “Learning to Think Outside the Box,” Laura Pappano writes about how and why creativity has become an academic discipline. Use the article and the related slide show of student projects, above, to answer the questions below.

headline: Alex Webb Looks Back in Black-and-White
text: Alex Webb was a 23-year-old photographer in 1976 when he put his belongings in a New York darkroom and headed south in his beat-up Volvo, which doubled as his bedroom. His experiences led his meanderings, and he occasionally picked up assignments that financed his work.

headline: What Are Five Everyday Problems That Bother You, and What Can You Do About Them?
text: Do you hate it when you go into a public bathroom stall and the lock won’t work? How about when businesses you need close too early, or when umbrellas are more hindrance than help? What are some everyday problems, small or large, that really annoy you?

headline: Fashion Week Preview: Day 2
text: Fashion Week officially began Thursday — for proof, look no further than the legions mugging for street-style photographers in front of Lincoln Center — but Friday is the day when the action really revs up.

headline: Times Minute | Russian Olympic Fashion
text: Also on the Minute, Oprah Winfrey eyes the Broadway stage and the colorful life of the longtime Mets announcer Ralph Kiner.
