headline: In Signing Farm Bill, Obama Extols Rural Growth
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. — President Obama signed the $956 billion farm bill on Friday at Michigan State University, where he extolled the benefits of a thriving agricultural sector for the nation’s overall economy.

headline: Supporters Call for Investigation Into Death of Chinese Activist’s Father
text: Chinese human rights lawyers have raised questions about the death of an activist’s father who fell from a government building while under detention in late January. The authorities have told family members that Xue Fushun committed suicide by jumping from the fourth story of a procurator’s office building in the city of Qufu in the northeastern province of Shandong.

headline: Report Finds Growth in Agriculture Economy
text: The Council of Economic Advisers released a report on Friday highlighting the growth in the agriculture economy as President Obama is set to sign the farm bill.

headline: The End of Snow?
text: OVER the next two weeks, hundreds of millions of people will watch Americans like Ted Ligety and Mikaela Shiffrin ski for gold on the downhill alpine course. Television crews will pan across epic vistas of the rugged Caucasus Mountains, draped with brilliant white ski slopes. What viewers might not see is the 16 million cubic feet of snow that was stored under insulated blankets last year to make sure those slopes remained white, or the hundreds of snow-making guns that have been running around the clock to keep them that way.

headline: Without Scotland, Premier Says, Britain Would Be Less ‘Great’
text: LONDON — Marking the formal beginning of the British government’s campaign to preserve the United Kingdom, Prime Minister David Cameron made an emotional plea to Scots to vote in September to remain in the union, saying on Friday that without Scotland, Britain would be “deeply diminished.”

headline: A New Vision for ‘Prince Igor’ at the Met
text: It is common in contemporary opera for a director to update the setting of a story and impose some interpretive concept on a piece. Most directors do not go so far, however, as to reorder scenes, tweak the plot, excise whole ensembles and interpolate musical numbers from a different score.

headline: A Hotelier Corrects His Testimony on the Impact of the Affordable Care Act
text: Last week, The Agenda reported on a House committee hearing that examined a provision in the Affordable Care Act that requires companies with at least 50 employees to offer health insurance to any employee who works at least 30 hours a week. It appeared that a bill to raise that threshold to 40 hours, the Save American Workers Act, could be on a fast track to debate by the full House, and on Tuesday the legislation took a big step forward when it passed out of the Ways and Means Committee.

headline: Highlights: The Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony
text: The New York Times covered the Winter Olympics opening ceremony from inside of Fisht Olympic Stadium in Sochi — live as it happened, not on tape delay.

headline: A Virtual Airline, a Real Crash
text: Europe is full of small upstart airlines, and Manx2, which served eight destinations in Britain and Ireland, certainly seemed to be one of them. Its planes were emblazoned with its name. The flight attendants said, “Welcome aboard this Manx2 flight.” Even the headrests and pilots’ ties advertised the airline.

headline: A Guilty Verdict for Former SAC Trader
text: FORMER SAC TRADER CONVICTED OF INSIDER TRADING  |  A federal jury in Manhattan found Mathew Martoma guilty on Thursday of insider trading , culminating a case that prosecutors had never thought would go to trial in the first place. The case may be the last criminal case to emerge from a decade-long investigation of Steven A. Cohen and his SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund, Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. Mr. Martoma, who is married and has three young children, is expected to face a prison sentence of seven to 10 years.

headline: British Regulator Hires Former Goldman and UBS Executive
text: LONDON – The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain said Friday that it had hired a former managing director at Goldman Sachs and UBS as an adviser in its division that supervises wholesale banking and investment management.

headline: U.S. Issues Penalties Over Violations of Iran Sanctions
text: The Obama administration penalized nearly three dozen companies and individuals in eight countries on Thursday, accusing them of evading Iranian sanctions. It was the administration’s most extensive enforcement action to target Iran since a temporary international agreement on that country’s disputed nuclear program was completed in November and put into effect last month.

headline: Talking to Children About Consent
text: HAVING THAT TALK with your child — the one about sex, babies and putting some distance between those two things — can be daunting. Now, a string of high-profile sexual assaults on campuses has put the topic of consent on the table. Debra Herbenick, a sexual health educator at the Kinsey Institute at Indiana University, discusses the kinds of conversations parents should have with their children about sexual misconduct.

headline: Making Consent Cool
text: IN 1993, when Antioch College introduced its “ask first” policy — mandating that students solicit permission for every intimate advance, including kissing — the policy was widely derided.

headline: Stepping Up to Stop Sexual Assault
text: BYSTANDER INTERVENTION is so easy to grasp, even by the most inexperienced college freshman, that the program may well be the best hope for reducing sexual assaults on campuses. Mostly it is common sense: If a drunk young man at a party is pawing a drunk young woman, then someone nearby (the bystander) needs to step in (intervene) and get one of them out of there. Of course, that can be tricky at times.

headline: Syria Says It Will Stay in Peace Talks as Homs Evacuation Begins
text: ISTANBUL — The Syrian government announced on Friday that it would participate in next round of Geneva peace talks aimed at ending the country’s civil war, as civilians trapped in a rebel-controlled part of Homs, one of the conflict’s urban epicenters, began trickling out under a deal negotiated by the United Nations.

headline: If Cineastes Could Pick the Oscar Winners
text: In the run-up to the Oscars, prognosticators trip over themselves to divine the Academy’s choices — rather than, as cineastes might hope, showcase the most deserving performers and filmmakers of the year.

headline: Homeless and Too Tired for Food
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Payroll Data Shows a Lag in Wages, Not Just Hiring
text: For the more than 10 million Americans who are out of work, finding a job is hard. For the 145 million or so who are employed, getting a raise is even harder.

headline: Biden Shows Interest in Another Presidential Run
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said in an interview broadcast on Friday that he would run for president “if no one else” can fight for the domestic, economic and foreign policy issues he cares about and said he would decide by mid-2015.

headline: Apollo Profit Fell 36% in Fourth Quarter
text: Apollo Global Management was a big seller of its holdings last year, but that wasn’t enough to lift the private equity giant’s profit for the final three months of 2013.

headline: Desperate for Clean Air, Delhi Residents Experiment with Solutions
text: NEW DELHI — For some worried expatriates and Indians, the battle to keep pollution out of their homes and their lungs started well before renewed media coverage in the past weeks unofficially crowned New Delhi as the world’s most polluted city.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | January 2014
text: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it in one handy spot. For ideas on how to use this series in your classroom, visit our lesson “Teaching With ‘Teenagers in The Times.’ ”

headline: Objects | Temptation Arises
text: Introducing clutches and sandals so elegantly modern and quietly sexy that they seem downright practical.

headline: Now, the Sentencing for Martoma
text: The impressive streak of 79 insider trading convictions won by the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan now includes Mathew Martoma, who dealt directly with the hedge fund titan Steven A. Cohen. But the verdict is unlikely to bring prosecutors any closer to what is apparently their aim: to bring criminal charges against Mr. Cohen.

headline: Second-Order Journalism
text: Dave Weigel looks at the disastrous initial media handling of the CBO report — CBOghazi, hah! — and addresses one of my pet peeves: reporting that skips right past the actual policy issues to speculation about how they will play politically. I think of this as “second-order” reporting, and it’s almost always a bad thing.

headline: Car Seats Save Lives but Are Still Underused
text: More than 9,000 children under 12 died in motor vehicle accidents from 2002 to 2011, in many cases because they were not properly restrained in child seats or seatbelts.

headline: Mixed Messages in the Employment Data
text: It is generally wise to take individual jobs reports with a grain of salt. The data, as the economists say, are “noisy” – imperfect estimates subject to revision. But the jobs report for January might need an extra few shakes of the shaker.

headline: For the Sake of Argument: Writing Persuasively to Craft Short, Evidence-Based Editorials
text: Overview | How can writing change people’s worldview? How can it influence public opinion? How can it lead to meaningful action?

headline: Sticky Situations
text: David Glasner has a thoughtful post about wage stickiness, a favorite topic of mine. And he is partially right in suggesting that there has been a bit of a role reversal regarding the role of sticky wages in recessions: Keynes asserted that wage flexibility would not help, but Keynes’s self-proclaimed heirs ended up putting downward nominal wage rigidity at the core of their analysis. By the way, this didn’t start with the New Keynesians; way back in the 1940s Franco Modigliani had already taught us to think that everything depended on M/w, the ratio of the money supply to the wage rate.

headline: Rewards Program Tries Bitcoin
text: PointsHound, a website that rewards travel reservations with frequent-flier miles and hotel points, is using the virtual currency Bitcoinin its payout system.

headline: Leaked Recordings Lay Bare E.U. and U.S. Divisions in Goals for Ukraine
text: BERLIN — “Really Pretty Stupid” was the headline chosen by the august Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung on Friday to describe an editorial on the latest eruption between the United States and Europe, this time over who should take the lead in trying to calm the crisis in Ukraine, and how to do it.

headline: The North Carolina Story
text: I’ve just praised Dave Weigel for his take on CBOghazi, the media debacle over health reform and employment. Let me now give an example of how even someone as good and skeptical as Weigel can be (slightly) taken in by right-wing spin. In another fine piece on the health-employment link, Weigel mentions states with falling unemployment, including North Carolina — and appropriately is skeptical about claims for NC’s success. But not skeptical enough! In his footnote he writes:

headline: 36 Hours in Yangon, Myanmar
text: It’s Myanmar’s moment, and the country’s major city, Yangon (formerly Rangoon), is hoping to become Southeast Asia’s next boomtown. Diplomatic missions, business delegations and tourists have filled Yangon’s hotels since the country’s military government began transferring power to civilian leaders in 2011. The spotlight continues this year as Myanmar, also known as Burma, takes on the chairmanship of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. For now, though, as the road map for laws and reforms is being drawn, the city remains in a kind of urban time warp, still awaiting a much-needed capital infusion to fuel what it hopes to be its renaissance. Golden pagodas, colonial-era buildings, traditional shop houses and moldering jazz-age mansions form a low-rise fabric unique to Asia, the whole stitched together by tree-lined avenues swarming with buses and cars. While ethnic and religious tensions simmer along Myanmar’s borderlands, including in remote Rakhine State, where there have been recent outbreaks of religious violence, Yangon is far from these areas. Still, time will tell whether the city will reclaim its former status as a cosmopolitan capital.

headline: Deep Inside Baz Luhrmann’s Creative Chaos
text: Baz Luhrmann likes to say that his life is “a circus run like an army,” and to step into his boudoir is to begin to understand what he means. After noon on a Friday, the 51-year-old auteur is sitting up in bed, his lower half under the covers, silver hair and black T-shirt rumpled from sleep. His wife and frequent creative collaborator, Catherine Martin, known to everyone as C. M., lies curled beside him atop a flax-colored linen duvet. Four assistants occupy chairs around them, all holding laptops. Each of the young people who gather under Luhrmann’s big top has a fantastical back story, at least in his telling. One went to Eton and speaks perfect Chinese; another has a “grandpappy who created a little firm called the C.I.A.” All have areas of concentration — communications, for example, or “moving Baz through time and geography” — and all have been trained in “the Bazmark way,” which means that they carry portable tape recorders to capture his directives and strive always to anticipate his needs. Judging by their alert posture at this moment, something momentous is about to happen. The impish ringmaster is having a vision.

headline: Winter Superpower Gets Its Turn as Olympic Host
text: SOCHI, Russia — That the organizers here spent a record $50 billion — capital improvements and alleged baksheesh included — and did not quite get a finished product is difficult to fathom.

headline: All of the Pleasure. None of the Guilt.
text: A friend of mine made a resolution once: No more guilty pleasures. I assumed at first that he meant he would no longer indulge in, you know, the usual cultural indulgences: those movies, books, TV shows, albums, et cetera, that are unabashedly enjoyable (like Miley Cyrus’s “Wrecking Ball”) but that also confer a patina of guilt to the self-conscious cultural consumer even as he’s enjoying them (like Miley Cyrus’s “Wrecking Ball”).

headline: Cecily Strong Is Being Serious
text: You’re younger than “Saturday Night Live” itself. Were you a comedy nerd as a kid? Totally. I grew up on “S.N.L.,” doing all the sketches on the playground. A friend and I would play these Chicago newscasters that were actually just impressions of the Bears’ “Superfans.” Two 11-year-old girls with fake mustaches — we were joke stealers already.

headline: Pilgrims’ Progress
text: In A.D. 441, St. Patrick, Ireland’s patron saint, climbed the third-highest mountain in County Mayo and, according to legend, spent 40 days and nights fasting and praying at its summit. Modern pilgrims inspired by his example still flock to what is now known as Croagh Patrick. The Rev. Charlie McDonnell, a local priest, says that 50 years ago, most climbed the mountain on Reek Sunday, the last Sunday in July. But now, people visit the site every day. Some climb for spiritual reasons, barefoot and clutching rosary beads (Mass is celebrated frequently at the peak), others for their physical health. Even before St. Patrick’s famous ascent, the mountain was a pagan holy spot. “Patrick claimed the mountain for Christianity,” Father McDonnell says. “But we welcome everybody to the mountain. It is a sacred place.” Julie Bosman

headline: Reply All: The 1.26.14 Issue
text: PLANET HILLARY

headline: Sochi vs. Sacha Baron Cohen
text: Steven Yeun shares his character’s Michigan background; assessing veteran rom-com duos.

headline: The Business-Dinner Spy
text: We recently had a teamwork dinner with the head of our division. One of my employees placed his iPhone on the table and recorded the discussion without anyone else knowing. The next day he transcribed what everybody said as a way to hold management accountable for things we’d talked about working on. Was he obliged to get our permission in advance for the recording? NAME WITHHELD, SALT LAKE CITY

headline: Who Made That Planetarium?
text: “Late in 1924 there appeared something new under the sun, an apparatus that shows every object in the sky that is visible to the unaided eye, and in a most realistic manner,” wrote the scientist and educator Clyde Fisher a decade after the opening of the world’s first projection planetarium in Munich. “It matters not whether the audience be made up of children or adults, professional people or laymen, the emotional experience is always the same. When the light is gradually diminished bringing on the darkness of night in the dome, and the stars are ‘turned on,’ the audience gasps audibly in surprise at the breathtaking beauty of it.”

headline: U.S. Factory Report May Not Be as Dire as It Looks
text: WORLD markets, already nervous over possibly fragile emerging-market economies, tumbled early this week after a survey of manufacturers in the United States showed a surprising drop in the proportion of companies saying their business was improving. On Monday, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index fell more than 2 percent, suffering its worst day since last June.

headline: As Knicks Fall Back, Amar’e Stoudemire Finds New Vigor
text: The loss was only seconds old when Amar’e Stoudemire, a towel draped around his neck, approached Giannis Antetokounmpo for a congratulatory handshake and some unsolicited advice.

headline: In the Eye of the Beholder
text: This week we turn our gaze to love stories, a subject that brought together one of the odder but more distinguished pairings in the Book Review’s history. In 1988, in his review of Gabriel García Márquez’s “Love in the Time of Cholera,” Thomas Pynchon judged that García Márquez wrote “with impassioned control, out of a maniacal serenity.” Calling the book “shining and heartbreaking,” he added it to the ranks of novels that can “return our worn souls to us.”

headline: The Body Politic
text: It was six yards square and extravagantly swathed in purple and gold, from its velvet headboard and valance to its voluminous damask curtains. The Virgin Queen took it with her when she moved from one royal residence to the next, chased by winter drafts and the inevitable buildup of noisome effluvia emanating from the rudimentary sanitation of her privy. As Anna Whitelock’s “The Queen’s Bed” proves, there is still a new and fascinating vantage from which to consider Elizabeth I. While most historians of the period dissect the body politic, Whitelock doesn’t waste time in the halls of Parliament. Instead, she hastens straight to the boudoir of the queen who chose celibacy as a means of wielding power.

headline: Mash Notes
text: The Modern Love column in this newspaper is a guilty pleasure for the many and a source of bitter rejection for the few: Over the past nine years only some 350 columns have been published out of 50,000 submissions. Imagine the countless Sunday brunches over which the previous night’s bad date / marital sex problem / unanswered Match.com posting was miserably rehashed, only to be transformed into the most glittering of silver linings: By God, this would make a fantastic Modern Love piece! And then — the flurry of typing, the excited phone calls to friends, the pinching-myself byline — the other shoe drops.

headline: GoPro to Go Public
text: Updated, 11:32 a.m. | GoPro, the video camera maker favored by extreme athletes and everyday adventurers, said on Friday that it planned to go public.

headline: Bridled Vows
text: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Scenes From a Marriage
text: Visitors to the White House who seek out the well-known portraits of Jacqueline Kennedy and Nancy Reagan — ­eerie, El Greco-like elongations executed by Aaron Shikler — are sometimes surprised to have their attention arrested by Henriette Wyeth Hurd’s rendering of the far-less-chronicled Pat Nixon. The picture was created several years after the Nixons’ abrupt departure from Washington, and only for the sake of the subject’s daughters. The painted Mrs. Nixon seems stricken, ready to brim with tears. If the portrait could speak, it would most likely say what she herself did after the helicopter lifted off from the South Lawn on Aug. 9, 1974: “It’s so sad. It’s so sad.”

headline: Passages
text: Is the sexual self an essential thing — immutable? Or can the complex matrix of desire change? These questions are fundamental to ideas of behavior and morality. I find myself with a foot in both worlds, willing to argue either point of view. The theme of “Sex After . . . ” — how women’s sexual lives shift over time — is a significant one, rich with possibility.

headline: Love in the Time of Neuroscience
text: In “The Devil’s Dictionary,” Ambrose Bierce defined love as “a temporary insanity curable by marriage.” Enter Sue Johnson, a clinical psychologist and couples therapist who says that relationships are a basic human need and that “a stable, loving relationship is the absolute cornerstone of human happiness and general well-being.” To repair ailing partnerships, she has developed a new approach in marriage counseling called Emotionally Focused Therapy, or EFT, which she introduces in her new book, “Love Sense.”

headline: French Kisses
text: “I’ll be gone soon,” Gore Vidal told me, not long before he died. “Then Edmund White can be king.” Queen bee, perhaps?

headline: Le Mariage
text: “Elizabeth Patterson ­Bonaparte was an American celebrity,” ­Carol Berkin declares. Indeed, she was “perhaps the first of her era.” The extraordinary story told in this slim volume goes some way toward justifying that extravagant claim.

headline: Oops, There Goes Another Fall on the Ice
text: Conditions in New York City are prime for the antics of Buster Keaton and other masters of the pratfall. But as any number of orthopedists and emergency room doctors in the city can attest, most people do not share Keaton’s grace.

headline: A High-Water Mark for Women, in Retrospect
text: During the worst part of the credit crisis, women had more paid jobs than men for the first time, the Labor Department now says.

headline: Blythe Masters of JPMorgan Is Said to Decline Advisory Post
text: Updated, 7:13 p.m. |

headline: A Conversation on Tobacco and Coal Exports and Moral Responsibility
text: I sent my recent post on exports of life-shortening tobacco and dirty fossil fuels to a variety of climate and energy scientists and analysts and the result was an interesting email conversation that is excerpted below.

headline: Correspondence Course
text: How rewarding to perch on the shoulder of a character Barbara Pym might have conjured — a late bloomer who possesses “brickish stoicism” and brews tea on an Aga. So when the British author Deborah McKinlay takes us to “the depths of the English countryside, in a house that was an advertisement for the English countryside,” we recognize that a Lively voice — à la Penelope, that is — will be reporting with wry detachment and affection.

headline: You Must Remember This
text: Michele Zackheim’s books, like treasure hunts, send their narrators scuttling after hidden gems. In “Violette’s Embrace,” an artist travels to Paris to unearth secrets about the writer Violette Leduc. In “Einstein’s Daughter,” Zackheim herself goes abroad to investigate the mysterious fate of the scientist’s illegitimate daughter. And in her new novel, “Last Train to Paris,” an elderly New York journalist named Rose digs through an old trunk of papers that holds reminders of her past life and lost love.

headline: Still in Thrall
text: “Last night I dreamt I went to Manderley again.” You can probably hear the late Joan Fontaine’s clipped Anglo-American voice declaiming that line in Alfred Hitchcock’s “Rebecca,” the voice of a young woman recalling the strange, wearying and totally dysfunctional secrets that once lay in wait for her.

headline: Inside the List
text: L’Affaire: Some thriller writers pick a topic and stick with it, more or less: John Grisham writes about lawyers, Brad Thor writes about government agents. Then there’s Robert Harris. He’s hit the list with novels about imperial Rome and World War II, a contemporary political drama, an alternative history in which the Nazis have won the war and a financial thriller about a computer that goes rogue, Kubrick style.

headline: Recovering From Surgery, Wendy Whelan Postpones National Dance Tour
text: Wendy Whelan, the longtime New York City Ballet star who has been making a critically acclaimed foray into modern dance, announced Friday that she was postponing a national tour this spring because she needs more time to heal from hip surgery.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: ALL JOY AND NO FUN: The Paradox of Modern Parenthood,  by Jennifer Senior. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $26.99.) Examining, with bracing honesty and authentic wisdom, what it means to be a parent, Senior presents both interviews and research.

headline: Paperback Row
text: MISSING OUT: In Praise of the Unlived Life,  by Adam Phillips. (Picador, $15.) One of Britain’s foremost psychoanalysts explores the alternative lives “we could be leading but for some reason are not.” Drawing on his own clinical experience and the works of Shakespeare and Freud, D. W. Winnicott and William James, Phillips encourages us to live, as gratifyingly as possible, the life we have, rather than be haunted by the “myth of our potential.”

headline: Sidestepping the Risk of a Privacy Breach
text: This week, we reached the inevitable point in the controversy over the credit and debit card breaches where grim-faced retail executives from Target and Neiman Marcus, industry experts and consumer advocates turned up in Washington. They raised their hands and delivered well-rehearsed statements to our elected representatives.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Lego Movie,’ ‘The Last of the Unjust’ and ‘Vic + Flo Saw a Bear’
text: In this week’s video, Times movie critics share their thoughts on the Canadian drama “Vic + Flo Saw a Bear,” the animated “Lego Movie” and “The Last of the Unjust,” a documentary. See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Postal Service Reports a Decline in Losses
text: WASHINGTON — Aggressive cost cutting and increased revenue from its packing and shipping business helped the Postal Service stem its losses in the first quarter of its fiscal year, which ended Dec. 31.

headline: 64th Berlinale Kicks Off With Premiere of ‘The Grand Budapest Hotel’
text: BERLIN — The 64th annual Berlin Film Festival opened here on Thursday evening with the gala world premiere of Wes Anderson’s “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” a tender, urbane caper movie set in an imaginary world of interwar Eastern Europe starring Ralph Fiennes and inspired by the Austrian writer Stefan Zweig (1881-1942) and the films of Ernst Lubitsch (1892-1947).

headline: Entering the Era of Private and Semi-Anonymous Apps
text: Today’s Web-enabled gadgets should come with a digital Miranda warning. “Anything you say or do online, from a status update to a selfie, can and will be used as evidence against you on the Internet.”

headline: I Was a Tonya Harding Look-Alike
text: In 1994, I looked exactly like Tonya Harding. Would you have agreed? Doesn’t matter. Because the ultimate decision rested with an expert team of celebrity-look-alike judges assembled by Geraldo Rivera. Let’s put it this way: Twenty years ago, one Tonya did bring home the gold; it is cheap plastic and somewhere in my children’s dress-up box. And it symbolizes the era of my life that, if Olympic judges scored for weirdness, would nail a perfect 6.0.

headline: Hamptons House: Make Mine New
text: In the Hamptons, where million-dollar vacation homes are snapped up like flea-market finds and $10 million spec homes are in such high demand that their developers could moonlight as fortunetellers were they not so busy building more, buying new has become not only the fashion but the first choice. Buying vintage tends to spawn repair and renovation headaches; choosing turnkey promises convenience and five-star amenities.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Todd Snyder Fall/Winter 2014

headline: Boycotting Israel and the First Amendment
text: Common sense, and maybe a renewed appreciation for first principles, seems to be stymying dangerous legislation that would undermine free speech in a misguided attempt to appear pro-Israel.

headline: Highlights From the Chicago Auto Show
text: With the Detroit auto show already growing smaller in the rearview mirror, the next big show of the 2014 season is underway in Chicago. The noticeably confident Detroit automakers may have received most of the attention at the show in their hometown, but this week, on the other side of Lake Michigan, the spotlight was on foreign manufacturers.

headline: Employment’s Decline, for Men of All Ages
text: Men who graduated from high school between 1982 and 1986 were victims of bad timing. They entered their prime working years during a period of slow growth. By January 1994, only 83.3 percent of men 25 to 29 years old were working.

headline: River of Fundament | Matthew Barney
text: Matthew Barney's latest film was inspired by the mythology of ancient Egypt as imagined by Norman Mailer's historical novel, “Ancient Evenings.”

headline: One-Wok Meals
text: Last week my impulse purchases at the farmers’ market included a lush bunch of red chard and a beautiful bunch of golden beets with the greens attached. Normally I use these vegetables in Mediterranean dishes – you have seen many of them in Recipes for Health – but I was craving stir-fries.

headline: Helmets: Because Their Thick Skulls Aren’t Thick Enough
text: If you make your kids wear helmets when they’re sledding and ice skating, not only will they better resemble all the gnarliest lugers and hockey players in the coming Olympics, but also, more important, you’ll be helping to change the culture. And, most importantly, my children will therefore be less mad at me about having to wear them.

headline: Keeping Swindlers Out of Your Bank and Brokerage Accounts
text: Data breaches at Target and Neiman Marcus were certainly scary. Personal information from tens of millions of people fell into the hands of cybercriminals.

text: From Berlin in 1936 to Sochi in 2014, the Olympic Games are not just an athletic stage but a political one, The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus explains.

headline: The Effect Crowdfunding Has on Venerable Nonprofits Raises Concern
text: THE ads ran for years. The global charity Save the Children  asked for a monthly donation, and in return, a few times a year the donors received a photo and handwritten note or drawing from children in impoverished places like Haiti.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Vic + Flow Saw a Bear’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Vic + Flo Saw a Bear.”

headline: Sexy Beast
text: Summoning Norman Mailer, Egyptian mythology, an oboe-playing porn star and one dead cow, Matthew Barney creates “River of Fundament,” a baroque and no less baffling art-world spectacle.

headline: Paul Taylor Dance Company to Begin Lincoln Center Run With $6 Tickets
text: It is the greatest bargain in modern dance: the Paul Taylor Dance Company is celebrating its 60th anniversary with a special performance at Lincoln Center at which all tickets will be only $6 — less than the cost of a child’s or senior’s movie ticket in Manhattan.

headline: Book Review Podcast: A Sentimental Education
text: As part of the Love Stories issue of The New York Times Book Review, writers in a variety of genres share the books that taught them about love — and a few that led them memorably astray. Hilary Mantel writes:

headline: Too Much Winter, and Not Nearly Enough Propane
text: EASTABOGA, Ala. — In the midst of one of the great natural gas drilling booms in the nation’s history, millions of Americans are struggling with a problem that is chilling their bones.

headline: Senate Seat of Baucus Is Filled in Montana
text: DENVER — The Democratic governor of Montana appointed the lieutenant governor on Friday to fill the Senate seat left open by the departure of Senator Max Baucus, a move Democrats hope will improve their chances of retaining the seat in what is expected to be a fiercely fought election this November.

headline: Deception Foils Attempt to Hijack Turkish Jet to Sochi
text: ISTANBUL — A passenger aboard a commercial airline flight from Ukraine to Turkey tried to hijack it to Sochi, Russia, on Friday after the Winter Olympics started. He threatened to set off a bomb with a cellphone if his demands were not met, but the crew fooled him — and the other passengers — into thinking the plane had landed in Sochi when it was actually in Istanbul, passengers and the authorities said.

headline: Emma Oak Transforms Backstage at Creatures of the Wind
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Emma Oak before (left) and after (right) makeup by James Boehmer and hair by Odile Gilbert.

text: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain made a plea to the people of Scotland to choose to remain part of the United Kingdom.

text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Last of the Unjust.”

text: Celebrities and locals gathered at the funeral in Manhattan.

headline: Peter Som: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: Young Thug as Vocal Stylist
text: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss Young Thug and the hip-hop tradition of irreducible voices.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 1
text: Berluti opened Madison Avenue flagship; Target collaborated with Peter Pilotto; Vince toasted IPO; Todd Snyder hosted after party.

headline: Tightrope for a Bad Boy Made Good
text: What happens to the outlaw after he is embraced by the mainstream? It’s a recurring question in American culture, from “Huckleberry Finn” to Kurt Cobain. Eric Church’s fourth studio album, “The Outsiders,” is the follow-up to “Chief,” from 2011, which took him to No. 1 on the country charts and won the Country Music Association’s album of the year award. The new record, which EMI Nashville will release on Tuesday, represents a reaffirmation of his independent spirit in the face of an increasingly homogenized Nashville sound.

headline: Popcast: Young Thug as Vocal Stylist
text: “Black Portland,” the new mixtape by the Atlanta rapper Young Thug and Bloody Jay, is full of southern cadence, trap beats, rhymes about cars and women, and mid-oughts Lil Wayne spaciness. But it’s more full of something else: Young Thug’s voice, which goes high and low, very young and very old. It sings and growls and yelps and moans and wobbles and articulates words or leaves them half-formed.

headline: Caught Between Cutie and the Boxer
text: In an Oscar field dominated by films that address weighty questions of international politics, Zachary Heinzerling’s “Cutie and the Boxer” is a bit of an outlier in the feature documentary category. Much of the film was shot in a messy apartment-cum-studio in Brooklyn, and it focuses not on upheaval or genocide but on Ushio and Noriko Shinohara, a pair of Japanese artists who are also husband and wife.

headline: Movie Review: 'The Lego Movie'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Lego Movie.”

headline: A White-Shoe Firm Unbuttons
text: Eliot and John W. Cross were the perfect patrician designers, brothers born into a family with plenty of money and social standing. They put their Ivy League and Beaux-Arts connections into play in 1907, and quickly gained a practice in discreet townhouses, clubs, country houses and jewel-like banks, all shown in the luxuriously illustrated monograph on their work, “New York Transformed — The Architecture of Cross & Cross,” by Peter Pennoyer and Anne Walker (Monacelli Press, 2014).

headline: On Amazon, Pilots — and Potential — on View
Why Europe’s Job Picture Looks Different
text: A theme often heard on this side of the Atlantic about the world’s Great Recession and its faltering recovery is how American policy has been more effective than Europe’s, which has been hitched to an expensive currency and shackled to a set of austere economic policies that served nobody but Germany.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Stomach Bug Solved!
text: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 70-year-old woman with 10 days of gastrointestinal distress that was just like an episode she had had four years earlier.

headline: Wheelies: The Carrot and Stick Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: A Meeting That Couples Often Find Daunting
text: With Valentine’s Day just ahead, now may be a good time to consider some of the more difficult things we do for love. Meeting the future in-laws is among the most daunting of those tasks, and since many of these meetings occur in the winter months, often a chilly one, too.

headline: Asphalt Orchestra Aims to Record Its Interpretation of a Pixies Album
text: The Alarm Will Sound orchestrations of the Beatles’ “Revolution 9” and works by Aphex Twin and the Shaggs have long been among the most surprising scores to turn up in a classical music ensemble’s programming. But they may soon have company: Asphalt Orchestra, a quirkily eclectic 12-piece wind, brass and percussion ensemble that performs as a post-modernist marching band, is hoping to record its own version of “Surfer Rosa,” the Pixies’ influential debut album, released in 1988.

headline: Coke and Einhorn Take Opposite Sides of Green Mountain Bet
text: Betraying its renowned jingle, Coca-Cola is singing in perfect disharmony with David Einhorn. To feel good paying nearly $1.3 billion for a minority stake in Green Mountain Coffee, the beverage giant must have answered some nagging questions posed by the hedge fund manager a few years ago. Investors seem to figure that Coke did its due diligence. Procter & Gamble and Hewlett-Packard have shown just how much that can matter.

headline: Coming to Trafalgar Square: An Unusual Horse and a Giant Thumb
text: LONDON — A skeletal, riderless horse by Hans Haacke and a giant thumb by David Shrigley are the winning proposals for 2015 and 2016 for the Fourth Plinth commissions in Trafalgar Square. The annual award, funded by the mayor of London and chosen by a commissioning group,  allows artists to propose a sculpture for the vacant plinth, built in 1841 to carry an equestrian statue of King William IV but left vacant until 1998, when this project began.

headline: Portrait of an Army Family
text: “Some give some, and some give more. Some have no clue to what they’re really fighting for,” Kristin Pruett sang at her home piano in Boise, Idaho, recently. She tape-recorded her holiday tribute to the family of veterans she’d married into, and put it online with photos.

headline: Once You’re On the No-Fly List, It’s Hard to Get Off
text: Rahinah Ibrahim’s nine-year journey to clear her name with the U.S. government may be nearing an end.

headline: Big Moments on Campus
text: Jack Begg, supervisor of news research at The Times, traces the nation’s history through its centers of learning.

headline: Final Decisions
text: CONGRATULATIONS. You’ve been accepted to more than one college. Now comes the hard part: deciding which to go to. Make a mistake and you could be repeating the whole application process again next year — to transfer out.

headline: The Man With Nerves Like Sewer Pipes
text: OVER THE LAST 33 YEARS, E. Gordon Gee has presided over an astounding five universities — Ohio State, Vanderbilt, Brown, West Virginia (twice) and Colorado. But Dr. Gee, 70, has a habit of getting in trouble — comparing his job at Ohio State to running the Polish Army, calling the fathers at Notre Dame “holy on Sunday, but holy hell the rest of the week.” He has come under fire for his high compensation (he made nearly $2 million at Ohio State) and his high-flying expense account. (His response: If he’s not worth it, fire him.) Still, Dr. Gee, named Time magazine’s top college president in 2009, is a constant presence on state and national policy commissions. He is finishing a book on the politics of higher education, and after stepping down at Ohio State on July 1, he’s back in office — last month, he became interim president of West Virginia University, where he served as president in the 1980s.

headline: Love, Actually
text: I RECENTLY OVERHEARD two students talking in a dining hall at the university where I teach. “Yeah, I might get married, too,” one confided. “But not until I’m at least 30 and have a career.” Then she grinned. “Until then? I’m going to party it up.”

headline: Adderall and Academics
text: PRO BASEBALL PLAYERS and cyclists have nothing on college students come exam time, when the demand for performance-enhancing stimulants, from Red Bull to Adderall, skyrockets.

headline: Sponsored by the Letter B…
text: GRADE INFLATION has returned as a hot point at the nation’s top colleges (or maybe they just have darn good students).

headline: Investing (More) in Daughters
text: TO THE LIST of expenses that make raising a girl pricey — clothes, makeup, smartphones — add one more item: education.

headline: Doctoral Cachet
text: WHAT DO Ph.D.’s have in common with car mechanics? We knew you were wondering. So we asked.

headline: Dancing With the Book Carts
text: WHAT SPORT demands the precision of synchronized swimming and the book smarts of a librarian?

headline: A Look at Korea’s Culture From the Bathhouse
text: My friend Arcadia Kim has three children and a Harvard business degree, but when she tried to negotiate on our behalf with the lady in charge of exfoliation at the Dragonhill Spa in Seoul, she did not stand a chance.

headline: Feasts for the Eyes, and the Palate, in Xian, China
text: On the “Muslim Street” in the Chinese city of Xian stands a bronze tableau in honor of street food. There, on a crowded lane packed with stalls selling Islamic-Chinese cuisine — lamb dumplings, mutton soup, pancakes and mung bean noodles — tourists can pose with statues of a soup seller and his customers. It’s a photo opportunity that brings together Xian’s two most famous tourist drawing cards: life-size human replicas and superb dumplings.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Second Cut to Junk Debt
text: Updated, 7:35 p.m. | Moody’s Investors Service downgraded Puerto Rico’s general-obligation debt to junk status on Friday, intensifying a cash squeeze on the island and prompting some residents to blame hard-nosed creditors for their mounting troubles.

headline: Lacking a House, a Senator Is Renewing His Ties in Kansas
text: DODGE CITY, Kan. — It is hard to find anyone who has seen Senator Pat Roberts here at the redbrick house on a golf course that his voter registration lists as his home. Across town at the Inn Pancake House on Wyatt Earp Boulevard, breakfast regulars say the Republican senator is a virtual stranger.

headline: Tanya Taylor: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: Weekend Reading: Sochi Olympics vs. Wall St.
text: If you prefer CNBC to NBC Sports, check out DealBook’s alternative programming guide to the Winter Olympics.

headline: Prepaid Debit Cards May Augment Bank Accounts
text: PREPAID debit cards are often thought of as an alternative for people who can’t qualify for traditional checking accounts, since you typically don’t have to undergo a credit check to get a prepaid card.

headline: A Policy Response to Job Market Weakness
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: U.S. Charging Coal Companies Too Little for Land, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — Some coal mining companies are paying lower-than-market rates to lease land from the federal government, while also enjoying low royalty rates, increasing their profits at the expense of taxpayers, investigators for the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee have found.

headline: Big Ticket | A Grand-Scale Restoration Yields $51 Million
text: An imposing Upper East Side mansion that underwent a flamboyant renovation after being gutted by a fire in 2006 and was rumored to be available for $52 million in 2009 has sold, quietly, for $51 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Monochromatic, but Many Folds
text: The British artist David Musgrave had his first solo show at Luhring Augustine in 2009, and now that gallery is mounting another, with new work that includes drawing, sculpture and digital animation. This time around, Mr. Musgrave has worked in a larger format for some of his drawings, whose subjects “resemble discarded sheets of board or paper that have been torn, creased, faded, stained or scored with a blade,” the gallery said.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Prince Igor’ at the Met
text: Ildar Abdrazakov sings the title role in this scene from a recent dress rehearsal.

headline: Relationship Repair for Valentine’s Day
text: For those whose Facebook relationship status reads “it’s complicated,” the Wolcott Hotel in New York may have an appropriate Valentine’s Day getaway package. Taking a practical approach to the holiday, the Wolcott is offering an “On the Mend” deal this month aimed at couples who want some big city amusements while sorting out a troubled relationship.

headline: A Steady Hand in Uncertain Times
text: The great Bernard Haitink, who turns 85 on March 4 and is celebrating his 60th season as a conductor, is a fixer, with a gift for swooping in at troubled times for major ensembles. He steadied the Chicago Symphony Orchestra before Riccardo Muti’s arrival as music director in 2010; he was also the principal guest conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra from 1995 to 2004, then played a key role in recent years as it faced a future without James Levine.

headline: Farewell Jeté to a Long Career
text: What City Ballet fan doesn’t love Jenifer Ringer, and who won’t be sad to learn that she is retiring from the company? Gentle, lyrical, romantic and, above all, able to infuse her dancing with a rare warmth and humanity, Ms. Ringer, with her oval face, dark hair and eyes, looks like every little girl’s idea of a ballerina. She was picked out as particularly promising soon after joining City Ballet at 17, in 1990, and promoted to soloist by 1995. But at 23, she left City Ballet, plagued by depression, injury and weight issues.

headline: Singing Jazz for Lovers
text: Valentine’s Day has become a red-letter day for elite jazz singers in Manhattan. This Friday, options include Dianne Reeves, who has a new release suited to the occasion, at the Rose Theater; Gregory Porter, who just won the Grammy for best jazz vocal album, at Town Hall; and Tierney Sutton, a polished songbook interpreter, at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola.

headline: Tax on Austrian 'Champagne' Has High Society Fuming
text: VIENNA — Just when it seemed that Austria was surviving Europe’s financial crisis unscathed, austerity has hit — in the form of a tax on sekt, the country’s version of Champagne.

headline: Immigrant’s Tale, Without Clichés
text: One of last year’s quiet surprises was “Mother of George,” a film by Andrew Dosunmu about a Nigerian couple in Brooklyn who, as the story begins, are being wed in a ceremony full of echoes from their homeland. But the opening joy gives way to stresses as the couple (played by Danai Gurira of “The Walking Dead” and Isaach De Bankolé) have trouble conceiving the child they are expected to produce.

headline: Sex and ... O.K., Just Sex
text: As soon as a buxom blonde squeaks down a stripper pole, it’s pretty evident that there will be nothing remotely ladylike about this ladies’ night out. In “Jenny McCarthy’s Dirty Sexy Funny,” on Friday night at 11 on Epix, Ms. McCarthy — her gift for raunch on full display — tackles the plight of the modern woman with backup from the comedians Justine Marino, Tammy Pescatelli, Lynne Koplitz, Paula Bel and Tiffany Haddish.

headline: ’70s Photorealism: Revived and Still Relevant
text: Photorealism was one of the major movements in American art of the early 1970s. A natural offshoot of Pop Art and heir to one-man movements like Edward Hopper, photorealist paintings depicted the postwar American landscape, highlighting Vietnam War pessimism and the plight of working-class people in the recession-era ’70s. The gritty realism of these painters mirrored the films of directors like Barbara Kopple, John Cassavetes or Robert Altman, or the minimalist fiction of Raymond Carver and Jayne Anne Phillips.

headline: Crossing Class Lines for Love, Again
text: Attention, “Downton Abbey” fans: Lady Sybil Crawley is alive and well and living in New York. Or at least someone uncannily like her. In the film “Winter’s Tale,” opening Friday, Jessica Brown Findlay, her ravishing tresses and plummy vowels intact, portrays Beverly Penn, the high-spirited consumptive daughter of an early-20th-century mogul. Colin Farrell plays the thief who breaks into her mansion to steal the silver — and absconds with her heart. And Russell Crowe, rejoining Akiva Goldsman — the writer for “A Beautiful Mind,” making his film directorial debut — is the gangster intent on putting their love asunder.

headline: For a Sage Tenor, It’s All in the Timing
text: “I don’t have more than this one life,” the tenor Jonas Kaufmann said in a recent conversation at the Metropolitan Opera. “I don’t have more to offer. And I’ve still got a family that I, from time to time, need to see. And that’s a problem.”

headline: Their Time Is Now
text: On a recent Sunday afternoon, David O. Russell, the director and screenwriter whose most recent film, “American Hustle,” is nominated for 10 Academy Awards, including best picture, best director and best original screenplay (which he co-wrote), arrived at the Beverly Hills home of the fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg like a gentleman caller with something to prove.

headline: Molding a Troupe to His Footprint
text: “I do miss it. It’s a wonderful thing to be a dancer,” the former American Ballet Theater principal Ethan Stiefel said recently, in an uncharacteristic moment of quasi-wistfulness. Mr. Stiefel was speaking by phone from Wellington, New Zealand, where, since September 2011, he has been the artistic director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet.

headline: Olympics Opening Ceremony Offers Fanfare for a Reinvented Russia
text: SOCHI, Russia — With an outsize extravaganza that reached deep into the repertory of classical music and ballet, traversed the sights and sounds of the world’s largest geopolitical expanse, soared into outer space and swept across millenniums of history in a celebration of everything from czarist military might to Soviet monumentalism, a swaggering, resurgent Russia turned its Winter Olympic aspirations into reality on Friday night.

headline: Pope Francis’ Harley-Davidson Sells for $327,000 at Paris Auction
text: PARIS — A private buyer on Thursday purchased Pope Francis’ 2013 Harley-Davidson Dyna Super Glide for about $327,000 at a Bonhams auction in Paris. The price far exceeded the $16,000 to $22,000 presale estimate.

headline: The Gun Report: February 7, 2014
text: In November 2012, Michael Dunn fatally shot Jordan Davis, 17, following a spat over loud music at a Jacksonville, Fla., gas station. Davis and three friends had stopped for gum and cigarettes, and Dunn, who was sitting in his Volkswagen, asked the teens to turn down the bass-heavy music blaring from their car. A verbal back-and-forth ensued, and Dunn opened fire into the car, hitting the victim three times. He then exited his car and fired off another half-dozen rounds. Dunn claims he saw a gun in Davis’s car, but a subsequent search turned up a basketball, some clothing and a camera tripod.

headline: Would You Lie for Me?
text: WHAT is the chance that you could get someone to lie for you? What about vandalizing public property at your suggestion?

headline: Through Russia, With Love (and a Few Leaks)
text: The 4-wheel-drive Lada Niva may be the closest thing to an automotive version of the Russian soul, as a 1,000-mile drive from Moscow to Sochi attests.

headline: Sochi or Bust: Have Niva, Need Hammer
text: SOCHI, Russia — Vlad Ketkovich, a documentary producer from Moscow, picked me up outside Domodedovo International Airport in a 4-wheel-drive, 4-door Lada Niva. He had rented that car in the belief that it is the closest thing to an automotive version of the Russian soul, and by far the best vehicle for the long drive ahead.

headline: Emotions Churning Under Armor
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Veena Sud, the creator of the dark television procedural “The Killing,” remembers first hearing about Joel Kinnaman when her casting team told her that a “phenomenal” actor from Sweden had put himself on tape. “The minute I clicked on the link, I knew we found Holder,” Ms. Sud said of the rumpled, soulful homicide detective Mr. Kinnaman plays on “The Killing.” “He felt like a real guy, edgy. And he had amazing tats.”

headline: Gramercy Park Condop, Man-Cave Included
text: A sophisticated ninth-floor aerie with panoramic views of historic Gramercy Park from its loftlike great room, which has a 22-foot expanse of floor-to-ceiling windows facing south, is poised to enter the market at $8.75 million.

headline: Modern Dishes, Served Fireside
text: When February’s deep freeze sends us looking for a snug spot with a fireplace and hearty food and friendly people to tend us, the Tack Room at Peter Pratt’s Inn will do quite well. This cellar room, in a mid-18th-century house, flaunts its age: A whitewashed stone foundation supports a dark ceiling of hand-hewn beams, but the tables are dressed in white linen finery and nosegays of full-blown white roses, soothing reminders that spring is less than six weeks away.

headline: Exclusive | 50 Gramercy Park North
text: A ninth-floor condop with panoramic views of Manhattan’s historic private park is about to enter the market at $8.75 million.

headline: ‘Aid in Dying’ Movement Takes Hold in Some States
text: DENVER — Helping the terminally ill end their lives, condemned for decades as immoral, is gaining traction. Banned everywhere but Oregon until 2008, it is now legal in five states. Its advocates, who have learned to shun the term “assisted suicide,” believe that as baby boomers watch frail parents suffer, support for what they call the “aid in dying” movement will grow further.

headline: Leno’s Farewell Drew More Than 14 Million Viewers
text: Jay Leno pumped his ratings muscles one last time for NBC Thursday night, ending his 22-year run as the “Tonight” show host with a huge audience of 14.6 million viewers.

headline: Maxine Kumin, Pulitzer-Winning Poet With a Naturalist’s Precision, Dies at 88
text: Maxine Kumin, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet whose spare, deceptively simple lines explored some of the most complex aspects of human existence — birth and death, evanescence and renewal, and the events large and small conjoining them all — died on Thursday at her home in Warner, N.H. She was 88.

headline: François Hollande: Casanova or Lout?
text: François Hollande is acting liberated now that he has dismissed his live-in companion, Valérie Trierweiler, and eliminated — Pravda-style — all traces of her as first lady from the official Élysée Palace website. The French president is smiling more, telling colleagues he feels “relieved” that his relationship is over. During a trip to Turkey last week, he bantered with French journalists. The next day he decorated the Turkish chanteuse Candan Ercetin as a knight of Arts and Letters, kissing her on both cheeks before gushing over her interpretation of Edith Piaf songs, including “Non, je ne regrette rien.”

headline: Arrivederci, Roma. Ciao, Bank Street.
text: It might be a challenge to try to maintain the ambience of a Roman trattoria in downtown Stamford, especially when the temperatures dip down to near zero.

headline: Making a Broken Family Whole Again
text: Eric Fleiss recently recalled the first words that his wife Susan said to him after she learned she had colon cancer in early 2011: “I need to find you a new wife.”

headline: The Move From Celebrity to Ubiquity
text: LOS ANGELES — Priyanka Chopra had a problem: what to do with the light.

headline: Review: 2014 Jeep Cherokee Limited
text: The original Cherokee’s design was so square, it could be mistaken for the box it came in. Jeep has revived the name for 2014 and has put quite a curve on the styling.

headline: The M.T.A. Switches Ad Agencies After 22 Years
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is changing advertising agencies after 22 years, parting ways with the firm that helped popularize the cautionary phrase “If you see something, say something.”

headline: Jason Wu: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: Signs of Life in Home Building
text: In a perfect world for the housing industry, the employment picture contains a virtuous cycle in which housing drives jobs and jobs drive housing. Some analysts found evidence of that Friday in the January jobs report.

headline: When Doctors Leave the Building
text: Forget images of hulking X-ray machines and pocket-size exam rooms framed by cinderblock. Forget the lingering odor of rubbing alcohol. New York doctors’ offices have come a long way over the years. And in their latest incarnation, these spaces are increasingly attractive as residential properties, enticing buyers with their prime locations, sometimes-lofty ceilings and unrivaled privacy.

headline: Chrysler Recalls 9,700 Ram Vans for Sticking Accelerator Pedal
text: Chrysler is recalling about 9,700 Ram ProMaster vans from the 2014 model year to correct a problem that can allow the accelerator pedal “to stick in the wide-open position,” the automaker said in a news release Friday.

headline: N.S.A. Program Gathers Data on a Third of Nation’s Calls, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency’s once-secret program that is collecting bulk records of Americans’ domestic phone calls is taking in a relatively small portion of the total volume of such calls each day, officials familiar with the program said on Friday.

headline: New York Fashion Week: General Idea Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Clip: 'Child's Pose'
text: A scene from the film, directed by Calin Peter Netzer.

headline: Graphic Novels to Graphic Prime Time
text: Shuffle ... stagger ... chomp! Shuffle ... stagger ... chomp!

headline: Winter’s Chill Turns to Spring’s Love in the Forest
text: “Blow, blow, thou winter wind” begins one of the songs that echo in the frosty forest of Arden while its denizens shiver through the middle scenes of “As You Like It.” As Shakespeare’s story progresses and its various romances blossom, however, the melancholy snows of winter gradually melt away into the greenery of spring, even as his characters are transformed for the better by love and kindness.

headline: Lord Zog, Your Ride Is Ready
text: TESTED Nissan Juke Nismo

headline: Same Name, but Gentler in Attitude
text: FREDERICK, MD. — “But is it a Jeep?”

headline: Reversal of Good Fortune
text: There’s something about a dessert that can be served with the bottom on top.

headline: From Private Repository to Public Forum
text: The divide between public and private has lessened considerably in recent decades as social media reveals what near strangers had for breakfast and corporations and governments collect personal data for their own uses. Artists have taken note, and “Dear Diary: Update on All” at the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College offers a global look at how the diary form evolved, as the gallery release puts it, from “a private repository” to a public forum in which “the personal becomes a platform for social interaction, reflection and activism.”

headline: Morgan Stanley Adds 4 Executives to Operating Committee
text: Morgan Stanley has named four executives to its operating committee, the bank’s most senior group of managers.

headline: The 7-Day Digital Diet
text: At first blush I may not seem like a prime candidate for a digital detox.

headline: Missed That Note? Wait a Few Minutes, and It’ll Return
text: Many new scores languish unheard after the fanfare of a premiere; for a work to have its American premiere and its second performance on the same program, as happened at the Miller Theater on Thursday evening, is fairly rare.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Africa, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Indonesia.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Greenwich Village loft; an Upper West Side Co-op; and a unit in a Park Slope building.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A converted barn in Stamford with a soaring ceiling; and an English manor in White Plains with eight bedrooms.

headline: A Not Quite Merry Christmas Reunion
text: It is often bad news for a family when one of its members decides to write a memoir, since the focus is likely to be a miserable childhood or a calamitous event the others would rather forget. The Wyeth family at the center of Jon Robin Baitz’s crackling “Other Desert Cities,” now at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport, faces that unwelcome situation.

headline: Jazz Brimming With Ideas
text: Danilo Pérez began his early set at the Jazz Standard on Thursday night with a busily efficient overture, laying out many of his themes and protocols for the ensuing hour. Within the first minute of the piece, “Rediscovery of the South Sea,” there was an intriguing bramble of push-pull tensions between bass, violin and percussion; a more spacious motif that Mr. Pérez unhurriedly teased out at the piano; and a hale-sounding Yoruban chant by Roman Díaz, providing his own punctuation on a batá drum.

headline: Scores Detained in Russia Before Olympic Ceremony
text: MOSCOW — From St. Petersburg to the Caucasus, the authorities detained at least 61 people on Friday for holding unauthorized protests ahead of the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics in Sochi. The detentions underscored the government’s efforts to stifle protests even far away from the Games.

headline: De Blasio’s Pick for Planning Puts Focus on Housing
text: From its perch as overseer of New York City’s growth, the City Planning Commission has helped mayors put their own stamp on the landscape, whether with luxury Midtown towers or a revitalized waterfront. But Mayor Bill de Blasio mostly sees the realm of zoning and land use as another means to address economic inequality.

headline: McDonald’s Opens in Vietnam, Bringing Big Mac to Fans of Banh Mi
text: HANOI, Vietnam — When Nguyen Hoang Anh and Nguyen Thi My Hao started dating, the 23-year-olds agreed to disagree about food: Mr. Anh adores Western-style fast food, but Ms. Hao mainly eats pho, a popular noodle soup, and other northern Vietnamese foods she has loved since childhood.

headline: Wine-Braised Oxtail
text: Melissa Clark braises oxtail with red wine, carrots and celery root for flavorful, fork-tender meat.

headline: Adversity, Relayed in Emoticons by a Troubled Gay Teenager
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The first thing to know about David Roussève’s “Stardust” is that you never actually see its protagonist, a black gay urban teenager named Junior. The voice at the heart of this 80-minute dance-theater piece, which had its regional premiere on Thursday in Montclair State University’s Peak Performances series, speaks to us via text messages, projected on the back wall of the theater.

headline: A Jeep That Serves Two Masters
text: The 2014 Jeep Cherokee Trailhawk faces a challenge: it must compete with the likes of the RAV4 and CR-V for the suburban market. and still get some respect from the Cherokee nation.

headline: Latin America Venture Capital Fund Raises New $135 Million Fund
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Despite the turbulence currently hitting emerging markets, the venture capital fund Kaszek Ventures, in Buenos Aires, recently raised a new $135 million fund, signaling that the region’s long-term prospects remain promising.

headline: Finding Warmth and Comfort in Noodle Soup
text: At Noodles and Company in Garden City on a recent afternoon, Matt Neary, 44, of Merrick, lifted a bowl to his lips and drained what was left of the Thai curry noodle soup at the bottom. A repeat customer at the restaurant, at the Gallery at Westbury Plaza mall, Mr. Neary said he had been craving the coconut curry broth laced with ginger, cabbage, shiitake mushrooms and rice noodles. “It’s got to have some kind of noodle in it,” he said. “That’s what makes it a one-pot meal.”

headline: The Marriage, Pragmatic; The Relatives, Troubling
text: Patience sometimes seems to be a lost art in creepy entertainment. The makers of such stuff, whether a television show about a hunt for a serial killer or a slasher film for the popcorn crowd, seem in a rush to get a scary abduction or bloody corpse onto the screen, as if they fear viewers will bail if they don’t see something ghastly in the first three minutes.

headline: Priyanka Chopra: The New Face of Guess
text: Priyanka Chopra is a household name in India. But she is a relative unknown in America, where she spent a part of her childhood. She hopes that being the new face of Guess will change that.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: Click the slide show to view the On the Market properties in the region for this week: A converted barn in Stamford with a soaring ceiling; and an English manor in White Plains with eight bedrooms.

headline: For a Plucky Upstart, Icy Industry Tundra
text: LOS ANGELES — “The Legend of Sarila” is Canada’s first 3-D animated feature film. The movie boasts a fine voice cast, including the Canadian-born Christopher Plummer and Geneviève Bujold, and a story that draws its inspiration from Inuit culture and legends. There are blizzards and avalanches, sled dog rides through twisting ice tunnels and mystical battles between rival shamans. After its premiere at the TIFF Kids International Film Festival in Toronto, the film opened in Canadian theaters; the producers later signed deals to distribute “Sarila” in more than 22 countries, including Germany, Russia, Israel and China.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Click the slide show to view the On the Market properties in New York City for this week: A Greenwich Village loft; an Upper West Side Co-op; and a unit in a Park Slope building.

headline: Rodriguez Drops Suits Against Baseball and Union
text: After a year of warring with Major League Baseball, Alex Rodriguez effectively ended his battle on Friday, dropping his lawsuits against baseball and the players union over his doping suspension.

headline: Ode to a Slow-Cooked Oxtail
text: A slice of oxtail terrine, with silken shreds of boneless beef molded into a neat square on the plate, is a refined and elegant dish. The meat is so soft and succulent you can eat it with a spoon. Teeth are purely optional.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Whiteout
text: Men in dress shoes leaping over slush-filled curbs added a humorous if precarious postscript.

headline: Sit Back, Relax and Enjoy the Show
text: Meals at Moroccan restaurants typically begin with salads, and if you begin yours at Marakesh with the mix of cold salads known as the sampler, you might want to come back and order it again the next day.

headline: The Singer’s Artifice, Flickering on Film
text: In Joan Didion’s Broadway adaptation of her memoir “The Year of Magical Thinking,” Vanessa Redgrave played a character named Joan Didion. Simple enough, but it suddenly gave a new twist to Ms. Didion’s large body of nonfiction, much of it written in the first person. While I used to take the authenticity of her narrative voice for granted, “The Year of Magical Thinking” reminded me that her “I” is as artificial, as carefully calibrated a construct, as any figure in a play or novel.

headline: Ex-Contractor at State Dept. Pleads Guilty in Leak Case
text: WASHINGTON — Stephen J. Kim, a former State Department contractor charged with leaking information from a highly classified report about North Korea to a Fox News reporter in 2009, pleaded guilty on Friday and agreed to serve a 13-month prison sentence.

headline: Work by Graffiti Artists From 5Pointz on Display
text: Subway riders who saw the graffiti-coated warehouse buildings in Queens known as 5Pointz from the 7 train and planned to visit them someday will never have the chance.

headline: Infusing Études With a Kaleidoscope of Flavors
text: Almost exactly one year after his Carnegie Hall recital debut, the young Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov returned to its main auditorium. Word of that triumphant debut, in which the then-21-year-old demonstrated his uncommon technical gifts and poetic sensibility in works by Scriabin, Liszt and Chopin, and the recent release of its live recording, contributed to the crush of ticket seekers outside the hall on Thursday evening.

headline: A Jeep That Must Serve Two Masters

headline: His Death, Their Lives

text: In an audacious reinvention of itself, Volvo Cars will replace its entire model line over the next few years, staking its immediate future on a single chassis architecture with one basic engine and transmission.

headline: Child Crash Deaths Decline 43%
text: Deaths of children 12 and younger in motor vehicle crashes fell by 43 percent from 2002 to 2011, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in a report released on Tuesday. Still, automobile accidents remain a leading cause of death among children in the United States.

headline: For a Power Girl, Cheers and Disses
text: Among the many chart-topping musicians who appeared at the Grammy Awards on Jan. 26, Lorde, the 17-year-old singer of the hit “Royals,” was the most mentioned on Twitter that night, according to the social media company’s blog. With her fingers dip-dyed in black (more reminiscent of the designer Michèle Lamy than a typical teenage pop star) and signature jerky dance moves, some young fans were giddy at her success. “Lorde might win four Grammys when I can’t even win the affection of my crush from school,” one wrote.

headline: Once Upon a Revolution: A Story With No End
text: CAIRO — The discussion started decorously enough. The novelist Alaa al-Aswany had screened “The Square,” the Oscar-nominated documentary about the Egyptian revolution, at his monthly salon two weeks ago, and he opened by lamenting that the film focused on just a handful of articulate characters instead of the masses of “simple people.” And as in almost every conversation here about the “The Square,” it did not take long before the fighting began.

headline: A Fantasy Found in the Morgue
text: A number of years ago, I had a major crush on a guy whose profession was identifying bodies that had been mutilated or decomposed so badly that they were beyond visual recognition (yes, it’s another sappy Valentine’s Day story).

headline: 22 Things The New York Times Has Called a ‘Guilty Pleasure’
text: In Sunday’s magazine, Adam Sternbergh riffs on so-called guilty pleasures. “How did these two concepts ever come to be married anyway?” he asks. “Aside from the obvious (sex), there are only three other arenas in life in which guilt and pleasure are habitually linked: gastronomy, religion and the arts. And while there are semi-plausible rationalizations for the first two (that cake was delicious, but I ate too much; I indulged in an act I’ve been taught to feel is wrong), for the life of me I’ve never been able to unravel how cultural guilt and cultural pleasure became so entwined.”

text: The San Francisco-born, New York-based artist Tauba Auerbach is about to have a London moment. Opening this weekend is “Tetractys – Art of the Fugue,” a ballet at the Royal Opera House for which she created the backdrops and costume designs. Soon to follow will be The New Ambidextrous Universe, a major exhibition in the spring at the city’s Institute of Contemporary Arts. (Auerbach’s work can also currently be seen at the University of Chicago and the Contemporary Art Museum in Houston.)

But on Tuesday night, when Rachel Frederickson, 24, walked onto the studio stage 155 pounds lighter than at the start of Season 15, the reaction was not one of awe, but shock, apparent even on the trainers’ frozen faces.

text: In the 1990s, a time of vexing homicide rates in cities across the country, William J. Bratton left the New York Police Department and began marketing the crime-fighting techniques he had deployed so successfully here to other municipalities struggling with rampant disorder. At the time, business and civic leaders in Birmingham, Ala., brought him on to advise them.

text: There is a certain type of New Yorker who lives in Manhattan, might deign to have a drink in Brooklyn and sees no more of the Bronx and Queens than their stadiums and airports. Staten Island? Never. The new public art project, New York (Outer Borough) Stories, now on display at two locations (24 Gouverneur Lane and 141 Water Street) near the South Street Seaport, was made for these provincials.

headline: Massachusetts Appoints Official and Hires Firm to Fix Exchange Problems

Deval Patrick of Massachusetts has appointed an insurance executive to oversee repairs to the state’s bungled effort to bring its health exchange in line with the requirements of President Obama’s health care law. Mr. Patrick also announced the state will pay a technology firm, Optum, nearly $10 million to help fix the exchange.

headline: Journalist Badly Wounded by Flare During Rio Protest
text: Santiago Andrade, a Brazilian cameraman, was badly wounded in Rio de Janeiro on Thursday evening when he was struck in the head by an explosive device while covering clashes between protesters and the police. He remained in critical condition on Friday after four hours of neurosurgery, according to the local Globo news site.

headline: In Left-Leaning Norway, Its Wealthy ‘Fox’ Gleefully Swings to the Right
text: OSLO — OLAV THON, at 90, is nearly as old as modern Norway, which became independent from Sweden in 1905. But today, having worked his way from being a poor farm boy in the mountains to Norway’s wealthiest resident, he is not so sure independence was such a good idea.

text: The Four Seasons, the restaurant on Park Avenue that is a lunchtime haunt for movie stars, wealthy financiers and titans of real estate and media, may have to vacate its space over something faced every day by far less renowned establishments: a steep rent increase.

She attended Peter Som’s 10 a.m. runway show at Milk Studios in a sleeveless blush chiffon frock and peep-toe pumps.

text: PARIS — Thousands of angry Bosnians took to the streets on Friday for a fourth day of protests against the political paralysis and economic stagnation that have engulfed one of Europe’s poorest and most divided countries.

text: Mayor Bill de Blasio swept into office promising to help low-wage workers and demand more from corporations that get support from the city — and now his allies intend to hold him to it.

headline: Despite Signs of Progress, Security Issues Rise in Tunisia
text: TUNIS — At the end of a 20-hour gun battle with the police in a northern borough here, a bearded man emerged from the besieged house, his rifle above his head. Residents watching from a street corner saw him kneel, lay down the weapon and reach for his vest. Then a government sniper shot him dead.
