headline: Republicans Criticize Rules to Aid Syrians Seeking Asylum
text: Republican lawmakers are assailing new exemptions from antiterrorism laws the Obama administration issued this week for war zone refugees seeking to come to the United States, saying the rules are examples of unilateral action by President Obama that weaken immigration security.

headline: China: Tibetan Dies in Act of Protest
text: A Tibetan man, Phakmo Samdup, died Wednesday after setting himself on fire in an act of protest against the Chinese government, which has ruled Tibet since invading it in the 1950s, according to information released Friday by Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London. Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the American government, said the protest took place in the prefecture of Malho in Qinghai Province, in western China. The death raises to 126 the number of self-immolations in Tibetan areas ruled by China, Radio Free Asia reported.

headline: Canada: Government Deletes Drawings, Posted Online, of a Secret Spying Site
text: The government of Canada on Friday removed detailed architectural drawings of a secret electronic eavesdropping station that had been posted online. About a dozen drawings, which detail the interior as well as mechanical and electrical specifications of the command center at Canadian Forces Station Leitrim in Ottawa were posted on Wednesday as part of a construction tender by Public Works and Government Services Canada. The military station conducts foreign communications interceptions and other work for the Communications Security Establishment Canada, Canada’s electronic spy agency. The public works department was unable to comment about the episode. The removal of the drawings followed the publication of an article in the newspaper The Ottawa Citizen.

headline: Try Your Luck, at the I.R.S. Wheel
text: “Taxes are Fun!” That’s the bright, bold and unconvincing message in an ad campaign from Jackson Hewitt, the tax preparers.

headline: A Taste Test for Three Flavors of Tax Software
text: My choice of tax preparation software brands me an old coot, or at least out of sync with the modern moment. My wife, Mary Ellen, says my taste in music does, too — my apologies, Mr. Jagger.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Liner Notes at Rag & Bone
text: You can always count on the Rag & Bone girl to make the call on what’s cool, beauty-wise. For fall, the answer is: loads of graphic eyeliner. “I was inspired by yé-yé girls from the ’60s, like Françoise Hardy,” the makeup artist Gucci Westman said of the “tomboy-ish” look she created backstage this afternoon. Her muse is “accessible and cool,” Westman continued, but has a “contemporary edge and toughness.” In the makeup chair, that translated into a modern cat-eye with a strong, geometric shape. The eyeliner “goes straight out, and doesn’t follow the lash line, which makes it slightly different,” Westman explained of her technique, which involved topping Revlon ColorStay Crème Gel Liner with Revlon ColorStay Liquid Eye Pen. To clean up the edges, Westman relied on an angled Q-Tip when necessary; she left the rest of the face relatively bare. “The eyeliner is meant to be your one trick,” she said. “This is not a high-maintenance girl.” Indeed, the British model Georgia May Jagger paid Westman the ultimate compliment by describing the finished look as “quite normal — it’s actually something I would wear out.”

headline: Ex-Mayor Confronts List of Transactions at His Corruption Trial in New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS — On Friday, it was C. Ray Nagin versus his paper trail.

headline: For Small Businesses, a Road Without a Map
text: Last year, owners of small businesses had to cope with higher tax rates. This year, they will wrestle with greater uncertainty about the fate of some deductions they have come to rely on.

headline: Minimizing the Tax Drag on Your Investments
text: Unless you happen to be a certified public accountant, or related to one, the topic of taxes you pay on your investments probably has as much appeal as a root canal. Understood. Nonetheless, it’s a topic well worth focusing on.

headline: At the I.R.S., Trying to Collect More With Less
text: The United States tax code is fast approaching 75,000 pages, and it is growing every year in complexity and bulk. Yet as the tax code has become more byzantine, the budget for enforcing it has been shrinking.

headline: Week After Being Hit by Bus, Rare Owl Is ‘Bright and Alert’ at Washington Clinic
text: WASHINGTON — One week after being hit by a bus and an S.U.V. not far from the White House, the snowy owl that made bird-watchers out of smartphone-gazers is recuperating at a Washington wildlife clinic.

headline: Victory, and Tax Changes, for Same-Sex Couples
text: Erin E. Miller and her wife may have to pay more income tax this year, but they aren’t about to protest. Quite the opposite.

headline: So Many Bribes, a Greek Official Can’t Recall Them All
text: ATHENS — When Antonis Kantas, a deputy in the Defense Ministry here, spoke up against the purchase of expensive German-made tanks in 2001, a representative of the tank’s manufacturer stopped by his office to leave a satchel on his sofa. It contained 600,000 euros, about $814,000. Other arms manufacturers eager to make deals came by, too, some guiding him through the ins and outs of international banking and then paying him off with deposits to his overseas accounts.

headline: Father and Son, Together on a Halfpipe Quest
text: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif. — The maintenance building smells like a garage, all rubber and grease and metal parts, the scents of construction and repairs. The Coke machine has a sticker that reads “Bretz 2014.”

headline: Time Travel and the Ballad Tradition
text: Since I was a kid, I’ve loved story songs, history ballads and concept albums. Songs with well-drawn characters, a strong sense of time and place, a narrative arc and a cinematic quality are endlessly fascinating. I remember hearing “The Battle of New Orleans” by Jimmy Driftwood (a hit for the country artist Johnny Horton) for the first time, as a very young, prekindergarten child, and being mesmerized by the march of the “bloody British,” at whom “we fired our guns” all the way “down the Mississippi to the Gulf of Mexico.” At the time I didn’t know who the “British” were, or why we wanted to kill them, or where the city of New Orleans might be, but the battle and the chase and the big river right in the center made an indelible imprint.

headline: Breaks in the Action
text: Union and Confederate soldiers viewed one another as the enemy — except sometimes when they needed to bum a smoke. Then, in unofficial “soldier’s truces,” warring opponents set down their weapons and became the American brothers they were before the war. In a conflict that exemplified the military axiom that soldiering is 99 percent boredom and 1 percent sheer terror, the blue and the gray called timeouts from opposition to trade tobacco for coffee, share food, relate war stories and converse about home, or play cards during downtime on the battlefield.

headline: Proposals
text: Readers share images of their wedding proposals or proposals they witnessed.

headline: Steps Toward Financial Fitness, for This Year and Beyond
text: For a vast majority of Americans, the current tax-filing season will be business as usual, with few changes to the ground rules of recent years. For the very affluent, it may bring sticker shock.

headline: Historic Hysterics: Witnesses to a Really Big Show
text: Debbie Gendler, a teenager from Oakland, N.J., had gone to television shows before, taking a seat in the studio audience and clapping dutifully when the “applause” light flashed. But this one was different. There were crowds outside the studio that chilly afternoon in February 1964, hysterical crowds, and a phalanx of police officers blocking the way.

Then Mr. Kogler made the fencer do something else — lie down and meditate, in the middle of a raucous practice in the athletic complex at the university’s campus in Manhattan.

headline: Virus Outbreak Shuts Down Hudson Valley Hotel for Week
text: Mohonk Mountain House, a historic hotel in the Hudson Valley, shut down for a week on Friday after a virus outbreak sickened a few hundred people this month, according to hotel officials.

headline: New York’s Affordable Housing Shortage
text: New York City stands at the epicenter of an affordable housing crisis that has placed poor and elderly people throughout the country at greater risk of homelessness and forced low-income renters to forgo food and medical care to stay in their homes.

headline: Currency Wars, Revisited
text: In recent years developing countries like Brazil complained that the United States and other industrialized countries were waging a “currency war” against them by artificially driving down the value of dollars, euros and yen. Now officials in some nations, like Argentina and Turkey, are blaming foreign “vultures” and “the interest rate lobby” for the sharp depreciation of their currencies.

headline: The Bloody Ivory Business
text: The slaughter of the African elephant continues. Nearly 100 of these majestic animals are sacrificed every day for ivory trinkets — bracelets, statuettes and other baubles sold illegally around the world. Wildlife experts estimate the remaining African elephant population at 350,000 to 500,000, with poachers targeting 30,000 to 35,000 a year. Elizabeth Bennett of the Wildlife Conservation Society estimates that one subspecies, the African forest elephant, could become extinct in the next decade.

headline: De Blasio Tests Political Might in Pre-K Push
text: He has phoned titans of finance and real estate to ask for donations. He has called on labor leaders to tap their war chests and lend their muscles. He has lined up endorsements from actors, musicians and movie producers.

headline: Knicks’ 20th Win Provides Relief for Woodson
text: Late in the first quarter, Coach Mike Woodson left his seat on the bench and stood with his arms folded as he surveyed a familiar scene: missed box-outs, errant passes, poor defensive rotations. What made the situation unusual was that Woodson seemed to delight in the mistakes, largely because the Denver Nuggets were making most of them.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) 42 (2013) Chadwick Boseman, above, portrays Jackie Robinson, a shortstop for the Kansas City Monarchs of the Negro leagues, a four-sport athlete at U.C.L.A. and an Army officer during World War II. Harrison Ford plays Branch Rickey, the president and general manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers who selected Robinson to become the first black major leaguer of the modern era. But when Rickey calls his new player “superhuman,” what he means is that Robinson will have to rise above ordinary temptations in the face of prejudice and hostility to become a flawless exemplar of his race. “While ‘42,’ Brian Helgeland’s new film about Robinson, gestures toward the complicated and painful history in which its subject was embroiled,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York York Times, “it is blunt, simple and sentimental, using time-tested methods to teach a clear and rousing lesson.” He continued, “In other hands — Spike Lee’s, let’s say, or even Clint Eastwood’s — ‘42’ might have taken a tougher, more contentious look at the breaking of Major League Baseball’s color barrier.” But Mr. Helgeland “has honorably sacrificed the chance to make a great movie in the interest of making one that is accessible and inspiring. Though not accurate in every particular, the movie mostly succeeds in respecting the facts of history and the personality of its hero, and in reminding audiences why he mattered.”

headline: From Russia With Love: A Chronicle of J. Mendel
text: The story of J. Mendel is a fashion fairytale that has seen the storied house migrate from St. Petersburg to Paris to New York City, where Gilles Mendel is creating the most elegant of designs for the swans of New York. In this unique multimedia feature, we explore the brand’s heritage and showcase some of its most extraordinary new pieces.

headline: 1914: Barnyard Gaiety at the Paris Poultry Show
text: The President of the French Republic yesterday afternoon opened the Fifteenth International Exhibition of the Société des Aviculteurs Français, better known to Anglo-Saxons as the Paris Poultry Show. The show is being held in one of the wings of the Grand Palais, which from now until Monday next will resound with the noise and gaiety peculiar to the barnyard.

headline: A Seaside Surfing Town on Sydney’s North Shore
text: Sydney’s scenic enclave Manly has long been overshadowed by glitzy Bondi on the other side of the harbor, but that suits its laid-back nature just fine. Locals regularly hit the waves before heading to work in Sydney’s financial district, a five-mile ferry ride across Sydney Harbor; it’s not uncommon, while slurping fresh oysters, to spot a humpback whale leap out of the water just a shell’s throw away. Lately, artists, musicians and creative types drawn to Manly’s natural beauty and mellow pace have transformed the area into a new hub of culture and dining, and starting today, the nine-day Australian Open of Surfing takes place along its shores. Here, a field guide to enjoying the area.

headline: The Path to Reading a Newborn’s DNA Map
text: What if laboratories could run comprehensive DNA tests on infants at birth, spotting important variations in their genomes that might indicate future medical problems? Should parents be told of each variation, even if any risk is still unclear? Would they even want to know?

headline: The Greater the Turmoil, the Stronger the Dollar. Again.
text: Chronic problems have been flaring up in financial markets lately, and some of them may emanate from the United States. Yet none of these issues have seriously damaged the exalted status of what Washington Irving once called “the almighty dollar.”

headline: Why Emerging Markets Should Look Within
text: In recent weeks, Argentina, Turkey, Ukraine and Thailand have endured plunging currencies, capital flight and political disruptions in varying combinations. While they have all been affected by global economic tides, these nations are facing crises because of problems in their national governance. And if we look elsewhere around the world, we find that governance has been re-emerging as a major factor behind success or failure in many emerging nations.

headline: As Northwestern Players Pursue Unionization, a Voice in the Wilderness Gains a Chorus

Ramogi Huma was a teenager then, a freshman linebacker at U.C.L.A., but he took notice when Donnie Edwards was suspended for accepting the food, a violation of N.C.A.A. rules. At workouts the next summer, Huma learned he was not covered by U.C.L.A.’s health insurance because some practices were voluntary. He began to see a pattern.

headline: Where Is My Family on TV?
text: ONE of my earliest memories is of sitting in an idling car with my mom and sister outside a convenience store in Virginia. Dad’s inside, buying cigarettes and scratch-off lottery tickets. Suddenly, a wild-eyed man appears at the driver-side window, yelling about white women and black men and how they don’t belong together. My mother goes feral, blocking his access to us. My father runs out, furious and swearing, before driving us away. I don’t remember what happened next, just a confusing and searing shame about the ugliness that the sight of my family could provoke.

headline: Michio Kaku
text: Michio Kaku is a theoretical physicist and professor at City College of New York. When not trying to complete Einstein’s theory of everything, he writes books that explain physics and how developments in the field will shape the future.

text: THE pope, a porn star and a parrot walk into a bar.

headline: The Games Begin in Russia, and an Actor’s Life Ends in New York
text: From their inception in the 1890s, the modern Olympic Games have differed from other sporting tournaments (the Super Bowl, for example, on which more later) in the overlay of idealism that Baron Pierre de Coubertin, the father of the modern Games, concocted from the mythology of the ancient Greek Games and his own 19th-century aristocratic sporting traditions. Never mind that his idealized Olympic Games have long given way to commercialism, professionalism, corruption, politics and boycotts; the notion that the Games somehow elevate the world above its usual sordid nastiness has remained an integral part of their image.

headline: Whose Garbage Is This Anyway?
text: HEBRON, West Bank — It was not your usual Holy Land tour, but surely one of the most revealing I’ve ever had. A team from Friends of the Earth Middle East took me around to see how waste, sewage and untreated water flow, or don’t, between Israel and the West Bank. I never realized how political garbage and dirty water could be, or how tracking it could reveal just why making peace here is so urgent.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Medicine as a Business
text: Readers discuss whether pressure to increase profits has compromised doctors’ ethics and their treatment of patients.

headline: Leaving Work Behind
text: IN 1930, in the darkening valley of the Great Depression, John Maynard Keynes wrote an essay on “Economic Possibilities for Our Grandchildren,” which foresaw a much happier future — one of growth, abundance and the steady decline of full-time work. Eventually, he suggested, civilization might settle on a 15-hour workweek, with three hours of daily labor being sufficient “to satisfy the old Adam in most of us.”

headline: Lost in Clinical Translation
text: A classic “Far Side” cartoon shows a man talking forcefully to his dog. The man says: “Okay, Ginger! I’ve had it! You stay out of the garbage!” But the dog hears only: “Blah blah Ginger blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah Ginger …”

headline: After War, a Failure of the Imagination

headline: Why Nutrition Is So Confusing
text: NEARLY six weeks into the 2014 diet season, it’s a good bet that many of us who made New Year’s resolutions to lose weight have already peaked. If clinical trials are any indication, we’ve lost much of the weight we can expect to lose. In a year or two we’ll be back within half a dozen pounds of where we are today.

headline: Inside a Mental Hospital Called Jail
text: CHICAGO — THE largest mental health center in America is a huge compound here in Chicago, with thousands of people suffering from manias, psychoses and other disorders, all surrounded by high fences and barbed wire.

headline: How Single Motherhood Hurts Kids
text: The last few weeks have brought an unusual convergence of voices from both the center and the left about a topic that is typically part of conservative rhetorical territory: poverty and single-parent families. Just as some conservatives have started talking seriously about rising inequality and stagnant incomes, some liberals have finally begun to admit that our stubbornly high rates of poverty and social and economic immobility are closely entwined with the rise of single motherhood.

headline: French Breakup Makes a Dinner Harder to Do

Engraved invitations, with the presidential seal in gold at the top, were printed and set to be mailed.

headline: When We House Mentally Ill People in Prisons
text: My sunday column is about the way the dearth of mental health services ends up propelling people with psychiatric disorders into prisons and jails, so that today many more mentally ill people are behind bars than in psychiatric hospitals. This column arose out of my earlier invitation to readers to suggest topics that we in journalism should cover more aggressively in 2014. I suggested that one of these is mental health issues, which I wrote about generally last month, and this is a follow-up. I’d welcome your thoughts on this.

headline: Can You Live on the Minimum Wage?
text: More than 4.8 million workers now earn the lowest legal pay. This calculator shows the hard choices that have to be made living on the smallest paychecks.

headline: The Case for a Higher Minimum Wage
text: The political posturing over raising the minimum wage sometimes obscures the huge and growing number of low-wage workers it would affect. An estimated 27.8 million people would earn more money under the Democratic proposal to lift the hourly minimum from $7.25 today to $10.10 by 2016. And most of them do not fit the low-wage stereotype of a teenager with a summer job. Their average age is 35; most work full time; more than one-fourth are parents; and, on average, they earn half of their families’ total income.

headline: The Winning Formula of Luge’s ‘Old Man’
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — To discover how the 40-year-old Italian luger Armin Zöggeler has remained at the top of his sport for more than 20 years, I persuaded him to tell me his secrets. “Apples,” he told me. “And I have lots of noodles for lunch, and steak for dinner every night.”

headline: With Team Skating, It’s Now Kiss, Cry, Squeeze In

headline: Judge Temporarily Bars Removal of Picasso Tapestry From Four Seasons

The tenant is not a person or a business, but “Le Tricorne,” a large curtain painted by Pablo Picasso that has decorated the Four Seasons Restaurant since its opening in 1959.

headline: Broad Museum in Los Angeles Delays Opening Until 2015

headline: Quora and the Search for Truth
text: The Internet has a nagging problem: There is lots of information, but often confusion about what’s true. Many big websites try to solve this problem with their services. At least one, Quora, suggests that maybe we don’t care that much about the truth.

headline: Document | Made for More Than Walking
text: A single photograph of a woman’s legs may be titillating. But a cluster of 30 glamorous gams cut from the pages of glossy magazines is more than that. “Legs,” by the German artist Hans-Peter Feldmann, questions, with an erotomaniac’s attention to detail, advertising’s ravenous commodification of beauty. The 73-year-old’s work, an obsessive appropriation of everyday objects — from photographs of unmade beds to the front pages of 250 newspapers dated Sept. 12, 2001 — is in line with that of American conceptualists like Richard Prince and Dash Snow. And yet, he has trouble explaining his ideas: “When they asked the Austrian composer Bruckner what inspired his masterwork ‘Te Deum,’ he said it came to him while . . . eating a cheese sandwich.” Feldmann frankly loves sitting in a cafe and admiring the pretty passers-by, but says that the best legs he knows belong to Ursula, his wife of more than 40 years. “Is it sexist of me to focus so much on a woman’s legs?” he wonders. “I don’t know. Ask the great inventor in the sky.”

headline: Jamie Anderson, Slopestyle’s Star, Is on Top Again
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Jamie Anderson stood at the top of the slopestyle course Sunday, her boots strapped to her snowboard and opportunity at her feet. She had won more of slopestyle’s big competitions than any other woman, but now the event was in the Olympics, and she had one run to capture the gold medal she was expected to win.

headline: Rejecting the U.S. to Skate for Russia
text: SOCHI, Russia — In 2011, the South Korean short-track speedskating star Ahn Hyun-soo became a Russian citizen, changed his name to Viktor Ahn and pledged to compete for his adopted homeland at the Sochi Games. President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was said to be especially pleased.

headline: Months After Deadly Fire, Owners of Bangladesh Factory Surrender to Court
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A husband and wife whose factory in Bangladesh was consumed by fire in 2012, a disaster that killed 112 employees, surrendered to a court on Sunday in Dhaka, the capital.

headline: Stirring Looks, Brooklyn to Nepal

headline: For Austrians, Downhill Is the Extreme Sport to Own
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Competitors do all manner of spectacular things above the snow at this postmodern stage of winter sport’s development: backside rodeos, double corks, tail grabs, switch mistys. The gravity-taunting soars on, and as the quadrenniums roll by, the Winter Olympics keep adding fresh diversions in an attempt to catch up with the curve.

headline: Disruptions: For a Restful Night, Make Your Smartphone Sleep on the Couch

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Parting Ways at Alexander Wang
text: “I wanted to do hair that was very drawn on, like an illustration,” the hairstylist Guido Palau said of the superslick and tight-to-the-head looks he created backstage at Alexander Wang last night. Fittingly, the inspiration turned out to be a fashion sketch the designer penned himself in advance of the show. To bring it all to life, Palau etched a deep side part with his comb and saturated strands in Redken Control Addict 28 High-Control Hairspray before wrapping them firmly around the head. “It’s like a very low sweep-over, like a man’s hair,” he remarked (otherwise known as the comb-over; who knew it could look so cool?). Palau then patted on a Redken Shine Flash 02 Glistening Mist for some sheen, and pulled strands into a slim ponytail, which was later tucked out of sight into the models’ clothing. To reinforce this idea of hair-as-fashion-illustration, he also “painted away” the part lines with makeup to prevent any skin from showing, and gave the models who closed the show — including Karlie Kloss, Jacquetta Wheeler and Joan Smalls — a blast of colored hair powder for an ultra-matte effect, like ink set to dry on paper.

headline: But You Can’t Deny Destiny
text: Just days before his wedding, Nikhil finds himself in a bit of a bind: Not only does he need to prove his business savvy, and therefore worth, to his fiancée, but he also must keep her recently returned, long-estranged sister, Meeta, out of sight. It’s a recipe for failure. But in Vinil Mathew’s “Hasee Toh Phasee,” the setup is also the perfect foil to what is an imperfect union.

headline: Swiss Voters Narrowly Approve Curbs on Immigration
text: BERLIN — A narrow majority of voters in Switzerland approved proposals on Sunday that would reintroduce restrictions on the number of foreigners who are allowed to live and work in the country, a move that could have far-reaching implications for Switzerland’s relations with the European Union.

headline: Bloody Trouble at School
text: The family line for the teenage flick “Vampire Academy” may trace back to “Dracula,” but the recycling policy is strictly from “Frankenstein.” Directed by Mark Waters and written by Daniel Waters, his brother, this genre rehash takes a helping of “Harry Potter,” a measure of “Mean Girls” and elements from various teenage adventures, monster movies and queen-bee stories and recombines the borrowed parts into an unsurprisingly familiar tale. What is surprising is that while the patchwork whole creaks terribly in places, the parts also show signs of life.

headline: Europe’s Painful Past Colors a Film Festival
text: BERLIN — From Wes Anderson’s “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” a tender, urbane caper set in a lost world of interwar Europe, to George Clooney’s “The Monuments Men,” in which the Allies try to save priceless art from the Nazis, Europe’s past — real, imagined, unresolved — is very present at this year’s Berlin International Film Festival.

headline: Fox Cancels ‘The X Factor’ After Three Seasons
text: Fox has canceled its version of the singing competition series “The X Factor” after three seasons. The announcement followed a statement by the program’s creator, Simon Cowell, who said that he would resume his hosting duties this year on the original British incarnation. “Last year, for a number of reasons, I had to make a decision to return to the U.K. version of ‘The X Factor’ in 2014,” Mr. Cowell said. “So for now, I’m back to the U.K., and I want to thank Fox for being an incredible partner, and I also want to thank everybody who has supported my shows.” “The X Factor” completed its third season in December, drawing 6.2 million total viewers for its finale. Before the series premiere in September 2011, Mr. Cowell said that if the show did not pull in 20 million viewers, it would have to be considered a failure. It fell well short of that, attracting 12.5 million at the start, and it never matched the ratings heights of “American Idol” (once the judging home of Mr. Cowell) on Fox or “The Voice” on NBC.

headline: ‘A Raisin in the Sun’ Loses Diahann Carroll
text: Diahann Carroll has dropped out of the Broadway revival of Lorraine Hansberry’s 1959 drama “A Raisin in the Sun.” Ms. Carroll, 78, below, was cast for the role of Lena Younger opposite Denzel Washington as Walter Lee Younger, but she has decided to withdraw “due to the demands of the vigorous rehearsal schedule and the subsequent eight-performances-a-week playing schedule,” according to Philip Rinaldi, a spokesman for the production. LaTanya Richardson Jackson (“Joe Turner’s Come and Gone”) is to assume the role in her place. This was to be Ms. Carroll’s first role on Broadway in over 30 years. She last appeared in a production of John Pielmeier’s play “Agnes of God” in 1983. In 2004, Ms. Carroll, a breast cancer survivor, also had to drop out of a Kennedy Center production of Ernest Thompson’s “On Golden Pond” because of a herniated disk and severe muscle strain. “A Raisin in the Sun” is scheduled to begin previews on March 8 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, with opening night set for April 3 for a 14-week run.

headline: Hailee Steinfeld at Prabal Gurung
text: A streaker notwithstanding, Prabal Gurung’s show went off without a hitch Saturday morning. Hailee Steinfeld, the 17-year-old actress, arrived near 11:15 a.m., punctual by fashion standards, shepherded by her Teen Vogue pal Andrew Bevan. Despite what may be an early weekend hour for the teenage actress, she was preternaturally polished in a monochromatic knit ensemble and black felt fedora.

headline: A Writer’s Pantheon, Focused on the Details
text: It’s tempting to say that “A Place in the Country,” lightly connected essays in which W. G. Sebald writes about six artists he admires, will hold interest only for Sebald completists. But then, it’s hard to imagine a Sebald reader who isn’t an obsessive completist.

headline: Rectitude and Desire, Both at Sea
text: Britten’s opera “Billy Budd” is the wrenching story of its title character, a young, naïve and guileless sailor pressed into service aboard a British war ship in 1797. Rather than resent the loss of his liberty, Billy, a foundling, is grateful to be part of something important, a contributing member of a community.

headline: Bounding Toward Balletic Maturity
text: Growing up involves successive acts of bravery. You must learn how to cross a street, pass examinations, take public transportation — things that so soon become standard fare that we forget their initial challenge. And so it is with dance. Child dancers regularly learn aspects of technique that are beyond the capacity of us nondancers. But in big theaters, it’s easy to take much for granted — whereas studio conditions bring us closer to the practical physics of ballet. On Saturday night, when the young dancers of American Ballet Theater’s Studio Company performed at the 92nd Street Y Buttenwieser Hall, their courage was evident — and admirable — in the opening ensemble adagio of the first item.

headline: ‘Get Lucky,’ Sochi Style
text: The Olympics usually mint new and unlikely stars. Nearly always, they are athletes. But on Friday night, a group of mostly stern-looking police officers became sudden celebrities by covering “Get Lucky,” Daft Punk’s Grammy Award-winning record of the year shortly before the opening ceremony of the Winter Games from Sochi, Russia. The performance by the Ministry of Internal Affairs choir of “Get Lucky” went viral: It has been seen about 750,000 times since NBC posted it online. The choir’s reward: an appearance on Monday morning on NBC’s “Today.” The incongruity of the choir, dressed in evergreen uniforms accented by yellow braided cords, performing the slightly racy song (“She’s up all night for good fun/I’m up all night to get lucky”), doubtlessly accounts for its appeal. The two lead singers were the stars (a baritone joined them later); some others bobbed their heads but did not get funky, while others looked uncomfortable at their surreal dip into dance music. Rolling Stone labeled the police choir’s rendition “incredible” and noted “the officers’ hilarious ‘old, goofy man dancing at a wedding reception’ dance moves.” A spokeswoman for Daft Punk had no comment on the choir’s cover. The performance followed a studio version of the same number that was posted on YouTube in November. That performance, even more animated than Friday’s, has been viewed nearly 4.4 million times.

headline: Is Atheism Irrational?
text: This is the first in a series of interviews about religion that I will conduct for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Alvin Plantinga, an emeritus professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, a former president of both the Society of Christian Philosophers and the American Philosophical Association, and the author, most recently, of “Where the Conflict Really Lies: Science, Religion, and Naturalism.”

headline: Who’s Savvy Now?
text: Via Digby, Jay Rosen has a very good piece on how some reporting on the CBO report was distorted by what he calls the “cult of the savvy”. It goes beyond what I said about second-order journalism; Rosen argues that there’s a value system at work, where being in the know about political maneuvering is considered all-important, whereas understanding the actual policy issue is for the drones.

headline: The Dust Bowl Returns

headline: The Excluded Middlebrow (Wonkish)
text: Simon Wren-Lewis protests against the division some of us (me included) have suggested between New Keynesians, or maybe New New Keynesians trying to revise their models to keep up with the financial crisis, and New Old Keynesians who are skeptical about the microfoundations imperative. He insists that the important divide is between Keynesians and anti-Keynesians, who aren’t expressing so much a theory as an ideology.

headline: N.F.L. Prospect Michael Sam Proudly Says What Teammates Knew: He’s Gay

headline: Michael Sam Opens Up About Sexuality

headline: Writing Off the Unemployed
text: Back in 1987 my Princeton colleague Alan Blinder published a very good book titled “Hard Heads, Soft Hearts.” It was, as you might guess, a call for tough-minded but compassionate economic policy. Unfortunately, what we actually got — especially, although not only, from Republicans — was the opposite. And it’s difficult to find a better example of the hardhearted, softheaded nature of today’s G.O.P. than what happened last week, as Senate Republicans once again used the filibuster to block aid to the long-term unemployed.

headline: Mercy in the Justice System
text: The constitutional provision that gives the president virtually unlimited authority to grant clemency was not an afterthought. The founders understood very well that there could be miscarriages of justice even under the rule of law. By allowing the president to commute unjust sentences or pardon deserving petitioners who had served their time, they sought to ensure that the workings of the courts could be tempered with mercy.

headline: Closing In on Basic Mideast Principles
text: For months, Israelis and Palestinians, with American mediation, have been working on a set of principles that would serve as the basis for negotiations on a final peace agreement. By the end of March, the world is likely to know whether they have been successful. If the two sides agree on basic principles — a framework for further talks — it will be an important step. But then comes the even tougher task of translating principles into a final deal that would recognize a Palestinian state alongside Israel.

headline: Celebrating Bert Berns, Sometimes Overlooked, but Not Forgotten
text: The songwriters who pounded out pop hits in the Brill Building and other New York hit factories in the 1950s and early 1960s, though eclipsed in the wake of the British Invasion, have mostly found a comfortable niche in pop music history by now. Carole King went on to have a rich career, and now her early days as part of the Goffin-King songwriting team are being revisited on Broadway in “Beautiful” — which also shines a light on the collaboration of their friendly competitors, Cynthia Weil and Barry Mann. Others, like Neil Sedaka, Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller, and Jeff Barry and Ellie Greenwich have all maintained their hold on the spotlight.

headline: Chamber Music Society Announces Season
text: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center plans to open its 45th anniversary season on Oct. 15 with the pianist Alessio Bax playing a pair of Mozart concertos for piano and string quintet, and will present more than 120 concerts, with about half in New York and half on tour. The season, which is being announced Monday, shows how large the society has grown since its first season in 1969, when it presented only 21 concerts; the society said that its ticket revenue has grown by 50 percent over the last five years. This season will include the German baritone Christian Gerhaher performing Schubert’s “Winterreise,” three performances of Bach’s “Brandenburg Concertos,” and a continuation of its new music series in the Kaplan Penthouse.

headline: Report Says Not Enough Children Get HPV Vaccine
text: Not enough children in the United States are being vaccinated against the cancer-causing human papillomavirus, or HPV, according to a report issued on Monday by the President’s Cancer Panel. The viruses, transmitted by intimate contact, cause cancers of the cervix, vagina, vulva, anus and penis and areas near the throat. Vaccines can protect against two strains that cause most of the cancers, and a series of three injections is recommended for boys and girls starting at age 11 to 12. But in 2012, only about a third of girls ages 13 to 15 and less than 7 percent of boys in the United States had received the shots. Vaccination rates are much higher in Australia (71.2 percent) and Britain (60.4 percent). Doctors and parents need better education, the report says, and it also urges that pharmacists be allowed to give the injections.

headline: What’s on Monday

Judging begins on this opening night with the hound, toy, nonsporting and herding groups. Sporting, working and terrier groups, followed by best in show, are to be judged from 8 to 11 p.m. Tuesday on USA. David Frei and Erica Hill are the hosts. headline: 50 Years Later, Beatles Steal Another Show
text: If there’s one thing pop has learned in the last 50 years, it’s that Beatles songs never wear out their welcome. The Beatles’ original recordings have retained not only their musical brilliance but also the nearly universal good will that the band generated in its time, as well as the accumulated nostalgia that makes baby boomers conflate its music with all the pleasures of their youth. On purely musical grounds — the foundation of melodies, harmonies and lyrics — Beatles songs have thrived through half a century of remakes.

headline: Why Do You Care How Much Other People Work?
text: The brouhaha over the CBO report – I don’t want to call it a debate, because that would suggest that people on both sides are making sense, or even listening – continues. But there is a massive lack of clarity. This is, no doubt, in large part because incoherence serves the interests of some parties. But I think there’s also some genuine intellectual confusion that might, for a few players at least, actually be reduced by careful analysis.

headline: A Big Pot of Simmered Pintos
text: This pot of beans was Step 1 for the other Recipes for Health this week. If I know that I’m going to use these beans for a Mexican dinner I season them with cilantro and, if I can find it, epazote. If I want Italian or Provençal flavors I make a bouquet garni with bay leaf, thyme, parsley, maybe sage, and most definitely a Parmesan rind. This week, since I am using my beans as a starting off point for other dishes, I season them only with onion, garlic, bay leaf and salt. The dishes that will follow throughout the week will introduce more flavors.

headline: Suicide Bomb Trainer in Iraq Accidentally Blows Up His Class

headline: Pasta e Fagiole
text: This is a classic Italian bean and pasta soup. If you have already made a pot of beans using a pound of beans, and want to use it for this soup, just use half the beans but all of the broth as directed in Step 1.

headline: Vegetarian Chili With Winter Vegetables
text: I have made several versions of vegetarian chili; in some the beans take center stage, others are just as focused on vegetables. This thick, satisfying chili is equally focused on both. I particularly like the way the sweet flavor and comforting, creamy texture of the winter squash plays against the spicy flavors in the chili.

headline: Bruschetta With Smashed Beans, Sage and Kale
text: This is comfort food – a generous spoonful of thick beans seasoned with fresh sage on top of a substantial slice of garlic toast. To make a meal of it I top the beans with seasoned greens and a little Parmesan.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Ballet Rehearsal Buns at Diane von Furstenberg
text: With show venues spread far and wide this season, there’s a certain athleticism involved in leaping around the city. On Diane von Furstenberg’s runway in Tribeca yesterday, the relative endurance of the day fit in well with the designer’s theme. “The collection was inspired by Russian ballerinas,” the hairstylist Orlando Pita said backstage. So naturally hair was whisked up into a bun. But Pita noted an important distinction: “Diane wanted the models to look like they were in rehearsal, rather than in performance.” Conveying that sense of unfinished, dashed-off elegance came down to misting BioSilk Dry Clean Shampoo on fine hair for body or rubbing BioSilk Silk Gel Medium Hold on thicker strands for control, and piling everything up into a high ponytail. The length of the tail was then twisted and wrapped around the base, and slightly spread out with the fingers to create a wide, round shape secured with a cupful of bobby pins. But just when the bun began to look too stage-ready, Pita pulled this last step: “The trick is to put finishing spray on your brush and comb back the hair vertically,” he said, demonstrating the technique around the crown. “This makes it look like someone has taken her fingers and combed her hair up.” It lent a subtle rawness, which did seem quite en pointe.

headline: Tostadas With Beans, Cabbage and Avocado
text: Beans are traditionally fried in lard, but I use a small amount of grapeseed or sunflower oil instead, and rely on the broth from the beans for flavor. This is a great buffet dish for a Mexican dinner party. I prefer to toast the tortillas using the microwave method, but you can also deep-fry them.

headline: Two Founding Members of Pussy Riot Respond to Criticism
text: Hours before they departed the United States, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova and Maria Alyokhina, founding members of Pussy Riot, responded sharply to a letter that other members of that Russian activist collective had posted online  and sent to journalists. The letter disparaged some of the behavior of Ms. Alyokhina and Ms. Tolokonnikova, who are now advocating for prison reform, as unbecoming of the radical feminist group, which became known across the world after its members were arrested for performing a protest song in a Moscow cathedral in 2012.

headline: An Economist Answers Questions About Online Dating
text: Paul Oyer, an economist at Stanford’s Graduate School of Business, is the author of “Everything I Ever Needed to Know About Economics I Learned From Online Dating,” published last month by Harvard Business Review Press. Through his own experience, Mr. Oyer became intrigued by the economics at work in the online dating marketplace. His book explores how knowledge of economic concepts can help narrow Cupid’s aim. Mr. Oyer’s personal strategy turned out to be a winning one: he met his current partner online.

Swami Aseemanand, a former activist with the influential Hindu nationalist group Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, or R.S.S., has been charged with plotting five of these attacks, which collectively killed 119 people.

headline: Flooding and Landslides in Burundi Kill Dozens
text: At least 60 people were killed and dozens injured in Burundi after heavy rains caused flooding and landslides in the small, landlocked African country, a government spokesman, Willy Nyamitwe, said on Monday. Harimenshi Hermes, a spokesman for the police, said that thousands more had been displaced because of damage to their homes. “Many houses in the suburbs were destroyed by the rain,” said Beatrice Nibogora, an information officer for the United Nations in Burundi. “Many of the victims are children, and the houses collapsed on them.” The government said it would organize burials for the dead and treatment for the injured. Torrential rains began on Sunday night and continued into Monday morning, causing power failures and cutting off roadways around Burundi’s capital, Bujumbura. The city sits on the shore of Lake Tanganyika near the border with the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: Tiny Plants’ Loss May Have Doomed Mammoths
text: A 50,000 year analysis of Arctic vegetation history reveals that a change in diet may have led to the demise of the woolly mammoth, the woolly rhinoceros and other large animals, according to a study in the journal Nature. About 10,000 years ago in the Arctic steppe, grasslands began to replace forbs, a flowery plant cover. Animals may have relied on forbs as a source of protein.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: February 7-9, 2014
text: In light of the start of the Florida trial of Michael Dunn, who is accused of shooting an unarmed 17-year-old to death at a gas station, ThinkProgress reported last week that at least 26 children and teens have died in Stand Your Ground cases across the state. Dunn reportedly plans to invoke Stand Your Ground, which states that a person who feels he is in danger may be justified in the use of deadly force, and some are asking whether laws such as these, which have proliferated in at least 20 states, empower people to shoot first and ask questions later.

headline: Seeking the Keys to Longevity in ‘What Makes Olga Run?’
text: No one would mistake Olga Kotelko for one of the Olympians competing in Sochi, Russia, but at age 94, she holds more world records than most: 26, to be exact, including age-group bests in the high jump, the hammer throw and the 200-meter run. Not bad for someone who took up track and field at age 77.

headline: Laurie Anderson Performances Planned for Spoleto Festival USA Are Canceled
text: Laurie Anderson’s “Language of the Future,” a work she performed at the River to River Festival in New York in June, was to have had three performances at the Spoleto Festival USA in Charleston, S.C., this spring. But Nigel Redden, the festival’s general director, announced on Monday that the performances, which had been scheduled for June 4, 5 and 7, had been canceled “due to unforeseen circumstances.” The festival would not elaborate, and a call to Ms. Anderson’s studio in New York was not returned. Mr. Redden, in a statement, said that the festival would not offer a substitution for Ms. Anderson’s work.

Most famously, a Spanish judge opened the case that led to the arrest of the former dictator of Chile, Augusto Pinochet.

headline: Next Reading for Big City Book Club
text: This time we outsourced our selection for the Big City Book Club to the writer and satirist Gary Shteyngart. We asked him to pick his favorite book about New York, and remarkably he did not demand that we read his own, newly published memoir, “Little Failure,” about his upbringing as a Russian émigré in Queens. Instead, he selflessly selected “Bright Lights, Big City,” Jay McInerney’s touchstone novel of the hedonistic ’80s life on the other side of the East River. Join us for the online discussion of the novel with Mr. Shteyngart on Monday, March 10, at 6:30 p.m. To join the club and receive regular email updates, visit: nytimes.com/marketing/bigcitybookclub.

headline: Bundle of Joy, Confusion and Doubt

Ms. Gilman’s drama, about a fight over the fate of a baby in jeopardy, concerns itself with two pathologies that have been much in the news: sexual abuse within a family and the corrosive effects of drug addiction. (I probably don’t need to explain why those problems have been screaming from the headlines lately.)

headline: Debating Evolution and Dealing With Climate Change
text: Last Tuesday’s debate between Bill Nye the Science Guy and Ken Ham, president of the Creation Museum, whipped up a Sharknado-like frenzy online. Five hundred thousand viewers and seemingly all of Twitter followed the event live, which pitted evolution against creationism. Some called it a modern-day Scopes “monkey” trial, others a waste of time. The video has more than a million views on YouTube.

headline: Movie Star Points Way to Sanity, Maybe
text: “The Good Luck of Right Now” is only the second nominally adult novel by Matthew Quick, whose attention-getting first was “The Silver Linings Playbook.” Mr. Quick’s other books have been categorized as young adult fiction, though, in his hands, the two genres are not that different. Among the adult aspects of this new book are the degrees of its characters’ dysfunctionality, the jokey fact that one of them can barely complete a word without inserting an obscenity in the middle of it, and that it takes the epistolary form of a series of letters to “Dear Mr. Richard Gere.”

text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced on Monday that it would postpone enforcement of a federal requirement for medium-size employers to provide health insurance to employees and allow larger employers more flexibility in how they provide coverage.

headline: Aging the Stars, a Man-Made Extinction, Being Cold While Globally Warming

headline: Labor Battle at Kellogg Plant in Memphis Drags On

headline: The ‘Grandpas’ of Hockey

The 12-team competition features five players in their 40s, including Petr Nedved of the Czech Republic and Sandis Ozolinsh of Latvia, who bumped into each other in the athletes’ village the other day at that soda fountain of youth, McDonald’s.

headline: Sometimes, Even the Young Know When to Slow Down
text: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has a hit ensemble on its hands with the remarkable Danish String Quartet. This season the group began a three-year residency with the society’s CMS Two program for outstanding younger performers. Having played to acclaim last fall at the Kaplan Penthouse, the ensemble gave its first performance at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. Demand was so great for this sold-out concert that an encore event of the same program was added for Monday night at the Rose Studio.

headline: Alarm and Anger Over Britain’s Lack of Preparation Flood Social Media and the Web
text: Video and other images shared online highlighted just how dire the flooding has become in England. Rivers are bursting their banks, railroad tracks are swamped and thousands of people have been stranded by flooding, particularly in southern England, over the past month.

headline: Fond Farewell to a Ballerina Who Mixes Warmth and Technique
text: A double bill of Jerome Robbins’s “Dances at a Gathering” and George Balanchine’s “Union Jack” might seem an odd choice of program for a ballerina’s farewell performance. Rather than star vehicles, these ballets are ensemble works: 10 fairly equal dancers share the first; an army of more than 70 floods the second. And yet at the David H. Koch Theater on Sunday afternoon, the program succeeded in displaying some of the finest qualities of Jenifer Ringer in her final show with New York City Ballet.

headline: A Mutable Feast
text: BOSTON — Ernest Hemingway was a hoarder. His own prose style may have been spare and economical, but he was unable to part with the words, printed or written, of just about anyone else. According to his fourth wife, Mary, he was incapable of throwing away “anything but magazine wrappers and three-year old newspapers.” A trove of some 2,500 documents collected and preserved at Finca Vigía, Hemingway’s farm outside Havana, and now digitized and newly available at the Hemingway Collection in the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum here, includes diaries, letters, lists, telegrams, insurance policies, bank statements, passports, tickets to bullfights and the Longchamp racecourse in Paris, a brochure from a swimming pool filter company, a page of his son Patrick’s homework and seemingly every Christmas card Hemingway ever received.

headline: The Archaeology of the Stars
text: Four years ago, Anna Frebel, a young astronomer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, found an ancient star in a neighboring galaxy whose chemical composition proved nearly identical to some unusual stars on the outskirts of our own galaxy, which are older than the Milky Way itself.

headline: Even Among the Richest of the Rich, Fortunes Diverge
text: WASHINGTON — YES, we know the economic fortunes of the 99 percent and 1 percent have diverged over the last three or four decades. But the fortunes of the 1 percent and the 0.1 percent, or the 0.01 percent, or the 0.001 percent, have diverged even more. Economists have taken to calling it “fractal inequality.” It is not just that the rich have pulled away from the average American. It is that the richer you are, the more you have pulled away.

Many investment managers are being drawn to E.T.F.’s, too, and are building portfolios substantially or even entirely from them instead of using elaborate combinations of mutual funds and individual securities.

headline: Reactions to Woody Allen and Dylan Farrow
Backstage Beauty Report | Sporty 3-D Hair at 3.1 Phillip Lim
text: Hairstyles captured in fashion photography look amazing — but those coifs need only hold up for a few shutter clicks. Backstage at 3.1 Phillip Lim this afternoon, hair pro Paul Hanlon whipped models’ manes into tousled, sporty-slick styles reminiscent of Bruce Weber’s “O Rio de Janeiro” book from the ’80s, but with a durability that would allow the ‘dos to withstand the rigors of the runway (and several hours’ worth of afterparties). “When you see those pictures, somebody’s gone in and done the hair, and it’s a moment. This is 3-D, the models are walking and moving, and you don’t want anything to fall out,” Hanlon explained. Perhaps that was his full-disclosure reason for applying what he admitted was an “excessive” amount of styling fixers: He first brushed through volumizing mousse for body, then massaged on a root booster to help form a pompadourish flip. Next he saturated strands, section by section, in Moroccanoil Treatment Light to create a wet, separated texture all over, and combed Moroccanoil Intense Curl Cream through on the front before pulling the hair tight on the sides and high on the top. To finish, Hanlon doused it all with hair spray. The maximalist approach went over well, creating a modern vibe that model Maggie Jablonski described as “punk, but artistic and beachy.” The only drawback: how to wash out all that product? Just follow Jablonski’s directive: “Stand and watch it melt away in the shower.”

headline: Court Rejects Apple Appeal in E-Book Case

headline: Anti-Defamation League’s Director to Retire After Leading Group for 27 Years

headline: Use Force to Save Starving Syrians
text: DENVER — THE Syrian people are starving. According to the United Nations, about 800,000 civilians are currently under siege. In areas around the cities of Homs, Aleppo and Deir Ezzor and in parts of the capital, Damascus, no food, medical supplies or humanitarian aid can get in, and people can’t get out. Many have already died under these “starvation sieges” and hundreds of thousands teeter on the brink, subsisting on grass and weeds. In Damascus, a cleric has ruled that under these conditions, Muslims are permitted to eat normally forbidden animals like cats, dogs and donkeys.

headline: Shockers Pursue Perfection One Victory at a Time

Wichita State Coach Gregg Marshall, his gold print tie undone and dark gray suit coat discarded, claimed one couch Saturday night while the rest of his staff fussed with suitcases, hustling for a charter flight home.

headline: A Line of Defense Against the Theft of Personal Data
text: The pattern with credit- and debit-card breaches tends to go something like this: A company like Target or Neiman Marcus announces that thieves may have stolen your card numbers or other information, then the company offers a year of credit-monitoring. But the chastened keeper of your personal data rarely if ever offers to pay for the most potent protection of all: A security freeze on the files that the three big credit bureaus keep on you.

headline: What to Watch from Sochi: February 10
text: SKI JUMPING The women’s competition is making its Olympic debut largely because of the efforts of competitors like the Americans Jessica Jerome and Lindsey Van, who were at the center of the long legal struggle to have it added to the Games program. Another American, Sarah Hendrickson, is the reigning world champion, and she usually would have been the obvious favorite. But Hendrickson, 19, is coming back from a serious knee injury and has not competed since August. Hendrickson struggled in practice and qualifying for the normal hill, and now a different teenager, 17-year-old Sara Takanashi of Japan, is the leading contender to win the gold. NBCSN, 1:30 p.m.

headline: Jury Weighs Whether Former Mayor Tried to Help New Orleans or Himself
text: NEW ORLEANS — After hearing six and a half days of testimony in the federal corruption case of C. Ray Nagin, a jury will now have to determine whether Mr. Nagin was doing his honest best to help a rebuilding city or was a politician on the take.

headline: Robert E. Cooke, Pediatrician Who Helped Create Head Start, Dies at 93
text: Dr. Robert E. Cooke, a pediatrician who helped Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson create major initiatives to benefit children, including Head Start, died on Feb. 2 at his home in Oak Bluffs, Mass., on Martha’s Vineyard. He was 93.

headline: Cuomo Says Education Board’s Plan Dilutes Teacher Reviews
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo attacked state education officials on Monday for what he saw as an attempt to water down a new teacher evaluation system that was one of his earliest legislative triumphs.

text: Updated, Tuesday, 11:48 a.m. | As my colleague Alison Smale reports from Sarajevo, antigovernment protesters returned to the streets in Bosnia on Monday, driven by anger at a dysfunctional political system’s inability to address an economic crisis.

headline: 18 New Subpoenas Authorized in Lane Closing Inquiry
text: The New Jersey legislative committee investigating the controversial lane closings at the George Washington Bridge authorized 18 new subpoenas Monday, including one seeking records that will show who was aboard state police helicopters during the four days of the closings in September.

headline: Clinton Scandal of ’90s Resurfaces With Papers
text: It has been more than 16 years since the Monica Lewinsky sex scandal. The 22-year-old White House intern is now a low-profile 40-year-old. The once-embattled President Bill Clinton has assumed a postpresidential role as global philanthropist and the first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, is now a former senator, a former secretary of state, and a potential 2016 presidential candidate.

headline: Majority of Americans Favor Ties With Cuba, Poll Finds
text: After more than a half-century of official United States hostility toward Cuba punctuated by a comprehensive trade embargo, a majority of Americans — and an even greater majority of Floridians, home to this country’s largest Cuban-American population — now favor normalizing relations or engaging more directly with the Cuban government, according to a nonpartisan survey.

headline: Seattle Gets Its Own Tech Bus Protest
text: SEATTLE — This city’s technology scene, though vibrant, is significantly smaller than that of its cousin to the south, the San Francisco Bay Area. So, too, it seems, are Seattle’s anti-gentrification protests.

headline: U.S. Reaches Out to Indian Opposition Leader It Once Rebuked
text: NEW DELHI — The United States has requested a meeting with Narendra Modi, a candidate for prime minister of India, signaling an attempt to establish a relationship after a chill that dates to 2005, when the American government imposed a visa ban to rebuke him for his role in religious riots in his home state.

text: WASHINGTON — Tuesday is the first state dinner of President Obama’s second term, honoring President François Hollande of France. Come for the intrigue and stay for Mary J. Blige and the cotton candy.

headline: Donovan and Ray Davies to Join Songwriters Hall of Fame
text: The Songwriters Hall of Fame is expected to announce on Tuesday that its 2014 class of inductees will include Donovan, Ray Davies, Graham Gouldman, Mark James and Jim Weatherly. They will be formally inducted in a ceremony in New York on June 12.

text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: A Leading Chinese Economist Warns of a Difficult Year and ‘Dead’ Companies
text: Sounding warnings that could have been made 20 or even 30 years ago, one of China’s most renowned economists said the country’s economy faces a “very difficult” year as it continues confronting a host of problems that have intensified over the past decade.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 9 P.M. (13, 49) BUTCH CASSIDY & THE SUNDANCE KID Long before Paul Newman and Robert Redford immortalized them, Robert Leroy Parker (better known as Butch Cassidy) and Harry Alonzo Longabaugh (the Sundance Kid) captured the country’s attention in the 1890s with their train and bank robberies. But who were they? And how did they manage to pull off spectacular holdups while eluding Pinkerton security forces, only to ride off into the sunset and die in a shootout in Bolivia? In this latest installment in “The Wild West” series presented by “American Experience,” the director John Maggio follows the men as they formed the Wild Bunch, rode the Outlaw Trail finding work as ranch hands, and escaped to South America.

headline: UBS Suspends 2 Bankers in China Hiring Investigation
text: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | UBS has suspended two staff members, including its top capital markets banker in Asia, as the Swiss bank investigates its hiring of the daughter of the chairman of a Chinese chemicals company that is considering a $1 billion share sale the bank has sought a role in.

text: Updated, 8:26 p.m. | LONDON – Barclays said on Tuesday that it would cut as many 12,000 jobs this year, or about 8 percent of its work force, as part of a painful restructuring that began a year ago.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | N.F.L. Prospect Michael Sam Proudly Says What Teammates Knew: He’s Gay

headline: A Note on Presidents’ Week
text: We’re taking the day off on this national holiday — and, since many schools will be out this week, we’re also suspending daily lesson plans until Monday, Feb. 24.

headline: American Lugers Annoyed by Group’s Gay Rights Video
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — There was a ripple of discontent over a gay rights issue at the Sochi Games on Tuesday, but it had nothing to do with Russia.

headline: How Credit-Card Debt Can Help the Poor
text: Last October, Jeffrey Shavers, a hotel maintenance worker in Chicago, took out an extremely unusual $300 loan. Shavers might have liked to use the money to visit his daughter, a college student in New Orleans, or to buy his 10-year-old son a new bike. But he couldn’t, because Shavers never actually saw the money. The cash went into a locked savings account that he couldn’t access. “It’s like an abstract $300,” he explained.

headline: African-American History, From Family Albums to Museum Walls
text: Although the photographer Hugh Bell had been part of “The Family of Man” exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art, he later realized inclusivity went only so far when he called to pitch a story to an editor at Esquire.

headline: Is It Unethical for a Zoo to Kill a Healthy Giraffe?
text: This weekend a Danish zoo euthanized a healthy 2-year-old giraffe. Bengt Holst, the zoo’s scientific director, explained, “We don’t do it to be cruel; we do it to ensure a healthy population.” But many animal rights activists, who mounted a furious last-minute campaign to save the giraffe, angrily protested the killing.

headline: R.B.S. Names New Head of British Retail Bank
text: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Tuesday that it had picked one of its own as the new head of its retail bank in Britain.

headline: Banking While Russian
text: IT was the quintessential immigrant moment. Two weeks after my family and I had arrived in New York, a friend drove me to Costco. Half an hour later, at the cash register, I was hidden from view by the pyramid of diapers, napkins and other paper products in the shopping cart. My friend laughed and snapped a picture, promising to post it online with the caption, “Masha comes to America.”

headline: At North’s Suggestion, Koreas Open Dialogue
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North and South Korea on Wednesday started their highest-level government dialogue since the North’s nuclear test last year prompted fears of armed conflict on the divided Korean Peninsula.

headline: New York Today: Greenmarket Blues

headline: China and Taiwan Hold First Direct Talks Since ’49
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Representatives of Taiwan and China held their first official talks on Tuesday since the end of China’s civil war in 1949, a meeting expected to produce few concrete results but one that was a symbolic development in the easing of the two sides’ longtime rivalry.

headline: Times Minute | Sochi's Halfpipe Problems
text: Also on the Minute, a personal conflict for Palestinians employed by Israeli companies in the occupied West Bank and a collection of Ernest Hemingway papers goes digital.

headline: Fashion Week Morning Report: Globe-Trotters
text: Hers was the label that launched a thousand flats. Tory Burch leads off Tuesday of New York Fashion Week with a 9 a.m. show at Lincoln Center’s Avery Fisher Hall. Ms. Burch first struck retail gold with her medallion-bearing Revas, but she has since found hit after hit (and expanded to store after store after store worldwide). For spring, she went as far afield as her collection — in this case, poolside, Franco-American style, channeling Romy Schneider in the 1969 film “La Piscine.” Next up? Only Ms. Burch knows. Wherever first-class travel can take her, one supposes.

headline: Shaun White’s Run Ends With a Thud Instead of a Gold
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Shaun White stood at the top of the halfpipe, the last contestant of the competition, needing a near-perfect run to capture his third consecutive gold medal at the Winter Olympics. He has built an empire on such moments.

headline: Shirley Temple Black, Hollywood’s Biggest Little Star, Dies at 85
text: Shirley Temple Black, who as a dimpled, precocious and determined little girl in the 1930s sang and tap-danced her way to a height of Hollywood stardom and worldwide fame that no other child has reached, died on Monday night at her home in Woodside, Calif. She was 85.

headline: Hollande’s United States Visit
text: President Hollande of France is invited to a state dinner at the White House.

headline: Seeking a Spoiler-Free Sochi Olympics
text: The yawning time difference between Sochi, Russia, and the United States has presented a challenge for people who want to watch NBC’s nightly Olympics coverage: avoiding spoilers. Even just grazing on your favorite websites and social media platforms can lead to discovering the outcome of an event before it hits TV, possibly deflating some of the joy in the drama.

headline: From Paul McCartney to Thakoon
text: Liz Goldwyn, a writer and filmmaker (and recent Sunday Styles cover subject), was at the Thakoon show on Sunday, unfashionably early and sitting by herself on a bench in the middle of the room, waiting for her seatmates Taylor Schilling, of “Orange Is the New Black,” and Caitlin FitzGerald, of “Masters of Sex,” to show up.

headline: Cries of ‘Death to America’ as Iranians Celebrate 35th Anniversary of Revolution
text: TEHRAN — Mixing exhortations of death to America with admonishments to children about healthy teeth and gums, Iran celebrated the 35th anniversary of the Islamic Revolution on Tuesday, and the state news media said millions had exuberantly participated.

headline: Bank of England to Investigate Foreign Exchange Manipulation Claims

headline: Examining AOL’s Apology
text: ‘APOLOGY WATCH’: AOL EDITION  |  Last week, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Dov Seidman started “Apology Watch” on DealBook to track apologies and follow up on what companies, institutions and individuals have done post-apology. And then, almost on cue, a highly publicized case study arrived courtesy of Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, Mr. Sorkin writes in this week’s DealBook column.

headline: Is There a Role For Wildlife Trade in Fighting Wildlife Trafficking?
text: An important two-day meeting is under way in London exploring fresh approaches to stemming the booming illegal trade in rare wildlife. The meeting, International Wildlife Trafficking: Solutions to a Global Crisis, was organized by the Royal Zoological Society, Wildlife Conservation Society and other groups. You can read the agenda here and dip in to watch a live video stream here:

text: LONDON – Mallinckrodt, an Irish specialty pharmaceutical company, said Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Cadence Pharmaceuticals for about $1.3 billion in cash.

headline: Attack on Movie Theater in Pakistan Kills 11
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A grenade attack on a movie theater killed 11 people and injured 25 in the northern Pakistani city of Peshawar on Tuesday, police and hospital officials said. It was the second such attack in Peshawar, the capital of the restive Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province, this month.

headline: Penguin Withdraws Book by American Scholar of Hinduism to Settle Lawsuit
text: BANGALORE — Penguin Books India, a unit of Penguin Random House, has agreed to withdraw and destroy all copies of a 2009 book on Hinduism by an American scholar to settle a lawsuit by a Hindu nationalist group that had objected to the book’s portrayal of the religion.

headline: Arrests in New York and Italy Thwart Mob Drug Scheme, Authorities Say
text: The mobsters, from the Calabria region of Italy, wanted a foothold in the underworld of New York City and thought their success smuggling drugs into Europe would serve them well on this side of the Atlantic.

headline: Artworks Removed From Austria Home of German Who Holds Huge Trove
text: BERLIN — For several days last November, reporters in Salzburg, Austria, staked out 9 Carl-Storch-Strasse, a rundown house in an elegant neighborhood identified as the home of Cornelius Gurlitt by a small metal plate on the door. Reports that the German authorities had confiscated a trove of 1,280 artworks, some of them suspected of having been traded or looted during the Nazi era, from Mr. Gurlitt’s apartment in Munich had set off a global outcry and deep curiosity.

headline: Stripe and Square Face Complexity Abroad
text: LONDON – International users now generate the majority of traffic for the social media giants Facebook and Twitter, and fast-growing tech companies like Airbnb, the online property rental service, have expanded rapidly into non-American markets to ward off local competitors.

headline: Holder Urges States to Lift Bans on Felons’ Voting
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. called Tuesday for the repeal of laws that prohibit millions of felons from voting, underscoring the Obama administration’s determination to elevate issues of criminal justice and race in the president’s second term and create a lasting civil rights legacy.

text: What was once the world’s largest Bitcoin exchange, Mt. Gox, appeared near collapse on Monday, the latest symbol of the woes facing early players in the world of virtual currencies, Nathaniel Popper reports.

headline: House Approves Higher Debt Limit Without Condition
text: WASHINGTON — Ending three years of brinkmanship in which the threat of a devastating default on the nation’s debt was used to wring conservative concessions from President Obama, the House on Tuesday voted to raise the government’s borrowing limit until March 2015, without any conditions.

headline: Islamic Extremists Slaughter 15 Soldiers in Northern Iraqi City
text: BAGHDAD — Fighters from a Sunni extremist group attacked an army unit in a northern Iraqi city on Tuesday, killing 15 soldiers in a rampage of beheadings, shootings and a hanging, security officials said.

headline: Food Matters | A Pilgrimage to a Plate
text: With his Michelin-starred restaurant, In De Wulf, Kobe Desramaults is the latest innovative chef to turn nowhere — here, a remote corner of Belgium — into a culinary somewhere.

headline: Finance Magnates Among Top Donors in 2013
text: David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder of the private equity giant Carlyle Group, is a fan of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. So much so, in fact, that he donated $50 million to the center last year. His total donations of $121.7 million ranked No. 21 on The Chronicle of Philanthropy’s 2013 list of top American donors.

headline: Military Plane Crash in Algeria Leaves Scores Dead
text: PARIS — An Algerian military plane crashed in a mountainous area of northeastern Algeria on Tuesday, and by nightfall rescuers had recovered at least 77 bodies and one survivor, according to Algerian National Television.

headline: A.B.A. Nominates New Jersey Lawyer as President
text: The American Bar Association, the 400,000-member group that establishes standards for law schools and formulates codes of conduct and ethics for lawyers, has nominated Paulette Brown as its president.

text: With La Quinta Holdings moving toward an initial public offering, its parent, the Blackstone Group, has shown that it’s still an eager seller.

headline: Karen O, Inspired by ‘The Jerk’
text: If there were a prize for most indie recording at the Oscars, Karen O’s “Moon Song,” featured in the film “Her,” would probably take it: she recorded it in her downtown Manhattan apartment, at her dining room table, as a demo for the actors to use. It was entirely off the cuff. “The first thing you hear” on the track, she said, “is the sirens going off on Lafayette Street,” from the nearby firehouse.

headline: Inequality and Indignity
text: In the aftermath of the CBO report, the initial botched reporting and political interpretation, and the subsequent backlash, conservatives have had two choices. They can stay with the lies about job destruction — and many have; or they can talk about the work disincentives and claim that they are a terrible thing.
