text: Does Fido deserve some pampering?

headline: Donna Karan: Three Decades in Fashion
text: With Rita Ora spilling out of a black wrap dress and Katie Holmes in a chiffon skirt and leather top that was as sleek as a rain-soaked Manhattan street, Donna Karan celebrated 30 years of serving women with meaningful fashion.

headline: When Marijuana Looks Like Candy, Not Drugs
text: This is not what I thought marijuana looked like.

headline: The Great Civil War Escape
text: Thomas Rose could see the Union troops approaching from the east. After five days of torturous travel on foot, he was about to make good his escape from Richmond’s infamous Libby Prison. Awaiting the arrival of his comrades, he noticed three soldiers to his rear. Assuming they were a federal vanguard, he rose to greet them, only to find himself recaptured. After wrestling a musket from one of his captors and firing it into the air, Rose ran toward the approaching Yankees. A dozen rebel soldiers quickly knocked him to the ground and bound him for return to Richmond, ending the short-lived escape of one of the masterminds of the Civil War’s most celebrated prison break.

headline: Chasing Gold (and Jeans That Fit)
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — There was no way to ask the question without sounding slightly creepy, but the downhill skier Jan Hudec kindly answered it with cheerful Canadian candor. “Yes, I have an enormous butt,” he said.

headline: Thomas Frank, Author and Historian, Will Join Salon
text: Salon Media Group said Tuesday that it was hiring Thomas Frank, the historian and author best known for his book “What’s the Matter With Kansas,” to write feature articles every Sunday as well as weigh in on current events as warranted.

headline: Fitch Cuts Puerto Rico’s Debt to Junk
text: Fitch Ratings lowered Puerto Rico’s debt to junk status on Tuesday, becoming the last of the top three ratings agencies to downgrade the financially struggling island.

headline: Do We Really Need Negative Book Reviews?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Zoë Heller discuss whether bad books should be written about or ignored.

headline: Alibaba’s Online Land Grab
text: Alibaba’s purchase of AutoNavi is a land grab, in two senses.

headline: New Round of Syria Talks Off to a Slow Start
text: GENEVA — Face-to-face peace talks between the Syrian government and opposition representatives here failed to make progress on Tuesday, both sides said, each making statements indicating that they were still talking past each other in this new round of discussions.

headline: Anna Kendrick at Carolina Herrera
text: Monday mornings usually take some easing in, but not for the Fashion Week herd, which continued to swarm runway spaces, battle for taxis and pick its way around icy sidewalks. Among the crowd at Lincoln Center for the Carolina Herrera show at 10 a.m. was the actress Anna Kendrick, who was seated next to Emmy Rossum and across the runway from Tina Fey.

headline: J. Crew: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: A Lighthouse in Winter
text: I occasionally try to step back from the nonstop flow of environmental news to consider the beautiful basics that too often hide in plain sight on a busy planet. I’ve explored the cycles of life on a farm and four seasons in a patch of woods in my part of the Hudson Valley. On Facebook, I’ve been enjoying an extraordinary photographic journal chronicling hour-by-hour changes in light and weather on the Hudson River around the Rondout Creek Lighthouse at Kingston, N.Y.  The images are taken by Carolyn Marks Blackwood, an award-winning film producer and photographer whose home and studio are perched on a ledge in Rhinecliff, on the opposite bank.

headline: The Dirty Martini Cleans Up Well
text: In this age of the aspirational cocktail, when bar menus can read like manifestoes or museum catalogs, certain drink orders are guaranteed to ignite the spleen of the serious bartender. Among them: the mojito (a lot of labor, particularly if customers ask for seven, which they often do); the Cosmopolitan (“Sex and the City” ended a while back); the vodka Red Bull (take your bad decisions outside); and the Bloody Mary, if ordered at night (seriously?).

Veerappa Moily, to look into whether the two men and others colluded to keep gas prices high.

headline: John Mack Calls for an End to ‘Beating Up’ on Wall St. C.E.O.’s
text: JPMorgan Chase touched off a round of criticism when it disclosed that it would give its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, a big raise for 2013, a year in which the bank paid billions to resolve legal problems. But another Wall Street titan came to Mr. Dimon’s defense on Tuesday.

headline: Eye Infection Forces Costas to Step Aside From Olympics Coverage

headline: Pop’s Prairie Woman Finds a Jazz Home on Broadway
text: Few would dispute that the Canadian singer-songwriter K. D. Lang has one of the great pop singing voices of our time. But in recent years, Ms. Lang, now 52, has retreated from the spotlight. On Tuesday, in a bold career move, she is replacing Fantasia Barrino in the jazz revue “After Midnight” — set in the Cotton Club in Harlem in the early 1930s — singing four songs with Wynton Marsalis’s Jazz at Lincoln Center All-Stars.

headline: New York State’s Top Judge Permits Early Bar Exam in Exchange for Pro Bono Work
text: In an effort to bolster the number of lawyers for the poor, New York State’s top judge has cleared the way for law students to take the bar exam early in return for devoting their last semester to pro bono work.

headline: Giffords to Write Book on Gun Violence

Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, previously released Ms. Giffords’s memoir in 2011, also co-written with her husband.

headline: Parents Are Poor Judges of Children’s Weight
text: Many parents apparently believe their children are leaner than they actually are.

headline: Hilary Mantel Portrait to Be Displayed at British Library
text: You might think, given Britain’s long and celebrated literary history, that portraits of British authors would have found their way into the British Library while those writers were still alive. But you would be wrong, at least for the next few days. On Feb. 24, a portrait of Hilary Mantel, painted by Nick Lord, will become the first painting of a living author to be displayed at the museum.

headline: Arcade Fire Gets Inside Spike Jonze’s Brain
text: Like Karen O, the members of Arcade Fire have long known and collaborated with Spike Jonze. They worked on his last movie, “Where the Wild Things Are,” and he directed a short film for their  album “The Suburbs” (and a live video for their song “Afterlife” at the YouTube Awards). So even though the band, based in Montreal, was busy working on its latest record, “Reflektor,” the musicians were eager to help Mr. Jonze with “Her.”

headline: Goldman Sachs Adds Five to Management Committee
text: Goldman Sachs has added five executives to the firm’s influential management committee, a group of Goldman insiders that has the ear of the bank’s top brass.

headline: Detainees Sentenced in Seconds in ‘Streamline’ Justice on Border
text: TUCSON — “My record is 30 minutes,” Magistrate Judge Bernardo P. Velasco of Federal District Court here said one afternoon, describing the speed with which he had sealed the fates of 70 migrants caught sneaking into the country. Each of the accused had 25 seconds, give or take, to hear the charges against him, enter a plea and receive a sentence.

headline: With Christie Under Fire, Republican Governors Have Big Fund-Raising Month
text: The Republican Governors Association announced on Wednesday that it had set a January record for fund-raising, seeking to refute suggestions that the troubles of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey have scared away the group’s donors.

headline: Former New York Cultural Commissioner Takes Fellowship at Southern Methodist University
text: Kate D. Levin, New York City’s former cultural affairs commissioner, has been appointed the first fellow at Southern Methodist University’s arts research center in Dallas, the university announced on Tuesday.

headline: Modified Corn a Step Closer to Approval in Europe
text: LONDON — After 13 years, six scientific opinions and two legal challenges, an insect-resistant type of corn is on the verge of being approved by the European Union. It would be only the third genetically modified crop to be authorized for cultivation in the 28-nation bloc.

headline: The Gun Report: February 11, 2014
text: This weekend, motorists in Beaumont, Tex., were treated to a peculiar sight: a man in a banana costume toting an AK-47 and a drum magazine with a 50-round capacity. He was promoting the grand opening of a nearby gun shop, Golden Triangle Tactical. Police let the 18-year-old go with a citation for violating a city ordinance which prohibits soliciting alongside roadways.

headline: The Debt Ceiling Is Now Pointless
text: After Speaker John Boehner announced this morning that he would let a clean increase of the debt ceiling pass with mostly Democratic votes, I imagined what the country would be like if he let all bills come to a majority vote, instead of just those bills Republicans approve.

headline: Obama Welcomes Hollande to the U.S.
text: President Obama and his French counterpart, President François Hollande, held a joint news conference to discuss a continuing alliance.

headline: Shelby Cobra Coupe Becomes the First Federally Registered Historic Car
text: A 1964 Shelby Cobra Daytona Coupe has become the first vehicle recorded under a federal program to identify and preserve important engineering marvels, the Historic Vehicle Association annouced last month.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Theory Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Dina Litovsky.

headline: Get Ready for a Long Proxy Fight Over Time Warner Cable

headline: Appeals Court Allows Challenges by Detainees at Guantánamo Prison
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruled Tuesday that judges had the power to oversee complaints by detainees about the conditions of their confinement at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The ruling was a defeat for the Obama administration and may open the door to new lawsuits by the remaining 155 Guantánamo inmates.

headline: U.S. Center for Russian Studies to Shut Moscow Office
text: MOSCOW — The Kennan Institute, a research center co-founded by George F. Kennan, the seminal Cold War theorist, that has fostered the study of Russia and the former Soviet Union since 1974, will shutter its office in Moscow this spring.

headline: On This Red Carpet, Aging Is Desirable
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — You know something has shifted in Hollywood when well-known actresses in their 40s dare to show up at the AARP awards. Reminding a youth-obsessed town that time marches on? Career suicide, or at least it used to be.

headline: Vail Dance Festival Announces Lineup
text: The American Ballet Theater principal Herman Cornejo will be the artist in residence at the 2014 Vail International Dance Festival, performing with the Pennsylvania Ballet and the Martha Graham Dance Company. The festival, which runs from July 27 to Aug. 9 in Vail, Colo., and is led by Damian Woetzel, will also feature the return of Wendy Whelan, bringing her “Restless Creature” project; a collaboration between the Taiwanese modern dancer Fang-Yi Sheu and the classical Indian dancer Shantala Shivalingappa; and new works by the Memphis jooker Lil Buck, and the contemporary dance choreographers Brian Brooks and Matthew Neenan.

headline: WWS 472, Economics of the Welfare State, Class 2: Health Care
text: Notes here (pdf).

headline: German Wins First Women’s Ski Jump
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — It took 90 years for women to earn the right to ski jump in the Winter Games and just a day to crown their first Olympic champion.

headline: Steve Reich Is Awarded $550,000 Prize by Spanish Foundation
text: The composer Steve Reich has won the 2013 BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award for contemporary composition, Mr. Reich’s publisher, Boosey & Hawkes, announced on Tuesday. The award, which is given by a foundation associated with a Spanish financial services group, carries a cash prize of 400,000 euros (about $550,000), and is to be presented at a ceremony in June.

headline: Rodarte: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: In Paris, a Worldly Good Deal
text: Savvy travelers know that location is everything, so it’s likely that Jules Verne, the world-roving French author of the celebrated 1873 adventure novel “Around the World in Eighty Days,” would be impressed by the 25-room Hôtel du Continent on the Rue du Mont-Thabor in Paris, newly renovated just in time for Paris Fashion Week. It’s tucked away right in the heart of the city in the stylish First Arrondissement on a charming back street that runs parallel to the boutique-lined Rue Saint-Honoré — and it’s only steps from the Louvre, the Tuileries Garden, the Place Vendôme and the Place de la Concorde too.

headline: Mark McNairy New Amsterdam: Fall 2014 RTW

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 5
text: Barneys toasted transgender campaign; Galore celebrated new issue; Purple held its seasonal bash.

headline: Midnight at the Museum, Breakfast at the Vatican
text: How about breakfast at the Vatican Museums before they open?

headline: Why Norovirus Crops Up on Cruises
text: It has not been the best season for cruise ships. By the time the Explorer of the Seas docked at Bayonne, N.J., late last month, more than 600 passengers and crew members were sick to their stomachs; the Caribbean Princess arrived in Houston the same day after an outbreak sickened at least 192 people onboard.

headline: In Letters, a Literary Force Lets Readers In
text: When The Paris Review finally got around to interviewing Malcolm Cowley in 1982, when he was 84, among the first questions the magazine posed was this: “Do you regret not having concentrated more fully on your poetry?” Cowley said yes. His problem, he added, “was the essentially middle-class feeling that I had to support myself.”

headline: Executions Are Suspended by Governor in Washington
text: The governor of Washington, Jay Inslee, announced Tuesday that no executions would take place in the state while he remained in office, despite the fact that the death penalty was legal there.

headline: Social Media Dispatches: Death and Destruction in Central African Republic
text: Witnesses have been documenting the violence in the Central African Republic over the past few days, with relentless slaughter and traces of entire communities wiped out as thousands of Muslims fled their homes to escape retaliatory attacks.

headline: Back Home, Sense of Pride in Michael Sam
text: Michael Sam, a defensive end at Missouri who will enter the N.F.L. draft, announced Sunday that he was gay. People in his hometown of Hitchcock, Tex., and on his college team voiced their support.

headline: Before Coming Out, a Hard Time Growing Up
text: COLUMBIA, Mo. — Michael Sam was the loud country boy who wore a tank top and a cowboy hat. He was the smooth-singing baritone who could irritate his coaches and crack up his teammates with his improvised songs.

headline: President Obama Speaks on Syria
text: President Obama answered a question from Mark Landler, a White House Correspondent for The New York Times, about the ongoing crisis in Syria and about putting pressure on the Assad regime.

headline: The Song Doesn’t Remain the Same
text: In January the U.S. military and I celebrated our 42nd anniversary. Sort of. I am one of those modern soldiers with commitment issues. I enlisted in the Air Force Jan. 31, 1972.

text: To Learn: A Culinary Exchange in the Kitchen

headline: Goldman Handed Out Cosmetic Mirrors and Nail Files at Women’s Coding Event
text: Updated, 8:43 p.m. | Goldman Sachs was the biggest sponsor of a Harvard event last weekend aimed at women interested in computer science. But the Wall Street bank’s conference swag at the event was found off-putting by at least one attendee.

headline: A Mad Den of Beasts, Maniacally Cackling
text: The seven women of LeeSaar the Company are a sleek pack. In “Grass and Jackals,” which had its New York premiere on Saturday in the troupe’s debut performance at the Joyce Theater, they are sheathed in black bodysuits. Under thick black slabs of painted-on eyebrows, their eyes gaze out with the look of animals encountered in the wild: now sanguinely alert, now spooked. Then they smile like contestants in a beauty pageant, a different kind of watched beast.

headline: The 13-Page Preschool Application
text: Holding a 13-page form from the pile on our dining room table, I called out across our apartment, trying to get my husband’s attention. This preschool application asked for not only an essay about my 23-month-old daughter, but also a reference letter, both mine and my husband’s credentials, and whether we were trustees at any major institutions. But it was the line where I was supposed to write my email address that really made me palpitate.

headline: A World Unprepared, Again, for Rising Interest Rates
text: MEXICO CITY — I was living in São Paulo in 1997 when, out of the blue, an investment banker I knew in London called to ask about Brazilian cocktails. He didn’t want one. He needed a name for a potential economic crisis, in the vein of Mexico’s Tequila affair in 1994 and Thailand’s Tom Yum Kung debacle, which was unfolding at the time.

headline: Hugh Jackman to Host the Tony Awards
text: Hugh Jackman will once again host the Tony Awards ceremony, which will be held on June 8 at Radio City Music Hall, the producers of the event announced on Tuesday. (Mr. Jackman made his own announcement via Instagram). A top Broadway box-office draw in the shows “Hugh Jackman: Back on Broadway,” “A Steady Rain” and “The Boy From Oz,” Mr. Jackman will follow Neil Patrick Harris, who hosted the awards for the past three seasons. Mr. Harris may be a Tony nominee himself this year in his role as the lead character in the coming Broadway production of “Hedwig and the Angry Inch.”

headline: Diesel Black Gold: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: What Makes Older People Happy
text: Every year, my husband and I wonder what kind of birthday gift to give his dad, now 86 years old. The newest gadget, which may be admired but almost surely will be put in a drawer? Something much more ordinary, like one of the cardigan sweaters he wears day in and day out?

headline: Teaching the Sochi Olympics | History, Geography and Social Studies
text: Updated: Feb. 13

headline: Living in Bedford Park, the Bronx
text: Affordable home prices, interesting prewar housing and good transportation draw buyers to the neighborhood.

headline: Attention Priced-Out Shoppers
text: As Brooklyn neighborhoods grow more expensive and the city’s affordability frontier shifts to the Bronx, Bedford Park, in the north-central section of the borough, could become prime territory, being both stable and financially within reach.

headline: L’Oréal’s Deal With Nestlé Puts Zaoui Brothers Back in Spotlight
text: L’Oréal’s deal to buy back 8 percent of itself from Nestlé has been a long time coming, with a number of big names involved.

headline: Why Can’t You Find That Wine?
text: Often plaintive and occasionally hostile, the missives arrive regularly by email, snail mail and phone: “You have an uncanny ability to discuss wines that are difficult if not impossible to find,” one California reader wrote in June.

text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Democrats and Republicans Unite Against Phone Calls on Airplanes
text: Congress may be deeply divided along partisan lines on most important national issues, but it turns out there is one thing Republicans and Democrats do agree on: restricting cellphone calls on planes.

headline: Yankees’ Newest Star Welcomes Biggest Stage
text: Nobody sells hope like the Yankees. Nobody has such easy access to it. With their money and their marquee, they are a magnetic draw to an overseas sensation like Masahiro Tanaka, who buttoned up a No. 19 pinstriped jersey on Tuesday, tugged on that famous navy blue cap and proclaimed, in English, “I’m very happy to be a Yankee.”

headline: Yellen and the Labor Market
text: In her first testimony as Fed chair, Janet Yellen said — as we all hoped and expected she would — that she doesn’t believe that the conventional unemployment rate gives a good picture of the amount of labor market slack. She mentioned, in particular, the high level of long-term unemployment and the large number of involuntary part-time workers.

headline: How’s Your Ballot Looking?
text: With less than three weeks to go until the Academy Award for best picture is revealed, New York Times readers are in synch with many Oscar prognosticators — sort of. Everyone seems to agree that there’s more than one front-runner. But how many leaders are there?

text: Slides here (pdf). For those following, Class 3 basically covered the material posted here for the snowed-out class 2, with some brief discussion of the Great Moderation folded in — it turned out that this topic was kind of thin anyway.

headline: Jazzing Things Up, on Piano and on Vocals, as She Has for Decades
text: Call it an early sign of spring in an especially punishing winter. The aptly nicknamed “first lady of jazz piano,” Barbara Carroll, opened her return engagement to Birdland on Saturday evening with a vigorous performance of “Let’s Face the Music and Dance.”

headline: Gatti Cancels Carnegie Hall Appearances
text: Updated, Feb. 14 Daniele Gatti, a conductor with a growing international career, has canceled two planned Carnegie Hall appearances with the Vienna Philharmonic — and the rest of his engagements for the next two months — citing inflamed tendons in his shoulders, Carnegie Hall announced.

text: NEW HAVEN — A firm that once turned up its nose at this collegiate city now wants to build a $360 million mixed-use development on a downtown parking lot.

headline: A Fashion Trend: Bigger Showrooms and Smaller Offices
text: With smartphones replacing landlines and online calendars doing the work of assistants, it often seems as if the modern office has moved permanently into cyberspace.

headline: A Performer Hews to the Shadows for Schubert Songs of Anguish and Joy
text: Wolfgang Holzmair did not so much perform for the audience assembled on Sunday evening at the Frick Collection as permit it to observe him.

headline: Love’s Details Translated
text: Amanda Majeski’s concert on Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall finally hit its stride when it began to feel like a cabaret show. Polished and sly, Ms. Majeski, a young American soprano, closed the program with the four songs that Britten wrote in the late 1930s for the singer and actress Hedli Anderson, to wry poems by Auden.

text: WHEN I ASKED a friend to meet me for dinner at a food court near the Javits Convention Center, he acted as if I had suggested we fill a fanny pack with Hot Pockets and eat them on the back of a bus.

headline: Feeling Economic Pressure, Kazakhstan Takes Sudden Action

text: SEATTLE — A potent premise fails to deliver the goods in “A Great Wilderness,” the frustratingly limp new drama by the talented Samuel D. Hunter (“A Bright New Boise,” “The Whale”), having its premiere here at Seattle Repertory Theater.

headline: On the Horizon: A Winter Tournament Waged in Snow
text: On Feb. 22, as the Olympics wind to a close, more than 150 teams will meet at the foot of a 1,300-foot volcanic dome, in Sobetso, Japan, to splatter each other with snowballs at the 26th annual Showa-Shinzan International Yukigassen (Snow Battle).

headline: Filling Club Spaces With Dance Beats and Arena-Size Sound
text: Oversize glasses, check. Asymmetrical haircut, check. Arm-pumping, climb-on-the-D.J.-desk enthusiasm, check. Lasers, check. And most of all: bass, check.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, South Sudan and Sochi, Russia. More images from the Winter Olympics here.

headline: Obama Greets France’s Leader, but Warns Against Doing Business With Iran
text: WASHINGTON — With the French president looking on, President Obama vowed on Tuesday to come down on companies that evade sanctions against Iran “like a ton of bricks.” He spoke a week after a delegation of French corporate executives traveled to Tehran looking for business opportunities amid diplomatic efforts to reach a nuclear deal.

headline: Antisurveillance Campaign Adds Itself to Washington’s Datebook
text: The antisurveillance crowd is trying to get onto the government’s radar. And though it’s a busy Tuesday in the nation’s capital, they seem to be having some success, repurposing an effective 2012 campaign to stop two Internet-related laws. But this time, instead of trying to block measures, a coalition of civil liberties groups and technology companies is flooding social media with calls to pass legislation that would limit the surveillance powers of the National Security Agency.

headline: Karen Elson at Tory Burch
text: The morning rush hour didn’t wait for the Fashion Week faces who dotted Tory Burch’s 9 a.m. show on Tuesday. Anna Kendrick and Q-Tip made it minutes before the first model strutted the runway. Ditto the model Karen Elson, who later attended Rodarte’s “Star Wars” themed spectacle and has had quite the last few days, on the catwalk and off.

headline: Three Men Leap Forward at City Ballet
text: Sara Mearns, a glory of New York City Ballet for several seasons, has recently brought a newly adult quality to her roles. But what consort has been worthy of her? An answer has at last emerged: Zachary Catazaro, who after Christmas danced in a couple of “Nutcrackers” as Cavalier to the Sugar Plum Fairy of Ms. Mearns and went on to partner her in other works. Their shared look of beauty, glamour, maturity and authority induced awe.

headline: S.E.C.’s Review of Stock Trading Will See Some of Its Own Work
text: There are now at least 58 stock exchanges in the United States, many of them dark pools where the trades can be made anonymously. With institutional investors claiming they are outgunned by high-frequency traders, and individual investors adrift in fragmented markets, it’s no wonder that Mary Jo White, the new head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is moving to review and overhaul how stocks are traded. The issue is that the S.E.C. may have created the problem it is now hoping to solve.

headline: Graco Recalls Car Seats Over Faulty Buckle
text: Graco Children’s Products is recalling almost 3.8 million car seats because faulty buckles can make it hard to free the child in an emergency, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: Build Your Own Chaos
text: What is the best way to play with Lego bricks? From youth, we have been able to dabble with a choice: conformity versus creativity.

headline: Sochi Video Notebook: Shaun White
text: The snowboarder spoke about his legacy after finishing fourth in the men’s halfpipe final in Sochi.

headline: Art Matters | Old and New Worlds Collide Around Mexico City’s Zona Maco
text: While tradition is big in Mexico City, bureaucratic efficiency is not. This past weekend marked the 11th edition of the Zona Maco art fair, which this year switched its dates surreptitiously from April to February, risking administrative upheaval in today’s ever-more-scheduled and globalized art world. Though Zona Maco proclaims itself Latin America’s most important fair, international gallerists and collectors seem to return not out of obligation, but because of the adventures and the pleasures its host city has to offer.

headline: Exploring Black Americans’ Opinions of Same-Sex Marriage
text: Perched precariously at the intersection of race, religion and sexual identity, “The New Black,” Yoruba Richen’s calm and nuanced exploration of African-American attitudes toward same-sex marriage, balances crude filmmaking with sophisticated insights.

headline: Beside the Flash of Gold, a Shadow
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The athletes willingly accept the risks in winter sports in which yesterday’s jaw-dropping trick too quickly becomes the new normal.

headline: Less Redemption, More Tears
text: The existential battle that rages through “RoboCop,” a nicely cast, respectable remake of the wittily corrosive 1987 Paul Verhoeven film, is less the struggle between man and machine than between the original’s pop nihilism and the bottom-line commercialism driving this new vehicle. Once again, an ordinary man, a Detroit cop, Alex Murphy (Joel Kinnaman), is transformed by corporate interests into a cyborg after being critically wounded in the line of duty. And, as before, the reanimated creature walks and talks like a latter-day Frankenstein’s monster, his recognizably human parts encased in an artificial carapace, although this version also mixes in tears with the bullets.

headline: Long-Term Care Insurance Priced by Gender
text: Deciding to buy long-term-care insurance is a big financial commitment — even more so if you are a woman.

headline: Putin Ally Claims Not to See Racism in Fake Image of Obama Craving Banana on Her Twitter Feed
text: Last Updated, 8:39 p.m. | One day after she apologized for a digitally altered image of President Obama posted on her Twitter feed, the Russian official who helped light the Olympic caldron to open the Sochi Games told the BBC that she had no idea why the fake photograph was racist.

headline: Samvir Sidhu
text: Mr. Sidhu, 30, who goes by Sam, is the managing principal of Megalith Capital, which recently moved its headquarters to New York from Philadelphia. The company specializes in multifamily developments. Its current projects include a condominium conversion in TriBeCa, as well as a condo conversion and rental development in Dumbo, Brooklyn.

headline: U.N. Court, on Appeal, Acquits 2 Rwandans in 1994 Genocide
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Twenty years after the small African nation of Rwanda descended into a frenzy of killing, a special United Nations court announced Tuesday that two high-ranking Rwandan officers convicted of taking part in the 1994 genocide had been acquitted on appeal.

headline: A Grizzly Answer for Obesity
text: PULLMAN, Wash. — CLINICALLY speaking, about 1.5 billion people worldwide are overweight. According to the World Health Organization, more than 10 percent of the world’s adults are obese, arguably making them the largest patient population in existence. We can debate the causes, but the long-term consequences of obesity — diabetes, heart disease, cancer — place huge burdens on our society. Public health campaigns have made little impression on this spreading medical crisis.

headline: Atlantic Media Executive Heads to Byron Trott’s Firm
text: Byron D. Trott, the former Goldman Sachs rain-maker known for having the ear of Warren E. Buffett, isn’t known for being a regular presence in the press. But his firm’s newest managing director just happens to be a longtime media executive.

headline: Barbie’s Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue Causes a Stir Online
text: TWO familiar brands that have for decades been the targets of complaints about their depictions of women have joined forces for a promotional campaign that tells critics they are proudly “unapologetic” about who they are.

headline: U.S. Military Denounces Afghanistan’s Planned Release of More Prisoners
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — American military officials in Afghanistan complained on Tuesday that Afghan authorities had ordered the release of more prisoners whom the Americans consider to be dangerous insurgents, and said their release would violate agreements between the Afghan and American governments.

headline: A Debate in New York Over the Name of a Sea Between Japan and the Koreas
text: If all politics were truly local, Brooklynites might be lobbying to rename the estuary that separates them from Manhattan. After all, it is only the East River if you happen to be a Manhattanite.

headline: In Skating, It’s All About Mind Games
text: SOCHI, Russia — Figure skating is the only Winter Olympic sport in which a competitor is so alone for so many minutes, so isolated in a contained space, accompanied only by thoughts that can be as quivery as tired legs.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Fairytale Lips at Rodarte
text: The innocence of childhood, glimpsed through the hazy filter of nostalgia, imparted a wistful, weirdly beautiful element to the makeup at Rodarte this afternoon. Backstage, the makeup artist James Kaliardos described the inspiration as the time when “you sort of romanticize things like movies and fairytales that stick with you, and affect the way you see beauty.” The Rodarte princess, however, is all grown up and has a dark side to her as well. Providing that much-needed edge: a pair of iridescent lip colors done in rich shades of mauve and lavender. “Kate and Laura are so into makeup, and the subtle differences in color,” Kaliardos said about the Mulleavy sisters, noting that they spent hours deciding on the final palette. The models’ skin tones largely dictated which of the two shades they would wear, but the application technique was the same: Kaliardos lined the mouth with either Nars Velvet Lip Liner Pencil in El Agua (a deep rose, to be released in the fall) or Nars Eyeliner in Mambo, a reddish brown, and then filled in the lips with a corresponding hue (Nars Lipstick in Dominique Audacious and Deborah Audacious, respectively; both available in the fall). Lastly, he topped everything off with a custom blend of glitter — rose and gold mixed into a base of lipstick and gloss — packed on the mouth with a small makeup brush for precision. (Note to those at home: Surgical tape helps to catch any sparkle fallout on your skin).

headline: Police Say Christie Copter Didn’t Fly Over Bridge
text: The New Jersey State Police released a statement on Tuesday saying that none of the three helicopter flights that carried Gov. Chris Christie during the controversial lane closings at the George Washington Bridge in September flew over or near the bridge or Fort Lee, N.J.

headline: What Is America All About?
text: CALL me obtuse, but I was surprised when President Obama, running for re-election two summers ago, declared that Costco is “representative of what America is all about.” It is? More than the Marshall Plan or the Bill of Rights? Or Walmart?

headline: Olympic Hockey Is the Same, Except for This and That
text: The men’s hockey tournament in Sochi, Russia, which begins Wednesday, will feature more than 140 N.H.L. players. But Olympic hockey, governed by the International Ice Hockey Federation, is not quite the same as N.H.L. hockey. Here are some of the differences:

headline: Wage Premium From College Is Said to Be Up
text: The millennials — born after 1980 — are the best-educated generation in history. By early adulthood, a third have college degrees, and those degrees help them earn more than ever before. So scholars at the Pew Research Center were puzzled when they found that the median, inflation-adjusted income of 25- to 32-year-olds had changed very little since 1965.

headline: Food Co-ops in Gentrifying Areas Find They Aren’t to Every Taste

headline: Tiger Population Grows in India, as Does Fear After Attacks
text: NEW DELHI — No one has lived long enough to describe the tiger in detail, but some things about her are known. She traverses great stretches of land in a day and is comfortable wandering deep into human territory. After killing her first three or four people, she began to eat her victims — starting rump-first, one expert said, as she would a deer.

headline: A ‘Repentant Rebel’ Addresses New York Abolitionists
text: Henry Ward Beecher, the best known minister in the United States, took the platform in his beloved Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn sometime after 8 p. m. on Feb. 10, 1864. Under Beecher’s guidance the members of Plymouth Church stood as the most committed abolitionist flock in New York and even throughout the nation. On this night Beecher deferred to Brooklyn’s mayor, A. M. Wood, who introduced the evening’s speaker, E. W. Gantt, “late a General in the rebel army.” Gantt took the stage in the beautiful hall. Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims had occupied this building at the beginning of 1850 and while the exterior was not especially prepossessing, with its simple brick facade, the sanctuary looked very elegant. The hall, with a seating capacity of more than 2,500, boasted the largest pipe organ in the United States at the time. White pews trimmed in stained hardwood filled the floor and balcony, with the pews set in an oval, giving the space a theater-in-the-round sense rather than that of a cathedral or Puritan meeting house.

headline: New York Fashion Week Street Style: Day 6

headline: Israel’s Big Question

And when they do, all hell could break loose in Israel. It is important to understand why.

headline: Medicaid Expansion, Red-State Style
text: Some 20 states have refused to expand their Medicaid programs to cover uninsured low-income people, an important element of the health reform law. Now several states that had been opposed, mostly for ideological reasons, are seeking to cover newly eligible Medicaid beneficiaries through private insurance.

text: A look at several White House state dinners, a tradition dating to 1874 and President Ulysses S. Grant.

headline: 6 Million Americans Without a Voice
text: The right to vote is the foundation of any democracy, yet nearly six million Americans are denied that right, in many cases for life, because they have been convicted of a crime. Some states disenfranchise more than 7 percent of their adult citizens.

headline: Sky, Wire Fox Terrier and Veteran Show Dog, Wins at Westminster
text: A bloodhound named Nathan stole the crowd’s heart Tuesday night at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Each time a camera caught his droopy-faced countenance, or a judge came within a few feet of him, his fans at Madison Square Garden erupted. They were nuts about Nathan, who was unfazed by the commotion.

headline: Christie Ridicules Democrats for Emphasizing Income Inequality
text: CHICAGO — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey delivered an unexpectedly blistering broadside on Tuesday against the Democratic Party’s growing emphasis on income inequality, warning that the movement would “drive America toward mediocrity” and portraying its leaders, like Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, as local liberals unlikely to ignite a national cause.

headline: For Women, a More Complicated Choice on Mammograms
text: For women who dutifully keep their mammogram appointments year after year, the latest results from a long-term trial in Canada, which found no difference in death rates from breast cancer among women who had regular mammograms and those who did not, are bound to sow confusion, perhaps even anger.

headline: Panel Won’t Change Naproxen Labels
text: A panel convened by the Food and Drug Administration concluded that naproxen, the active ingredient in Aleve, did not pose a lower risk of cardiovascular problems than ibuprofen and similar pain drugs. The panel voted 16 to 9 on Tuesday not to change warning labels on naproxen, a broadly used anti-inflammatory pain medication, to say that it is less risky. Naproxen, which is widely used to treat arthritis pain, had been found in some studies included in a large analysis published last year in The Lancet to carry a lower risk for heart problems than others in its class. A large clinical trial comparing a number of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, including naproxen and ibuprofen, is nearing completion, and some participants said they expected that the results would allow for more definitive conclusions on naproxen.

headline: Rival Industries Sweet-Talk the Public
text: WASHINGTON — The corn refinery and sugar industries, bitter rivals in the manufacture of billions of dollars’ worth of sweeteners for sodas and other high-calorie foods, covertly funded dueling nonprofit groups in Washington in a multiyear effort to grab market share, while also stoking fears among consumers about possible health risks, court records made public in a federal lawsuit between the two parties show.

headline: Union Drive Doesn’t Bother Management, but G.O.P. Fumes
text: As workers at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., prepare to vote this week on whether to join the United Automobile Workers, they are facing unusual pressure from the state’s Republican legislators to reject the union.

headline: Cuba’s Reward for the Dutiful: Gated Housing
text: HAVANA — In the splendid neighborhoods of this dilapidated city, old mansions are being upgraded with imported tile. Businessmen go out for sushi and drive home in plush Audis. Now, hoping to keep up, the government is erecting something special for its own: a housing development called Project Granma, featuring hundreds of comfortable apartments in a gated complex set to have its own movie theater and schools.

headline: Practice Is the Only Place Knicks Can’t Beat Themselves
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Coach Mike Woodson called a timeout. His team was trailing by 3 points with 5.7 seconds left, so he broke out his whiteboard and drew up a play for a game-tying shot. On the ensuing inbounds play, his plan vaporized like a plume of talcum powder. A swarm of defenders quickly converged on Beno Udrih, who failed to squeeze off a jumper before the buzzer sounded.

headline: Britain: Thames Flooding Causes Cameron to Skip Middle East Visit
text: Prime Minister David Cameron on Tuesday canceled a trip to Israel and the Palestinian territories, which would have been his first to the region as prime minister, to deal with extraordinary flooding in England. In the Thames Valley, which currently faces the most severe flood warnings, about 1,000 homes have been evacuated, and 1,600 military personnel had been deployed. The prime minister spent the last two days touring a number of villages, even as questions arose over whether the floods were his “Katrina moment,” a reference to the American government’s response to the hurricane that hit New Orleans in 2005.

headline: Facing Jail Time, Until a Lawyer With Survival Skills Helped Her Find Her Way

Sitting in a detention cell in December 2010 at age 17, Jessica Williams of East Harlem realized she had been caught cold and was about to be cooked: a year in jail on a Class D felony, and then lifetime membership in the Rikers Island Alumni Association. “Reality didn’t hit me until I was in Rikers Island, and thought, ‘Oh my God, this is not my life,’ ” Ms. Williams said this week.

But at the request of her husband, Dylan Benson, she was maintained on life support in a hospital intensive care unit and removed from life support shortly after giving birth. The case drew wide notice in Canada because of blog posts by Mr. Benson, who announced the birth on Monday.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) TOM JONES (1963) In this “31 Days of Oscar” presentation, Albert Finney stars as an 18th-century English foundling turned Casanova in Tony Richardson’s Academy Award-winning adaptation of the classic novel by Henry Fielding. Susannah York (above, with Mr. Finney) is Sophie, the passionate daughter of the blue-blooded Squire Western (Hugh Griffith) and the woman Tom hopes to wed — though her father has other plans. Writing in The New York Times, Bosley Crowther called the film “surely one of the wildest, bawdiest and funniest comedies that a refreshingly agile filmmaker has ever brought to the screen.”

headline: First Tie for Alpine Gold, Though Not Precisely
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A tie is not uncommon in most sports. Without it there would be no overtime, no extra innings and no sudden death. But a tie for the gold medal in an Alpine Olympic event had never occurred before Wednesday’s women’s downhill at the Sochi Games.

headline: Nanjing Meeting Leads to Pledge of Cross-Strait Communications
text: The chief outcome of Tuesday’s meeting between officials of Taiwan and mainland China was an agreement to set up a mechanism for regular communications between the two sides, which have previously relied on quasi-official bodies. Those organizations, Taiwan’s Straits Exchange Foundation and the mainland’s Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, will continue to operate alongside whatever official lines of communication are established, the Chinese state news agency Xinhua reported.

headline: Can Wendy Davis Have It All?
text: One sunny Friday morning in late January, Wendy Davis took me on a two-hour tour of the life she led just a decade or so ago, back when she was a city councilwoman and the world knew nothing of her or the pink running shoes she wore during her epic filibuster, or her ambition to be elected this November as a Democratic governor in the deeply Republican state of Texas, or the way her parenting has become a point of debate in whether she’s a suitable candidate for that office. We were in Fort Worth, where Davis, who is a state senator, has lived for about 35 of her 50 years, most in utter obscurity. When she joined the City Council in 1999, she was only the third-most-prominent Wendy Davis in town (the other two were socialites), and to the extent that community leaders knew her at all, it was as the wife of Jeff Davis, an attorney and former city councilman, whose civic passions would spark her own. Once that fire was lit, everything would later change for her — for her marriage, for her city, for Texas and, who knows, perhaps even for a national Democratic Party in search of a post-Obama non-Hillary superstar.

headline: Freeing Vegetables From Side-Dish Purgatory

headline: Free Press Groups Warn of China’s Influence on Hong Kong and Taiwan Media
text: Updated, 8:16 a.m. ET | Press freedom in Hong Kong and Taiwan, which have long been known for their boisterous news media, is under increasing pressure from China, as news outlets curtail coverage that might anger government officials or trigger businesses to pull advertising, the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists said in a new report published on Wednesday.

text: CHARTER’S BID FOR TIME WARNER CABLE HEATS UP  |  Charter Communications on Tuesday played its latest move in its pursuit of Time Warner Cable, nominating 13 directors to its target’s board. Now, as Time Warner Cable’s annual meeting approaches, shareholders will have to decide whether they want to force in a new board that would be more receptive to a deal with Charter, David Gelles writes in DealBook. Charter proposed to acquire Time Warner Cable for $132.50 a share last month, but Time Warner Cable maintains that Charter’s bid undervalues the cable operator.

headline: Take My Bro, Please
text: For a gross-out movie, “Someone Marry Barry” has a respectable number of genuinely funny moments. Over all, it’s still kind of crass and lowbrow, showing a particular obsession with flatulence, but there’s a good-heartedness to it that somehow overrides your gut instinct to stop watching.

headline: Q. and A. | His Influence More Pervasive Than Ever, Boy George Stages a Comeback
text: After years of tabloid-documented drug addictions and run-ins with the law, Boy George at last has his feet on solid ground. The 52-year-old singer — born George O’Dowd and sober for the past five years — was one of the biggest pop stars of the ’80s, when he and his band, Culture Club, scored chart-topping hits with “Karma Chameleon” and “Do You Really Want To Hurt Me.” More importantly, George openly blurred the boundaries of sexuality in the era of AIDS, serving as a trailblazer for gay rights — and for the avant-garde personas of countless pop stars since.

headline: Activist Fund to Back C.E.O. Candidate at Cliffs

headline: New York Loves, but It Forgets
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Nerve-Rattling Days for Cinematographer of ‘Gravity’
text: “This movie was the most scary film I’ve ever done. We created our own hell.”

headline: U.S. Businessman Accused of Being Crime Boss Stands Trial in China
text: BEIJING — An American businessman who is accused of loan-sharking, arson, kidnapping rivals and paying thugs to toss acid in the face of a judge, among other crimes, went on trial this week in a case that has raised questions about the use of forced confessions by Chinese courts and that has prompted concern from United States officials.

headline: Daily Report: Spy Chief Says Snowden Took Advantage of Security Lapses
text: The director of national intelligence acknowledged Tuesday that nearly a year after the contractor Edward J. Snowden “scraped” highly classified documents from the National Security Agency’s networks, the technology was not yet fully in place to prevent another insider from stealing top-secret data on a similarly large scale, David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt report.

headline: Truck Thief’s Getaway Try Ends in a Bus Driver’s Death
text: A stolen truck sideswiped a taxi and hit a scooter before colliding with a New York City bus in the West Village early Wednesday morning, sending both vehicles careering onto the sidewalk where they smashed into a building on the corner of Seventh Avenue and 14th Street.

headline: A View From the Mountains: Ted Ligety’s World in Photos
text: American skier Ted Ligety chronicles his travels on the ski circuit and shares them with his fans and followers on Instagram.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Fingers Crossed Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: For Wearable Computers, a New User Interface Challenge
text: We often think of user interfaces in terms of the way something looks. Is it flat, bright, clean or cluttered? Is it easy to navigate? Where’s the search box?

headline: CreatureCast: Stealing Poison Capsules
text: Cnidarians, including corals and many jellyfish, feed and defend themselves with stinging capsules. Some sea slugs have evolved several lines of defense.

headline: Poisonous Prey Turned Into Hunter’s Defense
text: Delicate beauty can often belie dangerous weapons. Take the cnidarians (pronounced ni-DAR-ee-uns), a group of animals that includes jellyfish, corals, hydroids, and other predators both small and large. Many are colorful and beautiful, and all of them are loaded with stinging capsules that each contain a neurotoxin-filled harpoon.

headline: Redrawing a Line That Is Sometimes Crossed
text: The relationship between those who consume sports and those who play them is changing, and probably not for the best.

headline: Women’s Ski Jumping
text: Women ski jumpers made their Olympic debut on Tuesday night, taking historic flights down the normal hill at the Sochi Olympics.

headline: Live Stream | Michael Kors’s Fall 2014 Collection at New York Fashion Week
text: The latest women’s collection from Michael Kors at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Railway Minister’s Budget Proposes More Trains But Leaves Fares Alone
text: NEW DELHI — The railroad minister asked Parliament on Wednesday for an 8 percent increase in his budget for the next fiscal year so that cash-strapped Indian Railways could add 72 new trains while leaving passenger fares and freight charges unchanged.

headline: Olympic Demonstration Sports We’d Like to See
text: The illustrator Bob Eckstein has some suggestions for the International Olympic Committee on how it could improve the Games.

headline: Atlanta Frozen Again as Winter Woes Chill South
text: ATLANTA — Here, in a nod to the Civil War, people joke that Atlanta is the city that won’t get burned twice. Wednesday, as the second major ice storm in two weeks froze the city in place, it proved true.

headline: Preparing for Disaster by Betting Against It
text: At 2 a.m. on Oct. 29, 2012, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (M.T.A.) shut down the New York City subway system in preparation for Hurricane Sandy.  By 9 p.m. storm surges reached nearly 14 feet at Manhattan’s Battery, as the waves of the East and Hudson Rivers deluged the city’s rail stations and tunnels, flooding tracks, corroding antiquated electric controls and wreaking $5 billion in damage on the largest regional transportation provider in the Western Hemisphere.  As it emerged from Sandy’s wreckage, the M.T.A. found it impossible to buy any existing kind of insurance against future storms.

headline: Vehicle Dependability Declines Significantly in J.D. Power Study
text: For the first time since 1998, vehicle dependability has declined, according to the 2014 J.D. Power Vehicle Dependability Study released today. Most of the problems are with engines and transmissions, the report said.

headline: The First Daughters’ Club
text: Audrey Rhodes is a pretty typical 13-year old in every respect but one: The home she returns to at the end of the school day is 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. In Rebecca Behrens’s debut novel, “When Audrey Met Alice,” the perks that come with living in the White House (swimming pool, bowling alley, fresh-baked cookies on demand) fail to outweigh the loneliness and restrictions Audrey suffers in her role as “first daughter.” Her mother, the president, is distracted by matters of national importance. Her father, a medical researcher known as “the first gent,” is often away at his lab in Baltimore. Audrey’s ordinary teenage conundrums — how to make friends at a new school; how to act around a boy she likes — are amplified by the demands of presidential protocol and security: she can’t even choose her own clothes. It’s no wonder Audrey, who doesn’t mince words, says she sometimes feels “like punching a hole through one of my historic walls.”

headline: In Our Pages: February 13
text: 1914: Inventor Tests Parachute

headline: Manchester United Trophy Tour Heads to New York
text: In and around the red half of Manchester, England, the Premier League of the present may look bleak — but the past has a resonance heard from Old Trafford to New Delhi, and now to New York.

text: From aviator sunglasses to plaid backpacks, these are the standout accessories from Tommy Hilfiger, Phillip Lim, Carolina Herrera and more.

headline: Sochi 2014: Interactive Stories
text: Athletes at the 2014 Winter Games barrel down an icy chute at 80 miles per hour and fly more than 15 vertical feet above the edge of the halfpipe, among other physical feats. In these interactive graphics and videos, learn their tricks and techniques — and then see how they used them to take home the gold.

headline: Sochi Video Notebook: Ted Ligety
text: The American skier talked about growing up in Park City, Utah, and about how he first learned to ski.

headline: Earthquake Strikes Remote Area of China
text: HONG KONG — A mountainous part of the Xinjiang region in far western China was hit by an intense earthquake on Wednesday, but officials said the area was isolated and thinly populated and there were no initial reports of deaths.

headline: Supercell Revenue and Profit Soared in 2013
text: LONDON – Supercell, the Finnish gaming company behind the popular Clash of Clans and Hay Day franchises, has pretty good reason to be happy.

headline: Grupo Bimbo to Buy Canada Bread for $1.7 Billion
text: Updated, 7:22 p.m. | Grupo Bimbo, a large Mexican baking company, is crossing North America for its latest bread deal.

headline: Dutch Speedskater Halts Shani Davis’s Reign in 1,000
text: SOCHI, Russia — Wednesday was supposed to provide the latest milestone moment in a career full of them for the American Shani Davis. Instead, it featured another dominant performance by the mighty Dutch speedskating team.

headline: Off the Runway | Shine On
text: Metallic, once the sheen of choice for louche after hours, is stepping out into the daylight in casual new ways.

headline: Hospitals’ Dialysis Plan Is Under New Scrutiny
text: For 400,000 people across the country with failed kidneys, dialysis care is a matter of life and death. It is also a lucrative business, in part because Medicare pays for such treatment regardless of age.

headline: Foundation to Offer New Commission for Symphonies by Women
text: The women’s opera commissioning program that Opera America announced in December will have a symphonic counterpart, supported by the Virginia B. Toulmin Foundation program for commissioning women in the performing arts — the same foundation that is supporting the opera project. The new orchestral project, announced on Wednesday by the League of American Orchestras, is to be administered by the league, and is part of EarShot, a national network of orchestras that offer readings and workshops for composers in the early stages of their careers.

headline: Maybe I Do Like Carrots
text: Five weeks ago, 4-year-old Andrew Nostrame was a “picky eater.” Dinnertime was a succession of jump-ups for his parents, Christine Zanchi and Fran Nostrame, who were aggravated and defeated. Andrew’s twin brother, Nathaniel, had a much wider repertory and was more willing to try things, but even so, dinnertime was not a happy place. Christine and Fran weren’t battling so much as they were retreating. They needed to make a change and asked that Dr. David Ludwig and I step in to offer tools, including recipes and encouragement.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Diesel Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Dina Litovsky.

headline: TV Network Meets Social Network
text: Late-night television is having a Gen X moment, with Jimmy Fallon, 39, and Jimmy Kimmel, 46, going head-to-head, and Seth Meyers, 40, soon to take over “Late Night.” Each has a strong social media presence and a vision for viral content that appeals to his own, and younger, generations.

headline: The Limbo of Asian Markets
text: SURABAYA, Indonesia — The docks at big Indonesian ports like this one are quieter these days, as China’s demand for raw materials has begun to cool.

headline: Image of the Day: February 12
text: A passing out parade in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh.

headline: Retail Businesses That Try Crowdfunding Face Some Skepticism
text: After nine years in Brooklyn, the Chocolate Room — a popular purveyor of wine, cake, candy and coffee — experienced one of those cataclysmic events retailers fear: a crippling rise in rent. Informed in late 2012 that they would face an increase of more than 500 percent, the cafe’s owners, Naomi Josepher and Jon Payson, reluctantly decided to abandon their space and begin figuring out how to finance a $200,000 relocation.

headline: The Bulldozer
text: When Ariel Sharon was elected prime minister of Israel in a landslide 13 years ago, many close to David Landau, a left-leaning British-born Israeli journalist, thought seriously of leaving the country. The future under Sharon, it seemed to them, held only war and bloodshed. Yet when Prime Minister Sharon collapsed from a stroke less than five years later, “We wept,” Landau writes. “Not just for him; for ourselves.”

headline: The Backup Singers Can Be Divas, Too
text: In a career devoted largely to films about music, Morgan Neville has directed or produced documentaries about acclaimed performers as different as Ray Charles and Iggy Pop, and James Brown and Brian Wilson. But it took “20 Feet From Stardom,” his examination of a group of predominantly black, female backup singers known only to the kind of obsessive music fan who reads the fine print on the back of CD covers, for him to earn his first Oscar nomination.

headline: Was the Chocolate Room a Good Candidate for Crowdfunding?
text: After nine years in Brooklyn, the Chocolate Room, a popular cafe that sells wine, cake, candy and coffee, experienced one of those cataclysmic events retailers fear: a crippling rent increase. As Stacy Cowley reports in an article we have just published, the cafe’s owners, Naomi Josepher and Jon Payson, were informed in late 2012 that they would face an increase of more than 500 percent. Reluctantly, they decided to abandon their space and begin figuring out how to finance a $200,000 relocation to their new store in Brooklyn.

headline: Technology Gives Ski Jumping Hills a Boost
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — At its most basic, ski jumping looks simple: slap on a pair of skis, strap on a helmet and ski down a slope at roughly 60 miles an hour, leap into the sky and land one leg in front of another about a football field away.

headline: Classical Playlist: Danish String Quartet, Thomas Meglioranza, Gidon Kremer and More
text: CARL NIELSEN: ‘The Masterworks, Vol. 2 — Chamber and Instrumental Works’Danish String Quartet and others(Dacapo Records) The chamber music of the Danish composer Carl Nielsen, composed in the late 19th and early 20th century, has been enjoying a renaissance recently. The superb Danish String Quartet offers passionate, elegantly rendered interpretations of its compatriot’s lyrical, characterful quartets. The six-disc set also features the genial Piano Trio in G, as well as works for wind; piano and violin sonatas; and pieces for solo violin and solo piano. (Vivien Schweitzer)

headline: New York Fall 2014: Elements | Shape
text: A thematic visual diary of New York Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.

headline: Looks That Are Up to the Job
text: No designer today can ignore the working woman. She is the one who demands the practicality (leaving aside perilously high heels) that was once reserved for the male of the species. So the conundrum becomes how to create appropriate clothes that still keep their feminine essence. That was the subject of three very different collections during New York Fashion Week for fall 2014.

headline: Folk Art Building May Be Lost, but Facade Will Live: In Storage Someplace
text: Contrary to what you may have read lately, the Museum of Modern Art is intent on carefully preserving the former American Folk Art Museum next door.

headline: Work and Health Insurance: Is There An Alternative?
text: Three blog posts and a column should probably suffice to cover the debate over Obamacare and work incentives, but I don’t want to let the topic drop without first stepping back and talking about the actual health policy disagreement here. My column and posts last week criticized what struck me as a kind of insouciance from liberals about this issue, shading into a post-work utopianism that doesn’t wrestle with what, in practice, the decline of work is actually likely to mean for issues of class, mobility, and social equality. But it’s also important to recognize that for many liberal writers, the controlling assumption here is not anti-work or pro-work. It’s just pro-universal health care as a basic standard for a decent society, with the consequences taken as they come.

headline: Meghan Collison Transforms Backstage at Rodarte
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Meghan Collison before (left) and after (right) makeup by Dick Page and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Gabriel Axel Dies at 95; Directed ‘Babette’s Feast’
text: Gabriel Axel, a director whose 1987 labor of love, “Babette’s Feast,” received the first foreign-language Oscar awarded to a Danish motion picture — and heralded a growing popular interest in all things food — died on Sunday in Copenhagen. He was 95.

headline: At Long Last, Westminster Gives Rat Terriers a Chance to Show
text: Harriett Browne had the chicken morsels that Q and Dinger coveted. They were hungry Tuesday afternoon, up on their hind legs, seeking their rewards after competing in the first breed judging for rat terriers in the history of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Q belongs to Browne, who lives in Columbus, Ohio, and Dinger is owned by her friend Darice Ragan, a rat terrier breeder from Greenback, Tenn.

headline: A Short Affair, Now With Songs
text: Robert James Waller’s 1992 novel “The Bridges of Madison County” slipped onto best-seller lists despite being ignored at first by many major reviewers. The unapologetically romantic tale of a lonely Iowa farm wife’s short, tempestuous affair with a photographer who passes through town, though, captivated booksellers and readers. There was a film version in 1995, too, starring Clint Eastwood and Meryl Streep.

headline: On the Death Penalty, ‘Too Many Doubts’
text: While multiple states continue to haggle over whether they can hide the way they kill people, the governor of Washington has decided to enter what he calls the “growing national conversation about capital punishment” on the other side — issuing a moratorium on all executions in the state because he is not convinced “equal justice is being served.”

headline: German Officials Discuss Plans for a New Center for Art Restitution
text: BERLIN — German culture officials will begin discussing plans for a new, independent center as part of efforts to strengthen the country’s handling of the restitution of art looted by the Nazis. The decision comes in the wake of international criticism over the handling of a discovery of hundreds of possibly stolen works.

headline: Browsing for Bargain Spring-Break Airfares
text: If you’re a student or teacher — or are in any way connected to the school schedule — you’ve are likely to have spring break coming up in March or April. Many public school systems have next week off, too.

headline: Paddling 2,500 Miles Around Florida
text: With a series of unfulfilling office jobs behind him, Justin Riney, 32, decided to “step off the ledge” three years ago. He spent the next year back home in Vero Beach, Fla., creating a plan to combine his attachment to the ocean with his desire to protect it. “I grew up a surfer, but I also loved fishing, camping, boating — anything that connected me with the water,” he said.

headline: After Marquee Roles, an Epiphany
text: Alexandra Silber stole the show at the Inner Voices series in November 2012, seated at an upright piano singing “Beautiful Dreamer” as if it had just been written by Taylor Swift (rather than in the 1860’s by Stephen Foster). The song was the highlight of Victor Lodato and Polly Pen’s “Arlington,” a mini-musical about war, which began performances Wednesday in an expanded version at the Vineyard Theater.

headline: Standard Chartered Looking to Sell Swiss Private Bank
text: LONDON – Standard Chartered, the British bank that earns most of its profit in Asia, is prepping its Swiss private bank for a sale as it prunes its non-core operations, a spokeswoman confirmed Wednesday.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 12
text: Women’s downhill skiing, men’s speedskating and women’s halfpipe on the seventh day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: A New York City State of Mind
text: After 15 years in San Francisco, Meg Crosby was eager to return to the East Coast. “New York was on my mind for a long time,” said Ms. Crosby, a Maryland native.

headline: Mob Princess Wages War on Concept of Inevitable
text: In “Philosophy for Gangsters,” a fitfully amusing dark comedy, Callie Rizzoli, a college-educated Mafia princess being groomed to lead the family business, is particularly aggrieved by the way her parents and brothers have departed — in a firefight with the police, shrugging that they were always meant to die that way.

headline: A. A. Gill Honored for Top Hatchet Job
text: As conversations continue to swirl around whether negative reviews are a worthy use of the dwindling amount of space devoted to covering books, the Hatchet Job of the Year Award has been given to A. A. Gill for his dyspeptic view of the rock star Morrissey’s “Autobiography.”

headline: An Act of Surrender May Strengthen Boehner’s Control
text: WASHINGTON — On Tuesday morning, after extended discussions of political fund-raising at the Capitol Hill Club, Speaker John A. Boehner stood to change the subject. He then told his House Republican troops that he would put to a vote a measure to raise the government’s borrowing limit, without preconditions.

headline: Disney Plans to Encourage Digital Start-Ups
text: LOS ANGELES — The Magic Kingdom is letting 10 technology start-ups inside its walls as part of an effort to find new digital growth.

headline: Judge Sets Nov. 3 as Start of Trial for Boston Bombing Suspect
text: BOSTON — A federal judge here on Wednesday set Nov. 3 as the start of the trial for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused of the deadly bombing of the Boston Marathon last year.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Marc by Marc Jacobs Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: How Not to React When a Child’s News Surprises You
text: Maybe this is a good time to take a moment and consider what you would say if your child made an announcement that really surprised you — especially if it both surprised and disappointed you. It could be, “Mom, I’m not going to college, because I’m traveling the country with my punk rock band.” Or it could be, “Dad, I’m leaving the Joffrey Ballet.” It doesn’t matter — but what you say does. That first reaction stays with your child no matter how you eventually turn it around, whether it’s disappointment in his choice of spouse or disbelief over her career decision.

headline: Doing the Math on Grupo Bimbo’s Deal for Canada Bread
text: In its latest deal north of the border, Grupo Bimbo, the acquisitive Mexican bread maker, is spending $1.8 billion to buy Canada Bread. Paying 20 times earnings to move into a mature market may seem questionable. But Bimbo’s earnings fetch an even higher multiple at home — and the deal should lower its weighted average cost of capital.

headline: Backpack Key to Snowboarder’s Survival
text: The professional snowboarder Jeremy Jones trusts his life to the contents of his backpack. Whether in Alaska or Antarctica, the equipment he carries on his back is essential.

headline: Below the Line: Makeup for ‘Dallas Buyers Club’
text: For “Dallas Buyers Club,” much has been said about the physical transformations  Matthew McConaughey and Jared Leto went through to portray characters struggling with the complications of AIDS. But their conversions were helped  by makeup artists who sometimes used experimental techniques to create their sickly looks. Robin Mathews, who, along with Adruitha Lee, is nominated for a makeup Oscar, said that because of the film’s low budget and 23-day shooting schedule, much of her design came together on the set.

headline: The Gaming Console Winner
text: Molly Wood tests the Sony PlayStation 4 and the Xbox One and declares one gaming console the winner.

headline: Two Game Consoles Battle for a Dubious Prize
text: A philosophical war is being waged in the world of video game consoles.

headline: Russian Environmentalist, and Critic of Olympics, Gets 3-Year Prison Sentence
text: SOCHI, Russia — An environmentalist and leading critic of Russia’s preparations to host the Winter Olympics was sentenced Wednesday to serve three years in a penal colony, in a ruling that rights groups condemned as legally flawed and obvious retribution for his political activities.

headline: Chief Executive Turnover High in January, Report Says
text: New year, new chief executive.

headline: Nagin Guilty of 20 Counts of Bribery and Fraud
text: NEW ORLEANS — C. Ray Nagin, a former corporate executive who became mayor in 2002 pledging to modernize city government and instead became an emblem of government dysfunction in the months and years after Hurricane Katrina, was found guilty in federal court on Wednesday on 20 counts of bribery and fraud.

headline: High-Traffic Walkways in Bronx Become Slippery Obstacles as Snow Lingers
text: Old men wielded their canes like ski poles across the slippery ice. Couples clung tightly to each other for balance. And subway riders climbing out of the 174th-175th Street station in the Bronx wobbled unsteadily as they tried to find a foothold.

headline: Mets Sign Reliever Jose Valverde
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — In 2012, pitching for the Detroit Tigers, Jose Valverde was considered a competent closer, perhaps on the verge of being elite. He had compiled 110 saves in his first three seasons in Detroit, but in the 2012 playoffs, as the Tigers marched to the World Series, they did so in spite of him. He imploded. He blew one save, allowed nine runs in four appearances, and was mercifully benched.

headline: Syrian Rebels Sketch Peace Plan That Omits Demand for Assad’s Ouster
text: GENEVA — The Syrian opposition coalition on Wednesday presented its most detailed vision yet of a political transition to end Syria’s conflict, in a 24-point plan that, strikingly, made no mention of President Bashar al-Assad or his ouster, while outlining strong requirements for human rights and justice in a future Syria.

headline: Michael Kors: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: Feeling For | Wearing Your Heart on Your Bag
text: From heart-studded store windows to Cupid-covered dinner menus, it’s hard to ignore the fact that Valentine’s Day is just around the corner. But come this time next week, empty chocolate boxes will get tossed into recycling bins, love notes will be tucked away for safe keeping and red-and-pink decorations will give way to the next Hallmark holiday, perhaps Easter. For a sweet statement with more staying power, consider this Stella McCartney bucket bag. The drawstring shape gets a playful boost from a painterly coeur print accented with Stella’s signature chain-link trim. This bonbon of a bag is one long-term commitment we wouldn’t be afraid to make.

headline: Upstart Ends Gold Medal Run by the Big 3 in Women’s Halfpipe
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The cattle auctions were on Wednesdays, Kaitlyn Farrington remembered. On the ranch near Bellevue, Idaho, before she left for school, she and her father would load a cow, maybe two, into the back of a trailer attached to the pickup truck. Gary Farrington drove about 40 miles south to Shoshone and made the sale, maybe $1,000 a head.

headline: The Gun Report: February 12, 2014
text: One thing we have discovered since we began chronicling gun violence is that a surprising number of Americans use guns to end arguments or register their frustration. This probably would not happen if guns weren’t so readily available. Sometimes when these stories make their way into the press, you have to wonder whether you’re reading The Onion.

headline: Teaching the Sochi Olympics | Science, Health and Math
text: The 2014 Winter Olympics offer a chance for students to dig into some of the more technical subjects.

headline: Storm Causes Traffic Chaos in North Carolina
text: Updated, 10:35 p.m. Thousands of motorists in North Carolina found themselves stuck on snow-covered highways Wednesday in a situation that looked similar to what took place in Georgia only two weeks ago, when motorists were stranded for hours.

headline: Apple and Samsung Took All Handset Profits in Fourth Quarter
text: Last year, Asian handset makers like Huawei and Lenovo gained major traction in the mobile phone business. Yet Samsung Electronics and Apple, the top two handset makers in the world, made all of the industry’s profits last quarter.

headline: Alan Alda Challenges Scientists to Explain Color to Kids
text: Alan Alda, the actor and evangelizer for effective science communication, is at it again, asking scientists for accurate, but engaging answers to a new question: What is color?

headline: Young Adults Need Flu Shots Too
text: Young adults who have not had a flu shot are at disproportionate risk of serious illness and hospitalization this flu season, a small new study suggests.

headline: A Night of Comedy (and Political Jabs) for a Cause
text: Feminism and comedy may seem like uneasy bedfellows: Does an activist, progressive cause thrive in an industry that prides itself on political incorrectness? But at “One Billion Laughing,” the comedy fund-raiser held on Tuesday night at the Creek and the Cave in Long Island City, Queens, it felt like a natural fit.

headline: Survey Suggests Voters Prefer Cuomo’s Proposal for Pre-K
text: ALBANY — A new poll released on Wednesday seemed to give a lift to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo as he quarrels with Mayor Bill de Blasio over the best way to pay for prekindergarten classes.

headline: Krawcheck Says Women on Wall Street Have ‘Gone Backwards’
text: It has long been a feature of Wall Street that women are underrepresented in the executive ranks. But since the financial crisis, the situation has gotten worse, according to one former big bank executive.

headline: “The High” by Kelela
text: A single produced by Gifted & Blessed.

headline: “Go All Night” by Kelela
text: A single from her 2013 album, “Cut 4 Me.”

headline: In Marrakesh, Art by Churchill
text: La Mamounia, the upscale hotel in Marrakesh, Morocco, is hosting an art exhibition in its Grand Salon from Feb. 20 to March 3 in which eight paintings by  Sir Winston Churchill and 17 by the 90-year-old Moroccan artist Hassan el Glaoui will be on display.

headline: Derek Jeter Says He’ll Retire at End of 2014 Season
text: For the past several weeks, Derek Jeter has been doing what he has long done as the Yankees’ redoubtable shortstop for two decades: getting a head start on spring training by working out almost daily at the team’s complex in Tampa, Fla.

headline: ‘Death to America’ in Perspective
text: For many Americans, the familiar chants of “death to America” on the 35th anniversary of the Iranian Islamic revolution on Tuesday were no doubt infuriating. How can the United States ever complete a nuclear deal, much less consider normalizing relations in the future, with such a relentlessly hostile country?

headline: With U.S. in Sights, Norwegian Airline Wins Irish License
text: PARIS — Norwegian Air Shuttle said Wednesday that its long-distance subsidiary had formally received an operating license from Ireland, paving the way for the budget carrier to seek approval in the United States for a plan to offer cut-rate flights across the Atlantic that has been fiercely opposed by airlines and pilots there and in Europe.

headline: App Smart: Your Family Tree
text: The Times’s Kit Eaton on Ancestry, MyHeritage and other apps to trace your family tree.

headline: Trace Your Family Tree, From Roots to Green Shoots
text: I’m British, Welsh to be exact, which means if I consulted the right databases and cross-referenced family documents I could probably trace my ancestry back 400 or 500 years. Nowadays, I can even carry out genealogy research with my smartphone.

headline: Listen Up | Melody Maker
text: Mixing soulful R&B with thumping club beats, the singer Kelela is bringing her underground dance mash-ups to the mainstream.

headline: Report Details Atrocities in Central African Republic
text: On Jan. 8, a man named Soba Tibati was sitting on a straw mat under a tree outside of his family’s hut in a small town called Boyali in the Central African Republic.
