text: New York

headline: Former Top S.E.C. Enforcer Returns to Milbank
text: Updated, 7:03 p.m. | After spending the last few years investigating financial institutions, George Canellos will now be defending them.

headline: Video: Snowboarder Trusts His Life to His Backpack
text: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: Scene City: The Benign King of Hollywood
text: Dozens of famous friends honor Bryan Lourd, the powerhouse agent of CAA.

headline: G.O.P. Senate Leaders Avert Debt Ceiling Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — It was a moment of real drama in a chamber known for its somnambulism. Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, counted votes on his hand, at one point holding up three fingers as he searched for the remaining votes. Senator John Cornyn of Texas, his No. 2, paced the Senate floor.

headline: I.M.F. Study Details Perils of Iranian Economy
text: The International Monetary Fund issued a sobering appraisal of Iran’s economy on Wednesday, warning that years of government mismanagement aggravated by the impact of the West’s antinuclear sanctions had left the country vulnerable to anemic growth and rampant inflation that require urgent attention.

headline: Russia Prevails in Pairs Skating, Renewing a Tradition
text: SOCHI, Russia — Maxim Trankov screamed and slid on his knees in a moment of triumph and renewal.

headline: BlackBerry’s Market Share Falls Below ‘Others’
text: Continuing a well-established pattern, BlackBerry posted a sharp market share loss in the latest global estimates released Wednesday by IDC, the market research company. Even though smartphone shipments rose 39 percent in 2013 compared with the year before, exceeding one billion units for the first time, BlackBerry shipments fell 41 percent.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 6
text: Miu Miu screened fashion film; Rodarte partied at Acme.

headline: 49th ‘Now’ Compilation Is No. 1
text: “Now That’s What I Call Music!,” a series of pop compilation albums that have been coming out like clockwork in the United States since 1998 — and since 1983 in Britain — has topped the Billboard chart once again.

headline: Scientists Hope to Sequence Genome of Richard III
text: LONDON — About a year and a half after finding King Richard III’s corpse under a parking lot in Leicester, British scientists will proceed to grind up some of his bones to try to sequence his genome. They hope to discover his hair and eye color and see what kind of infectious bacteria he might have been hosting.

headline: 3.3 Million Enrolled on Health Marketplaces, Including More Young People, Government Says
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly 3.3 million people have signed up for health insurance through the marketplaces established by President Obama’s health care law, and about one-fourth of them are young adults, the administration said Wednesday.

headline: Sting’s Musical ‘The Last Ship’ Finds a Home and a Cast
text: Casting and a Broadway theater were announced on Wednesday for “The Last Ship,” the new show with music and lyrics by the Grammy Award-winning singer Sting and a book by the Tony Award-winning author John Logan (“Red”) and the Putlizer Prize winner Brian Yorkey (“Next to Normal”).

headline: Canada Rallies to Beat U.S. in Women’s Hockey
text: SOCHI, Russia — Since 2010, the United States women’s hockey team got younger and faster while Canada’s Hayley Wickenheiser, the game’s gold standard, merely grew older. That was the running narrative, anyway, as the Canadians, the three-time defending Olympic champions, lost four consecutive games to the speedy, streaking Americans in the lead-up to the Sochi Games.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Juliana Schurig at Vera Wang
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Juliana Schurig before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Jimmy Paul.

headline: An Antique Palazzo in Malta
text: A renovated four-bedroom mid-19th-century palazzo on a narrow, cobbled lane is on the market for $1.13 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Malta
text: A RENOVATED PALAZZO IN BIRKIRKARA

headline: The Short Life of a Hard Choice
text: The real “cave” on Capitol Hill this week wasn’t the agreement to raise the debt ceiling, which was merely the victory of common sense over partisan posturing. It was actually the rush by both parties to reverse a small and perfectly sensible cut in a few military pensions.

headline: Left and Right Object to I.R.S. Plan to Restrict Nonprofits’ Political Activity
text: WASHINGTON — With time running short, both progressive and conservative advocacy groups are raising serious objections to new rules proposed by the Obama administration to rein in political activity by nonprofit organizations that are not required to disclose sources of their funding.

headline: The Art of Tuning Skis
text: A ski technician plays a behind-the-scenes role that is part crew chief, part caddie and part counselor. Ales Sopotnik spends countless hours tuning the skis of the American Alpine racer Leanne Smith.

headline: Making Instruments, Not Just Music: A Competition for Inventors
text: Are you a musician who has always felt that the current crop of musical instruments can’t quite capture that special, otherworldly sound that you can feel permeating your soul? You may want to keep an eye on the Margaret Guthman Musical Instrument Competition at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, where 23 instrument inventors from 14 countries are competing for a $10,000 in prizes (the top prize is $5,000) and recognition for their design, performance and engineering ingenuity.

headline: Video: The Art of Tuning Skis
text: The Alpine skiers at the Sochi Games are reaching speeds in excess of 80 miles an hour — and at that velocity, the condition of their equipment can spell the difference between a spot on the podium and a helicopter flight to a hospital. Little wonder that ski technicians are so valued. Part crew chief, part caddie and part counselor, a ski technician is responsible for maintaining and tuning the dozens of pairs of skis a racer might use in a season.

headline: Highlights From the Owner’s Manual
text: Every theater in New York should hire Stefan to make the precurtain announcements. With his baby face, bedroom eyes and alluring if indeterminate European accent, he can order us to turn off our cellphones and unwrap our hard candies any time.

headline: With His First Budget, de Blasio Hews to Familiar Campaign Themes
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday proposed his first budget for New York City, a $73.7 billion spending plan that gave more palpable, if not practical, shape to the robust liberal platform that carried him into office last year.

headline: Sid Caesar, Comedian of Comedians From TV’s Early Days, Dies at 91
text: Sid Caesar, a comedic force of nature who became one of television’s first stars in the early 1950s and influenced generations of comedians and comedy writers, died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Southern Gentleman as Hollywood Agent
text: The actress Ellen Barkin strode onstage at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, champagne in hand, to toast her “best friend” Bryan Lourd, the powerful but low-key managing partner of the Creative Artists Agency.

headline: Giant Laser Complex Makes Fusion Advance, Finally
text: After years of disappointing results and missed deadlines, a $5 billion laser complex has now achieved a step that revives optimism that thermonuclear fusion, the process that powers the sun, can one day be harnessed for almost limitless energy.

headline: Conservative Group Enters Michigan Fray on Side of Tea Party
text: One of the country’s most influential conservative political organizations announced Wednesday that it was diving into a bitter Republican primary in Michigan, its first such intervention into the broader battle  between the party establishment and Tea Party conservatives.

headline: Style Points Prove Scarce in Sochi
text: Bless the crazy-pants Norwegian curlers, the guys wearing trousers no one can quite believe, to compete in a sport few understand. For Sochi, the media-savvy Norwegians packed a wardrobe of multiple wacky changes — Missoni-on-acid zigzags (shout-out to Al Roker and Matt Lauer!); Mondrian squares; granny-print knickers, all designed by a California sportswear company specializing in golf duds — that garnered 500,000 likes on an unofficial Facebook page even before the Winter Games began.

headline: In Performance: Jonathan Groff
text: Jonathan Groff, who performed in Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series on Feb. 15, sings “I Got Lost in His Arms,” a number from Irving Berlin’s 1946 musical “Annie Get Your Gun.”

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Q. and A. With Dick Page
text: Don’t ever accuse Dick Page of holding back. The British makeup artist fires off witty remarks and unvarnished opinions as effortlessly as he paints on the perfect lipstick. Here, we caught up with the affable pro backstage at Michael Kors for some straight talk (and friendly ribbing) on how to be pretty but not boring, the virtues of undereye bags and why the show must always go on — yes, even if it snows.

headline: Valentine’s Stays With a Little Spice
text: Rose petals on the bed? Been there. Champagne on ice? Done that. This year in honor of Valentine’s Day, hoteliers are edging into racier territory.

headline: How Nonprofits Have Played in Politics
text: The I.R.S. has proposed new restrictions to rein in the political activity of nonprofit “social welfare” groups, which has increased with changes to federal campaign finance laws over the past decade.

headline: Rand Paul Files Lawsuit Over N.S.A. Call Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, on Wednesday filed a lawsuit against President Obama and the leaders of several intelligence agencies. The suit challenges as unconstitutional the National Security Agency’s once-secret program that is collecting bulk records about Americans’ phone calls.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Algeria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Algeria, Syria, New York and Sochi, Russia. More images from the Winter Olympics here.

headline: White House Puts Out Critical Infrastructure Security Guide
text: Updated: Industry reaction has been added to this post. |

headline: Hugo Boss: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: How to Survive the Next Wave of Technology Extinction
text: Don’t mock the beleaguered Nook owner. That could have been you.

headline: While Earth May Tremble, This Pianist Is Unlikely To
text: The ability to focus and perform well in myriad, and sometimes subpar, circumstances is a requisite skill for any successful musician. The Taiwanese-American pianist Steven Lin recently proved his unshakable mettle when he continued to play through an earthquake that struck during his performance in a competition in Sendai, Japan.

headline: Cate Blanchett’s True ‘Jasmine’
text: In “Blue Jasmine,” Cate Blanchett plays a wealthy socialite who has to start over again. The character is both palatable and unpalatable, Ms. Blanchett says, but the result is a richer role.

headline: Amid the Debris of Homs, a Guerrilla Is Born
text: Among the dwindling holdouts in the rebel-held Old City neighborhood of Homs, an area of the devastated Syrian city that international relief officials are trying to evacuate, is the former star goalkeeper of the national soccer team, transformed over three years from a pacifist antigovernment protest leader into a homegrown guerrilla fighter.

headline: Challengers Take On the Big Three in Gaming’s Arena
text: Here is a question with a surprisingly complex answer: What is the best option for playing video games these days?

headline: Sochi Video Notebook: Women's Halfpipe
text: Kaitlyn Farrington, Torah Bright and Kelly Clark, who won medals in the women’s halfpipe finals, spoke to the media after the event.

headline: Young Talents Working With Those Comedians Stravinsky and Berlioz
text: James Levine was just 37 when, in 1980, he inaugurated what is now called the Metropolitan Opera’s Lindemann Young Artist Development Program. His desire to foster young talent has now taken him across the Lincoln Center plaza to the Juilliard School. On Tuesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, he conducted the opening performance of a program of comic scenes from works by Mozart, Berlioz and Donizetti along with “Mavra,” Stravinsky’s rarely heard one-act. This ambitious program, lasting three hours, was the fourth co-production between the Met’s young artist program and Juilliard Opera since the two institutions began a partnership in 2010.

headline: Drew Nieporent to Open Bâtard in Corton’s Former Space
text: The restaurateur Drew Nieporent has settled on the new venture he plans to install in the TriiBeCa space that once housed Montrachet: Bâtard, a name that references the Montrachet wines of Burgundy.

headline: Lebanese Bloggers Defend Olympian Criticized for Racy Photo Shoot
text: Last Updated, Thursday, 11:44 a.m. | Lebanon’s fractured sense of national identity was on full display this week, as bloggers rallied online to defend the honor of a female Olympian, the skier Jackie Chamoun, accused by the country’s sports minister of tarnishing the nation’s image by posing for seminude photographs on the slopes outside Beirut.

headline: The Incomprehensible Sometimes Has Its Charms
text: The performing arts space of Roulette in Brooklyn appears only sporadically on the dance calendar. This week, however, its DanceRoulette season presents a different anthology of new pieces each evening.

headline: I Remember van Druten
text: In 1953, a writer leveled harsh criticism at John van Druten’s romantic comedy “London Wall,” calling its story “almost shamelessly inadequate” and arguing that the play would never work for American audiences. His name: John van Druten.

headline: ‘Sweeney Todd’ (Progressive Rock Remix)
text: Updated, 6:36 p.m. | When the demon barber of Fleet Street is next seen in the nation’s capital, he may be wielding an ax — six-string variety — rather than a razor. The Landless Theater Company of Washington has announced that it will stage “Sweeney Todd — Prog Metal Version” at the Undercroft Theater, in Washington, in August. And the project has Stephen Sondheim’s blessing, or at least his permission.

headline: Second Act | Screen Siren
text: Agnès Troublé is best known as the creator of the Agnès B. fashion brand, but with her directorial film debut this spring, the 72-year-old designer reveals that her true passion has always been edgy, experimental cinema.

headline: Long Island Bar in Brooklyn
text: After sitting empty for nearly seven years, a Brooklyn bar and its beloved neon sign have been brought back to life. In October, Joel Tompkins and the mixologist Toby Cecchini (who ran Passerby in Chelsea during the 1990s and is an occasional contributor to The New York Times) reopened the Long Island Bar, a fixture of Atlantic Avenue for more than 50 years until it closed in 2007 when the owner moved to Spain.

headline: Bird Thou Never Wert
text: Half a century or so ago, when literate Americans still read poetry or thought they should, everyone knew about Marianne Moore, the white-haired, great-auntish New York writer who loved polysyllables, exotic animals and the Brooklyn Dodgers, and turned up around town in a signature Paul Revere hat.

headline: Levine to Tackle Six Operas for the Met
text: James Levine, who is continuing to recover from the spine injury that sidelined him for two years, plans to conduct six productions at the Metropolitan Opera next season, including a new production of Mozart’s “Le Nozze di Figaro” on opening night and Wagner’s majestic “Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg,” which is not exactly known for its brevity.

headline: He’s a Real Rebel: He’ll Tell You Himself
text: In Nashville, most houses are made of glass, and most people love living in them. Merely pointing that out can qualify you as a rebel.

headline: Sacrificing His Fries for a Starring Role
text: Samuel Barnett ordered a salad. It wasn’t exactly what he wanted at Cafe Luxembourg, especially with its noted French fries on the menu, but as he noted wryly, “I have to get into a corset.”

headline: Peeling Back Time at Marc by Marc Jacobs
text: SITTING FRONT ROW at a fashion show on Tuesday afternoon was the designer Marc Jacobs, clad in Adidas track pants and surrounded by famous and powerful friends: Sofia Coppola, Alexa Chung, the LVMH executive Delphine Arnault.

headline: London Director to Draft Arts Vision for Ground Zero
text: Executives developing a performing arts center at ground zero have hired a temporary artistic director from the Young Vic theater in London, one of a series of steps to be announced Thursday to advance a project that has long faced political and logistical hurdles.

headline: A Night for Art on the Floor and Onstage
text: New York City Ballet presented the second of its Arts Nights series last Friday, and in honor of the occasion the principal dancer Adrian Danchig-Waring spoke a few words. His talk had nothing to do with the repertory, even though that surely would have been helpful to the youngish crowd, drawn to the David H. Koch Theater for a peek at the current promenade installation by the artist JR.

headline: Conflict in Oil Industry, Awash in Crude
text: HOUSTON — T. Boone Pickens has personified the nation’s oil industry for more than a generation. So when he made an offhand comment at a conference here a few weeks ago expressing reservations about lifting the nation’s ban on exports of crude oil, he startled some of his old allies in the business.

headline: Taking the Plunge at the Awards
text: Out with the Wonderbra, in with the ... sag? (And we don’t mean the Screen Actors Guild.) Dresses with revealing necklines have been stealing the spotlight this awards season, signaling, perhaps, a new era in red-carpet décolletage.

headline: Blowing This Way and That
text: Few violin concertos are as tightly scripted as those making up Vivaldi’s “Four Seasons.” Four sonnets chronicling the agricultural calendar — possibly by Vivaldi himself — accompany the music. Their lines are written into the score like stage directions, instructing the player to evoke the sounds of buzzing gnats on a hot summer day, hunting calls in autumn or the motion of someone walking gingerly on ice. Additional labels identify particular kinds of birds — a finch, a cuckoo, a turtledove — and barking dogs.

headline: Unskewing Obamacare
text: If you’ve been tracking the news on signups under the Affordable Care Act – which is easy thanks to Charles Gaba’s invaluable site – you already knew that the program was making a pretty good recovery from the botched start. Now, however, it’s official: as of the end of January signups were only about a million behind their projected track as of last spring, which means that as of March 31 the total is likely to be 6-point-something million rather than the projected 7 million. In other words, basically OK.

headline: Tranquil Islands in Passionate Seas
text: In both Beethoven’s Sonata No. 30 (Op. 109) and Schubert’s “Wanderer” Fantasy, quiet moments of resignation and introspection emerge suddenly from tempestuous thickets. In his admirable recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, the pianist Garrick Ohlsson rendered these elements with striking contrast.

headline: Record-Breaking Play at Bridge Base Online
text: The Internet has hurt attendance at bridge clubs, but it has been highly beneficial for pairs who live far apart. They can practice regularly online.

headline: The Problem With Mammograms
text: The front-page news today that mammograms don’t decrease the death rates from breast cancer — but do increase the likelihood of unnecessary treatment — reminded me that it’s worth going back to Peggy Orenstein’s cover story from last April. Even before the results of the newly published study, involving 90,000 women, were released, Orenstein’s reporting led her to the same conclusion: There is such a thing as too much screening. And she made a powerful argument that the Komen Foundation’s pink-ribbon “awareness” campaign is a big part of the problem. She also wrote insightfully about how difficult it is not to have a mammogram even if the science tells us that isn’t helpful.

headline: Desperate Times Call for Her
text: Cate Blanchett has played Blanche DuBois, the Queen of England (twice), Katharine Hepburn and all manner of elegant yet troubled heroines. But to portray Jasmine French, the socialite on a swift and bumpy fall from rank, and grace, in “Blue Jasmine,” she looked to Richard II for inspiration.

headline: Costas’s ‘Pinkeye’ Keeps Him Away Another Day at the Olympics
text: The viral infection in Bob Costas’s eyes did not clear up enough for him return on Wednesday to host the Winter Olympic broadcasts from Sochi, Russia, keeping Matt Lauer in the anchor seat while he co-hosts the “Today” show.

headline: Wheelies: The Half-Baked Jeep Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Times Minute | Derek Jeter to Retire
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Derek Jeter to Retire
text: The Yankees shortstop announces that the 2014 season will be his last. Also on the Minute, the U.N. evacuates Homs and a sinkhole swallows eight sports cars at the National Corvette Museum.

headline: London Auction Houses See High Prices for Contemporary Art
text: LONDON — Last week Sotheby’s and Christie’s proved that Impressionist and modern art hasn’t lost its luster, with a still life by Juan Gris fetching $56.7 million and a dreamy cityscape by Pissarro bringing $32 million.

headline: The Deficit on the Milk Carton
text: Has anyone noticed what we’re not talking about? I mean, really not at all? The budget deficit. After all those years when deficit scolds completely dominated the conversation, when Fix the Committee for a Responsible Debt Coalition were, if you listened to the press, the source of all that was good and noble and BowlesSimpsonish, quite suddenly the whole thing has dropped off the agenda.

headline: Blackstone’s Burger and Beer Night for Charity
text: High-flying financiers from the Blackstone Group would normally frequent power lunch spaces like the Four Seasons restaurant in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Beyond the Runway
text: Although New York Fashion Week officially begins on a Thursday (and, unofficially, days earlier than that), Saturday is the day when the full force of the event begins to take its toll.

headline: Court Challenge on Bond Buying Poses Test for Central Bank, and for E.U.
text: FRANKFURT — Courts are normally supposed to resolve disputes. But a decision last week by the Federal Constitutional Court in Germany has raised more questions than it has answered about the legality of a financial weapon that many analysts say saved the euro in its darkest hour — without even firing a shot.

headline: The Bright Side of the New Bulbs
text: A look at what’s replacing the old incandescent and compact fluorescent bulbs.

headline: For Skater Jason Brown, a Disciplined Approach Yields Joy on Ice
text: SOCHI, Russia — Many of the fans in TD Garden were on their feet before Jason Brown finished his free program at the United States figure skating championships last month in Boston.

headline: Sinkhole Beneath National Corvette Museum Devours 8 Cars
text: A huge sinkhole opened up early Wednesday at the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., swallowing eight rare and notable versions of the Chevrolet sports car.

headline: Skin Deep: Runway Maximal
text: Follow these steps to recreate Rodarte's runway look at home.

headline: Off the Runway
text: Scenes from New York Fashion Week.

headline: Reed Krakoff: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: The Winter Olympics Gear Guide
text: The gear behind the sports of the Winter Games.

headline: After Changes, Banking Group Drops Suit Against Volcker Rule
text: The American Bankers Association announced on Wednesday that it was dropping its lawsuit to block parts of the Volcker Rule from going into effect after regulators modified what the group found most objectionable.

headline: Dental Group Advises Fluoride Toothpaste Before Age 2
text: Parents should use a tiny smear of fluoride toothpaste to brush baby teeth twice daily as soon as they erupt, instead of waiting until children are older, according to new guidelines by the American Dental Association.

headline: Should I Have a Mammogram, or Not?
text: To the Editor:

headline: New York Fashion Week: Michael Kors Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Olivia Locher.

headline: Pregnancy Discrimination
text: To the Editor:

headline: Warnings of Ethnic Cleansing in Central African Republic
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Tens of thousands of Muslims are being forced by Christian militias to flee the Central African Republic in what human rights groups and a top United Nations official characterized on Wednesday as de facto ethnic cleansing.

headline: The Only Witches’ Brew Here Is the Beer
text: On a frigid evening in early January, 20-something hipster women of a boyish sartorial bent filled the Tandem Bar in outer Bushwick, Brooklyn, tall Narragansett beer cans in tow, sporting lots of arm-sleeve tattoos, knit stocking caps and their fair share of Theda Bara-esque kohl-rimmed eyes and blood-red lips. Several of them wore black football jerseys whose backs read “WITCHES 13.” (The number required for a coven.)

headline: Mayday Calls at the Navy Yard
text: The howls of anguish could be heard all the way to Manhattan. On Saturday night, as the fashion flock headed out in their town cars to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the unlikely and inconvenient space that Alexander Wang, above, had chosen to show his fall 2014 collection, New York Fashion Week entered its gridlock phase. Streets were packed, drivers got lost, anxiety mounted about missing the start time and Uber bills skyrocketed. If misery loves company, then Twitter was the place to be that night.

headline: Endangered Post Offices, on Main Street, U.S.A.
text: To the Editor:

headline: North Korea a Priority as Kerry Begins Asia Tour
text: ELMENDORF AIR FORCE BASE, Alaska — Secretary of State John Kerry headed to Asia on Wednesday to seek China’s help to try to pressure North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program.

headline: A Friendly Gesture to Cuba
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Doodles in a Book
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Little of This or a Lot of That
text: Runway beauty looks, usually concocted with some alien She-Ra in mind, are hard to translate into “trends” relatable to the average Jane. But this Fashion Week, a clear divide appeared between minimalist and maximalist makeup. Herein, experts who applied it explain how to attempt the same thing at home (if you dare).

headline: Beauty for Valentine’s Day
text: Better than bonbons: some pampering Valentine’s Day gift ideas.

headline: Basking in a New Glow
text: If you haven’t noticed the virtual disappearance of old-school incandescent bulbs from retailers’ shelves, there’s good reason.

headline: A Big Step Closer to Nutritional Science
text: To the Editor:

headline: Even a Stationery Logo Pits Palestinians Against Israel
text: JERUSALEM — The latest skirmish between Israel and the Palestinian Authority does not concern settlements or refugees, but stationery.

headline: At Reed Krakoff, Vivid Blue Sandals With a Plush Touch
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Night Stands: Snooze but Don’t Lose
text: At nearly three feet wide, the Ico Parisi cabinets at Bernd Goeckler’s antiques store in the East Village were much too big to be night stands. That was this reporter’s opinion, anyway. Barry Goralnick, an architect who has designed lighting for Visual Comfort, carpets for Starck and furnishings for Ferrell & Mittman, disagreed.

headline: A Marriage of Convenience
text: In 1999, Antony and Richard Joseph, twin industrial designers, were asked to update a part of their family’s 63-year-old British housewares business. Four years later, they created their own company, Joseph Joseph, which produces smartly functional items for the home like colorful stacking mixing bowls with integrated measuring cups. Their Nest containers, shown at the New York Now design show last week, tackle the problem of storage boxes that hog precious space when not in use. Whereas lids and bases often need to be stored separately, turning matchups into a problem, this design efficiently packs together bases and lids for up to six sizes of containers; color-coding makes the pairings foolproof. The containers are airtight and microwave-, freezer- and dishwasher-safe. A 12-piece set (6 containers, 6 lids) is $35, and an 8-piece set (4 containers, 4 lids) is $25. Information: 917-338-0900, or josephjoseph.com.

headline: Nature Woven in Silk
text: Rocio Moreno, a Spanish interior and product designer, works with artisans in northern India who hand-weave silk brocades in brilliant colors. Her newest collection includes Orissa, a wall hanging that depicts a stylized tree and takes the former name of a state in India. Orissa ($1,795), seen in magenta on green, is 29.5 inches wide by 79 inches long and available by special order from Barneys. To complement the garden theme, Ms. Moreno pored through a collection of natural history books for images of insects, which inspired two cushions, Mantis and Moth. Mantis ($365) is 24 inches square, and Moth ($350) is 20 by 24 inches. Both will be available in turquoise or orange at Barneys in late March. All three designs can be ordered in advance. Information: 212-450-8454 or rociomorenotextiles.com.

headline: Child-Proof Minimalism
text: A couple chooses a one-room suburban life with two young children. And their toys.

headline: The Anti-McMansion
text: Living in a one-room house with an ultra-minimalist aesthetic and two small children sounds more like the setup for a joke than something any reasonably sane person would attempt.

headline: Marchesa: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: The New Domestics
text: Dylan Leonard Brown is all of 30, with a master’s in psychology and an expansive résumé that includes three years working as an estate manager for a former ambassador and overseeing a household staff of 12, along with three properties, one yacht, numerous automobiles and a multimillion dollar annual budget. Mr. Brown also planned around 100 events every year, including a three-day colloquium on human trafficking and an orchestral concert. (The ambassador was an amateur composer, so Mr. Brown hired an orchestra and choir, auditioned soloists and hired street canvassers to hand out fliers at the Gay Pride Parade in Boston to drum up interest.)

headline: Table Manners at Work
text: Clive Wilkinson, a 59-year-old architect, has designed attention-getting offices for TBWA\Chiat\Day and Google, and now he has done one for the Barbarian Group, an Internet advertising company in New York. Its centerpiece is the “endless table,” a 1,100-foot-long surface that snakes around the 23,000-square-foot office, providing work space for all 125 employees, including the chairman, Benjamin Palmer. The $300,000 table, which was installed last month, forms seven archways leading to conference rooms, a video screening room and restrooms. “In our last office, there were separate offices, and people had to hunt people down,” Mr. Palmer said, adding that now he is “seeing more people than I have in years.”

headline: 2 U.S.-Led Coalition Soldiers Are Killed by Attackers in Afghan Uniforms
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two people wearing Afghan security forces uniforms opened fire on American-led coalition soldiers in eastern Afghanistan on Wednesday, killing two of the soldiers, officials said.

headline: Hot 97’s Owner in Deal for 2 Other Stations
text: In a deal that will align some of New York’s most popular radio stations specializing in black music, the owner of WQHT-FM — the hip-hop station better known as Hot 97 — is buying WBLS-FM and one other station for $131 million in cash.

headline: Modernism’s Giant Showcase
text: The dealers who attend the Palm Springs Modernism Show and Sale must luxuriate in their home-field advantage: With its copious midcentury architecture, the city is one big ad for their wares. This year’s show, which is timed to Modernism Week and begins Friday, is the largest in its 14 years. More than 85 exhibitors will be selling furniture, jewelry, pottery, textiles and other items representative of 20th-century design, like a welded steel sculpture by Paul Kasper ($14,000, from Fat ChanceLos Angeles) and a signed lithograph by Alexander Calder ($3,150, from Palette Contemporary Art & Craft).

headline: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Ballard Designs and Others
text: A blanket and a pillow are on sale at Brookstone, while supplies last (the Nap throw blanket, regularly about $40, is about $15; the FOM fun pillow, regularly about $20, is about $15); 30 Rockefeller Plaza (Fifth Avenue), concourse level, 212-489-3234, brookstone.com.

headline: Furniture with a Magic Touch
text: “Man Machine,” which opens Thursday at Galerie Kreo in Paris, features nine limited-edition furniture pieces by Konstantin Grcic made of window plate glass. “Glass is seen as fragile, and sometimes it’s scary,” said Mr. Grcic. To make it dynamic as well, he has worked gas pistons into the designs: The reclining chair adjusts as a car seat would; the dining table glides up to standing height, and the crate can be opened with a pinkie.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,294 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Facing Questions on Future, Cisco Posts a Revenue Drop
text: Changes in the technology business are hurting Cisco Systems, and so far its chief executive, John Chambers, hasn’t shown Wall Street many numbers that say his recovery strategy is working.

headline: Prices Skyrocket for Tickets to See Jeter’s Last Games
text: When Derek Jeter announced on Facebook on Wednesday that the 2014 season would be his last, fans fled to social media to express their reactions. More enterprising enthusiasts, though, rushed immediately to their computers for a different purpose — to scoop up tickets to games in late September at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Taking the Bite Out of Winter With a Crisp White Shirt
text: If you are eager to take the leap into spring (and who isn’t at this point?), a crisp and tailored cotton shirt is the easiest way to get a jump on the season. When indulging in trends, it’s always a plus to go with the classics, and the shirts now in the shops are easygoing tweaks on traditional tailoring. Among them, some shown in this sampling, are shirts covered in fringe (Junya Watanabe), cut with capelike backs (Margiela, Balenciaga) and accented with romantic needlework and lace (Carven, Chloé, Christopher Kane). While we are still in throes of winter, wear with wool pinstripe trousers and an oversize mannish coat; or, as Diane Kruger did at Sundance last month (above right), with a knee-length skirt and printed parka. When the days warm up, try with a sexy slit skirt — very Altuzarra.

headline: Embracing the Struggle

headline: Don’t Sell Cheap U.S. Coal to Asia

headline: Italian Premier’s Latest Challenge Comes From His Own Party
text: ROME — Like a piñata that has been battered but remains unbroken, Enrico Letta has demonstrated an unexpected resilience as Italy’s prime minister. He took office in April amid predictions that his coalition government would quickly collapse. It did not. Then Silvio Berlusconi, the powerful former prime minister, vowed to bring him down. That did not happen, either.

headline: Making College Pay
text: It seems logical: College graduates have lower unemployment and earn more than less educated workers, so, the thinking goes, the fix for today’s anemic growth in jobs and wages is to make sure that more people earn college degrees. But that’s a common misperception, deflecting attention from the serious work that has to be done to create jobs and improve incomes.

headline: Laying the Lox on Thick, a Dating Site Focuses on Jewish Humor
text: AMONG married Jews, the intermarriage rate of those wed since 2000 is 58 percent, well above the rate of those wed before 1970, when just 17 percent tied the knot with non-Jews, according to a 2013 survey by the Pew Research Center’s Religion & Public Life Project. Now the Jewish dating website JDate is introducing an advertising campaign that hopes to help buck the trend, with ads that may strike a chord with Jews but leave others scratching their heads.

headline: Trade Dispute Centers on Ukrainian Executive With Ties to Clintons

headline: Jared Leto at Jeremy Scott
text: For those who enjoy a good fashion spectacle, the showman Jeremy Scott lived up to expectations. On the runway, male and female models wore football-inspired pieces as if from a Super Bowl gone mad, while the front row was a lurid scene, including the ubiquitous Joe Jonas, in his usual black jacket; Kat Graham, in a red snakeskin harness crop top and matching bondage-style skirt (“I’ve been wearing Jeremy’s crop tops since I was 16,” she said); and a nearly late Jared Leto, who shouted to the crowd: “My apologies! You all look fabulous.” It turns out Mr. Leto, who had dressed for the gelid weather in a roomy parka and a flannel around his waist, was only in the city briefly.

headline: U.N. Report Says Progress for Women Is Unequal
text: UNITED NATIONS — Twenty years after a landmark United Nations summit meeting in Cairo called on countries around the world to allow women greater control over their health and destiny, women worldwide have fewer children, are less likely to die of childbirth and have made great strides in literacy, according to a major report released Wednesday by the world body.

headline: For de Blasio, No Magic Lost in Budget Draft

headline: Weapon in Slaying of Florida Teenager Figures Again in Court

headline: Why ‘Team G.B.’ Needs Scotland
text: Much of the debate over Scottish independence has focused on whether the Scots would be better off in or out of the United Kingdom. With the Sept. 18 Scottish referendum now only seven months off, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain has raised another critical question: Would Britain be better off without Scotland?

headline: Mr. de Blasio’s Welcoming Gesture
text: Creating a citywide identification card for people who can’t get driver’s licenses — unauthorized immigrants, mostly — sounds like a modest, well-meaning, good-government initiative that is part practical, part symbolic. Cities like New Haven and San Francisco have already done it. Bringing such an innovation to New York City, as Mayor Bill de Blasio proposed on Monday, would be a big deal.

headline: We Need Proof on Marijuana
text: MANY people have heard the story of Charlotte Figi, a young girl from Colorado with severe epilepsy. After her parents began giving her a marijuana strain rich in cannabidiol (CBD), the major nonpsychoactive ingredient in marijuana, Charlotte reportedly went from having hundreds of seizures per week to only two or three per month. Previously, her illness, Dravet Syndrome, was a daily torture despite multiple high doses of powerful anti-seizure drugs.

headline: Escaped Inmates From Iraq Fuel Syrian Insurgency
text: BAGHDAD — A series of daring but little noticed breakouts from Iraqi prisons has freed hundreds of hardened militants who are now among the leaders and foot soldiers of the radical Sunni groups operating in neighboring Syria and, increasingly, in Iraq itself.

headline: Ending ‘Gay Conversion’ for Good
text: NEW HAVEN — THERAPY programs that purport to “convert” lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender kids have caused immeasurable harm since they became prominent in the 1970s. Rigorous studies have shown again and again that efforts to change young people’s sexual orientation not only fail, but are also linked to suicidal behavior, depression, anxiety, drug use and risky sexual behavior.

headline: Derek Jeter Lived a Dream, and Never Disappointed
text: The greatest compliment we can give Derek Jeter, as he prepares to leave the grandest stage in baseball, is that he never let us down. He has made thousands of outs and hundreds of errors and finished most of his seasons without a championship. Yet he never disappointed us.

headline: Lawlessness Is Undoing Effort to Save Honduran Forests
text: COPÉN, Honduras — Nine men were harvesting mahogany deep in the woods here when Alonso Pineda and his son appeared, carrying shotguns. An arrest warrant hangs over the two for clearing the forest illegally, but on that day they posed as its protectors.

headline: High-Level Talks Between Koreas End Without an Agreement
text: An unusual high-level dialogue between North and South Korea ended without an agreement on Wednesday, casting doubt on prospects for reunions of families separated in the Korean War that the two Koreas have planned to hold later this month. The meeting of senior officials, the highest-level government talks between the countries in seven years, was held at Panmunjom on their mutual border at the suggestion of the North, which has recently called for improved relations. The meeting stalled because of sharp differences over the terms of improving relations. North Korean delegates left Panmunjom without even exchanging handshakes with their southern counterparts, officials in Seoul said.

headline: Venezuela: At Least Two People Are Killed in Protests
text: At least two people were killed in unrest in Caracas on Wednesday, officials said, as thousands of people took to the streets of the capital in the largest antigovernment protest in months. The violence erupted after government opponents attended a peaceful march and rally called to protest the arrest of student demonstrators elsewhere in the country. Following the march, several hundred young protesters threw rocks at riot police officers and broke windows in a government building. One demonstrator was shot in the head and killed, and protesters blamed armed pro-government supporters. Later, President Nicolás Maduro said a community activist he had known for years had also been killed. Diosdado Cabello, the president of the National Assembly, said the man was killed by “fascists,” a term the government uses for its opponents. Mr. Maduro later said on television, “I alert the world: we are facing a planned coup d’état.” The protests in various cities in recent weeks have sprung from widespread discontent amid increasing economic problems, including high inflation.

headline: Review Finds Police Failure to Report Driver Friskings

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 2 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE DIVING BELL AND THE BUTTERFLY (2007) Jean-Dominique Bauby, a 43-year-old French magazine editor and something of a playboy, had a stroke in 1995 that left him with a condition in which he retained vision, hearing and a functioning mind but was almost completely paralyzed. He told his story in a book that he dictated to an assistant by blinking. In this film from the artist Julian Schnabel, Bauby is played by Mathieu Amalric; Emmanuelle Seigner is Céline, the longtime partner he has recently left and the mother of his three children; and Marie-Josée Croze is the speech therapist who teaches him to use his left eyelid to communicate. “The phrase ‘triumph of the human spirit’ hovers over ‘The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,’ along with a swarm of other empty, uplifting clichés,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But Mr. Schnabel and the screenwriter, Ronald Harwood, have other themes in mind” — among them, limitation, constraint and incarceration — Mr. Scott said. (Both men were nominated for Oscars.) “Their common subject, however, is freedom, the self-willed liberation of a difficult, defiant individual,” Mr. Scott wrote, adding that Mr. Schnabel demonstrated this with “imaginative freedom in every frame and sequence, dispensing with narrative and expository conventions in favor of a wild, intuitive honesty.”

headline: In Prison Release, Signs of Karzai’s Rift With U.S.

headline: How to Build a Perfect Refugee Camp
text: From the outside, the temporary shelter for Syrian civilians in Kilis, Turkey, doesn’t look like an inviting place to live. It looks like a prison. All around are olive groves, but here, Turkey suddenly runs out. A metal archway announces the customs gate to Syria. To its right stands what is more formally known as the Republic of Turkey Prime Ministry Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency’s Kilis Oncupinar Accommodation Facility. High gates bar entry, and barbed wire tops the walls. Police officers and private security mill about.

headline: In Restive Remote China, Uighurs’ Piety and Peace
text: It’s rare to see mainstream news media reports on Xinjiang, China’s western borderland region, that do not invoke “turbulent,” “restive,” “unstable” or some variation. The area has long been the site of ethnic tensions between the majority Han Chinese and the Uighurs, China’s Turkic-speaking Muslim minority. But tight government controls on information and access make reporting on such clashes and protests, as well as everyday life, exceedingly difficult.

text: BEIJING — Chinese officials announced Thursday that they were offering a total of 10 billion renminbi, or $1.65 billion, this year to cities and regions that make “significant progress” in air pollution control, according to a report by Xinhua, the state-run news agency.

headline: Norwegian Air Swings to a Loss
text: PARIS — Norwegian Air Shuttle, the Scandinavian budget carrier, on Thursday reported a loss in the fourth quarter and sharply lower profits for 2013. The declines were the result of heavy investments in new long-haul aircraft and other expenses linked to its rapid and controversial expansion into Southeast Asia and the United States.

headline: Comcast Scoops Up Time Warner Cable
text: COMCAST SWOOPS IN TO ACQUIRE TIME WARNER CABLE  |  Time Warner Cable has been dodging a takeover for months, but it finally accepted another suitor with a sweeter offer. Comcast on Thursday announced an agreement to acquire Time Warner Cable in an all-stock deal valued at about $45.2 billion. The merger will unite the biggest and second-biggest cable television operators in the country, David Gelles writes in DealBook. Under the terms of the deal, Time Warner Cable shareholders will receive $158.82 a share based on Comcast’s closing price on Wednesday.

headline: How Absolute Power Can Delight Absolutely
text: “House of Cards” may well be the most joyless show on television.

headline: In Performance: Jonathan Groff
text: On Saturday the actor Jonathan Groff, one of the stars of the new HBO series “Looking,” will perform two shows as part of the American Songbook series at Lincoln Center. With a nod to Valentine’s Day, Mr. Groff recently taped this In Performance video featuring an excerpt from the number “I Got Lost in His Arms,” from the 1946 musical “Annie Get Your Gun,” with music and lyrics by Irving Berlin.

headline: In Our Pages: February 14
text: 1939: Belgian Abandons Efforts

headline: Olympic Officials Scramble to Counter Warm Weather
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — With the Winter Olympics melting under a heat wave, the effects could be seen Thursday from the coast of Sochi, where spectators were spotted sunbathing, to the mountains high above the city, where cross-country skiers raced in sleeveless jerseys. The balmy weather has forced changes in competition schedules, sent workers scrambling to harden the slushy snow and made Olympians reconsider what to wear for their warm-weather winter sports.

headline: Because Curlers Can Pull Muscles, Too
text: SOCHI, Russia — Among the things that a curling team would not seem to need, an official athletic trainer might rank with a beach umbrella and a maid to sweep up after the athletes. But here is Brian McWilliams, a certified athletic trainer, on hand to treat any injury that might befall an American curler.

headline: Happy Wife, Happy Life
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Worker Struck by Sled at Sliding Track
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A track maintenance employee working on the Olympic bobsled track was struck by a sled Thursday just before a training heat began. The man was treated by medics on the track and taken by helicopter to a hospital. A spokesman for the International Olympic Committee said the man was conscious and had two broken legs.

headline: Phantom Melodies Yield Real Clues to Brain’s Workings
text: In 2011, a 66-year-old retired math teacher walked into a London neurological clinic hoping to get some answers. A few years earlier, she explained to the doctors, she had heard someone playing a piano outside her house. But then she realized there was no piano.

headline: Video: Blanchett and Her Shakespearean King, Jasmine
text: The title character Cate Blanchett plays in “Blue Jasmine” has reminded some commentators of Blanche DuBois and others of Ruth Madoff. But the role of Jasmine French, the self-deceiving society type reeling from her husband’s fraud, reminds the actress of none other than Shakespeare’s Richard II.

headline: The Comcast-Time Warner Deal, by the Numbers
text: The all-stock, $45.2 billion deal by Comcast to buy Time Warner Cable is set to create a major player in the cable business. Here is a look at some of the important numbers.

headline: Sid Caesar, Television Comedian, Dies
text: Mr. Caesar headlined “Your Show of Shows,” which pioneered the way for later comic television.

headline: Greek Yogurt Meant for Olympians Will Be Donated, Chobani Says
text: In the cold war over yogurt, America blinked.

headline: Comcast’s Deal for Time Warner Cable Is Big Win for Advisers
text: Comcast’s $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable isn’t just a victory for the cable giant. It’s also an unexpected win for the company’s advisers.

headline: Big Cable Mergers in Europe Are Still Hard to Make
text: LONDON — For many European analysts, the Continent’s telecommunications industry is ripe for consolidation.

headline: Students Who Lose Recess Are the Ones Who Need It Most
text: Despite overwhelming evidence that periods of unstructured play and social interaction are a crucial part of children’s cognitive, academic, physical and mental wellness, schools continue to take away recess privileges as a penalty for academic or behavioral transgressions. I’ve done it, many times. When students fail to hand in assignments or when a child acts up in class, I’ve taken their recess privileges hostage. I did it both as a way of punishing for bad behavior or as a way to carve out a few extra minutes of learning time in an otherwise packed day.

headline: U.N. Security Council Urged to Act on Humanitarian Aid to Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — The hard-won humanitarian cease-fire in the Syrian city of Homs — the sole success that occurred during the peace talks in Geneva — cannot be considered “progress,” the United Nations’ top official for emergency operations said Thursday evening as she urged the Security Council to ensure that aid reach those who need it and aid workers can do their work without getting shot.

headline: Winter Offensive Takes Toll on East Coast
text: A powerful storm system swept up the East Coast on Thursday, leaving in its wake downed power lines, stranded travelers, abandoned vehicles and yet another mess of snow, slush and ice.

headline: In Haiti, Beauty That Plays Hard to Get (To)
text: It’s hard to know exactly how many waterfalls there are on the side of the mountain in a remote corner of southeast Haiti. From my vantage point on a nearby slope, I counted at least a dozen, and that was at the end of the dry season last year. The rainy season in the spring, I’d been told, puts the cascade in Cascade Pichon.

headline: Austin’s Moon Towers, Beyond ‘Dazed and Confused’
text: There are two kinds of people who think it would be cool to move to Austin.

headline: Alcoholism Through a Doctor’s Eyes
text: When I teach medical students about alcoholism, it is never easy. Students arrive with preconceived notions and stereotypes obtained from books, television and films — and their personal upbringings — about the subject.

headline: Take a Punch, Hope for a Hit
text: Massive sides of fake beef were being suspended from hooks onstage as workers zigzagged purposefully through the controlled chaos that was the Winter Garden Theater the other day. Somewhere in the middle of it all, taking a minute before a group stretch-and-limber session, was the man whose character’s name was already on the marquee outside and whose left eye was still black and blue from a poorly timed encounter with another actor’s glove a week or two earlier.

headline: Thai Court Orders Protest Leader Released From Detention
text: A Thai court on Thursday ordered the release from detention of a prominent leader of the protest movement seeking to overthrow the government, a case that highlights the movement’s influential backing amid Thailand’s debilitating power struggle.

headline: Excerpt: 'Dinner With Friends'
text: A scene from the Roundabout Theater's revival of the Donald Margulies play.

headline: Laura Lippman: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “After I’m Gone” likes books steeped in the quotidian. “You can learn how to run a chicken-and-waffle restaurant by reading ‘Mildred Pierce.’ ”

headline: General Motors Recalls 778,000 Small Cars for Ignition Switch Problem
text: UPDATED: Feb. 14, 2014, 10:47 a.m.

headline: Obama Raises Minimum Wage for Contract Workers
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama signed an executive order on Wednesday to raise the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour from $7.25 an hour for federal contract workers starting in 2015, a promise he made in his State of the Union address last month.

headline: Shafqat Islam, Chief of NewsCred, on Irrational Optimism
text: This interview with Shafqat Islam, chief executive of NewsCred, a content marketing platform, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Women’s Halfpipe
text: The women’s snowboarding halfpipe produced a lot of big jumps and a surprise winner in Kaitlyn Farrington of the United States.

headline: Among the Believers
text: I expected to be pained by Adam Gopnik’s New Yorker essay on atheism and belief, but I didn’t expect to be quite so … puzzled by his depiction of contemporary belief. Gopnik clearly has sympathy for the religious side of the argument he’s describing — or at the very least he’s straining to be sympathetic. But given the premises he’s working from, that sympathy manifests itself in a peculiar and telling misreading of what theists actually believe.

headline: Comcast-Time Warner Deal: How It’s Playing on Twitter
text: It is a huge merger between two household names. So, naturally, Comcast’s deal to buy Time Warner Cable is lighting up social media with quips and analyses.

headline: How to Be a Better Valentine, Through Economics
text: Paul Oyer is a professor of economics as Stanford University’s Graduate School of Business and the author of “Everything I Ever Needed to Know About Economics I Learned From Online Dating.” He answered questions about the book in a recent post on Economix.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘I have to tell you’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “I have to tell you” by Dorothea Grossman and “The Memory Lady’s Daughter Tries to Fill the Gaps” by Beth Thompson.

headline: Comcast Has History of Big Deals
text: Brian Roberts, the chairman and chief executive of Comcast, has an appetite for big deals.

headline: As Evgeni Plushenko Bows Out, Yuzuru Hanyu Soars to a Figure Skating Record
text: SOCHI, Russia — As Evgeni Plushenko warmed up Thursday night, he stumbled where a few days ago he had been so sturdy and charismatic. After he withdrew from the men’s short program before a stunned home crowd, and later retired, calamity seemed to spread as if it were contagious, like the flu.

headline: Today in Small Business: Entrepreneurial Nightmares
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today?

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘Invisible Woman’
text: Costume design isn’t just telling actors what to wear, says Michael O’Connor, the man behind “The Invisible Woman’s” blossoming cravats and crinoline cages. “It’s a conversation.”

headline: A Clubhouse for Women of Worry
text: It’s not quite the next Club Macanudo, but a number of millennial men are discovering regular group shvitzes, bonding at the banyas on East 10th Street or Fulton.

headline: Image of the Day: February 13
text: Villagers digging a pond in Ganjam district of Odisha.

headline: On Giant Slalom: Ted Ligety
text: No skier in the world carves turns the way Ted Ligety does. The American has practically invented a new way of skiing.

headline: Plenty to Watch in Giant Cable Deal
text: Comcast just gave merger junkies plenty to watch on cable.

headline: Donald Trump’s Magical Powers
text: In addition to his other reality-based issues — thinking any serious person wants him to be president, for example — Donald Trump has a cause-and-effect problem. He believes that when he mentions something in public, any related action that follows was his doing. Like when a small child closes his eyes and thinks he made the world disappear.

headline: U.S. Backs New Global Initiative Against Infectious Diseases
text: The United States government said on Thursday it would spend $40 million to help low and middle-income countries develop and improve sophisticated systems to detect and respond to threats of infectious diseases, epidemics and bioterrorism. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said it was already working with Uganda and Vietnam, and that it would expand to include India, Kenya, Ethopia and Tanzania. The project’s goals include creating high-tech laboratories and trained teams that would respond rapidly to threats from diseases such as Avian flu, SARS, tuberculosis, and antibiotic-resistant illnesses. The C.D.C. aims to extend the program to 30 countries over five years to cover 4 billion people.

headline: Clintons Introduce New Women’s Global Initiative
text: It’s been almost 20 years since Hillary Rodham Clinton solidified her feminist credentials and declared, wearing a pale pink suit in Beijing, “Women’s rights are human rights and human rights are women’s rights.”

headline: After Inquiry, Puerto Rican Day Parade Replaces Board
text: The nonprofit group that organizes the National Puerto Rican Day Parade will be significantly overhauled after a state investigation that found years of financial mismanagement in running the annual extravaganza on Fifth Avenue favored by celebrities, politicians, corporate sponsors and tens of thousands of marchers.

headline: Vox Anti-Populi
text: Right now the online current-policy economics journal VoxEU — edited by my old student Richard Baldwin — has two fantastic pieces on inequality.

headline: Times Minute | Comcast's Mega Deal
text: Also on the Minute, Cate Blanchett's source of inspiration for her role in the film "Blue Jasmine," and scientists plan to sequence King Richard III's genetic code.

headline: Comcast and Time Warner Cable Forgo a Breakup Fee
text: Comcast’s $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable has a lot of numbers that stand out. Among them is the breakup fee if either side walks away.

headline: The 2,000 Year Apartment
text: Bloomberg reports on the soaring prices of trophy apartments in Manhattan. The biggest sale so far was former Citigroup head Sandy Weill’s apartment, which he sold for $88 milion to the daughter of a Russian oligarch. But $100 million listings are out there.

headline: Fortress Buys Back Stake From Nomura
text: The Fortress Investment Group, the first publicly listed hedge fund in the United States, has bought back a stake from Nomura, one of its principal investors.

headline: Israeli Forces Kill Palestinian at Gaza Border
text: GAZA — Israeli forces stationed along the border with Gaza fatally shot one Palestinian man and wounded another on Thursday, according to a Palestinian official.

headline: S.E.C. Close to Naming New Senior Official
text: After months of deliberation, Mary Jo White is finalizing her inner circle.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Reed Krakoff Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Julieta Cervantes.

headline: Verizon Wireless Expands Mobile Data Plans
text: AT&T has made several big moves recently, including price cuts for its family plans, to fight off T-Mobile US and hold onto its customers. Now Verizon Wireless is sweetening its phone plans, too.

headline: Apprehensive, Many Doctors Shift to Jobs With Salaries
text: American physicians, worried about changes in the health care market, are streaming into salaried jobs with hospitals. Though the shift from private practice has been most pronounced in primary care, specialists are following.

headline: 19th Is as Good as Gold for Oft-Injured Downhill Skier
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — It is never easy being a ski racer from a snow-challenged country like England, something Chemmy Alcott has known all her life. The path grew more arduous when she broke her neck skiing at 12 and had two vertebrae surgically fused.

headline: Italy’s Prime Minister Announces Resignation Amid Party Revolt
text: ROME — Prime Minister Enrico Letta, whose weak coalition government has come under increasing criticism, announced on Thursday that he would resign, after his own Democratic Party staged a dramatic insurrection and set the stage to replace him with the party’s new leader, Matteo Renzi.

headline: A Timelapse of Snow Covering Washington
text: The biggest snowstorm of the year hit Washington Wednesday night, closing federal offices on Thursday.

headline: Charles Mingus-Inspired Jazz at Manhattan School of Music
text: The Miser once showed up for a shift at his college radio station as the previous D.J. was winding down his set in rollicking style with Charles Mingus’s “Better Git It in Your Soul.” Emerging from his reverie, the Miser’s colleague turned and exclaimed, “If I had heard this when I was 12, I never would have bothered with punk rock.”

headline: Hopes, and Homes, Crumbling on Indian Tea Plantations
text: NAHORANI TEA ESTATE, India — For a century and a half, Madhu Munda’s forebears toiled on the same tea plantation that she lives and works on now. Belonging to central Indian tribes brought to what is now the northeastern state of Assam by the British in the mid-19th century, they and millions of other plantation workers survived as little more than indentured servants, even as the British Raj gave way to Indian democracy.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 7
text: Lil’ Kim performed for The Blonds; Jeremy Scott partied at Up & Down.

headline: Prospect of Spanish Citizenship Appeals to Descendants of Jews Expelled in 1492
text: JERUSALEM — A Spanish initiative that would offer citizenship to Sephardic Jews as a gesture of conciliation for Spain’s expulsion of Jews during the Inquisition has set off a flurry of interest in Israel.

headline: Neatness Doesn’t Count
text: “You won’t like it,” we are warned.

headline: Matt Lauer’s Olympian Assignment for NBC Begins Early and Ends Late
text: Matt Lauer will pinch-host again Thursday night for Bob Costas, NBC’s prime-time anchor at the Winter Games in Sochi, as Mr. Costas continues to treat his infected eyes.

headline: Putin Encourages Egyptian’s Presidential Ambitions
text: CAIRO — Field Marshal Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, a universally acknowledged but unannounced presidential candidate, received an early endorsement on Thursday from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: Scholastic Gives Kids a Video-Game Power-Up
text: A friend’s son just brought home his Scholastic News, excited to share a particular article. Scholastic News isn’t available online, and it’s short, so I’ll share the item here:

headline: Obama to Nominate Jane Chu to Head Arts Endowment
text: President Obama announced his intention to nominate Jane Chu, a pianist and arts administrator from Kansas City, Mo., to lead the National Endowment for the Arts, which has been without a permanent chief for more than a year.

text: ‘The Burglary’
