text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Bobby Cannavale’s Modern Grease Monkey
text: Like his co-stars Cate Blanchett and Sally Hawkins, Bobby Cannavale was party to Woody Allen’s idiosyncratic filmmaking process when he won a part in “Blue Jasmine.” For starters, he was only allowed to read his character’s part of the script, and even then, not for long.

headline: Live Stream | Calvin Klein’s Fall 2014 Collection at New York Fashion Week
text: The latest women’s collection from Calvin Klein at New York Fashion Week.

headline: A Year Later, Ackman Sticks With His Bet Against Herbalife
text: It has been a little more than a year since William A. Ackman announced a $1 billion bet against Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company, and that wager is still in the red.

headline: Slovakian Player’s Absence Affects Teammates and Foes
text: SOCHI, Russia — His family’s background could have made the game more complicated for United States forward Paul Stastny, so on the eve of his Sochi Games debut, his father, Peter, kept his advice simple. Have fun, he told his son, and savor every shift.

headline: When New Yorkers Use Umbrellas During Snowstorms
text: The snow continues to fall, we’re in the middle of a winter boot shortage and New Yorkers on Twitter and elsewhere are talking about a sensitive topic:

headline: Anchorman
text: Paddy Chayefsky’s Oscar-winning screenplay for the 1976 film “Network” was, and remains, the kind of literate, darkly funny and breathtakingly prescient material that prompts many to claim it as the greatest screenplay of the 20th century. In “Mad as Hell: The Making of ‘Network’ and the Fateful Vision of the Angriest Man in Movies,” Dave Itzkoff, a culture reporter for The New York Times, takes us behind the curtain and shows us why.

headline: Car Bomb Kills 5 Outside Airport in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — At least five people were killed and a dozen wounded on Thursday when a car loaded with explosives blew up outside a restaurant next to the entrance to the international airport in Mogadishu, officials said.

headline: Assessing Who Benefits From the Latest Rulings on the Employer Mandate
text: Seth Perretta is a benefits lawyer in Washington who has represented several trade groups while the Internal Revenue Service has been writing the rules governing the Affordable Care Act’s employer mandate.

headline: ScienceTake: War of the Ants
text: Tawny crazy ants are replacing the notorious fire ant with the help of a never-before-seen chemical defense.

headline: Shakespeare in the Park Lineup: ‘Much Ado About Nothing’ and ‘King Lear’
text: The witty banter of Beatrice and Benedick and the avaricious scheming of Goneril and Regan will animate this summer’s Shakespeare in the Park, the Public Theater’s annual series of free performances at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. The series, which the Public announced on Thursday, begins with “Much Ado About Nothing,” which opens on June 3 for a five-week run. “King Lear,” the second of the two productions, opens on July 22 and runs through Aug. 17.

headline: Polo Lets Women Play, Too
text: “I am launching Polo Ralph Lauren for women and opening a store, but I wanted to show that the two worlds are the same,” said Mr. Lauren, who gave a second dimension to his elegant Ralph Lauren presentation on Thursday, which was played out in pastel colors, easy fur pieces and draped, almost Grecian dresses.

headline: Odd Future Barred From New Zealand
text: Odd Future’s past seems to have caught up with it. The hip-hop group, which is known for its violent and sometimes misogynistic lyrics, and for incidents like a 2011 Boston performance in which some witnesses said that the group’s frontman, Tyler, the Creator, incited fans to attack a policeman, has been barred from entering New Zealand, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Crazy Ant Invader Uses Acid to Its Advantage
text: The crazy ant, the latest ant to invade North America, is having remarkable success at replacing its predecessor, the red fire ant, former king of the invaders. Part of the reason, according to research at the University of Texas, is that the newcomer can detoxify fire ant venom in a way not seen before in other insects or animals.

headline: Investors Eye Comcast’s Bid for Time Warner Cable With Caution
text: That long proxy fight to take control of Time Warner Cable that I predicted earlier this week? It lasted days, ending with the announcement on Thursday that Comcast would acquire Time Warner Cable. The questions now are whether Time Warner Cable can complete the deal, and what lesson we’ve learned for future hostile takeovers.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Returns
text: Alessandra Stanley, the chief television critic for The Times, discusses the new season of the Netflix political drama.

headline: Tracing Ancestry, Researchers Produce a Genetic Atlas of Human Mixing Events
text: The rise and fall of empires, the march of armies, the flow of trade routes, the practice of slavery — all these events have led to a mixing of populations around the world. Such episodes have left a record in the human genome, but one that has so far been too complex to decipher on a global scale.

headline: The Making of a Rap Tribute to the Galleon Group
text: What rhymes with Raj Rajaratnam?

headline: Hastings Joins Roster of Retiring House Members
text: Representative Doc Hastings, a Republican who has represented Washington State for 20 years and who is chairman of the House Natural Resources Committee, announced Thursday that he would retire at the end of the year, joining a growing number of veterans heading for the congressional exits.

headline: Ralph Lauren: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: Learning to Silence My Inner Editor
text: I am trained to be a critic. After several years of graduate school, I started to enjoy pointing out flaws in people’s writing, a ruthless activity with all the destructive pleasure of picking at a scab. The voice of my inner editor had become so powerful that it almost kept me from finding the love of my life.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 13
text: Warm weather, men’s slopestyle skiing, individual skating and skeleton headline the eighth day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Proenza Schouler Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Anna Moller.

headline: The School Snow Run
text: New York parents dragged their children to school through snow and ice Thursday, on a day when the governor declared a state of emergency. Some were creative about transport; not all were happy.

headline: Schumer Offers Long-Shot Option to Skirt House G.O.P. on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, offered a long-shot option on Thursday to revive the moribund effort to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws that would require the support of more than a dozen House Republicans — and, if nothing else, pressure others to act on an election-year issue that Tea Party-aligned members strongly oppose.

headline: Study Sees Path to Cutting Substantial American Natural Gas Leaks
text: A policy analysis published in Science today examines 20 years of research on leakage from natural gas production and distribution systems in North America, including hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, and finds big opportunities to cut the worst leaks and a substantial climate benefit from a coal-to-gas switch, even accounting for higher leak rates.

headline: From Flat on Their Backs, Sliders Rise to Play Tag for the Team
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — It is the Winter Games equivalent of a dropped baton, the sort of Olympic nightmare that haunts lugers as they lie on their sleds and that wakes them as they lie in their beds.

headline: Scots Told They Risk Losing the Pound if They Gain Independence
text: LONDON — Britain’s three main political parties set aside routine disagreements on Thursday to issue an unusual collective warning to Scots that if they vote for independence, Scotland will lose the pound sterling as its currency.

headline: Modern Love | Under His Misspell
text: When a writer falls in love with someone whose spelling and grammar are poor, it challenges her assumptions about the type of man she'd want to marry.

headline: A Post-Soviet, Punk-Feminist Story
text: “Sleep with one eye open,” Annie’s mother warns, as she packs her daughter off to visit the old country. It’s good advice — Annie’s adventures in Russia will pit her against insatiable witches, angry bears, pugilistic potatoes and, last but not least, terrifyingly tight minis and grotesquely high heels.

headline: Snowfall Totals Around the Region
text: Inches of snow and time of measurement as reported by the National Weather Service.

headline: In Surprise Move, Terra Firma Shakes Up Renewable Energy Team
text: Updated, 3:48 p.m. | LONDON — Terra Firma, the European private equity fund founded by the British financier Guy Hands, is shaking up its management ranks.

headline: Bailout Gave Small Bank a Chance to Survive
text: The image of bank bailouts in the United States was set by the megabanks, and with it widespread public hostility to the bailouts.

headline: One-Fifth of New Enrollees Under Health Care Law Fail to Pay First Premium
text: WASHINGTON — One in five people who signed up for health insurance under the new health care law failed to pay their premiums on time and therefore did not receive coverage in January, insurance companies and industry experts say.

headline: J. Mendel: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: Teaching the Sochi Olympics | English Language Arts, Journalism and Fine Arts
text: All week we’ve been posting lesson ideas related to the 2014 Winter Games. Below, our list for literature, journalism, media studies and fine arts classes, as well as suggestions for E.L.L. students. You can find ideas for social studies, science, math and more by scrolling through our full collection.

headline: Too Secret for Congress
text: The Los Angeles Times had a great story today that helps explain why few Americans — including the ones who make the country’s laws — know much about the drone program that is the vanguard of the endless war against terror. The basic reason, of course, is that the Obama administration wants to keep everyone in the dark, but the lengths to which officials will go can sometimes be surprising.

headline: The Gun Report: February 13, 2014
text: In response to federal gun restrictions proposed after the Sandy Hook massacre, some states have adopted new laws under the banner of “gun nullification.” In Missouri on Tuesday, senators endorsed legislation that seeks to invalidate federal gun restrictions, and even send federal agents to jail for enforcing such laws. The measure will likely face a court challenge if it gets approved. The Democratic governor vetoed a similar measure that passed last year.

headline: Global Citizens, Bound by Soul and Sinew
text: After passing through galleries filled with small, craftsy, poetic objects in last year’s Venice Biennale, you suddenly had a Dante moment in an installation of life-size figures by the Polish artist Pawel Althamer.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: happiness and age, chick flicks and brushing children’s teeth. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: New Antiques Websites Join Crowded Field
text: The latest marketing craze in the antiques world, now that the recent wave of TV shows starring auctioneers and dealers has faded, is for websites that help collectors click and buy.

headline: Pro-Clinton ‘Super PAC’ Sets Event for Donors
text: The leading Democratic “super PAC” will hold a briefing for potential donors this month, its first such event since reorganizing in January as a vehicle to help elect Hillary Rodham Clinton as president.

headline: For New Age, the Next Generation
text: A sign on the door of the Body Actualized Center in Bushwick, Brooklyn, promised “Cosmic Yoga,” but on a recent snowy Monday night, a crowd had gathered for a concert of electronic music. Slushy boots were politely confiscated in the lobby, and about 75 shoeless patrons in their 20s and 30s sat cross-legged on pillows or reclined on blankets on the floor. The space was lit, just barely, by botanica candles, placed amid potted trees and colorful crystals. The aroma of incense permeated the room.

headline: Study Finds Methane Leaks Negate Benefits of Natural Gas as a Fuel for Vehicles
text: WASHINGTON — The sign is ubiquitous on city buses around the country: “This bus runs on clean burning natural gas.”

headline: Everyday Existence, With Eyes Wide Open
text: “Art at the Core: The Intersection of Visual Art, Performance and Technology” at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill feels more like an arbitrary collection of artworks than a specially curated show. Nonetheless, there is some attempt at binding the exhibition together with a common theme. According to a gallery release, the few dozen works by 23 artists “lend themselves to narrative interpretation” and look toward art to address “the very core of our everyday lives, our ‘Weltanschauung,’ ” or worldview.

headline: A Whodunit Asks, Why Isn’t He Dead?
text: Edmund Wilson wasn’t an admirer of genre fiction, mystery novels especially. He asked, testily, “Who cares who killed Roger Ackroyd?”

headline: Rediscovering New Age
text: Mike Rubin and Ben Ratliff discuss the current state of new-age music.

headline: Putting Music First
text: The Stone is considered, among its fans, a pinnacle of what a music space should be.

headline: For Dry Tastes, an Aromatic Altar to Bitters
text: EVEN if love were not part of the name, I would fall for Amor y Amargo in the East Village.

headline: Kerry Rejects Delaying South Korea Exercise
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Secretary of State John Kerry rebuffed North Korea’s demand that the United States and South Korea briefly delay a joint military exercise this month so that it does not coincide with the scheduled reunion of families separated by the Korean War.

headline: Caught Beneath the Wheels of the Comcast Juggernaut
text: Comcast’s deal machine has spit out a value destroyer. Digesting Time Warner Cable is ambitious even for a serial acquirer like Comcast’s chief executive, Brian Roberts. As with some of his many previous purchases, it looks set to generate a return on investment below Comcast’s cost of capital. That’s crummy but not criminal. It’s also not surprising given the medieval governance the Roberts family uses to oversee its fiefdom.

headline: N.S.A. Forces Out Civilian Employee With Snowden Tie
text: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency has told Congress that it has forced out a civilian employee after a lengthy investigation to “assign accountability” for the disclosure of intelligence secrets by Edward J. Snowden, one of its former contractors.

headline: Soap Opera Star, His Girlfriend and His Admirer
text: “One of Your Biggest Fans” is a fairly good play with some fairly big problems, in a production that is equal parts funny and frustrating.

headline: Calvin Klein: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: Choose the Artists, Ignore the Critics
text: PHILADELPHIA — Anthony Elms says that the first artwork he fell in love with, as a boy growing up in southern Michigan, was John Singleton Copley’s painting of a swimmer pulled from the clutches of sharks, at the Detroit Institute of Arts. Mr. Elms may soon be casting his mind back to that picture as he starts to feel like chum.

headline: Videos of Besieged Areas in Syria Highlight Need for Aid Access
text: As my colleagues reported  from Geneva, the halls of United Nations headquarters were quiet on Thursday morning, with no meetings between the two sides in the Syrian peace talks.

headline: A Loan Extends Museums’ Global Reach
text: Life at the Frick Collection may be a bit quieter since its blockbuster exhibition “Masterpieces of Dutch Painting From the Mauritshuis” closed there last month, leaving its galleries devoid of two star paintings, Vermeer’s “Girl With a Pearl Earring” (1665), one of the most recognizable faces in art history, and Fabritius’s “The Goldfinch,” a tiny 1654 canvas that is the protagonist of the best-selling novel of the same title.

headline: State by State in the Aftermath of Deadly Winter Storm
text: Updated, 6:42 p.m. Feb. 14 At least 50 vehicles, including tractor-trailers, were involved in two pileups along an ice-covered stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike on Friday morning, sending more than 30 people to area hospitals. Officials said that at least five people suffered serious injuries.

headline: Aesthetics Are Not the Point
text: Beauty is routinely dismissed by today’s progressive thinkers. It’s not politically or ethically meaningful, they’ll say. But this is wrong. Beauty is political. Groups of people convene around vehement feelings for particular forms of it. What some find beautiful, others find repulsive and morally disgusting, and sometimes even worth going to war over. The taste for certain styles of beauty is as likely to be aligned with revolutionary as with reactionary convictions.

headline: Retiring on the House
text: As baby boomers age, reverse mortgages are expected to gain popularity as a means of covering living expenses. Hence, in the future, more homes passed on to children will come with a bill attached — the balance due on these equity loans.

headline: Relais & Châteaux Puts on a Show
text: Relais & Châteaux, the collection of upscale hotels and restaurants, is holding its first wine and food festival from March 27 to March 30 in Carmel-by-the Sea, Calif.

headline: Clip: 'Jimmy P'
text: A scene from the Arnaud Desplechin film "Jimmy P: Psychotherapy of a Plains Indian," featuring Benicio del Toro and Mathieu Amalric.

headline: De Blasio Defends Opening Schools
text: The mayor defended the decision to keep schools open during the snowstorm, despite criticism from some parents.

headline: Belgium Close to Allowing Euthanasia for Ill Minors
text: PARIS — Belgian lawmakers gave final approval on Thursday to a measure that would allow euthanasia for incurably ill children enduring insufferable pain. King Philippe is expected to sign the measure into law and make Belgium the first country to lift all age restrictions on legal, medically induced deaths.

headline: Vintage French, Permitted to Breathe
text: As one typically more drawn to Germanic repertory than to French, I expected to enjoy the Boston Symphony Orchestra’s first concert conducted by Bernard Haitink at Carnegie Hall this week, on Tuesday evening, at least as much as its second, on Wednesday.

headline: A Journey to Bollywood for the Food
text: Any serious-minded restaurant named after a trilogy of Bollywood buddy-cop thrillers (imagine “Lethal Weapon” set in Mumbai) deserves some style points sight unseen. But it turns out there’s plenty more style on display once you enter Dhoom, an unusual three-month-old Indian spot in Secaucus.

headline: Bookshelf: Just Hatched
text: New picture books about young creatures include Jorey Hurley’s “Nest.”

headline: De Blasio Defends Call to Police About Supporter’s Arrest
text: Characterizing his actions as “appropriate,” Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday sharply defended his decision to call a top police official this week to inquire about the arrest of a Brooklyn bishop, a key political supporter.

headline: Serving the Standards for 35 Years
text: Sadler’s Ordinary, occupying a barnlike structure in out-of-the-way Marlborough, recently celebrated its 35th anniversary. Few marriages last that long, and the restaurant business is even more fickle than matrimony. Perhaps the secret lies in knowing who you are — and who you aren’t. “We don’t try to be pretentious,” says the chef and owner, Kevin Haggerty, who has run Sadler’s since 1994. “People like the standards.” And so his back-to-the-future menu features surf and turf and quiche Lorraine. Welcome to 1978!

headline: Italian Food the Old-Fashioned Way
text: Alex’s Bar and Grille in White Plains has been open only about a year and a half, but dining there makes me feel nostalgic.

headline: Show Your Affection (or Test Your Love)
text: WITH same-sex marriage working its way into the mainstream of American life, straight people aren’t the only ones figuring out just how boring wedded bliss can be. So what’s a couple to do when the flames of romance sputter? Several events in New York City this Valentine’s Day weekend offer unconventional, dramatic and tasty ways for couples — married or not, gay or otherwise — to kindle or rekindle a love story.

headline: An Artist’s Paintings, and His Complexities, on Display
text: PURCHASE, N.Y. — The small but potent paintings of Forrest Bess respond to the art world’s “either-ors” with a resounding “and.” Without resorting to big stretches of canvas or brash gestures, they merge inner and outer worlds, abstraction and representation, and ideas of masculinity and femininity. To a market still intent on labeling “insiders” and “outsiders,” they offer the conundrum of an artist who showed at the Betty Parsons Gallery in New York in the 1950s, alongside Rothko and Pollock, but made his living as a bait fisherman in Bay City, Tex.

headline: Effects of Raising the Minimum Wage
Celery Adds an Extra Dimension to Stewed Pork
text: Celery is the underlying backbone of many dishes. But sometimes it deserves to be played up front. Its vegetal freshness and somewhat bitter finish add a bright dimension to this earthy dish of pork and lentils, elements that go a long way toward welcoming a bottle of Rosso di Montalcino.

headline: Beyond the Bread, Glimpses of Italy
text: Some believe they can foretell the success of a restaurant meal by the bread served at the outset. If the bread is good, the meal will be great; if it is bad, abandon all hope. Those people would be proved wrong at Spezia, a new Italian restaurant in St. James.

headline: Which Is Your Favorite Modern Love Column?
text: Modern Love’s editor, Dan Jones, and his new book, “Love, Illuminated,” have been all over The Times the past few weeks, with a review in a love-themed edition of the Book Review, an article in the Sunday Review and an excerpt in his home, the Style section (“Good Enough? That’s Great”). You might think it’s because Dan is one of our own, but I’d beg to differ.

headline: Connected: Love in the Time of the Internet
Nothing to See, Yet So Much Not to Miss
text: Moviegoers may be experiencing a moment of mathematical confusion. Are there too many movies or not enough? Could it be both? At this time of year, interesting new commercial releases slow to a trickle, as the Oscar pachyderms dominate the landscape, making room for a few smaller films and the usual genre offerings — action, rom-com, animation, whatever. Slim pickings for the discerning cinephile. At the same time, bulletins from Sundance and Berlin, and reports from the not-fully-charted wilderness of digital distribution, suggest a state of unmanageable abundance, a cornucopia of docs, foreign-language art and genre films, and post-mumblecore youthquakes. There is nothing to see, but so much that we’re missing.

headline: Pieces That Invite a Closer Look
text: Grace Beza of Islip had strapped a small light onto her forehead and entered a dark, cavelike room. Inside, dozens of images painted on the walls showed men wearing headlamps on helmets. When she emerged, she was intrigued but mystified. The figures looked like miners in a womb, Ms. Beza said.

headline: Making His Case for the Second Montalcino
text: It could be because it’s the second wine of the region, made with grapes that for one reason or another didn’t make the cut for the first. Or maybe it’s because the status of Brunello di Montalcino, and therefore the wines of Montalcino, were under a cloud of scandal for several years, making them difficult to embrace.

headline: For DiCaprio, ‘Wolf’ Is ‘Reflection of the Truth’
text: “Let’s hug it out,” Leonardo DiCaprio said, reaching in for an embrace.

headline: Images of Turkish Reporter Felled by Police Water Cannon Stir Anger Online
text: Turkish bloggers and journalists expressed outrage on social networks Thursday at images of a female television reporter who was knocked down by a direct blast of red liquid fired from a police water cannon during a protest in the capital, Anakara.

text: Standout fall 2014 accessories from Proenza Schouler, Reed Krakoff, Michael Kors and more.

headline: When Age Belies Buying Power
text: In the universe of ultraluxury real estate, much attention has been lavished on foreign investors who pay record prices for glassy Midtown condominiums, and the wave of previously staunch uptown residents suddenly spending big to embrace unlikely neighborhoods in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Volkswagen to Stop Using Primates in Ads, Withdrawing Teaser for Super Bowl Commercial
text: The animal welfare organization People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals has scored again in its long-running fight against the use of primates in advertising, as Volkswagen of America agreed to abide by a no-primates policy and withdrew a video clip from online platforms that had served as a teaser for the company’s commercial during Super Bowl XLVIII on Feb. 2.

headline: That’s an Order!
text: Making good on a promise from his recent State of the Union address, President Obama signed an executive order on Wednesday to ensure that employees of federal contractors are paid at least $10.10 an hour starting in 2015.

text: To the Editor:

headline: PepsiCo Declines to Spin Off Beverage Unit
text: PepsiCo Inc. said on Thursday that it had decided not to spin off its North American beverage business, effectively rejecting a push by the activist investor Nelson Peltz.

headline: London’s West End, a Stage for Good Eating
text: It takes time to eat in a great restaurant, and time is precious pre- or post-theater. You’re either eating early and in a hurry to make the curtain, or you’re up late and half-ready for bed. In either case, a two-hour blowout is unlikely.

headline: New York Fashion Week Street Style: Day 8
text: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC took over our Instagram account for New York Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

headline: Under Cover: Capturing Wendy Davis
text: Jeff Brown, the photographer for this week’s cover story, took cues from classic movies to produce a warm and highly-saturated portrait of State Senator Wendy Davis.

headline: In Chiang Mai, Thailand, a Hub for Creative Types
text: Alongside its reputation for gilded, Buddha-filled temples and treks to hill tribe villages, Chiang Mai in northern Thailand has in recent years attracted creative types seeking a chilled-out alternative to Bangkok, 350 miles away. Nowhere is this more evident than Nimmanhaemin Road, a thoroughfare west of the old city center anchored by Chiang Mai University and known as Nimman. The area’s tranquil side streets, called sois, are home to quirky coffee shops, design boutiques and galleries. These, combined with boutique hotels like Artel Nimman, where guests access the ground floor by a slide, make Nimman an appealing base from which to explore the city.

headline: Learning the Language of Restaurant Week
text: A new video campaign launched by NYC & Company, New York’s marketing and tourism organization, offers a comedic look at the orthoepic challenges of NYC Restaurant Week.

headline: Bill O’Reilly’s Gift for the Ages
text: It’s been nearly two weeks now since Bill O’Reilly’s interview with President Obama on Super Bowl Sunday, and in the No Spin Zone of the host’s pretend world he’s still spinning the chat as the greatest conversation since Winston Churchill dined alone.

headline: In a Rare Visit, Three Chances to Impress
text: When the Royal New Zealand Ballet opened at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday night, it was a homecoming — not for the 61-year-old company, which hasn’t been in New York since 1993, but for its artistic director since 2011, a recently retired star of American Ballet Theater, Ethan Stiefel. Before an audience packed with ballet notables, Mr. Stiefel showed what he’s been up to, introducing his dancers through three recent works chosen for variety.

headline: Alex Katz / Dara Friedman
text: Gavin Brown’s Enterprise

headline: Fragmented Frames of the Love That Was, Taunting Yet Poignant
text: Most stories begin once upon a time and, after the usual chronological tramp toward the inevitable and an occasional detour into the past or future, end happily ever after (or not). In “Je T’Aime, Je T’Aime,” a magnificent film from out of the past, the French director Alain Resnais takes dozens of interludes from one man’s life — images of everyday banality and commonplace delights, scenes of him at work and at play — and arranges them nonchronologically. One minute, Claude (Claude Rich) is emerging from a swim, the next he’s violently quarreling with a lover, and then he’s emerging from that exact same swim all over again, as if stuck in a loop.

headline: Treadmills, Without the Tedium
text: AT a fitness expo in Germany four years ago, the trainer Joe DiAngelo was struck by how boring everything seemed. He eventually came to a realization: Perhaps that old gym standby — the treadmill — could use a makeover.

text: There is long-overdue support for raising the minimum wage. But among generally mistreated minimum wage workers there’s a subgroup of those whose wage experience is even more miserable and unfair.

headline: Acidic Bonbons for V-Day Contrarians
text: If you were in danger of becoming all dewy eyed about someone this Valentine’s Day, two windy women stand ready to suck all the joy out of love for you. A science-y show may have already done so earlier in the week. But have patience. Next week, a wedding provides a dose of optimism, despite the skull on the cake.

headline: A Couplet Fantasy Denied
text: “I really feel a lot!” declares Amy (Emma Roberts), a pushy 22-year-old aspiring poet in Scott Coffey’s smart but wince-inducing satirical comedy “Adult World.” “I want to speak for all the people that suffer, that feel the pain that I feel.”

headline: Sex and Candy
text: NOTHING is more symbolic of the romance of Valentine’s Day than a box of chocolates, traditionally a gift from Him to Her. Chocolate, with its luxurious texture and pleasurable taste, has become the edible correlate to love and desire. And although scientists haven’t discovered any definitive difference in the way men and women respond to chocolate, conventional wisdom is that women naturally crave the stuff.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Feb. 14-20
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: With a Dentist’s Chair and a Chicken Mask, a Girl Can’t Say No
text: It is now 40 years since the first performances of David Mamet’s “Sexual Perversity in Chicago” and almost 30 since the play was made into a movie, starring Rob Lowe and Demi Moore and directed by Edward Zwick, called “About Last Night ... .” Some things have changed (Mr. Mamet has evolved into a dyspeptic right-winger) and some have not (Mr. Lowe and Ms. Moore are still very good looking), but all in all, the thing holds up pretty well. Mr. Mamet’s title was always a bit of a misnomer — his jagged play is more interested in romantic confusion and emotional complication than in freaky bedroom matters — but his map of the crooked paths to heterosexual bliss remains useful and adaptable, even when softened and tidied up by Hollywood. The proof is in the new “About Last Night,” a sweet, silly, semi-raunchy Valentine’s Day confection directed by Steve Pink (“Hot Tub Time Machine”).

headline: Smartphone Sales Beat Feature Phones in 2013
text: Watching the sales of smartphones and feature phones in recent years has felt similar to watching a Ferrari race a horse. You know the Ferrari is going to win, it’s just a matter of when.

headline: Once a Lowlife, Always a Lowlife
text: Having just achieved Hollywood leading man status in the remake of “RoboCop,” Joel Kinnaman reappears as JW, a.k.a. Johan, in the Swedish gangster thriller “Easy Money: Hard to Kill.” It is the second movie of three in a popular Swedish franchise that follows the criminal career of this wily, serpentine social climber from the provinces.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Faking It
text: Three somehow related stories of the day:

headline: Hellbent on Fusing His Soul With Hers
text: There’s a promising edge to the opening of “Endless Love,” which begins with a young man, David (Alex Pettyfer), speaking in voice-over about a young woman, Jade (Gabriella Wilde). It’s a high school graduation somewhere in Atlanta, and as the camera picks Jade out of the celebrating crowd, David reminisces about how he’s been watching her for years. From the way he talks, he seems to have been watching her closely. Closely enough to suggest that he’s been long nurturing a passion, perhaps an obsession — something deep, troubling and real.

headline: Therapist and Patient, Odd and Charming
text: As played by Benicio Del Toro — flattening vowels, biting at consonants, pushing his tall, square frame though postures of graceful anguish — Jimmy Picard, a World War II veteran and a member of the Blackfoot Indian tribe, is the picture of a noble soul in torment. He is both charismatic and pathetic, and he inspires in his therapist, a French anthropologist and psychoanalyst named Georges Devereux (Mathieu Amalric), a complex mixture of responses, including sympathy, rivalry and unabashed ethnographic curiosity.

headline: Democrats Need Only Look to Past Voters
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: A Culinary Dalí, Delving Into Palettes
text: The only meal I ever ate at El Bulli, the Michelin-starred epicenter of Ferran Adrià’s innovative cuisine (now closed), began with hors d’oeuvres that included a deep-fried, mostly intact rabbit’s ear.  It seemed like a gauntlet thrown down, daring me to keep up. After a  pause, I plunged ahead.  It was surprisingly tasty, and I liked the economy of using overlooked parts of an animal, even bunnies.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Feb. 14-20
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Dates Blind and Less So in a Starry Metropolis
text: The urban tales in “Beijing Love Story” are shameless about conveying modern-age mores and old-fashioned sweetness. When two male friends speed down a road in a car, the cityscape is a riot of multicolored lights, and the techno music thumps as they fist-pumpingly exclaim, “This is life!” When two teenagers shyly get to know each other in another story, their hand-holding on a bus is played for its innocent romantic bliss.

headline: Challengers Say a Tea Party Favorite Shortchanged Constituents
text: As a freshman state senator in the last legislative session, Donna Campbell, Republican of New Braunfels, became known for her strong stance against abortion and for her impassioned speeches at committee hearings. But community leaders in her district have criticized Ms. Campbell, a darling of the Tea Party, for the establishment of a new taxing district in Wimberley and an increase in vehicle registration fees to build toll lanes in San Antonio. The criticism has fueled challenges from two fellow Republicans — Elisa Chan, a former San Antonio city councilwoman, and Mike Novak, a former Bexar County commissioner — hoping to unseat Ms. Campbell in the March 4 primary.

headline: Fantasy Girl at Your Service
text: Set in the world of online pornography — and with production values to match — Robert Nathan’s “Lucky Bastard” is a sorry-looking found-footage thriller as unconvincing as its characters’ thrashing orgasms.

headline: A Closer Look at Valentine’s Flowers
text: EL PASO —  The flowers that decorate offices, homes and restaurants along the Mexico border have been inspected as closely at border crossings as many door panels and car trunks, well-known hiding places used by drug mules to export heroin, cocaine and marijuana from Mexico.

headline: Bridgestone Admits Guilt in U.S. Price-Fixing Case
text: The Bridgestone Corporation became the latest automotive supplier to plead guilty to charges of conspiring to fix the prices of parts sold to automakers here and abroad, the Justice Department said on Thursday.

headline: Heightened Security, Visible and Invisible, Blankets the Olympics
text: SOCHI, Russia — Before boarding the new trains serving Sochi and the Olympic sites here, passengers must pass through metal detectors and place their bags on X-ray machines — just as in airports. What many do not realize is that they are also being scanned by a far more sophisticated system that gauges emotional state in an effort to identify potential terrorists.

headline: Demons at Work in Snowy Magic of New York
text: “Winter’s Tale,” Mark Helprin’s 1983 best seller, was the “Goldfinch” of its time: fat and ambitious, with a romantic view of New York City and an unabashed commitment to the kind of old-fashioned narrative abundance that seemed, then as now, to be missing from too much literary fiction. It is a bit surprising that the movie adaptation (written and directed by Akiva Goldsman) has taken so long to arrive, though perhaps less surprising that it should be so clumsy and inert, a lumbering white elephant rather than the flying white horse that is the novel’s magical mascot.

text: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: New York Fashion Week: Calvin Klein Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

headline: Spare Times for Feb. 14-20
text: Talks on Hip-Hop (Thursday) Hip-hop may be one of the newer kids on the musical block, but its cultural impact runs as deep as any genre that has preceded it. It’s the focus of a slide show that will accompany a discussion with the photographer Jamel Shabazz and Wes Jackson, founder of Brooklyn Bodega, a branding and promotional company, at the Brooklyn Historical Society, 128 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn Heights.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Feb. 14-20
text: ‘Mysteries of the Unseen World’

headline: Shedding the Cliché of High School Sex
text: Like a fresh ripple in the near-stagnant high school movie pool, Chris Nelson’s “Date and Switch” balances formula with winning performers, genuine humor and a generosity of spirit that this genre too often lacks.

headline: Francis Bacon Work Sells for $70 Million at Christie’s Auction
text: LONDON — Trophy hunters fought over trophy paintings by Gerhard Richter and Francis Bacon, as well as a pink stainless-steel “Cracked Egg” by Jeff Koons, at Christie’s sale of postwar and contemporary art here on Thursday night. But of the three artists, it was Bacon who once again stole the spotlight when an unnamed American collector paid $70 million for “Portrait of George Dyer Talking,” a 1966 canvas depicting the artist’s lover perched on a stool, his twisted body positioned under a naked light bulb as though he were being interrogated.

headline: Giant Jumps
text: All but two of the top six skaters after the women’s figure skating short program have performed a difficult triple-triple combination in their long program this season. The highest-scoring combination, a triple lutz-triple toe, was the gold medalist Kim Yu-na’s signature move in 2010 but this year, others have also mastered it.

headline: Romance and Tourism
text: If you’re willing to believe the old moviemaking canard that beautiful, intelligent women are attracted to underachieving men with no ambition or prospects, then you’ll find “Girl on a Bicycle” to be a sweet, often witty romantic comedy.

headline: Pandora Suit May Upend Century-Old Royalty Plan
text: As the music industry races toward a future of digital streams and smartphone apps, its latest crisis centers on a regulatory plan that has been in place since “Chattanooga Choo Choo” was a hit.

headline: Belles of the Wrecking Ball
text: The Museum of Modern Art’s decision to tear down the quirky little American Folk Art Museum, barely a decade old, has generated outrage; only the loss of Penn Station in 1963 and the fight that saved Grand Central in the 1970s have been more bitter.

headline: Trimmings NYFW, Day 7
text: From snakeskin clutches to stiletto sneakers, these are the standout fall 2014 accessories from Proenza Schouler, Reed Krakoff, Michael Kors and more.

headline: Inequality, Dignity and Freedom
text: Now that the Congressional Budget Office has explicitly denied saying that Obamacare destroys jobs, some (though by no means all) Republicans have stopped lying about that issue and turned to a different argument. O.K., they concede, any reduction in working hours because of health reform will be a voluntary choice by the workers themselves — but it’s still a bad thing because, as Representative Paul Ryan puts it, they’ll lose “the dignity of work.”

headline: Banks in London Devise Way Around Europe’s Bonus Rules
text: LONDON — A battle over banker bonuses is building in this financial capital.

headline: Opening Shouts and Whispers
text: There are two ways to announce your arrival on New York Fashion Week’s gridlocked calendar: gingerly or brashly, a gentle tap or a sharp elbow. The handful of debuts this week — including, not exhaustively, the first women’s collection from the men’s provocateurs of Duckie Brown, the first presentation by the surf-slacker line Baja East, and the first in New York by Manolo Blahnik — offered examples of both.

headline: The Refiner’s Fire
text: In 2005, Michael Ignatieff left a teaching job at Harvard to enter politics in his native Canada with hopes of becoming prime minister.

headline: Dropbox Hires a Google Executive, as It Starts Its Next Phase for Growth
text: Dennis Woodside, the chief executive of Motorola, owned by Google, is leaving to join Dropbox, which competes with Google in cloud storage.

headline: Massachusetts Is Given Extension
text: BOSTON — Massachusetts officials said Thursday that they have an additional three months to bring the state’s health care system in line with the national Affordable Care Act.

headline: Snow Day? That’s Great. Now Log In. Get to Class.
text: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J. — At 9 a.m. on Thursday the snow was piling high outside and officials had long since made the call to shutter the local schools.

headline: Should All Immigrants Get ID Cards?
text: Should cities issue identification for anyone who has no passport or driver's license, even if they are not in the country legally?

headline: Germans Propose Law to Ease Return of Art Looted by Nazis
text: MUNICH — German authorities proposed a law on Friday that would lift the country’s 30-year statute of limitations for certain cases involving stolen property, a move that would make it easier for Jewish families to seek the return of art, furniture or other valuables taken from them by the Nazis.

headline: Live Stream | Marc Jacobs’s Fall 2014 Collection at New York Fashion Week
text: The latest women’s collection from Marc Jacobs at New York Fashion Week.

headline: William Zeckendorf Jr., 84, Dies; Developer Put Stamp on Skyline
text: William Zeckendorf Jr., the son of a celebrated developer who himself transformed New York City by making big bets on big projects that helped refashion neighborhoods from the Upper West Side to Union Square, died on Wednesday in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 84.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Feb. 14, 2014
text: The New York Times movie critics on "RoboCop," "Winter's Tale" and "About Last Night."

headline: U.S. Dominance in Science Faces Asian Challenge
text: WASHINGTON — The United States’ predominance in science and technology is fading, a report released this month by the National Science Board warns.

headline: Bulldozer Clearing Snow Kills a Pregnant Woman
text: The snow was falling heavily as Min Lin, pregnant and nearing her due date, and her husband loaded groceries into their car on Thursday in a parking lot in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Nearby, a small bulldozer ran back and forth, furiously working to keep the lot behind Fei Long Market clear of snow.

headline: Another Big Month for Sony Game Console
text: March can’t come soon enough for Microsoft. That’s when the game Titanfall will come out exclusively for the company’s Xbox game consoles and PCs running Windows.

headline: States Struggle to Add Latinos to Health Rolls
text: LOS ANGELES — With an estimated 15 percent of the country’s uninsured population, California is crucial to the success of President Obama’s health care overhaul. Here, that success cannot come without enrolling Latinos, who make up more than half of the state’s uninsured.

headline: Putting the Romance in Cold Medicine and Fabric Softener
text: FLORISTS, chocolatiers, jewelers and greeting card publishers typically promote aggressively for Valentine’s Day, but brands that few would associate with romance also are courting consumers this year.

headline: For Daredevils on Snow, the Edge Has Always Been Near
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The X Games generation is sometimes referred to as a new breed of Winter Olympian, daredevils unafraid — even excited — to push the limit of gravity in sports that inherently push the limit of safety. And the Winter Olympics’ new slopestyle events are their test track.

headline: California Seeing Brown Where Green Used to Be
text: SELMA, Calif. — Fields that in any other year would be filled with broccoli, melons and onions are instead dusty patches of dirt. Farmers are calculating losses that add up with each arid day. Thousands of farm workers who rely on paychecks for tending the fields are expected to go unemployed this year.

headline: As Hate Crimes Rise, British Muslims Say They’re Becoming More Insular
text: BIRMINGHAM, England — Alum Rock, a neighborhood of Birmingham, looks the way Pakistan might, if Pakistan were under gray northern skies and British rule.

headline: A Huge Solar Plant Opens, Facing Doubts About Its Future
text: NIPTON, Calif. — The Ivanpah solar power plant stretches over more than five square miles of the Mojave Desert. Almost 350,000 mirrors the size of garage doors tilt toward the sun with an ability to energize 140,000 homes. The plant, which took almost four years and thousands of workers assembling millions of parts to complete, officially opened on Thursday, the first electric generator of its kind.

headline: Free Online University Receives Accreditation, in Time for Graduating Class of 7
text: Just in time for its first graduates, the University of the People, a tuition-free four-year-old online institution built to reach underserved students around the world, announced Thursday that it had received accreditation.

headline: For Mayor, Keeping Schools Open Brings Another Headache
text: His education chief declared Thursday “a beautiful day” as sleet poured down on parents wondering why schools had not been closed.

headline: Iris van Berne Transforms Backstage at J. Mendel
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Iris van Berne before (left) and after (right) makeup by Dick Page and hair by Anthony Turner.

headline: Industry Shifts May Aid Comcast in Takeover Bid
text: On the face of it, the merger of the country’s two largest cable companies would seem like a nonstarter, given its steep regulatory hurdles and skepticism from consumer watchdogs.

headline: If a Cable Giant Becomes Bigger
text: Regulators might be tempted to agree with Comcast that its proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable for $45.2 billion in stock poses no threat to competition and would actually benefit consumers by giving the company more resources to invest in new services. But government officials should not accept that argument without conducting a thorough investigation into what effect a merger between the country’s two largest cable companies would have on the media and the Internet.

headline: A First Stab at a Prudent City Budget
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday released a preliminary budget, his first, that surprised some fiscal watchdogs with its moderation and caution. It doesn’t break the bank on “progressive” agenda items. It restores $1 billion to a depleted trust fund for retiree health benefits and doubles, to $600 million, reserves set aside each year for unexpected shortfalls. The nonpartisan Citizens Budget Commission called it a “double dose of good news” that projected revenues are higher than expected, and that Mr. de Blasio is proposing to sock some money away.

headline: For New Air Force Secretary, a Baptism by Fire
text: WASHINGTON — Deborah Lee James had been Air Force secretary for less than three weeks when the email crash-landed in her inbox.

headline: For Comcast, Daring Deals to Expand Its Reach Across Industries
text: Three weeks ago, Comcast unveiled plans to build an addition to its headquarters, a gleaming steel-and-glass tower designed by the renowned architect Norman Foster that will cast a shadow over downtown Philadelphia.

headline: A Russian Protest Zone Where Almost No One Registers a Complaint
text: KHOSTA, Russia — In the small park here that has been designated by the Russian authorities as the official protest zone of the Sochi Winter Olympics, the only mobilization in sight on a sunny afternoon this week was a small armada of strollers, being pushed by a cadre of young mothers.

headline: More Engagement With India
text: The decision by the United States to have its ambassador to India, Nancy Powell, meet Narendra Modi, a star of the country’s Bharatiya Janata opposition party, reversed a long estrangement. It was a pragmatic step in engaging with India and the controversial and troubling politician who could well become the next prime minister after elections in May.

headline: Crowds Gather for Tanaka and Jeter, Who Is in a Joking Mood
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Derek Jeter pulled up to a line of autograph seekers, rolled down the window of his cobalt blue Mercedes sedan and, after being asked a question, said the two words that thousands of young women would love to hear him say to them.

headline: In Debate Over Paying for Pre-K, Little Agreement Aside From the Goal
text: Paul A. Dyster, the eldest of 10 children, spent many of his weekends as a teenager in western New York State moving tiny furniture around classrooms because his mother was an advocate and organizer of prekindergarten programs. “I had it pounded into me from an early age that this was important,” Mr. Dyster, 59, said. Now Bill de Blasio, the mayor of New York City, has proposed that the city be permitted to tax the income of rich people to pay for full-day prekindergarten classes.

headline: Kim Basinger at Ralph Lauren
text: A whirling blizzard and calf-deep snowdrifts did little to deter guests on the final morning of New York Fashion Week. Shrugging off puffers and stamping their snow boots, the full house at Ralph Lauren’s 10 a.m. show settled in under flattering chandelier light. Kim Basinger, seemingly ageless in an ivory and black blouse and black trousers, was aptly impressed.

headline: Let the Marketing of Derek Jeter’s Farewell Begin
text: The Derek Jeter farewell tour is coming, with the inevitable merchandising: caps and T-shirts with a Jeter-centric logo; dirt from his shortstop area packaged in vials; autographs; signed bases, balls, home plates and, well, almost anything else imaginable.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 13, 2014
Prominent Opposition Leader in Venezuela Is Blamed for Unrest
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Top government officials on Thursday blamed a prominent opposition leader for unrest that resulted in three deaths, amid growing tension over antigovernment protests.

headline: Brownback Leads Kansas in Sharp Right Turn
text: TOPEKA, Kan. — Sam Brownback took office as Kansas’ chief executive more than three years ago, promising a conservative revolution. By all accounts he has kept his promise.

headline: Heading Into Break, Talk of Anthony’s Next Act
text: NEW ORLEANS — Three years ago, Carmelo Anthony was the dominant figure during the N.B.A.’s All-Star weekend. The Denver Nuggets were in the process of completing a deal that would send Anthony to the Knicks (for no small price), and members of the news media formed concentric circles around Anthony, several cameras deep. A superstar was on the move, sending seismic tremors across the league.

headline: Wendy Davis, Texas Candidate, Offers Nuance on Abortion View
text: HOUSTON — Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator who became a national figure by filibustering abortion restrictions last year, told a Dallas newspaper that she would have supported one of those restrictions — a ban on abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy — had the bill been written differently and deferred to a woman and her doctor in making the decision.

headline: In Terrorism Case, New Path to Testimony From 9/11 Suspect
text: Lawyers for a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden moved closer on Thursday to being able to use Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, as a defense witness to rebut the government’s terrorism case against their client, Sulaiman Abu Ghaith.

headline: What’s Next, Synchronized Slopestyle?
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Having covered the last six Winter Olympics, and now one Summer Olympics in Sochi, I felt quite safe in saying that these Games, be they frozen or thawed, did not need a team luge event.

headline: Federal Agency and New York State Are in Accord Over $8 Billion Medicaid Waiver
text: The Obama administration has agreed “in principle” to grant an $8 billion Medicaid adjustment for New York State that could help stabilize some hospitals in Brooklyn and would reconfigure the delivery of health care there and throughout the state, state officials said on Thursday.

headline: With Urgency, David Wright Is Waiting to Win
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Growing up, David Wright said, he idolized Derek Jeter. Jeter was polished. He was a winner. He played the game the right way. He played shortstop for the best team in baseball. He was who every high school player wanted to be.

headline: Off the Runway: Last Day
text: Scenes from the final day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Rude Awakenings of Middle Age
text: Does time erode everything it touches? This painful question lies at the heart of “Dinner With Friends,” Donald Margulies’s delicate-hued, Pulitzer Prize-winning drama about two married couples who come to a crossroads in their long friendship when one pair breaks up.

headline: Phrase From Virgil
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — My, what a surprise! I really wasn’t expecting this, and I’ll bet you weren’t, either. Bruce Haight is back, and he has something special to ask us. If we all give him an enthusiastic “Yes,” this may be the first mass wedding the Internet has ever seen.

headline: Off the Runway | Before the Show
text: Behind the scenes of New York Fashion Week fall 2014.

text: New York Times fashion reporters and editors describe Day 8 of New York Fashion Week in 140 characters.

text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Kendall Jenner before (left) and after (right) makeup by Francois Nars and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Indian Publisher Withdraws Book, Stoking Fears of Nationalist Pressure
text: NEW DELHI — In a fight with a major company, a frail 84-year-old retired headmaster would seem to be the David to India’s publishing Goliath, Penguin Books India.

headline: Long-Lived Greatness
text: Derek Jeter not only has one of the highest batting averages among his peers, but also has shown extraordinary longevity.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Fall 2014 RTW
text: New York

headline: Thai Police Clear Areas of Protesters as Their Numbers Ebb
text: Hundreds of Thai police officers on Friday began reclaiming intersections in Bangkok that a dwindling protest movement seized several weeks ago.

headline: What to Watch at the Olympics: Friday
text: ALPINE SKIING Ted Ligety, a giant slalom specialist, is among the favorites in the super combined. NBC, 8 p.m.

headline: Driver of Stolen Truck Arraigned in Bus Driver’s Death
text: A man who stole a truck after a night of drinking, and hit a city bus, killing the bus driver, was arraigned in Manhattan criminal court on Thursday night on six charges, including vehicular homicide, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said.

headline: Sales of Iranian Crude Oil Rose in January
text: Sales of Iranian crude oil rose by 100,000 barrels a day in January, to 1.32 million, the International Energy Agency reported on Thursday in its monthly survey, offering what appeared to be a glimpse at the initial impact of the temporary nuclear agreement that eased some of the Western sanctions against Iran.

headline: Short Track
text: On a track crowded with skaters, these racers have to accelerate in the turns and pass when the moment is just right.

headline: In Living Color
text: The relationship between fashion and art is constantly evolving. Right now, many designers are collectively referencing a Pop aesthetic, from vivid cubism to the giddy kitsch of the Memphis group.

headline: The Writer's Room
text: Upstairs, downstairs, in a corner, at a desk, on the bed, with a view of trees, water, the street, the sky. Five writers, who all publish new books this year, explain how the right space can unlock the mind and let the words flow.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New by Chloe Sevigny vs. Elaine Stritch
text: (PHOTOGRAPHS FROM TOP: COURTESY OF MAD DECENT; COURTESY PHAIDON PRESS; COURTESY OF CHRISTIAN DIOR PARFUMS; COURTESY ALEXANDER MCQUEEN; JUAN C. LOPEZ ESPANTALEON/ZABAR’S AND COMPANY INC)

headline: Phoebe Philo’s Prophetic Fashion
text: At Céline, boundary-breaking fashion is secondary to the meaning behind the clothes.

headline: Portrait of a Lady
text: Ginevra Elkann’s classic beauty and old-world charm might be an inheritance from her grandmother Marella Agnelli, but her Roman apartment reflects her life as a busy, modern woman — producing films, running a museum and taking care of a young family.

headline: North American Leaders Urged to Restore Monarch Butterfly’s Habitat
text: MEXICO CITY — Hoping to focus attention on the plight of the monarch butterfly at a North American summit meeting next week, a group of prominent scientists and writers urged the leaders of Mexico, the United States and Canada to commit to restoring the habitat that supports the insect’s extraordinary migration across the continent.

headline: Tax Subsidies and the Incentive to Work
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

text: Question:

text: domineer •\ˌdä-mə-ˈnir\• verb

headline: Facing Bulls, Nets Stumble in Final Game Before All-Star Break
text: CHICAGO — At the close of 2013, less than two months ago, the Nets seemed to be on the brink of implosion. They had dealt with issues of futility (losing 12 of 15 games during one stretch), absurdity (their first-year coach, Jason Kidd, was fined for spilling a soda on the court on purpose) and personality (Kidd banished his top assistant, Lawrence Frank, from the bench).

headline: Corrections: February 14, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: U.S. to Play Mexico Before World Cup
text: The United States will face Mexico in Glendale, Ariz., on April 2 as both teams prepare for the World Cup.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 9 P.M. (13) NATIONAL THEATER: 50 YEARS ON STAGE In 1963, the National Theater in London raised its curtain with Laurence Olivier as its first artistic director. Eight hundred productions later, the organization celebrated its 50th anniversary in November with an evening of live performances and archival footage, overseen by its current artistic director, Nicholas Hytner, and presented here by “Great Performances.” Highlights include excerpts from “Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead,” with Benedict Cumberbatch; “The History Boys,” with its playwright, Alan Bennett, and two of its original stars, James Corden and Dominic Cooper; “Mourning Becomes Electra,” with Helen Mirren and Tim Pigott-Smith; “Bedroom Farce,” with Penelope Wilton; Judi Dench, above, singing “Send In the Clowns” from “A Little Night Music”; and archival scenes from “Hay Fever,” with Maggie Smith, and “Richard III,” with Ian McKellen. Joan Plowright, married for nearly 30 years to Olivier, recreates her Saint Joan on the stage of the Old Vic, home of the original National Theater.

headline: Ralph Waite, Depression-Era Patriarch in ‘The Waltons,’ Dies at 85
text: Ralph Waite, a multifaceted actor who became etched in television history as the craggy-faced, big-hearted patriarch of a rustic Depression-era clan on the popular 1970s dramatic series “The Waltons,” died on Thursday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Mets Name Radio Team
text: Howie Rose and Josh Lewin will return as the Mets’ radio team as the games shift to WOR-AM from WFAN-AM and FM. The announcement that they will still call the Mets took a while; the team revealed its move to WOR in November. The Yankees moved to WFAN from WCBS-AM.

headline: Federal Judge Overturns Virginia’s Same-Sex Marriage Ban
text: A federal judge on Thursday evening declared that Virginia’s ban on same-sex marriage was unconstitutional, in the strongest legal reversal yet of restrictive marriage amendments that exist throughout the South.

headline: When Senator Kefauver Inspired the Scripts
text: A sonorous introduction by a United States senator, location shots of a major American city taken over by “the syndicate,” didactic demonstrations of criminal power and an action-packed denouement in which the vaguely Latin vice lord is dispatched by a representative of the law: “The Miami Story” (1954), briskly directed by Fred F. Sears, a prolific specialist in juvenile delinquency scare films and sci-fi cheapsters — and a new manufactured-on-demand release from Sony Pictures — is a classic example of the Kefauver policier.

headline: A Constant Battle Against the Sale of Bodies in Bihar
text: The women’s rights activists Ruchira Gupta and Gloria Steinem are keeping a diary of their travels throughout India as they meet the country’s young feminists, writers and thought leaders (previous posts are here and here). In this installation for India Ink, Ms. Gupta and Ms. Steinem visit Patna, Bihar state’s capital, and Forbesgunge, a small town on the border of India and Nepal, in Bihar.

headline: China Celebrates First Gold Medals of Sochi
text: China is celebrating its first gold medals of the Sochi Olympics after two dramatic victories on Thursday in the women’s 500-meter short-track speedskating and the women’s 1,000-meter long-track speedskating events.

headline: A Surprise Swiss Skiing Victory as U.S. Stars Are Shut Out
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The medal podium after Friday’s men’s super combined was a smorgasbord of countries, upbringings and ski racing pedigrees, with one constant: Each racer was surprised by where he finished, and yet, wholly content with the result.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing, Feb. 14, 2014
text: Use the following question for practice using transition words.

headline: France and Germany Lead Euro Zone to Higher Growth
text: PARIS — The euro zone economy grew slightly faster than expected in the last three months of 2013, an official report showed on Friday, bringing welcome news for the global economy amid signs of slowing in the United States and China.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Winter Offensive Takes Toll on East Coast
text: In “Winter Offensive Takes Toll on East Coast,” Marc Santora writes about the latest winter storm to pound the eastern U.S.

headline: The All-or-Nothing Marriage
text: ARE marriages today better or worse than they used to be?

headline: Do Kids Need Recess?
text: Recess is one period in the day that many students don’t want to miss. Yet with all the pressures on increasing test scores, schools have cut back on the amount of time that kids get to be kids. Plus, teachers sometimes use recess as a privilege that can be taken away if students don’t behave. Of course, children hate to lose recess — but should the rest of us worry?

headline: A Panda’s Death Raises Questions About Its Treatment
text: The death of a panda in a zoo in central China has raised questions about whether its living conditions and treatment there may have contributed to its sudden illness.

headline: 2 Koreas to Proceed With Reunions of Families Separated by War
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Friday that it would honor its agreement to allow hundreds of older Koreans separated by the war on the peninsula six decades ago to reunite with their long-lost relatives, officials here said.

headline: King Will Attend Closing Ceremony
text: WASHINGTON — Billie Jean King, who withdrew from the presidential delegation at the opening of the Winter Olympics for family reasons, will represent the United States at the closing ceremony on Feb. 23, the White House announced Friday.

headline: The Self-Reflecting Pool
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Late last year, a designer and a geographer who met at M.I.T. revealed that they’d spent much of 2013 mapping every single swimming pool in Los Angeles — 43,123 of them, to be exact. Their satellite photos documented all the little aquamarine ovals and rectangles in a huge 74-book project called “The Big Atlas of L.A. Pools.” Though the cultural conversation mostly revolved around how unsettlingly easy it was for them to locate and discover personal details relating to each pool’s owner — address, property value, even sex-offender status — I found myself fantasizing instead about disappearing, and using those pools to do it.

headline: Times Minute | California's Drought
text: President Obama visits California to review the damage from the drought. Also on the Minute, anti-government protests in Venezuela escalate and Season 2 of "House of Cards" premieres on Netflix.

text: In the Video

headline: Britain’s Welfare Queen
text: LONDON — The British queen is down to her last pennies. Well, actually, her last millions of pennies.

headline: Gay Rights Activists in Beijing Protest for Their Russian Comrades
text: A small group of gay rights activists gathered outside the Russian Embassy in Beijing on Valentine’s Day to protest Russia’s antigay laws.

headline: Flooded Britain
text: But Brits remain stoic in the face of adversity.

headline: Jos. A. Bank, Trying to Fend Off Takeover Bid, Plans to Buy Parent of Eddie Bauer
text: Updated, 9:06 p.m. |After months of trying to fend off a takeover bid from Men’s Wearhouse, Jos. A. Bank Clothiers has found another merger partner. But the men’s wear retailer left the door wide open for its unwanted suitor.

headline: Footage of Margot Fonteyn Rediscovered
text: London — The prince walks hesitantly around the princess’s bed, then leans down and kisses her on the lips. The princess slowly sits up, her large dark eyes opening in wonder as the camera lingers upon her face.

headline: For Snowbound Elderly in Suburbs, a Season of Isolation
text: YONKERS — On Thursday morning, Tambudzai Marino, a nurse who makes house calls for the Visiting Nurse Service of Westchester, was weaving and skidding her car around icy, slushy mounds on clogged highways and unplowed side streets, even braving the hills of this Hudson River city, then getting stuck and reversing gears and finding flatter routes, finally slogging by foot along the last quarter-mile. All so she could change bandages on Selwyn Weston’s ulcerated right foot.

headline: Customer Service, Chinese Style
text: I have never written a bad online review of a business. If something about a company’s product or service seems out of character to me, I try to speak directly to management, because that’s how I like customers to deal with my business.

headline: The Pitfalls of Publishing Books in India
text: MUMBAI — In withdrawing “The Hindus: An Alternative History,” by the American scholar Wendy Doniger, Penguin Books India joined a long line of publishers that have pulled contentious books from the Indian market — a decision that they say has more to do with systemic problems in the country than a lack of commitment to freedom of expression.

headline: The Milk Carton Kids Tune Out an Auto-Tuned World
text: There is something almost unnatural about the mellifluous harmonies of the Milk Carton Kids, something freakish. It’s hard to believe that two people can sync to each other like that. They did not, after all, spring from the same womb like the Everly Brothers or even from the same corner of Queens like Simon and Garfunkel. In fact, Joey Ryan and Kenneth Pattengale did not find each other until fairly recently, after they were already performing as independent artists, a yin and a yang seeking each other out through the chaos.

headline: Morning Agenda: Jos. A. Bank Makes a Move for Eddie Bauer Parent
text: JOS. A. BANK TO BUY PARENT OF EDDIE BAUER  |  Jos. A. Bank Clothiers said Friday morning that it had agreed to buy the parent company of Eddie Bauer in a deal valued at $825 million, including cash and debt. The purchase of Eddie Bauer, which comes amid the monthslong merger battle between Jos. A. Bank and Men’s Wearhouse, will be done with a combination of $564 million in cash and approximately 4.7 million new shares of common stock of Jos. A. Bank.

headline: Stupidity in Economic Discourse
text: Jonathan Gruber is mad as hell, and he’s not going to take it anymore. The eminent health care economist and health reform architect is annoyed at Casey Mulligan’s latest, which misrepresents Gruber’s views; mine too.

headline: Daily Report: In Takeover Bid, Comcast Seeks to Stay Ahead of Changing Technology Landscape
text: Three weeks ago, Comcast revealed plans to build an addition to its headquarters, a gleaming steel-and-glass tower designed by the renowned architect Norman Foster that will cast a shadow over downtown Philadelphia, Michael J. de la Merced and Bill Carter report.

headline: ThyssenKrupp Shows Signs of a Turnaround
text: LONDON — ThyssenKrupp, the venerable but troubled German industrial conglomerate, produced some evidence on Friday that its management’s turnaround plan was working.

headline: Airbus Buys German Bank for In-House Finance Unit
text: PARIS — The Airbus Group, the parent company of the European plane maker, said Friday that it would acquire Salzburg München Bank, a small German private lender, to develop into an in-house bank providing loans to suppliers and other small-business partners.

headline: 1914: A Song For Valentine’s Day
text: A hundred years ago, The New York Herald published a song for Valentine’s Day by Clinton Scollard:

headline: Occidental to Spin Off California Division
text: Occidental Petroleum said on Friday that it planned to spin off its California business, breaking itself in two as it looks to narrow its operational focus.

headline: Deadlock Remains and Aid Crisis Mounts as 2nd Round of Syria Talks Nears End
text: GENEVA — Frustrations mounted here on Friday as the second round of Syrian peace talks drew near a close without breaking a weeklong deadlock. The meeting’s sponsors, Russia and the United States, traded barbs, and American officials said they were developing new policy options to respond to the violence and humanitarian crisis in Syria that have only escalated during the talks.

headline: A Valentine’s Day Diversion: Blame it on Biology
text: Here’s a brief Valentine’s Day diversion. “Blame it on Biology,” one of the songs on my first CD, explores the deep, even biological, roots of the cycles of miscommunication, argument and reconciliation that are part of most romantic relationships. I built a video version in the early stages of yesterday’s snowstorm, focusing on bird courtship behavior:

headline: Auction of Telecom Spectrum Raises Nearly $10 Billion for Government
text: NEW DELHI — Two years after the Supreme Court canceled the licenses of 22 telecom operators who received them at below-market prices, the Indian government raised nearly $10 billion in an auction of telecommunications spectrum for voice and data services, well above its initial goal of $1.8 billion.

headline: As War for Web Messaging Users Grows, Rakuten Buys Viber for $900 Million
text: Updated, 7:25 p.m. He recently lost the pitcher Masahiro Tanaka to the New York Yankees, but Hiroshi Mikitani, the billionaire owner of the Japanese e-commerce giant Rakuten, may now have found some solace.

headline: Hanyu Wins Men’s Figure Skating Gold
text: When Yuzuru Hanyu of Japan crashed to the ice on a quadruple jump, it seemed that the gold medal had slipped from his grasp. He fell again on another jump, and his hopes dimmed further.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Happy Days?
text: Clouds that looked like fluffy little lambs hung over the Marc Jacobs show, the audience seated beneath on mushroom-shaped stools. The soundtrack on this final day of New York Fashion Week endlessly repeated the same words: “Happy days are here again.”

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the New York Fall/Winter 2014 Women’s Shows

New York Fall 2014: Elements | Character
text: A thematic visual diary of New York Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.

headline: Italy’s Premier Leaves Post Amid Dispute
text: ROME — Prime Minister Enrico Letta of Italy resigned on Friday, the day after his own Democratic Party voted to replace him with the party’s new leader, Matteo Renzi, the 39-year-old mayor of Florence.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Marc Jacobs Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Popcast: Rediscovering New Age
text: Q: Does the return of new age music mean that punk is really dead, or is it the new punk?

headline: The Tom Perkins Theory of Taxation and Representation
text: This time, Tom Perkins knew he was courting controversy.

headline: Emma Wolfe, Mayor de Blasio’s Secret Weapon
text: You helped run Bill de Blasio’s campaign, which made a lot of promises. How does he carry those forward now?  Bill has a laser focus on addressing the city’s inequality crisis. Period. That’s what’s going to animate him and animate the team. That was our campaign message, and we did not swerve from it. And we were elected on it. Now we just have to fulfill the mandate.

headline: The Existential Anguish of the Tattoo
text: Somewhere between the release of “Reality Bites” and the closing of MTV’s sports bureau, my generation got tattoos. We were not the first Americans to do so, but we were the first to do it en masse. Now, two decades later, we are becoming the first to carry them into middle age. It turns out tattoos are permanent, even when little else is.

headline: Malfoy Is Still Scaring Kids
text: Also, Johnny Cash’s fallback career and Judge Hodgman’s stamp of disapproval.

headline: Tony Rice, Guitar Hero
text: One morning last September, the red carpet was laid in Raleigh, N.C., for the 2013 International Bluegrass Music Awards, which had moved there from Nashville to escape country music’s shadow. The city’s bronze statue of Sir Walter Raleigh was newly adorned with a banjo. A few miles from the convention center, I was on my phone, trying to find out if Tony Rice, the legendary flatpick guitarist, would show up for his induction into the Bluegrass Hall of Fame. “Tony has canceled a lot of dates over the last decade,”

headline: Fearing a Shootout at the E.R. Corral
text: My emergency unit handled a man who had been shot in the leg in the early hours of the morning. The trauma surgeons refused to have him transferred to the ward for wound management because they believed the victim would be pursued by his assailants, thereby posing a safety risk to staff members and patients. The police in the E.R. declined to pat down the injured man for weapons, as they were not legally empowered to do so. The man was retained in emergency for 12 hours. The emergency unit, which has an open-door policy for all comers 24/7, would most likely be the first place that assailants would look for an injured man. Are there ethical ramifications with the transfer of violent risk? JOSEPH TING, BRISBANE, AUSTRALIA

headline: Who Made That Pop-Up Ad?
text: When Brendan Eich set out to liven up the Internet in the spring of 1995, online ads were always banners: branded rectangles tucked into a home page. But over a 10-day stretch that May, Eich, a Netscape programmer and an amateur gymnast, worked up a new way to program on the web. Where pages had been inert and clogged with text, they now had wiggle room, and it was thanks to Eich’s language — called JavaScript. Elements could slide around or blink in response to user input. New windows could pop open on their own.

headline: What to Wear to My Gay Wedding
text: The last time I wore a bow in my hair, I was 10 years old. It was 1961, and my cousin was getting married. My mother insisted I wear the bow and a tight frilly dress. The crinoline slip scratched my thighs. When I sneezed, the belt buckle broke.

headline: Reply All: The 2.2.14 Issue
text: THE SUPER BOWL OF SPORTS GAMBLING

headline: At Open-Mike Night, Anything Goes
text: When the artist Jen Miller first started hosting “Reverend Jen’s Anti-Slam” in the mid-’90s, 100 people on a given night might have experienced anything from a comedy act to a primal-scream interpretive dance. These days, at a smaller venue on the Lower East Side called Old Man Hustle, the pool of audience members and participants might be 30 (though many now know one another). Miller, who considers her open-mike nights “the last vestiges of bohemianism in downtown New York,” attributes the decline to gentrification and the Internet, where people can more easily get their fix of performance art by up-and-comers. “There isn’t the incentive that we had in the ’90s to get out the door and actually do something.” But for Daniel Gallant, director of the Nuyorican Poets Cafe, which introduced open mikes in 1973, social media has been a boon: “The performances generate more viral activity online,” he says. Amy Kellner

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Stake in Malone’s Liberty Interactive
text: Jana Partners, the $8 billion hedge fund run by Barry Rosenstein, has taken a 5.5 percent stake in John C. Malone’s Liberty Interactive, which owns the home-shopping channel QVC and digital brands including TripAdvisor, Evite and Bodybuilding.com.

text: 1939: ‘Pope’ of Nudist Sect Dies

text: After five dormant years, a mystery ailment returns — with a vengeance.
