text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “RoboCop,” “Winter’s Tale” and “About Last Night.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Global Warming, Winter Weather and the Olympics – Leading Climate Scientists Weigh In
text: Updated below | There’s a noteworthy letter in today’s edition of the journal Science, titled “Global Warming and This Winter’s Cold Weather,” that aims to cut through the flood of overwrought assertions about recent Northern Hemisphere winter weather in the context of global warming.

headline: Rent Check
text: Condos, condos, condos. Sometimes they seem to be all that anybody talks about.

headline: A Parodist Who Calls Himself Hanksy
text: This is a story about art in the age of social media — about anonymity and self-promotion, about feral cats and viral cat videos.

text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "About Last Night."

headline: ‘A Classic Case of Bullying’ on the Dolphins, Report Finds
text: On the Miami Dolphins’ practice field, players simulated sexual acts as they taunted a teammate about his sister. In the team’s hallways and meeting rooms, racist epithets and homophobic language flowed. One coach gave an offensive lineman an inflatable male doll as part of his Christmas stocking stuffer. Many of the Dolphins knew, but did not say or do anything.

headline: Snapshots of Hanksy’s Short-Lived Work
text: Hanksy’s start as a street artist began when he downloaded a Banksy painting of a rat holding a paint roller and added an image of the actor Tom Hanks. He mashed the two together, pasted the cutout on a wall on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, signed it Hanksy and took a photograph of it to share. The image was an overnight hit on social media, and Mr. Hanks liked it, too.

headline: Movie Review: 'Winter's Tale'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Winter's Tale."

headline: Tom Perkins, Defender of the 1% Once Again
text: Like many semifamous people, Tom Perkins has publicly wondered how he will be remembered. As the venture capitalist who helped start Silicon Valley? As the extremely rich guy who built the most awesome sailing yacht of the era? Or even — although this is a long shot — as the author of the supremely trashy novel “Sex and the Single Zillionaire?”

headline: Movie Review: 'RoboCop'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "RoboCop."

headline: Today in Small Business: Weather!
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today?

headline: Police Fatally Shoot 8 After What China Calls a Terrorist Attack
text: HONG KONG — The police in Xinjiang, the ethnically divided region in far western China, fatally shot eight people on Friday after what the state-run news media described as an attack by assailants armed with bombs made from gas cylinders. Three other attackers died in an explosion they set off, the reports said.

headline: New Guests (and Actors) Headed to ‘Downton Abbey’
text: Good thing there are so many rooms at Downton Abbey, because that famous (if fictitious) Yorkshire estate will be receiving a few new visitors in its fifth season, which is currently being filmed in Britain.

headline: Friends of Bill de Blasio
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio seemed perplexed on Thursday when the Q. and A. at a news conference about snow turned into a blizzard of tough questions about why he had called a high-ranking police official to ask about a friend and supporter of his who had been arrested.

headline: Beware the End-of-Year 401(k) Match
text: AOL’s chief executive, Tim Armstrong, drew plenty of attention earlier this month when he seemed to attribute a change in the company’s 401(k) plan in part to a couple of employees whose infants required expensive care. But what was mostly lost in the discussion was just how much it would cost employees if every employer tried to do what AOL did.

headline: What I Love | Anna Trigiani
text: A visit to the West Village townhouse of the best-selling author and movie director.

headline: Adriana Trigiani Follows the Map of Her Heart
text: Adriana Trigiani considers herself extraordinarily lucky. She owns a four-story brick 1838 townhouse in the West Village, where she has lived since 1996. Her duplex apartment has a parlor floor with high ceilings, two fireplaces, period molding and a lower level that opens onto a private garden. She rents the upstairs duplex to her best friend, Michael Patrick King, a former “Sex and the City” writer and a creator of the TV show “2 Broke Girls.”

headline: Comcast Deal Shakes Up Adviser Rankings
text: Comcast’s $45.2 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable has shaken up a ranking of the biggest deal makers.

headline: Image of the Day: February 14
text: A man delivering roses on Valentine’s Day in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: The Valentine’s Day Treaty
text: Elijah Steele knew he wasn’t authorized to negotiate an Indian treaty. As a lawyer, a judge, a former Wisconsin state senator, a founding settler of Siskiyou County, Calif., and the agent of Indian affairs for the Northern District of California, he was well aware of the protocols established by the United States Constitution. But Washington, D.C., was far away, and the nation was in the grip of civil war. And besides, on Feb. 14, 1864, Valentine’s Day, several hundred Klamath Basin Indians, much to his surprise, were camped outside his home in Yreka.

headline: Big Ticket | Two Floors of Flourishes for $23.4 Million
text: A duplex penthouse with a pair of private terraces at 135 East 79th Street, a 19-story brick and limestone condominium developed by the Brodsky Organization, sold for $23,419,750 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Glorious Vienna, Warts and All
text: Carnegie Hall’s imminent festival, Vienna, City of Dreams, promises to be one of the most lavish in its rich history: a three-week citywide celebration with more than 50 events, anchored by five programs from the Vienna Philharmonic and two concert operas from that orchestra’s parent company, the Vienna State Opera, at Carnegie. A broad representation of Viennese music from the 18th to the 21st centuries will range from Strauss family waltzes and other froth to those cathartically harrowing operas Richard Strauss’s “Salome” and Alban Berg’s “Wozzeck.”

headline: A Reader’s Hunting Guide
text: The search engine BookFinder.com has issued its annual list of the 100 most sought-after titles currently out of print, and no bookshelf could possibly offer a more diverse selection.

headline: Futuristic Thrillers
text: ANNIHILATION

headline: Times Minute | Why Fallon Moved Up
text: Also on the Minute, a novel solution to China's pollution problem and can chocolate really hurt dogs?

headline: Inside the List
text: The Doctor Will Thrill You Now: Like a lot of brand-name novelists, Robin Cook drops a new book every year or two — in Cook’s case, medical thrillers with punchy, ominous titles like “Outbreak,” “Terminal” or “Contagion” that invariably land on the list. His latest, “Cell” (new at No. 11), is his 28th hardcover best seller since “Coma” made his reputation in 1977. Cook started his career as a practicing doctor, but eventually devoted himself more and more to writing, where the malpractice premiums are presumably lower. From the start, he has applied himself studiously to his craft. “It’s easier to get a book published if it’s going to be a best seller,” he told an interviewer in 1977, “so I went back to some old New York Times best-seller lists and tried to find books that came from theretofore unknown writers, to try to determine what kind of book had the best chances of making the list. I found the mystery-thriller genre seemed to do this best.” If that approach seems more robotic than inspired, well, so can Cook’s prose — “Cell” may be the first thriller to open with an entire paragraph about insulin molecules. (“Rapidly infiltrating the veins, they rushed headlong into the heart, to be pumped out through the arteries.”) Then again, Cook doesn’t make great claims for himself as a writer. “I’m a storyteller,” he told the CBS reporter Don Dahler earlier this month. “I have never been tempted to wear a turtleneck — big turtleneck, white turtleneck. I don’t drink.”

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE DISPENSABLE NATION: American Foreign Policy in Retreat,  by Vali Nasr. (Anchor, $16.) This is an astute, nonideological analysis of the weaknesses of United States foreign policy under President Obama. Nasr, a former senior adviser to Ambassador Richard C. Holbrooke, sheds light on the infighting between the White House and the State Department, and argues that, from North Africa to Afghanistan and Pakistan, diplomatic efforts have been crippled by the administration’s fear of political reprisals and the specter of terrorism.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: DEPT. OF SPECULATION,  by Jenny Offill. (Knopf, $22.95.) Building its story from fragments, observations, meditations and different points of view, Offill’s cannily paced second novel charts the course of a marriage.

headline: Times Minute | Why Fallon Moved Up
text: In the Video

headline: Women of a Certain Era
text: “I find life quite impossible,” wrote Nancy Cunard, the English heiress famous in the 1920s for her fashionable excess, “as I cannot enjoy a thing without carrying it to all the extremes and then nearly dying of the reaction.” She wasn’t the only one blowing past her limits during that risky era, but as Judith Mackrell puts it in “Flappers: Six Women of a Dangerous Generation,” she was an audacious female forerunner preceding a “collective surge in expectation.” Women on the verge demanded more from life than marriage and motherhood. Joining Cunard in her restless experimentation were the outrageous actress Tallulah Bankhead, the brazen aristocrat Diana Cooper, the electrifying jazz dancerJosephine Baker, the Polish-Russian painter Tamara de Lempicka and America’s über-flapper, Zelda Fitzgerald. They shared an edgy ambition and a taste for immoderation that led them crashing through the public psyche, sometimes brilliantly, sometimes not, but always on toward emancipation — or at least on to the next great party. As Mackrell demonstrates so elegantly, their collective defiance redefined the feminine possible.

headline: To Kill a King
text: In London last year, workers on Crossrail, a huge construction project tunneling a new rail network under the city, made a macabre discovery below Charterhouse Square: a burial pit dating from the period of the Black Death. Archaeologists were ecstatic. Such bones could reveal, one of them explained, “a snapshot of the population from the 14th century” — clues about what people ate and how they lived as well as how they died.

headline: Child, Slave, Soldier
text: In March 2012, a small American charity based in San Diego posted a video online about the Ugandan rebel Joseph Kony, leader of the Lord’s Resistance Army. Within days, the video had 100 million hits, making it one of the most viral videos in history.

headline: Where Was I?
text: A memoir of amnesia is a paradox. To write an autobiography, one must be able to consult one’s past. But what happens when that history is obliterated? The experience of such loss and the hard-won reclamation of identity form the bases of two new books. One is by a young man whose amnesia was a side effect of a prescribed medication. The other is by a young woman who sustained a devastating head wound.

headline: Bodily Harm
text: When she surfaced in Harry Bingham’s “Talking to the Dead,” Fiona Griffiths was a rookie on the South Wales police force who had more psychological quirks — including a disconcerting habit of spending quality time in the morgue — than most of the head cases she met in the line of duty. But the intensity she brought to the job made her a most intriguing, if peculiar, detective.

headline: It’s the Economy
text: Americans have struggled mightily since the nation’s birth to overcome racial prejudice. Recently, as symbolized by President Obama’s ascendancy and his message of racial reconciliation, we have basically succeeded and are now healing from our racial wounds. Or so the story goes. In “A Dreadful Deceit,” the distinguished historian Jacqueline Jones vehemently rejects this redemptive and self-congratulatory narrative. She believes that the country’s racial problems have little to do with racism and everything to do with economic exploitation. And, she claims, we have not even begun to come to terms with this.

headline: Ad Infinitum
text: Halfway into his new book, “Our Mathematical Universe,” the M.I.T. physicist Max Tegmark describes his “Dr. Jekyll/Mr. Hyde Strategy”: During the day he would do respectable work on mainstream topics in cosmology, but at night he would “transform into the evil Mr. Hyde” and indulge in writing “wacky” papers on “the ultimate nature of reality.”

headline: The Prophets’ Prophet
text: Look at the famous pictures of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. marching on Selma, Ala., in 1965. In one of them you’ll see a man in big glasses two people to King’s left who looks halfway between Leon Trotsky and Santa Claus. That’s Abraham Joshua Heschel. From his perch at the Jewish Theological Seminary of New York, the Warsaw-born rabbi cast a long shadow over American Jewry, especially its Conservative variant, during the quarter-­century after World War II. He also became a byword for American Jewish social-justice activism — most of all for the alliance between Jews and blacks.

headline: Skills Practice | Cause and Effect
text: The Winter Olympics are supposed to be all about snow, ice and bulky parkas, right?

headline: Snowbound
text: It happens all the time in children’s literature: Beloved parents die, and their sons and daughters have to come to terms with their loss. In Karen Foxlee’s “Ophelia and the Marvelous Boy,” this premise is explored in an original and fantastical manner, as Foxlee (“The Anatomy of Wings,” “The Midnight Dress”) deftly borrows and transforms elements from Hans Christian Andersen’s “The Snow Queen.”

headline: A Port in the Storm
text: Most of Rodman Philbrick’s new middle-grade novel, “Zane and the Hurricane,” is set in a battered green canoe floating on the oily sea that covered New Orleans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. The story is narrated by Zane Dupree, a mixed-race 12-year-old boy living contentedly in New Hampshire until his mother’s fateful discovery of the sole living relative on his father’s side, Miss Trissy.

headline: Kerry Says Obama Wants New Options for Syria Strife
text: BEIJING — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday that President Obama had asked aides to develop new policy options to deal with the deteriorating situation in Syria.

headline: Varieties of Loss
text: How does one teach children about the violence of history? How does one teach them to confront loss in the present day? Three new books take on these challenging tasks in the context of African-­American lives.

headline: Being Green
text: “Grasshopper Jungle” is two for one. On one level, it is a darkly comic story about the end of the world. The book’s narrator and protagonist — 16-year-old Austin Szerba, of the fictional town of Ealing, Iowa — accidentally unleashes an infestation of six-foot-tall praying mantises, products of a scientific experiment gone kookily awry. With exoskeletons “as tough as the exterior hull of an aircraft carrier” and razor-sharp barbs on their arms, the bugs are killing machines invulnerable to bullets, and they set about devouring humanity. The praying mantises are perpetually horny as well as ravenous, able to smell a mate four miles away, breeding ceaselessly while slaughtering everything in their path. The earth is consumed by implacable forces and mindless appetite.

headline: Big Crowds for De La Soul’s Online Buffet
text: De La Soul may have underestimated the public’s interest in its music, or at least in getting it free. On Thursday, the hip-hop group announced a plan to offer seven of their albums for free downloading for a limited time, from 11 a.m. on Friday to Saturday at noon, Eastern Standard Time.

headline: Nods to Haiti and Other Traditions
text: Angel Olsen

headline: TV the Old Way: Watching What’s On
text: Picture it: a cold, quiet night in December, little to do. On the television screen is the channel guide, a sea of possibility and a tantalizing burden. Scroll. Scroll. Scroll. Finally, a show with a title too blunt to resist: “Mega Shredders.”

headline: Step by Step, Into a New Dance Realm
text: CANTERBURY, England — “I hope you like steps,” said the choreographer Richard Alston in a talk before the performance of his new piece, “Rejoice in the Lamb,” here Wednesday. “Because there are a lot of them.”

headline: All by Herself, Friends Invited
text: Vanessa Anspaugh is a choreographer who has been steadily creating work in New York since 2006. But until now, with the premiere of “we were an island” at St. Mark’s Church, she has not had an evening-length program to herself. Her broad imagination and distinctive cast — Niv Acosta, Addys Gonzalez, Bessie McDonough-Thayer, Eleanor Smith and Jesse White — should be more than able to command the space alone.

headline: How ‘Let It Go’ Upended the ‘Frozen’ Plot
text: There is little stopping the momentum of “Let It Go,” the hit song from Disney’s blockbuster “Frozen.” The recording, by Idina Menzel, who voices the icy-but-thawing older sister Elsa in the movie, was certified platinum this week – that means at least a million sales – and the Academy also announced that Ms. Menzel was to perform it at the Oscars, where it is the favorite to win the prize for best song. The soundtrack, too, has been at or near the top of the charts for weeks.

headline: The World’s Best (Unaltered) Photos
text: Feb. 16 | Updated at bottom.

headline: Voices That Double as Camouflage
text: Psychologists, biologists and literary critics have long pondered the complex signals sent by an androgynous voice: of brave boundary crossing and lonely vulnerability, of idiosyncratic individuality and gender-bending camouflage. Pop listeners can consider their own reactions at two concerts featuring men who sound like women: Mike Milosh of the duo Rhye, and the Israeli songwriter Asaf Avidan. Rhye — Mr. Milosh and Robin Hannibal — has come the long way around, via more abstract electronic music, to a comforting, if shallow, facsimile of the pop-R&B ballads of the early 1980s. (8 p.m., Friday, Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, 212-353-1600, websterhall.com.)

headline: No Rest for a Tenor
text: Most tenors, just two days after singing the demanding title role of Massenet’s “Werther” in a new production at the Metropolitan Opera, would still be resting up. Not Jonas Kaufmann, who may be the finest all-around tenor in the business right now, certainly the most sought after.

headline: Grand Transport, as Envisioned
text: Preservationists get a chance to mourn all over again on Tuesday night, when PBS revisits the grand, sad story of the original Pennsylvania Station in an episode of “American Experience.” The program, “The Rise and Fall of Penn Station,” conveys just how brash was the vision of Alexander Cassatt, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, when he decided late in the 19th century that he was no longer content to have the company’s lines stop in New Jersey. He would, he decided, extend them into Manhattan and out to Long Island via tunnels under the rivers. And he would have those lines converge in a lavish station.

headline: An Art Movement, Warts and All
text: Futurism is a tricky subject for curators because of the movement’s ties to fascism. Museums tend to show pre-World War I works that exemplify “heroic Futurism,” the Boccioni sculptures and Balla paintings that glorify speed and dynamism, while ignoring the violence and nationalism of later Futurist art. But “Italian Futurism, 1909-1944: Reconstructing the Universe,” opening Friday at the Guggenheim Museum, surveys this thrilling but troubled period in Italian art from beginning to end.

headline: Old World Meets New
text: The Danish Athletic Club, long a haven for Scandinavian immigrants in Brooklyn and now struggling with declining membership, is getting a lift from immigrants from Mexico.

headline: Polish Cinema on Display
text: Kino Polska: New Polish Cinema, a five-day series of nine recent Polish films presented by BAMcinématek, opens on Wednesday with “Walesa: Man of Hope,” a biography of the charismatic Polish leader, trade-union organizer and co-founder of the Solidarity movement. Directed by the 87-year-old titan of Polish cinema, Andrzej Wajda (“Ashes and Diamonds”), it stars Robert Wieckiewicz, who portrays Lech Walesa as a firebrand with a big streak of paranoia. A soundtrack of Polish punk rock jacks up the mood of rebellion.

headline: The Xoogler Diaspora
text: #bits-xooglers strong { font-family: nyt-franklin, arial, helvetica, sans-serif; }

headline: The Danes’ New Amigos
text: In the candlelit banquet hall of the Danish Athletic Club, a 120-year-old institution near the border of the Bay Ridge and Sunset Park neighborhoods in Brooklyn, the annual St. Lucia procession is underway, led by a teenage girl crowned with a wreath of candles. Outside on 65th Street a light snow is falling. The auto repair shops and the warehouses bearing signs in Chinese that line this side of the block are shuttered, and across the street the park known as the Dust Bowl is the site of an early-evening soccer match between local Hispanic teams. Toward the corner of Seventh Avenue, the mall-size dim sum mecca East Harbor turns its outdoor lights on, bathing the slick four-lane industrial boulevard in a red and yellow glow.

headline: Financial Stability Board to Examine Currency Markets
text: LONDON – The Financial Stability Board said Friday that it would review foreign exchange markets in light of a series of investigations into potential manipulation of currency benchmark rates.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Sixth Extinction’
text: This week, Elizabeth Kolbert talks about “The Sixth Extinction”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Dave Itzkoff discusses “Mad as Hell,” about the making of the movie “Network”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Obama Announces Aid for Drought-Stricken California
text: FRESNO, Calif. — President Obama arrived in the heart of California’s parched farmland on Friday afternoon to offer tens of millions of dollars in federal assistance to the state, where the lack of rain and snow this winter has led to the severest drought in its modern history.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Sixth Extinction’
text: This week, Elizabeth Kolbert and Dave Itzkoff.

headline: Populist Party Makes Strong Showing in British By-Election
text: LONDON — Britain’s upstart U.K. Independence Party finished second in a by-election for a vacant parliamentary seat in Wythenshawe and Sale East, pushing the governing Conservative Party, led by Prime Minister David Cameron, into third place. The by-election, held Thursday, was won comfortably by the opposition Labour Party. It attracted almost 9,000 votes more than the U.K. Independence Party, which campaigns against immigration and membership of the European Union. The results embarrassed the Conservatives and their coalition allies, the Liberal Democrats, who finished fourth.

headline: Wheelies: The Global Pentastar Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: One Pot of Beans, Four Dinners
text: If you are good about keeping a well-stocked pantry, you probably have some bags of beans lying around. From time to time, check the “best before” date on the bags. Or if you buy in bulk and put the beans into jars, put a little sticker on the jars with the date you purchased the beans. Although dried beans won’t spoil, older beans can become hard and brittle, and sometimes they don’t soften properly when you cook them.

headline: More Reflection, Less Action
text: Earlier this week, I found myself talking with the chief of staff to the chief executive at a large company. The two of them had been on the road together for four consecutive weeks. I asked how that felt. “It’s brutal,” he said. “But it’s typical. My boss essentially has no openings on his schedule for the next three months.”

headline: Skiing in My Own Backyard
text: I’d been motoring west across Oregon’s high desert in a jalopy full of holes when at last the snowy volcanoes I was aiming for bubbled up on the horizon. The drive from New Mexico had taken me all night and I was weary, but now the Cascades of central Oregon cut through the pale winter light like a beam. Those peaks would be my new backyard, and I was impatient to play. In the back of my truck bounced three pairs of my favorite skis.

headline: British Marmalade Cake
text: Melissa Clark makes butter-rich British marmalade cake topped with icing.

headline: Even Good Films May Go to Purgatory
text: They show up in discount DVD bins, or more often today online, sometimes looking a little worse for the wear. A general pall of darkness might cloud the image; the dialogue might be a bit tinnier than you remembered. Often the quality is not too shabby, though in the case of the web, it can be a surprise that they’re online at all. They’re films that have fallen out of copyright for one reason or another and must weather the wilds of the public domain.

headline: Sweetness Is Found in a Slice
text: Long before the food revolution in England brought us gastro pubs, Jamie Oliver and the Fat Duck, there was British marmalade.

headline: 36 Hours in Baton Rouge, La.
text: Louisiana’s capital has neither the nonstop party scene nor the obvious cultural charm of its more celebrated neighbor to the southeast, yet this laid-back Mississippi River town offers a unique appeal. The French, Spanish, Creole and Cajun influences of its three-century history blend with the youthful spirit of Louisiana State University’s nearly 30,000 students, stewing up a Southern mélange that’s on full display during Baton Rouge’s own Mardi Gras celebrations, through March 1, as well as events like the Baton Rouge Blues Festival (April 12). Along rural roads and in revitalized downtown neighborhoods, inside strip malls and by industrial sites, this unheralded city reveals a dynamic musical heritage and rich culinary history that demand to be discovered.

headline: Welcome Words: Why The Times Bucked the Government on a Drone Strike Story
text: The United States is considering a drone strike to kill an American with alleged terrorist ties. That’s a pretty big deal – shocking to those of us who haven’t become completely inured to such news.

headline: For Two Snowboarders, the Calm After the Fall
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Danny Davis made his own jump, carving it out of a deep, crusty shelf of snow with the edges of his snowboard. He angled the ramp skyward, smoothed it, gave it a final look and hiked back up the hill.

headline: Zachary Catazaro Named a Soloist at New York City Ballet
text: Zachary Catazaro, a dancer who came to the New York City Ballet as an apprentice in 2007 and joined the corps de ballet in 2008, has been promoted to soloist, the company announced on Friday. Peter Martins, the company’s ballet master in chief, informed Mr. Catazaro about the promotion after rehearsals on Thursday.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Sixth Extinction’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Al Gore reviews Elizabeth Kolbert’s “The Sixth Extinction: An Unnatural History.” Mr. Gore writes:

headline: Racial Discrimination in Renting?
text: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: The Greatest Film Role Ever Cast
text: When the matinee idol Jeffrey Hunter starred in the 1961 version of “King of Kings,” snarkier critics called it “I Was a Teenage Jesus.” When “The Last Temptation of Christ” played Paris in 1988, with Willem Dafoe as a conflicted Messiah, the theater was firebombed. In both “The Robe” (1953) and “Ben-Hur” (1959), Jesus was a character, but his face was never seen — out of respect, perhaps, but maybe out of caution, too.

headline: Cuomo Offers de Blasio Support, With Barbs
text: In politics, friendship can be a complicated thing.

headline: China Reports Another Case of New Bird Flu Strain
text: BEIJING — Chinese officials have said a new strain of avian influenza, H10N8, has killed another person, according to a report on Friday by Xinhua, the state news agency. The victim was a 75-year-old man living in Nanchang, the capital of Jiangxi Province, who entered a hospital on Feb. 4 after falling ill. He died on Feb. 8, Xinhua reported.

headline: Israeli Museum Receives $10 Million in Gifts for New Extension
text: The Museum of the Jewish People, known as Beit Hatfutsot, in Tel Aviv, has received a pair of $5 million gifts from American philanthropists.

headline: At Retromobile in Paris, Early Record-Setters Roar Again
text: PARIS — On March 3, 1927, on a cold, windswept beach in Wales, John G. Parry-Thomas, a working-class engineer, steeled himself to set a land speed record. The year before, he’d pushed the mark to 169 miles per hour, then to 171. But his aristocratic archrival, Sir Malcolm Campbell, reached 174, and just a month later Parry-Thomas was trying to regain the record.

headline: 100 Years Later, Celebrating the Taxis That Saved Paris
text: PARIS — The echoes of the guns of August 1914 had barely subsided when France faced its first crisis of World War I. By early September, the German army had moved through Belgium and was within 30 miles of Paris; the French government was preparing to decamp to Bordeaux, and panic spread through the city.

headline: Love and the Fed
text: It’s Valentine’s Day, and economists and Fed-watchers are again waxing poetic on Twitter. Whether inspired by Federal Reserve leaders past and present, or the policies they represent, the ardent declarations are pouring forth, defying those who would say economics is a world without love. Here are some favorites from #FedValentines:

headline: Trade Pact With Asia Faces Imposing Hurdle: Midterm Politics
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s ambitious trade agenda appeared to fall further victim to election-year politics on Capitol Hill on Friday when Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., in a closed-door retreat with House Democrats, said he understood why they would not grant Mr. Obama the crucial authority he needs to conclude large trade deals with Asia and Europe.

headline: A Minister in Germany Steps Down Amid Uproar
text: BERLIN — The German agriculture minister, Hans-Peter Friedrich, resigned on Friday after it was revealed that four months ago, as interior minister, he tipped off another senior politician to the criminal investigation of a prominent lawmaker.

headline: Headlines, Happy Meals, and Now Homes
text: Stepping into the lobby of the Lara, a new luxury rental building in the financial district, a visitor would never know that the site of this 30-story tower had been the birthplace of The New York Times.

headline: Microsoft’s Stakes in the Battle for Handsets
text: When Microsoft announced in September that it was buying Nokia’s struggling handset business and would meld its Windows operating system with the devices, it offered two major reasons for the $7.2 billion deal:

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 14
text: Figure skating, bobsled and skiing on the ninth day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Pharrell’s Hat and Karen O’s Brain Tricks
text: It’s the first day of the final round of Oscar voting – a last countdown to the big broadcast.

headline: A Moment of Transparency
text: A new kind of transparency is coursing through fashion. From open weaves and sheer fabrics to slashed fringing and laser-print cutouts, each look offers a unique way to expose some skin.

headline: Toyota Recalls 261,000 Trucks and S.U.V.’s for Traction Control Malfunction
text: Toyota is recalling about 261,000 pickups and sport utility vehicles because several electronic safety systems could be disabled, according to a report the automaker posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Change the Way Stock Prices Are Quoted to Help the Economy? The S.E.C. Is Skeptical
text: Call it the JOBS Act’s little brother.

headline: In Libya, a Coup. Or Perhaps Not.
text: CAIRO — Stealing a page from neighboring Egypt, a senior army officer in Libya on Friday announced a military takeover, the suspension of Parliament and a new “road map” for the future.

headline: An App for Diners to Pay Their Bill
text: On the surface, a new dining app called Cover does something simple: It takes care of the bill. No, this is not a case of persuading Siri to be more generous. Rather, if you go to one of the 43 New York restaurants that support the app, and you tell your server that you are paying with Cover, the back and forth that usually accompanies the payment process disappears.

headline: In New York, a Showcase for Chinese Performers
text: New York University’s Skirball Center will bring China’s contemporary performing arts scene to New York for three months this year with its second annual Visions and Voices Global Performance series.

headline: The Gun Report: February 14, 2014
text: • On Thursday, a federal appeals court in California struck down rules permitting counties to restrict the right to carry a concealed weapon in public, saying that such restrictions violate the Second Amendment. The decision was hailed by gun rights advocates, while gun control supporters described the ruling as aberrant and reckless. The decision will affect populated areas like Los Angeles, San Diego and San Francisco, but the the rules will remain in effect pending appeals. California generally prohibits carrying guns, loaded or not, in public locations. Before the ban was enacted, state courts routinely upheld restrictions on carrying concealed weapons.

headline: ‘The Croods’ Team Can at Least Count on 2 Votes
text: Kirk DeMicco and Chris Sanders, the writer-directors of the DreamWorks animated hit “The Croods,” know that they aren’t favored to beat out Disney’s “Frozen” for the best animated feature Oscar. “It’s the reality that we live with,” Mr. Sanders said, and joked, when asked about his chances: “I’m holding my head in my hands, trying to figure out how to answer that. So many feelings!”

headline: Yuzuru Hanyu of Japan Wins Men’s Figure Skating Gold
text: SOCHI, Russia — Yuzuru Hanyu was skating when the devastating earthquake and tsunami struck northeast Japan. He was 16, and he felt the ice rumbling and the ground thrusting and his legs wobbling. He ran from the rink in his skates, with no time even to put on skate guards.

headline: Lead Prosecutor’s Abrupt Departure Rattles a Military Sexual Assault Case
text: The military’s most closely watched sexual misconduct prosecution has been thrown into turmoil after the Army’s lead prosecutor abruptly left the case this week, less than a month before the scheduled court-martial of Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair on sexual assault charges.

headline: A Family Office for the Superrich, and Lessons for the Less Wealthy
text: STEVEN A. COHEN, the billionaire hedge fund manager, has been in the news for a string of insider trading convictions of current or former portfolio managers at his SAC Capital Advisors. But less attention has been given to his decision to convert his hedge fund into a family office to free himself from Securities and Exchange Commission regulations.

headline: Stretching the Mind and the Body
text: When Grace Aneiza Ali moved to New York in 2006 for graduate school, she found herself immersed in a contradiction. There were 140,000 Guyanese immigrants in the city, the fifth-largest foreign-born population. Yet most New Yorkers knew little about her home country, she said. “They know Jim Jones and the Jonestown massacre,” she said. “Or they confuse it with Ghana.” Ms. Ali, 32, now an adjunct professor in the department of interdisciplinary arts and sciences at the City College of New York, has set out to change that — by founding Of Note magazine, an online journal about the arts and social activism; and curating a photography exhibition, “Guyana Modern,” scheduled for Aljira, a Center for Contemporary Art, in Newark in 2015. She lives alone in Harlem, where she worries about becoming too Manhattan-centric.

headline: ‘Are Parents Better Lovers?’
text: “You have no room for anyone in your life but your kid,” said an amorous language director last year who ended up hiring instead of bedding me.

headline: A Deal Tailor-Made for Disaster
text: Jos. A. Bank’s daft deal is knitting its shareholders in a bind. To avoid being acquired, or perhaps to fetch a higher price from rival Men’s Wearhouse, the company is issuing stock to buy Eddie Bauer at $56 a share, only to buy more back at $65. If the $875 million transaction isn’t unraveled, investors will find themselves painfully stitched up.

headline: Striking a Lone Star Pose at Betony
text: Seeking a refuge from the runways during New York Fashion Week,  industry people flocked to nine-month-old Betony, a two-tiered restaurant on West 57th Street where cozy and trendy blend. Advertising executives from Glamour magazine and Macy’s enjoyed a business dinner with crisp cocktails and glasses of Riesling. Hair salon and boutique owners booked late reservations. Walk-ins landed in the lounge, resting between shows and fortifying themselves with velvety flavors. As food lovers and fashionistas know, it takes hard work to look good; harder work, still, to create great taste.

headline: Twitter, Can You Hear Me Now?
text: O, the cawing and the self-directed cooing. Two recent events on Twitter have breathed new life into the question: At what point does jaunty confidence metastasize into abject bragging?

headline: Driving the Market for a Car Service
text: On Feb. 8 at 7:45 p.m., after the spectacularly weird and amazing Moncler Grenoble presentation at the Hammerstein Ballroom in Midtown Manhattan, fashion editors and fashion show attendees were in a panic. They were running late and had only 45 minutes to make it to a choked-off-from-mass-transit portion of Brooklyn for Alexander Wang’s show at the Navy Yard. On 34th Street, cars idled and fashionistas forcefully marched through snow banks to find their car, or find any car at all.

headline: Activists Raise Stake in Williams Companies and Hire an Adviser
text: The two activist hedge funds looking to spur change at the Williams Companies disclosed on Friday that they have raised their collective stake in the gas pipeline company and have hired an investment banker to aid them in their campaign.

headline: Won Tons Are Easily Domesticated
text: Winter does not retreat. Here’s what I want: a table by a fogged-up window, with fat won tons, drizzled with hot pepper oil and stinking of garlic and ginger, bobbing in a huge bowl of steamy broth. Where? Why, at home — where else?

headline: Scenes of Indonesians Fleeing Eruption
text: The eruption of Mount Kelud, a volcano in Indonesia, covered villages in ash and forced people to evacuate.

headline: Ike Davis in Mets’ Camp With Revamped Swing and Trade Rumors Behind Him
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — All off-season, family members and friends asked Ike Davis if he was going to be traded. He had heard the rumors and read the newspaper reports. He figured he might be, but no, he told them. His father eventually spoke out about how the Mets were handling the situation. All the while, Davis was busy rehabbing his oblique and working yet again on his swing.

headline: Her Creative Exuberance Has No Limits
text: Florence Wint scoffs at the stereotype of spending her golden years relaxing.

headline: From Hugo França, Nature Sculpted
text: Hugo França was working as an industrial engineer for a computer company in São Paulo, in his native Brazil, when in 1981, at the age of 26, he moved to Trancoso, in the northeastern coastal area of Bahia, to live among the indigenous Pataxó people. The move was prompted by a love of nature, but it eventually led him to a new career as a wood sculptor.

headline: Studio Visit With Hugo França
text: The Brazilian designer Hugo França reclaims felled wood from the rainforest to create sculptural furniture.

headline: Is the Universe a Simulation?
text: IN Mikhail Bulgakov’s novel “The Master and Margarita,” the protagonist, a writer, burns a manuscript in a moment of despair, only to find out later from the Devil that “manuscripts don’t burn.” While you might appreciate this romantic sentiment, there is of course no reason to think that it is true. Nikolai Gogol apparently burned the second volume of “Dead Souls,” and it has been lost forever. Likewise, if Bulgakov had burned his manuscript, we would have never known “Master and Margarita.” No other author would have written the same novel.

headline: A Victory for Gay Rights in Virginia, but Opponents Vow to Fight On
text: Supporters of gay rights celebrated on Friday their latest courtroom victory, the overturning of Virginia’s ban on same-sex marriage, as opponents condemned the decision as an infringement on states’ rights and vowed to take the issue to the Supreme Court.

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Fall/Winter 2014 Men’s Wear Shows in New York
text: Though New York Fashion Week is still officially focused on women’s clothing, in the men’s wear business, designers are increasingly making their own rules. Many presented their fall/winter 2014 collections days before the official start of the season in the Big Apple, while others snuck their men’s designs onto the runway alongside those for the ladies. Regardless of when, where or how the clothes were introduced, though, it was undeniably a week of great men’s fashion filled with wearable, updated takes on the sportswear for which the American men’s market is best known.

headline: In the Church of Difficult Music
text: They trickled in to an anonymous, mostly shuttered storefront on a rugged corner at Avenue C and Second Street, prompting occasional confusion from pedestrians walking by. They were entering a place of almost spartan simplicity: a dimly lit chamber with a brick wall and folding chairs, and no food or alcohol served. They paid $15 cash to a man seated inside.

headline: The Jig Is Up, if You’re Irish or Not
text: WHITE PLAINS — Growing up in Woodlawn, a section of the Bronx also known as Little Ireland, Kristi Corcione envied her Irish-American friends. They got to take Irish dancing lessons, but as the self-described “token Italian” in her neighborhood, Ms. Corcione wasn’t allowed to join them.

headline: Venezuela’s Leader Pulls Foreign Channel Over Protest Coverage
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela’s president said that a Colombia-based cable news channel was ordered to be removed from cable lineups in Venezuela because of its coverage of an antigovernment protest. President Nicolás Maduro said Thursday that the channel, NTN24, had tried to “foment anxiety about a coup d'état.” He said that he gave the order to pull the channel because “No one is going to come from abroad and try to perturb the psychological climate of Venezuela.”

headline: A Wink and Then a Nod
text: The period during which Alex Chan and Sue Choe were on the Match.com dating site about four years ago wasn’t long, but somehow they both found that window, opened it and climbed through.

headline: Pomp and Coincidence
text: The countess stayed seated, but her gentleman companion chivalrously rose in his tuxedo to receive us. “Good evening,” he whispered with a continental bow. Uncertain how to answer him, I moved my head as he had, but didn’t really manage it as gracefully. While our tablemates looked on, he took a step behind me and kissed my girlfriend’s hand.

headline: Goodell’s Pay of $44.2 Million in 2012 Puts Him in the Big Leagues
text: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell was paid $44.2 million in 2012, making him among the best-paid executives in the country and perhaps the highest-paid leader of a nonprofit organization.

headline: Andris Nelsons to Conduct Lucerne Concerts
text: Andris Nelsons will step in to conduct two concerts this summer with the Lucerne Festival Orchestra that were planned by its founder, Claudio Abbado, the festival announced. Mr. Abbado, who founded the orchestra in 2003, died last month at 80. Mr. Nelsons, who will officially become the music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra next season, will lead the Lucerne orchestra in Brahms programs on the festival’s first two nights, on Aug. 15 and 16. Michael Haefliger, the executive and artistic director of the Lucerne Festival, said in a statement that by performing works planned by Mr. Abaddo “the memory of the Lucerne Festival Orchestra’s founder remains alive in the festival’s artistic programming.” He will conduct the orchestra in Brahms in another pair pf concerts on Aug. 22 and 24.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Thailand, Indonesia, Syria and Sochi, Russia. More images from the Winter Olympics here.

headline: A Blushing Bride May Match Her Dress, and Her Guests
text: Everyone knows not to wear white to a wedding so as not to upstage the bride, but what happens if a bride decides to wear pink, yellow or even blue? The answer: added stress for some brides and sartorial confusion for wedding guests.

headline: What Area Is Considered Upstate New York?
text: Q. Living in a New York suburb, I’d like to know what people mean by “upstate New York.” Just how far do you have to be from the city to be upstate? Also, what are the boundaries of two upstate areas, the North Country and the Southern Tier?

headline: Every Men’s Figure Skating Jump, on One Page
text: Yuzuru Hanyu, the 19-year-old from Japan, stumbled on multiple jumps in his long program, but he did well enough to win the first men’s singles skating gold in his country’s history.

headline: Weekend Reading: Cable Deals and JPMorgan Hiring
text: A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Being an Efficient Valentine
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline: Paying for Pot, With Paper or Plastic
text: At a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing in September, Senator Patrick Leahy brought attention to the financial aspect of the conflict between state and federal marijuana laws. Under federal law, it is illegal for banks to handle proceeds from drug sales, meaning marijuana businesses have to deal exclusively in cash. That’s not optimal, to say the least, since, as we put it in an editorial on the subject, “where there are piles of cash, there’s armed robbery.” Other potential problems include: Wage theft, money laundering and tax evasion.

headline: In U.S.-Russia Hockey Game, Cold War Shifts to the Ice
text: SOCHI, Russia — Around every corner, the face of Russia lurks. Not the stony visage of President Vladimir V. Putin, who delivered the Winter Games to his country, but the jack-o'-lantern grin of Alex Ovechkin, on whose stick the host nation’s success rests.

headline: Snap Sketch | Coco Rocha, Colin Self and the Faces of New York Fashion Week
text: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressions of the fashion set around New York City this week.

headline: Strutting and Fretting Their Way Toward Bankruptcy
text: We know from theater’s long history of self-examination that what’s going on backstage during any given production is often more entertaining than what’s presented to the audience. The activity behind the curtain is particularly delicious in Fault Line Theater’s premiere of “The Faire,” a sharp comedy by Crystal Finn at the Fourth Street Theater about a sad-sack Renaissance fair and the actors who are watching it slowly die.

headline: Honoring a Bounteous Earth, While Warning of Man’s Destructive Trail
text: As sleet pummeled the city on Thursday in the hours leading up to the premiere of Souleymane Badolo’s “Benon” at Danspace Project, the idea of a work about nature’s redeeming qualities, its gifts as opposed to its hazards, seemed attractive. A program note suggested that “Benon” would offer just that: Inspired by celebrations surrounding the harvest in Burkina Faso, where Mr. Badolo was born, it explores “the essential nature of food and the need to protect the environment.”

headline: Review: 2014 Chevy Silverado
text: The Silverado High Country is Chevy's first crack at a luxury pickup. It's a rig that's as comfortable at the symphony as it is on the farm.

headline: What the Elite Wear to Meet the Sleet
text: New York Fashion Week came in like a lamb and went out like a lion.

headline: For Two Snowboarders, No Medals but Plenty of Sky
text: The American snowboarders Danny Davis and Greg Bretz had the mountain nearly to themselves on Friday when they headed to the slopes far from Olympic competitions.

headline: For Interns, All Work and No Payoff
text: Like other 20-somethings seeking a career foothold, Andrew Lang, a graduate of Penn State, took an internship at an upstart Beverly Hills production company at age 29 as a way of breaking into movie production. It didn’t pay, but he hoped the exposure would open doors.

headline: In the Pitch Darkness of the London Blitz, a Cover for Evil Doings
text: In case this season’s next-to-last episode of “Downton Abbey” isn’t enough Anglostalgia for you on Sunday night, PBS is following it with “Murder on the Home Front,” a cheerfully preposterous British television movie set in London during the Blitz. The film is a slender but lively entry in the exceedingly crowded field of British period mysteries. Its World War II backdrop aligns it with the more serious “Foyle’s War,” while its focus on forensics as an as yet unappreciated science links it to the Victorian-era “Ripper Street.”

headline: Chief Minister of Delhi Resigns After 49 Days, Citing Resistance to Antigraft Bill
text: NEW DELHI — Arvind Kejriwal, a protest leader who was vaulted into the top post of Delhi’s city government after a startling electoral victory, resigned from his seat after just 49 tumultuous days in office on Friday, saying his central anticorruption initiative was being stonewalled by legislators from India’s two well-established parties.

headline: For Cars, Aluminum Is a Back to the Future Metal
text: While the 2015 Ford F-150 is on track to become the industry’s highest-volume aluminum-body vehicle — and a breakthrough in pickup truck design — it follows many earlier ventures in aluminum auto production. Since the dawn of the automobile, manufacturers have exploited the metal’s advantages for reasons that include weight reduction, corrosion resistance and ease of recycling, which is why a growing number of luxury brands and sports cars rely on aluminum structures.

headline: A Luxury-Class Metal Is Asked to Do Farm Chores
text: In the hotly contested part of the vehicle market where bragging rights go to the vehicle that has the engine with the most pulling power or the cargo bed that hauls the heaviest payload, Ford is testing its owners’ loyalty by building pickup bodies from a lightweight material more commonly used for luxury cars.

headline: Listen Up | Lo-Fang’s Globetrotting, Left-of-Center Pop
text: The Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter Lo-Fang — the nom de musique of 30-year-old Matthew Hemerlein — wrote and recorded much of his debut album, “Blue Film” (out Feb. 25, 4AD), while globetrotting with friends. “There’s definitely a traveling quality to the record,” says Hemerlein, who worked with the acclaimed producer François Tétaz (Gotye) to bring his electro-tinged, “left-of-center pop” songs to life. In an interview last month, the singer described a nomadic recording process that took him to London, Nashville, Maryland and Southeast Asia, among other locales — including one particularly unusual violin session in Cambodia. “My friend who I went to Asia with was like, ‘Dude, you need to be playing while you’re riding an elephant up a mountain,’ ” he recalls. So he did just that, much to the delight of onlookers, as the friend recorded the melody.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 14
text: Subjects include: another snowstorm, the Columbia University fencing team and a fatal bus crash in Manhattan.

headline: Junior Exhibitors Vie for Westminster Prize
text: Teenagers show dogs as part of the Junior Showmanship competition of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

headline: Maggie Gyllenhaal Withdraws From a Downtown Show to Focus on Broadway Debut
text: Academy Award nominee Maggie Gyllenhaal has dropped out of a downtown play in order to focus on making her Broadway debut in October in Tom Stoppard’s “The Real Thing,” several theater executives said on Friday.

headline: Exclusive | 845 United Nations Plaza
text: A four-bedroom unit on the 32nd floor of the Trump World Tower underwent a total makeover.

headline: An Overhaul That Looks More Like a Tuneup
text: Glencliff, N.H. — Not far from where some emergency vehicles had pulled off the dirt road, Douglas Dutile, the Grafton County sheriff, was keeping an eye on the traffic. When he saw me appear over the crest of a hill here in the White Mountain National Forest, he recognized the truck I was driving as the new-for-2014 Chevrolet Silverado.

headline: A Haunting, Sepulchral Note, and Then a Swirl of Hyperactivity
text: You could barely hear the most memorable note in the pianist Christian Zacharias’s recital on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

headline: A French Lesson in Speed and Power
text: Retromobile, the annual classic-car show held this month in Paris, turned its focus this year to racecars and World War I military vehicles.

headline: Checking the Fairness of College-Provided Debit Cards
text: When Harris Foster arrived at Portland State University in Portland, Ore., he was offered a special debit card promoted by his school as a convenient way to get access to his student aid funds.

headline: Fancy Face-Lift
text: A combination unit at 845 United Nations Plaza that underwent a multimillion-dollar three-year renovation to transform a modern bachelor pad on the 32nd floor into a contemporary showplace with a 95-foot west/east wingspan, dynamic East River views, and an assortment of futuristic home-technology systems is about to enter the market at $25 million.

headline: Jos. A. Bank Takes a Page From a Long Ago Deal
text: In purchasing Eddie Bauer, Jos. A. Bank Clothiers has cleverly structured its deal to try and avoid criticism that its pursuit of Eddie Bauer shuts down Men’s Wearhouse’s own bid for the men’s clothing company. It’s a deft maneuver, based on both Delaware law and a bit of ancient history.

headline: ‘Dreamgirls’ and Beyond
text: If I had to pick one song that encapsulates what is special about the Broadway composer Henry Krieger it might be “Here Is the Heart.” With a strong, declarative melody by Mr. Krieger, best known as the composer of “Dreamgirls,” and lyrics by Tom Eyen, his “Dreamgirls” collaborator, the ballad, from their musical “Dangerous Music,” is all heart.

headline: In the West, It’s Not Just About the Snow
text: Recent storms have dumped loads of fresh snow in the Western United States, welcome news for the region’s national parks and resorts, many of which have been adding history, wildlife and ecology tours to their usual winter menus.

headline: Addicted on Staten Island
text: Late last month, Corey Epstein, a peripheral cast member on the reality television series “Jerseylicious,” was arrested along with 20 others in a drug sweep on Staten Island that grew out of a 16-month investigation called Operation Silent Hill. Mr. Epstein was charged with selling three oxycodone pills to an undercover officer, in front of his house on Nehring Avenue in New Springville, an area that had been largely rural until the 1970s, when malls and what has since become the vernacular architectural style of Staten Island — the deep-backed, two-family split level with a high, occasionally baroque stoop — imbued it and so much of Staten Island with a sense of inanimate prosperity.

headline: Puppy Love Is Not Enough
text: Every child begs for a dog. But to be a dog handler takes true commitment, from traveling to competitions around the country to grooming poodle hair for seven hours and trotting in circles in sensible flats. At the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in Manhattan last week, 91 once and future handlers from as far away as Alaska competed in the Junior Showmanship division. They were serious and professional, yet possessing those teenage flashes that the photographer Fred R. Conrad of The New York Times found captivating.

headline: A World-Changing Discussions
text: No, there’s nothing wrong with my headline. I’ve been walking around NYC today, and there are ads for the Wall Street Journal telling you that $1 can buy you either a 4-minute phone call or “a world-changing discussions”.

headline: Bail on This Bond
text: Whenever I flip through Tinder (a matchmaking — or let’s face it, hookup — app that uses the geography, “likes” and other components of our Facebook accounts to find us frisky partners), my boss is nearly always suggested to me as a potential match. I know that talking to him about our sexual exploits would be inappropriate. But he’s chosen a very public app for his search, and I would like us to be better friends. Don’t you agree that talking with him about our Tinder experiences might be a great way to bond?

headline: Friday Night Music: Suzanne Vega
text: Update: And that was excellent: Sarah Neufeld of Arcade Fire with Colin Stetson of Bon Iver ,performing Neufeld’s compositions. Virtuosic violin aside, who knew that Neufeld had such a lovely voice? And in the last piece, Stetson gave a spectacular demonstration of circular breathing.

headline: In the Air | In Living Color
text: Many fashion designers are collectively referencing a Pop aesthetic.

headline: The Making of the Pinacoteca Agnelli
text: Ginevra Elkann discusses the Pinacoteca Giovanni e Marella Agnelli, the Renzo Piano-designed museum in Turin built around her grandparents’ trove of masterpieces from Canaletto to Matisse.

headline: On the Market in Los Angeles
text: Homes in Venice Beach; Brentwood; West Hollywood; Hollywood Hills; and Beverly Hills, priced from $999,000 to $8,145,000.

headline: A Bridge Deal With Lindsey Weinger
text: Every once in a while, someone takes up bridge almost by accident and turns out to have a talent for the game. One such player is Lindsey Weinger of New York City.

headline: WNET to Return $3.5 Million Grant for Pension Series
text: WNET, the New York City public television broadcaster, said on Friday that it would return a $3.5 million grant it received to sponsor an ambitious project on public pensions in the face of charges that it solicited inappropriate underwriting for the series.

headline: After a Snowy Overnight Trek, That Velvety Sound, Accented by Impetuosity
text: There is a growing perception that the distinctive characteristics of orchestras from various national traditions are merging into an overall international style. If so, the St. Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra is an exception to this trend.

headline: Low-Key Makeover
text: Chevrolet has made numerous improvements to its Silverado pickup, though they’re not obvious to the naked eye.

headline: Scalia Has Seen the Future, and Its Name Is Marriage Equality
text: One must feel for Antonin Scalia. Which is not to say precisely what one must feel for him, but still: the 77-year-old Supreme Court Justice surely did not need another reminder of his prescience on the future of marriage equality in America, and yet he got one, thanks to the latest court ruling striking down a ban on same-sex marriage — this time in Virginia, which as we know is for lovers.

headline: Attuned to Strings, Plaintive or Manic
text: “Opus 19/The Dreamer,” a Jerome Robbins ballet choreographed in 1979 for Mikhail Baryshnikov and Patricia McBride, exists in a moody place where mystery and anxiety walk a delicate line. Is this strange, fitful landscape meant to evoke a dream or a nightmare?

headline: On the Market in Los Angeles, Calif.
text: Click the slide show to view this week’s On the Market properties in Venice Beach; Brentwood; West Hollywood; Hollywood Hills; and Beverly Hills. Prices range from $999,000 to $8,145,000.

headline: An Editor’s Olympic Turn on TV
text: It was a surprising voice to hear. David Remnick, the editor of The New Yorker, was on NBC explaining what the Olympic Games and the opening ceremony meant to Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: How ‘Rocky’ Learns to Fight
text: Andy Karl, who plays the title role in the new musical “Rocky,” can take a punch. Literally. The show’s choreographer designed stage fights that combine timed punches with old-fashioned theatrics.

headline: Why Did Anyone Buy a TV? He Made It Indispensable
text: Television owes a lot to people like Sid Caesar, who died on Wednesday at 91. I’m not talking about television the entertainment medium, although that, too, owes a lot to Mr. Caesar. I’m talking about television the appliance.

headline: Phoenixes Rise in China and Float in New York
text: On a recent wintry afternoon, a team of eight was putting the final touches on a pair of monumental birds that had just been hung in the majestic nave of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights. As these phoenixes hovered some 20 feet above, their tiny, twinkling lights illuminated an array of unexpected materials: feathers fashioned from impeccably layered shovels; crowns made of weathered hard hats; heads created from jackhammers; and birds’ bodies sculpted from other salvaged construction debris, including pliers, saws, screwdrivers, plastic accordion tubing and drills.

headline: Why Did I Become a Comic? He Inspired Me
text: The death of Sid Caesar on Wednesday caused a chain reaction in my soon to be 66-year-old mind. I was saddened, of course, but felt a sense of relief that he was at last free from the indignity of aging. Then I felt a nostalgic breeze blowing over me as I remembered why he was so important to me.

headline: From Tender to Blustery to Haunted
text: The Canadian baritone Gerald Finley and the British pianist Julius Drake gave a recital at Zankel Hall on Thursday that was the final stop of a North American tour featuring Schubert’s “Winterreise.” The performance almost fell victim to 21st-century winter blues after a power failure plunged Zankel Hall into darkness earlier that day.

headline: Times Minute | Goodell’s Big Payday
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Goodell's Big Payday
text: A big payday for the N.F.L.'s commissioner, Roger Goodell. Also on the Minute, rethinking the benefits of natural gas and an adventure to Haiti's hidden waterfalls.

headline: The World Celebrates Valentine's Day
text: From a hugging marathon in Thailand to naked bungee jumping in Latvia, different cultures celebrate Valentine’s Day in their own way.

headline: Batista’s Flagship Company Presents Bankruptcy Plan
text: SAO PAULO — The flagship company of the Brazilian businessman Eike Batista took a big step toward exiting bankruptcy on Friday as it presented a court with its creditor-approved restructuring plan.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: André Leon Talley’s Secret Shoes, Valentino’s Morbid Mess-Up and Barbie’s Newest Designer Frocks
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: A Murder to Solve, as Holmes Did
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — If you make your way to the Center of Science and Industry to see “The International Exhibition of Sherlock Holmes,” which opened here last Saturday, these are some of the cases you will not learn much about: the repulsive story of the red leech and the horrible death of Crosby, the banker; the singular tale of the politician, the lighthouse and the trained cormorant; and an account of Ricoletti, of the club foot, and his abominable wife.

headline: Hanyu Falls Twice, but Still Wins Gold
text: After a world record-setting short program performance, Yuzuru Hanyu, a teenager from Japan, fell twice in his free skate but still prevailed.

headline: Deferential Remarks in Martyrdom Video Said to Show Briton’s Last Words Before Suicide Attack in Syria
text: Peering into the camera and shaking his head slowly, a British man in Syria, dressed in the white robe worn by suicide bombers, apologized for being at a loss for words. “Sheikh, I can’t speak,” the man said to the militant acting as his translator in video apparently recorded last week, just before he got behind the wheel of an explosives-laden truck. “My tongue’s got like a knot in it,” he explained. “Tell him I can’t speak.”

headline: WBAI, Still Fighting Deficits, Fires Its Programming Chief
text: WBAI, the liberal radio station in New York that occupies a powerful spot on the FM dial but has been struggling financially for years, this week dismissed its latest programming chief.

headline: The After-Party Circuit
text: Here are some memorable faces from eight nights of Fashion Week partying.

headline: China Set to Press North Korea Further on Nuclear Aims, Kerry Says
text: BEIJING — After a day of meetings with senior Chinese officials, Secretary of State John Kerry asserted on Friday that China was prepared to step up the pressure on North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons programs.

headline: U.S. Issues Marijuana Guidelines for Banks
text: The Obama administration on Friday issued guidelines intended to give banks confidence that they will not be punished if they provide services to legitimate marijuana businesses in states that have legalized the medical or recreational use of the drug, even though it remains illicit under federal law.

headline: Single Motherhood, Poverty and Kids
The Childless Plan for Their Fading Days
text: HAVING children was never on Francine Tint’s to-do list. A painter of large abstract canvases, Ms. Tint never felt a biological imperative to reproduce or pass on her name to future generations.

headline: Chief Compliance Officer at SAC Capital Is Stepping Down
text: Steven L. Kessler, the chief compliance officer at SAC Capital Advisors, will step down on Feb. 28, marking the latest turn in the the final chapter of Steven A. Cohen’s once wildly successful hedge fund.

headline: Capturing the Energy of Hood by Air
text: There were moments, there are always moments. Four hundred poetic soft-sculpture clouds were set afloat in the New York State Armory for a cool, masterly Marc Jacobs show on Thursday. An ostentatiously costly tableau vivant involving complex hydraulics and Alpine singers tested the endurance of hundreds who had braved bitter cold to see what essentially amounted to the latest news in puffer jackets (Moncler). A disaster movie scene played out in an elevator at Oscar de la Renta as a passel of overheated editors stood trapped with André Leon Talley, latter-day Shelley Winters, wearing a fur blanket and Uggs.

headline: In Fashion, Fame’s Last Bastion
text: Free clothes, free clothes, step up celebrities, there are free clothes.
