text: To the Editor:

headline: Women and Mammograms: Doctors Weigh In
Rape on Campuses
text: To the Editor:

headline: Evening Hours | New York Fashion Week
text: Bill Cunningham takes a look at the fall 2014 collections.

headline: New York Fall 2014: The Fifth Element
text: Over the course of New York Fashion Week, it was hard to ignore the ubiquity of cellphones as a fashion accessory, a toy, a portable diary and an essential element of style.

headline: The Cure for Obesity
text: To the Editor:

headline: Act Now on Housing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lawmakers Promise Scrutiny of Comcast Deal
text: The ink on Comcast’s $45.2 billion agreement to acquire Time Warner Cable is barely dry, but already lawmakers have begun to weigh in on the antitrust issues raised by the deal, the largest this year so far.

headline: Football’s Loving Culture
text: WHEN the football star Michael Sam, the all-American University of Missouri defensive end, came out this week, it meant that he might become the first openly gay N.F.L. player.

headline: Bill Cunningham | On the Street
text: Ugh! Fashion and reality had a head-on smashup during Fashion Week, with more than 250 shows all over the city in often freezing, snowy or slushy weather. The shows ended Thursday, with heavy snow in the morning and a downpour with thunder and lighting at night. While many dressed for the weather, left, others continued to dress up for a fashion show, right. In the end, reality triumphed.

headline: The Beat Goes On
text: Bill Cunningham takes a look at the fall 2014 collections.

headline: Why I Never Got a Mammogram
text: I HAVE never had a mammogram. I’m almost 50 — nearly a decade into the age when the screening is recommended by the American Cancer Society. I’m college educated, adequately insured. And I am the bane of my health care providers. Once, my midwife went so far as to request that I never speak of my decision in any space where other patients might hear.

headline: The Book on Jeter
text: Every major league player is deeded real estate in the book of baseball. Some may be granted only one word, others a paragraph. And then there is Derek Jeter, who is closing out, in a masterly way, one of the great chapters in baseball’s history.

headline: It’s Not Much Fun Under a Little Paper Umbrella
text: Like everybody I know on the East Coast, I’ve been beaten down by the freezing winter and am desperate to get away to a warm place. But I’m wavering, because in my experience, the tropics are the New Year’s Eve of vacations: There is no way they are going to match your expectations.

headline: Lego Builds an Empire, Brick by Brick
text: In this week’s top-grossing children’s movie, not only skyscrapers but actors built of tiny bricks inhabit a rather dystopian world known as “Lego-verse.”

headline: Guantánamo Bay Prosecutors Accuse Detainee of Conspiracy
text: WASHINGTON — Prosecutors for the military commission trials at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, disclosed in a document posted Friday that they had added a charge of conspiracy against an Iraqi detainee, potentially setting up a test of whether Congress has the power to make conspiracy a prosecutable offense in a war-crimes tribunal despite its not being recognized as an international war crime.

headline: Anthony Open to Pay Cut to Bolster Knicks
text: NEW ORLEANS — Far removed from the prying eyes of his employers at Madison Square Garden, Carmelo Anthony sat on a dais inside a large ballroom at the Hyatt Regency on Friday afternoon and, with the news media gently nudging him along, decided to make some announcements.

headline: Roots of Bosnian Protests Lie in Peace Accords of 1995
text: TUZLA, Bosnia and Herzegovina — The local government headquarters here is a shell, its 12 stories charred by fire. Shards of glass tumble from its smashed windows.

headline: A Funeral Fraud
text: The subject line of the email usually says something like “funeral notification” or perhaps “your friend’s memorial service.” It appears to come from a funeral home, maybe even a real funeral home.

headline: Plushenko’s Withdrawal Stirs a Backlash
text: MOSCOW — The crowd at the Iceberg Skating Palace in Sochi went silent when Evgeni Plushenko stumbled with the back injury that ended his figure skating career on Thursday. But the stunned silence that followed his withdrawal from the men’s short program and the almost immediate announcement of his retirement has quickly been replaced by angry questions about whether Plushenko should have been competing in the first place.

headline: The Real Deal
text: The mood fashion shows inspire is a far cry from the one many women feel in the morning while getting dressed, when a series of realities must be addressed and decisions made.

headline: A Conflict of Faith: Devoted to Jewish Observance, but at Odds With Israel
text: There is no question that Charles H. Manekin is a rarity. Not because he is an Orthodox Jew who keeps the Sabbath, refraining from driving, turning on lights, even riding in elevators on Saturdays. Rather, this philosophy professor at the University of Maryland is rare because he believes that his Orthodox faith calls him to take stands against Israel.

headline: The Plus in Google Plus? It’s Mostly for Google
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google Plus, the company’s social network, is like a ghost town. Want to see your old roommate’s baby or post your vacation status? Chances are, you’ll use Facebook instead.

headline: Pope Pressed on Bishop Who Supervised Pedophile
text: A group of Roman Catholics in Kansas City, Mo., and a priest with expertise in canon law petitioned Pope Francis this week to take disciplinary action against Bishop Robert W. Finn, who was convicted in 2012 of failing to report a priest who was an active pedophile.

headline: U.S. and Canada Feel Putin Charm, Hockey Excluded
text: SOCHI, Russia — Turning on the charm as the host of the Winter Olympics, President Vladimir V. Putin dropped by the headquarters of the American and Canadian teams on Friday evening. He sipped red wine with leaders of the United States Olympic Committee, posed for photographs with stunned athletes and jokingly wished Canada luck — except on the ice in hockey.

headline: Winter’s Not Just Cold and Snowy. It’s Expensive.
text: The mighty $16 trillion American economy can easily shrug off a snowstorm or two, even in regions unaccustomed to wintry snow and ice. But a prolonged bout of unusual weather is taking a toll, especially on small businesses like Abbadabba’s, a shoe store chain in Atlanta, which has weathered two major storms this year.

headline: Lawyer Says Man Arrested in Hoffman Case Is an Addict, Not a Dealer
text: A studio musician who was  arrested on drug charges during the investigation into Philip Seymour Hoffman’s death argued through his lawyer on Friday that he was not a drug dealer, but merely a longtime heroin addict.

headline: Political Star Rises on Vow to Upend Italy’s Old Order
text: ROME — HE sometimes wears a leather bomber jacket, embracing the iconography of the rebel. He has rocketed through Italian politics by taking on the establishment, especially in his own left-leaning party. He is media savvy, evoking comparisons to Tony Blair, and he has tapped into a national yearning for change by cultivating a persona as a political wrecking ball with an Everyman appeal.

headline: Rhode Island Reaches Deal to Soften Pension Changes
text: A tentative agreement between Rhode Island and representatives of its public employees, brokered by federal mediators and unveiled on Friday afternoon, softens some provisions in a sweeping 2011 law intended to control the spiraling cost of the state’s pension system.

headline: Terran Lyons, McDonald’s Crew Trainer, on Raising 2 on the Minimum Wage
text: I’m 24 years old. I’m a single mother. I work at McDonald’s. I make $9.85 an hour. I usually get about 40 hours a week. I like it. I work the night shift, because I’m a hard worker, and they have plenty of workers for the day shift. They need workers at night — good workers.

headline: With a Bigger Comcast May Come More Deals
text: Just last month, Discovery Communications, the owner of cable networks including Animal Planet and TLC, had considered acquiring rival Scripps Networks Interactive in a deal that would have been valued at more than $10 billion.

headline: Justice Dept. Defends Its Conduct on Evidence
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has told a federal judge in Oregon that it did not engage in misconduct when prosecutors failed to tell a defendant that he faced evidence derived from warrantless wiretapping before his trial last year on terrorism-related charges.

headline: Pikus-Pace Goes Bump in the Night, but Still Wins a Silver
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Noelle Pikus-Pace thought she lost it. As she came out of the fifth curve at Sanki Sliding Center on Friday night, Pikus-Pace, the veteran American skeleton rider, felt her body bump the wall and her heart sink to her toes.

headline: Spring Women’s Fashion Issue
text: In the spring 2014 women’s fashion issue, T looks at the way women really want to dress. Our cover subject is the cult fashion-designer Phoebe Philo, whose quiet, understated designs for Céline give new meaning to the term “power dressing” — and are coveted by some of the smartest, savviest women out there. In our Sign of the Times essay, Cathy Horyn examines the divide between what women actually want to wear — beautiful clothes that they feel good in — and the tricked-out, challenging get-ups that come down the runway. We also celebrate three women who insist on doing things their way: the designer Maria Cornejo, whose art-inspired designs stay true to her singular vision; the up-and-coming singer Kelela, who is finding her voice somewhere between electronic music and old-school R&B; and the Fiat heiress Ginevra Elkann, who juggles duties as a film producer, art museum boss and mother while building a legacy — and a home — that goes beyond her famous name. Additional highlights include a behind-the-scenes look at Matthew Barney’s epic new art film; a pair of New York icons, Elaine Stritch and Chloë Sevigny, tune in to the latest rap music; and five prominent novelists — Colson Whitehead, Douglas Coupland, Mona Simpson, Joyce Carol Oates and Roddy Doyle — invite us into the spaces where they created their latest works. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Efforts to Mark Turf When Snowstorms Hit Endure Despite Critics
text: BOSTON — It is a time-honored winter tradition here: Shovel out your car, and guard your newly cleared parking spot with whatever you have handy — a traffic cone, a potted plant, a bust of Elvis.

headline: As Services Expand, Cable Bills Keep Rising
text: WASHINGTON — Of the many benefits that Comcast executives said would flow to consumers from its proposed $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable — more innovation, advanced technology, improved service — the one it did not mention is probably the one consumers care about most: their cable bills.

headline: De Blasio’s Vow to End Traffic Deaths Meets Reality of New York Streets
text: The announcement was bold, if somewhat quixotic: Mayor Bill de Blasio, whose campaign was focused on reforming the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk tactics, would commit his administration to reducing traffic deaths “literally” to zero.

headline: Disgraced Scientist Granted U.S. Patent for Work Found to be Fraudulent
text: Korean researcher Hwang Woo-suk electrified the science world 10 years ago with his claim that he had created the world’s first cloned human embryos and had extracted stem cells from them. But the work was later found to be fraudulent, and Dr. Hwang was fired from his university and convicted of crimes.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: A bad winter for travelers, a submersible computer and a dispute over exporting oil from the United States.

headline: A Steady Path to Supreme Court as Gay Marriage Gains Momentum in States
text: WASHINGTON — A sweeping decision on Thursday night struck down Virginia’s ban on same-sex marriage and continued a remarkable winning streak for gay rights advocates, putting new pressure on the Supreme Court to decide the momentous question it ducked last summer: whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage.

headline: Medicines Made in India Set Off Safety Worries
text: NEW DELHI — India, the second-largest exporter of over-the-counter and prescription drugs to the United States, is coming under increased scrutiny by American regulators for safety lapses, falsified drug test results and selling fake medicines.

headline: Innovation, Optimism and Jobs
text: Is digital technology destroying middle-class jobs? Does it exacerbate income inequality? Does it boost economic growth and productivity — without creating the jobs that ought to come with economic growth?

headline: If You Shovel It, It’s Yours? Not so Fast
text: The neighborhood of South End wants to ban the practice of space saving: shoveling out a parking spot and then leaving anything from a chair to a laundry basket to reserve it.

headline: The Common Core in New York
text: The new Common Core learning standards, which set ambitious goals for what students should learn from one year to the next, are desperately needed in New York, where only about a third of high school students graduate with the math and English skills necessary to succeed at college. But the standards, adopted in 2010, have had a bumpy rollout and are under siege from several constituencies.

headline: Making Retirements Less Secure
text: The chief executive of AOL, Tim Armstrong, was roundly criticized for wrongly connecting the expensive health problems of two babies born to his employees and the health care reform law to the company’s rising health care costs. He eventually apologized for those remarks. Just as wrongheaded was his plan to deal with higher costs by changing the way the company contributes to retirement accounts.

headline: No Evidence of Coffee Break on Mars
text: Scientists did not find a Dunkin’ Donuts on Mars, but they did figure out where a rock that looks like a small jelly doughnut came from. Last month, the rock, about an inch and a half wide, showed up in one of the photographs taken by the NASA’s Opportunity rover. In addition to the unusual appearance, it had not been there when Opportunity photographed the same spot on the Martian landscape less than two weeks earlier. A new photograph shows an overturned rock with a similar dark red center and white surface about a yard away. The jelly doughnut piece, named Pinnacle Island, broke off and rolled downhill when the rover drove over it in early January, scientists working on the mission said Friday.

headline: 2 Companies to Destroy Chemicals in Syria’s Arsenal
text: Two hazardous-waste disposal companies, based in the United States and Finland, have been selected to help incinerate the chemicals in Syria’s weapons arsenal, the organization responsible for overseeing the destruction announced on Friday, as new worries emerged about possible Syrian procrastination in exporting the 1,200-ton stockpile.

headline: Next Move on Press Freedom
text: Last July, Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. spoke eloquently of “the importance of the constitutionally protected news gathering process,” the essential role of a free press when it comes to “government accountability and an open society,” and the need to better protect journalists from federal leak investigations.

headline: New York Tries to Rid Its Sewers of FOG (Fat, Oil and Grease)
text: Out of sight of most New Yorkers is a sprawling underground labyrinth of about 7,500 miles of sewers, part of the city’s vast and, in many cases, aging subterranean infrastructure. Besides old age, the sewers, which are essential to the health of the city, are under assault from a nemesis above ground: grease.

headline: Time for N.F.L. Sponsors to Demand Change
text: You know those funny Campbell Soup ads starring N.F.L. players and their mothers? The ones where moms pop up in locker rooms and on fields to bring their sons bowls of steaming Chunky soup?

headline: Where to Read a Plot Summary
text: Administrivial “Win Valuable Prizes” Alert! If you haven’t already signed up for the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, running from March 7 through March 9 in Brooklyn, New York — and why not? You can play along at home too, you know — you can still register here. Feeling shy? Don’t know anyone who will be there? Pish tosh. Sign up for the annual Cru dinner (click the first link to register) and meet your tribe: friendly folk who love crossword puzzles almost as much as you do.

headline: A Friend in Need, or Merely a Swindler
text: “She was approached by a male and a female,” the police captain explained. “Very well dressed. Late 40s, early 50s.”

headline: Volkswagen Vote Is Defeat for Labor in South
text: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — In a defeat for organized labor in the South, employees at the Volkswagen plant here voted 712 to 626 against joining the United Automobile Workers.

headline: South China Sea Tensions a Backdrop to Kerry’s China Visit
text: North Korea and bilateral relations between the United States and China are dominating Secretary of State John Kerry’s visit to East Asia this week, but tensions continue to simmer in the South China Sea as well.

headline: Genevieve Bell on Furby vs. Siri
text: During a lecture at Stanford University, Ms. Bell, an anthropologist at Intel Labs, compared the Furby toy with Siri, Apple’s personal assistant.

headline: A Newscast Unveiled by Cuomo, for Cuomo
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is often unhappy about the news coverage of his administration. So now his administration is starting to cover itself.

headline: Dining Outside in Little Italy: ‘I’m Starting to Miss My Mouth’
text: Even in the dead of winter, Mulberry Street in Little Italy does its best to look festive. The lights glow. Open-armed hosts in restaurant doorways greet prospective diners.

headline: Flips and Spins in Sochi and on Mammograms
text: It was a week of grand spectacles that would have made Julius “Bread and Circuses” Caesar proud. There were the Sochi Games, of course, a festival of sports both familiar and arcane, many set against the stunning white peaks of the Caucasus. And there was the state dinner on the South Lawn of the White House for President François Hollande of France, so rich in pomp and gossip that it was easy to forget that the host was a liberal and the guest a socialist, and that both their countries were forged in revolution.

headline: After Storm, 100% Attendance Is Not 100% Accurate
text: On a day when more than half of the city’s students were marked absent, three public schools reported 100 percent attendance on Thursday, a seemingly miraculous feat in the face of all the ice and snow.

headline: Jeter’s Decision Makes Things Easier for Girardi and Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla. — When Derek Jeter announced Wednesday that 2014 would be his final year in baseball, it probably removed a burden from the Yankees, particularly from Manager Joe Girardi.

headline: Legislator Up for Re-election Wants to Delay Bribery Trial
text: State Senator Malcolm A. Smith, who has been charged in a plot to bribe his way onto the ballot to run for mayor of New York City, asked a judge recently to delay his corruption trial for a very practical reason: It would interfere with his re-election campaign.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 14, 2014
Jim Fregosi, All-Star, Dies at 71; Angel Was Traded for Nolan Ryan
text: Jim Fregosi, a baseball lifer who made six All-Star teams as a player and managed the 1993 Philadelphia Phillies to the National League pennant, but who is probably best known — by New Yorkers, at least — as the player the Mets received from the California Angels in exchange for the future Hall of Fame pitcher Nolan Ryan in one of baseball’s more infamous trades, died Friday in Miami. He was 71.

headline: Alice Babs, Who Sang for Ellington, Dies at 90
text: Alice Babs, a Swedish singer acclaimed for her work with Duke Ellington, died on Tuesday in Stockholm. She was 90.

headline: Curtain Call | New York Fashion Week
text: To mark the conclusion of New York Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of some fashion visionaries.

headline: It May Be a Nonprofit Theater, but the Tickets Look For-Profit
text: New York’s nonprofit theaters are acting more like for-profits, and there’s no greater sign than the return of “Cabaret” at Roundabout Theater Company.

headline: Obama Promises New Aid to Jordan in Refugee Crisis
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — President Obama announced during a meeting here Friday night with King Abdullah II of Jordan that he would seek to renew a five-year aid package to help Jordan bear the burden of the more than 600,000 Syrian refugees who have fled the civil war there.

headline: Filipino Figure Skater Is Happy Just Being in Sochi
text: SOCHI, Russia — Michael Christian Martinez did not win a medal at the men’s singles competition at the Iceberg Skating Palace. His 19th-place finish was marked by trips and tossups.

headline: Sweet, Slushy Valentine
text: Constantine Tribushniy trudged through the snow and icy conditions like a modern-day Cupid on Friday delivering several flower orders on the Upper West Side.

headline: Corrections: February 15, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: What to Watch at the Olympics: Saturday
text: HOCKEY It may not be the Miracle on Ice — this game is merely about positioning for the medal round — but United States versus Russia seems worthy of setting an early-morning alarm. The Czech Republic then faces Switzerland in a noon game. They split their first two games and trail Sweden (2-0) in Group C. NBCSN, 7:30 a.m.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (CBS) 48 HOURS PRESENTS: THE WHOLE GRITTY CITY Wynton Marsalis hosts this documentary, in which the filmmakers Richard Barber and Andre Lambertson follow five students in New Orleans marching bands whose directors, while preparing them to perform in Mardi Gras parades, have also instilled survival lessons in a city with one of the highest murder rates in the country. The students have all lost someone close to them. “This is the street I don’t like, because it has guns,” says Jaron Williams, 11, not far from where his 19-year-old brother was shot to death. “I cried the whole day. I couldn’t get him out of my head.” Then Jaron, above, joined the Roots of Music, a free music education program for middle schoolers, and learned to play the trumpet, earning his way into the Marching Crusaders — and a parade. “I feel like I’m the best thing in the world and I can’t be stopped,” he says. It’s the power of the music, Wilbert Rawlins Jr., one of the featured band directors ,maintains. “I don’t care if you just had something very tragic that happened to you in your life,” he says. “Once that band gives you that downbeat, and that music is right, and it’s powerful — just for that brief two or three minutes, you forget everything, every problem you had. You have no cares in the world.”

headline: As Austrians Prevail, American Skiers Falter
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The ski racing rivalry between Austria and the United States has been less than subtle at times in the last eight years.

headline: Oshie Lifts U.S. Over Russia in Hockey Shootout
text: The United States defeated Russia, 3-2, in a shootout in men’s hockey at the Sochi Olympics.

headline: A List of Favorites From a Man Who Knows His Apps
text: Some people have a friend that can recommend the hottest new music album or latest and greatest upcoming television show. My friend Michael Galpert is my go-to person for the most obscure and often most useful apps that would otherwise be lost to me amid the million-plus options in the App Store.

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of New York Fashion Week Take Their Bows
text: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of New York Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 19 fashion visionaries.

headline: Suit Change Does Not Matter as U.S. Misses Podium Again
text: SOCHI, Russia — Zbigniew Brodka of Poland won the men’s 1,500-meter speedskating event here Saturday, but the continuing story at Adler Arena was the Americans’ baffling performances. The United States team includes world-record holders and Olympic and world champions. Yet Americans won none of the first 21 speedskating medals at the Sochi Games.

headline: Monopsony Begets Monopoly, And Vice Versa
text: Nothing to see here, folks, says Comcast. The cable giant’s defenders insist that its already awesome market power won’t be increased if it acquires Time Warner, because they serve (i.e., are local monopolists in) different geographical areas:

headline: What’s Happening Off the Runway During London Fashion Week
text: London Fashion Week has begun, and out-of-towners and locals alike are making their final preparations for another season of back-to-back shows and star-studded events. Here, a guide to surviving (and enjoying) the festivities.

headline: Mentally Ill Inmates
text: Responses to Nicholas Kristof’s column about how jails have become mental hospitals.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Feb. 16
text: “A clean debt ceiling is a complete capitulation on the speaker’s part.”

headline: The Case for Swapping Roles With China
text: Stephen Roach proposes to remake the two largest economies on the globe, ours and China’s. For decades, he writes, the United States and China relied too much on a “marriage of convenience” that guaranteed China a huge market for its exports. In exchange, China gave American consumers a cornucopia of inexpensive products, while creating a willing buyer of the United States government’s swollen debt. But that marriage has played out, Mr. Roach says; it has warped the two economies, leaving them ill-equipped for further growth.

headline: Patrolling a Bruised City
Drama, if Not Miracle, as U.S. Beats Russia
text: SOCHI, Russia — Every member of the United States men’s hockey team playing in the Sochi Games was born after the Americans’ shocking victory at the 1980 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid, N.Y., against a Soviet team stocked with stars. Four times since that Miracle on Ice, the teams had met in Olympic competition, with the Americans compiling a 1-2-1 record, but none of the games were on Russian soil.

headline: Small Business, Joining a Parade of Outsourcing
text: Going abroad for cheap labor isn’t just for big businesses anymore. Thanks to the rise of online job marketplaces, small businesses are increasingly using foreign contract workers to lower their costs.

headline: Expedited Service, Except When It’s Not
text: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: Where the Fish Swims, Ideas Fly
text: When I was in Reykjavik, Iceland, last summer on vacation, a peculiar object in a local design store caught my eye. It was a cod that had been turned into a light.

headline: At the Ready, at the Sochi Games
text: In January 2008, an American skier named Brett Buckles flew 10 feet into the air during a training run in the village of Tignes, France. Instead of landing gingerly on her skis, she came down with a thud 40 feet down the course and was knocked unconscious. Later, at a small local hospital, she learned that she had broken her pelvis in two places, fractured her sacrum, sustained a severe concussion and torn the labrum in her right shoulder.

headline: An About-Face for the Stock Market’s 5-Year Return
text: Take the long view. That’s standard advice in investing, and it makes sense. After all, if you’ve salted money away for a serious purpose like retiring or buying a house or paying for a child’s education, you really don’t want to focus on how the stock market has done today or on what it might do tomorrow. You need a longer perspective.

headline: Microfoundations and Mephistopheles (Wonkish)
text: Simon Wren-Lewis asks whether New Keynesians made a Faustian bargain by accepting the New Classical dictat that models must be grounded in intertemporal optimization — whether they purchased academic respectability at the expense of losing their ability to grapple usefully with the real world.

headline: Yes, the Wealthy Can Be Deserving
text: In 2012, the actor Robert Downey Jr., played the role of Tony Stark, a.k.a. Iron Man, in “The Avengers.” For his work in that single film, Mr. Downey was paid an astounding $50 million.

headline: A Great Teammate Is a Great Listener
text: This interview with  John W. Rogers Jr., chairman, chief executive and chief investment officer of Ariel Investments, based in Chicago, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: The Untouchable Profits of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
text: Would you buy stock in a company that barred you from sharing in its future earnings? Of course not. Participating in the upside is what stock ownership is all about.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: What to Watch: Sunday
text: ALPINE SKIING It has been a rough Olympics so far for the stars of men’s skiing. Aksel Lund Svindal, Bode Miller and Ted Ligety are without medals entering Sunday’s super-G. Svindal won the event at Vancouver. NBC, 7 p.m.

headline: Comcast vs. the Cord Cutters
text: The typical American household pays about $90 a month for cable television service, according to the NPD Group, the market research firm. But according to the research firm of You and Pretty Much Everyone You Know, when you click on your TV and browse the guide, what you often find hardly seems worth $90 a month.

headline: Variety: A Philosophical Diagramless
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — From 2005 to 2008, Nickelodeon broadcast an Asian-influenced animated series called “Avatar: The Last Airbender,” which my children watched fanatically, and which they insist was mangled as a live-action film in 2010. (The sequel, “The Legend of Korra,” is still in production.) In this series, some people are able to manipulate the classic ELEMENTs of FIRE, AIR, WATER and EARTH by “bending” them.

headline: Coveted Player to Train With U.S. Team
text: Julian Green, a young, promising player for Bayern Munich, will train with the United States national team for two days before the Americans travel to Ukraine for an international friendly match on March 5.

headline: Creighton Is Succeeding on Strength of a Father-Son Bond
text: Doug McDermott, a star forward for No. 18 Creighton, has almost wordless communication when he looks to his coach for guidance during a game. Sometimes, they are so alike in their thinking that nothing more than a nod is needed for a critical adjustment to be made.

headline: Defeat of Auto Union in Tennessee Casts Its Strategy Into Doubt
text: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Bob King has pursued one goal above all as president of the United Automobile Workers — to unionize several foreign-owned auto plants in the South. He said he viewed that as pivotal if his once-mighty union was to gain numbers and strength after decades of decline.

headline: A Debate Becomes a Brawl as Turkey’s Parliament Votes to Rein In Courts
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s Parliament met through the night, Friday into Saturday, and passed a controversial new bill that gives the government greater control over the judiciary — but not before a brawl on the floor of the assembly left one lawmaker with a broken finger and another with a bloodied nose.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 15
text: Hockey, skiing, and speedskating highlight the 10th day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Ugandan President Says He Will Sign Tough Antigay Measure
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Gay rights in Africa suffered another setback when President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda told members of his party on Friday that he would sign a bill imposing harsh sentences for homosexual acts, including life imprisonment in some cases.

headline: A Generational Wealth of N.B.A. Talent
text: NEW ORLEANS — Tim Hardaway Jr., a rookie swingman who has been a bright spot for the Knicks in an otherwise drab season, is a full-grown adult capable of his own decisions, but he still calls his father for advice.

headline: Behind Bars
text: The secret vocabulary of New York’s finest drinking establishments.

headline: In Report on Bullying, the Vile and the Gripping
text: My first reaction to reading Ted Wells’s 144-page report on the Miami Dolphins harassment case was that Commissioner Roger Goodell should ensure that Richie Incognito never be allowed to play another down in the N.F.L. Incognito, the Dolphins’ suspended offensive lineman, was the ringleader and catalyst of a reign of terror directed primarily at his teammate Jonathan Martin for two seasons.

headline: Ancestral Enemies Meet at Olympics for a Toast to Amity
text: SOCHI, Russia — I nearly missed my tea with a Cossack.

headline: Lebanon Forms a Cabinet After 11 Months of Deadlock
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon’s new prime minister, Tammam Salam, announced the formation of a cabinet on Saturday that represents many of the country’s deeply divided political factions, ending a nearly 11-month standoff that had left the government ill equipped to deal with increasing violence and a growing Syrian refugee population.

headline: At 18, Mikaela Shiffrin Has Envisioned the Best and the Worst
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Mikaela Shiffrin, the 18-year-old defending world champion in slalom, arrived here Friday night, and less than 24 hours later reporters asked her if she could rescue the struggling American ski team.

headline: Document Describes Eavesdropping on American Law Firm
text: Following is an excerpt from a document provided by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden. It is from the February 2013 edition of a monthly bulletin of SUSLOC, the acronym for the N.S.A. office that handles liaisons with Australian intelligence. It describes how Australian intelligence conducted surveillance of trade talks between Indonesia and the United States and, in the process, monitored communications between Indonesian officials and an American law firm retained by Indonesia for help with the trade dispute. The Australians then sought legal guidance from the N.S.A. (The document refers to the D.S.D — the Defense Signals Directorate — the former name of Australia’s counterpart to the N.S.A. In May 2013, the agency was renamed the Australian Signals Directorate, or A.S.D.)

headline: Spying by N.S.A. Ally Entangled U.S. Law Firm
text: The list of those caught up in the global surveillance net cast by the National Security Agency and its overseas partners, from social media users to foreign heads of state, now includes another entry: American lawyers.

headline: After Second Round of Syria Talks, No Agreement Even on How to Negotiate
text: GENEVA — The United Nations mediator for Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi, wrapped up the second round of peace talks here on Saturday without breaking a longstanding deadlock or setting a date for a third round, and urged the parties to think seriously about their commitment to the negotiations.

headline: Chinese Ask Kerry to Help Tear Down a Firewall
text: BEIJING — A group of Chinese bloggers asked the United States to take up the cause of Internet freedom in an unusual meeting on Saturday with Secretary of State John Kerry.

headline: Mob Attacks More Than a Dozen Gay Men in Nigeria’s Capital
text: DAKAR, Senegal — A mob attacked gay people in a neighborhood in Abuja, the capital of Nigeria, dragging young men from their homes, beating them with nail-studded clubs and whips, and shouting that they were “cleansing the community” of gays, several Nigerian activists and a witness said Saturday.

headline: J.W. Anderson: Fall 2014 RTW
text: London

headline: Olympians May Go From Sochi to N.H.L. Trading Block
text: The best hockey players in the world are competing in the Olympics, but some of them face the prospect of being traded by their N.H.L. teams when the season resumes.

headline: A Severe Winter Breaks Budgets as Well as Pipes
text: SYRACUSE — Century-old water mains here have ruptured behind City Hall, popped in residential areas and split under the city’s bar and restaurant district. The mayor says she has personally reported three breaks, while exhausted crews work 18-hour shifts in subfreezing temperatures to repair the damage.

headline: The Remarkable One-Man Show Called T. J. Oshie
text: SOCHI, Russia — Hockey is a team game, and this one was so big that it pitted country against country. But by the end, it turned into a simple contest of one-on-one.

headline: The Tame Truth About the Wolves of Wall Street
text: MAYBE it’s those five Oscar nominations for “The Wolf of Wall Street,” including for best picture, best director and best actor, but we seem to be in another of those moments in popular culture when Hollywood plies us with skewed answers about how Wall Street miscreants caused so much mayhem.

headline: Driving to the Music of Chance
text: I BOUGHT my car, a Jetta wagon, back in 2006. It was four years old and came with a five-CD cartridge lodged, impractically, over a rear wheel well. Not surprisingly, the CD player refuses to function on any less-than-perfect road — and in Brooklyn, where I live, there are few perfect roads. Even stop-and-start traffic makes the discs, well, stop and start. So when we want to hear music in the car, which is always, my family relies on the ad-riddled idiosyncrasies of commercial radio.

headline: The Never-Ending Candy Crush Saga
text: BY the end of 2013, more than half a billion people had installed Candy Crush Saga, and the addictive game app was generating just a little less than $1 million per day, according to its developer, King. Candy Crush Saga was the most downloaded app of the year in 2013, according to Apple.

headline: Start-Up America: Our Best Hope
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — THE most striking thing about visiting Silicon Valley these days is how many creative ideas you can hear in just 48 hours.

headline: Marry First, Then Cheat
text: PARIS — ONLY the French could have an etiquette scandal.

headline: The Line at the ‘Super PAC’ Trough
text: If you need something out of Washington and want to give a satchel of cash to a political candidate, no need to give it directly to the candidate. Federal law limits those contributions to $2,600 anyway. The thing to do is to give the money to the candidate’s “super PAC,” where no limits apply, to pay for attack ads against the candidate’s opponent.

headline: An Encouraging Chinese Courtship
text: Just a few years ago, the rivalry between mainland China and Taiwan was seen as one of the more likely triggers for international conflict. But while fundamental differences remain, the two sides have worked to ease tensions.

headline: James Bridle
text: James Bridle is a British writer and artist whose work focuses on technology and how it shapes culture and societies. He is the creator of Dronestagram, on the photo-sharing site Instagram, which supplies images of the locations of drone strikes as they occur.

headline: Transgender, Schlumpy and Human
text: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — THERE’S a scene in the new Amazon show “Transparent” when the family patriarch, Mort, walks in on his oldest daughter in flagrante with her lesbian lover. The character, who’s been struggling throughout the pilot with how to come out as trans, stands there in drag with a bemused expression. “Hello, ladies,” Mort — now Maura — says.

headline: The Lore of Labor
text: WHEN my water broke during the 35th week of my first pregnancy, I waddled down the block to our neighborhood’s brand-new hospital. This was in London, where I then lived, around 2 a.m., Dec. 13, 1993.

headline: Parental Pity Party
text: WHEN I became a father, I expected to change in all the predictable ways — to become more responsible and more exhausted, to lose contact with friends and lean more heavily on relatives, to grow steadily balder of head and softer of belly.

headline: To Save Fish and Birds
text: One of the few bright spots in the struggle to protect the world’s fragile oceans has been the rapidly increasing number of “marine-protected areas,” places where fishing is limited or banned and where, presumably, depleted species can recover by simply being left to themselves. The benefits of hands-off environmental protection may seem self-evident. But creating a preserve and rebuilding a healthy ecosystem are not necessarily the same thing. A recent study published in Nature found that, more often than not, marine-protected areas don’t work as well as they could.

headline: Professors, We Need You!
text: SOME of the smartest thinkers on problems at home and around the world are university professors, but most of them just don’t matter in today’s great debates.

headline: Is Harlem ‘Good’ Now?
text: WHEN I was walking to work one day last summer, I noticed that Crab Man Mike was gone from his usual post at 125th Street and Fifth Avenue. Mike has been cooking shellfish in his special pot on the streets of Harlem for 23 years. Concerned, I began asking the other street vendors where he went. Johnny Portland, one of the Jamaican guys who also sets up some days at 125th and Fifth, told me Crab Mike had moved.

headline: Social Media, a Trove of Clues and Confessions
text: IT seems as if every week there’s a news story about someone committing a crime and confessing to it on Facebook, bragging about it on Twitter or sharing photos of it via Instagram. In many ways, social media has been a boon for law enforcement, handing the police ready admissions of guilt, equipping criminal investigators with new types of evidence and empowering prosecutors to better dispel reasonable doubt of guilt.

headline: Home, Dismantled
text: This is the first part of an eight-part series.

headline: Let Our Lawmakers Hide!
text: AN idea for the Senate: brown paper bags. You know, the kind in which you cut little holes for your eyes and your nose and a bigger, wider hole for your mouth. Senators could wear these in the chamber, so that the C-Span cameras and the outside world wouldn’t know precisely who’s supporting what. Or maybe ski masks, though those wreak havoc on hairdos. Alternately, the lawmakers could communicate in code: anything to obscure their actions and make it easier for them to actually cast votes in line with their best judgment and consciences. Oh, you thought they always did that? Well then I won’t spill the beans on Santa or the Easter bunny, either.

headline: Sochi Video Notebook: T. J. Oshie
text: T. J. Oshie, who took six of the Americans’ eight shots, scoring on four of them to lift the team to a victory over Russia, spoke to the media after the game.

headline: London Fashion Week: Central Saint Martins Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Photos Become Ads With New Technology
text: Online publishers have been doing a lot of soul-searching lately about how to give their advertising revenue a shot of adrenaline without upsetting their readers. Native advertising, in which stories commissioned by sponsors are dressed up to resemble editorial material, is one of the most widely discussed efforts by publishers (including efforts at The New York Times).

headline: A Long, Strange Trip to the Basketball Hall of Fame
text: In the 1992 Summer Olympics, most eyes were on the Dream Team. Perhaps the greatest group of players ever assembled, the Americans took the world by storm, reclaiming supremacy in basketball and inspiring the world to take up the sport in earnest.

headline: Out in the Cold
text: Cities deal with water main breaks, potholes and roof damage as a result of the severe winter weather.

headline: In Short-Track Speedskating, Skill Struggles to Overcome Dumb Luck
text: The collision that sent Eddy Alvarez sprawling on the ice and out of the men’s 1,000-meter short-track competition happened so fast that even his description of it, a few minutes later, was barely longer than a haiku.

headline: Bridging the Moat Around Universities
text: My Sunday column is about the unfortunate way America has marginalized university professors–and, perhaps sadder still, the way they have marginalized themselves from public debate. When I was a kid, the Kennedy administration had its “brain trust” of Harvard faculty members, and university professors were often vital public intellectuals who served off and on in government. That’s still true to some degree of economists, but not of most other Ph.D programs. And we’re all the losers for that.

headline: U.N. Panel Finds Crimes Against Humanity in North Korea
text: GENEVA — United Nations investigators say North Korea has committed wide-ranging crimes against humanity to sustain its political system, and recommend that it be referred to the International Criminal Court.

headline: Addendum: Geithner and Treasury Department on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
text: Efforts to obtain comment from both the Treasury Department and Timothy F. Geithner, the former Treasury secretary, were unsuccessful before publication of “The Untouchable Profits of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac” (Feb. 16, 2014). A Treasury Department spokesman declined to comment, and Mr. Geithner did not respond to a request for comment. In both instances, they were asked why the department had not disclosed to Fannie and Freddie stockholders the administration’s commitment to deprive them of any future positive earnings generated by the companies.

headline: One Nation Under Guard
text: Another dubious first for America: We now employ as many private security guards as high school teachers — over one million of them, or nearly double their number in 1980.

headline: Ahn Wins Second Medal in 1,000 Meters
text: Picture sequence showing who held the lead in each lap of the race.

headline: Obama Meets With the King of Jordan
text: President Barack Obama meets with King Abdullah II to pledge $1 billion in loan guarantees for Jordan and to consider new ways to pressure the regime of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

headline: Intel’s Sharp-Eyed Social Scientist
text: Behind the gray, noise-absorbing cubicle walls at the Intel Corporation in Hillsboro, Ore., researchers who forecast the future of computing can sense her arrival.

headline: As Bubka Watches, His Record, Set in 1993, Falls
text: The timing could have been better for the French pole-vaulter Renaud Lavillenie.

headline: On the Mountain, a Wild Ride
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — I was not enjoying my cable car ride high above the mountains the other day, so I turned for reassurance to my gondola-mates, some Russian luge fans passing the time by cracking what seemed to be jokes about Kazakhstan. They did not understand me — I think they thought I was making the international signal for choking rather than for vertigo — so I tried to focus on the matter at hand: getting from the snowboarding park to the luge track sometime within the next 24 hours.

headline: Jury Reaches Partial Verdict in Florida Killing Over Loud Music
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — After four days of deliberation, the jury in the racially tinged trial of Michael Dunn, a Florida man who set off another firestorm over the state’s self-defense laws when he shot a teenager to death in a parking lot during a dispute over loud music, said it could not agree on whether Mr. Dunn had acted to protect himself or was guilty of murder.

headline: A Hockey Rivalry Moves Beyond the Ice
text: SOCHI, Russia — The Sochi Games organizer Dmitry Chernyshenko has turned to the same line again and again when asked to describe how he and certain other Russians feel about the United States’ Olympic hockey team.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 16
text: A powerful storm dumped record amounts of snow and ice on the East Coast, leaving stranded travelers and downed power lines in its wake. North Carolina’s highways were littered with abandoned cars after snowfall during the day paralyzed the evening rush, a similar scene to Atlanta’s gridlock in late January.

headline: American’s Skeleton Run Goes Awry
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — John Daly of the United States was in fourth place going into the fourth heat of the men’s skeleton final on Saturday when he botched his run just as it was beginning. It is unclear how exactly it happened — possibly he was too eager or too aggressive — but as he ran alongside and flung himself onto his sled at the top of the track, the sled popped out of the groove meant to guide it through its initial descent.

headline: Now No. 96 for Yankees, Possible Future Alternative to No. 13
text: TAMPA, Fla. — There is no better time for wishful thinking, if not pure fantasy, than on the day of the first spring training workout for pitchers and catchers. So mull over the delicious possibility, however distant or remote, of Alex Rodriguez’s eventual long-term replacement at third base being a converted catcher who hails from Miami and happened to play a season of college baseball at the ballpark that bears A-Rod’s tainted name.

headline: Polish Ski Jumper Sweeps Individual Events
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Kamil Stoch of Poland and Noriaki Kasai of Japan seemed to wait forever as they watched the scoreboard to see who would get the gold medal and who would settle for the silver in the large-hill ski jump on Saturday.

headline: The Oddities of Olympic Park
text: SOCHI, Russia — Snicker all you like at the well-publicized oddities and spectacular expense of these Winter Games, but give it up for the train that delivers visitors to Olympic Park. A digital sign on the platform at the next-to-last stop says that it will arrive at 1:14 and leave at 1:15, and it delivers on that promise, right down to the second.

headline: Mets Hope an Aging Ace Can Still Provide a Lift
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Early in the summer of 2002, Omar Minaya, the general manager of the Montreal Expos, made what he thought was an easy trade. After five consecutive losing seasons, the Expos, behind Vladimir Guerrero and Jose Vidro, were surprise contenders, in need of a boost. This was perhaps their last hurrah.

headline: Tanaka Gains a Mentor but Loses His Breath
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Soon after Masahiro Tanaka signed with the Yankees last month, one of the first things he did was to call Hiroki Kuroda, his new teammate and Japanese compatriot. It was part of Tanaka’s duty in accordance with the senpai-kohai relationship.

headline: Passing Grades
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s always a relief when you find out the teacher is grading on a curve, and that’s precisely what Yaakov BenDavid has for us today. You wouldn’t want to get all the way to the end of your solving week just to find out that you had failed.

headline: London Fashion Week: J.W. Anderson Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: A Ukraine City Spins Beyond the Government’s Reach
text: LVIV, UKRAINE — Oleh Salo, the Ukrainian state’s senior representative in this western region, was hard at work keeping up appearances. He had just completed a new budget, he explained, and had an urgent meeting with the newly appointed local chief of Ukraine’s security service.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: February 14, 2014
text: Volkswagen autoworkers in Tennessee may form the nation’s first “works council,” a type of union popular in Germany in which employees and management work together to make decisions. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine examine how significant the move would be for the nation’s labor movement, and why some officials and policy groups are opposed to it. Plus, a discussion of Comcast’s purchase of Time Warner Cable.

headline: Crossing Borders and Changing Lives, Lured by Higher State Minimum Wages
text: ONTARIO, Ore. — Carly Lynch dreams of a life one day on the professional rodeo circuit, but for now she commutes 20 miles from Idaho to this small city in eastern Oregon to work as a waitress. There are restaurant jobs closer to home, but she is willing to drive the extra miles for a simple reason: Oregon’s minimum wage is $1.85 higher per hour than Idaho’s.

headline: Pete Camarata, Who Fought Fellow Teamsters for Reforms, Dies at 67
text: In 1976, Frank Fitzsimmons, president of the Teamsters, struck a defiant note in a speech at the union’s convention in Las Vegas. “To those who say it is time to reform this organization, and it’s time officers stopped selling out the members,” he said, “I say to them, ‘Go to hell.’ ”

headline: Examples of Health Care 'Props'
text: Both Democrats and Republicans like to use real-life examples to back up their positions on the Affordable Care Act. But sometimes reality is more complicated.

headline: In the Debate Over Health Care, ‘Real People’ Become Human Volleyballs
text: WASHINGTON — In the Republican response to the State of the Union address, Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington lamented the travails of “Bette in Spokane,” whose insurance policy had been canceled because of the health care law and who faced huge premium increases to replace it.

headline: Reconsidering the Legacy of Lyndon B. Johnson
text: Relatives and friends of Lyndon Baines Johnson say that his legacy has been tainted by the Vietnam War, and they are working to put forth a broader view of his presidency.

headline: Legacy of L.B.J.
text: “The agony of Vietnam looms over all of us,” said Luci Baines Johnson, who argues that the war overshadowed the domestic achievements of her father, President Lyndon B. Johnson.

headline: A New Resource for Buddhist Scholars
text: The Tibetan Buddhist Resource Center opened its library, with 12,000 works, at the Southwest University for Nationalities in Chengdu, China, in October. Archivists plan to scan the texts digitally.

headline: In the Party, but Trying Hard to Stand Out
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: After Winding Odyssey, Tibetan Texts Find Home in China
text: CHENGDU, China — Decades ago, the thousands of Tibetan-language books now ensconced in a lavishly decorated library in southwest China might have ended up in a raging bonfire. During the tumultuous decade of the Cultural Revolution, which ended in 1976, Red Guard zealots destroyed anything deemed “feudal.” But an American scholar, galvanized in part by those rampages, embarked on a mission to collect and preserve the remnants of Tibetan culture.

headline: Rescuing a Vietnam Casualty: Johnson’s Legacy
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Luci Baines Johnson leaned forward in her father’s private suite at the L.B.J. Presidential Library, her voice breaking as she recounted the “agony of Vietnam” that engulfed Lyndon Baines Johnson and the pain she feels to this day of witnessing his presidency judged through the prism of a failed war.

headline: Union Hears From Potential Leaders
text: NEW ORLEANS — The N.B.A. players union, which has been without an executive director since Billy Hunter was fired a year ago, gathered Saturday afternoon for a two-hour meeting during which candidates for the position gave presentations and answered questions from about 30 players, including the Knicks’ Carmelo Anthony.

headline: ‘Las Marthas’: Debutantes in Laredo, Surprisingly Colonial
text: Most contemporary entertainment set along the Mexican border tends to focus on the brutal drug wars that have killed scores of thousands. Consider the film “No Country for Old Men,” or the FX series “The Bridge.” And with the exception of the occasional hard-driving female detective, women in these stories tend to be passive figures or the victims of grisly violence.

headline: Elite Couple’s Valentine: Be Mine but Be Rested
text: On the sixth anniversary of their first date, Ashton Eaton and Brianne Thiesen-Eaton skipped the fancy dinner and were in bed by 9 p.m., forgoing romance for much-needed rest. A big afternoon awaited.

headline: The Confederate Washingtons
text: Abraham Lincoln must have been pained by the number of Washingtons on the other side during the Civil War. He idolized George Washington. One of the first books he read as a boy was Parson Weems’s apocryphal biography of the first president, and it made a lasting impression. Later, as a congressman, Lincoln made a pilgrimage to Washington’s Mount Vernon and regaled his friends afterward about the experience.

headline: The Next Colorado or Washington: Probably Not Here
text: EL PASO — It was not long after Gov. Rick Perry’s remarks that states should enact their own marijuana laws that social media sites began wondering if the theory of relativity was a sham or whether Pink Floyd’s estranged founder would finally rejoin the band.

headline: Pregnant Inmates Find Help to Ease Shift to World Outside
text: HOUSTON — At the “pregnancy tank” at the Harris County Jail, asking a female inmate “How much longer do you have?” can get a puzzled look in response. She could answer with a due date or an anticipated date of discharge from jail.

headline: Afghan Army’s Test Begins With Fight for Vital Highway
text: CHAK, Afghanistan — In a deserted village off Highway 1, southwest of Kabul, an Afghan Army bomb disposal team was unearthing its 15th bomb of the day when sniper shots began to rain down.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 15, 2014
After Unexpected Climb Into Playoff, Bulgarian Is King of the Rock
text: Ivan Cheparinov won a three-way playoff to take the title at the 12th Tradewise Gibraltar Chess Festival this month.

headline: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund Trust and Estate Donors
text: TRUSTS

headline: Fund Provided Relief, and Then Readers Gave Even More
text: Once again, a host of empathetic readers and donors helped those seeking a change in their lives, with their contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund during its 102nd campaign.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 16, 2014
text: “Nobody wanted that war less than Lyndon Johnson. No matter how hard he tried, he didn’t seem to be able to get out of that quagmire. Not only did he not get out of it in his lifetime, but his legacy indeed has that weight of the world on it.”

headline: Slave No More
text: As the runway revolves, one front-row fashion fixture ponders how practical dressing has come to feel like the most modern of ideas, and why designers haven’t quite caught on.

headline: Corrections: February 16, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Adam Rose and Peter McQuillan
text: Adam R. Rose, a son of Sandra Priest Rose of Rye, N.Y., and the late Frederick P. Rose, was married Tuesday evening to Peter R. McQuillan, the son of Celia M. McQuillan of Boynton Beach, Fla., and the late Richard J. McQuillan. Betsy Gotbaum, a friend of the couple who until 2009 was the public advocate of the City of New York, became a Universal Life minister for the occasion and officiated at the couple’s Manhattan apartment.

headline: Danielle McFall, Schuyler Weiss
text: Danielle Renée McFall and Schuyler Sussman Weiss are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Nikki L. DeBlosi at the Park restaurant in New York.

headline: Eve Weston, Zachary Pincus-Roth
text: Eve Meryl Weston and Zachary Pincus-Roth are to be married Sunday at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in San Diego, where Rabbi Wayne D. Dosick will officiate in the Robert Paine Scripps Forum for Science, Society and the Environment.

headline: Delia Pais and Joseph Kristol

headline: What’s On Today?
text: 8 P.M. (Telemundo) TOP CHEF ESTRELLAS Eight Hispanic celebrities — above from left, Nancy Álvarez, David Chocarro, Erika De La Rosa and Christian Chávez, along with Fernando Arau, Christian de la Campa, Lorena Herrera and Cynthia Olavarría — demonstrate their culinary skills in an effort to win $100,000 for charity in this new Spanish-language series, based on Bravo’s “Top Chef” franchise. The actress Aylín Mújica hosts; the chefs Lorena García, Jaime Martin Del Campo and Ramiro Arvizu are the judges. In a twist, eliminated contestants will become sous chefs instead of going home. “Suelta La Sopa Extra,” at 10, features recaps with cast members and behind-the-scenes footage.

headline: At Asia Air Show, Plenty of Competition for Sales of Drones
text: SINGAPORE — While the supersonic jets, attack helicopters and surface-to-air missiles longer than a stretch limousine wowed an estimated 80,000 people who attended the final days of the Singapore Airshow over the weekend, it was a small, silent and unarmed weapon that took center stage as major players in the Southeast Asia weapons market hawked their wares.

headline: Preen: Fall 2014 RTW
text: London

headline: In Carolina Herrera They Trust
text: When Michelle Obama wore a Carolina Herrera dress, with a scoop front lacy embroidered top and “French blue” ball skirt, to greet President François Hollande of France at the White House, she could not have given a better fillip to New York Fashion Week.

headline: Jason Wu Debuts at Hugo Boss
text: Men’s wear companies expanding their female lines seem to be a strong fashion trend. Even before Ralph Lauren made his bold New York Fashion Week statement by showing a new female Polo range, Hugo Boss, the German men’s fashion powerhouse, had tapped Jason Wu to expand and clarify its women’s collection.

headline: Anna Sui: Asia Through Western Eyes
text: The idea of designers with Asian roots being inspired by a Western parody of their countries’ clothes would have been unthinkable a decade ago, but fusion fashion is fast following the food version.

headline: Reed Krakoff: Fusing Luxury and Minimalism
text: Reed Krakoff has finally found his comfort zone for modern style. His collection for winter 2014 was all about a rare but important species: the WWWs, or the “wealthy who work.”

headline: Lindsey Jacobellis Again Comes Up Short in Snowboard Cross
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Again, there was nothing in front of Lindsey Jacobellis but open snow, a finish line and a mountain of possibility. She was in the lead, a pack of women chasing with little hope of catching the most accomplished female snowboard-cross rider in history.

headline: Coach’s New Designer Puts the Emphasis on American Luxury
text: When Bonnie Cashin, the inventor of American sportswear, worked at Coach from 1962 to 1975, she revolutionized the handbag, giving it color, practical inside pockets for a dynamic new woman and the silver toggle — an early brand hallmark — that was inspired by the hood fastening on her convertible.

headline: Marchesa Goes to the Scottish Highlands
text: Could Marchesa, a fashion child of the red carpet, really be pulling back from celebrity and migrating to the Scottish Highlands? The most immediate statement from Keren Craig and Georgina Chapman might have been the colors, inspired by copper pans, a fiery hearth, smoky fog and cinnamon in the soup. It all seemed a long way from the duo’s favored Los Angeles.

text: London

text: 1889: A Church Scandal

headline: The Dog’s One Big Headache, but My Kids Adore Her
text: Our dog, who is nervous, incontinent and prone to other “accidents,” has been a liability since Day 1. The sensible thing for me to do would be to find her a good new home, which I’m sure I could do. But not only do I feel like that would be a failure on my part, I also suspect it might send the message to my kids that problematic family members can be cast off when they become burdensome. As an older parent, I need to consider these things carefully.

text: KATMANDU, Nepal — A Nepal Airlines plane bound for the city of Jumla from Katmandu, the capital, crashed in the forests of western Nepal on Sunday, almost certainly killing all 18 people aboard, officials said.

headline: Difficult Day for South Koreans as Native Son Wins Gold, for Russia
text: SEOUL, South Korea — When the short-track speed skater Viktor Ahn waved the Russian flag on his victory lap and sang the Russian national anthem on Saturday after winning the gold medal in the men’s 1,000 meters at Winter Olympics on Saturday, it was a poignant scene for South Koreans.

headline: Bombing of Tourist Bus Kills at Least Three in Sinai
text: CAIRO — At least two South Korean tourists and their Egyptian driver were killed on Sunday when an explosion ripped through a tour bus in a resort town in the Sinai Peninsula, in what officials said was the first deadly attack on tourists by militants in Egypt in at least three years.

text: Greg Mankiw has written another defense of the 0.1 percent — and this one is kind of amazing.

headline: Disruptions: Using Addictive Games to Build Better Brains
text: First it was Doodle Jump. Then Dots. And now — will it never end? — Flappy Bird.

headline: Iraqi Cleric Says Again He’ll Quit Politics
text: BAGHDAD — Moktada al-Sadr, the anti-American Shiite cleric who became one of Iraq’s most powerful political leaders, said he was withdrawing from politics and would no longer be represented in the Iraqi government or Parliament.

headline: Phil Kessel’s Hat Trick Gives Americans a Win
text: SOCHI, Russia — Both goaltenders making their Sochi Games debuts in Sunday’s round-robin game between the United States and Slovenia had a certain measure of international success in 2010.

headline: Christopher Raeburn
text: Christopher Raeburn is known for repurposing materials in exciting ways. At London Fashion Week, Suzy Menkes talked with the designer about his vision and the future of his work.

headline: ‘Black Coal, Thin Ice’ Wins Top Prize at Berlin Festival
text: A Chinese film noir, “Black Coal, Thin Ice,” directed by Diao Yinan, took the Golden Bear prize for best feature film at the Berlin Film Festival, while “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” a period caper set in interwar Europe took the Silver Bear Grand Jury Prize.

headline: A Harrowing Trip, Far From the Runways
text: Never let it be said that the Brits don’t have a sense of irony. Whether by design or odd coincidence, the models in the Marios Schwab show here on Sunday morning strutted out to the strains of the Doors’ “Riders on the Storm,” which drew a wry smile from more than a few people sitting in the front row.

headline: The Dutch Speedskaters Are Thrilled, the Americans Baffled
text: SOCHI, Russia — It was another tale of two speedskating teams here on Sunday night, with the Dutch team sweeping the podium yet again in the women’s 1,500 meters and the United States coming up empty-handed.

headline: South Africans in Mine Rescued and Then Arrested
text: Emergency crews in South Africa rescued 11 miners who were trapped while working illegally in an abandoned gold mine near Johannesburg on Sunday, but other miners decided to stay underground to avoid being arrested, emergency workers said.

headline: Protesters Vacate Kiev’s City Hall in Deal for Amnesty
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Ending an occupation of City Hall here that began in December, Ukrainian protesters cemented an amnesty deal with the authorities on Sunday amid signs that both sides in a volatile political crisis were seeking to reduce tensions.

headline: Russian Skier Who Broke Her Spine Is Moved to a German Hospital
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A day after a six-and-a-half-hour operation to repair her spine, which was fractured when she fell during a training run, the Russian ski cross racer Maria Komissarova was transferred to a hospital in Munich, where she will receive additional treatment, the Russian Olympic Committee said Sunday.

headline: Paul Smith: Fall 2014 RTW
text: London

headline: Kerry Implores Indonesia on Climate Change Peril
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Secretary of State John Kerry urged Indonesia on Sunday to take steps to combat climate change, warning that failure to act would jeopardize the nation’s resources and damage its economy.

headline: ‘Lego Movie’ Tops Box Office, With ‘About Last Night’ Strong Second
text: Bookended by Valentine’s Day and President’s Day, the weekend was a strong one for Hollywood, despite a flatlining “Winter’s Tale” and worries that winter storms in parts of the United States would keep moviegoers on their sofas. Certifying itself as a full-blown phenomenon, “The Lego Movie” (Warner Brothers) will take in a projected $60 million between Friday and Monday, for a two-week domestic total of roughly $140 million. “About Last Night” (Sony), one of three 1980s-era remakes to arrive over the weekend, was expected to be the No. 1 newcomer by selling a strong $30.2 million in tickets. Co-starring the popular comedian Kevin Hart, “About Last Night” cost $13 million to make. Third-place “RoboCop” from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Sony was a disappointment considering that it had a production budget of at least $100 million; if analyst projections hold, the science-fiction remake will take in $25.1 million over the long weekend, for a total since opening on Wednesday of about $30 million. (A Sony spokeswoman noted that “RoboCop” is performing “very strongly” overseas, where it has taken in more than $70 million since opening earlier this month.) “The Monuments Men,” also from Sony, was expected to be a solid fourth, generating a projected $17.3 million, for a two-week total of about $46 million. Analysts estimated that Universal’s poorly reviewed remake of “Endless Love” would take in about $15.2 million, which is fine for a lightly marketed movie that cost about $20 million to make. But Akiva Goldsman’s “Winter’s Tale” (Warner) bombed badly, taking in a projected $8.5 million. Adapted from the 1983 magical realism novel, “Winter’s Tale” cost Warner and financing partner Village Roadshow at least $45 million to make.

headline: Kerry on Climate Change
text: On Sunday, Secretary of State John Kerry delivered remarks on climate change to an audience of students in Jakarta, Indonesia. He accused climate change deniers of burying their heads in the sand.

headline: Obama Condemns Uganda’s Tough Antigay Measure
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — President Obama on Sunday condemned a measure to criminalize homosexuality in Uganda, publicly warning the country’s president that such discrimination could harm its relationship with the United States.

headline: Mulberry Bags Raise Eyebrows
text: LONDON — “They call me ‘bag lady,' ” said Cara Delevingne, better known in the fashion world as Ms. Eyebrows. And on Sunday, the model of the moment staged a handbag happening, surrounded by greyhounds and a fairy tale forest created by the British set designer Michael Howells.

headline: Deadly Blast on a Bus in Egypt
text: A television news feed captured the explosion of a tourist bus in Saba, Egypt, that killed at least four people.

headline: Obama on Uganda’s Antigay Bill
text: President Obama said the bill, likely to be signed by Uganda’s president, would “be more than an affront and a danger to the gay community in Uganda.”

headline: Author Resigned to Ill Fate of Book in India
text: After Penguin Books India recently decided to recall and pulp all copies of “The Hindus: An Alternative History” in the face of legal action, the book’s author, Wendy Doniger, was not surprised.

headline: A Mad Dash for Salt Rescues Olympic Slopes
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A senior adviser to the Sochi Olympics convened an emergency meeting late last week with top winter sports officials at the Park Inn hotel in the Alpine village here.

headline: Jazzman, Newly Lauded, Stays Contained but Loose
text: About an hour into his Town Hall concert on Friday night, Gregory Porter, a good man singing good-man music on Valentine’s Day, started to ease out of Nat Adderley’s “Work Song.” He gripped the microphone stand at chest level, humming slowly in a blues scale, with the same level, deliberate, ethical steadiness he’d put into everything else up to that point. His band played a vamp, waiting for signals. The humming seemed as if it could go on for a while.

headline: Kerry Blames Syrian Government for Deadlocked Talks
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Secretary of State John Kerry issued a statement on Sunday night that blamed the Syrian government for the deadlock in peace talks but asserted that the United States remained “committed to the Geneva process.”

text: London

headline: A Year After Acid Attack, Bolshoi Director to Visit New York
text: Sergei Filin, the Bolshoi Ballet artistic director who was wounded in an acid attack last year, will come to New York in April as one of the judges in the Youth America Grand Prix ballet competition, officials from the contest announced.

text: Here (pdf).

text: Among the highlights were Bode Miller’s bronze medal, a victorious Czech woman’s painted-on mustache and a postponement of a biathlon because of fog.

headline: Don’t Mess With Malvolio
text: How do you exact revenge on people who have cruelly tricked you and humiliated you in front of the woman you work for and hope to marry? You steal the show, that’s how.

headline: London Fashion Week: House of Holland Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Fighters for Freedom Abroad Found Another Battle at Home
text: The short version of the relationship between the military and racial equality goes like this: “In 1948, President Harry S. Truman issued an executive order desegregating the armed forces, and that spurred the civil rights movement.” The documentary “Breath of Freedom,” Monday night on the Smithsonian Channel, is clumsily structured and unnecessarily sentimental, but at least it puts across how oversimplified that narrative is.

headline: A Program That Honors Two Vital Mentors
text: If you’ve managed to run your own dance company for 20 years, chances are you haven’t made it alone. Pascal Rioult, the director of Rioult Dance New York, had some serious mentors as a young artist: May O’Donnell and Martha Graham, with whom he danced in the 1980s and ’90s.

headline: Honing Their Chances With Photos and Wit
text: SOCHI, Russia — Each ice dance and pairs figure skating team at the Olympics will have no more than seven minutes of ice time, if they are lucky, to prove to a panel of judges and the world that they are a single unit, a duo that can twizzle, trot and leap harmoniously as one.

headline: Disparate Backgrounds but a Common Thread
text: When two dancers as eloquently meticulous as Elena Demyanenko and Dai Jian decide to choreograph a work, you know that you’re in for silky fluidity: movement that emanates from deep under the skin, where joints are loose, and the spine is airy.

headline: A Bit of Sondheim, a Bit of Judy Garland, and a Whole Lot of ‘Glee’
text: A garrulous apple-cheeked farm boy with a grin on his face, stars in his eyes, and Judy Garland in his heart: that describes the Broadway and TV star Jonathan Groff in his New York concert debut at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series on Saturday evening. The only thing wrong with that description is the word “boy.” Mr. Groff may look and act 15, but he is 28 and has amassed an impressive list of theatrical and TV credits, including “Spring Awakening,” “Glee,” and the new HBO series “Looking.”

headline: Bandit Buddies Separated by a Woman
text: Bikram and Bala, the outlaw heroes of “Gunday,” are all hair spray, body oil and swagger. Their chests — no shirts can contain them — glisten; and their muscles bulge as they grimace and run in slow motion. As for their personalities, it takes an hour or so before you discern, or even care, which one is which: Bikram (Ranveer Singh) is shorter, and his hair does more tricks; Bala (Arjun Kapoor) has a temper.

headline: 40 Kilometers to Glory
text: Sweden, Russia and France won medals in the men’s 4x10-kilometer cross-country race in Krasnaya Polanya, Russia.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Feb. 17
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Fighting the Last Macro War? (Slightly Wonkish)
text: Oh, good — Noah Smith has given me some more economic methodology stuff to waste time on, instead of turning to my various deadlines. OK, I’ll make this shortish.

headline: Family Life Was Complicated, Then the Body Turned Up
text: The characters in Laura Lippman’s “After I’m Gone” are so well drawn that it’s easy to forget why they happen to be connected. Almost all of them are strong, willful women, starting with this novel’s matriarch: Bambi Brewer, née Gottschalk, a raving beauty whose role in the story spans more than 50 years. Even as a teenager at a high school dance, Bambi is aware of how valuable her allure can be. She plays it to her best advantage, even after life hands her an exceedingly raw deal.

headline: A Breezy Chameleon, Blurring Social Borders
text: When the literary scholar George Hutchinson was in the archives at Howard University one afternoon a decade ago, he thought he knew which story of a neglected African-American woman writer he was chasing.

headline: Tubby Stayman Feted for Her Charity Work and Her Play
text: Tubby Stayman turned 90 two weeks ago. The milestone was celebrated with 34 family members in Palm Beach, Fla., her winter retreat.

headline: Matthew Williamson: Fall 2014 RTW
text: London

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Drama Plays On
text: Just over a month ago, on Jan. 14, the warring parties of the Minnesota Orchestra — management and musicians — agreed to a treaty, of sorts, though in some ways it seems more like a truce. The peace still feels all too tentative.

headline: A Romance From Beyond Mars and Venus
text: CW series are like nesting dolls. At the center of each is a weepy young-adult melodrama, hidden inside a vampire show, a superhero show or a costume drama. The latest, “Star Crossed,” on Monday night, uses science fiction as its shell.

headline: Behind Meryl Davis and Charlie White, U.S. Is Close to Its First Ice Dance Gold
text: SOCHI, Russia — The ice dance teams train together in suburban Detroit, tossing world titles back and forth like jugglers. One seems certain to win a gold medal after Monday’s free skate.

headline: Bach’s ‘Art of Fugue’ Inspires Art of Ballet
text: LONDON — You could assemble a rewardingly hybrid festival of all the choreography of note that’s been made to the music of Bach. His scores welcome dance anachronisms: point work or bare feet, jeans or leotards.

text: London

text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This is only David Gray’s second time out in The New York Times, and here he is, telling us what to SAY. Should we repeat after him?

text: Nuclear proliferation, religious militancy and income inequality are all major threats to Middle East stability. Sadly, a new one is brewing: water scarcity.
