headline: Transgender Former Member of Italian Parliament Detained in Sochi
text: SOCHI, Russia — Vladimir Luxuria, a transgender former member of the Italian Parliament, was detained by the Russian authorities Sunday after holding up a sign that read, “Gay Is OK,” at Olympic Park, the leader of an Italian gay-rights group said.

headline: Real Discipline in School
text: LAST month, Maryland became one of the first states to tackle the widespread injustice of overly harsh discipline policies in our schools, adopting regulations that require an end to practices that have doubled the number of out-of-school suspensions for African-American students in the past decade.

headline: A Berlusconi Reminder as Italy Faces Another Unelected Premier
text: ROME — It speaks to the strange state of Italian democracy that Silvio Berlusconi, the disgraced former prime minister, is now claiming the high moral ground in politics — and that his claim is not completely without merit as Italy prepares for its third consecutive unelected prime minister.

headline: For Yankees, Big Money Can’t Buy Certainty
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Soon after Mark Teixeira became the first high-priced veteran to arrive in training camp and concede that “I’d be lying if I said there wasn’t” some anxiety about his surgically repaired right wrist, C. C. Sabathia seconded the motion that uncertainty might be one of the few certainties about the 2014 Yankees.

headline: Reframing ‘Obamacare’
text: As Democrats head into the 2014 midterm elections, they are taking a new approach to talking about the Affordable Care Act: acknowledging that the law has problems, and offering their own solutions.

headline: On Health Act, Democrats Run in Fix-It Mode
text: WASHINGTON — The ad supporting Representative Ann Kirkpatrick, Democrat of Arizona, opens with a montage of Americana Main Streets, followed by the green fields and dirt roads of the West — the “small towns and wide-open spaces,” the narrator explains, where Ms. Kirkpatrick “listens and learns.”

headline: Common Core Curriculum Now Has Critics on the Left
text: The Common Core has been applauded by education leaders and promoted by the Obama administration as a way to replace a hodgepodge of state standards with one set of rigorous learning goals. Though 45 states and the District of Columbia have signed on to them since 2010, resistance came quickly, mostly from right-leaning states, where some leaders and political action groups have protested what they see as a federal takeover of local classrooms.

headline: Mary Katrantzou’s High-Heeled Loafers
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: In Egypt, a Chasm Grows Between Young and Old
text: CAIRO — Shady el-Ghazaly Harb says he has given up trying to help the military-backed government address its worries about losing the support of young Egyptians.

headline: A Watchful Eye in Hospitals
text: HANOVER, N.H. — DESPITE the intensely personal moments that happen in hospitals, patient privacy can be elusive. Hospitals are multimillion-dollar corporations that look like shopping malls and function like factories. Doctors knock on exam room doors to signal they are about to enter — not to ask permission. The curtain that encircles the hospital bed always lets in a crack of light.

headline: Barons of Broadband
text: Last week’s big business news was the announcement that Comcast, a gigantic provider of cable TV and high-speed Internet service, has reached a deal to acquire Time Warner Cable, which is merely huge. If regulators approve the deal, Comcast will be an overwhelmingly dominant player in the business, with around 30 million subscribers.

headline: Florida Self-Defense Law Complicated Jury’s Job in Michael Dunn Trial
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — In failing to acquit or convict Michael Dunn on the most significant charge — the premeditated murder of a teenager in a dispute over loud music — a jury on Saturday may have run headlong into the breadth and reach of Florida’s contentious self-defense law.

headline: In Praise of Disregard
text: Perhaps this experience sounds familiar to you: Sometimes, particularly during elections or other politically feverish moments, I spend many hours reading about the issues; but I have a tendency to dwell on stories I find truly distressing, such as tales of leaked videos showing the blunt discrepancy between a politician’s on- and off-screen selves. I am drawn to the most hopeless headlines, the reports that make humans seem like wolves, the kind that make it impossible to stifle my expletives. I feel it physiologically: My adrenaline surges, my breaths get quick and short, and I pace and fume around the apartment trying to get rid of this nervous energy.

headline: Scenes of Confusion
text: This is the second part of an eight-part series.

headline: Labor Regroups in South After VW Vote
text: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Volkswagen labor officials in Germany renewed calls on Sunday for the company’s three-year-old plant here to establish a German-style works council even though its workers voted days earlier against unionizing.

headline: At Church Service, Pastor Makes No Mention of de Blasio or Arrest
text: The pastor whose arrest last week has turned into a political headache for Mayor Bill de Blasio appeared publicly on Sunday for the first time since the incident, leading a rousing service in Brooklyn but saying nothing about his arrest — or the controversy that has entangled the mayor.

headline: Regulatory Favoritism in North Carolina
text: North Carolina citizens have good reason to wonder just whom their environmental regulators are trying to protect. The state’s Department of Environment and Natural Resources has engaged in a series of maneuvers that seem designed to protect the state’s largest utility, Duke Energy, from paying big fines for water pollution from coal ash ponds and meeting reasonable requirements that it move toxic coal ash to lined landfills away from rivers and lakes used for drinking water and recreation.

headline: Stealthily, Comcast Fortifies Its Arsenal
text: Big media companies are generally warships, bristling with firepower and declaring their might long before they attack. But Comcast, which is headed toward being one of the biggest of them all, is much more like a submarine, silently running beneath the waves and making its presence known only when it is too late for its targets.

headline: The New College Campus
text: Imagine meeting someone who says she works at a university. Some years ago, it would have been fairly safe to assume that she was a professor, and a member of the middle class with enviable job security. Not anymore. Two reports make clear that the nature of the college work force has changed substantially, possibly to the detriment of educational quality.

headline: Japan’s Growth Slows, Raising Concerns About Obstacles That Lie Ahead
text: TOKYO — The Japanese economy grew at a tepid rate of 1.0 percent in the final quarter of 2013, falling short of analyst expectations and heightening concerns that Japan’s recovery may not be strong enough to weather further challenges expected this year.

headline: New York’s Broken Parole System
text: The fact of a crime never changes, but the person who commits it can, and often does. This is the basic principle of parole — that while people must be punished for their wrongdoing, most are capable of growing, changing and rejoining society before the end of their sentence.

headline: One Group Sees Silver Lining in Winter’s Storm Clouds: Meteorologists
text: Brian A. Colle woke up at 1 a.m. on Thursday and headed out into the snow. Using plates of glass he had been storing in a freezer in his garage, he collected snowflakes for analysis with a powerful microscope.

headline: The Games’ Unfamiliar Honor (Even Among Its Recipients)
text: SOCHI, Russia — Gold. Silver. Bronze. Paper?

headline: Magnet Schools Find a Renewed Embrace in Cities
text: MIAMI — Nearly five decades ago, as racial tension raged in cities, magnet schools were introduced here and elsewhere as an alternative to court-ordered busing in the hope that specialized theme schools would slow white flight and offer options to racial minorities zoned for low-performing schools.

headline: Turnabout in Bolivia as Economy Rises From Instability
text: LA PAZ, Bolivia — Argentina’s currency has plunged, setting off global worries about developing economies. Brazil is struggling to shake concerns over years of sluggish growth. Venezuela, which sits atop the world’s largest oil reserves, has one of the world’s highest inflation rates. Farther afield, countries like Turkey and South Africa have watched their currencies suffer as investors search for safer returns elsewhere.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 17, 2014
text: “It’s kind of like the one you get for participation. It’s really nice. I mean, it’s not the same as medaling, of course.”

headline: In Kansas, Right Joins Left to Halt Bill on Gays
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A bill that would have allowed individuals to refuse to provide business services to same-sex couples in Kansas because of religious beliefs met a surprising and quick end last week when conservative senators sided with liberal advocates in saying that the measure promoted discrimination.

headline: De Blasio Strikes Conciliatory Note on Pre-K
text: ALBANY — A strong winter sun streamed through the green and yellow stained-glass windows at Wilborn Temple as worshipers swayed and clapped to rousing hymns and chants of “Praise the Lord.”

headline: Body of Michele Savoia, Fashion Designer, Found in Hudson River
text: The body of a fashion designer known for his flamboyant vintage clothing was pulled from the Hudson River on Sunday, days after he apparently slipped and fell into the water while trying to board his boat at the Chelsea Piers, the police and a friend said.

headline: Sleepless in New York
text: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Downton’ Recap, Episode 7: Advice From the Dowager
text: [Programming note: this week’s regularly scheduled recap of “Downton Abbey” will not be seen, so that we can bring you this edition of “Dear Dowager Countess,” the popular advice column that is syndicated in hundreds of fictional British newspapers of the early 20th century. Lady Violet, the Dowager Countess of Grantham, is a member of the aristocracy, president of the Downton Cottage Hospital and a multiple winner of the Best Bloom in the Village award. She is not a licensed therapist and her views do not necessarily represent those of this newspaper or anyone born after World War I.]

headline: ‘Tonight’ Show Returns to New York After Nearly 42 Years
text: On Monday night, for the first time in almost 42 years, NBC’s “Tonight” show will be hosted from New York. The show, which invented the form of entertainment known as late-night television, is returning to the place of its birth: Manhattan.

headline: Polk Awards Honor Articles on N.S.A. Surveillance
text: Four journalists who revealed the National Security Agency’s vast electronic data mining operation were among the winners of the George Polk Awards in Journalism for 2013, announced on Sunday by Long Island University, which administers the prizes.

headline: Merkel Backs Plan to Keep European Data in Europe
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has embraced proposals to create European data networks that would keep emails and other communications on the European side of the Atlantic, farther from prying American eyes, and said she would raise the matter this week with President François Hollande of France.

headline: Science Linking Drought to Global Warming Remains Matter of Dispute
text: In delivering aid to drought-stricken California last week, President Obama and his aides cited the state as an example of what could be in store for much of the rest of the country as human-caused climate change intensifies.

headline: Crossing His Fingers, Yankees’ Teixeira Counts on Full Comeback From Wrist Injury
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Robinson Cano is gone, Derek Jeter is trying to come back from a twice-broken ankle at 39, and Alex Rodriguez is suspended. In other words, the Yankees’ infield, once a dominant feature of a World Series champion, has been sacked by free agency, age, infirmity and penalty.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 16, 2014
A Poet Mines Memories of Drug Addiction
text: Gil Fagiani pulled out a copy of “White Lightning,” a tabloid from 1972, whose yellowed, brittle pages declared revolution. Inside, he pointed to a polemic he wrote headlined “Racism and Dope.” It described how he — a heroin addict with white, middle-class roots — was let off by the police with a warning inside an East Harlem tenement while his would-be connection, a Puerto Rican ex-con, was stripped, arrested and clubbed.

headline: Tunisian B-Boys’ Biggest Battle: Keeping Youths From Extremism
text: BEN AOUN, Tunisia — The youth center in this small provincial town is brimming with energy on a Saturday morning. Teenage girls in pink tracksuits compete in a fencing tournament in one room, and soccer teams play on a bright emerald green patch on the far side of the compound. But the most intense activity is inside a classroom where youths of all ages are crammed around a dance floor watching break dancers test their skills and wits against one another to a thumping music track.

headline: Fallout From the Auto Union’s Defeat
text: In recent months, a majority of workers at the Volkswagen car assembly plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., reportedly signed cards in favor of joining the United Auto Workers.

headline: Abbas, Talking to Israeli Students About Peace, Finds a Receptive Audience
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — A decade ago, after the suicide bombings of the second Palestinian uprising, Israelis mostly came to Ramallah and the Mukata, the West Bank headquarters of the Palestinian leadership here, in tanks or armored military vehicles. On Sunday, about 300 Israeli students and youth leaders arrived in busloads to meet President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority for a conversation about the peace process.

headline: ‘Girls’ Recap: A Beach House and a Fight
text: How perfect is it that the Shoshi Games tumblr was born mere days ago?

headline: Love Fine With Timberwolves but Hungry to Win
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The amateur mind-reading bothers Kevin Love the most, even though he caused most of it.

headline: Reporting From the Web’s Underbelly
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the last year, Eastern European cybercriminals have stolen Brian Krebs’s identity a half dozen times, brought down his website, included his name and some unpleasant epithets in their malware code, sent fecal matter and heroin to his doorstep, and called a SWAT team to his home just as his mother was arriving for dinner.

headline: One Step Goes Awry, and Mulder’s Pitching Comeback Ends
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — Mark Mulder was always proud that the competition never drove him from the game. When Mulder was healthy, he was a force. His shoulder betrayed him after 103 major league victories in his 20s, and he accepted the occupational hazard. He did not miss baseball, he said, because he knew his body would not let him play it.

headline: South Africa’s Growing Pains
text: South Africa — the democratic version fathered by Nelson Mandela — turns 20 this year. Like most adolescents emerging into adulthood, it has issues. It could use more impulse control, better self-esteem, less conformity to peer pressure and some plain old parental wisdom. For those of us who watch and root for this struggling young democracy, the year began with a disappointing setback.

headline: The Highs and Lows of City Life
text: Early this month, Michael M. Grynbaum of The New York Times took a look at New York’s “Bunyanesque” mayor, Bill de Blasio, and how he takes in his new job from his elevated viewpoint. At 6-foot-5⅞, Mr. de Blasio is the tallest mayor in the city’s modern history, requiring City Hall to make a series of ergonomic adjustments. So we wondered about other New Yorkers, how they navigate the city daily, and whether for them bigness is a burden too. Here are some of the stories — edited for space — that we heard from New Yorkers, tall or not:

headline: What to Watch: Monday, Feb. 17
text: FIGURE SKATING The Americans Meryl Davis and Charlie White, who won the Olympic short dance Sunday, are a solid free dance performance away from a gold medal. Davis and White, the reigning world champions, earned 78.89 points and lead the 2010 gold medalists, Tessa Virtue and Scott Moir of Canada, by 2.56. The two teams train together in the Detroit area and share a coach. NBCSN, 10 a.m.

headline: Corrections: February 17, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Punching Above Its Weight, Upstart Netflix Pokes at HBO
text: On the night of the Golden Globes ceremony last month, Netflix and HBO held dueling parties at the Beverly Hilton hotel. Bono and Julia Roberts mingled underneath a bejeweled tent as Netflix, the upstart streaming service, joined forces for the party with the Weinstein Company and celebrated a small piece of history — its first Globe, for “House of Cards,” its splashy entrant into original programming. At HBO’s party, Matt Damon and Lady Gaga sipped drinks by the pool as the cable network toasted its two awards, pushing its total to 101.

headline: U.S. in Nordic Combined: It’s About Now
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — It is one of the rarest of rarities: Americans attempting to win medals in Nordic combined in consecutive Winter Games.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Longtime Critic of Police Policies Basks in a de Blasio Moment
text: If Mayor Bill de Blasio’s announcement on Jan. 30 that his administration would agree to reform the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk tactic was a stunning about-face for a city that has promoted aggressive policing for nearly two decades, there was a smaller surprise, for those with long memories, in his choice of one guest. Sitting near the mayor was Eric L. Adams, a former police officer, longtime irritant to several mayors and police commissioners, former state senator, and now, Brooklyn borough president.

headline: Saving an Endangered British Species: The Pub
text: LONDON — One by one, the pubs are disappearing in Hampstead, a jewel-box village of cobbled lanes and Georgian homes that has become one of this city’s most fashionable neighborhoods. The Nags Head has become a realty office. The King of Bohemia is now a clothing shop. The Hare & Hounds has been replaced with an apartment building.

headline: Biathlon Penalty Loop Is Like the Dunce Cap of the Olympics
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — For many Olympians, there is no place more wretched these days than a 150-meter patch of snow, ringed with bright red cones, that sits in the corner of the biathlon stadium.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Washington’s Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Writers Guild Plans Forum on Affordable Care Act
text: LOS ANGELES — On Tuesday night, an expected crowd of 100 or so screenwriters and others will gather in Lower Manhattan at the headquarters of the Writers Guild of America East to hear thoughts about the Affordable Care Act and its place in comedy and drama.

headline: Hudson, Gallerist and Nurturer of Artists, Dies at 63
text: Hudson, a former dancer and performance artist known only by his last name, who went on to become one of the most prescient, independent-minded and admired gallerists of his generation, died on Feb. 10 at his home in Manhattan. He was 63.

headline: Venezuelan Leader Announces Expulsion of 3 U.S. Officials
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — After several days of student-led protests against his government, President Nicolás Maduro said Sunday that he was expelling three American consular officials who he said had been visiting universities here.

headline: Bollywood Superstar’s Movie Gets Tangled in Electoral Politics
text: NEW DELHI — For most Bollywood movies, earning 1 billion rupees at the box office would be seen as a resounding success.

headline: Jacques le Sourd, Theater Critic, Dies at 64
text: Jacques le Sourd, a theater critic whose Broadway and Off Broadway reviews for The Journal News of Westchester were syndicated nationally in the Gannett Company’s newspaper chain for three decades, died on Feb. 5 in Preston, Lancashire, England. He was 64.

headline: Water-Cleaning Technology Could Help Farmers
text: FIREBAUGH, Calif. — The giant solar receiver installed on a wheat field here in California’s agricultural heartland slowly rotates to track the sun and capture its energy. The 377-foot array, however, does not generate electricity but instead creates heat used to desalinate water.

headline: Lashing Out
text: So much happens in the blink of an eye. A single flutter, a slow sweep downwards: What will a woman’s eyelashes reveal? Interest? Curiosity? Sexual chemistry? Ennui? Tenderness? Excitement? Or distress, as in that most famous Man Ray image of 1930-32, “Tears”? Those perfect globules of glass are clearly fake, but the eyelashes give pause for thought. How did their owner get such precise separation? Such fabulous length? Those wonderful eighth-note-shaped ends?

headline: Before Blaming the Robots, Let’s Get the Policy Right
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Caring for the Alzheimer’s Caregiver
text: Paul Divinigracia does not consider himself a saint. But to observe how he cares for his wife, Virgie, now 11 years into Alzheimer’s disease, you might think otherwise.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10 P.M. (13) LAS MARTHAS (2014) In the border town of Laredo, Tex., debutante season is centered on bicultural celebrations, many of them involving its city sister, Nuevo Laredo, Mexico. The pre-eminent event is the invitation-only Colonial Ball, hosted by the Society of Martha Washington, in which young women, most of them Mexican-American, make their debuts in elaborate colonial gowns — weighing as much as 100 pounds and costing up to $30,000 — representing figures from America’s revolutionary history. Their goal: to recreate a party hosted by Martha herself. In this “Independent Lens” documentary, the director Cristina Ibarra follows two of the debutantes — one from a prominent Laredo family, the other a newcomer from Mexico — as they prepare for this rite of passage. (Above, the debutante Laura Garza Hovel.)

headline: Electrifying Rivalry and Overheated Scoreboard in N.B.A. All-Star Game
text: NEW ORLEANS — After 45 minutes’ worth of pregame festivities that included a music concert, an appearance by Snoop Dogg, streamers that fell from the ceiling and player introductions, LeBron James finally christened the N.B.A. All-Star Game on Sunday night in familiar fashion: with a steal near midcourt, a handful of loping strides and a dunk with just the right amount of ferocity.

headline: Well-Conditioned St. John’s Runs Georgetown Out of the Garden
text: Throughout the course of its march back to respectability in the Big East, St. John’s came to rely on two numbers.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: The Stars Come Back Out
text: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: NBC Pushes Too Far in Bringing Bode Miller to Tears
text: Bode Miller had just tied for a bronze medal in the men’s super-G at the Olympics in Sochi, Russia, on Sunday and it was time to be interviewed. NBC had already established Miller’s quest as an emotional story line, putting a microphone on his wife, Morgan, to hear her reactions to his races, and having the couple sit for an interview with Tom Brokaw. He was being humanized — as the changed man, the family man, the mature 36-year-old whose brother had died last year.

headline: Indonesia Takes Aim at Australia Over Spying on Talks
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s foreign minister said Monday that it was a “bit mind-boggling” that the Australian intelligence agency had spied on his nation’s trade deliberations with American officials.

headline: Economic Growth in Thailand Cools to 0.6%
text: HONG KONG — It was, until recently, one of the fastest-growing economies in Asia. It shrugged off coups, street protests and natural disasters. And it earned the nickname “Teflon Thailand.”

headline: Ethiopian Co-Pilot Hijacks Jet, Then Asks for Asylum in Geneva
text: GENEVA — The co-pilot of an Ethiopian Airlines passenger jet en route to Rome from Ethiopia seized control of the Boeing 767-300 early on Monday and flew it to Geneva, where he asked for asylum, a spokesman for the Geneva police said.

headline: As Edgy Chinese Films Sweep Berlin Festival, Pride and Caution at Home
text: “After a very long wait, Chinese films have finally burst forth magnificently again in the world’s film festivals, with fireworks,” the state news agency Xinhua wrote. The proud statement was a play on the Chinese title for “Black Coal, Thin Ice,” the gritty detective movie by Diao Yinan that took the top award at the just-concluded 64th Berlin International Film Festival: “Fireworks in Daylight.”

headline: Differing Accounts of Recent Violence in Xinjiang
text: The ethnic polarization troubling the northwestern Chinese region of Xinjiang has brought a grim succession of bloody incidents pitting Uighurs against security forces – and has also been echoed in the vastly different interpretations from the government and from advocates of Uighur self-determination that invariably follow those incidents. The latest bloodshed has followed that pattern.

headline: A Note on Presidents’ Day
text: We are taking the day off on this national holiday — and, since many schools will be out this week, we are also suspending daily lesson plans until Monday, Feb. 24.

headline: The Hunter Collection
text: Alasdhair Willis is the creative director for Hunter, the English boot maker, and its new Hunter Original clothing. The advice from his wife, the designer Stella McCartney? Trust your instincts.

headline: For the Love of Art, and Money
text: LONDON — A record 413 million pounds of Impressionist and modern art sold at Sotheby’s and Christie’s in one week. Nearly £200,000 went for a canvas painted by a 24 year-old with a fire extinguisher a week later. Auctions of high-end artworks were booming in London in February, to be sure. But in the 21st century’s increasingly financialized market — where art is treated as an investment and where paintings are tracked and traded instantaneously — one has to ask, what does the word “collector” mean nowadays?

headline: Bouygues to Take 1.4 Billion Euro Write-Down on Its Alstom Stake
text: LONDON — The French conglomerate Bouygues said on Monday that it would take a 1.4 billion euro write-down on its stake in the transport and energy company Alstom.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Robert Draper on Wendy Davis and the Challenge of Biography
text: Robert Draper, a contributing writer for the magazine, is the author of this week’s cover story about the Texas gubernatorial candidate Wendy Davis. Draper is the author of “When the Tea Party Came to Town.” He last wrote for the magazine about the National Rifle Association.

headline: South Korean Lawmaker Jailed on Treason Charges
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean court sentenced an opposition lawmaker to 12 years in prison on Monday for forming a “revolutionary organization” and conspiring to start an armed revolt to overthrow the Seoul government in the event of war with North Korea.

headline: Waffle House Shows Atlanta How to Handle a Snowstorm
text: Atlanta’s second snow jam of 2014 shut down practically every business of every size in the city. But I don’t think we can entirely blame Mother Nature or even the governor this time for the lost revenue and customers we will all be adding up at the end of the month.

headline: Readers’ Comments on Freedom of Speech in India
text: NEW DELHI — Last week, Penguin, one of India’s biggest publishing houses, declared that it would withdraw and destroy remaining copies of a book on Hinduism written by Wendy Doniger after Dinanath Batra, a right-wing campaigner filed a lawsuit terming the book “dirty” and “perverse.”

text: Considered the last major set of trophies before the Academy Awards, the Baftas, the British version of the Oscars, were handed out on Sunday, and the winners may presage ours — or they may further muddle the race.

headline: Cornelius Gurlitt, German at Center of Art-Cache Case, Sets Up Website
text: BERLIN — Cornelius Gurlitt, the 81-year-old German who inherited a collection of drawings, prints and paintings from his father, an art dealer who worked for the Nazis, has set up a website to provide his side of the story.

headline: C.V. Starr and Partner Buy Health Care Concern in a $4.4 Billion Deal
text: Updated, 6:24 p.m. | A group of investors led by an affiliate of C. V. Starr & Company and the Swiss investment firm Partners Group announced on Monday that it had acquired MultiPlan, a health care cost management company.

headline: The Trouble With Being Abstruse (Slightly Wonkish)
text: Political scientists who write clearly for a broader audience are upset with Nick Kristof for saying that political scientists no longer write for a broader audience. I’m not going to get into that fight. I do want to register one point, however: In my field there is indeed a problem with abstruseness, with the many academics who never even try to put their thoughts in plain language.

text: The latest women’s collection from Burberry Prorsum at London fashion week.

headline: Medals, and Time, Slip Away
text: SOCHI, Russia — After finishing her 1,500-meter race Sunday, Heather Richardson stepped off the speedskating oval and buried her face in her hands. She did not have to say a thing. The leader board said it all.

headline: Fog Postpones Snowboard Cross and Biathlon Events
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — As fans gathered for the men’s snowboard cross race on Monday at the Winter Olympics, they could barely see beyond the finish line. Competitors headed to the starting area on a chairlift, but it was an ascent into a white unknown, the thick fog obscuring even the chair in front of them.

headline: Weekends Made for Maple
text: Adirondack maple syrup producers will open their maple farms and sugar bushes across the six-million-acre park for one of New York State’s tastiest traditions – Maple Weekends, this year on March 22 and 23 and March 29 and 30.

headline: Party’s New Leader Agrees to Form Government in Italy
text: ROME — Pledging to commit all his “enthusiasm, courage and energy” to the task, Matteo Renzi, the leader of the Democratic Party, said on Monday that he would try to form a new government that could stabilize Italy’s politics and economy.

text: 1889: Demonstration in Buda Pesth

headline: Threes, a New Addictive Puzzle Game
text: If I can just connect the red “2” card with the blue “1” card, and then slide together those “3’s,” I’ll be able to get another “12” and… Sorry, you’ll have to excuse me, I’m in the middle of another game of Threes, the latest game for iOS that I’m slightly obsessed with.

headline: Tepid Economic Growth in Japan
text: TOKYO — The Japanese economy grew at the tepid rate of 1 percent in the final quarter of 2013, data showed Monday, falling short of analysts’ expectations and heightening concerns that the country’s recovery might not be strong enough to weather an impending sales tax increase, a worsening trade balance and other problems expected this year.

headline: ‘Philomena’s’ Composer: Turning a Secret Into a Score
text: Having been nominated now six times in eight years, the composer Alexandre Desplat is a veteran of Academy campaigning. He called his latest Oscar-nominated work, the score for “Philomena,” among his most difficult assignments, and not only because it had more music than his first Oscar-nominated film, “The Queen.”

headline: 3 Who Worked at Barclays Face Charges in Libor Case
text: Updated, 7:16 p.m. | LONDON — Regulators in Britain said on Monday that they had begun criminal proceedings against three former Barclays employees suspected in the manipulation of a global benchmark interest rate.

headline: Standing Out Amid Monotony in Residential Design
text: David Boyle did not build his house out of shipping containers to be hip, though he does live in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He left the water pipes exposed not in pursuit of an industrial chic aesthetic, but to make them easier to fix.

headline: No Beauty Goes Unexplored in ‘La Clemenza di Tito’
text: Munich — Kirill Petrenko, the new general music director of the Bavarian State Opera, is enjoying a honeymoon with his audience. He assumed the post in September, fresh from conducting Wagner’s “Ring” cycle at the Bayreuth Festival, where he won a slew of accolades, even as Frank Castorf’s new production was roasted to a crisp by critics.

headline: Apple Compote
text: Apple compote is what the French call applesauce. It is utterly simple to make, but freshly made it is several cuts above storebought. Serve it warm, for a comforting dessert, topped with a dollop of crème fraiche if you like. Or use it as a filling for crêpes.

headline: Apple and Bitter Lettuces Salad
text: You can use a mix of lettuces for this salad, and you can also add some milder lettuce. My favorite combination is endive, radicchio and arugula. It is a simple salad with wonderful contrasts. Dice the apples small.

headline: Apple, Lime and Chia Smoothie
text: I love the pale green color of this smoothie. Granny Smith and lime make a great marriage and the yogurt and chia seeds make the sweet and tart smoothie substantial enough to get me through the morning.

headline: Buckwheat Crêpes With Caramelized Apples
text: Buckwheat crêpes have wonderful earthy/nutty flavor. They are equally at home with a sweet or savory topping. If you have any caramelized apples left over, stir them into your yogurt for breakfast.

headline: Country Bread With Apples
text: This is a whole wheat version of a classic Norman country bread. Normandy is apple country and apples find their way into many dishes in this region. I came across the bread in “Bread Alone” by Daniel Leader, and have adapted the recipe. The dough ferments overnight in the refrigerator, and after it has come back to room temperature the chopped apples are kneaded in. It goes beautifully with cheese.

headline: On Short-Track Speedskating
text: Short-track speedskaters whip around a relatively small oval, pushing forward in short bursts of acceleration on extremely sharp blades.

text: Kevin Roose, a former reporter for DealBook, has been at New York magazine since 2012, writing about the more offbeat aspects of Wall Street’s culture.

headline: Former Prime Minister of Georgia Convicted of Corruption
text: TBILISI, Georgia — A former prime minister of Georgia, Ivane Merabishvili, was convicted on Monday of public corruption charges and sentenced to five years in prison, making him the most senior official yet to be convicted in a series of seemingly politically motivated prosecutions that followed a change in control of the government in 2012.

headline: In Moscow, Russians Protest Disallowed Hockey Goal
text: MOSCOW — It was the biggest demonstration so far concerning the Sochi Olympics, and it had nothing to do with gay rights, environmental damage or corruption.

headline: Humble-Nishiyama Randomness Game
text: This week’s challenge was suggested by Steve Humble (aka Dr Maths), a mathematics educator from Newcastle University. The game starts with a standard 52-card deck of playing cards, which includes, obviously, 26 red cards and 26 black cards. At the start of a game, each player announces, one player after the other, a three-color sequence she will be watching for as the deck of cards is dealt out card by card. Cards are then dealt, and when a player’s sequence appears in a series of three consecutive cards, all cards in play are removed from the game as a winning trick. This continues until the full pack of 52 cards is exhausted. At the end, the player with the most tricks is declared the winner.

text: Biathlon, figure skating and a thick fog that postponed some events on Day 12 of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: The Beatles Started the British Invasion, but Not One in Cars
text: On Feb. 9, 1964, the Beatles took to the stage on “The Ed Sullivan Show.” It wasn’t long before other bands — the Rolling Stones, the Kinks, the Who and the Yardbirds, among others — joined what is now known as the British Invasion.

headline: Wireless Charging: Still Plenty of Kinks in the Cord
text: As personal devices proliferate — smartphones, wearable fitness bands, Kindles, tablets, smart glasses — our charger collections are starting to look like the electrical outlet in the movie “A Christmas Story.”

headline: U.N. Panel Says North Korean Leader Could Face Trial
text: GENEVA — A United Nations panel has served notice to Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, that he may be personally held liable in court for crimes against humanity committed by state institutions and officials under his direct control.

headline: Driving Under the Influence, of Marijuana
text: If you are pulled over on suspicion of drunken driving, the police officer is likely to ask you to complete three tasks: Follow a pen with your eyes while the officer moves it back and forth; get out of the car and walk nine steps, heel to toe, turn on one foot and go back; and stand on one leg for 30 seconds.

headline: Indian Journalist Charged With Rape of a Reporter
text: NEW DELHI — The police in the coastal state of Goa charged Tarun J. Tejpal, an investigative journalist and magazine editor, with raping and sexually assaulting a staff reporter during a November encounter in a hotel elevator.

headline: Attendance Up, Disney to Add Hotel Rooms at Hong Kong Park
text: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company on Monday said that it planned to increase the number of hotel rooms at Hong Kong Disneyland by 75 percent following gains in attendance and profit at the eight-year-old resort.

headline: Penn State Looks South in Naming New President
text: Eric J. Barron, the president of Florida State University and a nationally known climatologist, was named on Monday as the president of Penn State University, which has spent the past year trying to find a new leader as it continues to wrestle with the aftermath of the Jerry Sandusky child sex-abuse scandal.

headline: Peter Pilotto: Fall 2014 RTW
text: London

headline: Meryl Davis and Charlie White Give U.S. First Olympic Gold in Ice Dancing
text: SOCHI, Russia — When Meryl Davis and Charlie White began skating together in suburban Detroit, she was 9 and he was 8. It was an awkward age, when a girl is not yet comfortable looking into a boy’s eyes, even for the theatricality of sport.

headline: Jailed Russian Critic of Sochi Olympics Now on Hunger Strike
text: SOCHI, Russia — An environmental activist critical of the Olympic Games who was sentenced to three years in prison last week has gone on a hunger strike, members of a public oversight committee who met with him in jail said Monday.

headline: The Peruvian Green Velvet Tarantula’s Gift
text: Venoms from spiders and other animals, fine-tuned by evolution to stun and paralyze prey, are an abundant source of painkillers and other drugs. But screening for useful toxins can be an arduous process.

headline: Neil Gaiman Brings a Storytelling Performance to the States
text: The novelist Neil Gaiman (“American Gods; “The Graveyard Book) who turned his novelette “The Truth Is a Cave in the Black Mountains” into a performance that is a synchronized mix of music, art and storytelling for audiences abroad, is bringing the show to these shores.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Erdem’s Ruby Sparklers
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Retreat on Debt Fight Seen as G.O.P. Campaign Salvo
text: WASHINGTON — Senators Mitch McConnell and John Cornyn, two Republican leaders facing primary challenges, knew they would take an immediate political hit from the Republicans’ Tea Party wing by voting to clear the way for a debt-limit increase. They also knew that their willingness to cast that vote would enhance their party’s chances of gaining a majority in the Senate next year.

headline: At New-York Historical Society, Civil War History Told Through Textiles
text: In time for the upcoming sesquicentennial marking the end of the Civil War, the New-York Historical Society is featuring the exhibition “Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts & Context in the Civil War.” Running April 4 through Aug. 24, the exhibition uses approximately 130 objects, including quilts, clothing and other artifacts, to explore the ways that textiles expressed the era’s politics and culture. The show, from the American Textile History Museum in Lowell, Mass., where it was shown in 2012, includes additional artifacts from the New-York Historical Society’s collection.

headline: Treating Tuberculosis and AIDS Together Saves Lives
text: Patients who have multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis and AIDS are more likely to live if they get simultaneous treatment for both diseases rather than waiting weeks to start the AIDS treatment, a new study has found.

headline: Cigarette Ads Come Back to British TV
text: LONDON — About 50 years after Britain banned television advertisements for cigarettes, they are back. Except this time they are for the electronic kind.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Ugh!
text: Fashion and reality had a head-on smashup during Fashion Week, with more than 250 shows throughout the city in often freezing, snowy or slushy weather.

headline: Russia to Release Loan Money for Ukraine, Lifting Leader
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The protracted struggle for Ukraine between Russia and the West was on vivid display on Monday with Russia throwing an unexpected financial lifeline to the embattled Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, just as Germany rolled out an unusually high-level reception for two of the president’s most ardent opponents.

headline: A Writer Recalls His Amnesia
text: David Stuart MacLean’s first book, “The Answer to the Riddle Is Me,” opens with a scene out of Robert Ludlum: The protagonist wakes from a blackout to find himself on a crowded train platform in India, with no idea who he is or what he’s doing in a foreign country.

headline: The Tall and the Small
text: Q. Among dogs, small breeds often live longer than larger ones. Is there any evidence that life expectancy for taller humans is also briefer?

headline: Monday Motorsports: A Demolition Derby at Daytona
text: A new Nascar season got off to an exciting start over the weekend at Daytona International Speedway in Florida with a demolition derby-caliber Sprint Unlimited shootout. Denny Hamlin won the bruising Unlimited after a late race rally, and a Sprint Cup rookie, Austin Dillon, set the fastest qualifying time for the Feb. 23 Daytona 500.

headline: U.S. Bombards One Swedish Goaltender, Then Another
text: SOCHI, Russia — Add another competitor to the list of extreme athletes at the Winter Olympics, those skicross racers, snowboarders and skiers who risk life and limb for their one shining moment. Valentina Wallner is her name, and it can be argued that there was no rougher patch of ice in all Rosa Khutor Extreme Park than the goal crease Wallner tried mightily to defend Monday when her country, Sweden, played the United States in a women’s hockey semifinal at Shayba Arena.

headline: Little Optimism as Iran Nuclear Talks Resume
text: VIENNA — Talks with Iran over a permanent agreement on its nuclear program begin on Tuesday in Vienna, but there is little immediate optimism over a negotiation that is expected to last up to a year.

headline: Skating With a Smile, No Matter What
text: SOCHI, Russia — Hockey players gnash their teeth. Ski jumpers can hide their fear behind goggles. Speedskaters huff and puff as they round the bend.

headline: Russians Return to Cyprus, a Favorite Tax Haven
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — When the Cypriot government forced bank depositors — many of them Russian — to pay their share of an international bailout last spring, Vasilis Zertalis’s phone started ringing.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Dewy Skin and Modern Mermaid Hair at Mary Katrantzou
text: “I don’t know why I’m telling you this, but we have changed the makeup three times in the past hour,” the makeup artist Val Garland said backstage at Mary Katrantzou. Garland’s early tests had included stronger, darker eyes and lips in an attempt to go someplace different from Katrantzou’s typical fresh-faced runway look. But why do away with a great thing? The designer and Garland decided to stick with what Garland called “very Mary” makeup. “The Katrantzou woman is pure and statuesque,” Garland said. “What stands out ultimately is her skin.” To complement the architecture and craftsmanship of the new collection, which strayed from the designer’s famed and oft-imitated digital prints, Garland opted for a down-to-earth and dewy look created using MAC products. Models’ lips were matte and natural, cheekbones were dusted with pink blush and eyelids sported a faint wash of silver. “I haven’t picked up a tube of mascara yet in London,” Garland said.

headline: Quadruple Bombing in Baghdad Kills at Least 25
text: BAGHDAD — Three bombs that targeted public markets and a fourth bomb placed outside a Shiite mosque exploded Monday night in Baghdad, killing 25 people and wounding dozens, the police reported.

headline: Holcomb Skilled at Ending 62-Year Slumps
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Four years ago at the Vancouver Games, Steven Holcomb helped end a 62-year medal drought in bobsled by piloting the United States to a gold medal in the four-man event. On Monday at Sanki Sliding Center here, Holcomb did it again, this time teaming with Steve Langton to drive an American sled to its first medal in 62 years in the two-man.

headline: Chinese Officials Widen Campaign Against Vices
text: BEIJING — The Chinese government has widened a crackdown on prostitution, gambling and drug use to major provinces across the country, according to reports on Monday in state-run news organizations.

headline: Itching: More Than Skin-Deep
text: The experiment was not for the squirmish. Volunteers were made to itch like crazy on one arm, but not allowed to scratch. Then they were whisked into an M.R.I. scanner to see what parts of their brains lit up when they itched, when researchers scratched them and when they were finally allowed to scratch themselves.

headline: Giles: Fall 2014 RTW
text: London

headline: Earwax’s Smell Influenced by Ethnicity
text: The smell of a person’s earwax depends partly on his ethnic origin, a new study reports, suggesting that the substance could be an overlooked source of personal information.

headline: Understanding Opioid Abuse (2 Letters)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: The Distinct Role of Nurses (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Hills to Scientific Discoveries Grow Steeper
text: Armed with a stopwatch and a perfume atomizer, Robert Millikan embarked in 1909 on a landmark discovery in physics. Squirting out a mist of oil drops and timing how quickly they fell in the presence of an electrical field, he ultimately showed that the world is awash with tiny, identically charged specks of matter — subatomic particles called electrons.

headline: Valery Kaufman Transforms Backstage at Peter Pilotto
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Valery Kaufman before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pica and hair by Anthony Turner.

headline: Pakistan Suspends Taliban Peace Talks Over Killings
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Peace talks between the Pakistani government and the Taliban were suspended in acrimony on Monday, as a government committee refused to meet with Taliban representatives in the aftermath of the reported killing of 23 paramilitary soldiers in militant captivity.

headline: King Richard III’s Eyes, and the Munchies
text: It was a week of revived hopes. Thermonuclear fusion is looking a bit more promising; a moon rover thought dead may yet work; and we may finally discover the color of King Richard III’s eyes. Keep your fingers crossed.

headline: A Battle for Gold and Posterity
text: SOCHI, Russia — Kim Yu-na had arrived on a long flight from South Korea to defend her Olympic figure skating title. This was her first practice, near dusk on Thursday, and dozens of reporters and photographers recorded every jump and spin and mop of the brow. The whir of cameras made a hushed, clattering sound like cards in the spokes of a bicycle tire.

headline: It’s Snack Time in the Cosmos
text: Black holes, the ultradense collapsed objects predicted by Einstein’s theory of general relativity, are often depicted as voracious feeders whose extraordinary gravity acts like a one-way membrane: Everything is sucked in, even light, and virtually nothing leaks out.

headline: Why Russian Men Don’t Live as Long
text: The probability that a Russian man will die before he turns 55 is 25 percent.

headline: Happy to Fly, When the Alternative Is Driving Off a Cliff
text: I’VE traveled most of my career, but until about five years ago, most of my business trips were domestic. I’m starting my 20th year with Johnson Controls, and as its chief marketing officer now, most of my trips are international. Whether I like flying is debatable. It’s probably fairer to say that I’ve gotten used to flying. At one time, I was a horrible “white-knuckle” flier, and now I’m just kind of numb to it. Takeoffs and landings don’t worry me as much anymore, and I don’t even think twice about turbulence.

headline: Just Ahead, Your Next Office
text: Joe Bunner, a sales executive from Austin, Tex., recently found himself in Denver for the day, with no place to work after a meeting had been canceled. “I didn’t want to go back to the hotel and get holed up in that box all day,” said Mr. Bunner, who works for Dynamic Signal, a marketing company.

headline: Q&A With Bayern Munich’s Jérôme Boateng
text: Jérôme Boateng, a disciplined central defender for the German powerhouse Bayern Munich, is bound for London this week and the first leg of a knockout home-and-away series against Arsenal in the UEFA Champions League.

headline: A New Kind of Transplant Bank
text: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. — Around noon on a recent Friday, Donor Five, a healthy 31-year-old, walked across M.I.T.’s frigid, wind-swept campus to a third-floor restroom to make a contribution to public health.

headline: London Fashion Week: Christopher Kane Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: Tom Ford: Fall 2014 RTW
text: London

headline: A Picture of Detroit Ruin, Street by Forlorn Street
text: DETROIT — A midnight blue Chevy rolls slowly down a snow-covered street, an emergency strobe light on its roof and a sign on its side that promises this is “official business.” At each house, business, even vacant lot, workers in the car pause to decide whether someone lives there and what shape the place is in before snapping a photo and beaming it to “mission control” miles away.

headline: A Fresh Case for Breast Self-Exams
text: Scientists produced dismal news last week about mammograms. After tracking 90,000 women for 25 years, researchers in Canada found that those who received regular mammograms did not experience fewer deaths from breast cancer or from all causes, compared with those who did not.

headline: From India, Proof That a Trip to Mars Doesn’t Have to Break the Bank
text: BANGALORE, India — While India’s recent launch of a spacecraft to Mars was a remarkable feat in its own right, it is the $75 million mission’s thrifty approach to time, money and materials that is getting attention.

headline: A Website Offers Help Finding a Hotel Where You Can Light Up
text: SMOKERS are often reviled and pitied by those with lesser vices, but do not they who smoke also need a place to lay their weary heads? Yes, they do, insists Shawn Bradley, who runs an odd little website called Smoketels.com, where those who puff can book a hotel that welcomes them.

headline: Bravado and Longing
text: SABINA

headline: U.S. Takes Gold in Ice Dancing
text: Meryl Davis and Charlie White won the United States’ first gold medal in ice dancing on Monday by a large margin over Canada and Russia’s top teams.

headline: Lorrie Moore’s New Book Is a Reminder and a Departure
text: NASHVILLE — Lorrie Moore doesn’t much resemble a Lorrie Moore character. She’s shy and self-deprecating but not melancholy, witty but not jokey. Her conversation doesn’t bristle with wordplay or throwaway one-liners; there are no zingers. Two of her favorite expressions are “I don’t know” and, added to the end of a sentence, “Or maybe not.”

headline: Notes From an Unpredictable Maestro
text: The veteran maestro Yuri Temirkanov is famous not only for his podium mastery, but also for his unpredictability, personal as well as musical. Certainly, few could have foreseen the benighted comments about female conductors that he made a couple of years ago and that Alex Ross reported on The New Yorker’s website last fall: “The essence of the conductor’s profession is strength. The essence of a woman is weakness.”

headline: Amusement, Absurdity and Abuse
text: LONDON — For 25 years before her death in 2009, Pina Bausch and her Tanztheater Wuppertal were an international phenomenon. But her singular genre of dance theater reached many countries for the first time in the 1980s.

headline: Oh, Penn Station, Where Are You Now?
text: The legacy of Pennsylvania Station, opened in 1910 and demolished a half-century ago — the bulldozers started work in October 1963, a New York sidebar to the country’s early-’60s upheavals — is more than a little contradictory. Built to celebrate America’s immense ambitions, in its death it became the poster building for historic preservation, the effort to protect our architectural heritage from those very ambitions in their later, lesser forms.

headline: Fighting (and Dancing) Like Bruce Lee
text: There was an audible thud when Ari Loeb fell on his backside in the midst of a scrappy, eight-against-one brawl at the Signature Theater Company recently. The fight was fictional, of course: Mr. Loeb was rehearsing the finale of “Kung Fu,” the new play by David Henry Hwang about the martial arts master Bruce Lee that is now in previews at Signature, where it opens on Monday.

headline: London Fashion Week: Erdem Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Waespi.

headline: France Tries to Tempt In More Foreign Investment
text: PARIS — President François Hollande of France has begun a major charm offensive to convince the world that France is open for business in a bid to lure back investments, which have slumped since he took office.

headline: Manifest Destiny: Into the Wild With a Tool Belt
text: The dead of winter may not seem like the liveliest time in the real estate business, but on television one segment of the new-construction market is booming: the cabin-in-the-woods market.

headline: A Nation Perpetually Under a Thumb
text: The extravagant, sometimes kitschy opening ceremony of the Sochi Olympics on Feb. 7 gave us a cleaned-up, World’s Fair version of Russian history, celebrating the glories of its scientific and artistic achievements while airbrushing the horrors of its Stalinist past. At the same time, the ceremony was devised to try to make the world forget the dark side of President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia — its smothering of dissent, its oppressive antigay laws — and to promote an image of the country as a modernizing great power ascendant on the world stage.

headline: Neil Gaiman to Perform ‘Black Mountains’ in U.S.
text: The novelist Neil Gaiman (“American Gods”; “The Graveyard Book”). who turned his novelette “The Truth Is a Cave in the Black Mountains” into a performance that is a synchronized mix of music, art and storytelling for audiences abroad, is bringing the show to the United States. At a performance on June 25 at the Warfield in San Francisco and one on June 27 at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Gaiman, above, will read his tale of crime and search for buried treasure, accompanied by a score written for the event from the FourPlay String Quartet, from Sydney, Australia. As Mr. Gaiman reads, the images from the story will be displayed on a screen behind him, courtesy of the artist Eddie Campbell. Mr. Campbell will also illustrate a hardcover edition of “The Truth Is a Cave in the Black Mountains” when the story is published in June by William Morrow. The story had been in an anthology, but the new edition draws on the art created for the live performances. The 90-minute multimedia event was commissioned by the Sydney Opera House for its Graphic Festival in 2010 and was performed a year later in Tasmania for Mona Foma, an arts festival. The show is scheduled to travel to the Barbican in London on July 4 and 5.

headline: In Shampoo Ads for Men, It’s Not Just the Hair, It’s What It Does for You
text: WHILE unisex personal care products proliferated a generation ago, today the antiperspirant and soap aisles, for example, are dominated by products marketed to just men or women. The shampoo aisle remained a haven for unisex products, but that, too, is shifting, with Old Spice now introducing a hair care line, joining men’s brands like Axe, which began selling hair products in 2009, and Dove Men+Care, which did so in 2013.

headline: In a Village, Love Is in the Air Before a Doll Comes Into Play
text: The doll that the ballet “Coppélia” is named after never comes to life. That the ballet itself is still living, nearly 150 years after its first staging, is largely because of Léo Delibes’s vivacious score. New York City Ballet’s production, which will be 40 this summer, has further life-extending virtues: folk dances theatricalized by Petipa and others, as remembered and restaged by Alexandra Danilova and George Balanchine; a third act of allegorical dances by Balanchine, framed by 24 adorably well-trained little girls from the School of American Ballet.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,297 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Thomas Tait: Fall 2014 RTW
text: London

headline: Regulators and Hackers Put Bitcoin to the Test
text: Bitcoin is facing significant growing pains as it struggles to move beyond a stormy adolescence.

headline: Gold and Silver Medal Jumps in Men’s Aerials
text: Composite picture of both winning jumps side-by-side.

headline: At Newark Airport, the Lights Are On, and They’re Watching You
text: Visitors to Terminal B at Newark Liberty International Airport may notice the bright, clean lighting that now blankets the cavernous interior, courtesy of 171 recently installed LED fixtures. But they probably will not realize that the light fixtures are the backbone of a system that is watching them.

headline: Speaking Up for the Mute Swan
text: THE Department of Environmental Conservation is proposing to kill New York State’s entire population of free-ranging mute swans, those graceful white water birds long treasured as symbols of romance and fidelity. New Yorkers have until Feb. 21 to submit responses to a plan that calls for the removal by 2025 of the estimated 2,200 birds by methods that could include shooting, gassing, decapitation and egg addling.

headline: Eyes in the Skies, City of the Future, Your Virtual Self
text: This week the podcast hits the road, traveling to Chicago for the annual American Association for the Advancement of Science conference to track a stream of data that flows from above Earth, along city streets and inside your body.

headline: The Podcast Hits the Road
text: This week the Science Times podcast hit the road. I traveled to Chicago for the annual American Association for the Advancement of Science conference.

headline: What to Do About Drug Shortages
text: To the Editor:

headline: Step Up ‘Soft Diplomacy’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Small Towns in Southwest Fear Loss of Cherished Train Line
text: LAMY, N.M. — For 18 years, Maryalice Garrigan has been taking the train from this wisp of a town near Santa Fe to visit her family in Albany, spending four days to reach New York via a connection in Chicago. She cherishes the annual ritual: Sipping the whiskey she packs in a cooler, and tracing the creeks and mesas that whiz by with a map she brings on each trip.

headline: Health Law and Antitrust
text: To the Editor:

headline: China-Taiwan Talks
Executive Coaches
text: To the Editor:

headline: Watching Sliding Sports Live? The Athletes Wish You Luck
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Sergei and Oksana Barilo traveled to Sanki Sliding Center from Novocherkassk, a city about 400 miles away. They dressed warmly. They took their two children. And they packed plenty of patience.

headline: Hemingway’s Papers
text: To the Editor:

headline: VHS vs. Communism
text: In Communist Romania in the 1980s, a young translator became an unlikely voice of freedom. She illicitly dubbed thousands of foreign films, distributed on VHS tapes, turning B-movie stars into heroes.

headline: ‘VHS vs. Communism’
text: I was raised in Romania in the 1980s, under a Communist regime that, among countless repressions, reduced television to two hours a day of dull propaganda, traditional music, patriotic poems and censored films. One day when I was 6, my parents found a way to borrow a VCR. They invited their friends, and all night they watched grainy VHS tapes of Hollywood B-movies. I remember the films, but more so I remember how I felt when I stepped into the living room — like walking into a secret, magical and free world.

headline: A Big Bet on Gluten-Free
text: The Girl Scouts recently introduced a gluten-free chocolate chip shortbread cookie to their annually anticipated line of sweet treats.

headline: Hillary’s Secrets
text: Her perseverance often awes me. Her arrogance sometimes galls me. And her particular braid of high-mindedness and high-handedness almost always leaves me puzzled and exhausted.

headline: Beltran and Roberts Note Honor and Responsibility in Being Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Piece by piece, player by player, the 2014 Yankees are assembling here. Two days ahead of the official reporting date, Carlos Beltran, Brian Roberts and Kelly Johnson were the latest players to arrive at spring training Monday, working out together at the team’s minor league complex in anticipation of what some of them say could be a special season, perhaps even ending in ultimate glory.

headline: The Prodigal Sons
text: We take as our text today the parable of the prodigal sons. As I hope you know, the story is about a father with two sons. The younger son took his share of the inheritance early and blew it on prostitutes and riotous living. When the money was gone, he returned home.

headline: Geologists Glimpse a Heaven Below
text: Imagine the frustration faced for so many years by Eric W. Jordan and his colleagues. They could take a pretty good guess at what lay hundreds of feet beneath the macadam-sealed surface of New York City’s streets. They just had no way of knowing for sure.

headline: Nobel Winner’s Frank Advice to China’s Leadership
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — A. Michael Spence won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 2001 for esoteric research on how people make decisions when critical information is hard to obtain. But by that time, after more than a decade and a half as an academic dean at Harvard and Stanford, many of Mr. Spence’s colleagues had begun referring to him as a “former economist.”

headline: Celebrations, and Unease, in Libya on Anniversary of Uprising
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Rockets exploded in showers of sparkles over Martyrs’ Square here on Monday, and thousands of Libyans raced their cars up and down the coastal highway, flying flags and honking their horns in celebration of the third anniversary of the start of the uprising that overthrew the longtime ruler Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: A Curse to Many in New York Is a Thrill for the More Daring
text: The white stuff that has fallen unrelentingly on New York this winter goes by a number of printable words in several languages — neve, neige, thalj, sneg — but on a sparkling Presidents’ Day in Central Park, the snow on the ground translated into one unified cry of fun: “Aiiiieeeee!”

headline: In Diluting Measure to Ban Gay Marriage, Indiana Shows a Shift
text: It was a choice expected to come and go with little debate. Indiana, a conservative state controlled by Republicans, wanted to do what plenty of other states did long ago: add an amendment to its Constitution defining marriage as between a man and a woman. The notion had sped through Indiana’s legislature a few years ago, the first of two required votes.

headline: Chad Kellogg, a Speed Climbing Pioneer, Dies in Rock Fall at 42
text: Chad Kellogg, an elite climber known for his speed ascents of large mountains, died on Friday after being struck on the head by a falling rock while descending the Patagonian peak Fitz Roy. He was 42.

headline: Venezuela Cites Unrest in Expelling 3 U.S. Officials
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela on Monday ordered three American Embassy officials to leave the country, saying they had been recruiting students to take part in violent antigovernment protests, in the latest in a series of expulsions that have marked a low point in relations between the two countries.

headline: Banning Ivory Sales in America
text: The slaughter of the dwindling elephant herds in Africa grows worse by the year as organized criminals get rich from selling elephant tusks in lucrative black markets around the world, where a pound of ivory can fetch $1,500. African elephants, whose numbers have been reduced in less than a century from several million to an estimated 500,000, are being killed at a rate of 30,000 to 35,000 a year.

headline: What to Watch: Tuesday, Feb. 18
text: SPEEDSKATING Sven Kramer of the Netherlands won a gold medal in the 5,000 meters at the 2010 Games but is better remembered for the one he lost. That came in the 10,000, where he was on pace to win easily when his coach, Gerard Kemkers, directed him into the wrong lane. Kramer was disqualified, and inconsolable. Now he is back, and still the favorite in the grueling, 25-lap 10,000. And you know who else is back? Kemkers, who still coaches him. They will be paying especially close attention today. NBCSN, 8 a.m.

headline: The Confederate Submarine
text: The moonlit sea was unusually calm on the bitterly cold night of Feb. 17, 1864, when a watchman spotted a strange, partially submerged shape gliding steadily toward the side of the Union sloop-of-war Housatonic. The steam-powered warship was serving blockade duty outside Charleston Harbor, and was one of the Union’s biggest, best-armed vessels. Its men had heard reports of a new Confederate weapon, a “sub-torpedo”; still, it took a few minutes for the officer of the deck, John Crosby, to comprehend what he was seeing. By the time he did, it was too late.

headline: Stalin and Soap
text: This is the third part of an eight-part series.

headline: The Art of Vernacular Voice
text: In an interview with the Pulitzer Prize-winning writer Rick Bragg, John Sledge tells the story of Mr. Bragg’s encounter with the acclaimed author Willie Morris, who opened Mr. Bragg’s memoir “All Over But the Shoutin’,” and read several pages aloud. He slammed the book and leaned forward, telling Mr. Bragg, “You say it’s the story, and I say it’s the language.” Mr. Sledge is talking about the voices in Mr. Bragg’s books, which ring true down to the red Alabama grit on their shoes. Every voice on paper has a linguistic and social history that needs to be heard.

headline: Chelsea Complex Divided Over Rare Indoor Amenity
text: It was the star of a little silent film in the days when not every movie was one of those newfangled talkies. Later it was where the performers trained for Billy Rose’s Aquacade, a water carnival that featured Johnny Weissmuller, a competition swimmer better known these days for playing Tarzan in the movies.

headline: Sudanese TV Show, Without the Cutthroat ‘You’re Fired,’ Rewards Entrepreneurs
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — It was the final episode, broadcast live from Khartoum’s 18-story, egg-shaped Corinthia Hotel tower, built by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya. On stage, under flashing colored lights, the five contestants, three men and two women, waited anxiously for the outcome.

headline: The Port Authority Loses Its Way
text: Gov. Chris Christie and his political allies have done the near-impossible. Their notorious traffic jam at the George Washington Bridge, engineered by Mr. Christie’s colleagues, has succeeded in getting people to pay attention to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the sprawling and secretive agency that runs not only that bridge but three other major bridges, two tunnels, five airports and port operations in the region. And, like many of those huge structures, the authority itself desperately needs fixing.

headline: U.S. Scolds Russia as It Weighs Options on Syrian War
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Secretary of State John Kerry on Monday sharpened the Obama administration’s mounting criticism of Russia’s role in the escalating violence in Syria, asserting that the Kremlin was undermining the prospects of a negotiated solution by “contributing so many more weapons” and political support to President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Skiing With the Greatest of Ease, and Fear
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Few sports that take place on skis have less to do with skiing than aerials.

headline: Europe Flirts With Deflation
text: Some analysts and public officials say the beleaguered euro zone is finally on the road to recovery. Unemployment has decreased slightly, though it remains high at 12 percent, and the euro zone as a whole grew by 0.3 percent in the last quarter of 2013.

headline: Spain, Land of 10 P.M. Dinners, Asks if It’s Time to Reset Clock
text: MADRID — Dipping into a bucket filled with Mahou beers, Jorge Rodríguez and his friends hunkered down on a recent Wednesday night to watch soccer at Mesón Viña, a local bar. At a nearby table a couple were cuddling, oblivious to others, as a waitress brought out potato omelets and other dinner orders. Then the game began. At 10 p.m.

headline: Financier Plans Big Ad Campaign on Climate Change
text: A billionaire retired investor is forging plans to spend as much as $100 million during the 2014 election, seeking to pressure federal and state officials to enact climate change measures through a hard-edge campaign of attack ads against governors and lawmakers.

headline: Joyce Does It Her Way
text: I’d like to tell you a story about a Brazilian musician you’ve probably never heard of. Her name is Joyce Moreno; she is 66 and has been singing and composing professionally for 47 years, during which time she has made more than 30 recordings. I flipped for her music when I first heard her last spring at Birdland, in Midtown Manhattan, and I’ve been listening to her, more or less obsessively, ever since.

headline: In Queens, the Fate of a Towering Relic From the 1964 World’s Fair Is Debated

Next on the list is the New York State Pavilion, the futuristic cluster of towers that appear to have been plucked from “The Jetsons” and deposited near the Van Wyck Expressway.

headline: A Diamondbacks Outfielder Who Throws Strikes

headline: Bombings in Syria Force Wave of Civilians to Flee

headline: An Interview Up Close, and Far Too Personal

headline: Stuart Hall, Trailblazing British Scholar of Multicultural Influences, Is Dead at 82

headline: Staying Fit and Well the (Cheeky) British Way

The exercises were created by Russell Bateman, a personal trainer who founded theSBC gym in London — where the only thing more motivating than the grueling regimen is the array of impossibly toned, A-list bodies in the room.

headline: Q.&A.: Steven I. Levine on the Tiananmen Initiative Project
text: This year will mark 25 years since the upheavals of 1989 in China, when student protests prompted by the death of Hu Yaobang — the relatively liberal Communist Party leader who was pressed into resigning in 1987 — grew into huge, passionate demonstrations in Beijing and other cities demanding clean government, democratic change and respect for human rights. The party patriarch Deng Xiaoping deemed the demonstrations, based in Tiananmen Square in Beijing, a grave threat to party power. He authorized martial law in urban Beijing, ousted Mr. Hu’s successor as party general secretary, the reform-minded Zhao Ziyang, and ordered the People’s Liberation Army to end the demonstrations. The crackdown culminated in troops taking Tiananmen Square in the early hours of June 4. Across Beijing, many hundreds of protesters and ordinary citizens caught in the wrong place died from military gunfire, and soldiers also died at the hands of incensed residents. The precise number of dead has been in dispute ever since 1989.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 7:20 P.M. (Starz Edge) CELESTE AND JESSE FOREVER (2012) Rashida Jones portrays Celeste, and Andy Samberg is Jesse (above, with Ms. Jones), a married couple in Los Angeles who have split up without moving on or out in this wistful romantic comedy. Ms. Jones plays a hard-driving trend forecaster who lives in the house they once shared; he is a laid-back artist who now flops in the backyard studio. Though they are best friends bound by the same adolescent humor, Jesse’s lack of ambition doesn’t allow the focused Celeste to stay with him. But she can’t quit him, either — until suddenly she must. “While ‘Celeste and Jesse’ is decidedly conventional in most respects, it’s pretty swell as an exploration of a relationship between a man and a woman that’s no longer predicated by mutual desire,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Should Felons Be Allowed to Vote After They Have Served Their Time?
text: Almost six million Americans have been stripped of their right to vote — many for the rest of their lives. Most states prohibit prisoners in jail from voting, but some states bar felons from ever voting, even decades after they are released, unless they receive clemency from the governor. Felonies can include violent crimes like murder and assault, but also nonviolent crimes like tax evasion, drug dealing and check fraud.

headline: Protest Installation to Document Prisoners in Iran
text: The “Inside Out” project, created by the Parisian street artist J R, joined forces with the Iran Human Rights Documentation Center in a pop-up protest against the incarceration of journalists, artists, feminists and other activists in Iran on Tuesday morning outside the United Nations. Like the J R project, in which large portraits of ordinary people are plastered on walls and sidewalks, the installation at the protest included portraits of 11 people who are currently imprisoned in Iran, and two who were recently executed. A second protest, originally scheduled for noon in SoHo, has been postoned until Thursday because of the weather, a spokeswoman for the center said on Tuesday morning.

headline: Finding 3 Ways to Enjoy Alaska’s Winter
text: Alone on a ridge in the Chugach Mountains of southern Alaska, I struggled to see. The wind was blowing upslope from the south, pelting my face with snow. Around me, all was white — or purple, as after a few hours of trying to rise in the sky, the sun had given up, leaving me alone in the dark. There was no shelter from the cutting wind as trees didn’t even try to grow at this extreme elevation. I had already had an exhausting day of climbing and descending the ridges, and I wasn’t sure how much more I could handle. Far below, the sea ice boulders strewn across the low tide line of the Turnagain Arm pointed the way back toward Anchorage, and civilization. But right about then, I didn’t know what I was going to do.
