headline: Money Lessons From Where the Air Is Thinner
text: I had a conversation this month with Alison Levine, a polar explorer and mountaineer who has climbed the tallest peak on every continent. While I’m a casual climber in comparison, we do share a love of the mountains and the things they can teach us. In fact, Alison’s new book, On the Edge: The Art of High-Impact Leadership, is full of lessons she learned outside and how they apply to making decisions of all sorts, including smarter ones about money.

headline: Image of the Day: February 18
text: Cricketer Virat Kohli after hitting a hundred runs in the second test match against New Zealand in Wellington.

headline: Public Defenders, Bolstered by a Work Analysis and Rulings, Push Back Against a Tide of Cases
text: CLAYTON, Mo. — On a typical recent morning Colleen M. Polak, a St. Louis County public defender, ran upstairs and down and up again and in and out of four courtrooms, simultaneously representing clients in 10 cases. She consulted, negotiated and sometimes just waited.

headline: De Blasio Outlines Steps to Eliminate Traffic Deaths
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday unveiled a sweeping set of proposals aimed at improving street safety in New York City, pledging considerable police resources and even precious political capital in Albany to a most ambitious goal: eliminating traffic deaths.

headline: 2 Egyptians Charged With Spying for Israel
text: CAIRO — Prosecutors announced Tuesday that they had arrested two Egyptian citizens on charges of spying for Israel, saying the suspects had confessed to supplying Israeli agents with information on Egypt’s military, its political movements and about the 2011 uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: London Fashion Week: Peter Pilotto Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Chinese Developer Envisions a Future for Abandoned London Docks
text: LONDON — Known for ambitious plans in China for business parks the size of cities, Xu Weiping says he cannot wait to start work on his first project abroad: turning an abandoned London dock into Europe’s main hub for Chinese companies.

headline: For Bradley, Toronto Is the Place to Be
text: The second-guessing began moments after word oozed from the wires and tubes of the Internets that Michael Bradley was about to leave European soccer to return to Major League Soccer.

headline: E.U. Leaders Seek Way to Protect Individuals’ Data
text: LONDON — Some European politicians want to keep Internet data closer to home.

headline: In a World of Free Spirits, the Undude Is Best
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — For the freestyle skier David Wise, the reminders of home, two doses of perspective, sat inside a zippered pocket of his uniform and on a wooden stick at the bottom of the halfpipe.

headline: ‘Raisin in the Sun’ Exhibit Opens at New York Public Library
text: An exhibit of items relating to the original 1959 Broadway production of Lorraine Hansberry’s “A Raisin in the Sun” has opened at the New York Public Library, in conjunction with the revival starring Denzel Washington, which begins previews on March 8.

headline: For Fleet-Footed Karlsson, Safety Comes in a Sock
text: SOCHI, Russia — The Swedish defenseman Erik Karlsson moves like an ice dancer, his feet a blur of motion. He has a quick first step that allows him to jump into rushes like a 500-meter speedskater bursting off the starting line. Through the first three games of the Olympics, Karlsson’s feet did not fail him.

headline: CBS Drops Two and Adds Gonzalez to ‘NFL Today’
text: CBS Sports changed the cast of its “NFL Today” pregame show on Tuesday by hiring Tony Gonzalez to the panel and parting with Shannon Sharpe and Dan Marino.

headline: Lewis Carroll Letter Illustrates How He Hated Fame
text: J.K. Rowling drew headlines recently with her regrets about how she handled the romantic pairings at the end of the “Harry Potter” series. But Lewis Carroll, according to a letter to be sold at auction next month, once declared that he regretted having written his “Alice in Wonderland” books at all.

headline: Iraqi Cleric, Exiting Politics, Urges Others to Keep Serving
text: BAGHDAD — Moktada al-Sadr, the influential anti-American Shiite cleric, reaffirmed in a speech in Najaf on Tuesday that he was withdrawing from Iraqi politics, telling his followers in Parliament to continue to serve but not on his behalf.

headline: New Murakami Novel Coming in August
text: Haruki Murakami’s latest novel, “Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage,” will be published in the United States on Aug. 12, Alfred A. Knopf has announced. The novel was an enormous hit in Japan in April, where it sold more than a million copies in its first week, according to Knopf.

headline: Taking Their Investments Elsewhere
text: The Treasury on Tuesday released its estimates of international capital flows into and out of the United States, and they indicate that foreigners were net sellers of $40.2 billion of American stocks in 2013. That is hardly a large amount, but it is the first year since 1992 that they were net sellers.

headline: Meadham Kirchhoff: Fall 2014 RTW
text: London

headline: Simone Rocha: Rebellious and Royal
text: LONDON — They were the New Elizabethans, with regal frills on puffed-up sleeves wrapped with trimmings of dull gold. A small diadem or golden paint on the forehead signaled their royal status.

headline: Long (-Way) Weekends
text: Epic Tomato, a London-based bespoke travel company specializing in adventure trips, recently started three mini-expeditions called Epic Weekends designed for time-pressed but thrill-seeking travelers.

headline: London Fashion Week: Tom Ford Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Online Video of Intense Clashes in Kiev
text: Last Updated, 6:50 p.m. | As the deadly clashes in the Ukrainian capital, Kiev, continued late Tuesday, hundreds of thousands of people followed the violence as it unfolded, watching a live YouTube video stream from the besieged protest camp provided by the local website Espreso.tv, and reading Twitter updates from reporters and activists in Independence Square.

text: Slides here (pdf).

headline: The Bank Rescue, Five Years Later
text: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Actavis Deal May Become the Standard for Drug Deals
text: Actavis makes pharmaceutical deals look generic. Its $25 billion acquisition of Forest Laboratories follows a familiar formula in the sector. Agitating investor? Check. Low-tax jurisdiction? Check. Buyer’s stock rises? Check. And with over $8 billion of value created, financiers will keep busy with their own merger success.

headline: Minimum Wage Increase Would Have Mixed Effects, C.B.O. Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — A popular Democratic proposal to raise the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour, championed by President Obama, could reduce total employment by 500,000 workers by the second half of 2016. But it would also lift 900,000 families out of poverty and increase the incomes of 16.5 million low-wage workers in an average week.

headline: For Gold, Perfection Is Overrated
text: SOCHI, Russia — It was a teenage figure skater’s fear, impenetrable, overwhelming.

headline: Mavis Gallant, 91, Dies; Her Stories Told of Uprooted Lives and Loss
text: Mavis Gallant, an acclaimed short-story writer who was abandoned as a child and later left Canada for Europe, where she made her name writing about the dislocated and the dispossessed, died on Tuesday at her home in Paris. She was 91.

headline: Clip: 'Captain Phillips'
text: A scene from the film.

headline: Keeping a Computer Offline
text: Q. Is it possible to use a computer and purposely have it not connected to the Internet so it is not subject to hacking or malware?

headline: Devious and Fierce, but Call It Honey
text: Caught in an unguarded moment, Al Gore would surely admit that he invented the Internet solely for the purpose of disseminating Randall’s honey badger video.

headline: The Stimulus Anniversary
text: Lots of discussion around the fifth anniversary of the Recovery Act. I don’t have time for an extended discussion today, but my quick verdict remains the same as it was right from the beginning: this was a plan that did considerable economic good but considerable political harm.

headline: Stuffed Dates to Remember
text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: There Is a Salary Gap Even When Women Pay Themselves
text: Most of us have heard that in the workplace, women are paid less than men. But here’s a surprising corollary, courtesy of a recent study by Babson College: Female entrepreneurs actually pay themselves less than male entrepreneurs pay themselves.

headline: Stew Season Gets a New Star
text: There is an extreme version of just about every stew you can name — beef stew, Irish stew, curry, cassoulet, bouillabaisse — in which vegetables are used, if at all, as “aromatics.” You may start by sweating a little bit of onion, carrot, celery, maybe garlic, with a bay leaf and a thyme sprig, and then you proceed to brown your main ingredient, usually chunks of meat, and add some liquid.

headline: Indian Journalist Accused of Rape Claims ‘Political Vendetta’
text: NEW DELHI — Tarun Tejpal, a high-profile magazine editor facing charges of raping a younger journalist inside a hotel elevator, said in a statement on Tuesday night that the case against him was driven by a “political vendetta” and that the police in Goa have refused to release surveillance camera footage that would prove that the encounter was not forced.

headline: Fed Closes a Loophole for Banks Overseas
text: Updated, 8:51 p.m. | Foreign banks with a major presence on Wall Street will no longer be allowed to avoid many of the tougher rules that the United States introduced after the financial crisis to prevent banking failures and bailouts.

headline: Obama Delivers Remarks on Economy
text: The president spoke at the Safeway Distribution Center in Maryland about efforts to bolster the economy and announced plans for new fuel economy standards for trucks.

headline: The Harder They Fall: Shared Slopes Take Bigger Toll on Women
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Sarka Pancochova, a Czech snowboarder, led the slopestyle event after the first run. On her second trip down the course of obstacles and jumps, she flew through the air, performed a high-arcing, spinning trick and smacked her head upon landing. Her limp body spun like a propeller into the gully between jumps and slid to a stop.

headline: Chinese Firm and France to Buy Stakes in Peugeot
text: HONG KONG — PSA Peugeot Citroën, the struggling French automaker, will receive big injections of capital from the Chinese automaker Dongfeng Motor and the French government, Dongfeng announced Wednesday in a filing in Hong Kong.

headline: Jimmy Fallon’s ‘Tonight’ Debut Draws 11 Million Viewers
text: Jimmy Fallon’s debut as host of NBC’s “Tonight” show had all the trappings of a television event — and he had an audience to match.

headline: Aide’s Return to White House Reflects Changing U.S. Role in Middle East
text: WASHINGTON — The last time Robert Malley went to work for the White House, it was as a Middle East peacemaker, advising President Bill Clinton during his futile effort to broker an agreement between the Israelis and the Palestinians at Camp David in 2000.

headline: Bar 54 Opens in the Hyatt Times Square Hotel
text: Headliner

headline: El País Ousts Editor; 3rd Spanish Paper to Do So Amid Financial Woes
text: MADRID — El País, Spain’s leading daily newspaper, ousted its top editor on Tuesday in a new sign of economic turmoil in an industry in which the leaders of two other top Spanish papers were recently replaced amid slumping advertising and dwindling circulation.

headline: Jeter Brings Out the Kid in a Future Opponent
text: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — The first time Todd Frazier set foot on a major league field, he stood next to Derek Jeter. Frazier was 12.

headline: Strong Sales for ‘All the Way’ in Previews
text: Even Walter White might’ve cracked a smile over this. The new play “All the Way,” which is the Broadway debut of Bryan Cranston (who played the drug-dealing White on the cable series “Breaking Bad”), grossed a relatively strong $770,789 for its first performances last week, according to box-office data released on Tuesday by the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

headline: Andrew Carmellini’s French Quarters Series, Jarred Kimchi and More
text: To Savor: The Regions of France on a Plate and in a Glass

headline: A Timelessness for Seven Blocks
text: Anybody who’s had a hard time remembering what store used to be on a certain corner, despite having walked past it every day for years, may understand how ephemeral New York can be, even when it comes to landmarks etched in stone.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Class 6
text: Slides here (pdf).

headline: A Nordic Quest in New York
text: For months, I dodged the question.

headline: Liberal Donors Pollute Politics, Too
text: Those who are worried about man-made climate change might be tempted to welcome the news that Tom Steyer, a Democratic billionaire, will spend $100 million this year to fight it. Mr. Steyer plans to put up half the money himself for attack ads against governors and lawmakers who ignore climate change, and will raise the rest from like-minded rich people.

headline: Readers Respond to School Snow Days
text: The snow has finally tapered off in most places around the city, but the truth is the mere forecast of snow makes me anxious these days. In my column this week, I describe the way many suburban parents, including my husband and myself, have been struggling to cope with the slew of snow-related school closings. We have been trying to juggle work — conference calls, column writing — and caring for our antsy little ones. It is no easy task. We have had seven snow days so far this winter in Montclair, N.J., which is why I commended New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio for keeping city schools open during most of these storms, despite some complaints from parents.

headline: Smuggling Case Against Antiquities Collector Is Dismissed
text: Joseph A. Lewis II, a Virginia businessman and avid collector who was indicted in 2011 on charges that he conspired to smuggle Egyptian antiquities and to launder money, has been cleared of wrongdoing. A federal judge in New York dismissed all the charges against him last month.

headline: European Finance Ministers Revisit Plans for Failing Banks
text: BRUSSELS — With their plans to create a banking union facing deadlock, European finance ministers promised Tuesday to explore new ways to assuage critics who contend that their proposed system to deal with failing banks would be too feeble, too cumbersome and take too long to introduce.

headline: Antigovernment Protests in Venezuela
text: The opposition leader Leopoldo López appeared at a student-led protest in Caracas.

headline: Riding a Chef’s Twists and Turns
text: IF YOU HAVE a wide-ranging appetite and more time than money, there’s never been a better time to eat in New York. Every corner of the city is churning out affordable hits of deliciousness, and a long wait is often the only obstacle between wanting some and getting some. Even acclaimed chefs are in this game now, making creative cooking more accessible than ever. And if the meal turns out to be less exciting than you had hoped, you’ve lost only a few hours and a few dollars. The next day will bring some new taste, a Filipino tapas bar or an artisanal spaetzle truck.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Thailand, South Africa and Sochi, Russia. More images from the Winter Olympics here.

headline: Coaching Americans and Canadians, but Russian Through and Through
text: SOCHI, Russia — The career of Marina Zoueva, the celebrated ice dancing coach whose students won the gold and silver medals on Tuesday night, seems defined by conflicting loyalties.

headline: Capital One to Revisit Credit Card Contract Terms After Outcry
text: Banks are known for sticking terms into the fine print that don’t always sit well with consumers. But on Tuesday, Capital One said it would rethink the wording of its credit card contracts after a little-known provision began attracting a lot of unwanted attention.

headline: At a California Resort, a Tequila Tutorial
text: A resort in Southern California is capitalizing on the recent proliferation of mezcal and other agave-derived liquor distilleries to draw new devotees to a members-only club. The Rancho Valencia Resort and Spa near San Diego recently started its All Agave Project, a series of seminars and tastings for the cocktail crowd.

headline: Funny, You Don’t Look Like My Wife
text: Technology hurtles forward, spinning off new surprises by the year, but I’ve not yet heard that emails can be sent from beyond the grave. This startling concept is among the many oddities of “The Correspondent,” a psychological drama by Ken Urban that shovels on the preposterous twists in depicting the desperation of a widower trying to make contact with his dead wife.

headline: App Smart: Walking
text: The same smartphones that often keep us sitting down can also encourage us to get up and walk more by tracking our steps.

headline: These Apps Are Made for Walking
text: We spend too much time sitting around. It’s true. Luckily the same smartphones that often keep us sitting down can also encourage us to get up and walk more by tracking our steps.

headline: A Crusader on What Ails Artists
text: PITTSBURGH — Beer bottles clinked and indie-rock classics played overhead at a gallery opening here on a Friday night recently, as one artist after another chatted with Julie Sokolow, a filmmaker and health care advocate who has documented the Pittsburgh scene in detail.

headline: A Frustrated Woman on the Verge of More of the Same
text: All kinds of monstrous mothers rage and rail in the movies, including those who love too little or too much. In Douglas Sirk’s 1959 melodrama, “Imitation of Life,” Lana Turner plays one type, a selfish white woman who’s blissfully indifferent to her child’s needs. Yet the more disturbing mother is played by Juanita Moore as a black domestic who smothers her own daughter in so much goodness that it’s no surprise that the girl flees. At the end, the saint’s daughter throws herself on her mother’s coffin; it’s a wonder she doesn’t leap in front of a train. In “Child’s Pose,” a drama with a story as cold, merciless and inevitable as a tomb, escape proves every bit as futile.

headline: London Fashion Week: Fashion East Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Waespi.

headline: Romance Stirs on the Way Down Memory Lane
text: In Nilo Cruz’s best-known play, the Pulitzer Prize-winning “Anna in the Tropics,” a Tolstoy novel read aloud has the power to alter lives.

headline: American David Wise Wins Men’s Ski Halfpipe
text: In the debut of ski halfpipe as an Olympic sport, David Wise won a gold medal with a clean, elegant run through snowy, low-visibility conditions that tripped up other medal contenders.

headline: ‘Today’ Claws Ahead of ‘Good Morning America’ With Help of Olympics
text: It took all the power of the Winter Olympics, but NBC’s “Today” show clawed its way back to the top of the ratings last week, besting by an average of 211,000 viewers a day the now-consistent morning leader, “Good Morning America” on ABC.

headline: The Impact of a Minimum-Wage Increase
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Off to a Bigger Journey, After Years in the World of ’30s-Style Swing Music
text: The young jazz singer Brianna Thomas has been playing clubs and festivals off and on since 2006. She has also led her own band for several years, but if you haven’t come across her it could be because she’s done a fair amount of work in the specialized world of ’30s-style swing music. That world generates work, but it also obscures.

headline: Hitler’s Germany, Seen Through Young Eyes
text: In 1936, Joachim Fest, 10 at the time, was summoned by his father, Johannes, to come with his older brother for a heart-to-heart talk in the study of their house in Berlin.

headline: President Obama Writes Apology to Art Historian
text: President Obama raised hackles last month when, during a speech at a factory in Wisconsin, he said that people could make more money with skills in manufacturing or the trades “than they might with an art history degree.”

headline: Amid Blunders on Ice, a Few Signs of Grace
text: It’s a consolation to know you aren’t alone. A few days before the Sochi Olympics started, several figure skating luminaries gathered for a screening as part of the Dance on Camera festival at Lincoln Center. After viewing a clip of the transcendent British skater John Curry, Dorothy Hamill made an astute observation: “This was the first time I watched skating in a long time without swearing at the television set.” There’s nothing like the Olympics to incite foul language. It’s not just the flawed judging system, in which skaters who hope to win a medal must focus more energy on racking up points than on refining their artistic point of view, or even Scott Hamilton’s effusive screech.

headline: Hedge Fund Suit Seeks Identity of Anonymous Blogger
text: David Einhorn has filed a lawsuit seeking to unmask the identity of an anonymous financial blogger who, he says, disclosed that Mr. Einhorn’s hedge fund was buying shares in a technology company. The legal maneuver illustrates the tension between a money manager’s ability to safeguard his trading strategies and the rights of others to report on them.

headline: Behind the Smashing of a Vase
text: MIAMI — Any new museum can expect teething problems.

text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: DC Home Buzz
text: Kenyan-born Ati Williams attended university in Canada, eventually coming to the U.S. for a post-college internship. She runs a boutique real-estate firm that charges an all-inclusive flat fee.

headline: White House Responds to Net Neutrality Petition
text: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials said Tuesday that the president continues to support a free and open Internet but that he cannot order the Federal Communications Commission to reclassify broadband service as a utility that is subject to the same rules and rate regulation as local telephone service.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Burberry’s Bloomsbury Chic
text: “Our girl is in touch with her artistic side this season,” the makeup artist Wendy Rowe said backstage at Burberry Prorsum. To complement Christopher Bailey’s collection, which was inspired by the romance of the early 20th-century circle of British writers and artists known as the Bloomsbury Group, Rowe mixed Burberry Fresh Glow Fluid in two colors — Nude Radiance and Golden Radiance — to achieve the relaxed, “slightly sun-kissed” aesthetic of a woman with greater things on her mind than makeup. Brows were groomed and lashes were left bare, while the aubergine-hued eye shadow — Rowe’s tribute to the group’s painters, such as Vanessa Bell and Roger Fry— tied in with the one-off painted pieces in the collection.

headline: Schumer Recuses Himself From Review of Comcast Deal
text: Senator Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, has recused himself from reviewing Comcast’s agreement to buy Time Warner Cable after the revelation that his brother, the lawyer Robert Schumer, worked on the deal.

headline: Lending Where Banks Can’t, Blackstone Thrives in Ireland
text: Bankers have been blanketing Ireland in search of cheap assets and lucrative deals, and few firms have been as aggressive as the Blackstone Group.

headline: F.B.I. Joins Ole Miss Inquiry After Noose Is Left on Statue
text: OXFORD, Miss. — The Federal Bureau of Investigation said Tuesday that it had joined the inquiry into an act of vandalism at the University of Mississippi, where a statue of the university’s first black student was found with a noose and a flag with the Confederate battle emblem.

headline: Former Aides to Christie Again Reject a Subpoena
text: Setting up a likely court battle, two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey refused again on Tuesday to provide materials subpoenaed by the legislative panel investigating the politically charged lane closings leading to the George Washington Bridge last September.

headline: After Delays, Musharraf Appears Before Pakistani Court
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pervez Musharraf, the former military ruler of Pakistan, finally made an appearance on Tuesday before a special court that is deciding whether to try him for treason, after he failed to appear at a series of earlier proceedings.

headline: Biathlon Reveals Slim Margin Between Silver and Gold
text: Emil Hegle Svendsen of Norway edged Martin Fourcade of France in a photo finish in the mass start 15,000 kilometer biathlon.

headline: Allowing Felons to Vote
Godot Arrives in Sarajevo
text: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — A BOY, his voice heavy with embarrassment and regret, was performing Samuel Beckett in Serbo-Croatian. “Mr. Godot,” he said, “told me to tell you that he won’t come this evening, but surely tomorrow.”

headline: Alison Jolly, Who Found Female Dominance in Lemurs, Dies at 76
text: Alison Jolly, an American-born primatologist whose research in the forests of Madagascar shed new light on the evolution of social intelligence and helped disprove a longstanding scientific tenet that males were dominant in every primate species, died on Feb. 6 in Lewes, East Sussex, England. She was 76.

text: RECENT SALE

headline: John A. Catsimatidis
text: Mr. Catsimatidis, 65, is the owner and chief executive of the Red Apple Group, a New York company with holdings in real estate, oil refining, retail petroleum products, convenience stores and the Red Apple and Gristedes supermarkets.

headline: Mormon Church to Expand Development in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — Plans for expansion of a Mormon complex along two blocks of north-central Philadelphia are providing city officials with a hope of reconnecting those sections to the city’s core business district of Center City.

headline: Ex-U.S. Lawmaker Charged With Pornography Possession in Zimbabwe
text: A former United States congressman from Illinois has been arrested in Zimbabwe and charged with possession of pornographic material, a local law enforcement spokeswoman said on Tuesday.

headline: South Sudan’s Forces Clash With Rebels Near U.N. Base
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — A fierce battle erupted between government and rebel forces in an oil-rich part of South Sudan on Tuesday, in the most significant violation of the cease-fire that was supposed to help bring peace to the fractured young nation.

headline: Profit Slides 8.5% for Coke, as Weak Sales Abroad Hit Hard
text: Changing consumer tastes and concerns about the role of soda in the nation’s obesity crisis were among the problems cited by analysts as responsible for lower earnings and sales for Coca-Cola in the fourth quarter.

headline: Olympics Can Be a Coaching Wilderness
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Coaches for Norway’s men’s biathlon team fanned out around the track for the 15-kilometer mass start race Tuesday afternoon with much of the equipment you would need for a really good bank heist. They had a truck, walkie-talkies, spotting scopes and 14 people, staked out along the course.

headline: In N.Y.U. Merger, One University and, for Now, Two Teams
text: On a recent night in Brooklyn, the N.Y.U.-Poly volleyball team won an exciting point in the first game of a match against visiting Purchase College.

headline: Loan Program for Reactors Is Fizzling
text: WASHINGTON — Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz is set to announce on Wednesday that he will finish a $6.5 billion loan guarantee this week and another soon for $1.8 billion to help three Georgia electric companies build the first new nuclear reactors in the United States in three decades.

headline: Breakfast Before the MOOC
text: Beginning March 2, Prof. Hossam Haick, will teach the first ever massive open online course, or MOOC, on nanotechnology in Arabic. What’s more interesting, though, he explained to me the other day over breakfast is some of the curious email he’s received from students registering for his MOOC from all over the Arab world. Their questions include: Are you a real person? Are you really an Arab, or are you an Israeli Jew speaking Arabic, pretending to be an Arab? That’s because Haick is an Israeli Arab from Nazareth and will be teaching this course from his home university, the Technion, Israel’s premier science and technology institute, and the place we were having breakfast was Tel Aviv.

headline: An Ambiguous Omen, U.S. Household Debt Begins to Rise Again
text: American households took on $241 billion in additional debt in the fourth quarter of last year, signaling the end of an extended period of hunkering down. Total household debt increased 2.1 percent, the largest quarterly increase since before the recession, according to a new report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: Candidate for Texas Governor Stands By Outspoken Musician
text: HOUSTON — Attorney General Greg Abbott of Texas, the leading candidate for the Republican nomination for governor, on Tuesday defended his decision to campaign with the pro-gun musician and conservative commentator Ted Nugent a month after Mr. Nugent called President Obama a “communist-nurtured subhuman mongrel.”

headline: Germany’s Coal Addiction
text: Germany is in the midst of an unprecedented shift to renewable energy, but is still dependent on brown coal. The village of Atterwasch may become a victim of Germany’s hunger for brown coal.

headline: 54 Drawers
text: This is the fourth part of an eight-part series.

headline: Violent Crimes Declined Across Country in First Six Months of 2013, F.B.I. Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Bureau of Investigation said Tuesday that violent crimes, including murders, fell by 5.4 percent in the first six months of 2013 compared with the same period in 2012, continuing a long reduction in violent crime across the country.

headline: German Village Resists Plans to Strip It Away for the Coal Underneath
text: ATTERWASCH, Germany — A grove of apple saplings grows on the lee side of Ulrich Schulz’s barn. He did not plant them for the fruit, he said, but as an act of rebellion against a nearby mining company that wants to raze his farm, which his family has owned since 1560, to get at the coal beneath his land.

headline: Puerto Rico Wants to Incur More Debt to Regain Financial Footing
text: Puerto Rico still has the capacity to issue more than $3 billion in new debt, senior officials said Tuesday, adding that they hoped to tap the credit markets in March despite concern about whether the commonwealth can sustain its current large debt load.

headline: Outrage Over Wall St. Pay, but Shrugs for Silicon Valley?
text: Big paydays on Wall Street often come under laserlike scrutiny, while Silicon Valley gets a pass on its own compensation excesses. Why the double standard?

headline: Difficult Turns in Footwork Sequence
text: Gold gets additional points by skimming across the ice while doing a series of turns, called a twizzle, which helps increase the difficulty level of her footwork sequence.

headline: A Challenging Spin Position
text: Gold enters a high-scoring combination spin with a challenging entry, known as a back entrance, then holds her camel position for two revolutions.

headline: A Quick Turn Before a Jump

headline: Venezuelan Protest Leader Jabs at Government on the Streets and Online

Mr. López, a Harvard-educated former mayor of a wealthy section of Caracas, is the political face of ongoing demonstrations against President Nicolás Maduro’s government.

headline: ‘Rhapsody in Blue’ or Rap? Skating Will Add Vocals

headline: Obama’s Vote-Getting Tactics Struggle to Find the Uninsured
text: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — The hunt for the uninsured in Broward County got underway one recent afternoon when 41 canvassers, armed with electronic maps on Samsung tablets, set off through working-class neighborhoods to peddle the Affordable Care Act door to door. Four hours later, they had made contact with 2,623 residents and signed up exactly 25 people.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Bold Step on Prison Education
text: One of the biggest obstacles to reducing America’s enormous prison population is the stubbornly high rates of recidivism. Nationwide, as many as half of those released end up back in prison within three years.

headline: Venezuelan Opposition Chief Surrenders, but Not Without a Rally
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — A prominent Venezuelan opposition leader surrendered to the authorities on Tuesday in the midst of a large crowd of supporters who tried to block his arrest on accusations that he was responsible for violence that erupted during recent antigovernment protests.

headline: What Next for Syria?
text: With the apparent collapse of the United Nations-mediated peace talks on Syria, the United States and its allies find themselves in a difficult spot. Absent a diplomatic and political option, what can the world do about a civil war that has killed an estimated 136,000 people, produced nine million refugees, displaced 4.25 million civilians internally and now threatens to destabilize several other countries in the region?

headline: ‘Too Perfect’ Job Offer Lures a Parks Expert Back to Work

headline: Change the Rules on Secret Money
text: In November, when the Internal Revenue Service finally stirred itself to propose a modest crackdown on the abuse of the tax code by political groups, it was immediately attacked by tax-exempt nonprofit groups on the right. That wasn’t too surprising; secret donations from conservatives to these groups are the principal reason American politics is now dominated by those with huge bank accounts.

The man with three lockers — one with his name above it, between two empty stalls in the far left corner of the clubhouse — is the cornerstone, charged with reviving a sagging brand.

headline: Chief of New Jersey Transit to Quit After a Rocky Tenure

headline: Doctors Train to Spot Signs of A.D.H.D. in Children

The child began flitting around the room distractedly, ignoring the doctor’s questions and squirming in his chair — but then he leapt up and yelled: “Freeze! What do you think is the problem here?”

headline: Politics to Shadow Obama’s Trade Talks in Mexico
text: TOLUCA, Mexico — President Obama traveled to Mexico on Wednesday for a brief but politically fraught visit aimed at forging closer trade ties with America’s two closest neighbors even as his party’s leaders back home have vowed to undercut his efforts.

headline: Northwestern Quarterback Makes His Case for Players’ Union
text: CHICAGO — Kain Colter, a football recruit, arrived at Northwestern University with dreams of becoming an orthopedic surgeon. But the summer before his freshman year, he said, he was steered away from a chemistry class toward less strenuous options like sociology and African history. He is now pursuing a psychology degree instead of the premed track.

headline: Motivational Words

headline: Educating Doctors About A.D.H.D. Without Resorting to ‘Ritalin Wars’
text: Not long ago, amid what felt like a rising tide of criticism of parents of children who were being medicated for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (A.D.H.D.), readers in this space complained, and I joined them. It’s offensive, we said, to accuse parents (and teachers, and doctors) of using drug treatment to get “off the hook” for more complex problems, or teaching children to “reach for a pill” instead of finding another way to cope with a problem. It’s also useless. If A.D.H.D. is being over-diagnosed or overmedicated, pointing fingers won’t help either children who do need treatment or those who need something else.

headline: City’s Safety Net on Trial Over a Baby Killed in ’07
text: By all accounts, Hailey Gonzalez’s life was short, impoverished and brutal. She was born in November 2005 to unwed parents living in a homeless shelter. Her mother, Marlene Medina, a foster child herself, had already lost custody of another daughter, Elizabeth, because a judge had determined that she was not fit to care for her.

headline: Former Marine in Tehran Jail Retains a Top Iranian Lawyer
text: Amir Hekmati, a former Marine incarcerated in Iran on spying charges, has retained a prominent Iranian lawyer to represent him in a new effort to gain his release after nearly two and a half years in Tehran’s Evin Prison, Mr. Hekmati’s family reported on Tuesday.

headline: Militant Group Says It Attacked Tourist Bus in Sinai
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian militant group that has carried out months of deadly assaults on the police and the military has claimed responsibility for the bombing of a tourist bus that killed four people in the Sinai Peninsula on Sunday.

headline: In Ryan, Yankees Have Understudy Who Knows His Role

He felt the need to go, he said, because the three previous times he had seen the Clippers this season, their star point guard, Chris Paul, did not play because of injury.

headline: Snowboarders and Skiers Fly in Face of Logo Rules

Fans at the venues and viewers at home will not see any business logos in the background, except the ubiquitous Olympic rings and Sochi 2014 emblem. Compared with Nascar cars, international soccer uniforms or outfield fences, the illusion of the Olympics is one of noncommercial purity.

headline: Bob Casale, Guitarist in Devo, Dies at 61

While the Whitney features artists from across the country, the Hammer focuses on new or under-recognized artists working in Los Angeles.

Of course, he knew it was unlikely. After everything that had happened against the Grizzlies on Tuesday night — the early deficit, the late comeback — Anthony and the Knicks could only watch.

headline: The Employer Mandate: Dukakis All Over Again

text: Watching participants in slopestyle and half-pipe skiing and snowboarding flip, curl, cartwheel and otherwise contort themselves in the air during the Winter Olympics competition, many of us have probably wondered not only how the athletes managed to perform such feats but also why. Helpfully, a recent study of the genetics of risk-taking intimates that their behavior may be motivated, at least in part, by their DNA.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: Noon (IFC) THE LIFE AQUATIC WITH STEVE ZISSOU (2004) Bill Murray, above center, is Steve Zissou, a flashy oceanographer far past his prime, who, after the death of his friend (Seymour Cassel), is confronted by his own sense of mortality, the sudden appearance of an airplane pilot (Owen Wilson) who may or may not be his son, an investigative reporter (Cate Blanchett) and a bond company stooge (Bud Cort) in this comedy from Wes Anderson, who wrote the screenplay with Noah Baumbach. “In my ideal cinémathèque, ‘The Life Aquatic’ would play on a permanent double bill with ‘The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie,’ ” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Anderson and Stephen Hillenburg, Mr. SquarePants’s creator, share not only a taste for nautical nonsense, but also a willingness to carry the banner of unfettered imaginative silliness into battle against the tyranny of maturity.”

headline: A Chilling Phone Call Adds to Hurdles of Publishing Xi Jinping Book

text: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine spiraled deeper into disarray on Wednesday as the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovych and several thousand grimly determined protesters, along with their supporters in Russia and Europe, faced off in a confrontation over the fate of this fractured country of 46 million.

headline: Pity Brazil’s Military Police
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — In Brazil, police officers kill an average of five people every day. In 2012, according to a security report from the Brazilian Forum on Public Security, 1,890 Brazilians were killed by the police, 351 here in São Paulo. That was around 20 percent of all homicides in the city. At the same time, 11 police officers were killed on duty here and around 100 were executed off-duty, allegedly by organized crime. Police officers are three times more likely to be murdered than the average Brazilian.

headline: State Media Outlets Call Xi Jinping Cartoon a First

headline: After Two Centuries, Peugeot Family Cedes Control
text: PARIS — The family business that grew into PSA Peugeot Citroën got its start more than 200 years ago, making manufactured goods like pepper mills, bicycles and whale-bone corsets on its way to becoming the largest automaker in France. This week the Peugeot family, one of the country’s wealthiest, agreed to give up control of the company it had been running for eight generations.

headline: Learning to Cut the Sugar
text: Dr. Robert Lustig became widely known as “the anti-sugar guy” after a lecture of his called “Sugar: The Bitter Truth” was posted on YouTube and gained widespread attention. In his talk, Dr. Lustig explains why all calories are not created equal, and why he believes those from sugar in particular are driving an epidemic of obesity and chronic disease.

headline: Things End Badly for a Poet, but Quite Well for the Tenor
text: Last February, the German tenor Jonas Kaufmann had a triumph at the Metropolitan Opera when he performed the title role of Wagner’s “Parsifal” in the company’s very bleak but theatrically riveting new production. On Tuesday night, a year later, Mr. Kaufmann was back at the Met in the title role of Massenet’s “Werther” on the opening night of Richard Eyre’s new production. It was another success for Mr. Kaufmann, currently the most in-demand, versatile and exciting tenor in opera.

headline: As Far as Possible From His Sitcom
text: Sporting a Marc Jacobs tuxedo and fashionably mussed hair, Neil Patrick Harris sweeps into the Pierre Hotel looking super-duper, as he likes to say, but craving his usual pick-me-up, a sugar-free Red Bull. It’s 7 p.m. on a Monday, and he has just finished his first rehearsal for the Broadway rock musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” testing his vocal range against the show’s thrashing score. Ahead are hours of schmoozing as the 2014 honoree of the Drama League, an organization that usually celebrates Tony Award-winning stars.

headline: LinkedIn Wants to Be Your Soapbox, Not Just Your Résumé
text: LinkedIn has established itself as the digital résumé service for the white-collar world, with 277 million users globally. On Wednesday, it will announce features that will help users enhance their profiles with essays, work samples or industry manifestos to stand out from the crowd.

headline: Carlyle’s Profit Soars on Rise in Performance Fees

headline: Doubts About Candy Crush’s Sweetness
text: SUGAR RUSH FOR CANDY CRUSH  |  King Digital Entertainment’s filing of a $500 million initial public offering on Tuesday had many investors salivating. But it remains to be seen whether the company behind the addictive game Candy Crush can sustain its sweetness and avoid the pitfalls of other game makers, Jenna Wortham and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. Indeed, Candy Crush attracts 93 million players each day and accounts for nearly 80 percent of the company’s revenue, which neared $1.9 billion by the end of 2013 from $164 million in 2012.

headline: Amid Efforts to Expand Marine Preserves, a Warning to Focus on Quality
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A generation ago, when Tommy Remengesau Jr. went fishing off the beautiful island nation of Palau, the seas were so rich, he said, that “I could see great stocks of fish.” Such bounty has since dwindled, in Palau and worldwide.

headline: U.S. Imposes Visa Ban on 20 Ukrainian Officials as Further Sanctions Are Threatened

The Obama administration later said it had placed 20 top Ukrainian officials on a visa blacklist.

headline: Letting Lehman Fail

Today’s class was a sort of narrative walkthrough of the financial crisis, and in the course of preparing I found myself trying to recall who actually thought letting Lehman fail was a good idea.

headline: Two Burches Branch Out with a Chic New Brand
text: Like the mountainous collection of trinkets scattered throughout Pookie Burch’s East Village apartment, Trademark, the new women’s wear line she started with her younger sister Louisa, is tempting to close-read. The collection’s influences — Donald Judd, Maine in the 1960s — are apparent but ineffable, abstracted to an obscure likability. The clothes are the product of two self-taught designers who embrace eclecticism without veering into quirk — and whose father just so happens to be the billionaire venture capitalist J. Christopher Burch.

headline: Court in Thailand Limits Crackdown on Protesters
text: BANGKOK — Describing the movement to overthrow the Thai government as peaceful, a Bangkok civil court on Wednesday sharply curtailed the powers of the authorities and barred them from dispersing protesters, a decision that a prominent legal analyst described as “one step closer to a full-scale judicial coup.”

headline: In West Asheville, N.C., Bistros Mix With Tattoo Parlors
text: Gritty is still an operative description for West Asheville, N.C., a section of this city where pawn shops, tattoo parlors and auto repair shops have reigned. But as Ashevillians move to this side of the French Broad River to escape downtown’s escalating rents and tourism, the area has become a blue-collar hybrid with yoga studios and bistros joining longtime establishments along the main drag, Haywood Road. West Asheville has been called the “Worst Asheville,” said Jodi Rhoden, who owns a bakery, Short Street Cakes. “So there’s a sense of embattled pride and a determination to make it work.”

headline: Home-Front Heroines
text: Ten years ago, Cokie Roberts, the political commentator and contributor to National Public Radio’s “Morning Edition,” published “Founding Mothers: The Women Who Raised Our Nation.” Now she has distilled that much longer work about women’s roles at the time of the American Revolution to create “Founding Mothers: Remembering the Ladies,” a picture book intended for children from 7 to 12, engagingly illustrated by Diane Goode.

headline: An Awards Night Suited for Royalty
text: LONDON — As the minutes ticked down to the start of the Bafta Awards on Sunday night, Uma Thurman, magisterially dressed in a floor-length, strapless navy blue Atelier Versace gown, had a pressing question for one of the show’s organizers: What should we do when Prince William arrives?

headline: F.C.C. Seeks a New Path on ‘Net Neutrality’ Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Regulators are taking another crack at their effort to keep the web free and open, introducing new rules that would discourage Internet service providers from charging companies to stream their movies, music and other content through a faster express lane.

headline: Below the Line: Editing ‘Captain Phillips’
text: The film editor Christopher Rouse has built an intimate collaborative relationship with the director Paul Greengrass over the past decade. Their partnership began with  “The Bourne Supremacy” in 2004, and he won an Oscar in 2008 for his editing of “The Bourne Ultimatum.” He’s up for another Oscar for his  work on “Captain Phillips,” based on the  hijacking of an American container ship by Somali pirates. Whether Mr. Rouse is editing fiction features or ones based on true events (“United 93”), he is driven by the characters’ motivations.

headline: The Audi S3 Cabriolet is Sporty, but Is Not Headed for U.S.

headline: When Work Disappears
text: At the risk of exhausting my readers, I wanted to return yet again to the debate over workforce participation, because a couple of recent pieces that aren’t directly about the recent Obamacare argument have been helpful in clarifying the deeper issues in play. The first one is from Martin Wolf of the Financial Times, a sensible man of the center-left, making recommendations for how the developed world might adapt to automation, computerization and the disappearance of low-wage, low-skilled work:

headline: Classical Playlist: Jenny Lin, Joshua Rubin, David Aladashvili and More
text: STRAVINSKY: Solo Piano WorksJenny Lin, pianist(Steinway & Sons)Stravinsky may not have written that many works for solo piano. But he left pianists some astonishing scores, especially the Piano Sonata and the Serenade in A, along with many smart shorter works and charming miniatures. The excellent and inquisitive American pianist Jenny Lin, born in Taiwan in 1973, plays just about the complete Stravinsky solo piano music on this impressive release, from Steinway & Sons, which some years ago started a recording label. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Immigrants Welcome Here
text: Earlier this month, John Boehner declared that it was unlikely that the House of Representatives would pass major immigration reform legislation this year. Given the desperate need for an overhaul of the system, the political gridlock is dismaying. But thankfully it’s not the whole immigration story.

headline: A Content Company Weighs Becoming a Technology Company
text: TPR MEDIA creates and distributes medical-related messages and information to patients. Co-founded by Betsy Weaver in 2002, the company, which is based in Boston and has 20 employees, helps hospitals reduce the number of calls doctors receive from patients and keeps people informed of what to expect on their medical journeys.

headline: Detention of Snowden Journalist’s Partner by British Is Upheld
text: LONDON — The partner of Glenn Greenwald, the journalist who published information leaked by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden, lost his legal challenge on Wednesday over his nine-hour detention at London’s Heathrow Airport last August under counterterrorism laws. Mr. Greenwald’s partner, David Michael Miranda, was stopped while in transit from Germany to Brazil and was told he was being detained under Section 7 of the British Terrorism Act.

headline: Can a Content Company Become a Tech Company?
text: We just published a case study about the owner of a company that delivers health care-related messages to patients via email and is faced with some big decisions. When Betsy Weaver started TPR Media in Boston in 2002, she was working with hospital maternity divisions to send emails to patients that explained what they needed to bring to the hospital, what medications to take, what happens after they see the doctor and more. Her service allowed physicians to cut down on the many patient phone calls they had been receiving.

But that one person was sitting behind the microphone, answering questions as if he were discussing just another Wednesday game in Cleveland or Chicago.

headline: Silver Is the Winter Color for a Summer Gold Medalist
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Lauryn Williams is not certain where her Olympic track medals are — she thinks the silver from the 2004 Olympics may be at her mother’s house — so it was not hard to believe her on Wednesday night when she said that missing history by a measly tenth of a second was not especially disappointing.

headline: Thin-Skinned Spies
text: Dan McCall, operator of the website Liberty Maniacs, uses the National Security Agency seal on T-shirts and mugs that say “Spying on you since 1952” and “The only part of government that actually listens.” He also sells merchandise with a “Department of Homeland Stupidity” logo.

headline: The Gun Report: February 19, 2014
text: About 60 more people than usual have been murdered with firearms each year since Missouri got rid of background checks for gun sales in 2007, according to a new study by the Johns Hopkins Center for Gun Policy and Research. The state has seen a 23 percent increase in firearm homicide rates, even as the murder rate dropped 5 percent nationally. The rise in murders occurred only for those involving a firearm.

headline: Nerd Factor Aside, Bluetooth Headsets Are Useful on the Go
text: After about an hour of getting odd looks from co-workers, I felt compelled to explain myself. The Jawbone Era headset sticking out of my right ear, I said, was for this review.

headline: If Acne Doesn’t Bother My Son, Why Should It Bother Me?
text: My 15-year-old son doesn’t care about his acne. This astonishes me. How could acne not ruin his life? When I was his age I thought it had ruined mine.

headline: Celebrating a Building That Has Stood for Decades as a Symbol of the Press
text: The exhibition occurs within the genteel precincts of the Grolier Club on the Upper East Side. But the principal object is a muscular industrial fortress almost three miles downtown.

headline: The Tall-Order Rental
text: In California, where they used to live, Beatrice Gomberg and Ray Barba had no trouble finding housing. “We got offered every apartment we could have possibly wanted,” Ms. Gomberg said.

headline: Where Timelessness Meets Time Travel
text: With a head full of blond curls, and wearing a glittery blouse, Nellie McKay flounced into Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening, ushering a gust of downtown freshness into this elegant uptown precinct. Ms. McKay, 31, has been a presence on the cultural scene for at least a decade. But she still wears the mystique of a willful prodigy who is smarter, more talented and hipper than everyone else: a performer who answers only to herself. Gifts that others spend years refining seem to come naturally to her.

headline: Harper Lee Settles Lawsuit With Museum
text: Harper Lee, the author of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” is settling a lawsuit filed last year against a museum in her Alabama hometown claiming that it had sold merchandise featuring her name and the title of her novel without compensation.

headline: The Auditing Roadblock: It’s Not Just China
text: The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board is out with a list of 58 international audit firms that it has been unable to inspect for at least four years. Those firms all audited companies registered in the United States, and — under American law — must be inspected by the board. The board has tried to arrange joint inspections with regulators from other countries, but a variety of impediments have arisen.

headline: Luck’s on Their Side, but Americans Don’t Need It in Rout
text: SOCHI, Russia — The bounces seemed to go the Americans’ way on Wednesday.

headline: A Case That Lets You Be the Designer
text: With a sea of device accessories designed by other people, one company, Caseable, is turning the tables and letting you be the designer.

headline: Port Authority Official ‘Deeply Sorry’ for Closed Lanes
text: Amid unyielding scrutiny into the role of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and his administration in the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, a top official of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey apologized on Wednesday to the commuters who sat in manufactured traffic over the course of several days in September.

headline: Still Life in Motion From a Road Trip Across South America
text: David Guttenfelder captures scenes along the Interoceanic Highway.

headline: A Bloody Night in Cres
text: Not long ago, I spent a month with Aniza and Dinko Muskardin, residents of the Croatian island of Cres, enjoying their emphatic Balkan hospitality in exchange for a few weeks’ help around their farm. I was besotted by my elderly hosts. I helped Dinko cut oak and juniper, search the hills for lost sheep and bottle the evil-smelling yellow wine that he aged in a cracked, slimy barrel. I was so besotted, in fact, that I didn’t hesitate when my host said to me, with an ominous gleam in his eyes, that it was time to kill the year-old “pecorina.” (Dinko was old enough to remember the Mussolini era, and we spoke in a pidgin of Italian.)

headline: A Busman’s Honeymoon
text: I had been cooking avidly for six years when, in the fall of 1976, thinking it was important to learn about “French” and “Northern Italian,” I flew to Rome with my new wife to begin what we called a “sort of honeymoon.”

headline: Wet Hot Israeli Summer
text: In 1990, just before Saddam Hussein began lobbing Scud missiles at Tel Aviv and Haifa, my father and I paid our first visit to Israel. The men in my family can be adventurous: Before he emigrated from the Soviet Union, my father had taken to marching outside Leningrad’s Grand Choral Synagogue chanting: “We! Are! Jews!” with a group of fellow believers, a beautiful and lunatic gesture under an increasingly anti-Semitic regime. Likewise, the looming threat of Iraqi Scuds made us giddy at the thought of floating in the Dead Sea hoisting copies of The International Herald Tribune with its daily war cries by Saddam’s ever-present little buddy, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz.

headline: In the Company of Truckers
text: One summer in the late 1990s, I was driving across the country on Interstate 80, having just stopped to visit some friends in Des Moines. I was behind the wheel of a 1963 Chevrolet Impala I bought outside Asheville, N.C. The car ran well and was beautiful — champagne body with a cream top, no dents, no rust. It still even had these original plastic discs, like thin translucent washers, that fit between the window roller and the door panel to keep the upholstery from being indented or pinched. I was planning to sell it in Los Angeles, where a ’63 two-door Impala in such cherry condition was the ultimate low rider and worth a lot of money.

headline: ‘We Were About Half a Mile From Shore, Naked and Drunk to a Man’
text: On a sticky day in late June 2003, I was walking down West 16th Street in New York feeling sorry for myself — the only person in a city of eight million without Fourth of July plans — when I ran into a beautiful and sophisticated woman I slightly knew. She was sitting on a stoop with an equally glamorous friend, drinking iced coffee. She had been meaning to call me. She knew it was late notice, but she wondered if by any chance I was free for a party at a friend’s compound — compound! — in the Hamptons that weekend. Oh, um, well . . . yes.

headline: The ‘Braveheart’ Fantasy
text: Years ago, two friends and I rented a car and drove through the Scottish Highlands, stopping at bed-and-breakfasts and drinking whisky. The rental car had only a CD player, and one of the few CDs we had was the soundtrack to “Braveheart,” which I’d brought with me as kind of a joke. (I say “kind of a joke” because I don’t want you to think I’m the type of person who brings the “Braveheart” soundtrack on a trip to Scotland. But I am.)

headline: 5 Books to Take on Your Travels
text: 1. The Moronic Inferno: And Other Visits to America, by Martin Amis (1987)

headline: Traveling From Ocean to Ocean Across South America
text: Before the passengers turned on the driver and began plotting a mutiny, the ride was smooth. The bus rolled out of the station in São Paulo at about 4 o’clock on a Wednesday afternoon last July, and within an hour it had shaken free of the city’s clotted tunnels, jammed overpasses and coded graffiti. By 6, we were barreling straight into a lurid sunset that endowed everything with the candied luster of fresh paint. Green hills, silver ponds, golden palms. Two parrots soared in tandem over a sugar-cane field, inviting us to drift into a pastoral trance.

headline: An Instagram Travel Diary
text: I’ve been to 55 places in the past year. I pick a spot and some dates, and then whoever wants to come can come, even if I don’t know them that well. I look for naturally beautiful spots that I’ve never been to before. There was a phase last summer when it was only swimming holes in upstate New York. And then after that, I wanted to go only to places with the biggest, weirdest rocks. Two specific memories come to mind from the past year: one is sleeping on a boat deck with my brothers under what felt like the darkest sky with the brightest stars in the Andaman Sea off Myanmar. And the other is standing with friends at the throat of an eroded volcano in New Mexico called Shiprock, right as the sun was setting on one of the last days of the year. Both places were shockingly beautiful and isolated and contained only a handful of people I really love.

headline: A Tour of the Center of the World
text: Just head toward the 21-foot pyramid in the middle of the desert.

headline: In Soweto, History From Those Who Live It
text: Three sounds competed to rule the Soweto night, at least as heard from the roof deck of Flossie’s B&B in Pimville Zone 1: a surround-sound chorus of crickets; the intermittent barking of neighborhood dogs; and cars zooming by on Chris Hani Road two blocks north. The roof’s shiny railing arced out like an observation deck, but all there was to observe was the intersection of Dube and Gonsi Streets, a brick house with corrugated metal roof and satellite dish on the corner, other just slightly neater houses beyond.

headline: Where the World’s Greatest Photographers Go to Get Away
text: They may be off the clock, but they still have their cameras.

headline: A Journey to the Center of the World
text: One morning in late January, Jacques-André Istel woke up at his home in Felicity, Calif., did 100 push-ups and 125 squats, swam in his elegantly lit lap pool, then went back upstairs, where he took a light breakfast in bed, as has been his custom since his boyhood in Paris. After breakfast, he dressed in a blue shirt and ascot and walked to his office at 1 Center of the World Plaza. It was Istel’s birthday; he was turning 85.

headline: From England to the Edge of Africa
text: After graduating from college, Tom Allen searched for an escape from an unfulfilling, deskbound career. A plan to bike through a few countries snowballed into a four-year trip through 32 countries, from his home in England through Europe, the Middle East and down the northeastern edge of Africa.

headline: Signet and Zale Deal Casts 2 Other Deals in a Poor Light
text: Leave it to a couple of diamond dealers to show how to make mergers and acquisitions sparkle. The stock of the jewelry retailer Signet rose after it agreed to buy its smaller rival Zale at a 41 percent premium for an enterprise value, which includes debt, of $1.4 billion. That’s what happens when the cost savings effectively cover the purchase price. It makes the shareholder-unfriendly transactions involving Comcast and Jos. A. Bank all the more noticeable.

text: SOCHI, Russia — Her choice of music for Wednesday’s short program, “Send In the Clowns,” might have suggested departure and regret instead of victory for Kim Yu-na of South Korea, the defending Olympic women’s figure skating champion.

headline: Lawmaker Urges U.S. Regulators to Scrutinize Mortgage Servicers
text: Representative Maxine Waters of California is urging federal banking regulators to scrutinize the sale of billions of dollars of mortgage-servicing rights to a fleet of specialty firms, a move that comes amid mounting concerns that some of the most vulnerable homeowners are facing fresh abuses in battles to save their homes.

headline: Eric Church Hits No. 1
text: Eric Church, a country singer with a taste for big rock ’n’ roll riffs, opened at No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart with his latest release, “The Outsiders” (EMI Nashville). The album, his second to reach the top, sold 288,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Escape Plan: It Starts With the Dress
text: Bone-chilling temperatures, snow — and let’s not even talk about the treacherous black ice. No one needs to tell us it’s time for an escape. A few personal days and an inexpensive ticket, and you’re in a warm place. Here’s what to take with you.

headline: A Freshman Representative Sizes Up Congress
text: Representative Gloria Negrete McLeod of California required less than a full term in the House to size up the place and decide it was better to go back home and run for a seat on the San Bernardino County Board of Supervisors. I doubt she regretted her choice when the fellow Democrat she had defeated in 2012, former Representative Joe Baca, denounced her as “some bimbo” for quitting.

headline: Two Authors Ask Indian Publisher to Pulp Their Books
text: Penguin India drew strong criticism from authors earlier this month after it decided to withdraw and pulp the scholar Wendy Doniger’s book “The Hindus: An Alternative History,” thus ending a four-year legal battle with Hindu nationalists who argued the book violated Indian laws against giving religious offense.

headline: Tony Blair Emerges as Figure in Tabloid Hacking Case

headline: Passage to Midlife on Broken Pavement
text: “Bark,” the title of Lorrie Moore’s disappointing new collection of stories, seems to refer to several things at once: the yelp of a dog, the peeling garb of a tree and the process of “debarking” from a plane. Each meaning can be taken to allude to the animal fact of human mortality, and the experience of loss and departure that marks the human condition. The multiple meanings also underscore Ms. Moore’s love of wordplay and puns — her hyper-awareness of language and her attunement to what one character calls the “missingness” of life.

headline: Pushing Back Against Government Surveillance
text: As Edward J. Snowden’s revelations of the extent of spying by the United States National Security Agency roiled the world last June, Xie Yanyi, a Beijing lawyer, asked the Ministry of Public Security to tell him about Chinese security officials’ spying on their own citizens, especially regarding online and telephone communications.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Lebanon, Thailand and India.

headline: Self-Examination for All to See and Hear
text: We are all in the constant process of creating, refining or redefining our identities. Today, it has become practically a full-time job, as social networks spread like kudzu, and people spend countless hours considering how best to present themselves to the watching world. Who do you think you are? The question has become ever more pressing and ever more public: I Instagram, therefore I am.

headline: Those Brand-Name Musicals
text: Back in the days of vaudeville — or to be precise, a 1959 musical’s version of vaudeville — a wise old stripper delivered some immortal advice for anyone starting out in showbiz: “You gotta have a gimmick, if you wanna have a chance.” Thus spake the trumpet-tooting Mazeppa, addressing the title character of “Gypsy.”

headline: Indian State to Free 7 Convicted in Rajiv Gandhi Assassination Plot
text: MUMBAI, India — The chief minister of Tamil Nadu said Wednesday that her government would free six men and one woman who were convicted of plotting the 1991 assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, the former prime minister of India.

headline: The Corcoran Gallery of Art May Cede Control of Its Collection
