headline: Slithering Through the Air With the Greatest of Ease
text: Some people might view a snake that can launch itself from trees and glide through the air as their worst nightmare, something to be avoided, proof positive that human beings were not meant to venture out of doors.

headline: And Surrogacy Makes 3
text: A month before their baby’s due date, Brad Hoylman and David Sigal got a call from the woman they had hired to have their child.

headline: A New York Chef’s Home-Cooking Essentials
text: Camille Becerra is no stranger to departures and homecomings. “We actually lived here before,” the chef and food stylist says, waving around her sun-filled TriBeCa loft. “That day the towers went down, we physically left,” she says of Sept. 11, which prompted her to flee with her then six-month-old daughter to the Brooklyn neighborhood of Greenpoint, where they lived for seven years. During that period in her new neighborhood, Becerra opened Paloma, a restaurant housed in a converted parking garage, which she named after her daughter. In 2008 the restaurant burned down, and Becerra returned to her beloved loft in Manhattan.

headline: Derek Jeter Keeps His Cool, but His Outlook Has Changed
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Control was the defining issue. If he could ward off distractions, if he could make it all about the ball, the glove and his opportunistic bat, baseball would forever be the little boys’ game even when it was being played for riches once beyond his imagination.

headline: Jimmy Fallon’s Audience Stays Large, but Where Will It Settle?
text: The falloff was predictable for Night 2 of “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” — down to 7.3 million viewers from 11.3 million viewers for his premiere on Monday.

headline: Russian Riot Grrrls Beaten but Not Arrested in Sochi
text: There were signs of confusion in the official response to a new performance by the Russian protest group Pussy Riot on Wednesday in Sochi, as the activists were first set upon by Cossack militiamen and beaten with whips and pepper spray, but then allowed to retrieve their guitar from a trash can and leave without being arrested.

headline: Forget the Fantasy, Keep It Friendly
text: The basement of the Palais de Tokyo was staged like a snowbound park at twilight. Lampposts glowed faintly throughout the sea of white. This winter wonderland during the rainy men’s fashion shows in Paris last month was courtesy of Alexandre Mattiussi, the designer of the nascent label Ami.

headline: Sic Transit New Jersey
text: After more than four years on the job and three massive foul-ups on his watch, James Weinstein is resigning as executive director of New Jersey Transit. Gov. Chris Christie has already announced his replacement, and we can only hope that Veronique Hakim, head of the state’s thruway authority, is independent-minded enough to worry first and foremost about commuters.

headline: Facebook Enters $16 Billion Deal for WhatsApp
text: The frenzy to acquire fast-growing technology start-ups reached new heights on Wednesday as Facebook announced its largest acquisition ever, saying it would pay at least $16 billion for WhatsApp, a text messaging application with 450 million users around the world who pay little or no money for it.

headline: Excerpts as Obama Signs the Farm Bill
text: President Obama on Friday signed the $956 billion farm bill into law. It replaces direct crop payments to farmers with an insurance program, and trims the food stamp program.

headline: A Star From Norway Stands Alone
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — His tie with his countryman Bjorn Daehlie was broken, and Ole Einar Bjorndalen was posing for group photographs.

headline: Obama Reacts to Unrest in Ukraine
text: President Obama commented on the continuing violence in Ukraine.

headline: Safeway Says It Is Exploring a Sale
text: Shares of Safeway climbed in after-market trading on Wednesday after the supermarket chain disclosed that it was “in discussions concerning a possible transaction involving the sale of the company.”

headline: Study Finds Drops Are Best Treatment for Ear Tube-Related Dripping
text: For children with ear tubes, topical antibiotic drops treat the leaky discharge caused by an ear infection much more effectively than oral antibiotics or observation, according to a study published in The New England Journal of Medicine on Wednesday.

headline: James Patterson Giving Cash to Bookstores
text: Independent bookstores, with their paper-thin profit margins and competition from Amazon, have found themselves a Daddy Warbucks.

headline: To Be Young in a Vienna That’s Headed Nowhere Good
text: Consider Desiree, a Viennese medical student in 1923: Young, sexually knowing and effortlessly good at her studies, she seems at first blush like a wunderkind in a red slip. But to Desiree, the future looks bleak. “Bourgeois existence or suicide,” she says, “there are no other choices.”

headline: 350,000 Ways to Harness Energy From the Sun
text: Jamey Stillings, a photographer from Santa Fe, N.M., has photographed the development of the Ivanpah Solar thermal plant for more than three years.

headline: Her Blog, Her Brand
text: On her popular blog, Maskcara.com, Cara Brook, 28, sings the praises of highlighting and contouring one’s facial features, a process she refers to as HAC’ing (pronounced “hacking”). She gleaned the technique, in which a color a few shades darker than the skin is used to create shadows on the edges and in the hollows of the face while a slightly lighter one plays up the high planes of the cheekbones, nose, forehead and chin, from books by the makeup artist Kevyn Aucoin, which she pored over as a teenager obsessed with the beauty business. “It’s a magical thing,” she effused in a how-to video.

headline: Derek Jeter Talks Retirement
text: The New York Yankees’ Derek Jeter held a news conference Wednesday to discuss his retirement at the end of the 2014 season.

headline: Events and Sales Starting the Week of Feb. 20
text: Sales

headline: The Nominees Are Blockbusters
text: The story in “Frozen,” the blockbuster Disney musical, did not originally center on two sister princesses. Based loosely on “The Snow Queen” fairy tale, it always had a pair of girls at its core, but it wasn’t until several years into the production process, at a story meeting in the company’s Burbank, Calif., headquarters, that someone suggested that Elsa and Anna be siblings.

headline: This Phone Is Great, Till It’s Time to Add Apps
text: If the tech business were fair, you would be considering the Nokia Icon for your next smartphone.

headline: Selected Emails Released in Wisconsin
text: Thousands of pages of email messages were released on Wednesday in connection with a secret criminal investigation into whether campaigning had been conducted on government time in a county office once led by Scott Walker, now the governor of Wisconsin. These are just a handful.

headline: An Invitation to Revel in Their Claim to History
text: “WE WERE TALKING about getting older,” Diane von Furstenberg said not long ago as she reminisced about a conversation she had shared over lunch with Anna Wintour. What are a few furrows and frown lines? Ms. Wintour said blithely. “We’re legends, you know.”

headline: Milan Fashion Week: N°21 Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Founder of Citadel Pledges $150 Million to Harvard, Its Largest Gift Ever
text: Updated, 8:32 p.m. | When the billionaire hedge fund manager Kenneth C. Griffin was a sophomore at Harvard, he was betting on convertible bonds in his dorm room — thanks to a satellite dish he had hooked up on the roof — while his fellow students were going to classes.

headline: A Mexican Showcase for Ambition
text: MEXICO CITY — Churning and wired, this city is a place of many devotions. Some of them revolve around art. Worshipers throng the Señora de Guadalupe shrine to gaze on a miraculous painting of the Virgin. Secular pilgrims on the hunt for saints crowd Casa Azul, “The Blue House,” Frida Kahlo’s home. Every tourist makes a must-see stop at the National Museum of Anthropology with its hair-raising sculptures of Aztec gods.

headline: Times Minute | Fairness in Web Access
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | News on Internet Access
text: Also on the Minute, changes to New York State's prison system and tight competition for the bronze in the ladies figure skating short program.

headline: Advisers on Facebook Deal Could Earn More Than $80 Million
text: The two advisers who helped Facebook make its largest acquisition to date stand to earn tens of millions of dollars for their work.

headline: Meet Lord Huron, a Musical Project That Is Also an Alternate Reality Game
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Ask Ben Schneider to name the inspiration for his band, Lord Huron, and he will name George Ranger Johnson, one of the more prolific Western adventure novelists you’ve never heard of.

headline: L.B.J. and the Shadow of Vietnam
In Women’s Figure Skating, Kim Carves Slim Lead for Gold Medal
text: The short program on Wednesday set up an unpredictable race for the Olympic gold medal in women’s figure skating.

headline: Makeup That Can Enliven Winter Skin
text: With the tan now a beauty boogeyman, some consumers are looking for different ways to enliven winter-dulled skin. Enter the illuminator, several new versions of which have come to market recently.

headline: Which Is Better, Shower Curtain or Glass Door?
text: Q. I want my shower to look as high-end as possible, but I’m on a budget: Which is better, shower curtain or glass door?

headline: Preindustrial Design Meets Politics
text: “Prima Materia,” which opened this week at the Stedelijk Museum’s-Hertogenbosch in the Netherlands, is the first retrospective of the work of Studio Formafantasma, the partnership of Simone Farresin and Andrea Trimarchi.

headline: A Treasure Trove of Wood-Block Prints
text: Though the technique of printing fabrics with wood blocks is ancient, Western Europeans adopted it only a few hundred years ago. Zucchi, an Italian textiles manufacturer, has amassed a collection of some 56,000 examples from 1785 to 1935, and has created a museum for them in Rescaldina, near Milan. Now the company has dipped into this trove to create a line of bedding, table linens, throws and area rugs.

headline: Whatever Floats Your Soap
text: It looks like a teak salad bowl and costs as much as a new Honda. The Salish Sea is a wood bathtub by Seth Rolland, a furniture maker in Washington State. “I live in Port Townsend, the wooden-boat-building capital of the West Coast,” he said. He started building boats, but switched to furniture because it offered more artistic license. “A table has to have a flat surface and be about 28 inches high,” he said. “After that, everything is open.” Making the tub, for a client in Tennessee, involved 200 pieces of sustainable sapele wood, glued with epoxy, hand sanded, then waterproofed by a local wood kayak maker with layers of epoxy over an invisible fiberglass lining, on top of which went six coats of varnish. Shown above, it is 85 inches long and 36 inches deep. Prices start at $28,000. Information: sethrolland.com or 360-379-0414.

headline: Paper Furnishings
text: Luca Nichetto is an Italian designer who grew up professionally among the glassmaking studios of Murano. These days, however, he often finds himself inspired by a humbler medium.

headline: What Goes Beep in the Night
text: Machines that insinuate themselves into their surroundings, quietly monitoring your behavior, may be worrying, but as far as I’m concerned, those that bombard you with reminders of their presence are more disturbing.

headline: Some Bot to Watch Over Me
text: For a month now, I have been spying on my apartment.

headline: If It’s Icky, She Has the Solution
text: For a generation overwhelmed not just by dust bunnies, but by bong water on the carpet, pee stains on the ceiling and vomit seemingly everywhere, Jolie Kerr, 37, dispenses cleaning advice free of judgment. Writing first on The Hairpin, The Awl’s girlish sister blog, and now on Jezebel and Deadspin, Ms. Kerr gently cautions her readers to beware of their handbags, noting that researchers have found that the stuff banging around inside carries more bacteria than most toilet seats. But microbes are not the worst Coach-invader.

headline: Sales at Company C, Module R and Mondo Collection
text: Discontinued rugs, pillows and bedding are 60 percent off at Company C, while supplies last (the Chevron Julep ColorSpree pillow, usually $65, is $26; a 5-by-8-foot Hyannisport aqua ColorSpree rug, usually $395, is $158; the Gidget multi pillow, usually $125, is $50); 800-818-8288, companyc.com.

headline: Small World, Big Idea
text: OLYMPIA, Wash. — On Christmas Eve, Kevin Johnson received the following gifts: a bed and mattress, a blanket and sheets, a desk and chair, a toilet and sink, towels and washcloths, toothpaste and floss, and a brand-new house.

headline: As Obama Vows to Act on Climate Change, Justices Weigh His Approach
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama in recent days has been announcing muscular executive actions to address climate change, making good on his promise to act on pressing problems “with or without Congress.” On Monday, the Supreme Court will consider the limits of that approach, in a case on greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Strikes and Spare Wood
text: Jim Malone, the owner of CounterEvolution, a Brooklyn company that makes furniture out of wood reclaimed from bowling lanes, discovered the material while sourcing kitchen countertops several years ago and has used it in his tables and slat-back chairs ever since. He began by selling pieces at the Brooklyn Flea and now produces furniture for Shake Shack and Starbucks; recently, the company opened a Manhattan showroom.

text: Molly Wood recommends a few apps that will help you secure your smartphone communications.

Banned in India

headline: Stray Voltage Temporarily Electrifies Block in Chelsea
text: This winter, New Yorkers have been told time and again to look down and watch their step. And they have been told to look up for snow and ice tumbling from towering buildings.

headline: Medical Marijuana
text: To the Editor:

headline: Privacy Please: Tools to Shield Your Smartphone
text: Here’s a thought: Maybe it’s O.K. to care about your privacy even if you have nothing to hide.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Promoting Health With Enticing Photos of Fruits and Vegetables
text: Pity the poor beet.

headline: Disney’s ‘Frozen’ Kingdom
text: Melena Ryzik explores the Disney animation studios and speaks with the creators of the Oscar-nominated film “Frozen.”

headline: Facebook’s Deal for WhatsApp: The Chatter on Twitter
text: Facebook made a huge splash in the tech world on Wednesday with a $16 billion deal to buy WhatsApp, a messaging start-up — the social media giant’s biggest acquisition by far.

headline: Denver Museum Returns Artifacts to Kenyan Government
text: Museums hoping to return stolen cultural items to indigenous tribes that may have lost them generations ago often say they are stymied by the difficulty of identifying a “rightful owner” to take legal custody of the objects. But on Wednesday, one museum, the Denver Museum of Nature and Science, with a large collection of East African spiritual carvings known as vigango, resolved that problem by returning 30 of the artifacts to the Kenyan government.

headline: For Super Bowl, Familiar Ads And Star Endorsements
text: AFTER each Super Bowl, there are lingering questions about the 50 or more commercials that viewers watched during the game on what is typically the biggest day of the year for advertising as well as for football. (This year, it was certainly the biggest day for television with a record average audience of 112.2 million viewers.) What follows are answers to questions about some spots in Super Bowl XLVIII.

headline: Why Actors Act Out
text: THE recent erratic behavior of Shia LaBeouf, the 27-year-old actor best known as the star of the “Transformers” movies, has sent the press into a feeding frenzy. Though the wisdom of some of his actions may seem questionable, as an actor and artist I’m inclined to take an empathetic view of his conduct.

headline: Embracing Sticker Shock
text: Adhesive images covering two neighboring homes in Los Angeles offer privacy, and stop traffic, too.

headline: The Power of Sticker Shock
text: The idea of wrapping a house in giant graphic stickers, like the ones used for ads on city buses, appealed to Eric Chu the moment his architect suggested it.

headline: The Sochi Olympics, Frame by Frame
text: See the Winter Games in a series of composite images.

headline: Edmunds, 15-Year-Old American Figure Skater, Is Still in Sight of Podium Finish
text: SOCHI, Russia — It’s hard enough to be a 15-year-old girl.

headline: Start-Up Site Hires Critic of Wall St.
text: Matt Taibbi, who made a name as a fierce critic of Wall Street at Rolling Stone magazine, has joined First Look Media, the latest big-name journalist to leave an established brand to enter the thriving and well-financed world of news start-ups.

headline: Google Fiber, Ultrahigh-Speed Internet, May Expand to 34 New Cities
text: Google is taking steps to expand Google Fiber, its nascent ultrahigh-speed Internet service, to 34 cities in nine metropolitan areas across the country as it grapples with the challenges of working with local governments.

headline: Russians’ Hockey Elimination Prompts Anger and Dismay
text: SOCHI, Russia — For the home-country fans here celebrating the first Winter Games on Russian soil, there could be no bigger debacle than failing to win a medal in hockey, the nation’s most popular sport.

headline: Global Bond Frenzy Raises Concerns
text: Prospecting for oil in Brazil, manufacturing steel in Russia, erecting skyscrapers in China: Global bond investors have financed some of the grandest investment projects taken on by emerging economies in recent years.

headline: Law and Politics
text: I first read about Robert A. Dahl’s death earlier this month in the Yale Daily News. Why would the editors of a student newspaper publish a Page 1 obituary of a 98-year-old political science professor who had retired from teaching well before any of today’s undergraduates were born?

headline: Year in Prison for Ex-Guard Who Had Child With Inmate
text: Nancy Gonzalez, the former correction officer who was impregnated by an inmate who was twice sentenced to the federal death penalty, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison on Wednesday for her role in the illicit relationship.

headline: Hard Times Leave Some Greek Car Owners With Nothing but Rust
text: ATHENS — No longer able to pay for gas, Giannis Zgourakis parked his prized BMW on the street near his home and turned to a motorcycle. That was more than a year ago. Now, the car sits there a forlorn wreck, its battery dead, its tires ruined.

headline: Bank of America’s Chief Receives $12.5 Million in Stock
text: Brian T. Moynihan, the chief executive of Bank of America, received about $12.5 million in restricted stock grants for 2013, according to a regulatory filing on Wednesday night.

headline: Cheer Everyone? Russian Biathlon Spectators Are Still Learning
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — From their perch in the bleachers high above the shooting range, biathlon fans generally follow two unspoken rules: Stay quiet when a biathlete is shooting at the target, and do not cheer when a competitor from another country misses.

headline: Loss Tapers at Tesla as Its Sales Still Climb
text: Nearly 20 months after delivering the first all-electric Model S sedan to customers, Tesla Motors is narrowing its losses as sales of its cars continue to climb.

headline: The Bias Against Black Bodies
text: The Michael Dunn case has caused us to look once again at the American culture and criminal justice system, and many don’t like what they see.

headline: Disillusionment in Libya Over Vote on Charter Assembly
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — For the second time since the overthrow of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi two and a half years ago, Libyans are being asked to go to the polls to elect lawmakers responsible for preparing a new constitution. On Thursday, increasingly frustrated voters will directly elect a 60-member assembly to draft the charter after Parliament failed to appoint the body as originally planned.

headline: Amid Toxic Waste, a Navajo Village Could Lose Its Land
text: CHURCH ROCK, N.M. — In this dusty corner of the Navajo reservation, where seven generations of families have been raised among the arroyos and mesas, Bertha Nez is facing the prospect of having to leave her land forever.

headline: The Least We Can Do
text: Can we talk about the United Nations? I know, I know. But give me a minute. We don’t do this very often.

headline: Missing Costas? Fleeting Glimpses of a Lasting Presence
text: How much time would you guess Bob Costas spends on the air during one of NBC’s prime-time Olympic shows?

headline: A City Safe for Walking
text: What steps can city officials, pedestrians and drivers take to reduce the number of accidents?

headline: At Lunar New Year, a Big, Red Target for Pickpockets
text: There is no red bunting on the front door of Helen Hsu’s home in Rego Park, Queens, no festive garlands or totems that often bedeck Chinese homes like hers during the monthlong Lunar New Year celebration, which began more than two weeks ago. If she were in her native Taiwan there would be fluttering red paper streamers, glinting mirrors and equine caricatures heralding the Year of the Horse. Here in Queens, though, Ms. Hsu has tacked up only military flags and a crest from her son, a United States Marine.

headline: Gap to Raise Minimum Hourly Pay
text: In a surprising move, Gap Inc. informed its employees on Wednesday that it would set $9 as the minimum hourly rate for its United States work force this year and then establish a minimum of $10 next year.

headline: A Piece of DNA
text: This is the fifth part of an eight-part series.

headline: A Church So Poor It Has to Close Schools, Yet So Rich It Can Build a Palace
text: KEARNY, N.J. — Mater Dei Academy sits shuttered, blue drapes pulled across its windows, atop a hill in this working-class city. From its steps, you can peer across the mist-shrouded expanse of the Meadowlands to the distant spires of Manhattan.

headline: Is That Sausage Worth This?
text: Modern factory farms have so much wrong with them, but a starting point is the practice of turning pigs into cannibals.

headline: Calmer Streets, Safer City
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday released his plan to eliminate traffic deaths in New York City. Every preventable traffic death is unacceptable, he said, and New Yorkers deserve a systematic, citywide campaign for safer streets. He’s right on both counts.

headline: Nationalistic Remarks From Japan Lead to Warnings of Chill With U.S.
text: TOKYO — A series of defiantly nationalistic comments, including remarks critical of the United States, by close political associates of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has led analysts to warn of a growing chill between his right-wing government and the Obama administration, which views Japan as a linchpin of its strategic pivot to Asia.

headline: Brit Awards Red Carpet
text: View looks from Rita Ora, Kylie Minogue, Pharrell Williams, Iggy Azalea and more.

headline: Ukraine’s Deadly Turn
text: Three months of confrontations in Kiev, Ukraine, erupted in sudden and brutal violence on Tuesday and Wednesday, leaving at least 25 dead and the heart of the capital city in flames.

headline: Defendant in Terror Trial Gets Access to Detainee
text: A federal judge in Manhattan on Wednesday cleared the way for a terrorism defendant’s lawyers to question, in writing, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 attacks, to see if his testimony might help their client’s case.

headline: The Clear Benefits of a Higher Wage
text: Republicans sputtered with outrage when the Congressional Budget Office said that immigration reform would lower the deficit, strengthen Social Security and speed up economic growth. They called for the office to be abolished when it dared to point out that tax cuts raise the deficit or when it highlighted the benefits of health care reform. But now that the budget office has predicted (and exaggerated) the possibility that an increase in the minimum wage might result in a loss of jobs, Republicans think it’s gospel.

headline: Violence in Ukraine Creates Deepening Clash Between East and West
text: MOSCOW — The two sides in what is developing into an East-West clash over Ukraine hardened their positions on Wednesday, with Russian officials denouncing what they called a coup by right-wing extremists, even as the United States and Europe threatened to impose sanctions on those responsible for the violence that has erupted in the capital, Kiev, and spread to other cities.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 19, 2014
Figure Skaters Battle for Steady Nerves and Legs
text: SOCHI, Russia — Usually, the legs are the first to go. They get tight. Or turn into jelly. Or in the worst case, they are unable to move at all.

headline: Divorced From My Husband, and My Faith
text: I stood before the panel of rabbis, waiting to have a religious divorce conferred upon me. I was dressed as the Orthodox Jewish woman I was supposed to be, modestly, in a below-the-knee navy skirt and buttoned cardigan. But I felt exposed. What kind of shameful woman, I imagined the rabbis thinking, leaves her marriage; what kind of mother uproots her life?

headline: What to Watch: Thursday, Feb. 20
text: WOMEN’S HOCKEY Canada and the United States traded wins and punches on their way to Sochi, but the Olympics have long been Canada’s turf. The Canadians have won the last three gold medals, and they have not lost a game at the Olympics since 1998. They also beat the Americans, 3-2, in the teams’ first-round meeting here. So the gold is Canada’s to lose. But it can happen. The last team to beat the Canadians at the Olympics? The United States, in the gold medal game in Nagano. NBC, noon

headline: Federal Lawsuit Accuses For-Profit Schools of Fraud
text: LINWOOD, N.J. — It was the electronic monitor around a student’s ankle that first gave Kelli J. Amaya serious doubts about the Harris School of Business.

headline: Getting Stares on the Streets of Cambodia: Buses for the Masses
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — This city of nearly two million people has many of the amenities of a modern metropolis — broadband Internet, automated teller machines and fancy restaurants, to name a few. But until this month, the capital of Cambodia had no public transportation system. To get around, residents had to inure themselves to perilous rides on motorcycle taxis or dust-smothered commutes in open three-wheeled tuk-tuks.

headline: In Mexico Meeting, a Show of Friendship With Few Results on Immigration and Trade
text: TOLUCA, Mexico — They call it the “Three Amigos” summit meeting, and President Obama and his Mexican and Canadian counterparts played their parts on Wednesday. They shared a lunch, joshed about the Olympics, promised enduring cooperation, and took a staged stroll through a botanical garden, complete with requisite smiles for the cameras.

headline: Paul Colby, Whose Club Helped Fuel Greenwich Village’s Rise, Dies at 96
text: Paul Colby, the owner since 1974 of the Bitter End, a celebrated coffeehouse-cum-nightclub that helped make Greenwich Village a legendary place by showcasing young performers like Bob Dylan, Joni Mitchell, Billy Crystal and countless others, died on Feb. 13 at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 96.

headline: University of Maryland Computer Breach Exposes Records of Students and Staff
text: The University of Maryland said on Wednesday that more than 300,000 records for students, faculty and staff were stolen in a sophisticated cyberattack.

headline: 57 Bits of Emotional Knowledge
text: Tell me. I want to know. I need to know. I have to know. Oh, I’m sorry you told me. I wish I didn’t know that.

headline: Millard Fillmore and Company
text: Ulysses. Abraham. Millard. Be it here resolved that the presidents of the United States have had some pretty rad first names. It’s a topic that comes up in this puzzle, coming as it does just on the heels of Presidents Day. You’ll have to flip through your mental Rolodex of commanders-in-chief to come up with the one name that will explain today’s theme.

headline: Phnom Penh’s First Buses
text: A Japanese-sponsored pilot project introduced a bus service to the chaotic streets of the capital of Cambodia.

headline: Mike Stepovich, Who Led Alaska to Statehood, Dies at 94
text: Mike Stepovich, the last presidentially appointed governor of the Territory of Alaska, who helped lobby Congress for statehood, died on Friday in San Diego. He was 94.

headline: 3 Opposed First-Degree Murder Conviction in Florida Trial, Juror Says
text: A juror in the Florida trial of a man who fatally shot a teenager in a dispute over loud music said in an interview broadcast Tuesday that three jurors believed the gunman had acted in self-defense, which negated any chance of a first-degree murder conviction.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 20, 2014
text: “I have lost any desire to stay here any longer. There is no sense to stay. As for me, the Olympic flame can be put down as well.”

headline: Yahoo Introduces Service for Buying Mobile Ads
text: Yahoo introduced a new service for companies to buy different forms of mobile advertising, as it seeks to build its clout in two increasingly important parts of the advertising business.

headline: California Health Insurance Enrollments Rise, but Hispanics Still Lag
text: LOS ANGELES — With six weeks left in the open enrollment period for insurance under President Obama’s health care law, more than 828,000 Californians have signed up for private coverage through the state’s online health care exchange, state officials announced Wednesday.

headline: F.B.I. Papers Yield Clues in Vanishing of Civil Rights Activist
text: Cheryl Robinson says she has waited more than four decades to find out what happened to her husband, an Alabama civil rights activist who disappeared, and now she thinks she has at least the beginning of an answer.

headline: Shumpert Hurts Knee Amid Talk of a Trade
text: NEW ORLEANS — Iman Shumpert had a bad day. It started with seeing his name in trade reports, and about an hour before the Knicks faced the Pelicans on Wednesday night, Shumpert acknowledged what everyone else was thinking: that the game had the potential to be his final one with the Knicks. All he could do, he said, was play.

headline: Labor Leaders See Focus on Wages as Key to Union and Democratic Victories
text: HOUSTON — Gathered for their annual winter meeting, the nation’s labor leaders say that what they see as the best theme for reviving the union movement — American workers need a raise — also would be a winning issue for their Democratic allies in this fall’s elections.

headline: Latest Attacks on Doctors Prompt New Call for Deterrent Measures
text: On Monday, Sun Dongtao, an ear, nose and throat doctor at Qiqihar Beigang Hospital, in the northern province of Heilongjiang, was beaten to death with an iron bar by a patient unhappy with his treatment,  the state news agency Xinhua reported.

headline: Corrections: February 20, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Animal Prints in Living Color
text: For resort, designers offered up a delightfully fresh interpretation of classic animal prints, switching the expected natural colors for a rainbow-hued, yet slightly subdued, palette. A zesty shade of lime adds punch to a sweater from Equipment and bag from Valentino, while cool-toned touches look refreshing on a phone case from Marc Jacobs, a ring from Marc Alary and brogues from Robert Clergerie. Acidic shades of apple liven up a DSquared2 slingback and Eugène Riconneaus skate deck, while Amaya Arzuaga’s draped miniskirt with lemon-speckled spots lets the print whisper and the silhouette roar.

headline: The Art of Texting While Walking
text: This article appeared in the Feb. 23, 2014 issue of The New York Times Magazine

headline: Study Finds Greater Income Inequality in Nation’s Thriving Cities
text: WASHINGTON — If you want to live in a more equal community, it might mean living in a more moribund economy.

headline: Two Steps Forward and One Step Back for the Federal Reserve
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Scrutiny in California for Software in Schools
text: A leading California lawmaker plans to introduce state legislation on Thursday that would shore up privacy and security protections for the personal information of students in elementary through high school, a move that could alter business practices across the nearly $8 billion education technology software industry.

headline: Word of the Day | wan
text: wan •\ˈwän\• adjective

headline: U.N. Security Council Members Propose Resolution on Syrian Aid
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council hurtled toward a showdown over Syria, as members put forth a draft resolution late Wednesday to try to force the warring parties to let in humanitarian aid while Russia, the Syrian government’s principal ally, warned about unduly politicizing aid.

headline: Colorado: New Psychiatric Exam Is Ordered for Theater Gunman
text: A judge on Wednesday ordered a new psychiatric examination for James E. Holmes, who killed 12 people in an Aurora theater in 2012, saying that an earlier evaluation by a state doctor was “incomplete and inadequate.” The ruling, by Judge Carlos A. Samour, orders the state mental hospital to have a new mental-health expert examine Mr. Holmes and offer an opinion on whether he was sane on the night of the shooting. Mr. Holmes’s lawyers have admitted he was the gunman, but argue he is not guilty by reason of insanity. The exam is to be completed by July 11, further delaying the trial.

headline: Nebraska: Judge Blocks Pipeline Route
text: A judge on Wednesday blocked the Keystone XL pipeline’s planned route through the state, a new hurdle for the embattled project. The judge, Stephanie F. Stacy of the Third Judicial District Court, ruled that the law giving Gov. Dave Heineman, a Republican, the authority to approve a crude oil pipeline was unconstitutional. The governor said he would appeal. The proposed pipeline from Canadian oil sands in Alberta to Gulf Coast refineries has become a touchstone fight for environmentalists, and the State Department is considering whether to allow it to cross the border.

headline: Airlines Warned of Possible Shoe Bombs
text: The Department of Homeland Security alerted airlines on Wednesday to a possible new threat from shoe bombs and urged carriers to pay extra attention to flights arriving from overseas. Intelligence officials recently detected what they considered credible warnings of terrorist efforts to strike passenger jets using explosives concealed in shoes. The threat information, first reported by NBC News, was not related to any particular airline, country or date, the officials said.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO James Lipton interviews Matthew McConaughey (above right, with Mr. Lipton) about his first major part, in “Dazed and Confused”; about the film that made him a household name in a single weekend; and about the homework he conducted for his leading role in “Dallas Buyers Club,” for which he is nominated for an Oscar.

headline: Chinese Paper Links Ukraine Strife to Rapid Political Reform
text: The Chinese people should draw an important lesson from the turmoil engulfing Ukraine: Beware of rapid political reform, because it will only end in chaos and bloodshed.

headline: Chinese Censors Have Kept Their Hands Off ‘House of Cards’
text: “Mao is dead. And so is his China.”

headline: Elton John and Kanye West Among Performers Set for Bonnaroo Festival
text: It could be, like the man sang in “Bennie and the Jets,” weird and wonderful, or it could be just plain weird. But either way, Elton John will be one of the headlining performers at this year’s Bonnaroo festival, its organizers said on Wednesday, after several days of rumors that that best-selling pop pianist and showman would make a rare appearance at this annual outdoor music and comedy event in Manchester, Tenn. He’ll have no shortage of competition for most outrageous eyewear at Bonnaroo, which will run from June 12 through June 15, and will also see Kanye West, Jack White, and Lionel Richie atop the bill. Other artists on the lineup, which is expected to include more than 125 bands, are Vampire Weekend, Ms. Lauryn Hill, Skrillex, Damon Albarn, Arctic Monkeys, Frank Ocean, Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds, Ice Cube, Wiz Khalifa and Neutral Milk Hotel. The announced comedians include Taran Killam of “Saturday Night Live” and Hannibal Buress, the standup comic and co-star of “Broad City.” More information can be found at the festival’s official website, bonnaroo.com.

headline: Politics Behind Move to Free Gandhi Assassination Plotters, Analysts Say
text: MUMBAI — The decision by J. Jayalalithaa, the chief minister of Tamil Nadu, to release seven people who plotted the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, the former prime minister, has set up a showdown between the southern state and New Delhi.

headline: Renewed Fighting Shatters Truce in Ukraine
text: A new wave of fighting broke out in Kiev early Thursday, hours after opposition leaders confirmed that a truce had been reached.

headline: Air France-KLM Swings Back to Underlying Profit
text: PARIS — After more than 18 months of painful cost-cutting and staff reductions, Air France-KLM reported its first underlying profit in three years on Thursday, and confirmed that it was making steady progress toward reducing debt even as it steps up investment in premium-class service and new international partnerships.

text: In “Kiev Protesters Set Square Ablaze to Thwart Police” and “Ukraine Puts ‘Extremists’ on Notice After Deadly Clashes,” Andrew Higgins and Andrew E. Kramer write about the latest developments in the conflict in Ukraine.

headline: Sochi Under Siege
text: SOCHI, Russia — ON Feb. 7, the opening day of the Olympics, several people walked out onto Red Square in Moscow. When they attempted to sing the Russian national anthem, all were arrested and taken to the nearest police station. “We were holding small rainbow flags to show support for the L.G.B.T. community,” wrote my protester friend, who found herself taken into custody for the first time in her life.

headline: How Obamacare Could Unlock Job Opportunities
text: During college, Lauren Braun worked at a health clinic in Peru, where she spent an inordinate amount of time tracking down mothers in an effort to get them to bring their children in for vaccinations. The experience was frustrating, but through it Braun came up with a business plan: Make silicone bracelets that function as punch cards, to remind mothers about upcoming appointments. Back in the United States, she consulted with mentors and perfected the idea, but then, she set it aside after graduation, going to work for a large health-insurance company, taking a salary and benefits over the uncertain life of an entrepreneur.

headline: This Ain’t No Disco. It’s a Photograph.
text: A paradox of Studio 54 was that it was both the most exclusive party in town, stopping all but the chosen few at its impenetrable velvet rope, and the most accessible, bombarding the public with images of the glitterati and the high life inside. The club was a fantasy about which it was not necessary to fantasize, since torrents of ink and celebrity photographs did the work for you. If you wanted to know what it was like to rub shoulders (or more) with Halston or Liza or Name-Your-Boldface-Name, you could pick up a magazine that chronicled the rubbing. It was not just a place to see and be seen. In the miasma of sex and fame and money and pleasure that swirled around New York in the late 1970s, it was a place to be photographed, mass-produced and consumed as a shimmering commodity.

headline: Deal Reached to Resume Expansion of Panama Canal
text: Work on the planned expansion of the Panama Canal was set to resume on Thursday after the construction consortium and the canal authorities reached a preliminary accord to pay suppliers and put an end to their dispute over $1.6 billion of cost overruns.

headline: Should Terminally Ill Patients Be Allowed to Die on Their Own Terms?
text: When the term “assisted suicide” is used, many people think it should be illegal. But when “aid in dying” and “death with dignity” are used instead, support increases dramatically. But no matter what we call the practice, the idea is still the same. A small group of people face an outlook of imminent suffering and death. Should they have the option to end their life on their own terms?

headline: Amid Hugs and Tears, Korean Families Divided by War Reunite
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Lee Beom-ju, 86, had little to say at first.

headline: Pakistani Airstrikes Target Militants in Tribal Areas
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Fighter jets and helicopter gunships pounded areas believed to be Taliban hide-outs in the tribal regions of northwestern Pakistan late Wednesday and early Thursday, as the prospects for a peace initiative appeared to evaporate.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook to Pay $16 Billion in Deal for Popular Texting App
text: The frenzy to acquire fast-growing technology start-ups reached new heights on Wednesday as Facebook announced its largest acquisition ever, saying it would pay at least $16 billion for WhatsApp, a text messaging application with 450 million users around the world who pay little or no money for it, David Gelles and Vindu Goel report.

headline: Every Business Has a Special Number, or Metric. Do You Know Yours?
text: Dane Atkinson used to own a bar. Like many bar owners, he occasionally had problems with “shrinkage.” When this happens, some bar owners measure liquor bottles and some employ fancy point of sale systems. Mr. Atkinson learned to track limes.

headline: Peltz Renews Call for a PepsiCo Split
text: The activist investor Nelson Peltz is again pushing for PepsiCo to spin off its North American beverage business after the company announced that it had decided against such a split.

headline: Advocate for Uighurs Seems to Have Foretold Detention
text: Ilham Tohti, the Uighur intellectual who disappeared into the black hole of China’s security apparatus more than a month ago, appears to have prophesied his detention and what are expected to be charges of inciting ethnic separatism in the far western region of Xinjiang.

headline: Facebook’s $16 Billion Deal for WhatsApp
text: BIG DEAL: FACEBOOK BUYS WHATSAPP FOR $16 BILLION  |  When Facebook offered to buy Snapchat last year for $3 billion, the messaging app turned Facebook down. So this time, Facebook made it harder for its target to say no. On Wednesday, Facebook announced it would acquire WhatsApp, a text messaging application with 450 million users, for at least $16 billion in cash and stock, its largest acquisition by far and one that represents a new height in the frenzy to acquire popular technology start-ups, David Gelles and Vindu Goel write in DealBook.

headline: Iran and 6 Powers Agree on Terms for Nuclear Talks
text: VIENNA — In what officials described as a serious, workmanlike and conversational atmosphere, Iran and six world powers have agreed on a timetable and framework for negotiating a comprehensive agreement to end the confrontation over Iran’s nuclear program, the European Union’s foreign policy chief and Iran’s foreign minister said Thursday.

headline: Women’s Figure Skating Live Updates
text: Times reporters offer updates, analysis and observations during the long program of the women’s figure skating competition as Kim Yu-Na of South Korea tries to win her second consecutive gold medal.

headline: Seeking a Break in a 252 Million-Year-Old Mass Killing
text: Sam Bowring is officially a geologist at M.I.T. Unofficially, he’s a homicide detective trying to solve the ultimate cold case. Dr. Bowring wants to understand how an estimated 96 percent of all species on Earth became extinct at the end of the Permian Period 252 million years ago. It was the biggest of the five mass extinctions recorded in the fossil record. But because this killing happened so long ago, the culprit has evaded discovery for decades.

headline: How a Family Spread Its Gospel
text: In the 1960s and ’70s, black entertainers, politicians and sports stars visiting Chicago knew where to go for comfort food and warm conversation: to the home of the Staples family.

headline: A Woman at a Crossroads
text: When Idina Menzel accepted the lead role in “If/Then,” a new musical that follows two divergent paths in one woman’s life, she thought she was getting that rarest of theatrical opportunities: a rich part in an original and emotionally complex show.

text: BANGALORE — The man who once declared “the world is flat” is now readying himself for an uneven, uphill battle.

headline: Video: ‘Frozen’s’ Secret Rink
text: “How does snow think?” That was the question one of the story editors asked as the team behind “Frozen” struggled over years to shape the film into a relatable tale. In this video, the Carpetbagger goes behind the scenes at Disney’s Burbank, Calif., headquarters to learn more about the inspirations — like Grumpy Cat and a hidden roller rink — behind the film and especially the hit soundtrack.

headline: Back to the Future on Tech M.&.A.
text: With Facebook‘s deal for WhatsApp, the volume of technology mergers and acquisitions in the United States has risen to its highest level since the dot-com boom, Thomson Reuters data shows.

headline: Credit Issuers Making It Easier to Know Your Score
text: It is fairly simple to get a free copy of your annual credit report. But you usually must pay to see your credit score — the three-digit number that summarizes your credit report for lenders, to help them decide if you’re likely to repay a loan.

headline: The Lies That Doctors and Patients Tell
text: The doctor-patient relationship is ideally an intimate partnership where information is exchanged openly and honestly. That is seldom the reality, however. Deception in the doctor-patient relationship is more common than we’d like to believe.

headline: Confusion and Courage at Olustee
text: “We [are] off on another tramp,” Cpl. James Henry Gooding reported to the readers of his hometown newspaper on Feb. 8, 1864, “but with no knowledge of our destination.” His regiment, the 54th Massachusetts, the first regiment of African-American troops recruited from the Northern states, had won fame six months earlier when they attacked Fort Wagner on the South Carolina coast. Since then, they had been involved in mundane siege operations around Charleston, and morale was sinking. However, now that they were aboard steamers heading south, Gooding noted, “the excitement on board” was “intense.”

headline: Learning to Deal With Billboards
text: “It’s really fast,” Matthew Hemerlein, an electronic pop musician who records under the name Lo-Fang, said of his recent career trajectory. In the next month, he’ll release his debut album, “Blue Film”; appear on the ABC drama “Revenge”; perform on the “Late Show With David Letterman”— oh, and he’ll be opening for Lorde, the 17-year old Grammy winner, who handpicked him for a tour that kicks off on March 3. (They’ll be at the Roseland Ballroom in New York on March 10, 11 and 12.)

headline: Darkness Arrives Onstage
text: Few operas are as challenging, or as cathartic, as Berg’s “Wozzeck,” the 1925 setting of Georg Büchner’s play about an army private driven by poverty, illness and countless acts of humiliation, to murder Marie, his common-law wife. With its atonal score, poured into traditional forms that are as concise as they are eloquent, and passages of speechlike singing, it’s the early masterwork that defined and in many ways dominated 20th-century opera.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee Pleads Guilty in 2002 Attack on Tanker Off Yemen
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — A Saudi detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, pleaded guilty on Thursday before a military commission to terrorism-related offenses involving a 2002 attack by Al Qaeda on a French-flagged oil tanker off the coast of Yemen. The plea deal will give him a specific sentence and a prospect of leaving the American military prison, where he has been held in indefinite detention.

headline: Graham Center Gets $1 Million for Dance Archive
text: One of the biggest revolutions in the dance world over the past century has been the use of technology to help preserve choreography and pass it on from one generation to the next. The Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance announced Thursday that its efforts in that direction had received a major boost: a $1 million grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation that will allow it to build on, digitize and organize its archive of materials on Graham dances.

headline: India’s Upper House Approves Creation of New State
text: NEW DELHI — After hours of shouting, paper-shredding and chanting in India’s upper house of Parliament, lawmakers on Thursday passed a bill creating a 29th state by dividing Andhra Pradesh, a large southern state, in two.

headline: Hey, You Guys, Come and See This!
text: Roughly two-thirds of the theatergoers at Broadway shows are female, a disparity that many producers have tried to address. With its mullets and strip clubs, the hair-metal jukebox musical “Rock of Ages” made some progress in attracting men in 2009, and shows like “The Book of Mormon” and “That Championship Season” have aggressively courted them since. Several contenders on and Off Broadway are vying for the male demographic this season, flinging enough testosterone to make that Super Bowl takeover of Times Square look like a pillow fight. Still, by the final round (hint), the title belt (hint hint) for Ultimate Guy Show can go to just one contender, shadowboxing alone at the top of the TKTS steps (hint).

text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Early Shot at Redemption for U.S. Hockey Team
text: SOCHI, Russia — The groom has fled the altar, leaving a jilted Russia, which paid $51 billion for the once-in-a-lifetime ceremony, only to watch one of the four groomsmen, none with blood ties, commandeer the celebration.

headline: Parting Glance: Frank Espada
text: I went to El Barrio this week thinking of Frank Espada. On blocks where renovated tenements stood alongside luxury high-rises, I strained to imagine what he had witnessed more than a half-century earlier, before anyone thought this stretch of Manhattan would sit in the cross hairs of gentrification. When it was home to people like him, who came to this frozen city, exiled from the verdant hills of Puerto Rico. When it was among the few havens for the dispossessed.

headline: An Open Letter on Homosexuality to My Fellow Scientists in Uganda
text: President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda is about to sign into law a vehement anti-gay law after “medical experts presented a report that homosexuality is not genetic but a social behaviour,” according to a tweet from Ofwono Opondo, a Ugandan government spokesman. It is sad and ironic that Mr. Museveni will do so just as scientists at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science report that they have robustly confirmed my original finding of molecular linkage between male sexual orientation and a specific genetic region, Xq28.

headline: In Store | Prada’s Harlem Renaissance Homage
text: With its ongoing Iconoclasts project, Prada has commissioned some of the world’s top fashion stylists to reinvent its flagship stores with immersive themed installations. Tonight, as part of Milan Fashion Week, the brand’s boutique there reopens with a Harlem Renaissance-inspired design — complete with Art Deco bar and handpainted flapper mannequins — by the creative director Edward Enninful. Here, a video documents the process of transforming the space from minimalist gallery to lavish speakeasy — and provides an up-close look at the rich textures and details of Prada’s just-arrived spring collection.

headline: ‘Buyer & Cellar’ Gets a New Star
text: The Off Broadway understudy Clancy O’Connor drew attention and full audiences last month when he went on for Michael Urie in the hit play “Buyer & Cellar,” but he didn’t end up with the permanent gig when the time came to recast the one-man show. The producers announced on Thursday that Christopher J. Hanke, who played Bud Frump in the 2011 Broadway revival of “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,” will begin performances on March 18 as Alex More, a struggling actor who takes an unusual job working for Barbra Streisand.

headline: Parallels Seen in Two Jet Crashes in 2013
text: WASHINGTON — The crew of a U.P.S. cargo jet that crashed on approach to Birmingham, Ala., last August had planned to land by using a method that was rare for them, following a computer-generated path to give vertical guidance, according to testimony given Thursday at a National Transportation Safety Board hearing. But the crew changed its strategy in the last minutes because the onboard computer did not perform as they had planned, investigators said.

headline: Art Auctions Without the Attitude
text: EILEEN OGLE of Brooklyn comes so often to shop at Hutter Auction Galleries on West 55th Street in Manhattan that she admits she may have a bit of “collectivitis.”

headline: Street Style in Shoreditch, London
text: The Broadway Market and Columbia Flower Market in East London are vibrant weekend shopping hubs, where you can find anything from Cornish pasties to vintage clothing. The cobblestone streets are packed with merchants and shoppers until sunset, when the action moves to the pubs.

headline: Wall Street: Working for the Weekend or Through It?
text: Last month, Bank of America Merrill Lynch told its junior bankers to take four days off a month, on the weekends. Credit Suisse discouraged its analysts and associates from working on Saturdays. Last year, Goldman Sachs recommended that its analysts take weekends off whenever possible.

headline: A Homey Addition to a Dallas Hotel
text: Hotel ZaZa, the more-than-decade-old 165-room luxury hotel in the Arts District of Dallas, recently expanded with the Bungalows, a collection of 12 suites on a separate residential leafy street near the main property.

headline: Worst Spill in 6 Months Is Reported at Fukushima
text: TOKYO — About 100 tons of highly radioactive water leaked from one of the hundreds of storage tanks at the devastated Fukushima nuclear plant, its operator said Thursday, calling the leak the worst spill at the plant in six months.

text: More than 30 years since its premiere, Athol Fugard’s “ ‘Master Harold’ ... and the Boys” endures as an understated yet meaningful study in racism.

text: CBS rewarded its long-time programming president, Nina Tassler, with a new contract and a new title Thursday, elevating her to chairwoman of CBS Entertainment.

headline: The Other Big Winner in the WhatsApp Deal: Your Wallet
text: Facebook’s acquisition of WhatsApp for at least $16 billion has minted dozens of new millionaires and billionaires this week, but there was another big winner in the deal: Parents and their teenage children, who have most likely saved hundreds or even thousands of dollars in texting fees thanks to the hugely popular messaging app, and will continue to do so after the deal.

headline: No, Employment Protections Aren’t Like Segregation
text: Since the 1960s federal law has recognized various protected classes. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 made it illegal to discriminate on the basis of race, color or religion; the 1990 Disabilities Act on the basis of disability. It should be screamingly obvious that a “protected” class isn’t a “privileged” class — but apparently it isn’t.

headline: A Digitally Printed, Star Studded, Cashmere Scarf
text: The heritage brand Asprey has been around since 1781 and is best known for its mega-watt jewelry. But in recent years, the company has recruited a slew of fresh design talent to reinvigorate the brand, a roster that includes Shaun Leane, Katie Hillier and, most recently, Asprey’s newest contributing designer Benjamin Seidler.

headline: Vampires and Aging Rockers Make the Cut for New Directors/New Films
text: Updated, 3:20 p.m. | It’s a moody forecast for this year’s New Directors/New Films series. The complete lineup, announced Wednesday by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, includes an eclectic mix of 40 features and shorts ranging from the tale of a bloodthirsty teenager to a documentary about modern colonialism in war-torn Sudan and a semi-factual look into the life of an aging rocker.

headline: Jonathan Martin and the Soft, White, Private School Question

headline: Miuccia Prada’s Powerhouse

They were treated to the designer wiggling the crystal fringes on her Miu Miu skirt.

headline: Letter From Hackley to Alumni
text: Read the letter sent from Hackley to alumni regarding allegations of sexual abuse in the 1960s.

headline: 36 Hours in Upper Manhattan
text: In the 18th century, the northern half of Manhattan Island served as a bucolic escape for New Yorkers with the cash to afford it and the horse and carriage to get them there. It’s easier to visit these days (the A train to Harlem being the most famous of many routes) and easier to get around, with the city’s newfangled green cabs in abundance in neighborhoods where yellow cabs have always been scarce. There’s also a whole lot more to do these days. Harlem, the Dutch settlement that became the black capital of America, is in the throes of gentrification: a mix of old and new, from gospel-filled black church services to fine cocktail bars abuzz with young professionals of all races. Meanwhile, farther north, between the island’s oldest surviving house and its largest swath of never developed land, is a Latino neighborhood the likes of which you can no longer find south of Central Park.

headline: Escaping to the Cloisters
text: A visit to this branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art could make you forget you’re in Manhattan.

headline: The Gun Report: February 20, 2014
text: • Trustees at Occidental College in Los Angeles are pledging to stay away from any investments in companies that manufacture military-style assault weapons and high-capacity ammunition magazines for public sale. The recent move came at the urging of faculty members, who were horrified by the Newtown massacre. The college, President Obama’s alma mater, found that its endowment does not have investments in companies that manufacture such weapons for public sale, and its board of trustees voted to ensure it stays that way. “It’s a statement of principle about the mission of higher education to be a voice of reason in a world of a lot of violence,” said Occidental politics professor Peter Dreier, who was a prime mover on the issue.

headline: ‘Frozen’ and the Art of Breathing in Animation
text: Animating snow is no easy feat, as the creators of Disney’s “Frozen” discovered sort of late in the process: do it wrong and it winds up looking like “Styrofoam packing peanuts,” as Chris Buck, a director of the movie, put it.
