headline: Russian Is Surprise Winner in Women’s Figure Skating
text: SOCHI, Russia — Many expected a Russian to win a gold medal in women’s figure skating at the Sochi Games, but hardly anyone expected that it would be Adelina Sotnikova.

headline: Romantic Fendi
text: MILAN — A furry monster dangled from the model’s hand at the start of Fendi’s show in Milan on Thursday. It had white hair with a punk Mohawk tip in pink, a stiff white high collar and a black necktie above a gray fur jacket.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: dogs, cats and adrenaline junkies. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: BBVA Buys Banking Start-Up Simple for $117 Million
text: The online banking start-up Simple, which seeks to distinguish itself from traditional banks by eschewing fees and offering its customers data-rich analysis of their transactions, is selling itself to a giant of European finance.

headline: Masterpieces in Miniature
text: Black-and-white floor tiles at his feet, brass chandelier overhead, work table at his left, an artist in 17th-century pantaloons sits at his easel with his back to us, a beret cocked smartly on his head, a brush lightly grasped in his right hand. His model, her satiny blue robe aglow in the angled light, stands in front of the large creased map hanging on the wall.

headline: Where It’s All Served Sotto Voce
text: Wallflower lies in the shadows just off Greenwich Avenue, without a sign, barely exhaling light. Inside, the space is tight in that way called bijou, two brief rooms under a tin ceiling painted gold, requiring you to lean close to your companions and reminding you that New York really does live up to its myth, as a city of half-secret places like this one.

headline: Prada: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: Liverpool and Manchester City Will Play at Yankee Stadium
text: Liverpool and Manchester City will play at Yankee Stadium on July 30 as part of a multicity preseason tournament featuring some of Europe’s top soccer clubs.

headline: Fei Fei Sun Transforms Backstage at Max Mara
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Fei Fei Sun (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Luigi Murenu.

headline: Herbalife to Make Presentation to Lawmakers
text: Updated, 3:37 p.m. | Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company, will conduct a briefing on Friday to educate congressional staff members about its business in what appears to be an effort to ramp up its lobbying efforts in Washington.

headline: Quinoa Spaghetti With Cauliflower, Almonds, Tomatoes and Chickpeas
text: Pasta with cauliflower comes in many variations throughout Italy. This one is all about texture — crunchy almonds, tender (but not mushy) cauliflower and plush chickpeas.

headline: Living With Cancer: Wigged Out
text: The targeted cancer drug extending my life is killing my hair. Especially at the top of my head, a beige scalp gleams through sparse black and white wires. For obvious reasons, I’m not complaining.

headline: Public Sector Cuts Part-Time Shifts to Bypass Insurance Law
text: WASHINGTON — Cities, counties, public schools and community colleges around the country have limited or reduced the work hours of part-time employees to avoid having to provide them with health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, state and local officials say.

headline: An Exhibition With a Sweet Spot for Sound
text: Talk to David Jacobs about his sound sculptures — tall, columnar forms that make up about half the exhibition of his work now at Hofstra University’s Emily Lowe Gallery — and you might also find yourself discussing vacuum cleaners, in his life and his art.

headline: WhatsApp and the Rage for Eyeballs
text: As I read about Facebook’s acquisition of the messaging service WhatsApp, one word kept coming to mind: eyeballs.

headline: Letters: ‘Inside a Pearl,’ and More
text: His Majesty

headline: Canadian Women Rally to Beat U.S. in Overtime for Hockey Gold
text: SOCHI, Russia — The decisive goal in Canada’s 3-2 overtime victory against the United States in the Olympic women’s hockey final Thursday night could not have been diagramed on a whiteboard any better. Never mind that it was not the play Canada’s coach, Kevin Dineen, had drawn up. Who was he to complain?

headline: Restaurant Review: Bones in Paris
text: In the last few years, Paris, particularly in the eastern arrondissements, has had a miniboom of laid-back, tiny, Brooklyn-meets-bistronomique restaurants. Not surprisingly, the chef is often not native to France. Although many local food lovers are already bemoaning the trend, these kitchens are still going strong. One of the most lively of the bunch is Bones, which opened in January 2013, a small dining room on two levels, overseen by James Henry, a 32-year-old Australian chef.

headline: For Christie, Awkward Return to a Setting He Once Ruled
text: PORT MONMOUTH, N.J. — When Chris Christie started to talk over a complaining questioner, a signature tactic of the bellicose, pre-scandal governor, the audience here briefly turned on him.

headline: Life Unleashed
text: “Bark” is the first collection of stories in 16 years by Lorrie Moore, and I’ll admit that when I first saw its modest size and table of contents — eight stories? one every two years? — I felt let down. I would have traded her moving but relatively conventional 2009 novel, “A Gate at the Stairs,” for a horse-choking stack of 15 long, dense stories, each with the specific gravity (and the desperate levity) of “People Like That Are the Only People Here,” the astonishing centerpiece of her previous collection, “Birds of America.” But I was wrong! (Moore is one of the all-time great deployers of the exclamation point, that cheap and skinny punctuational powerhouse — she’s also a great deployer of the epithet — so I thought I’d try one and see how it felt. Felt transgressive!)

headline: Madame Secretary
text: On the day Hillary Clinton returned to Capitol Hill after losing the 2008 Democratic nomination for president, her staff donned sweatbands and gym shorts and staged a Ping-Pong tournament in her office to cheer her up. Frustrated at the way Barack Obama had left her in the technological dust, she turned herself into a digitally charged secretary of state, champ­ioning the use of Twitter for diplomacy and once telling a group of technology executives, “Use me like an app.”

headline: Turkish Beyond the Facade
text: Ephesus, a modest storefront a stone’s throw from the Massapequa Park railroad station, has the best Turkish food I’ve had outside Turkey. It beats out all the well-regarded Turkish restaurants I’ve been to in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

headline: Buoyed by Olympics, Fallon’s Ratings Stay Strong
text: NBC’s strategy of starting Jimmy Fallon’s “Tonight” show following its Olympics coverage appears to be working, as the third night of the new version of the show improved modestly over its second night, defying the usual pattern of a steady falloff in ratings after a premiere.

headline: Tragedy and Farce
text: Gregory Feifer’s “Russians: The People Behind the Power” joins a list of classic books by Western correspondents who have covered the politics and culture of what was once the Soviet Union. ­Hedrick Smith, Robert G. Kaiser, David K. Shipler and David Remnick, among others, wrote acclaimed accounts of what they witnessed as the Soviet Union first challenged the West and then gradually collapsed under the weight of a sclerotic regime. In August 1991, Feifer was an undergraduate spending a summer in Moscow when a group of hard-line Communist officials tried to carry out a coup in a last-ditch effort to prolong Soviet rule. Their failure only sped up the process of dissolution and led to an initial period of such euphoria that many people inside and outside the country believed — as did Feifer himself — that “the U.S.S.R. would be a part of the international community, enjoying the West’s previously unimaginable freedom and prosperity.”

headline: Freezing January for Easterners Was Not Felt Round the World
text: For people throughout the Eastern United States who spent January slipping, sliding and shivering, here is a counterintuitive fact: For the earth as a whole, it was the fourth-warmest January on record.

headline: Facebook Looks to Become Big Fish in Another Big Pond
text: LONDON — Facebook is already the world’s biggest social network. Now it wants to be the biggest player in a new global field by buying WhatsApp, the global leader in mobile messaging.

headline: Lessons in Street Art
text: Like a lot of precocious adolescents animated by the spirit of punk, the Miser and his cronies put in more than a few hours down at the local Kinkos, with scissors, Sharpies and glue sticks at the ready. We were building a body of agitprop works to promote the causes and bands du jour across a forest of posters, fliers, pamphlets, skateboard decks and, inevitably, to our parents’ chagrin, our T-shirts, jeans and leather or denim jackets.

headline: Modeling the Financial Logic for Facebook’s Huge Deal
text: For mere mortals who haven’t partaken in whatever Kool-Aid Mark Zuckerberg is serving at Facebook’s Hacker Way headquarters, is there any way to justify the $19 billion ($16 billion, plus $3 billion in restricted stock units that vest in four years) it is paying for WhatsApp?

headline: When a Wig Parts Ways With Its Scalp
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Rinspeed’s XchangE: From Tesla Model S to Living Room on Wheels
text: Whatever your opinion of the Tesla Model S, it stands as an impressive technological achievement. Rinspeed, the Swiss customizer, decided to take things a few steps further and turned one into a study in autonomous driving interior space and leisure time.

headline: An Aggressive Fed Faces Criticism on Wall Street
text: Updated, 8:41 p.m. | Every time Janet L. Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, testifies in Congress, she can expect some senators to scoff and representatives to question.

headline: Massachusetts Regulators Approve a Gas-Fired Power Plant With an Expiration Date
text: For years, proponents of natural gas, including President Obama, have promoted it as a “bridge fuel,” cleaner than coal but not clean enough to solve the climate problem. On Thursday, regulators in Massachusetts, in an unusual vote, put that theory into practice when it approved a new gas-fired power plant with only a limited life span.

headline: A Chinese Spy Novelist’s World of Dark Secrets
text: Mai Jia, a top-selling Chinese espionage novelist and former soldier, has been writing about secrets for years.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Prada Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Child Astronauts and Other Would-Be Oscar Moments
text: Ask yourself: have you ever wanted to see children in bad wigs spouting very adult dialogue, pretending to drive minivans or scamming drugs while dressed as priests? As usual, the Internet has provided a solution, in the form of kids re-enacting Oscar-nominated movies. Check out the montage above with nuggets of kid wisdom (like this scene from kid-“Gravity”: “You have to let go.” “Why?” “It’s the theme of the movie!”). And don’t worry, they went tasteful for “12 Years a Slave.”

headline: Obama’s Budget Omits Trims to Social Security
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s forthcoming budget plan will not include a proposal to trim cost-of-living increases in Social Security checks, the gesture of bipartisanship he made to Republicans last year in a failed strategy to reach a “grand compromise” on reducing projected federal debt.

headline: A Strange, Familiar Place in ‘Planetary Omnibus’
text: “The Planetary Omnibus” is a junkyard wonderland that revels in the cultural detritus of a certain kind of childhood — one in which plastic Aurora models of classic monsters stalked the dresser, Marvel and DC comics tumbled from the closet and “The Outer Limits” and the local “creature feature” were must-see TV.

headline: Kurdish Travels With the Tramp
text: A charmingly shaggy road trip with clear political undertones, “Chaplin of the Mountains” winds its way across the Iraqi Kurdistan region, using silent movies to give voice to the troubles of a war-battered people.

headline: Questions Raised About AT&T’s Transparency Report
text: Updated with additional comment from AT&T

headline: Artistic Forecasts, From Sun to Snow
text: New art books display Gerhard Richter’s abstracts, Leonora Carrington’s Surrealism and William Christenberry’s look at the American South.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 20
text: A 17-year-old Russian took figure skating gold and France swept the men’s ski cross on Day 15 of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Man Framed by Detective Will Get $6.4 Million From New York City After Serving 23 Years for Murder
text: A man who was framed by a rogue detective and served 23 years in prison for a murder he did not commit will receive $6.4 million from the City of New York in a settlement that came before a civil rights lawsuit was even filed, lawyers involved in the case said on Thursday.

headline: Moschino: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: An Elegant Space for Creative Sushi
text: As sushi bars go, Wafu Asian Bistro in Southport is as fancy as they get, at least in Connecticut. Wafu’s main dining room has double-glass walls with shimmering, curtainlike strands pressed between the panes of glass, and its ceiling dazzles with rows and rows of round mirrors.

headline: The Stresses of a Tough Winter
text: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Clinging to Each Other, We Survived the Storm
text: Every couple has a story, and this was ours. We were prepared to weather storms. For our wedding, we skipped the tissue paper and cream-colored card stock of standard invitations. Instead, we glued a photograph of ourselves swing-dancing onto a black-and-white picture of stormy ocean waves.

headline: F.C.C. Wants Better 911 Location Tracking for Cellphones
text: Want to dial 911 from a mobile phone? Better go outside. Chances are an operator cannot automatically find the location of an emergency call made indoors.

headline: Sports Bar Chain Agrees to Pay $6.8 Million for Violating Wage Laws
text: A popular chain of sports bars based in Philadelphia has agreed to pay $6.8 million in back wages and damages for improperly taking tips from waiters and bartenders and for violating minimum wage and overtime laws, the Labor Department announced Thursday.

headline: Gracie Gold Places Fourth and Finds She’s in Good Company
text: SOCHI, Russia — Gracie Gold, an 18-year-old American who placed fourth in women’s figure skating Thursday, said she knew the competition would be fierce. Based on international rankings, she was not necessarily a medal favorite going in. But with the surprising tumbles of Yulia Lipnitskaya of Russia and Mao Asada of Japan in the short program, Gold had to feel as if she could make the podium.

headline: The Hefty Yoke of Student Loan Debt
text: More than five years after the binge of irresponsible lending led to the credit crisis and Great Recession, the amount of consumer debt in the United States has begun to rise again, but with an important difference. This time the credit standards appear far tougher. Those who should not borrow generally do not.

headline: A Drive-In Flickers to Life for a Teenager
text: “Angels in Stardust” ends up being too tidy to be a great coming-of-age movie, but it’s a decent one, with nice work by Alicia Silverstone as an indifferent mother and A J Michalka as her daydreaming teenage daughter, Vallie Sue.

headline: Variations on Doughnuts
text: When Vincent DePaola and Nick Giannakopoulos opened DoCo, the Donut and Coffee Company in Farmingdale in July, they knew they were steering their career paths in an improbable direction.

headline: Who Were the Figure Skating Judges?
text: SOCHI, Russia — Rarely does a Winter Olympics pass without something happening that invites intense scrutiny of the figure skating judges. On Thursday night, the latest issue emerged — this time at the most high-profile moment, after the reigning gold medalist, Kim Yu-na of South Korea, performed the final free skate of the competition.

headline: The Change That Just Might Come
text: No one spring is quite like another. Buds, blooms, and leaves arrive in different conjunctions every time. The annual season by the Paul Taylor Dance Company is always a highlight of the New York dance calendar; the openness and energy of the Taylor troupe leave a beloved, truly springlike impression in the mind. Its nature changes subtly each year.

headline: Varied Pitches to Fill Empty Spaces
text: “Is the idea that this is the right world, and this is the destroyed world?” the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas asked recently, after playing and comparing the same chord on the three upright Yamaha pianos — each tuned differently — that form a triangle in his small studio at Columbia University.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Central African Republic, Afghanistan and Italy.

headline: Big Dreams, Then Rude Awakening
text: It is with gratitude and sadness that I am looking forward to the fourth annual Spring for Music festival. Gratitude because each year this weeklong series of orchestra concerts at Carnegie Hall has been so exciting. Sadness because this spring’s festival (running from May 5 to 10) will be its last.

headline: A Dane Is Getting His Due
text: Alan Gilbert’s most important efforts as music director of the New York Philharmonic have been in the realm of new music, hoisting the orchestra into the 21st century with initiatives like the Contact! series and the forthcoming NY Phil Biennial. But some of his biggest successes have been with a composer who died in 1931, the Danish symphonic master Carl Nielsen.

headline: Conjuring Thrills From the Living and the Dead
text: Reviewing a concert featuring the “Infernal Dance” of Stravinsky’s “Firebird” that Gustavo Dudamel led with the Los Angeles Philharmonic last March at Avery Fisher Hall, Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times that Mr. Dudamel “drew such blazing colors, slashing attacks and sheer terror from the orchestra that at the climax of the dance, some people in the hall broke into applause and shouted ‘Bravo.’ ”

headline: Open Restaurant. Pack With Patrons. Repeat.
text: Having enjoyed a nice run with Polpettina, their close-quartered pizza kitchen in Eastchester, Michael Abruzese and Kyle Inserra must have gotten to wondering: With ardent fans and not enough space to satisfy demand, why not open a second place nearby, with the same name and the same wholesome, high-spirited menu?

headline: No, Not So Smart
text: I went to a screening of several Academy Award-nominated short films, each ranging from 4 to 15 minutes. Between shorts, I took notes on my cellphone. I didn’t have a pen and paper, and wouldn’t have been able to see them in the dark if I had. The woman beside me asked me sternly to take my phone out of the theater because it was bothering her. I did. But at the end of each short, I had to walk in front of an entire row of people, causing more disruption than if I had simply typed a few notes on my dimly lit phone. Should I have asked the woman to reconsider?

headline: ‘Bronx Bombers’ to Close on Broadway
text: First A-Rod. Then Jeter. Now Yogi, too? “Bronx Bombers,” an homage to the New York Yankees, will end its run at Circle in the Square Theater on March 2, less than a month after its official Broadway opening, its producers announced Thursday.

headline: Outkast Reunion, Rain or Shine
text: The downpour at last year’s Governors Ball music festival, which turned the open fields of Randalls Island into shoe-sucking mud pits, hasn’t daunted its ever more ambitious promoters. In June, Governors Ball will bring to New York the top booking of this year’s festival season: the reunion of the hip-hop band Outkast. That reunion was first announced by the Coachella festival, held in the California desert, which — with its advantage of climate — opens the major festival circuit in the United States, on the weekends of April 11 and 18.

headline: So Far, a Chanteuse Mainly for the Camera
text: FKA Twigs is a mixed-race, tawny-skinned 26-year-old singer and dancer from rural Gloucestershire, England; her real name is Tahlia Barnett, and her old nickname was Twigs, hence “Formerly Known as Twigs.” Her music, on two EPs released in the space of a little more than a year, is tremulous and slow and commanding, with eerie barren stretches. (The second EP was produced by Arca, who worked on Kanye West’s “Yeezus.”) The methodical, strangely placed stresses of the beats signify a lot: isolation, displacement, missed connections. Something of interest — a little burst of rhythm or a bending, decaying electronic tone — occurs in nearly every bar. There’s some deconstructed, first-generation drum-and-bass in there, and Portishead and mid-period Madonna, too; she seizes on and transforms some drowsy energies in early-’90s pop.

headline: Go on, Rant and Rave: It Shows You’re Real
text: Last October, Donald Glover had a modern meltdown, or something like it. On his Instagram account, he posted a series of notes handwritten on a hotel pad: “I feel like I’m letting everyone down. I’m afraid people hate who I really am. I’m afraid I hate who I really am.” And so on.

headline: Investments in Brazil Rose Last Year, Study Says
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Despite its economic woes, Brazil experienced an increase in private equity and venture capital investments in 2013 over the year before, the Latin American Private Equity and Venture Capital Association said on Thursday, in presenting its annual survey.

headline: A Trail of Tears and Corpses
text: Taking a credibility-straining premise and running with it, the Dutch director Arne Toonen gives “Black Out” way more energy than sense. Luckily, his antihero, Jos (Raymond Thiry), lacks neither: A retired gangster whose weary face belies a still-up-for-it body, Jos is less dismayed than most when he wakes up the day before his wedding to find a bloody body sharing his bed.

headline: Rates Rising for Modified Loans
text: The federal government’s Home Affordable Modification Program, known as HAMP, was designed to keep borrowers from losing their homes to foreclosure. It has resulted in lower monthly mortgage payments for more than a million homeowners.

headline: Katherine Bernhardt: ‘Stupid, Crazy, Ridiculous, Funny Patterns’
text: Canada

headline: ‘Queer Threads: Crafting Identity and Community’
text: Leslie Lohman Museum of Gay and Lesbian Art

headline: Alex Prager: ‘Face in the Crowd’
text: Lehmann Maupin

headline: David Altmejd: ‘Juices’
text: Andrea Rosen Gallery

headline: Wheelies: The Aluminum Bandwagon Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Sardinian Food and History, Via Bike
text: Ciclismo Classico has enlisted the skills of a James Beard Award-winning chef (and former competitor on Bravo’s “Top Chef Masters”) to entice tourists into a culinary-focused bike tour through Sardinia. The tour will be a combination of eating and exercise, with the Boston chef Jody Adams as host.

headline: ‘American Folk Art’
text: Edward Thorp

headline: Indoor Food Market Planned for Midtown
text: Don’t drag out the shopping cart just yet, but a spacious new food market is planned for Midtown Manhattan. Urban Space, the company that runs the pop-up markets at Union Square Park, Madison Square Park, Columbus Circle and elsewhere, has rented 12,000 square feet in the Helmsley Building, the grand Beaux-Arts tower that straddles Park Avenue at 46th Street.

headline: Prada’s Industrial Evolution
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Violence Threatens U.S. Soccer Friendly in Ukraine
text: Political violence in Ukraine continued to imperil the United States national team’s friendly against Ukraine, which is scheduled to be played in the eastern city of Kharkiv in March but seems increasingly likely to be played elsewhere — if at all.

headline: For a Kurdish Woman, No Way Out
text: There may be knee-slappers to be written about forced marriage, but they aren’t to be found in the goofy, slapdash “One Candle, Two Candles ....” The Kurdish filmmaker Jano Rosebiani, who directed the well-received drama “Jiyan,” about the aftermath of chemical attacks, inflicts an antic approach on the story of a teenager betrothed to a rich older man. Sparks do not fly.

headline: New York Versus New Jersey: Airport Wages Edition
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, as the name suggests, is supposed to be one uber-agency that makes transportation-related decisions for both states. Too often, however, it is really two authorities—a New York operation run by Gov. Andrew Cuomo and a New Jersey version dominated by Gov. Chris Christie.

headline: Waiting With Bittersweet Anxiety for Their Moment
text: “You get paid for the groan,” an actress named Aléna Watters says in the engaging documentary “The Standbys,” perfectly summing up the bittersweet reality of life as a backup performer on Broadway.

headline: A Pretty Mental Patient Comes Home to Meet the Folks
text: “Barefoot,” a catastrophic American remake of “Barfuss,” a 2005 German romantic comedy, wastes the talents of respectable actors like Kate Burton, Treat Williams, J. K. Simmons and, most painfully, Evan Rachel Wood. Ms. Wood is miscast as Daisy, a possibly psychotic woman-child enlisted by Jay (Scott Speedman), the black sheep scion of a wealthy New Orleans family, to pose as his girlfriend when he returns home for the wedding of his younger brother.

headline: A Scallop for a Sherry
text: Amontillado is the broad-spectrum sherry, the one I would happily sip with a meal from start to finish. You want a fino with your oysters? Consider amontillado in a classic style, not sweetened, and go from there. During the tasting I wanted big sea scallops with a deep, almost candied burnish. That very evening, a memorable midcourse of sea scallops with pistachios and licorice at Restaurant Daniel suggested the pairing may be worth a test run. Raj Vaidya, the sommelier, was on board at once, with glasses of good amontillado. Though pistachios are sweeter and more herbaceous than the toasty essence of hazelnut that wraps the sherry, they drove the dish in the right direction. The recipe is my interpretation.

headline: Juniper Networks Reaches Deal With Hedge Fund
text: Juniper Networks, the networking equipment company, said on Thursday that it had reached an agreement with the hedge fund Elliott Management to nominate two new directors to its board and return more money to shareholders, avoiding a possible proxy fight with the hedge fund.

headline: French and Americans in a Moving Dialogue
text: It’s been far too long — choreographically speaking — since France invaded New York. In the spring of 2001, France Moves, a festival programmed by Yorgos Lukos, the artistic director of the Lyon Opera Ballet, filled New York with a wealth of dances by established and experimental French dance artists. Remember, in his American debut, the breath of fresh air that was Boris Charmatz?

headline: The Book on Amontillado
text: Diving into amontillado is the equivalent of committing to a long, complicated novel. You may be surprised, even astounded by what you find. You will almost certainly be rewarded if you permit yourself to be challenged.

headline: The Ukraine Divide, Explained
text: Ukraine is being pulled in different directions: one toward Russia, the other toward Western Europe.

headline: Next Step for Force in Ballet
text: Identifying the next great ballet choreographer isn’t exactly like recognizing the Messiah, yet for the ballet-obsessed there are similarities. Since the deaths of George Balanchine, Frederick Ashton and Jerome Robbins at the end of last century, the sense of loss has remained so strong that critics and audiences have been both desperate to find successors and reflexively skeptical about candidates. Thus it was a big deal in January 2013 when Alastair Macaulay declared in The New York Times that Justin Peck was “the third important choreographer to have emerged in classical ballet this century.”

headline: Lava and Lust
text: In Paul W. S. Anderson’s last three movies, a swashbuckler and two films based on the “Resident Evil” video game, he trained his camera on his wife, Milla Jovovich, in the obsessive way Josef von Sternberg once filmed Marlene Dietrich. In “Pompeii,” Mr. Anderson’s latest 3-D extravaganza, and his first film without Ms. Jovovich since 2008, he seems to be without visual focus.

headline: Get the Laughs, but Follow the Rules
text: Is there anything improv can’t do?

headline: From Zola, With Blood, Lust and Bloodlust
text: “In Secret,” the latest adaptation of Émile Zola’s “Thérèse Raquin,” opens with a dip in the water and quickly comes ashore with furiously galloping horses and sweeping camera movements. The galloping suggests urgency; the camera movements imply narrative grandeur, or maybe directorial ambition. The darkly muted colors, evoking gathering storms and winter chill, add a brooding note. The river that runs alongside the road like a parallel boulevard will probably mean something only to those who have read Zola’s book, a classic of literary naturalism, which was published in 1867 and greeted by one appalled critic as “a pool of mud and blood.”

headline: Clip: 'Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me'
text: A scene from the documentary.

headline: Hackley School Tells Parents of Accusations of Abuse From the ’60s
text: Another prominent private school in the New York area has acknowledged accusations of long-ago sexual abuse of students, joining a small group of schools that have grappled in recent years with claims of abuse that happened decades earlier.

headline: White House Discusses Ukraine Unrest
text: The White House principal deputy press secretary, Josh Earnest, told reporters that the Ukrainian government had primary responsibility for stemming its country’s violence.

headline: Recalling Velvet, Pretzels and Beer, She’s Still Here
text: “A Molotov cocktail of madness, sanity and genius.” That is one description of the great Broadway and cabaret entertainer Elaine Stritch in Chiemi Karasawa’s acutely intimate documentary portrait, “Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me.”

headline: Former Hedge Fund Analyst Charged With Stealing Data
text: A former hedge fund analyst has been charged with stealing confidential computer data from his previous employer, the latest crackdown by the Manhattan district attorney on suspected violations of cybersecurity.

headline: My First Apartment, Guiltily Remembered
text: I was lucky in 1970, when I backed into my first apartment, a $45-a-month railroad flat built in 1887 at 1422 Third Avenue, south of 81st Street. It was with apartment 2C I learned how to circumvent the rent laws and that when it comes to housing in New York, even a friend will stab you in the back.

headline: Hedge Fund Commercial
text: Topturn Capital, a $100 million hedge fund, created an ad with images of a professional surfer interspersed with the company’s two founders discussing how managing money is a lot like surfing.

headline: For Your Consideration: Apathy
text: LOS ANGELES — HOLLYWOOD’S biggest party of the year is only nine days away, but festive the movie capital is not.

headline: Times Minute | Women’s Skating Upset
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Women's Skating Upset
text: Adelina Sotnikova wins gold in the women's skating competition. Also on the Minute, quiet nuclear diplomacy and cities cut hours for part-time, public government workers.

headline: Ask a Question About the Crisis in Ukraine
text: Violence erupted in the center of the Ukrainian capital, Kiev, this week as protesters and riot police officers used firearms against each other. Bodies were lined up on a sidewalk on Thursday, a hotel lobby was turned into a medical center and fears grew that the president would declare a state of emergency.

headline: G.M. Recalls Some Cars, but Not All, With Ignition Switch Problem
text: General Motors in 2006 sent dealers a technical service bulletin warning that because of an ignition problem, a heavy key chain hanging from the ignition could turn off the engine on six models. But only two of those models were covered in last week’s recall  of 778,000 vehicles in the United States and Canada for the problem that the automaker now says could keep air bags from deploying in a crash.

headline: With Ban on Ads Removed, Hedge Funds Test Waters
text: Updated, 8:58 p.m. | It looks like the kind of motivational poster on a college student’s dorm room wall. Snowboarders stand at the peak of a steep mountain, reveling in victory, with the tag line, “Performing in all conditions.”

headline: Fragments of a Monastery, Reunited in Body and Spirit
text: You have to hate or fear something a lot to do what China did to Tibetan Buddhism. In the early 20th century, Tibet had thousands of active monasteries; when the Cultural Revolution ended in 1976, it had fewer than 10. The politics of blame are always tricky; some scholars argue that Tibetans themselves, for complicated reasons, contributed to the purge. But one reality is plain: By the time the mass demolition wound down, centuries’ worth of religious art was gone.

headline: Events in Westchester for Feb. 23-March 1
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Mondrian Inspires Moods and Form
text: One point is undeniable about Jessica Lang: She is prolific, having created more than 80 dances since she started working as a freelance choreographer in 1999. But what drives her vision? After the curtain fell on the last of six pieces presented by Jessica Lang Dance at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday, I still wasn’t sure.

headline: ‘We’re Really Happy You Decided to Come’
text: The Turner Prize has lost much of its capacity to shock, but it can still deliver modest surprises: Critics and bookies were caught off guard in December when the 2013 honors went to Laure Prouvost. Ms. Prouvost, born in France but based in Britain, was the dark horse on the shortlist for the Turner, presented to a British visual artist under the age of 50; this year, it also included the puckish draftsman David Shrigley, the painter of imaginary figures Lynette Yiadom-Boakye and the conceptual-performance artist Tino Sehgal.

headline: Events in Connecticut for Feb. 23-March 1
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: War of Words Signals a Changed BlackBerry
text: OTTAWA — In one of the more public illustrations of how things have changed at BlackBerry, John S. Chen, the company’s relatively new chief executive and executive chairman, engaged in some exceptional online sniping this week with his counterpart at T-Mobile US.

headline: Ill-Fated Love, Made Intimate
text: Student opera productions, often mounted to highlight an individual star talent or two, typically prove uneven. Such, evidently, was the case when the Juilliard Opera last presented Tchaikovsky’s “Eugene Onegin,” in 2002.

headline: Dan Graham to Design Met Museum Rooftop Exhibit
text: The American Conceptualist Dan Graham has long worn many art world hats. He has produced films and videos, drawings and prints; chronicled rock culture; and collaborated with bands like Sonic Youth and Japanther. But Mr. Graham is perhaps best known for his architectural environments and glass pavilions, which he has been designing since the 1980s. Often constructed of two-way mirrored glass and steel, they are created in such a way that the viewer and the surrounding landscape can become actors in his creations.

headline: Venturing Into Noise in Search of Melody
text: It’s been hard to hear some of the most beautiful music played in New York recently. Last week, one of the finest moments in the pianist Christian Zacharias’s recital at Alice Tully Hall was the quiet dying away of a sepulchral A flat at the end of the Funeral March in Beethoven’s Sonata No. 12.

headline: The Impact of Four Decades, Experienced Room by Room
text: Thanks to mega-dealers like David Zwirner and Larry Gagosian, it’s no surprise these days to see art exhibitions in commercial galleries that resemble ambitious, high-quality museum shows. But “Re-View: Onnasch Collection” at Hauser & Wirth raises the bar. The show more effectively simulates the experience of a modern art museum than any private gallery exhibition I’ve seen in New York. It is, in many ways, a terrific show. So why does it make me feel so bad?

headline: Treachery Thrives Where Trust Withers
text: Hany Abu-Assad’s new film, “Omar,” is about Israeli-Palestinian violence and also about three friends, young men who seem familiar almost as soon as we see them together. Tarek (Eyad Hourani) is the leader, Amjad (Samer Bisharat) is the joker, and Omar (Adam Bakri) is the sensitive one, handsome and athletic with the soul of a poet. He and Amjad are both in love with Tarek’s sister Nadia (Leem Lubany), but their rivalry is kept in check by their affection for each other and by strict customs governing courtship and family life.

headline: In Thrall to Machines, War and a More Manly Future
text: Was any avowedly modern art movement as obnoxious and noisily contradictory as Italian Futurism? By turn aesthetically revolutionary and politically reactionary, farsighted and visually challenged, not to mention officially misogynist, it is both a stain on the Modernist brand and a point of pride. It needs all the help it can get and it receives a large dose from “Italian Futurism, 1909-1944: Reconstructing the Universe,” an epic exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum.

headline: Anti-Putin Punk Activists Release New Music Video
text: Suspicions that footage of Pussy Riot activists being manhandled by the police in Sochi, Russia, on Tuesday and whipped by Cossacks on Wednesday might help the feminist collective make its point about state repression were proved correct on Thursday, with the release of the group’s latest music video, “Putin Will Teach You How to Love the Motherland.”

headline: Events in New Jersey for Feb. 23-March 1
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: The Furniture and Life of Paul Evans
text: Aggressive metal furniture by the designer Paul Evans is not easy to categorize.

headline: Down and Armed in Paris, Teenager in Tow
text: In the new movie “3 Days to Kill,” Paris is full of thugs for hire with bald heads and dark suits, and the last thing they want to see — in many cases the last thing they do see — is Kevin Costner, unshaven and in faded jeans, shuffling down the hallway in their direction. Sometimes these tough guys make fun of the fact that Mr. Costner’s character, Ethan Renner, is American, calling him “cowboy” and other hilarious names. The deeper joke, perhaps unintentional, is that Ethan looks more French than most of the Parisians he encounters. With his loosely tied scarf and graying stubble, his sunglasses and his world-weary demeanor, he could easily pass for a philosophy professor or the leader of a Serge Gainsbourg tribute band. If he spoke any French, that is.

headline: Look, but Mostly Listen: Remembering Sept. 11
text: The portentous narration begins soon after Dan Rather delivers a windy recorded video message to start “Bikeman: A 9/11 Play,” a docudrama by Thomas F. Flynn that recounts his experiences on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Events on Long Island for Feb. 23-March 1
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Celebrating Bondage Over Bonds of Marriage
text: “In bondage, she found freedom.” That’s the tagline in the trailer for the Hindi movie “Highway,” and it makes you wonder if the film will be appalling or merely clueless. It’s neither, though it has tone trouble as it searches for a genre to contain a story with built-in believability problems.

headline: Conversation Hearts, More ‘Scram’ Than ‘Be Mine’
text: The set designer Mitchell Greenberg’s proscenium for “Til Divorce Do Us Part: The Musical” nicely suggests the show: enlarged Valentine’s Day candies — those hearts inscribed with messages — surround the stage. But these pink morsels don’t offer words of love; they have expressions like “Really?,” “Scram,” “Bite Me,” “Buh Bye” and “Be Mine Not.” They look good enough to eat. Maybe revenge truly is sweet.

headline: How Sotnikova Beat Kim, Move by Move

text: Many octogenarians will not have to travel far to find senior living housing after the merger of two of the country’s leading elder care companies.

headline: Former Liverpool Star Fowler Paints New York Red
text: Robbie Fowler's 330 games and 171 goals for Liverpool, the club he joined as a boy three decades ago, earned him the affectionate nickname of God in his hometown. He was a local boy made good, a so-called Scouse scally from a rough side of town who endeared himself to the club’s rabid fans at Anfield stadium for 11 seasons during his heyday in the 1990s.

headline: American Meat Plants Said to Face Shortages of Inspectors
text: WASHINGTON — The Agriculture Department is suffering from a shortage of inspectors at some of the nation’s meat and poultry plants, a top inspectors’ union official and a food safety group said this week, raising the possibility that contaminated products could reach consumers.
