headline: My Night in Solitary
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — AT 6:45 p.m. on Jan. 23, I was delivered to a Colorado state penitentiary, where I was issued an inmate uniform and a mesh bag with my toiletries and bedding. My arms were handcuffed behind my back, my legs were shackled and I was deposited in Administrative Segregation — solitary confinement.

headline: Robert M. Fresco, Oscar-Winning Documentary Filmmaker, Dies at 83
text: Robert M. Fresco, an Academy Award-winning documentary filmmaker who began his career as a writer of horror pictures, died on Feb. 14 in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Days of Desiccation
text: SAN DIEGO — The bathtub rings in the reservoirs that hold California’s liquid life have never been more exposed. Shorelines are bare, brown and bony. Much of the Sierra Nevada is naked of snow. And fields in the Central Valley may soon take to the sky. A Dust Bowl? Not yet. Though this drought will surely go down as the worst in the state’s recorded history. Until next year.

headline: Russian Punk Group Ends Protest Tour of Sochi
text: SOCHI, Russia — For an Olympics that was anticipated by critics of the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, as a rare public platform to bring together and amplify Russia’s scattered voices of dissent, the protest here had largely turned out to be a bust. And then Pussy Riot came to town.

headline: Back From Suspension, Braun Hopes to Get Back in Game
text: PHOENIX — Ryan Braun’s second chance began Thursday at Maryvale Baseball Park, the site of his greatest embarrassment. It was here, two years ago, that Braun said he would bet his life that he had never used performance-enhancing drugs. Braun lost the bet, of course, but has emerged with his life and career intact.

headline: 2 Former Christie Aides Who Ignored Subpoenas Are Ordered to Court
text: A judge in New Jersey has ordered two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie to appear in court to explain their refusal to turn over potential evidence to a legislative committee investigating the politically charged closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: Pussy Riot, Putin and the Law of the Cossack
text: When two members of Pussy Riot, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova and Maria Alyokhina, spoke to the Times editorial board a few weeks ago, someone asked them what they expected upon their return to Russia. They made it clear they were not going to remain silent. Beyond that, they couldn’t say. “We don’t know what’s going to happen,” Ms. Alyokhina said. “The state might have other plans for us.”

headline: Amarillo Struggles to Handle Influx of Refugees
text: For the last five years, Titus Pa Thawng has lived thousands of miles from his native Myanmar in Amarillo, where he is a Christian pastor for a congregation of fellow refugees. “God has sent us here,” said Mr. Thawng, 45, a married father of three daughters.

headline: Texas G.O.P. Eagerly Jumps on Neglected Bandwagons
text: When a group of data-savvy operatives from Barack Obama’s presidential campaigns created Battleground Texas a year ago and vowed to work day and night to make the Republican-ruled state politically competitive again, Gov. Rick Perry, a Republican, described the idea as unalloyed fantasy.

headline: New Russian Protest Video
text: The Russian punk group Pussy Riot released a new music video protesting the human rights record of President Vladimir V. Putin during the Olympics.

headline: Abbott’s Choice of Help on Campaign Trail Is a Real Puzzle
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Banana Republic Ads With Real-Life Unions Include a Gay Couple
text: TO help a new campaign stand out in the crowded marketplace for apparel retailers, Banana Republic decided, among other things, to change ad themes, adopting “The true outfitters of modern American style,” and feature pairs of models who are also coupled up in real life — with a twist. Amid the stylish men and women wearing the new spring line for Banana Republic is a couple composed of two men, the interior designer Nate Berkus and his fiancé, Jeremiah Brent, who is also an interior designer.

headline: He Came, He Saw, He Conquered ... Hilariously
text: I had cut a college class or two and hopped the rickety New Haven R.R. to New York on one of my many jaunts to the Apple. I did this whenever possible to hang around the city of my dreams and the world of show business, sneaking into TV studios and Broadway play rehearsals — a star-struck, show-struck kid, accosting the famous on the streets, in restaurants and in dressing rooms. It’s a wonder I was never knocked cold.

headline: Whitman’s Vision for H.P. in 2017
text: Hewlett-Packard’s boss has a plan. Or at least a vision for the long-struggling company.

headline: Venezuelan Beauty Queen Is Among Protesters Killed
text: A 22-year-old beauty queen, shot while attending a protest march in Venezuela, is one of five people killed since demonstrations around the country turned violent in the last week.

headline: Do Curlers Make Good Housekeepers? Don’t Ask!
text: SOCHI, Russia — The conversations follow a wearying and familiar pattern. First, Troels Harry identifies himself as a curler, master of a sport many people know (if they know about it at all) as the thing that looks like shuffleboard on ice, with brooms.

headline: Contraception in the Shadow of Abortion
text: I’m late turning to this, but before it disappears down the memory hole I wanted to say something about some of the criticisms of my column from a few weeks back, on the link between liberal victories on abortion and divorce law and the subsequent decline of marriage. I’m particularly interested in addressing the point, raised by Will Saletan and James Taranto, that my argument also implies a sweeping case against legal contraception — with Taranto accusing me of “a subtle deception” in eliding that point, and Saletan writing that I’m tiptoeing around an anti-contraception position that he doesn’t think I have “the stomach to defend.”

headline: Racist Episodes Continue to Stir Ole Miss Campus
text: OXFORD, Miss. — On the campus of the University of Mississippi, a few hundred yards from a monument honoring Confederate soldiers, a statue of the university’s first black student, who enrolled in 1962 amid rioting that left two people dead, stands as what administrators call a powerful symbol of progress.

headline: Murdoch Is Said to Pay $57 Million for Condo
text: The media mogul Rupert Murdoch has paid more than $57 million for the top four flours of One Madison, a steel and glass luxury condominium tower in downtown Manhattan, according to people briefed on the sale.

headline: Canada Defeats United States for Women’s Hockey Gold
text: The Canadians won, 3-2, in overtime to take the top honor in the Olympic tournament.

headline: For Facebook, It’s Users First and Profits Later
text: Technology companies have always been paranoid about missing the next big thing, be it email, e-commerce or social media.

headline: 14-Year Term for Leader in Bronx Antigay Attack
text: The leader of a street gang that lured a man to an apartment in the Bronx and then beat and tortured him for hours in one of New York’s most savage antigay crimes will be sentenced to 14 years in prison under a plea deal announced on Thursday.

headline: Weighing the Ice Cream
text: This is the sixth part of an eight-part series.

headline: The Stimulus Tragedy
text: Five years have passed since President Obama signed the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act — the “stimulus” — into law. With the passage of time, it has become clear that the act did a vast amount of good. It helped end the economy’s plunge; it created or saved millions of jobs; it left behind an important legacy of public and private investment.

headline: Syrian Rebels Sought to Bolster Coalition’s Case in Peace Talks
text: GENEVA — In a crowd of suits in the softly lighted lobby of the InterContinental Hotel here, the military men stood out, wearing leather jackets, overcoats and skeptical expressions. They represented the dominant surviving faction of the Free Syrian Army, the first active leaders of that military arm of the Western-backed exile coalition who attended peace talks earlier this month — a milestone, since many insurgents view the talks with the Syrian government as tantamount to treason.

headline: Colorado Expects to Reap Tax Bonanza From Legal Marijuana Sales
text: DENVER — For Colorado’s new flock of recreational marijuana growers and sellers, Thursday was Tax Day — their first deadline to hand over the taxes they had collected during their inaugural month of sales. And as store owners stuffed cash into lockboxes and made the nervous trek to government offices, new budget numbers predicted that those marijuana taxes could add more than $100 million a year to state coffers, far more than earlier estimates.

headline: With Eye on Summer of 2015, Knicks Are Quiet at Trade Deadline
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The Knicks did not do anything rash or imprudent ahead of Thursday’s 3 p.m. trade deadline, like take on an onerous long-term contract. Given their history, it was always a possibility.

headline: Capitalism for the Masses
text: When Arthur Brooks was 24, he was playing the French horn in a chamber music concert in Dijon, France. He noticed a beautiful woman smiling at him from the front row, so, after the recital, he made a beeline for her and introduced himself.

headline: Muzzling Speech in India
text: The decision last week by Penguin India to withdraw from publication and pulp copies of “The Hindus: An Alternative History” is only the latest assault on free speech in India. The publisher’s move is likely to encourage more demands for censorship.

headline: A Billionaire Philanthropist in Washington Who’s Big on ‘Patriotic Giving’
text: WASHINGTON — The expansive reach of David M. Rubenstein into the public life of the nation’s capital can be seen during a brief excursion from his downtown office at the Carlyle Group, the private equity firm that he co-founded and that made him a billionaire.

headline: Comcast’s Web of Lobbying and Philanthropy
text: WASHINGTON — Only a few hours had passed after the $45 billion merger between Comcast and Time Warner Cable was announced last week when an early voice emerged endorsing the giant deal.

headline: Haitian Dictator May Be Charged With Human Rights Crimes, Court Says
text: MEXICO CITY — An appeals court in Haiti ruled Thursday that one of the country’s most brutal dictators could be charged with crimes against humanity but stopped short of ordering a trial to proceed, calling for further investigation.

headline: The Go-To Congresswoman on Gun Control Packs It In
text: Representative Carolyn McCarthy hopes she can quit Washington for good before another group of families left grieving by gun violence arrives at her office. She suspects otherwise, since she’s got another 10 months to go before finishing out her 18-year career at the end of the year, and she knows better than anyone in Congress the unyielding rhythm of the nation’s gun trauma.

headline: Deal Reached on Litigation Over Long Island College Hospital
text: The State University of New York and a coalition including unions and community groups in northern Brooklyn have agreed to settle litigation that has kept the troubled Long Island College Hospital open for a year, officials on both sides said on Thursday.

headline: Founders of an Anti-Facebook Are Won Over
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Jan Koum fled the former Soviet Union with his mother when he was 16, leaving his father behind. He worked in the engineering trenches for a decade at Yahoo before starting out on his own. When he was a young man growing up in Mountain View, Calif., his family relied on food stamps to get by.

headline: Los Angeles’s Costly Lesson for the Vatican
text: Pope Francis has been meeting this week with eight cardinals he selected to shape proposals for reforming the Roman Catholic Church. It is too early to tell what will result from an agenda that will range from Vatican finances to the recruitment of new believers. But the deliberations surely cannot afford to overlook the shocking price tag announced as a final figure that the Los Angeles Archdiocese paid to victims of child sexual abuse by priests.

headline: 2 Plead Guilty in Beating of Giants Fan Outside Dodger Stadium
text: LOS ANGELES — Two men pleaded guilty on Thursday in the 2011 beating of Bryan Stow, a San Francisco Giants fan who was attacked outside Dodger Stadium and left with permanent brain injuries.

headline: New York Rethinks Solitary Confinement
text: The New York State prison system has for years been among the nation’s worst when it comes to the overuse of solitary confinement. At any given time about 3,800 inmates across the state are held in windowless isolation for 23 hours a day, the vast majority for disciplinary infractions. The average length of a stay in solitary is five months, and from 2007 to 2011, nearly 2,800 people  were in solitary for a year or more.

headline: Adelina Sotnikova’s Upset Victory Is Hard to Figure
text: SOCHI, Russia — I ran to the first skating insider I could find: Kurt Browning, a four-time world champion who had been commentating for Canadian television. Could he explain what just happened?

headline: Police Coercion Cited in Order for Retrial in Upstate New York Killing
text: Declaring that there are limits to the lies and deceptions the police can employ to get a person to confess to a crime, New York State’s highest court on Thursday ordered a new trial for a man convicted five years ago of killing his infant son.

headline: Life After Gluten
text: For people who don't suffer from celiac disease, is the gluten-free diet a fad or an innovative way to approach eating?

headline: No. 3 Returns, Stirring Painful Memories for Earnhardt’s Fans
text: MOORESVILLE, N.C. — Jackie King held back tears as she sat outside the old Dale Earnhardt Inc. race shop, which serves as a shrine to Earnhardt, the revered Nascar driver. Tuesday was the 13th anniversary of the crash on the last lap of the 2001 Daytona 500 that killed Earnhardt, and King had come to attend the annual candlelight tribute there.

headline: Flu Rate Rises in the Young and the Middle-Aged
text: The flu is hitting young and middle-aged people particularly hard this season, as a tough flu strain re-emerged and too few people were vaccinated, health authorities said on Thursday. More than 60 percent of the severe flu cases in the United States this season have been in people 18 to 64 years old — about double the usual rate, they said. Typically, people at risk for flu complications include pregnant women, the elderly, children and people with compromised immune systems. The main flu circulating this season is H1N1, the “swine flu” that caused a pandemic four years ago. Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, chief of the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said that only a third of people ages 18 to 64 were vaccinated as of November, compared with nearly two-thirds of children and elderly people.

headline: At Olympic Curling Matches, Hands Speak Louder Than Words
text: SOCHI, Russia — As the fans roared in the background at a recent curling match here, the Swedish skip, Margaretha Sigfridsson, examined the smattering of stones on the ice, her red hair pulled back and her face stern. Her team trailed Russia by 2 points in the third end.

headline: Egypt Extends Its Crackdown to Journalists
text: CAIRO — The three men, wearing white prison scrubs in metal cages reserved for criminal suspects, listened to the list of explosive charges accusing them of aiding a plot to undermine Egypt’s national security.

headline: He Played Blues Concerts Where the Admission Price Was Subway Fare
text: Carolina Slim appeared at Avery Fisher Hall once, but mostly he plugged in his guitar and performed underground. Not in one of those clubs in a subbasement with a two-drink minimum. In subway stations.

headline: ‘Elijah and Jeremiah’
text: A short documentary on Elijah “Carolina Slim” Staley and Jeremiah Lockwood, musicians who played the blues on the subway together for years.

headline: Hearts Ache in the Heartland
text: “Iowa.” When Kelli O’Hara sings that word, a plain place name becomes a prism of rippling ambivalence.

headline: Of Clogs and Cordwainers
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s no unifying theme in this Friday puzzle from Patrick Berry, but he has decided to GO BIG OR GO HOME by stacking the puzzle with plenty of brilliantly worded clues that tease the solver with double meanings and subtle misdirection.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 20, 2014
Coping with Retirement
text: For more than a year, I have been trying my hardest to move on with my life after being medically retired from the Marine Corps. I have developed compensatory strategies that allow me to succeed personally and professionally, despite having suffered a traumatic brain injury in Afghanistan more than three years ago. I haven’t just had to overcome T.B.I. since leaving the corps, though: I have also had to battle post-traumatic stress disorder, something that Luke, my service dog, has made much easier.

headline: Jason Collins Is Considered Candidate for the Nets
text: SAN FRANCISCO — After failing to acquire a frontcourt player before the N.B.A.’s trade deadline passed Thursday afternoon, the Nets shifted their focus to a list of free-agent big men they could sign and plug into their rotation down the stretch.

headline: A Packed Forum for a Rising Concern: New Skyscrapers Near Central Park
text: The image on the screen was arresting: four long foreboding shadows thrown by a new set of skyscrapers across one of New York City’s brightest green gems, Central Park.

headline: A Pharmacy Provides Salves for a Community’s Spirits
text: Just about no one knows the territory like a neighborhood pharmacist, membrane by membrane.

headline: Knee Injury Will Keep Islanders’ Tavares Out for Season
text: SYOSSET, N.Y. — John Tavares is featured this month on the cover of the Islanders’ program, wearing a red and white Team Canada sweater. But when fans return to Nassau Coliseum on Feb. 27 for a game against Toronto, the Islanders’ first matchup after the Olympic break, they will not see Tavares, the team’s captain, on the ice.

headline: Obama’s Plan to Meet Dalai Lama Draws Swift Chinese Rebuke
text: President Obama plans to meet at the White House on Friday with the Dalai Lama, a visit that drew a swift rebuke from the Chinese government, which has tried to diminish the influence of the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader and his efforts to promote the autonomy of Tibet.

headline: Junior’s Brooklyn Site Will Be Sold to Developer, but Restaurant Will Return
text: The reigning dessert of Downtown Brooklyn is so creamy it sticks to the teeth, so famous it has fed presidents and princes, so precious that when the building where it is made nearly burned to the ground in 1981, people rushed to the scene to wail, “Save the cheesecake!”

headline: Converts Join With Militants in Kiev Clash
text: KIEV, Ukraine — As the center of the Ukrainian capital tipped into a maelstrom of gunfire and blood on Thursday, a man wearing a helmet stood on a street corner near Independence Square, the epicenter of the violence, holding a leaf of printer paper.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Like Father, Like Son? The Mets Can Only Hope
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — At an early age, Cory Vaughn was conditioned to act like a professional baseball player. His father, Greg Vaughn, who hit 50 homers for the San Diego Padres in 1998, would bring him to the ballpark, where he let him shag fly balls and take grounders. But there were rules. It was not a playground, his father said. He had to be respectful and carry himself seriously. He was about 5 years old.

headline: Leader of Port Authority’s Police Union to Reduce Role Amid Bridge Scandal
text: The president of the union that represents police officers for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, who has come under increasing scrutiny in connection with the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, told his membership on Thursday that he would step aside from the union’s day-to-day operations, a person briefed on the matter said.

headline: Toshiko d’Elia Dies at 84; Gritty Runner Was Champion in an Age Group
text: Toshiko d’Elia, who emerged from the destitution of postwar Japan to achieve renown in the United States as a marathon runner, taking up the sport at age 44 in the 1970s when few older women were doing so, died on Wednesday in Allendale, N.J. She was 84.

headline: Protests Swell in Venezuela as Places to Rally Disappear
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The only television station that relentlessly broadcast voices critical of the government was sold last year, and the new owners have softened its news coverage. Last week, President Nicolás Maduro banned a foreign cable news channel after it showed images of a young protester shot to death here.

headline: Jeter Savoring His Last Season but Not Letting It Distract Him
text: TAMPA, Fla. — In the ninth inning of the penultimate game at the old Yankee Stadium in 2008, Derek Jeter was trying to absorb every aspect of the final moments at the sacred grounds. He knew there would be only a few more at-bats there, and he wanted to soak them up.

headline: Greek and Turkish Cypriots Unite to Restore a Church and a Bond
text: KONTEA, Cyprus — In the days before this island was cleft between Greek and Turkish control, the church of St. Charalambos in this tiny village was a gathering place for all. But after decades of division, and fruitless talks between political leaders, local people grew tired of watching its paint peel and its altar decay. They took matters into their own hands.

headline: Kiev: Triage in Crisis
text: In the Ukrainian capital, triage centers have sprung up around Independence Square, where dozens of people have died in the fighting.

headline: Libyan Vote on Charter Assembly Is Marred by Violence and Low Turnout
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Libya’s long-delayed efforts to prepare a new charter hit another obstacle on Thursday when elections for a 60-member constitutional drafting committee fell well short of expectations, with a low turnout and 13 of 60 constituencies failing to elect candidates by the end of the day.

headline: Dead Guards on Freighter Are Identified as Former Navy SEAL Members
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Two former Navy SEAL members who had been hired to protect the container ship that was attacked by Somali pirates in 2009 — an episode that became the basis of the Oscar-nominated film “Captain Phillips” — were found dead while the ship, the Maersk Alabama, was docked in the Seychelles, officials said Thursday.

headline: Greece: Far-Rightists’ Immunity at Risk
text: Judges handling a criminal investigation into the country’s far-right party Golden Dawn asked Parliament on Thursday to permit the prosecution of nine more of the party’s 18 lawmakers. If the judges’ request is approved, in a vote in Parliament to lift the lawmakers’ immunity from prosecution, all 18 of the party’s lawmakers will face charges of belonging to a criminal organization. Since a police crackdown on the party last fall, prompted by the killing of a rapper by a Golden Dawn supporter, nine of the party’s lawmakers have been prosecuted on criminal charges.

headline: Governor of Nigeria’s Central Bank Is Fired After Warning of Missing Oil Revenue
text: DAKAR, Senegal — President Goodluck Jonathan of Nigeria removed the governor of the country’s central bank from his post on Thursday, after the bank governor repeatedly charged that billions of dollars in oil revenue owed to the treasury was missing.

headline: Britain: Defense Heard in Hacking Case
text: Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper unit, testified in court on Thursday that during her time as the editor of the tabloid The News of the World she did not know about the activities of a private investigator who has admitted that he hacked phones on behalf of the newspaper. Ms. Brooks, 45, is accused of condoning hacking into telephone voice mail systems while she was the editor of The News of the World; of authorizing the bribing of a public official for an article; and of trying to hide evidence from the police. She denies it all. On the first day of her defense in the trial’s fourth month, Ms. Brooks’s lawyer asked if the involvement of the investigator, Glenn Mulcaire, in intercepting voice mail messages was ever brought to her attention between May 2000 and June 2003. “No, not at all,” she said. Earlier, she was cleared of a charge that she had authorized a reporter to pay for a picture of Prince William in a bikini.

headline: China: Dissident’s Wife Is Hospitalized
text: Liu Xia, the wife of Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned dissident who won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize, has been hospitalized, according to family friends. Ms. Liu, who has been under house arrest for the past three years, is said to be suffering from a heart ailment and severe depression. A poet and photographer, Ms. Liu, 52, has not been charged with any crime. Her husband, a writer and democracy advocate, is serving an 11-year sentence after being convicted of subversion charges. She was admitted to a Beijing hospital on Tuesday, and family members have been pressing the authorities to let her leave the country for medical care.

headline: New York Is Removing Over 400 Children From 2 Homeless Shelters
text: In the face of New York’s mounting homeless crisis, Mayor Bill de Blasio will announce on Friday that his administration is removing hundreds of children from two city-owned homeless shelters that inspectors have repeatedly cited for deplorable conditions over the last decade, officials said.

headline: In Ukraine’s West, a Jumping-Off Point for Volunteers Heading to Kiev
text: LVIV, Ukraine — This rebellious city in western Ukraine, which basically declared itself autonomous as the nation’s political crisis escalated into deadly violence this week, is the recruiting center for volunteers to staff the bloodied protester ramparts in the capital, Kiev, 330 miles to the east.

headline: The Founders of WhatsApp
text: Operating under the radar, the creators of the app have worked to fulfill a singular vision: Create a good messaging service.

headline: Ask Well: Awake at 2 A.M.
text: Question:

headline: Iraq: Mortar Fire Kills at Least 21 People
text: Seven mortar shells fell on the Shiite town of Musayyib, south of Baghdad, on Thursday, killing 21 people and wounding 65, Iraqi officials said. Security officials said the shells had been fired from a Sunni area near Musayyib where security forces were conducting a weeklong search for fighters from the militant group the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria. No group immediately claimed responsibility for Thursday’s attack on the residential area. The Sunni area, Jurf al-Sakhar, was one of Al Qaeda’s strongholds during some of the worst of the sectarian fighting in 2006 and 2007. Now members of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria have moved to the area, according to officials, prompting the sweeps.

headline: Word of the Day | regatta
text: regatta •\ri-ˈgä-tə, -ˈga-\• noun

headline: U.N. Secretary General Seeks More Help for Central African Republic
text: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, on Thursday called for an immediate deployment of more troops and aid to rescue the Central African Republic from a de facto partition of the country into Christian and Muslim areas. France has already increased its contingent, and the European Union has said it will start sending as many as 1,000 soldiers to the country in March.

headline: What to Watch at the Olympics: Friday
text: ALPINE SKIING Mikaela Shiffrin, 18, the reigning world champion, will try to win the United States’ first Olympic medal in the women’s slalom in 42 years. NBC, 8 p.m.

headline: Clip: 'Anchorman 2,' With New Jokes
text: A clip from the alternate version of “Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues.”

headline: ‘Anchorman 2’ Returns (Call It 2 ½)
text: LOS ANGELES — TAKE a raunchy Hollywood comedy, remove the jokes, and what do you have left?

headline: What’s on Friday
text: 8 P.M. (13) STING: THE LAST SHIP Sting performs songs from his latest album, “The Last Ship,” and regales the audience with memories of growing up in the shipbuilding community of Wallsend, England — including how, when the queen’s motorcade drove by, he longed to be in her car — in this concert recorded on Oct. 2 at the Public Theater in Manhattan and presented here by “Great Performances.” The program also chronicles the creation of the Broadway musical “The Last Ship,” with music and lyrics by Sting, above, and a book by John Logan and Brian Yorkey, which is to begin previews on Sept. 30 at the Neil Simon Theater. “ ‘The Last Ship’ contains Sting’s first new songs in nearly a decade, and he has said that they came in a surge,” Nate Chinen wrote in The New York Times. “The breakthrough was in writing for voices other than his own,” though Sting admits that one song features “the self-taught, pompous intellectual of the shipyard, played by me, of course.” Mr. Chinen added, “The dream-filled boy that Sting once was, and the privileged artist he became, have that much in common.”

headline: The Red Chains of Bureaucracy That ‘Torment’ Chinese
text: The Germans coined a word for its excesses: Behördengang. Franz Kafka, the great novelist of pain, described its dehumanizing effect: “The chains of tormented mankind are made out of red tape.” And Confucian China may have perfected it: bureaucracy.

headline: North Carolina Rallies Late to Upset No. 5 Duke
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — Inside the Dean Smith Dome, fans clad in Carolina blue lusted for an upset. They roared for it, demanded it and urged the underdog Tar Heels to complete their mission against No. 5 Duke.

headline: Ukraine Has Deal, but Both Russia and Protesters Appear Wary
text: KIEV, Ukraine — A deal aimed at ending a lethal spiral of violence in Ukraine began to show serious strains late Friday just hours after it had been signed, with angry protesters shouting down opposition members of Parliament who negotiated the accord and a militant leader threatening armed attacks if President Viktor F. Yanukovych did not step down by morning.

headline: Corrections: February 21, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Negotiating in Ukraine
text: Antigovernment protesters and police clashed violently on Independence Square in Kiev this week.

headline: Profit Falls at French Luxury and Sportswear Group Kering
text: PARIS — Profit at Kering, the French luxury-to-lifestyle conglomerate, slumped last year, reflecting sharply weaker sales at Puma, its struggling sportswear brand, as well as a slowdown in growth at Gucci, its flagship high-end brand.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Feb. 21, 2014
text: Use the following question for practice in rewording phrases.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | An Oscar-Nominated Song in a Hit Movie
text: In “The Nominees Are Blockbusters” Melena Ryzik writes about the making of “Frozen.” Watch the video and read the article to answer the questions.

headline: Born by a River, Watching the Change
text: The interplay of images in LaToya Ruby Frazier’s “Landscape of the Body (Epilepsy Test)” is haunting: a portrait of the artist’s mother in a disheveled hospital bed hooked up to monitors, juxtaposed with a shot of the Braddock, Pa., hospital’s demolition taken shortly after her stay, its tangled wiring exposed (Slide 14).

headline: How Much of a Daredevil Are You?
text: How much physical stimulation do you need? How comfortable are you in taking physical risks when you do sports? Are you always trying to go faster or higher, or are you happier with a slower, more controlled experience?

headline: Shell to Sell Refinery and Gas Stations in Australia
text: LONDON — Royal Dutch Shell said Friday that it would sell most of its Australian refining and marketing business to Vitol, a large commodity trading house, for about $2.6 billion.

headline: Snapdeal, the EBay of India, Sees Plenty of Room to Grow
text: BANGALORE – Snapdeal and Flipkart, India’s two largest online marketplaces, are frequently recipients of honorific, hopeful nicknames. They are, respectively, called the eBay and Amazon of India.

headline: The Courage of Transgender Soldiers
text: SYDNEY, Australia — IT was 2 a.m., just a few days before Christmas, in a remote part of Afghanistan. Eight hours into a 16-hour shift, Ryan, a 23-year-old American naval sailor, was standing tense and alert, watching the footage of soldiers undertaking a nearby mission on a screen in front of him.

headline: South Korea Aids North as Families Are Reunited
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea on Friday approved a shipment of $988,000 worth of medicine and powdered milk for North Korea and promised more humanitarian aid as the two Koreas continued the emotional reunions of families separated by the Korean War six decades ago.

headline: New York Today: Winter Interruptus
text: Updated 11:32 a.m.

headline: Stray Dogs and Stateless Babies
text: ON National Geographic Traveler Magazine’s Best of the World list this year, Sarajevo joined such select destinations as Liechtenstein, Puglia and Rocky Mountain National Park. But had the innocent tourist recently visited “the Balkan urban phoenix,” as the list labeled the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, he would most certainly have run into packs of stray dogs roaming the city.

headline: Times Minute | Profiting From Marijuana
text: Also on the Minute, the roots of the violence in Ukraine's opposition groups and watch for record online viewership for today's hockey match between the U.S. and Canada.

headline: Times Minute | Profiting From Marijuana
text: In the Video

headline: Sleep Apnea May Worsen Diabetes
text: Sleep apnea can worsen blood sugar control in people with Type 2 diabetes by disrupting the deepest stage of sleep, a new study suggests. The findings provide another good reason for people with sleep apnea to wear a CPAP mask that helps assure uninterrupted breathing, the standard treatment for the condition, throughout the night.

headline: Billionaire’s Arrest Intensifies Focus on Former Security Chief
text: A Chinese billionaire, Liu Han, stands accused of running a “mafia-style gang’’ that ran roughshod over one of the country’s most populous provinces for more than a decade, reportedly killing nine people and bullying villagers into surrendering their land to fuel his growing empire that included real estate, mining and natural gas.

headline: Beijing Official Detained in Investigation of Former Security Chief
text: HONG KONG — A Communist Party corruption investigation focusing on the former head of China’s domestic security apparatus has reached into the secretive realm of the intelligence services with the detention of a senior official, people close to party and military leaders said this week.

headline: Sweden Beats Finland, 2-1, to Advance to Hockey Final
text: For the second time in three Olympics, Sweden will be playing for the gold medal in men’s hockey. Sweden, the 2006 gold medalist, defeated its longtime rival Finland, 2-1, Thursday.

headline: Your Ancestors, Your Fate
text: Inequality of income and wealth has risen in America since the 1970s, yet a large-scale research study recently found that social mobility hadn’t changed much during that time. How can that be?

headline: 2 Prominent Women Under Detention Are Hospitalized
text: Two prominent women — Liu Xia and Cao Shunli — were hospitalized in poor health this week, after months or years of detention, according to their lawyers and friends.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Bets on Users First and Profits Later
text: Technology companies have always been paranoid about missing the next big thing, be it email, e-commerce or social media, David Gelles reports.

headline: A Business Owner Talks About Having to Cut Costs to Stay Competitive
text: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, Susan Parker shared some of the challenges facing her company, Bari Jay.

headline: Militants Attack Presidential Palace in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — In a deadly attack on the heart of the Somali government, multiple explosions and a firefight erupted on Friday near the presidential palace in Mogadishu, killing 12 people, nine of them militants, officials said. The Shabab, the militant Somali Islamist group, claimed responsibility.

headline: Detroit Outlines Map to Solvency, Stressing Repair
text: DETROIT — Seven months after this city entered bankruptcy, its leaders on Friday presented a federal judge with the first official road map to Detroit’s future — documents designed to show how it aims to settle its $18 billion debt to creditors and make itself livable again.

headline: Tech’s New Feeding Frenzy
text: TECH’S NEW FEEDING FRENZY  |  As soon as Facebook announced on Wednesday that it would acquire WhatsApp, a text messaging start-up, for up to $19 billion, almost everyone asked the same question: Why? What it boils down to is Facebook’s fear of missing out (F.O.M.O., for you cool kids). “Today, with Google, Facebook and others all fighting for the same customers and wallets, the competition has never been more intense, and big companies have never had to act so quickly — and with such conviction — to avoid being left behind,” David Gelles writes in DealBook. But the deal has raised fears that, by valuing the number of users above revenue, Facebook is inflating another dot-com bubble.

headline: Applying for College? Writing About Money?
text: The New York Times is seeking college application essays about money, working or social class from current high school seniors. We will publish the best ones in a “Your Money” column in May (and pay the writers our normal freelance rate), as we did last year. Please send essays to MoneyEssays@nytimes.com.

headline: Structural Reform is the Last Refuge of Scoundrels
text: OK, let’s be clear: I’m in favor of structural reform (as long as it’s the right kind of reform). I’m also in favor of peace, kindness, and good coffee for everyone.

headline: Behind These Olympic Doors Is Anyone’s Guess
text: SOCHI, Russia — Deep in the back alleyways of the Ice Cube Curling Center in the Olympic Park stands a door marked “TER Secondary.” It is not clear exactly what goes on in there or why it is so close to doors labeled “Language Services” and “Venue Technology Operations,” but it is further evidence, if any was needed, that the Olympics occupy an exotic alternative world that makes sense only on its own terms.

headline: Court Convicts 8 in 2012 Protest Against Putin
text: MOSCOW — Eight people were convicted on Friday of taking part in a violent protest before the inauguration of President Vladimir V. Putin in 2012, after a prolonged trial that became a symbol of the Kremlin’s renewed stifling of political dissent.

headline: HearSay Economics
text: David Glasner has another interesting post on the history of economic thought, this time on Say’s Law — which, at least since Keynes, has come to be identified as the doctrine that shortfalls in overall demand aren’t possible, because money has to be spent on something. If people save more, well, their money goes into banks, which lend it out, so it finances business investment, and overall spending doesn’t change.

headline: Shredlocks and Lucky Socks
text: Olympic athletes in Sochi talk about the rituals and superstitions that help them focus.

headline: Commissioner Bratton on a Threat to Pedestrians
text: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Act of Killing’ and Oscar Voters’ Aversion to Violence
text: No feature documentary film in recent years has provoked more debate than Joshua Oppenheimer’s “Act of Killing,” one of five nominees for the Oscar in that category. It’s not only that Mr. Oppenheimer tackles an extremely difficult subject — the mass murders that followed a military coup in Indonesia in 1965 and resulted in the deaths of as many as a million people — but also the way he tells the story, through extensive use of re-enactments featuring members of death squads that carried out the killings.

headline: Ain’t It Not Grand?
text: Hurray: President Obama has dropped his notion of using a change in the price index to cut Social Security benefits.

headline: In Slalom, Mikaela Shiffrin Zips to Bottom and Reaches the Pinnacle
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Mikaela Shiffrin, the 18-year-old wunderkind of ski racing, is a product of a countercultural movement in American youth sports, an initiative of parents who encourage their children to focus on the process of athletic achievement instead of the results. In theory, both the journey and the destination are enhanced.

headline: Inadvertently Baring Necessities
text: Although the name Disney is synonymous for some with timeless entertainment, “The Jungle Book” occupies a special place in Disney company history. Newly released on Blu-ray (as well as on DVD and digital HD), it was the last of the studio’s animated features to have been made under Walt Disney himself. That pop-culture titan died in December 1966, three years after work on the movie began and 10 months before its release.

headline: In the Back of the Bobsled, the Not-So-Scenic Route
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Judith Vis is a member of the Dutch women’s bobsled team and, by all accounts, a dutiful and conscientious athlete. Yet earlier this month — only minutes after she completed a practice run at the Sanki Sliding Center — she struggled with a relatively basic question.

headline: Stasha Yatchuk Transforms Backstage at Prada
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Stasha Yatchuk (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: No Surprise, Fed Was Biggest Buyer of Treasuries in 2013
text: THE Federal Reserve financed most of the government’s deficit in 2013, in sharp contrast to the year before, when the Fed did not add to its holdings of Treasury securities. The American private sector appears to have been a net seller of Treasuries in 2013, but the foreign private sector was a substantial buyer, according to government estimates released this week.

headline: The Final Battle for a REIT May Be Drawing Near
text: Is this the endgame for the battle to control CommonWealth REIT, or will shareholders once again be left to wait for the Portnoys, the father and son who control the real estate investment concern, to admit defeat?

headline: Fed Misread Crisis in 2008, Records Show
text: WASHINGTON — On the morning after Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy in 2008, most Federal Reserve officials still believed that the American economy would keep growing despite the metastasizing financial crisis.

headline: California: 4 Killed at Indian Tribal Meeting
text: A former tribal leader in California opened fire during eviction proceedings on Thursday, killing four people and injuring two others, the police said. The former leader, Sherie Rhoades, 44, shot five people inside the headquarters of the Cedarville Rancheria in Alturas, the police said, before stabbing a sixth person with a knife. Leaders were holding a meeting about evicting several residents, including Ms. Rhoades, the Modoc County Record, a local newspaper, quoted the police as saying. Ms. Rhoades is facing murder and attempted murder charges. The police had not identified the dead, two men and two women, as of midnight Thursday. According to its website, the Cedarville Rancheria is a small, federally recognized tribe of 35 members on 26 acres in Cedarville, about 20 minutes from Alturas.

headline: In Our Pages: February 22
text: 1914: Leap Proves Parachute’s Value

headline: Hundreds of Anne Frank Books Vandalized in Japan
text: TOKYO — Japan on Friday promised to begin an investigation into the mysterious mutilation of hundreds of copies of “Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl” and other books related to her at public libraries across Tokyo.

headline: In Store | Pamela Love’s Finer Things
text: “I love to layer on a lot of big sterling silver statement jewelry,” says Pamela Love, “but I’m getting a bit more delicate.” The young jewelry designer has drawn a celebrity and fashion-world following to her signature bohemian aesthetic since she began making pieces in her Brooklyn apartment in 2006. She has since gotten married and moved into a design studio in Manhattan — and is starting to notice that her clientele has been growing up, too. And so, this week, Love has reached another milestone: her first fine-jewelry line called, appropriately, Pamela Love Fine.

headline: The Home Crowd at the Sochi Games
text: Russian fans have welcomed the Sochi Games as an opportunity to be creative and patriotic in the way they dress for the events.

headline: A Wine Trail, by Ski and Snowshoe
text: In many wine regions of the world, aficionados can bike or hike between tasting rooms. But Michigan offers a novel vineyard-to-vineyard option: by ski and snowshoe.

headline: Send a Payment With Square Cash, the Service That’s Free, for Now
text: It’s rare that any new product or service quickly and simply makes our financial lives a whole lot easier. It’s rarer still that the offering is free.

headline: Marginal Marginalia
text: The prime minister’s cat; get a haircut.

headline: Who Made That Ski Lift?
text: “It is essential,” wrote the railway magnate William Averell Harriman in a telegram dated April 15, 1936, “. . . to develop a method of lifting skiers 2,000 feet above the valley floor.” For America’s first ski resort — Idaho’s Sun Valley — Harriman wanted a new approach to moving skiers up the slopes that would be more comfortable than the pulls and hoists that had come before. So he posed the problem to his staff at the Union Pacific office in Omaha.

headline: Reply All: The 2.9.14 Issue
text: SEXLESS BUT EQUAL

headline: Red(dit) Alert at the Workplace!
text: I recently realized a colleague posts several times a day to the website Reddit. If the opinions he shares on this site are about his boss or his work environment (or even reveal his political leanings), he could potentially lose his current contract and have a hard time getting a new position in our insular field. I find this colleague to be immature and ill suited for our profession — he seems to spend most of the day posting on Reddit — and some of his posts have made his identity obvious to me. Do I have an ethical obligation to tell him that this behavior could hurt his career? NAME WITHHELD, PENNSYLVANIA

headline: David J. Hand’s Lottery Tips
text: Your latest book, “The Improbability Principle,” aims to prove that extremely improbable events are in fact commonplace. Can you explain that a bit?  Things like roulette wheels coming up in strange configurations or the same lottery numbers hitting two weeks in a row are clearly very rare events, but if you look at the number of lotteries and the number of roulette wheels, then you realize that you should actually expect these sorts of things to happen. I think within the statistical community people accept this. They’re aware of the impact of the law of truly large numbers.

headline: Milan Fashion Week Street Style: Day 2
text: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC takes over our Instagram account for Milan Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

headline: Working to Block Those Advertising Annoyances
text: WITH so much attention to digital overload — too much email, too many photos on Facebook, too many mindless tweets — some of life’s biggest annoyances are still analog, especially when people want to sell you things.

headline: Inside the Fed’s 2008 Proceedings
text: On Friday, the Federal Reserve released the transcripts of its policy meetings of 2008, a year that began with little hint that a recession and a world financial crisis were unfolding. The transcripts provide new insights into the debates, miscalculations and actions of the Fed’s policy making council, the Federal Open Market Committee, in assessing and countering the crisis. In a running analysis of the documents, reporters for The New York Times shared their findings.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Canada Defeats United States in Men’s Hockey Semifinal
text: Canada defeated the United States, 1-0, in the semifinals of the men’s hockey tournament to advance to the gold medal game.

headline: That Sweet Lamb in Wolf’s Clothing
text: It seems likely that Leonardo DiCaprio will not win an Oscar next Sunday for his portrayal of the financial scam artist Jordan Belfort in “The Wolf of Wall Street.” As a rule, Academy voters prefer displays of suffering and stoicism in the face of adversity from leading men. Jordan’s brief sojourn in a country-club prison hardly qualifies; nor do the ill effects of too many quaaludes in the film’s most celebrated scene not involving cocaine and a prostitute’s rear end. And though Jordan gives up stock swindles for sales seminars, he can hardly be said to undergo the kind of redemption that the Academy likes to consecrate.

headline: Being Human Seems Enough
text: It was at the 2008 Venice Film Festival that Jennifer Lawrence — future Oscar winner, squirrel skinner, American warrior — signaled that she was no ordinary starlet. She wasn’t yet famous then, just a paparazzi afterthought to Charlize Theron, her co-star in “The Burning Plain,” one of those agonizingly dopey movies that play at major festivals because of their red-carpet power. During a pseudo-event for the movie, Ms. Theron spoke about the limited number of older actresses working in the industry and showered praise on another co-star, Kim Basinger, who wasn’t there. Ms. Lawrence apparently silenced the room by joking that Ms. Basinger had died. The girl can’t help it!

headline: Start-Up Disguises Wearable Tech as Jewelry
text: There are two broad strains of wearable technology emerging: the doo-dads that proclaim their techiness from the wrists, faces and other body parts that they are fastened to, and those that try to conceal that quality.

headline: Video and Tweets From Kiev’s Independence Square
text: This post will be updated as new information becomes available.

headline: New Yorker to Be Music Director of Phoenix Symphony
text: The Phoenix Symphony’s new music director is a native New Yorker who goes west by way of France: Tito Muñoz, who has led French orchestras in Lorraine and Nancy.

headline: Crossing a Divide, Seeking Good
text: As he does every year, David Wilson recently faced a decision about which documentary film to honor with a major prize in the True/False Film Fest, which he co-directs. And as he does each year, he reached out to the Dave Cover, a founding pastor of the Crossing, a 4,000-member Evangelical Presbyterian church in Columbia, Mo., to set up a screening of a candidate.

headline: Miscarriage, Superstition and the Jewish Baby Shower
text: No baby shower. No baby names. No nursery set up in the appropriate bedroom or apartment corner. That’s the common Jewish approach to pregnancy. The baby shower mishegas is an outright invitation to the evil eye to descend upon the unborn baby in vengeance for rubbing your happiness in others’ faces and “counting your chickens before they hatch.”

headline: Special Squalor
text: Within a five-day period in 1962, two reviews in The Times captured the variety of reaction to William S. Burroughs’s “Naked Lunch.” The book had appeared three years earlier in more lenient Paris; Charles Poore wrote that it arrived in the United States “already somewhat barnacled with notoriety and no doubt considered demi-passe in demi-avant-garde quadrangles.” Poore sniffed at the news that participants at an Edinburgh festival “pronounced it a work of considerable influence. This we can easily believe, in view of the more esoteric tendencies of current writing. The sad realm of squalor may look to it for, shall we say, inspiration.”

headline: Rural Life
text: OUT OF THE WOODS

headline: An Indian Appetizer, Subtly Spiced
text: NEW DELHI — Mumbai is one of cinema’s great divas. She storms onto the screen with blasts of color, noise and music. She can be beautiful, with ocean views and stunning tableaus. And she can be ugly, her slums among the world’s worst.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Blumarine Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: A World of Ties
text: Seigo Neckwear on Madison Avenue is a small boutique specializing in regular ties, bow ties and pocket squares.

headline: Image of the Day: February 21
text: An elderly farmer at a demonstration in New Delhi.

headline: Movie Review: 'Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me'
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me."

headline: Etro: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: Pledging a Fraternity of Silk
text: There is a certain kind of man who, even amid the sea of New York men in ties, can spot a fellow Seigo traveler. Yo-Yo Ma, Eliot Spitzer and select others — newscasters, doctors, lawyers — are members of this tacit clique, which extends well beyond the city limits. These ties that unite them come from Seigo Neckwear, and each one is the handiwork of Seigo Katsuragawa, the designer and proprietor, who cares for his creations deeply. “Each tie is our baby,” he said.

headline: Pharrell Williams Auctioning Grammy Hat for Charity
text: The Vivienne Westwood hat that earned Pharrell Williams a great deal of attention at the Grammy Awards last month is now for sale on eBay. With nine days to go, the high bid stood at $10,500 on Friday, with 64 bids so far. Proceeds are to benefit From One Hand to Another, a nonprofit that Mr. Williams founded in 2008 to support community centers and education.

headline: Movie Review: 'In Secret'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "In Secret."

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE HOUR OF PERIL: The Secret Plot to Murder Lincoln Before the Civil War,  by Daniel Stashower. (Minotaur, $16.99.) This is a swift and detailed rendering of the little-known Baltimore-based plot to assassinate Abraham Lincoln in February 1861, days before he assumed the presidency. Stashower’s narrative hurtles along Lincoln’s train route from Springfield, Ill., to Washington; standing tall among the conspirators and politicos is the “fierce and incorruptible lawman” Allan Pinkerton, who led efforts to thwart the scheme.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE SIXTH EXTINCTION: An Unnatural History,  by Elizabeth Kolbert. (Holt, $28.) A powerful examination of the role of man-made climate change in causing the current spasm of plant and animal loss that threatens the planet.

headline: Out of Character
text: Before you dismiss B. J. Novak’s debut fiction collection, “One More Thing,” as the latest example of a Hollywood actor’s trespassing into the far more glamorous and affluent gated community of short stories, read his humor piece “If I Had a Nickel.”

headline: ‘A Guest of My Time’
text: “All conservatism begins with loss,” Andrew Sullivan writes. “If we never knew loss, we would never feel the need to conserve.” That’s why the first and still canonical conservative text is Edmund Burke’s “Reflections on the Revolution in France,” a lamentation on the uprooting of that country’s monarchical order. And that’s why America, as an experiment in modernity, hasn’t had many genuine conservatives in its history.

headline: Monument Man
text: No president has written as well as Abraham Lincoln. He could thrill, reason, prophesy, mourn and crack jokes. Who wouldn’t want to read a book in his own words — all the more enticing if it scanted the political and administrative minutiae that fill his collected works and gave us a window into his inner life?

headline: Poet of the Caribbean
text: “Writing poetry is an unnatural act,” Elizabeth Bishop once wrote. “It takes skill to make it seem natural.” The thought is kin to the one John Keats expressed in an 1818 letter to his friend John Taylor: “If Poetry comes not as naturally as the Leaves to a tree it had better not come at all.” Bishop and Keats both evoked a double sense of “natural”: that which is concerned with nature, with landscape, flora and fauna, and that which is unforced and fluent. In both senses, Derek Walcott is a natural poet.

headline: The Rage in Harlem
text: One of the milestones of modernism occurred in Paris on May 29, 1913, when “The Rite of Spring” debuted at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées and almost caused a riot. Startled by Stravinsky’s pounding rhythms and Nijinsky’s salacious choreography, the well-heeled philistines in the audience roared with disapproval while the connoisseurs, the happy few, tried shouting them down. One of the most memorable accounts of that first night was written by the American critic Carl Van Vechten, who allied himself decidedly with the latter camp, reporting that a kindred soul in the seat behind him was so carried away that he began beating a tattoo on the critic’s head with his fists. “My emotion was so great,” Van Vechten wrote, “that I did not feel the blows for some time.” Sharing his box was another pillar of the avant-garde, Gertrude Stein, who remembered certain details differently — as well she should, Van Vechten assured her. They had actually attended the less eventful second night of the ballet, but, as he suavely added, “one must only be accurate about such details in a work of fiction.”

headline: King of Cool
text: William S. Burroughs “didn’t say anything for shock value,” his student Sam Kashner once observed. “His life had shock value.”

headline: The Last Trial
text: In Jay Cantor’s 1988 novel, “Krazy Kat,” the feline heroine praises Rube Goldberg contraptions: “Krazy liked having her mind pulled through one of Goldberg’s gadgets. He was a real artist; he had a vision.” Cantor’s vision often fo­cuses on public figures: George Herriman’s cartoon cat and J. Robert Oppenheimer; Che Guevara in Cantor’s first novel, “The Death of Che Guevara”; and now Kafka in “Forgiving the Angel.” These works and his graphic novel, “Aaron and Ahmed,” are contraptions of mixed materials: animal and human characters in “Krazy Kat,” fact and invention in “Che Guevara,” lucid writing and hallucinatory illustrations (by James Romberger) in “Aaron and Ahmed,” and now a story putatively by Kafka and stories about contemporaries who loved him. All of Cantor’s fiction (including “Great Neck,” his un-­gadgety novel of the American 1960s and ’70s) pulls the reader’s mind through sensitive history: atom bomb tests at Alamogordo; the Cuban revolution; the events of 9/11; and, in “Forgiving the Angel,” Stalin’s gulag and Hitler’s death camps.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Omar,’ ‘Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me’ and ‘In Secret’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Omar,” “Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me” and “In Secret.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: A Singular Ballerina’s Multiple Paths
text: The dancer Misty Copeland has performed with the singer Prince and the pop group TLC. She has appeared in commercials for Diet Dr Pepper and Coach handbags, is national youth of the year ambassador for Boys & Girls Clubs of America and has a contract with the Under Armour sports clothing brand. She has her own dance wear line, and next month Simon & Schuster will publish her memoir, “Life in Motion: An Unlikely Ballerina.”

headline: Lundqvist and Sweden Return to Gold Medal Game
text: SOCHI, Russia — In 2006, Henrik Lundqvist was a 23-year-old rookie for the Rangers who went to the Turin Games motivated to win a gold medal for the older players on the Swedish team that he grew up idolizing.

headline: Garrick Utley, a Mainstay at NBC News, Dies at 74
text: Garrick Utley, a former anchor for NBC News who for many years was one of a rare breed in television news reporting, a full-time foreign correspondent, died Thursday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: “Out of the Black” featuring Robyn
text: A single from Neneh Cherry’s new album, “The Blank Project.”

headline: ‘All Is Lost’s’ 2 Crucial Characters: Redford and That Boat
text: Sound design is one of the technical aspects of filmmaking that may be the most mystifying to non-filmmakers; at the very least, sound editing and mixing are the categories that will probably cause you to lose your office Oscar pool.

headline: Ole Miss Students May Face Charges in Racist Episode
text: OXFORD, Miss. — The University of Mississippi said Friday that students could face criminal charges for placing a noose on a statue honoring the college’s first black student, and a fraternity announced that it had expelled three men because of the incident.

headline: The Sounds of Things Ending, Continuing and Reshaping
text: Neneh Cherry

headline: Inside the List
text: The Contender: Martin Sixsmith’s book “Philomena” was originally published in 2009, under the title “The Lost Child of Philomena Lee.” But once the movie version appeared last year, with its sleeker name and attention-­grabbing story of a single mother forced by nuns to give up her child for adoption, Sixsmith’s publishers retitled the book in a successful effort to cash in: Last week, “Philomena” was No. 17 in its fifth week on the paperback nonfiction list.

headline: Movie Review: 'Omar'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Omar."

headline: The Marxist Dalai Lama Visits a Washington Shrine to Free Markets
text: The Dalai Lama, who has said, “Deep inside, as far as social economic theory is concerned, I am a Marxist,” spent Thursday morning speaking on two panels at a Washington shrine to free markets and limited government — the American Enterprise Institute.

headline: From Johnny Weir’s Team, a Fresh Voice for NBC
text: NBC’s deployment of two figure skating announcing teams for the Sochi Games creates an opportunity to compare how each performed at an important moment.

headline: Getting Together to Say Goodbye
text: Vivian Girls died so that Williamsburg could ... live? Die? Get really into dance music? For a time, it was the most exciting band in the city, and then, in the way the city squashes all good things, it was a band in pieces. Its legacy: three albums of dirty lite-garage-rock with strong instinctual melodies, some EPs and singles, a warp-speed tour through the Internet’s hype cycle — and a mention in a “Jeopardy” clue.

headline: Kentucky Challenger Sets Sights on Senate G.O.P. Heavyweight
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Alison Lundergan Grimes leaned across a table at an upscale bar near her home in this city’s historic district, sipped Maker’s Mark bourbon — a Kentucky staple — mixed with Diet Coke, and let out a belly laugh. “We’re in this campaign to kick butt!” she said.

headline: Son of Robert Johnson to Retain Photograph Rights
text: The Mississippi Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the son of the Delta blues musician Robert Johnson retains the rights to the only two known photographs of his father and the profits from those pictures, The Associated Press reported.

headline: When Muscle Meets Tension
text: “In all of us there’s that little monster inside that comes out to play when the time is right,” says Cobra Rhodes, a trained chef and Zen master. “When it happens, it’s pretty intense. You’re trying to impose on someone, and they have other ideas. Someone’s going to eat, and someone’s not. Arm wrestling is when my monster comes out.” Mr. Rhodes, a world champion arm wrestler on the Rolling Thunder team of Kansas City, Mo., is one of the incredible hulks on view in “Game of Arms,” to have its premiere Tuesday at 10 p.m. on AMC.

headline: Tales of Vienna (With Coquette)
text: Hot on the heels of the Met’s recent production of Johann Strauss Jr.’s comic opera “Die Fledermaus” comes Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger’s “Oh ... Rosalinda!!” (1955), an adaptation of the same material, playing March 1 at the Museum of Modern Art as part of Vienna Unveiled: A City in Cinema. The program, which marks the 50th anniversary of the Austrian Film Museum, runs from Friday through April 20 and spotlights some 70 movies pertaining to that city by the likes of Max Ophuls, Erich von Stroheim, Billy Wilder, Ernst Lubitsch, Michael Haneke, Carol Reed and Richard Linklater.

headline: A Little Sizzle for a Cold City
text: When will it stop snowing? No, seriously: When? Brazil sounds good right about now, and a holiday in the theater is better than none. Starting Wednesday, the Joyce hosts a showcase of Brazilian dance starting with Mimulus Companhia de Dança’s take on the darkly humorous films of the Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar in “Dolores,” created by the artistic director, Jomar Mesquita, and company members.

headline: Protests Swell in Venezuela
text: In February, Venezuela was convulsed by the biggest protests since the country’s longtime president, the charismatic Hugo Chávez, died 11 months earlier.

headline: Still Rebels, Even as Maturity Looms
text: Interviewing Calle 13, the firebrand Puerto Rican hip-hop duo, involved a little 21st-century technology. René Pérez Joglar, the rapper who calls himself Residente, was at Electric Lady Studios in Greenwich Village, where Calle 13’s new album, “Multi_Viral,” was being mixed. Residente’s stepbrother and partner in Calle 13, Eduardo Cabra Martínez, the producer and musician who calls himself Visitante, was on a tablet screen in a Skype window, speaking from his studio, Música Satánica, in San Juan.

headline: Filling a Museum With Baroque Art
text: The charismatic French countertenor Philippe Jaroussky has recently released a disc of arias written by the Baroque composer Porpora for Farinelli, his student and a famous castrato. Sparks should fly on Tuesday, when Mr. Jaroussky joins the Venice Baroque Orchestra and the conductor Andrea Marcon to perform selections from the disc; the ensemble will also offer works by Vivaldi and Geminiani. (7 p.m., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 212-570-3949, metmuseum.org/tickets.)

headline: Many Losses, and Fans, Surround Yeshiva Coach’s Departure
text: Jonathan Halpert has coached at Yeshiva University for 42 years, the longest tenure of any men’s basketball coach in New York City history. But even Division III Yeshiva, which has not had a winning season since 2007, is not immune to the pressures that much larger N.C.A.A. institutions face.

headline: Piecing Together Dream Fragments
text: Laure Prouvost, born in France in 1978 and now living in London, was the dark-horse winner of the 2013 Turner Prize, but she is still something of a mystery in New York. And for all the right reasons, her solo show at the New Museum lets the mystery be. Multimedia is her form: The New Museum installation combines video, painting, drawing, sculpture and found objects. Narrative is her mode.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: George F. Kennan’s Diaries
text: This week, Fareed Zakaria talks about “The Kennan Diaries”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Jodi Kantor discusses “HRC”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Making Antifreeze Less Deadly for Pets, and People
text: Toxicologists have long considered ethylene glycol, the active ingredient in many antifreeze and engine coolant formulas, to be a seductive and uniquely dangerous poison.

headline: How Do You Like These Apples?
text: When I was in France late last fall, every time I went to the market I was reminded of what an integral part apples play in everyday cooking in that country. This is especially true in fall and winter, when shoppers buy them by the kilo to use for compotes, pies, cakes, savory dishes and salads. Bakers in Normandy, the region of apples, even work them into rustic country breads.

headline: Mayor Do as I Say
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio gave an impassioned presentation about traffic safety on Tuesday. On Thursday, under the immutable law of political comeuppance, he got busted by a TV news crew that caught his two-S.U.V. detail rolling through stop signs, changing lanes without signaling and barreling down the highway over the speed limit.

headline: Protest All You Want, but It’ll Cost You
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — When the coach of the Canadian women’s snowboarding team gathers his belongings each morning, he makes sure he has his hat, his sunglasses, his cellphone and 100 Swiss francs.

headline: German Biathlete and Italian Bobsledder Fail Doping Tests
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A German biathlete and an Italian bobsledder were kicked out of the Olympics Friday for doping, the first known violations of the Sochi Games.

headline: Four Decades of Preservation
text: Although the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was once considered among the nation’s most devastated neighborhoods, efforts to preserve its resplendent Victorian architecture have been pursued energetically for more than four decades.

headline: Argument Over a Brownstone Neighborhood
text: Most people would agree that the brownstones and small apartment buildings nestled in the southwest corner of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, are for the most part drop-dead gorgeous. The 800 largely intact residential buildings, representing Italianate, Queen Anne, Romanesque Revival and Renaissance Revival styles, are executed in rich rusts, browns and terra cottas, and adorned with gracious bowed windows, generously proportioned stoops and adorable little turrets. The result, in the opinion of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, is “an extraordinary well-preserved late-19th-century streetscape.”

headline: Toledo Museum Announces Review of Items Received From Suspect Dealer
text: The Toledo Museum of Art has announced that it is reviewing the legality of 64 Indian artifacts it obtained from Subhash Kapoor, a former Madison Avenue art dealer who is accused by United States officials of operating one of the largest antiquities smuggling rings uncovered on American soil.

text: One of the first questions you confront in any five-borough conversation is, “Where do you live?”

headline: The Fed’s Actions in 2008: What the Transcripts Reveal
text: On Feb. 22, the Federal Reserve released the transcripts of the 2008 meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy. The transcripts provide a detailed account of some of the Fed’s key decisions during that crisis year.

headline: Attack on Presidential Palace in Somalia
text: A militant Somali group, the Shabab, claimed responsibility for a deadly attack in Mogadishu, the capital, in which militants blasted through a gate and fought a gun battle with guards.

headline: Accord Signed in Ukraine
text: Opposition leaders and President Viktor F. Yanukovych signed an agreement on Friday to try to defuse a deadly political crisis that has left scores of protesters and security officers dead or wounded.

headline: Listen Up | Neneh Cherry Makes a Cathartic Comeback
text: It’s been 18 years since Neneh Cherry released her last solo album. During that time, she’s been highly productive: she’s worked as a D.J. around Europe; formed a band, cirKus, with her husband and daughter; had guest spots on countless other records; co-hosted a cooking series on BBC Two and focused on raising her three children. It was the pain of loss, however, that brought her back to the spotlight. When her mother, the Swedish painter and textile artist Monica Karlsson (known as Moki), passed away in 2009, Cherry began to write in a journal, documenting dark emotional recesses she hadn’t previously explored. Her entries became the basis for “The Blank Project,” a soulful new album that’s danceable, but comes from the deep.

headline: Federal Reserve 2008 Transcripts
text: The Federal Reserve released the transcripts of the 2008 meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy.

headline: China Criticizes Obama Over Visit by Dalai Lama
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama welcomed the Dalai Lama to the White House on Friday morning, provoking a sharp rebuke from the Chinese government, which warned that the meeting would severely damage relations between Washington and Beijing.

headline: Basque Group Is Said to Disable Some of Its Arms
text: MADRID — ETA, the Basque separatist group, has disabled some of the weapons that allowed it to wage a lengthy terrorist campaign for independence that has killed more than 800 people, an international verification commission said Friday.

headline: Disclosure Statement for the City of Detroit
text: This is a detailed description of how Detroit intends to repay its creditors and how it aims to restore the city to health, including by lowering police-response time, restoring streetlights and renewing blighted neighborhoods.

headline: A Translator of Blueprints
text: When “60 Minutes,” the CBS News show, secured an exclusive interview with a member of the Navy SEAL team that killed Osama bin Laden, one of the first things it did was search for a model maker who could replicate the compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan.

headline: Stained Gold Can Help Clean Up System
text: SOCHI, Russia — Adelina Sotnikova of Russia is a 17-year-old with a teenager’s insatiable appetite. She sees her Olympic gold medal as a mere appetizer on figure skating’s endless buffet.

headline: Semper Opera Severs Ties With Appointed General Manager
text: BERLIN — Just months before he was supposed to take over as the general manager of the Semper Opera in Dresden, Germany, cultural authorities have severed their contract with Serge Dorny, citing a climate of mistrust.

headline: Barnes & Noble Receives Conditional Offer
text: G Asset Management, a little-known investment firm, offered on Thursday to acquire 51 percent of Barnes & Noble in a deal that would value the bookseller’s shares at $22 apiece.

headline: On a Caribbean Rum Trail
text: “Care to kiss the ground?”

headline: Back to Borneo, and an Eden at Risk
text: There are no roads to the village of Pa Lungan, just a mucky water buffalo trail beneath a tight-knit canopy — among the last standing highland jungles on the island of Borneo. In spots, the trail is more swamp than path. But that does not mean all is quiet: The rain forest is a cacophonous place. Cicadas squeal and monkeys hoot as they romp through the trees. Bamboo creaks in the breeze as its stalks grind and rub in a primitive dance.

headline: N.F.L. Combine Camp
text: At Prolific Athletes in Carlsbad, Calif., Ryan Flaherty uses the latest exercise science to prepare N.F.L. draft prospects like Johnny Manziel, Mike Evans and Logan Thomas for the combine test.

headline: 7 Years Before Recall, Crash Investigator Raised Concern Over Switched-Off G.M. Air Bags
text: In 2007, about seven years before General Motors’ recent recall of 778,000 small cars because a jolt or a heavy key ring could turn off the engine and disable the air bags, an investigator for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration raised the possibility of such danger after researching a crash that had killed two teenagers.

headline: Volkswagen Offers to Buy Rest of Swedish Truck Maker for $9.2 Billion
text: LONDON — Volkswagen said late Friday that it had made an offer to acquire the outstanding shares of the Swedish truck maker Scania it doesn’t already own for 6.7 billion euros, or about $9.2 billion.

headline: Speed Coach Prepares N.F.L. Prospects for Combine
text: CARLSBAD, Calif. — Mike Evans, a former star receiver at Texas A&M, crouched in a three-point stance in shorts and a T-shirt and then bolted down a soccer field as a high-speed camera recorded every step. Evans was here not to catch footballs or to practice dodging defenders, but to hone his technique for the 40-yard dash.

headline: Calle 13 Goes ‘Multi_Viral’
text: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss Calle 13, the political hip-hop and reggaeton band from San Juan, Puerto Rico, and it’s new album, “Multi_Viral.”

headline: France Honors Two Women With Burial in the Panthéon
text: PARIS — President François Hollande, who had been strongly urged for more than a year to add more women to those awarded the honor of burial in the Panthéon, named two women on Friday — but also two men.

headline: Is There Any Escape From ‘Recommended for You’?
text: Based on what The New York Times thinks I’m interested in reading, I am not a fun person.

headline: Aching Canada Hands United States a Stinging Loss
text: SOCHI, Russia — From the twin beds in the athletes’ village to the cramped competition schedule, the Olympics are not a comfortable fit for N.H.L. players. Crossing the globe to play five games in nine days, as the semifinalists United States and Canada did, is a prescription for insomnia at best and injury at worst.

headline: Popcast: Calle 13 Goes ‘Multi_Viral’
text: Calle 13, from San Juan, Puerto Rico, led by the stepbrothers René Pérez Joglar and Eduardo Cabra Martínez, is a hip-hop and reggaeton band, but not only that; it’s a political band, but not only that; it’s a band that’s heading toward fatherhood and middle age, but not only that.

text: What does the current uprising and subsequent bloodshed in Ukraine have to do with gun rights in America? Plenty, say Second Amendment advocates.

headline: Light in Her Heart and on Her Feet
text: Even as a little girl, Kristen Schulte was serious, shy and driven to succeed. She was an honors student and the star sweeper on her high school soccer team in Ewing Township, N.J. She made lists of tasks and arrived on time for appointments.

headline: Better Than a Credit Card
text: Every time we read or hear about older adults victimized by scams on the phone, scams on the street, thefts in senior residences or attacks via the Internet, we wince.

headline: Want a Flight Upgrade? Schmooze the Crew
text: As part of the magazine’s Voyages issue, Paul Mallatt, a flight attendant and 30-year veteran of the airline industry, explains how to earn an upgrade without paying extra.

text: It might have been little more than a tabloid curiosity: A married New York investment banker has a child with a woman in Austin, Tex., and the couple goes through a breakup.

headline: Lesson for de Blasio as His S.U.V. Breaks Rules of the Road
text: Political scandals can be complicated. Kickbacks are hard to explain, pay to play is rarely black and white, even elaborate frauds seldom boil down to a sentence or two.

headline: Corbat Receives a 23% Pay Raise at Citigroup
text: Michael Corbat, the chief executive of Citigroup, received a 23 percent increase in compensation for 2013, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday.

text: A closer look at the Palestinian thriller “Omar,” an Oscar nominee for best foreign language film.

headline: Making an Android Tablet Easier to Read
text: Q. The seven-inch Nexus tablet itself is just big enough, but I find the type too small. Is it possible to increase the size of the text on the screen?

headline: Bermuda Court Rules in Dispute Over Lucerne Opera House
text: It is one of the most closely watched disputes in the world of classical music: a lawsuit filed by a group including officials of the Lucerne Festival to compel a Bermuda-based trust to honor the pledge of a philanthropist who had offered to donate more than $130 million to build a new opera house in Lucerne, but who died before the money was paid.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Sportmax Fall/Winter 2014
