text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Weekend Reading: Which Technology Pundit Are You?
text: Facebook’s $16 billion bid for the text messaging application WhatsApp has captured everyone’s attention. Is it a sign that the tech bubble is about to burst or is it a savvy move to cement the future of the social media giant?

headline: Versace: A Bias Toward Beauty
text: MILAN — “I wanted to clean up what is not necessary,” said Donatella Versace — usually a designer who likes at least a flourish and prefers lavish excess.

headline: The Jury Pool Wrangler
text: At 9 a.m. sharp on Wednesday, a door opened in the front of the central jury room in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, and an impeccably dressed man walked in and sat alone at a broad lectern.

headline: House Republicans in Texas Donate to Protect One of Their Own
text: One of the surest signs that an incumbent is concerned about re-election is the amount of money that other lawmakers send his way.

headline: Meat and Potato Skillet Gratin
text: Melissa Clark transforms two cold-weather favorites into a single luscious, flavor-layered meal.

headline: Should Obesity Be a ‘Disease’?
text: IN June 2013, millions of Americans contracted a disease. They developed it not because of some pathogen or illness, but thanks to the American Medical Association’s decision to label obesity a “multi-metabolic and hormonal disease state.”

headline: An Artful Bike Path to the Armory Show
text: Enjoy looking at art? How about riding it? The opportunity will be available next month when the Armory Show art fair teams up with Citi Bike to offer 10 art-adorned bicycles for the duration of the Armory’s annual art fair, March 6-9 at Piers 92 and 94.

headline: Rich Comfort Food to the Extreme
text: The colder the weather, the more rich and hearty the meals you can justify eating. And this is why, ever since the polar vortex forced me to layer on two down coats before leaving the house, I’ve craved the likes of potato gratin and shepherd’s pie.

headline: A Surprise Guest at the S.E.C.’s Annual Gathering
text: WASHINGTON — In a room overflowing with suited lawyers scribbling handwritten notes, the man live tweeting in a hooded sweatshirt stood out.

headline: A Bonus Is Declined; a Problem Remains
text: When IBM reported fourth-quarter and full-year earnings a few weeks ago, they could have been an excuse for popping champagne corks in the executive suite.

headline: How the Fed Saw a Recession, Then Didn’t, Then Did
text: Federal Reserve officials went back and forth on whether the economy was in a recession in 2008.

headline: The Dream of Moving Abroad in Later Life, With Good Health Care
text: FOR the well-traveled, the idea of retirement abroad can seem an idyll. You pick a place you’ve loved visiting, whether it’s the thrumming avenues of Paris or the sunny strands of Panama, and jet off for the perfect permanent vacation.

headline: Exploring a World of Animals
text: Dinaw Mengestu, 35, has racked up a list of enviable accomplishments. He is a highly acclaimed novelist. He was a recipient of a MacArthur “genius” grant in 2012. The New Yorker named him one of its “20 Under 40” writers in 2010. And on Sundays, he says, he makes a mean roast chicken. “All Our Names,” the third novel by Mr. Mengestu, who was born in Ethiopia and raised in Illinois, is being published next month by Knopf. Mr. Mengestu lives in West Harlem with his wife, Anne-Emanuelle Mengestu, 41, and their sons, Gabriel, 4, and Luis-Selassie, 3.

headline: Haters Going to Hate, Research Suggests
text: Not only is it lonely at the top, but a paper by two business professors suggests that, at least for literary prize winners, the view can get a little ugly, too. The study, by Balazs Kovacs of the University of Lugano and Amanda Sharkey of the University of Chicago, compared online reader reviews for 32 pairs of books that either won or were nominated for a major literary prize. They found that winning a prestigious award not only garners more attention for a book, but also more negative reviews.

headline: To Warm Two Hearts That Beat as One
text: When shopping for wedding gifts, think about the couples’ comfort during the next big chill.

headline: A Tenor Finds Energy for Intense, Lyrical Pain
text: Most tenors, after singing the challenging title role of Massenet’s “Werther,” especially for the high-pressured opening night of a new production at the Metropolitan Opera, would welcome a few days of rest.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 21
text: Canada defeated the U.S. in a men’s hockey semifinal and Mikaela Shiffrin of the United States won the women’s slalom.

headline: Versace: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: Cacophony Amid the Cool Marble
text: For a dancer turned choreographer, there are pros and cons to having danced for someone as famous as Mark Morris for 14 years. The label “former Mark Morris dancer” will trail you for a long time as you try to chart your own creative path. On the upside, though, your former boss is very well connected.

headline: Sills Award Goes to a Rising Tenor
text: Michael Fabiano, a 29-year-old tenor from Montclair, N.J., has been given the Beverly Sills Artist Award for young singers, the Metropolitan Opera announced on Friday. The $50,000 award honors singers between the ages of 25 and 40 who have had featured roles at the Met.

headline: A Celebration of Sandhill Cranes in Nebraska
text: From February to April, more than half a million sandhill cranes and millions of waterfowl will make their way to central Nebraska as a part of their yearly migration north.

headline: Emulating a Model Communist Through Cosmetic Surgery
text: For the poor, the homeless, people down on their luck in the central province of Anhui, Zhang Yidong has often been there to help. He has made a career of raising money and public interest to help the downtrodden.

headline: Big Ticket | Sweeping Views for $17.8 Million
text: A corner unit in the 35-story limestone tower portion of 15 Central Park West, the address where units perform like blue chip stock on the resale market, sold for $17.8 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘Her’
text: Working in a screen trade was a no-brainer for Casey Storm, who grew up on the sets of television shows of “Laverne and Shirley” and “Mork and Mindy,” watching his father, the prolific director Howard Storm, at work. “My parents, their friends were all involved,” he said, so it was obvious that he would be too.

headline: The Online Challenge for Banking
text: Francisco González, chairman of BBVA, recently said that banks needed to take on Amazon and Google or die. He aims to be one of the survivors.

headline: First Time’s the Charm With Fresh Pita
text: I’m giving you a great recipe for a kind of rustic homemade hummus. And I’m going to tell you how to make your own pita bread at home.

headline: Prince William’s Ivory Intolerance, The Newest Kardashian Kids and Cara Delevingne’s Designs for Mulberry
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Review: 2014 BMW 428i
text: The new BMW 428i coupe is one better than the 3 Series sedan. Thank a sleek design and a lower center of gravity.

headline: A Daughter’s Loyalty Shines Through Song
text: Deep into Jonatha Brooke’s solo theater piece the other night, a gentle wave of sniffles swelled through the audience at the Duke on 42nd Street, where a daughter’s love and loyalty were on tender display.

headline: Women as Bosses Still Face Bias
text: Marissa Mayer. Indra Nooyi. Virginia Rometty. Mary T. Barra.

headline: Oprah Winfrey, the Comfort Queen
text: WHO Oprah Winfrey

headline: Oprah Winfrey’s Style
text: Ms. Winfrey’s red carpet style is all about comfort.

headline: Greenwich Village Condo: A Nod to the Past
text: Greenwich Village is known for its corner cafes and doglegs of streets. But in recent years, it’s been associated with something that doesn’t wind up in too many guidebooks: divisive development projects.

headline: At Private Schools, Another Way to Say ‘Financial Aid’
text: SHANNON LUBIANO never dreamed she could send her children to the Duke School, an independent elementary school in Durham, N.C., where the tuition is $15,000 for prekindergarten, rising to nearly $18,000 for eighth grade.

headline: Just Adding a ‘1’ Alters the Equation
text: If two heads are better than one, and four of a kind beats three, BMW’s naming strategy makes perfect sense.

headline: One Step Up
text: While some rivals have closed the performance gap, the 4 Series is another reminder that BMW still knows how to make a fast, hugely entertaining car.

headline: Get Your $50,000 Hatchback Here
text: TESTED 2014 BMW 335i Gran Turismo

headline: In a Dark Year, a Lighter Side at the Fed
text: The Federal Reserve’s 2008 transcripts are shot through with dark and corny — very dark, and very corny — humor.

headline: Olympians Stand Tall in Their Onesies
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The German bobsledders had a day off before their competition began, so they decided to go shopping in the charming Alpine village that has sprouted in the mountains above Sochi.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Chad, Afghanistan and Sochi, Russia. More images from the Winter Olympics here.

headline: Credit Suisse Admits Guilt in Settling With S.E.C.
text: Updated, 8:49 p.m. | Credit Suisse on Friday became the latest big bank to admit wrongdoing to the Securities and Exchange Commission, striking a deal over its failure to comply with a cardinal rule of the financial industry.

headline: With Some Selfies, the Uglier the Better
text: Thirteen-year-old Ruby Karp was sitting in a dark corner of a coffee shop on the Upper West Side, angling a glowing iPhone underneath her chin. She scrunched up her face and tilted her head downward.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Moschino’s Tomboy Tresses
text: Despite the loud pop-culture references in Jeremy Scott’s first Moschino collection — strewn with McDonald’s, SpongeBob SquarePants and candy bar insignia — hair and makeup felt fairly down-to-earth. Backstage at yesterday’s show, the makeup artist Lucia Pieroni explained the inspiration for the “gorgeous, tomboyish” look. “It’s a Linda Evangelista kind, with very boyish eyebrows, brushed up to make them strong,” she said, adding that the flawless finish on the skin was inspired by Peter Lindbergh’s photography. To achieve the milky complexions, Pieroni stuck to the basics: a light foundation base, cream color on the eyes for a bit of shine and nude M.A.C. lipsticks that ranged from peachy and pink to soft shades of mocha. And on top of all those neutral faces, Paul Hanlon’s shaggy, pixie-cut wigs lent just enough attitude to the models as they walked past the front row, from which a very happy Katy Perry cheered them along.

headline: Fitbit Recalls Force Device After Complaints of Rashes
text: Fitbit said on Friday that it was issuing a voluntary recall for the Fitbit Force wrist-worn fitness tracker and would stop selling the device immediately after determining that the device caused serious skin irritation for some users.

headline: Casting Shadows on ‘Ice Cream Castles in the Air and Feather Canyons Everywhere’
text: An actor first, and a singer second: that was how Jessica Molaskey described herself during her enthralling Thursday evening concert of Joni Mitchell songs, “Portraits of Joni: Jessica Molaskey Sings Joni Mitchell,” at the Allen Room, presented as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.

headline: How Mikaela Shiffrin Won the Slalom
text: Looking powerful and poised, the 18-year-old American dominated the first run and hung on in the second to pick up the gold medal.

headline: Descents Into Sounds Of Dementia and War
text: Discerning the correlation between a composer’s description of a new piece and its actual sound is not always easy. But there was no such ambiguity in “Vera’s Ghosts” by Lisa Renée Coons, which received its premiere on Thursday evening at Zankel Hall by the American Composers Orchestra, conducted by George Manahan.

headline: Plan to Limit Some Drugs in Medicare Is Criticized
text: An alliance of drug companies and patient advocates, joined by Democrats and Republicans in Congress, is fiercely opposing an Obama administration proposal that would allow insurers to limit Medicare coverage for certain classes of drugs, including those used to treat depression and schizophrenia.

headline: Philharmonic Clarinetist to Return to Chicago Symphony
text: It seemed as if the New York Philharmonic had successfully poached some talent from the competition last year when it announced it had lured Stephen Williamson away from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra to be its new principal clarinet player. But Mr. Williamson remained technically on a leave of absence, and on Friday he announced that he would be taking his woodwind back to Chicago next season.

headline: Semifinals of the District 24 Grand National
text: One team in the semifinals of the District 24 (New York City and Long Island) Grand National Teams qualifying event is Kelley Hwang, Michael Kopera, Michael Lipkin and Michael Radin, all of New York City.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Tod’s Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: In Drag, It Turns Out, There Are Second Acts
text: LOS ANGELES — RuPaul Charles zoomed down Sunset Boulevard in a 1979 red Volvo he inherited from his mother. He wore a pinstripe suit and an open-collar shirt revealing a wedge of shaved chest.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s On the Market properties in New York City include a two-bedroom loft in Greenwich Village; a hotel-like studio in Lincoln Square; and a Downtown Brooklyn condo corner unit.

headline: Brooklyn on the Spree
text: BERLIN — “The music reminds me of Brooklyn!” said Winston Chmielinski, a 25-year-old painter who moved here from New York last year. Like one of the cranes hanging over the city but never managing to create a skyline, he was dancing with outstretched arms, lowering and raising himself at the Panorama Bar, the upstairs dance floor at Berghain, a popular club.

headline: Leaders in Supporting Roles
text: LOS ANGELES — Forget the celebrity stylists. That persnickety bunch tends to a handful of the highest-wattage Oscar contenders. There are 203 nominees this year.

headline: Cost $1,000, Sold for $21 Million
text: The bull market in vintage racing cars recently gained an eye-opening data point: A 1958 Ferrari 335S that had been bailed out of a United States Customs warehouse in New York for $1,000 in 1963 was sold for $21.5 million in a private transaction to an Austrian collector, Andreas Mohringer.

headline: A Stable Full of Thoroughbreds
text: Found among the holdings of collectors — any of the millions of enthusiasts who accumulate stamps, coins, autographed baseballs, ticket stubs, anything from bottle caps to Rembrandts — are both the detritus of civilization and the objects that recall its finest hours.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Unbuttoned
text: The nonchalant style of coats worn wide open on the coldest days was popular during New York Fashion Week (when daytime temperatures were in the 20s).

headline: A Singular Obsession, Ranging Far and Wide
text: Sam Mann, a New Jersey industrial designer, has a collection that reflects everything from his background as an engineer to his fascination with the dirt-track competitors of his youth.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: Lighting systems that watch and gather data, conversations inside the Federal Reserve during the financial crisis and a new wave of mortgage problems for homeowners.

headline: The Music of Fire, Stars, Tears and Light
text: “I feel so lonesome I could cry,” Angel Olsen sings at the beginning of “Hi-Five.” And sure, she sounds the part — ravaged, tense, dark, history-minded.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Unbuttoned
text: The nonchalant style of coats worn wide open on the coldest days was popular during New York Fashion Week (when daytime temperatures were in the 20s). This vanity dates from 1940s Hollywood stars, who wore their coats on their shoulders. A few women left their coats in chauffeured cars, expecting to rush into a runway show — only to wait in the freezing cold. Tourists (above) were buttoned up to the chin. Near right: another laugh-at-the-cold look, shredded jeans, resembled icicles.

headline: Evening Hours | On the Catwalks
text: Fashion Week took us from heaven to earth, and then to church.

headline: Adventure With an Italian Accent
text: LAS VEGAS — No international motorcycle manufacturer, it seems, can afford to be without an adventure-touring offering — and an attendant line of high-couture color-coordinated rider apparel — in its lineup.

headline: The Magnetic Pull of Touching, and Not Touching
text: Tao Ye doesn’t think in terms of Eastern or Western where his art is concerned. This Chinese choreographer, who formed his company in Beijing in 2008, avoids such categorical boxes; his dances, he believes, should stand on their own, and they do, with a quiet, dazzling resolve.

headline: Sculptural Slip-Ons at Tod’s
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Fannie Mae Posts Profit That Sets a Record
text: The mortgage giant Fannie Mae passed a symbolic milestone at the end of the fourth quarter, generating profits that will push its total payments to the federal government higher than the amount it received in the 2008 bailout, the company reported Friday.

headline: Times Minute | Preps and Superstitions
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Preps and Superstitions
text: Whether it's the N.F.L. scouting combine or luck at the Olympics, a look at how athletes prep. Also on the Minute, 2008 Fed transcripts reveal Janet Yellen's actions before she was chairwoman.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: This week’s On the Market homes in the New York region include a six-bedroom home on 1.27 acres in Colts Neck, N.J., and a five-bedroom home with a separate 1,000-square-foot artist’s studio in Sea Cliff, Long Island.

headline: A ‘House of Cards’ Binge Takes Its Toll
text: As last weekend approached, I was astonished to hear how many people were planning on binge watching Netflix’s “House of Cards.” I had dismissed the show the very first episode when the hot female journalist tried to seduce the bad Congressman Frank Underwood, played by Kevin Spacey, as a shortcut to what we in the business call reporting. I understand the impulse. Reporting can be deadly dull and take days, whereas the hottie’s method can be dispensed with in 20 industrious minutes.

headline: Imitation of Life, Outsiders Version
text: I thought of James Benning exclusively as an experimental filmmaker until I saw four of his drawings in “Macho Man, Tell It to My Heart,” the marvelous exhibition at Artists Space, which closes on Sunday. Displaying works by nearly 50 artists, it is based on the collection and many friendships of Julie Ault, the artist, writer and founding member of the Group Material collective.

headline: High School Wrestlers in New Jersey Apologize for Photo Seen as Racist
text: Eight members of one of New Jersey’s top high school wrestling teams were suspended and barred from participating in a state tournament this weekend after they arranged a photo that looked like a lynching scene, with a black dummy hanging by a rope around its neck.

headline: Exonerated. Now What?
text: It had been a while since Jeffrey Deskovic hosted one of his weekday evening singalongs, so last month he made a few calls and brought some friends together at the Karaoke Cave, a noisy little bar on East 13th Street in Manhattan. At 6 p.m. the place was filled with young professionals sipping beers and shouting into microphones in an undemanding, if embarrassing, environment. But to Mr. Deskovic and the men who joined him, standing up in public and singing cheesy pop songs was more than an innocent release.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,298 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Singular Art, Made by Plurals
text: In Sienna Shields’s spacious studio in Dumbo, Brooklyn, with homemade rag dolls decorating one wall and hair-bead sculptures dangling from the ceiling, the mood was festive one recent frigid night. The Yams, as members of her high-energy artist collective call themselves, danced, sipped wine and traded tales about projects. “If you’re doing it, I’m in it” was a frequent refrain.

headline: Photographers Band Together to Protect Work in ‘Fair Use’ Cases
text: To many photographers, a federal appeals court ruling last spring that permitted Richard Prince to use someone else’s photographs in his art was akin to slapping a “Steal This” label on their work.

headline: Was Anyone Killed at the Knickerbocker Club?
text: Q. Has there ever been a murder at the Knickerbocker Club?

headline: Week in Pictures for Feb. 21
text: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes Valentine’s Day deliveries, sledding in Central Park and pothole repairs in Queens.

headline: Venezuela Battles Media, Social and Otherwise, to Restrict Protest Coverage
text: Tensions escalated further in Venezuela on Friday as street protests that began nine days ago continued and the government persisted in clamping down on coverage of the unrest in the broadcast media and online.

headline: The Fun of Having a Single Parent
text: NBC is on a love campaign.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | At Blumarine, Low-Maintenance Loveliness
text: “This collection reminds me of the times of Mr. Yves Saint Laurent,” the makeup artist Tom Pecheux said backstage at Blumarine, where models were dressed in lavish brocades and furs. “There is a richness, there is a glamour. So we had to make the girls look so beautiful.” To achieve that aim, Pecheux kept things simple. He left skin almost nude, with only a light application of M.A.C foundation — no blush or highlighter necessary. He didn’t touch the eyebrows or eyelashes either; the sole element of visible makeup was a simple sweep of M.A.C black eyeliner around the inner rims of the eyes and in the tiny spaces between eyelashes.

headline: Where Death Was a Friend, and Gods Were Ordinary Folk
text: I can imagine worse fates for my bones than being housed for eternity — or at least 6,000 years or so — in one of the astonishing ossuaries now on display at New York University’s Institute for the Study of the Ancient World in a modest but weighty new exhibition, “Masters of Fire: Copper Age Art From Israel.” If facial expressions have any enduring meanings across cultures and time (and it often seems that they do), the figures who adorn these ancient clay burial vaults would provide congenial company.

headline: Collectors of Keith Haring Works File Lawsuit
text: A group of nine collectors of artwork by Keith Haring sued the foundation that bears his name and its directors on Friday, accusing the defendants of “wrongfully destroying” the value of their paintings by publicly labeling them as fakes and refusing to consider information that would establish their provenance.

headline: Hollywood and the City, Take 2
text: By the early 1970s, New York’s reign as a television and filmmaking capital seemed to be over. The transplanting of Johnny Carson and the “Tonight” show to California, coupled with the demise of “The Ed Sullivan Show” the year before, Frank Rich wrote in The New York Times, “marked the end of Manhattan’s parity with Hollywood as a glitz capital for a national audience.”

headline: More Ex-Players Join Concussion Suit Against N.H.L.
text: Four more former N.H.L. players have joined the concussion lawsuit against the league, their lawyers said Friday.

headline: Children in School, and Out of Court
text: To the Editor:

headline: Changing Seasons to Take Woolmark Prize
text: The International Woolmark Prize scours the world for talent, then travels the world to reward it. This year, it has arrived in Milan.

headline: A Sharp-Eyed Squirrel, Leaping Into the Darkness
text: Few of us ever get a good view of a flying squirrel, but then again, not many of us know they truly exist. Not unlike its cartoon depiction, as the brainy, be-goggled sidekick of Bullwinkle the Moose, the Southern flying squirrel is an impressively well-adapted resident of New York City. With a preference for older beech and oak woods, these squirrels are primarily nocturnal. An uncommon habitat and our very urban instinct to avoid late-night walks through obscure woodlands make finding one a deliberate effort.

headline: The Joy of Swimming, and Meditating
text: To the Editor:

headline: Uninsured? Get Covered
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reforming the Port Authority
The Once and Future Gowanus
text: By a recent and not remotely exacting tally, the Gowanus neighborhood in Brooklyn has at least eight community groups dedicated to its planning and self-analysis: the Gowanus Alliance, the Gowanus Canal Conservancy, Bridging Gowanus, the Gowanus Canal Community Advisory Group, the Gowanus Canal Community Development Corporation, Friends and Residents of Greater Gowanus, Save Gowanus and the Gowanus Ecology Initiative. This does not include the block associations and housing groups that have an interest in the area, nor does it take full measure of the conferencing that Gowanus has inspired. Four years ago, after the Gowanus Canal was designated a Superfund site, a summit called Reconsidering Gowanus was held. Last month, Gowanus was the subject of its own TEDx talks.

headline: Under Cover: The Voyages Issue
text: This week’s cover image features a photograph of the beach in Santos, Brazil, taken by David Guttenfelder, a photographer for The Associated Press. Guttenfelder traveled across South America on the recently opened Interoceanic Highway for the magazine’s Voyages issue.

headline: Women in Labor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Basque Separatists Display Surrendered Weapons, in Front of Picasso’s ‘Guernica’
text: As my colleague Raphael Minder reports, an international verification commission said on Friday that the Basque separatist group ETA had disabled “some of the weapons that allowed it to wage a lengthy terror campaign for independence that has claimed more than 800 victims.”

headline: Marriage, a Matter of Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Discussion About ‘Bright Lights, Big City’
text: This time we outsourced our selection for the Big City Book Club to the writer and satirist Gary Shteyngart. We asked him to pick his favorite book about New York, and he did not demand that we read his own newly published memoir, “Little Failure,” about his upbringing as a Russian émigré in Queens. Instead, he selflessly selected “Bright Lights, Big City,” Jay McInerney’s touchstone novel of the hedonistic ’80s life on the other side of the East River. Join us for the online discussion of the novel with Mr. Shteyngart on Monday, March 10, at 6:30 p.m.

headline: Unequal From the Start
text: To the Editor:

headline: New York, Behind the Facades
text: The photographs of Sean Vegezzi go beyond closed doors and down subway tunnels.

headline: David M. Herszenhorn Answers Questions on Ukraine
text: The center of Ukraine’s capital, Kiev, came to resemble a war zone this week when protesters and riot police officers used firearms against each other as they battled for control. On Friday, President Viktor F. Yanukovych and opposition leaders signed a political deal aimed at ending the days of violence and three months of protests, and Parliament voted to allow the release of the president’s imprisoned rival. David M. Herszenhorn, a Moscow-based correspondent for The New York Times who has been covering the crisis in Ukraine since it began in November, answered readers’ questions on the situation submitted via comments, Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Closed Doors? Not a Problem
text: It’s safe to say that most New Yorkers have a limited, even literal view of their city: The door to that building over there leads to a lobby, right? The stairs to that subway station head down toward the J train.

headline: U.A.W. Asks Labor Board to Examine Vote at Tennessee Plant
text: The United Automobile Workers asked the National Labor Relations Board on Friday to order a new unionization election at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., asserting that the union’s loss last week was because of improper interference by the state’s lawmakers.

headline: Attorney General Signs New Rules to Limit Access to Journalists’ Records
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., who drew fire last spring over the Justice Department’s aggressive tactics for secretly obtaining reporters’ phone logs and emails as part of leak investigations, on Friday signed new guidelines narrowing the circumstances in which law enforcement officials may obtain journalists’ records.

headline: Friday Night Music: Fleetwood Mac, The Chain
text: In honor of President Obama’s decision not to propose cutting Social Security by switching to a chain-linked price index, a blast from the past:

headline: Flaws Persist in L.I.R.R.’s Disability Claims, a Report Finds
text: A federal watchdog has concluded that the method of granting occupational disability payments to former employees of the Long Island Rail Road is still so flawed that roughly 96 percent of those who apply receive it, roughly the same approval rate as before a vast cheating scandal was first exposed more than five years ago.

headline: F.D.A. Orders 4 Bidi Cigarette Brands Removed From Shelves
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday ordered four tobacco products removed from the market, the first time the agency has done so since being given the legal authority in 2009.

headline: Yankees’ Top Starting Pitchers Impress Girardi
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Before Friday, the last time Masahiro Tanaka had thrown a pitch to a batter was in the ninth inning of Game 7 of the Japan Series against the Yomiuri Giants — “Nov. 3,” Tanaka said in English, a date he will find difficult to forget. He threw a split-fingered fastball to get the final out and secure the Rakuten Golden Eagles’ first championship.

headline: Ted Nugent Apologizes for Obama Insult
text: HOUSTON — The rock guitarist Ted Nugent, responding to cascading criticism that had become an embarrassment for his conservative Republican allies, apologized Friday for calling President Obama a “subhuman mongrel.” But Democrats expressed frustration that their calls for an apology from the Texas Republican who took Mr. Nugent on the campaign trail had been ignored.

headline: Another Step on the Path to Settling Frisk Cases
text: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan cleared the way on Friday for the lawsuits challenging the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practices to be sent back to a lower-court judge, a step toward negotiating a final settlement in the longstanding legal dispute.

headline: Streaming of Olympic Hockey Continues to Expand
text: With each succeeding United States Olympic hockey game from Sochi, Russia, this week, NBC Sports watched as the number of people streaming the game live grew.

headline: In Sake, Japan Sees a Potential Stimulus
text: NIHONMATSU, Japan — As Japan confronts troubling economic data and memories of its stagnant “lost generation,” the country’s government is offering a little something to take the edge off: a bottle or two of sake.

headline: Will the Net Stay Neutral?
text: It is no doubt a coincidence that six days after the Comcast-Time Warner Cable merger was unveiled, Tom Wheeler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, announced that his agency was planning — yet again — to come up with rules to ensure that no Internet service provider could discriminate against any company or website. And it is also a coincidence — for sure! — that on the same day as the Wheeler announcement, Google let it be known that it was going to begin discussions with 34 cities to expand its Google Fiber business. Google Fiber provides high speed Internet service, though so far only in Kansas City and Provo, Utah. (It is about to begin service in Austin, Tex.)

headline: To Make Shipping Oil Safer, Railroads Agree to 8 Measures
text: Responding to concerns about the safety of trains carrying oil around the country, federal regulators on Friday outlined steps to reduce the risk of rail shipments and bolster confidence in the fast-growing industry.

headline: Coping With Infectious Disease
text: The list of infectious diseases that could leap from remote areas of the world to strike countries thousands of miles away is growing. A warning of what can happen occurred a decade ago when an outbreak in China of a mysterious new viral disease, known as SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, was covered up by the Chinese authorities, allowing infected airline passengers to carry the virus to more than two dozen other countries. The disease killed nearly 800 people and caused large economic losses in Asia and Canada.

headline: Army General’s Lawyers Seek Dismissal of Sexual Misconduct Charges
text: One week after the lead prosecutor in the court-martial of Brig. Gen. Jeffrey Sinclair abruptly quit the case, defense lawyers have asked a military judge to dismiss sexual misconduct charges against General Sinclair in a motion that asserts that officials all the way up to Gen. Raymond T. Odierno, the Army chief of staff, have acknowledged weaknesses in the case.

headline: Uncovering Legacies in Staten Island’s Neglected Graveyards
text: Lynn Rogers is proud of her work and is not concerned that she receives no recognition from those whose stories she unveils. Not that they could sing her praises — they are all dead.

headline: Alcoholics Anonymous, Without the Religion
text: Three floors above a Manhattan street of loading docks and coffee shops, in a functional room of folding chairs and linoleum tile, a man who introduced himself as Vic began to speak. “Today is my 35th anniversary,” he said. The dozen people seated around him applauded, and several even whooped in support.

headline: Fed Fretted Over Reaction to Demise of Lehman
text: Six weeks after Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy in September 2008, Ben S. Bernanke, then chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave his central bank colleagues an imitation of the people who were already criticizing the government’s decision to let the Wall Street bank collapse.

headline: Rewriting the Gettysburg Address
text: Abraham Lincoln did not give the Gettysburg Address on Nov. 19, 1863 — at least, not the one engraved on the Lincoln Memorial, the one memorized by millions the world over. Lincoln actually wrote the words recognized today as the Gettysburg Address months after the cemetery dedication, during a full and complete revision of his speech that he finished in February 1864.

headline: To Read or Not to Read?
text: This is the seventh part of an eight-part series.

headline: Don’t Let Up on Iran
text: WASHINGTON — LIKE all Americans, we strongly hope that the Obama administration’s diplomatic efforts lead to the peaceful dismantling of Iran’s nuclear weapons program. To achieve this key national security goal, we support a policy that complements the current negotiations with a range of congressional actions that threaten greater economic and diplomatic pressure on the Iranian government.

headline: Montessori Schools Surge in Popularity Among New Generation of Jewish Parents
text: In the boys’ classroom at Lamplighters Yeshivah in the Hasidic Jewish stronghold of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Montessori number-counting boards and decimal beads share space with Hebrew-learning materials. A colorful timeline on the wall shows two strands of world history in parallel: secular on the left, Jewish on the right. A photo of the grand rabbi of the Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic movement hangs above a list of tasks that children perform individually: make a fractions poster, practice cursive, learn about the moon’s phases.

headline: In Sochi, Connecticut Is a Winner
text: MADISON, Conn. — The board of selectmen for this tranquil shoreline town addressed an unusual request on Feb. 10. Andrea Perullo, the proprietor of a local jewelry store, asked if this year’s Presidents’ Day could be formally recognized as Mac Bohonnon Day.

headline: Medals of Honor, Denied Because of Prejudice, to Be Belatedly Awarded
text: President Obama will award the Medal of Honor next month to 24 Army veterans, most of them Hispanic or Jewish, who were passed over for the nation’s highest military award because of their race or ethnicity, the White House announced on Friday.

headline: Collins Would Be an Asset on the Court, the Nets Say, Not a Distraction Off It
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Nets continued internal conversations on Friday about potential frontcourt players to add to their roster. After the team practiced at the Olympic Club, a private athletic and social club, Coach Jason Kidd said he had briefly joined discussions with the front office.

headline: Texas Strikes Again
text: Election season in Texas! They’re voting right now in the primaries. And I know you are interested because whatever happens in Texas has a way of coming back and biting the rest of the nation.

headline: Terror Case Has Lawyer With Several Distinctions
text: When the terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, begins next month in Manhattan, his defense team will include one lawyer with a particularly interesting background.

headline: Accommodating Divisiveness
text: Ted Nugent, a.k.a. the Motor City Madman, an ex-rocker who’s off his rocker, is at it again.

headline: Turkey’s Internet Crackdown
text: President Abdullah Gul, Turkey’s head of state, has now joined Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan in the government’s assault on free speech. On Tuesday, Mr. Gul approved a new law, passed earlier by Parliament, that is intended to help protect Mr. Erdogan and his allies from a widening corruption scandal by tightening government control of the Internet. It would allow the authorities, without a court order, to block web pages under the guise of protecting personal privacy, and to collect users’ browsing histories.

headline: An End to the Grand-Bargain Charades
text: The phony budget games finally came to an end this week. After years of trying to entice Republicans into serious negotiations over a fiscal deal — years of instant rejection and painful austerity — the White House announced it was giving up.

headline: Syrians Seek New Delay in Export of Chemical Arms
text: The Syrian government has sought a new delay, until mid-May, for the export of its chemical weapons arsenal and is balking at a deadline looming in three weeks to destroy the 12 facilities that once produced the munitions, Western diplomats said Friday. The announcement is a new indication that Syria’s pledge to eradicate the banned arsenal — under a timetable already weeks behind schedule — is fraying.

headline: G.O.P. Congressman in South Carolina Takes a Risk With a Foray Into Immigration
text: GAFFNEY, S.C. — After the sterling conservative voting record he has established during three years in Washington, Representative Mick Mulvaney, a Republican, can take a few political risks in his South Carolina district, one of the most conservative in this reliably Republican state. This week he did just that.

headline: New Comptroller Stands by Handling of a Wrongful Conviction Case
text: The city comptroller’s decision to pay $6.4 million to a man wrongfully convicted of murder before he even filed a lawsuit marked a sharp break with past practice and could have ramifications for similar cases, lawyers who specialize in wrongful convictions said.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 21, 2014
Religious Right in Arizona Cheers Bill Allowing Businesses to Refuse to Serve Gays
text: In New Mexico, a photographer declined to take pictures of a lesbian couple’s commitment ceremony. In Washington State, a florist would not provide flowers for a same-sex wedding. And in Colorado, a baker refused to make a cake for a party celebrating the wedding of two men.

headline: What to Watch at the Olympics: Saturday
text: MIX AND MATCH You’ve feasted on hockey, skiing, figure skating and biathlon during the past two weeks, so why not use the final full day of competition in Sochi to experience something new? Skip the hockey bronze medal game (NBCSN, 10 a.m.) and the figure skating gala (NBCSN, 12:30 p.m.) and opt instead for snowboarding’s parallel giant slalom (NBC, 2:30 p.m.). Or wait for the pursuit events in speedskating (NBC, 8 p.m.), in which teams of three skaters start on opposite sides of the ice and race as groups to the finish, mano-a-mano-a-mano-a-mano. It’s just like the cycling version held at the Summer Games. Only colder.

headline: A Week of Fire and Ice
text: That barricades remain a brutal but effective final resort for desperate citizens was amply on display this past week, not only in Ukraine, where President Viktor F. Yanukovych appeared finally to surrender, but also in Venezuela, where the batons and tear gas of riot police officers failed to quell anti-government demonstrations, and in Thailand, where the police engaged in bloody efforts to clear sites occupied by protesters since late November.

headline: Bad Egg
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Something wicked this way comes.

headline: As Crisis Loomed, Yellen Made Wry and Forceful Calls for Action
text: As the world’s financial system stood on the verge of collapse in October 2008, Janet L. Yellen was not even a full voting member of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee, but she was not shy about admonishing her colleagues for not acting faster.

headline: With Tumult Around Him, Russian Diplomat Keeps Calm
text: UNITED NATIONS — Sweptback silver hair, polar blue tie, signature pinstripe suit: The only thing out of place was a bandage around Vitaly I. Churkin’s right thumb as he departed for a meeting of his fellow United Nations Security Council ambassadors the other day to have what he called a thorny discussion about Syria.

headline: U.S. Proposes Cuts to Rates in Medicare Payments
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday proposed cuts in Medicare payment rates for managed-care plans serving more than one-fourth of all beneficiaries, and Republicans immediately pounced on the proposal, which appears likely to become a significant issue in this year’s midterm elections.

headline: In Struggles of Artist With His Work, Hints of Mexico’s Own
text: MEXICO CITY — DAMIÁN ORTEGA’S completed installation outside the new Museo Jumex here looks, at first, like a workaday kitchen filmed in space. A teapot, plates, bowls and utensils slowly spin above an unassuming wooden table. A chair, then another, seem to be balancing on one leg.

headline: Video Notebook: Mexican Art
text: The Times’s Damien Cave tracks the delayed debut of Damián Ortega’s modern art installation outside the new Museo Jumex in Mexico City.

headline: Walter Ehlers, Last of Medal of Honor Recipients in D-Day Attack, Dies at 92
text: Walter D. Ehlers, who received the Medal of Honor for his exploits as an Army sergeant in the D-Day invasion of France and came to personify the heroism of the G.I.’s who stormed the beaches of Normandy on June 6, 1944, died on Thursday in Long Beach, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Richard Cabela, Who Sold the Great Outdoors, Is Dead at 77
text: Richard N. Cabela, founder of the hunting and outdoors retail chain Cabela’s, one of the largest sellers of guns and ammunition in the country, died on Monday at his home in Sidney, Neb., where the company is based. He was 77.

headline: Amid Fence-Mending, Another U.S.-Russia Rift
text: WASHINGTON — After putting the tense Russian-American relationship on “pause” last year, President Obama and his team have lately been working to get it back on track by quietly planning a possible meeting this summer with President Vladimir V. Putin. The two sides have even begun discussing a trade agreement for the two to sign.

headline: Two Ticks of Clock Against Magic Prove Microcosm of the Knicks’ Fading Season
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The entire sequence lasted less than two seconds, yet it provided the perfect summation of everything that had gone wrong for the Knicks this season.

headline: Two Sexual Assaults Are Reported at Yale
text: The Yale University Police Department has received anonymous reports that two undergraduate students were sexually assaulted at an off-campus party this month, the university said on Friday night.

headline: Growing Support, and Tea From Young Women, Embolden Kiev Street Fighters
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The street fighters in Independence Square, kitted out with motorcycle helmets, plywood shields and baseball bats, are an intimidating lot by any measure, and this week they turned whole battalions of riot police officers on their heels in epic, bloody clashes that stunned the world.

headline: WhatsApp Deal Bets on a Few Fewer ‘Friends’
text: The address book is making a billion-dollar comeback.

headline: U.N. Office Criticizes Australia Detention Policies
text: Australia’s treatment of asylum seekers sent to offshore processing centers is cruel, inhuman and degrading and it violates international law, the United Nations’ human rights office said Friday.

headline: Response From Latin American Leaders on Venezuelan Unrest Is Muted
text: MEXICO CITY — When President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela arrived in Havana for a regional summit meeting last month, Latin American and Caribbean solidarity seemed triumphant. The United States was not invited, and in speech after speech, the region’s leaders expressed confidence in a shared, unified future.

headline: Hope Springs, Again, for Yankees and Mets
text: With new faces and renewed optimism, the Yankees began training in Tampa, Fla., while the Mets opened their camp in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

headline: Brushing Up On the Most Curious New Beauty Tools
text: Backstage at Diane von Furstenberg’s fall show, there was an unusual makeup tool being swept across the preternaturally smooth complexion of the singer Annie Clark, a.k.a. St. Vincent. From a distance, it looked a bit like a toothbrush or perhaps one of those hand-held, skin-firming wands. Nope! Turns out, it was one of three new Masterclass Makeup Brushes from M.A.C. Launched this winter, these newfangled tools perform all the usual beauty tasks — blending eye shadow, smudging eyeliner, buffing foundation into the skin, saturating the lips with color — albeit with a supercool design unlike that of a traditional brush. The most noticeable difference: The head and handle point toward the face, rather than away from it, which allows you to actually see what you’re doing in the mirror without hands getting in the way (imagine that!). Another plus: The densely packed synthetic bristles — or, rather, “cosmefibres” — evenly disperse makeup particles over the face, sans streaks. Oh, and the rubberized handles are just comfy to hold, which is key for a busy makeup artist like Regan Rabanal, who spent hours painting faces at numerous New York Fashion Week shows, including Zac Posen, Cushnie Et Ochs and Badgley Mischka.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) NOW YOU SEE ME (2013) A group of magicians — a sleight-of-hand virtuoso (Jesse Eisenberg, above), a mentalist (Woody Harrelson), a pickpocket (Dave Franco) and an escape artist (Isla Fisher) — turned Robin Hoods try to outrun an F.B.I. agent (Mark Ruffalo) and an Interpol detective (Mélanie Laurent), sending cash showering down on their audiences. “Up to this point, ‘Now You See Me’ is an enjoyable goof that in its giddy way evokes a world propelled by technological wizardry enabling those who are clever enough to steal from everybody else,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times of this caper directed by Louis Leterrier, which also stars Morgan Freeman and Michael Caine. But “long before the story culminates with a preposterous final revelation, whatever hopes you had that ‘Now You See Me’ might have had anything to say about the profession of magic, rampant greed or anything else have been dashed.”

headline: U.S. Army Seeks Better Ties With China’s Military
text: BEIJING — A top American military commander said Saturday that the United States Army was working to start a formal dialogue and exchange program with the Chinese People’s Liberation Army before the end of the year.

headline: Corrections: February 22, 2014
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Archrival Is Freed as Ukraine Leader Flees
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Abandoned by his own guards and reviled across the Ukrainian capital but still determined to recover his shredded authority, President Viktor F. Yanukovych fled Kiev on Friday night to denounce what he called a violent coup, as his official residence, his vast, colonnaded office complex and other once impregnable centers of power fell without a fight to throngs of joyous citizens stunned by their triumph.

headline: Extreme Park Rosa Khutor
text: A view from Sochi’s Extreme Park, which hosts newer events like snowboard slopestyle and ski cross.

headline: The Narrow Margin Between Agony and Ecstasy
text: Canada advanced to the final of the men’s ice hockey tournament with a 1-0 victory over the United States at Bolshoi Ice Dome.

headline: Bottega Veneta: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: Once Filled With Stars, Yankees Infield Now Hopes to Overachieve
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Whenever the Yankees made a pitching change from 2009 through 2012, the superstars lined up behind the mound in a grand array of infield royalty, a foursome of the best, the best known or the best paid at each position.

headline: Three Stand as Test Cases for the Hidebound N.F.L.
text: Richard Sherman, Jonathan Martin and Michael Sam are young African-American football players who represent three explosive elements in American culture: race, class and sexual orientation.

headline: Protecting the Square
text: In Kiev, Ukraine, the opposition fighters in Independence Square are considered heroes by many supporters of the movement.

headline: White Sox Lean on Sale, the Skinny Guy Throwing Strikes
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Chris Sale stands 6 feet 6 inches and weighs only 180 pounds. In the history of baseball’s major leagues, only one pitcher at least that tall, weighing no more than Sale, has ever made more starts. His name was William Jennings Bryan Harriss, but he was known, naturally, as Slim. He pitched in the 1920s.

headline: A Fabled Track Tries to Come Back
text: John Brunetti Sr., owner of Hialeah Park, revived the famed track with quarter horse racing and a casino, and he hopes thoroughbreds will follow.

headline: Hialeah’s Fabled Track Seeks a Rebirth
text: HIALEAH, Fla. — John Brunetti is 83, which makes him slightly younger than Hialeah Park, the famous racetrack he owns. Both are looking pretty good for their age.

headline: Sasha Luss Transforms Backstage at Etro
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Sasha Luss (left) and after (right) makeup by Mark Carrasquillo and hair by Eugene Souleiman.

headline: The Urge To Tighten
text: People are going through the Fed’s 2008 transcripts, and finding that most officials had no idea what was going down. (Incidentally, guys, whatever you want to call 2008, the one thing it definitely wasn’t was a FISCAL crisis. A case of BowlesSimpson on the brain?) I’m a bit surprised, but that’s not the most surprising thing.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Feb. 23
text: “Facebook is constantly working to not lose anybody.”

headline: Roberto Cavalli: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: Rewarding the Rich
Writing Her Own Story
text: Thuy Vu left Vietnam in 1975 with her family, eventually settling in California. She is the host of “KQED Newsroom” on the PBS television station in San Francisco, and does occasional reporting for the program.

headline: Caution: Stuffed Shirts Ahead
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: 1964: U.S. TV Corps Grapples with Cops, Alps and Lingo
text: INNSBRUCK — The project of televising the ninth Winter Olympics from Austria to the United States requires, among other things, some rapport with the local cops.

headline: Chicken Soup for Flu-Weary Guests
text: With flu season at its peak in the United States, some hotels, especially in New York City, are trying to help guests ward off the illness or at least make it easier to manage. The Kitano in Midtown Manhattan has a new immune-system-boosting menu with ingredients like ginger and plum paste in dishes like steamed egg custard with crab meat. The Hotel Chandler in the Murray Hill neighborhood has a “Flu Away” package through the end of March — a room with a pamphlet that has tips on staying healthy and a Vicks GermFree humidifier. Prices start at $250 a night.

headline: Going the Distance Grows Shorter for Many Runners
text: When 30,000 competitors considered what distance to run in this weekend’s Gasparilla Distance Classic, they had five choices: traditional or stroller-friendly 5-kilometer, an 8k, a 15k or a half marathon.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Mars, Venus and the Handling of Money
text: I was out at dinner with a friend and her husband when they started squabbling about her financial adviser.

headline: Winners Take All, but Can’t We Still Dream?
text: It’s clear that the lives of many creative artists are being transformed by digital technology. But competing schools of thought cite the very same technology in support of strikingly different conclusions.

headline: David Rosenblatt of 1stdibs, on Teamwork at the Top
text: This interview with  David Rosenblatt, chief executive of 1stdibs, an online marketplace for high-end goods including art, antiques, jewelry and furniture, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: A New Light on Regulators in the Dark
text: In the five years that have elapsed since the direst days of the financial crisis, we’ve learned much about how the nation’s high-level banking regulators worked to keep the debacle from turning into a full-blown economic Depression. Tales of these herculean efforts have emerged in books by some of the major players, and in the exhaustive testimony they’ve presented before congressional inquisitors and others trying to determine what went wrong and why.

headline: A Young Inventor, Finding the Crunch Factor
text: The way Mark King tells the story, the idea came to him in an instant just three years ago, when he was a 21-year-old community-college dropout. Like the proverbial Edisonian light bulb, there it was: an organoleptic analyzer.

headline: In His Office, There’s Always Cause for Celebration
text: Reluctant officeholder

headline: Jimmie Johnson Does Triathlons, but Is He an Athlete?
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — A typical week in the life of Jimmie Johnson on the way to winning his sixth Nascar Sprint Cup championship last season included five miles of swimming, 40 miles of running, 100 miles of cycling and one race.

headline: Oysters Make a Comeback
text: Connoisseurs across the country are binging on oysters. The trend is, at least in part, the result of a rapid growth of oyster farms on the East and West Coasts.

headline: Loss Leaders on the Half Shell
text: The joint is jumpin’: Three mixologists in striped dress shirts, dark slacks and suspenders pour drinks almost as fast as three shuckers send platter after platter of raw oysters to their fate. A bluesy soundtrack wafts over the standing-room-only din as patrons sip and slurp, oblivious to the crowd that has gathered outside for what can be a 90-minute wait.

headline: Jil Sander: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: Wisconsin’s Legacy for Unions
text: Three years ago, a labor leader named Marty Beil was one of the loudest opponents of Gov. Scott Walker’s “budget repair bill,” a proposal that brought tens of thousands of protesters out to the Wisconsin State Capitol in Madison in frigid February weather. A gruff-voiced grizzly of a man, Mr. Beil warned that the bill was rigged with booby traps that would cripple the state’s public-sector unions.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Versace’s Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Test in Northwestern Case: Is College Football a Job?
text: CHICAGO — For four days last week in a courtroom on the 13th floor of the Dirksen Federal Building, a National Labor Relations Board panel heard testimony concerning whether Northwestern football players should have the right to collectively bargain as university employees.

headline: Jordan Keeps Haunting Knicks’ Playoff Hopes
text: There was a time when it felt as if the only thing standing in the way of a Knicks championship was Michael Jordan. Throughout the 1990s, the Knicks would charge into the playoffs looking for the team’s first title since 1973 only to be sent home unceremoniously by Jordan’s Chicago Bulls.

headline: N.H.L. and Players Differ Over 2018 Games
text: No moment symbolized the uncertain future of N.H.L. Olympic participation more than the friendly disagreement between Commissioner Gary Bettman and René Fasel, the president of the International Ice Hockey Federation, at their news conference last week in Sochi, Russia.

headline: U.N. Orders Both Sides in Syria to Allow Humanitarian Aid
text: UNITED NATIONS — In a rare show of unity among world powers, the United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution on Saturday ordering the warring parties in Syria to stop blocking the delivery of humanitarian aid, though without the immediate prospect of punishment for those who disobey.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Bottega Veneta Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Shiffrin Wants 5 Alpine Wins in ’18
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Less than 24 hours after winning her first Olympic gold medal, Mikaela Shiffrin announced that her goal in the 2018 Winter Olympics was to win all five Alpine events. It would be an unprecedented sweep for a ski racer.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: February 21, 2014
text: The F.C.C. is making a renewed push to pass net neutrality rules to keep the Internet free and open. This week on Money Talking, Joe and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine examine whether broadband Internet service should be regulated like a utility, similar to power, water or telephone service. They also weigh in on Facebook’s $19 billion acquisition of the messaging app WhatsApp, and the imminent I.P.O. from King, the creator of the ubiquitous cellphone game Candy Crush Saga.

headline: Variety: Miracle on Ice
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — The Sochi Olympics are underway, and this week’s acrostic takes inspiration from some of the events held during the Winter Games. The quote has to do with ice skating, and several answers and clues are related to sports done in an ice rink, like hockey and figure skating.

headline: With President’s Departure, Ukraine Looks Toward a Murky Future
text: KIEV, Ukraine — As ranks of riot police officers, Interior Ministry troops and even the president vanished from the capital, Ukraine slipped, with often-eerie calm after months of tumultuous protests and a week of bloody mayhem, into the hands of revolution.

headline: El Chapo, Most-Wanted Drug Lord, Is Captured in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — Just before 7 a.m. on Saturday, dozens of soldiers and police officers descended on a condominium tower in Mazatlán, Mexico, a beach resort known as much as a hangout for drug traffickers as for its seafood and surf.

headline: Translating Thrills on the Skiing Trails
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — For the past two weeks, cross-country skiing fans have been among the most boisterous, screaming, waving flags and ringing cowbells as the athletes circled on the trails around them.

headline: Updates on a Day of Upheaval in Ukraine
text: As my colleagues Andrew Higgins and Andrew Kramer report from Kiev, on a day of upheaval, Ukraine’s president, Viktor Yanukovych, fled the capital, the Parliament called for early elections to replace him, protesters strolled the grounds of the abandoned presidential palace and the jailed opposition leader Yulia Tymoshenko was released from a prison hospital in eastern Ukraine where she was being held.

headline: What to Watch at the Olympics: Sunday
text: MEN’S HOCKEY Gold medals will be awarded in four-man bobsled, the men’s 50-kilometer cross-country race and, finally, men’s hockey. The final game will not feature the beloved home team, but it is a meeting of hockey heavyweights nonetheless. Canada and Sweden have won three of the four gold medals since N.H.L. players became part of the men’s tournament in 1998, Canada in 2002 and 2010 and Sweden in 2006. Neither team has lost in the tournament. Henrik Lundqvist and Sweden have given up just six goals in the tournament; Carey Price and Canada have allowed only three NBC, 7 a.m.

headline: How It All Began: A Cold War Battle Heats Up
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Three months of civic unrest in Ukraine spiraled out of control last week with dozens of people dead, the center of this elegant city turned into a burning war zone and the eventual flight from the capital on Friday by the president. Puzzled about the conflict and how it got so bad? Here’s a primer.

headline: Holdout’s Faith Rewarded Amid Olympic Makeover
text: SOCHI, Russia — It was a year ago, almost to the day, that Prokofey Drovichev stood in his mud yard and wondered what would happen to him and his family. The Olympics were coming, and he needed to get out of the way.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Roberto Cavalli Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Antonio Marras: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: U.S. Fans Snap Up World Cup Tickets
text: More tickets to the 2014 World Cup have been allocated by FIFA to fans from the United States than to those in any other nation, other than Brazil, the host.

headline: Live Stream | Emilio Pucci’s Fall 2014 Collection at Milan Fashion Week
text: The latest women’s collection from Emilio Pucci at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: In a First for Spain, a Woman Is Convicted of Inciting Terror Over Twitter
text: MADRID — The line between youthful rebelliousness and something more dangerous is not always clear. But in her angry musings on Twitter, Alba González Camacho, 21, who describes herself as a “very normal girl,” sailed across it. After she posted messages calling for a far-left terrorist organization to return to arms and kill politicians, Spain’s national court convicted her of inciting terrorism using a social media network.

headline: Resolution From the United Nations Security Council on Syria
text: In a hard-fought show of unity among world powers, the United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Saturday to order the warring parties in Syria to stop blocking the delivery of humanitarian aid, though without the immediate prospect of punishment against those who disobey.

headline: Celtics-Lakers Rivalry, Once Lustrous, Is Now Lackluster
text: LOS ANGELES — It was just four years ago that the Celtics were beaten by the Lakers, and Coach Doc Rivers went around the visitors’ locker room and collected $100 from every player and coach. He removed a ceiling tile and hid the money, then told his players they would be coming back in June to collect it.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 22
text: Saturday was the next-to-last day of competition at the Winter Games in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 23
text: The Ukrainian Parliament voted Saturday to oust President Viktor F. Yanukovych after weeks of antigovernment protests and violent clashes with the military. Protesters claimed to have established control of the capital city, while Mr. Yanukovych called the events a “coup” in a television interview on Saturday.

headline: Flying High While Still on the Ground
text: Emily Cook, of the United States freestyle ski team, visualizes each aerial jump as part of her training for the Olympics.

headline: Olympians Use Imagery as Mental Training
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The Canadian bobsledder Lyndon Rush had not yet arrived in Sochi. But he was already on the Olympic sliding track as he sat in a chair in the Munich airport several days before the Winter Olympics, his eyes wide open but his mind’s eye far away as he traced a sinuous path through the air with his left hand.

headline: When Doctors Need to Lie
text: I ONCE had the unenviable task of informing a 22-year-old Jamaican man that he was suffering from severe heart failure and would probably need a heart transplant. The man’s father warned me that his son would be devastated to hear the diagnosis. “It would mean a lot to me if you could go back in and tell him he’s going to be all right,” the father pleaded. “Please tell him that if he does the things you say, he’s going to be O.K.”

headline: Audiobooks and the Return of Storytelling
text: STANFORD, Calif. — THE ferns under my oak trees evoke moments from “The Great Gatsby” for me. I read the book many years ago, but I listened to it last summer while planting 50 polypodium californicas and 50 festuca idahoensis in the dappled light beneath my oaks. Now, when I look at them, I think about that last awful accident, the yellow Rolls-Royce screaming past the repair shop, and what F. Scott Fitzgerald’s narrator called Gatsby’s extraordinary gift for hope.

headline: A Picasso in Trouble
text: The largest and most endangered Picasso many of us have never seen lives on Park Avenue, in the Seagram Building. To get to it, walk to East 52nd Street, past the idling Town Cars, through the door of the Four Seasons restaurant. Give a nod to the friendly coat-check guy, then head up the stairs, into the soaring space of the Grill Room, where the city’s uppermost crust is having lunch or drinks. Keep going into the corridor that leads to the Pool Room. Look right, and up.

headline: Can God Make It in Hollywood?
text: LOS ANGELES — SOME years ago, when I was producing films at Columbia Pictures, I learned up close how hard it was to make Hollywood get religion. It was in the mid-1990s, and a good writer, earlier nominated for an Oscar, had an earnest modern-day Christ story about a damaged man in Los Angeles who might or might not be the Messiah. “The Greatest Story Ever Told” meets “Falling Down,” more or less.

headline: How to Get a Job at Google
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — LAST June, in an interview with Adam Bryant of The Times, Laszlo Bock, the senior vice president of people operations for Google — i.e., the guy in charge of hiring for one of the world’s most successful companies — noted that Google had determined that “G.P.A.’s are worthless as a criteria for hiring, and test scores are worthless. ... We found that they don’t predict anything.” He also noted that the “proportion of people without any college education at Google has increased over time” — now as high as 14 percent on some teams. At a time when many people are asking, “How’s my kid gonna get a job?” I thought it would be useful to visit Google and hear how Bock would answer.

headline: The F.C.C. Tries Again
text: After losing two court cases on the issue, the Federal Communications Commission last week came up with a promising way to prevent broadband companies from giving preferential treatment to big players like Netflix and Google, which could hurt smaller businesses and start-ups, as well as consumers.

headline: Happiness Is a Warm iPhone
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — IN Spike Jonze’s new film “Her,” Theodore Twombly, a lonely writer living in the nearish future, develops feelings for Samantha, an operating system. It is a love story wrapped around a thought experiment wrapped around a metaphor: We fall in love with our technology. That’s how we talk about our gadgets — with the language of emotional attachment, with irrational expectations about happily ever after. Now that I’m holding you, my sexy 5G smartphone, my life will never be the same.

headline: Elias Ghanem
text: Elias Ghanem is the director of the Middle East and North Africa division of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.

headline: On Campaign Trail, Missteps on Gender
text: KATHA POLLITT’s judgment, on Twitter, was harsh. The feminist writer observed: “NYT mag: First Hillary as giant bald fleshball, now ‘Can Wendy Davis Have It All?’ Sexist much?”

headline: The Games Putin Plays
text: THE last time geopolitics intruded into an Olympics, during the 2008 Beijing Games, Vladimir Putin was the crisis’s winner: his military delivered a decisive spanking to Russia’s neighbor Georgia, whose government had fatally overestimated the West’s willingness to intervene on its behalf. The mini-war sent a clear message: after a long period of retrenchment, the Russian bear still had an appetite for power politics, and the claws to satisfy it.

headline: Mumbai’s Empty Parlor Games
text: GOA, India — THERE was a time, only a few years ago now, when I prided myself as a host of parties — soirees, as some plummy guests called them. Before one such gathering, I was asked: “Are you having another sorry this week?” Rather than correct my guest’s French, I simply furnished the time, and the usual address: my sparse studio in the north Mumbai enclave of Juhu, overlooking a pond and a parking lot dotted with identically hooded black and yellow rickshaws.

headline: In the Treetops, a Winter Gift
text: THEY looked, at first glance, like trees in a paint-by-number picture, snow outlining branches in idiot-proof chiaroscuro — a child’s “Winter Scene.” Yet as I stood in a recent wet snowstorm on 110th Street, looking down Fifth Avenue along Central Park, I saw that the elms flanking the sidewalk had an aspect in winter less observable in other seasons, when their branches are cloaked in leaves.

headline: When Even the Starting Line Is Out of Reach
text: POINT PLEASANT, W.Va. — JOHNNY WEETHEE, a beautiful and beaming child who at the age of 3 still struggles to speak, encapsulates the shortcomings of our approach to poverty.

headline: A Viable Common Core?
text: Educators and others take part in a national debate over the new learning standards.

headline: Christie Puts the Gloves On
text: PORT MONMOUTH, N.J. — THERE’S nothing more amusing than a bully forced to be on his best behavior.

headline: What the Stimulus Accomplished
text: Of all the myths and falsehoods that Republicans have spread about President Obama, the most pernicious and long-lasting is that the $832 billion stimulus package did not work. Since 2009, Republican lawmakers have inextricably linked the words “failed” and “stimulus,” and last week, five years after passage of the Recovery Act, they dusted off their old playbook again.

headline: Slalom Champion Sets an Age Record
text: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A day after Mikaela Shiffrin became the youngest women’s Olympic slalom champion, the 34-year-old Mario Matt of Austria became the oldest men’s Olympic slalom champion on Saturday, winning the gold medal over his teammate Marcel Hirscher by 28-hundredths of a second.

headline: Parliament Votes to Dismiss Yanukovych
text: The Ukrainian Parliament voted to declare Viktor F. Yanukovych constitutionally unable to be the president of the country. It scheduled an early vote for May 25.

headline: Classics Aflame at Bottega Veneta
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Emilio Pucci: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: New York City Chancellor Meets With Charter School Leaders
text: The meeting was something like an early gathering of merging families. Both sides already knew each other, but no one was ready to broach potential conflict, lingering instead in the space of common interest: the well-being of the children.

headline: At N.F.L. Combine, Michael Sam Says He Wants Focus on Field
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Like the other top N.F.L. draft prospects this year, Michael Sam met with reporters Saturday at Lucas Oil Stadium. Unlike any other soon-to-be professional football players, Sam wore a special button on the lanyard that hung around his neck.

headline: Chain of Betrayal
text: It was big news this past week when President Obama dropped the notion of effectively cutting Social Security benefits by switching to “chain-linked” consumer prices, because it marked a turn away from BowlesSimpsonized discourse, from Grand Bargain-seeking. But there’s a bit more to it: an acknowledgement, finally, that today’s Republicans are utterly cynical and untrustworthy, that there’s no point in seeking compromise.

headline: Investing in Kids
text: My Sunday column, about the importance of anti-poverty efforts that focus on children, was motivated by a sense of frustration about the debate in this country. On the one hand, it’s terrific that we’re beginning to have a serious discussion about inequality, poverty and opportunity. On the other, the debate is mostly about the minimum wage and unemployment benefits, which to my thinking are useful but not the most cost-effective measures. The single most important measures we could take to build opportunity is to invest in children at the dawn of life to try harder to snap the cycle of poverty.

headline: Age of Austerity
text: Zachary Goldfarb defends the argument that we’ve been living in an age of austerity against conservative denialists. He’s right, of course — but I think there are more graphic ways to make the point.

headline: Mets’ Matt Harvey Tosses a Ball for the First Time Since Surgery
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Exactly four months after having Tommy John surgery on his right elbow, Matt Harvey stood in the outfield grass at the Mets’ complex Saturday and tossed a baseball 20 times to the bullpen catcher Dave Racaniello about 60 feet away.

headline: Ready to Shed 2 Players, Knicks Let Game Get Away
text: ATLANTA — As the ball went up for the opening tip at Philips Arena on Saturday night, Cole Aldrich draped his left arm over the back of the folding chair next to him. It was empty.

headline: Reel-Life Anniversary
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s a strange feeling when someone has the same name as you.

headline: The Memory Stone
text: This is the last part of an eight-part series.

headline: Obama to Propose Shift in Wildfire Funding
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s annual budget request to Congress will propose a significant change in how the government pays to fight wildfires, administration officials said, a move that they say reflects the ways in which climate change is increasing the risk for and cost of those fires.

headline: Behind Gates, Bizarre Vision of Opulence
text: KIEV, Ukraine — An eerie calm and a light mist shrouded President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s sprawling residential compound just outside the capital on Saturday morning as street fighters from the center of Kiev made their way inside, gingerly passing a wrought-iron gate and cautioning one another about booby traps and snipers.

headline: South Korea Puts Anger Aside After Olympic Skating Disappointment
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Yu-na was a perfect heroine for her country. Like postwar South Korea, she rose from a humble start, skating on a tatty rink as a 6-year-old, to win gold for a nation that had felt sidelined in a sport dominated by Western athletes.

headline: 30 Seconds with Kyle Larson
text: Kyle Larson will begin his first full season in the Nascar Sprint Cup Series at the Daytona 500 on Sunday, driving the No. 42 car for Target Chip Ganassi Racing.

headline: A Hot Debate Over E-Cigarettes as a Path to Tobacco, or From It
text: Dr. Michael Siegel, a hard-charging public health researcher at Boston University, argues that e-cigarettes could be the beginning of the end of smoking in America. He sees them as a disruptive innovation that could make cigarettes obsolete, like the computer did to the typewriter.

headline: After Farmers Commit Suicide, Debts Fall on Families in India
text: BOLLIKUNTA, India — Latha Reddy Musukula was making tea on a recent morning when she spotted the money lenders walking down the dirt path toward her house. They came in a phalanx of 15 men, by her estimate. She knew their faces, because they had walked down the path before.

headline: Opening the Corporation
text: Software may be eating the world, as Marc Andreessen likes to say, but the habits around modern software seem to have just as profound an impact.

headline: An Underground Eye for the Border Patrol
text: Federal agents rely on military-grade robots to search drug-smuggling tunnels in Nogales, Ariz.

headline: Border’s New Sentinels Are Robots, Penetrating Deepest Drug Routes
text: NOGALES, Ariz. — Tom Pittman has made a career as a Border Patrol agent here guarding this city’s underground drainage system, where the tunnels that carry sewage and storm runoff between the United States and Mexico are also busy drug-smuggling routes. Over the years, he has crawled and slithered past putrid puddles, makeshift latrines and discarded needles left behind by drug users, relying on instincts, mostly, to gauge the risks ahead.

headline: Opponents of Same-Sex Marriage Take Bad-for-Children Argument to Court
text: As they reel from a succession of defeats in courtrooms and legislatures, opponents of same-sex marriage have a new chance this week to play one of their most emotional and, they hope, potent cards: the claim that having parents of the same sex is bad for children.

headline: Officer Shoots Knife-Wielding Woman in Brooklyn, Police Say
text: A police officer shot a woman inside a Brooklyn apartment on Saturday after she lunged at officers with a knife, an official said.

headline: Mexican Drug Kingpin Is Captured
text: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, “El Chapo,” one of Mexico’s top drug bosses and a Forbes list billionaire since 2009, was captured today in a Mexican resort after a 13-year manhunt.

headline: Asylum Fraud in Chinatown: An Industry of Lies
text: A Chinese woman walked into a law office in New York’s Chinatown and asked to see her lawyer. She had applied for asylum, claiming that she had been forced to get an abortion in China to comply with the country’s family-planning laws, and she was anxious about her coming interview with immigration officials.

headline: Wildcat Red Emerges as Derby Contender
text: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — The trainer Jose Garoffalo spent all of his $30,000 budget last June to buy Wildcat Red as a 2-year-old, never imagining the bargain he was bringing home.

headline: A Lesson for Detroit in Efforts to Aid a New Orleans Devastated by Katrina
