text: NEW ORLEANS — As Detroit confronts some of the most intractable challenges of any city in America, with an array of civic leaders and urban planners offering solutions and ideas, it may be helpful to consider Harvey Bender.

headline: In Japan’s Drill With the U.S., a Message for Beijing
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. — In the early morning along a barren stretch of beach here last week, Japanese soldiers and American Marines practiced how to invade and retake an island captured by hostile forces.

headline: Horst Rechelbacher, ‘Father of Safe Cosmetics,’ Dies at 72
text: Horst Rechelbacher, an Austrian-born hairstylist who went on to found Aveda, a company whose pledge to eliminate toxic chemicals from its products helped give rise to a vast market for so-called natural cosmetics in the United States, died on Feb. 15 in Osceola, Wis. He was 72.

headline: The Wisconsin Labor Fight
text: An epic fight with unions continues to dominate the tenure of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin.

headline: Princeton a Repeat Champ at Amateur Tournament
text: Princeton University’s A team won the United States Amateur Team East championship last week for the second year in a row.

headline: Terry Adkins, Composer of Art, Sculptor of Music, Dies at 60
text: Terry Adkins, a conceptual artist whose work married the quicksilver evanescence of music to the solid permanence of sculpture, died on Feb. 8 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 60.

headline: Lviv, in Western Ukraine, Mourns One of Its Own Killed in Kiev
text: LVIV, Ukraine — Under a leaden sky that wept intermittent rain, this fiercely proud city bade farewell on Saturday to one of its sons, a 28-year-old university lecturer killed by a bullet on Thursday in Kiev in the carnage on and around Independence Square.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 22, 2014
Environmental Groups Resort to Suing Industries Directly
text: Starting Monday, a federal judge in Waco will hear arguments from the Sierra Club that Luminant Generation Company, the state’s largest electric generator, has been spewing far more pollution into the air from an East Texas coal plant than is allowed by federal and state law.

headline: For the Sake of the Primaries, a Simple Vision
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Kerry Says Venezuela Crackdown Is ‘Unacceptable’
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Secretary of State John Kerry has markedly stepped up his criticism of Venezuela over its response to more than two weeks of antigovernment demonstrations, as the protests continued to grow this weekend.

headline: Trying to Help Thousands in Colonias Obtain Health Coverage
text: EDINBURG — Sitting at an old picnic table in front of a dilapidated house, María Díaz, a hotel housekeeper, tells stories of the rejection that comes with living in impoverished Texas colonias.

headline: Let’s Talk a Bit More About Bates and Anna
text: Ernie Manouse traveled to Amsterdam at the end of August 2012 but spent the three-day trip holed up in his hotel room, unexpectedly binging on the first two seasons of “Downton Abbey.”

headline: After Boeheim Leaves in a Rage, Syracuse Exits With a Loss
text: DURHAM, N.C. — Forward C. J. Fair had never played at Cameron Indoor Stadium before Saturday night. Point guard Tyler Ennis had never dribbled on Coach K Court. Guard Trevor Cooney had never risen for a 3-pointer with the Cameron Crazies screaming at him.

headline: Declaring Victory in Kiev
text: After months of protests and a week of bloody mayhem, demonstrators in Independence Square celebrated the departure of President Viktor F. Yanukovych.

headline: A Forensic Approach to a Sidewalk Nuisance
text: NAPLES, Italy — Problems? Yes, conceded Tommaso Sodano, the vice mayor here, Naples has problems. Unpaid debts have reportedly topped $2 billion. Many streets are pocked with potholes. The police department is underfunded, organized crime operates like a shadow state, and illegal dumps are scattered around what is still a grittily beautiful port city.

headline: Monica Hickey and Joseph Coquelin
text: Monica Clare Hickey and Joseph Anthony Coquelin were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the city clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Grace Lin, Michael Paley
text: Grace Liting Lin, a daughter of Jane S. Tsai and William T. Lin of Indianapolis, was married Saturday evening to Michael Alexander Paley, the son of Marianne Steiner and Dr. Robert H. Paley of Washington. Cantor Sharon Grainer officiated in the Hamilton Garden at the Kimmel Center in Philadelphia.

headline: Ruth Halvey and Francisco Morales Barrón
text: Ruth Kathryn Halvey, a daughter of Louise Platt Halvey and Dr. Cornelius H. Halvey of Sarasota, Fla., was married there Saturday evening to Francisco José Morales Barrón, a son of Odette Barrón and José A. Morales of Zapopan, Mexico. Cantor Marci Vitkus officiated at the Field Club.

headline: Bronwen Baumgardner and David Sanders
text: Bronwen Baumgardner, a daughter of Colleen Reidy Baumgardner and Andrew Baumgardner of Fairfield, Conn., was married Saturday to David Robert Sanders, a son of Isabelle Peck Sanders and the Rev. Robert E. Sanders of Waterbury, Vt. The groom’s father, a Presbyterian minister who retired as the pastor to Princeton Theological Seminary, officiated at the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. John E. Barclay, also a Presbyterian minister, participated.

headline: Marissa Teicher, Andrew Miller
text: Marissa Ellen Teicher and Andrew Douglas Miller were married Saturday evening at Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein officiated.

headline: Gillian Tullman, Ryan Whalen
text: Gillian Blythe Tullman and Ryan James Whalen were married Saturday at the Harvard Club in New York. Judge William J. Corbett, who retired as a village justice of Floral Park, N.Y., officiated.

headline: Priscilla Painton and Andrew Heyward
text: Priscilla Painton and Andrew John Heyward were married Tuesday evening at the Manhattan home of their friends Lili Lynton and Michael Ryan. Judge Carol Stokinger, the supervising judge of Queens County Family Court, officiated.

headline: Emily Hart Cobb, Bradley Breece
text: Emily Hart Cobb, a daughter of Margaret M. Cobb and Ike W. Cobb of Atlanta, was married Saturday to Bradley Joseph Breece, a son of Rose D. Breece and Brooks J. Breece of Dale City, Va. The Rev. Joanna Adams performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Atlanta.

headline: Lea Paganelli, Ryan Cassidy
text: Lea O’Brien Paganelli and Ryan John Cassidy were married Saturday at the First Parish Church of Groton in Groton, Mass. The Rev. Dr. John A. Nelson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jamie Shupak, Brian Stelter
text: Jamie Gayle Shupak and Brian Patrick Stelter were married Saturday evening at the Sheraton Society Hill in Philadelphia. Cantor Amy E. Levy performed the ceremony.

headline: Nathan Lump and Charles Runnette
text: Nathan Lump and Charles Runnette were married Saturday evening at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in New York. The officiant was Mary Shields, a friend of the couple who is a minister affiliated with the Church of Gaiabriel in Alexandria, Va.

headline: Ninamarie Bojekian, Daniel Mendoza
text: Ninamarie Bojekian, the daughter of Maria Bojekian and Stephen Bojekian of Franklin Lakes. N.J., was married Saturday to Daniel Manuel Mendoza, a son of Olga Delgado-Mendoza and Carlos A. Mendoza, both of North Bergen, N.J. The Rev. Panagiotis Lekkas, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony at St. John the Theologian Cathedral in Tenafly, N.J., with the Rev. Basil Gikas, also Greek Orthodox, taking part.

headline: Hinda Schuman, Susan Toler
text: Hinda Schuman and Susan Gayle Toler were married Saturday in Brooklyn at the apartment of Thomas Halper and his wife, Marilyn Halper. Mr. Halper, who is a Universal Life minister and a cousin of Ms. Schuman, officiated.

headline: Zoe Settle, James Schriebl
text: Zoe Grace Settle and James Hubert Schriebl were married Saturday evening in New York. Peter Kendall, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

headline: Sarah Norton, Michael Burns
text: Sarah Christine Norton and Michael George Burns were married Saturday at the Old Mission Church in Santa Barbara, Calif. The Rev. Larry Gosselin, a Franciscan friar and the associate pastor of St. Barbara Parish at the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Amanda Wolin, Jonathan Moskowitz
text: Amanda Nicole Wolin and Jonathan David Moskowitz were married Saturday at the Four Seasons Los Angeles. Cantor Marcus Feldman performed the ceremony.

headline: Angeli Saijwani and Rahul Sharma
text: Angeli Saijwani and Dr. Rahul Sharma were married Saturday at Cipriani 42nd Street, an event space in Manhattan. Pandit Himanshu D. Jani, a Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: Sara Gillesby, Peter Sabatino
text: Sara Michelle Gillesby and Peter Anthony Sabatino were married Saturday at Devil’s Thumb Ranch in Tabernash, Colo. The Rev. Martin N. Hunckler, a retired Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

headline: He Won Her Vote
text: Amy Cecilia Salomone and Nicholas Justin Thornton were married Saturday by the Rev. Emmanuel Taylor at St. Dominic’s Catholic Church in San Francisco.

headline: Big Shot by Curry and Frustrating Night for Nets
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Stephen Curry has delivered countless late-game daggers. His latest one left his hand askew, but it did its job nevertheless.

text: METROPOLITAN

headline: Gas Leak Kills Man at Long Island Mall
text: A carbon monoxide leak at a mall on Long Island killed one person Saturday night and sickened more than two dozen, according to the local authorities.

headline: Taliban Raid Afghan Army Base, Killing Soldiers in Their Sleep
text: ASADABAD, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents overran an Afghan National Army base near here on Sunday morning, killing 21 soldiers in their bunks in what appeared to be the worst single blow to government forces since 2010, according to both government and insurgent officials.

headline: Ukraine Rushes to Shift Power and Mend Rifts
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukrainian lawmakers moved swiftly on Sunday to assert control over the government, racing to restore calm after a week of upheaval and bloodshed that ended in President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s flight and ouster on Saturday, and in sudden fears that the country might fall into civil war.

headline: In Milan
text: Designers send out their autumn 2014 collections, with highlights ranging from furry fantasies to intricate embellishment.

headline: Sochi Olympics Closing Ceremony Latest Updates
text: Russia had so much to prove at the Winter Games. That spending however-many-billion dollars to build an Olympics-industrial complex from scratch on the edge of the Black Sea was worth it. That despite a thicket of security worries, logistical obstacles, weather annoyances and the darkening specter of revolution in nearby Ukraine, the country could put on a Games that ran seamlessly, at times even exuberantly.

headline: Marni: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: Strong Finish Gives Russia Most Medals
text: SOCHI, Russia — The host country shone on Sunday, the final day of the 2014 Winter Olympics, as Alexander Zubkov drove Russia to victory in the four-man bobsled, Alexander Legkov led a Russian sweep of the 50-kilometer cross-country skiing race, and Russia ended the Games at the top of the medals table.

headline: In Our Pages: February 24
text: 1914: French Armored Cruiser Driven Ashore

headline: The Price of a Child I Wouldn’t Let Go
text: When I was a child, my family never discussed money. It was sufficient to know we didn’t have any. I was the quintessential American dream: girl from a trailer park who ate government cheese but became a first-generation high school graduate. I went on to earn a master’s degree and sit solidly in the top 25 percent of taxpayers, hovering around six figures as a family, a demographic reached with great effort.

headline: Stingy Defense Adds to Canada’s Gold Pile
text: SOCHI, Russia — The Canadian men’s hockey team was one of the favorites to win the gold medal here when the Winter Games began, and on the road to the final, it steamrollered Norway and Austria before winning battles over Finland, Latvia and the United States.

headline: Samsung Introduces Two New Smartwatches
text: Samsung Electronics introduced two new smartwatches on Sunday, the Gear 2 and Gear 2 Neo, and dropped the popular Galaxy branding from its first smartwatch, the Galaxy Gear. Also, unlike Samsung’s first smartwatch, the new products use Tizen, an operating system that Samsung developed with several partners, instead of Google’s Android.

headline: Live Stream | Missoni’s Fall 2014 Collection at Milan Fashion Week
text: The latest women’s collection from Missoni at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: An Odd Couple in the News Business Partner in a Series on Fatherhood
text: In recent days, The Deseret News, a newspaper in Salt Lake City, prominently displayed on its website a feature about Mormons on reality TV shows. The Atlantic magazine’s home page, meanwhile, drew readers to an article on why women struggle to write about sex.

headline: Fatal Violence Strikes Antigovernment Rallies in Thailand
text: BANGKOK — Four people were killed, including three children, and more than 50 injured at antigovernment protests in Thailand over the weekend as the country’s protracted power struggle gave rise to more violence.

headline: What Did I Know and When Did I Know It?
text: The big takeaway from the 2008 Fed transcripts is that for the most part Fed officials other than Janet Yellen and Eric Rosengren failed to appreciate the danger the economy was in — that many were preoccupied with the supposed threat of inflation even as a once-in-three-generations crisis in demand was building.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Jil Sander Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: After WhatsApp Deal, Visions of Magic Numbers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — “What’s your number?”

headline: The Myth of German Austerity
text: Every once in a while I hear people trying to dismiss the overwhelming evidence for large economic damage from fiscal austerity by pointing to Germany: “You say that austerity hurts growth, but the Germans have done a lot of austerity and they’re booming.”

headline: Can California Avoid a ‘Shock to Trance’ Approach to Water Policy?
text: Forecasters predict heavy rains will sweep in from the Pacific Ocean over much of California late next week. The state’s extreme drought will be far from over, but the shift from parched days to downpours illustrates on a short time scale one factor explaining why it’s hard to change deeply ingrained and wasteful approaches to water policy.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Emilio Pucci Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 7 P.M. (NBC) NANCY & TONYA (2014) In this documentary, Mary Carillo looks back at events leading up to the 1994 Winter Olympics, which pitted the figure skater Nancy Kerrigan against her rival Tonya Harding (above left, with Ms. Kerrigan), just weeks after Ms. Harding’s ex-husband and bodyguard were charged with plotting an attack on Ms. Kerrigan that injured her knee. Both women are interviewed, as are their coaches, the skater Scott Hamilton and members of the media. The closing ceremony of the Sochi Games follows at 8.

headline: Nicklas Backstrom Misses Final After Failed Drug Test
text: SOCHI, Russia — Nicklas Backstrom, a player for the Washington Capitals in the N.H.L. who represented Sweden in its five victories on the way to the Olympic gold medal game, failed a drug test at the Sochi Games. He was removed from Sweden’s lineup Sunday before the final, which Canada won, 3-0.

headline: Missoni: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: Model-Morphosis | Lindsey Wixson at Emilio Pucci
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Lindsey Wixson (left) and after (right) makeup by Yadim and hair by Luigi Murenu.

headline: Those Lego Bricks Keep Piling Up at the Box Office
text: And the Lego pieces keep marching on. For the third weekend in a row, “The Lego Movie” was the top draw at North American theaters, while an expensive new volcano adventure, “Pompeii,” blew its chance at profitability. “The Lego Movie” (Warner Brothers) took in an estimated $31.5 million, for a new domestic total of $183.2 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles box-office data.

headline: Bottega Veneta: Tomas Maier Turns Soft Into Sharp
text: MILAN — Taking a scalpel to all that is fancy, yet controlling pattern in a defined space. It sounds so easy. Yet only a designer of the caliber of Tomas Maier atBottega Veneta can pull off such a combination.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana Create a Fashion Fairytale
text: MILAN — There was not a church, a cross or a Sicilian landscape in sight as Dolce & Gabbana sent out its winter 2014 show on Sunday. Instead, falling snow, the bare branches of winter trees and Tchaikovsky’s soaring music started a fashion fairy tale.

headline: Ominous Stirrings In a Fitful Realm
text: BERLIN — The nightmares evoked by the title of Georg Friedrich Haas’s new “dark dreams,” which the Berlin Philharmonic played with its chief conductor, Simon Rattle, on Saturday evening at the Philharmonie here, involve repetition and circling back: the ominous sense that even as things change, they remain the same.

headline: A Fall Collection, and a Giant New Boutique, From Cavalli
text: Roberto Cavalli’s ambitions have never run small. Not content to simply put on a show at Milan Fashion Week, he staged what his team called a Roberto Cavalli Day.

headline: Jason Collins, First Openly Gay N.B.A. Player, Signs With Nets and Appears in Game
text: LOS ANGELES — Jason Collins, a 35-year-old center, signed a 10-day contract with the Nets on Sunday afternoon and played against the Lakers hours later, appearing in an N.B.A. uniform for the first time since last spring, when he announced that he was gay.

headline: Q.&A. With Joe Belfiore on the Future of Windows Phone
text: Joe Belfiore is the corporate vice president of Microsoft Windows Phone, and he oversees the software that powers handsets using the company’s operating system. Microsoft is expected to close its $7.2 billion deal to buy the handset and services division of Nokia by the end of March. The acquisition will give Microsoft control of both mobile software and hardware, as it looks to expand its 4 percent market share in global smartphone sales. Mr. Belfiore will play a crucial role in Microsoft’s efforts to take on Apple and the cellphone makers that use Google’s Android operating system.

headline: Strutting With Style in Sochi
text: They come in Red Army hats, silly hats, even cowboy hats. They have painted faces and wigs in the national colors. A few wear bear costumes, tongue-in-cheek displays as much for the television cameras as for the tourists.

headline: Salvatore Ferragamo: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: Michigan Beats Michigan State to Grab Big Ten Lead
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Nik Stauskas had been quiet and cold for the better part of February. Stauskas, a sophomore guard, had scored more than 11 points once in Michigan’s past five games, and with him taking just three shots in the first half against Michigan State on Sunday, the dormancy seemed likely to continue.

headline: MSGM: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Milan

headline: At Mobile World Congress, a Sign of Tech Industry’s Shifting Focus
text: In a sign that the tech industry may have moved past computers, Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, will be the most prominent speaker this week at the Mobile World Congress, a trade show in Barcelona that revolves around smartphones and other devices.

headline: Taking Stock in Ukraine
text: Ukrainians turned out in Kiev to mourn those who died in last week’s conflict while pro-Yanukovych protests took place in several cities in the south and east.

text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Old Railroad Stirs Memories of a Pre-Industrial China
text: My father rode the Xinning Railway once. He was 4 years old and traveling from Hong Kong with his parents and older brother to their ancestral village in Guangdong Province. It was 1936, in a China without six-lane highways and gleaming airports. They were returning to the countryside to build a new family home.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Bailout
text: Notes here (pdf).

headline: Sochi Wrap-Up
text: Athletes discuss their experiences getting into the 2014 Olympics and once in Sochi.

headline: Comcast and Netflix Reach Deal on Service
text: Comcast, the country’s largest cable and broadband provider, and Netflix, the giant television and movie streaming service, announced an agreement Sunday in which Netflix will pay Comcast for faster and more reliable access to Comcast’s subscribers.

headline: Happy Days and Happy Feet, Despite the Depression
text: What, if anything, does it mean that the giddiest, most euphoric popular music ever produced in the United States bubbled and kicked up its heels while the country was sliding into the Great Depression? That question hovered over the joyous opening-night performance on Saturday of “Sweepin’ the Clouds Away: Boom, Bust and High Spirits,” presented by the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series, almost all of whose songs were written between 1929 and 1932.

headline: A Hint of Jazz From a Classical Quartet
text: The superb Quatuor Ébène has made a name for itself not only as an elegant purveyor of classical fare but also for jazz performances. That influence could be heard on Friday evening at Zankel Hall in the group’s encore, an arrangement of Erroll Garner’s “Misty,” and in its interpretation of Schumann’s String Quartet in A (Op. 41, No. 3).

headline: Floating Together, Staring and Circling
text: No man is an island, John Donne said, and it would seem that the choreographer Vanessa Anspaugh agrees. In her “we were an island,” which debuted at Danspace Project on Thursday, the five performers are distinctive, but the connections among them are more various and ineluctable than they appear on the surface. Once the dancers have all made their entrances, no one escapes the others’ gaze.

headline: Balanchine and Robbins, With Echoes of a Long-Ago Star
text: What seemed like just another New York City Ballet program on Friday night at the David H. Koch Theater turned out to be nothing of the sort. It was impossible to be in the presence of Jerome Robbins’s “Afternoon of a Faun” and George Balanchine’s “La Valse” without thinking of Tanaquil le Clercq.

headline: Stories and Explanations Rooted in the Personal
text: One part of Asaf Avidan, the Israeli songwriter who gave a solo concert on Friday night at Irving Plaza, is a lot like Leonard Cohen: the Leonard Cohen who sings delicately fingerpicked songs full of finely calibrated metaphors, aphoristic phrases, paradoxes and mournful romance. “I said, Baby you are magic/ She said, No, hon, just a trick,” he sang in “Anchor.”

headline: A Four-and-a-Half-Ring Circus Ends, and a Relieved Russia Roars
text: SOCHI, Russia — Russia had so much to prove at the Winter Games. Was spending however-many billions of dollars to build an Olympics-industrial complex from scratch on the edge of the Black Sea worth it? How could the country overcome a thicket of potential problems: security worries, logistical obstacles, weather annoyances and the darkening specter of revolution in nearby Ukraine?

headline: A Show of Love: Farewell, City Opera
text: Often, when a performing arts institution is forced to shut down, it at least is able to present a special closing performance, an occasion for artists and audiences to look back at all the accomplishments and find comfort together.

headline: Audiences That Devise Game Plans
text: On Friday at New York Live Arts, in the wake of a government collapse, 63 citizens — “humanoids,” we were called — gathered to develop strategies for rebuilding society. There to help us were two experts in catastrophe survival from the former Yugoslavia.

headline: Thailand at an Impasse
text: Thailand rolls to a democratic standstill.

headline: Seth Meyers: Smart Guy in the Wiseguy Seat
text: Seth Meyers is the oldest, most experienced and most hostlike comedian to take the reins of NBC’s three-decade-old “Late Night.”

headline: Writers’ Biographer Creates a Portrait of His Own Family
text: Blake Bailey has now written four books about families blessed with literary talent and plagued by the ravages of alcohol. His fierce affinity for these subjects is now a little easier to understand. The writers Richard Yates, John Cheever (my father-in-law) and Charles Jackson, who wrote what he knew in his novel “The Lost Weekend,” all spoke to Mr. Bailey’s own turbulent background. Both he and, to a much greater extent, his older brother, Scott, walked a thin line between self-discipline and drunken disaster.

headline: Applying Olympic Sinew to Strauss
text: The Winter Olympics may have been seven time zones away, in Sochi, Russia, but energy, athleticism and showmanship also filled the air at another Olympus, Carnegie Hall, on Friday evening, in a concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra.

headline: Looking for Characters
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Time to hit the reset button and get started on a brand new week. After two challenging Sunday puzzles, a Monday crossword is a most welcome sight.

headline: Listening to Ancients in Zimbabwe and Finding a Prehistoric Fable
text: Coming up with the right story for a new musical is notoriously difficult. Yet the measures that Chris Berry took to get the narrative for “The Legend of Yauna” still count as extreme. Mr. Berry, a musician of European descent, has said that the tale came to him in Zimbabwe, through a spiritual medium, from people who lived 12,000 years ago.

headline: What the West Must Do for Ukraine
text: BRUSSELS — Thanks in part to the coordinated efforts of Germany, Poland, France and the United States, irrevocable change has finally come to Ukraine, with President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s flight from Kiev and Parliament’s vote to call for new elections in May.

headline: ‘12 Years a Slave’ Is Headed to Schools
text: High school students could soon be studying “12 Years a Slave.” Starting in September, the film, the book and a study guide will be distributed to public high schools by the National School Boards Association in partnership with New Regency, Penguin Books and the filmmakers. Montel Williams coordinated the program, which is modeled after similar distribution by “The Montel Williams Show” of copies of the Civil War film “Glory.” “When Hollywood is at its best, the power of the movies can be harnessed into a powerful educational tool,” Mr. Williams said in a statement. “This film uniquely highlights a shameful period in American history, and in doing so will evoke in students a desire to not repeat the evils of the past while inspiring them to dream big of a better and brighter future.” Steve McQueen, above, the film’s director, said: “Since first reading ‘12 Years a Slave,’ it has been my dream that this book be taught in schools.”

headline: NBC to Bring Back ‘Heroes’ in New Form
text: They’re coming back: once-dead television series, that is — revived as so-called event series by networks discovering a form that has distinguished cable drama for much of the past decade. The latest example is the onetime hit science-fiction series “Heroes,” which NBC announced it would resurrect as “Heroes Reborn,” a 13-episode series in 2015. The network used its platform of the Winter Olympics to tease out the announcement on Saturday, running a brief promotion. The news release that followed on Saturday night confirmed a few details: Tim Kring, who created the original “Heroes” in the 2006 television season, will be back as the executive producer. Before that, NBC is to create a digital series that will introduce the new story and characters. (Some original cast members may return.) Jennifer Salke, NBC’s president for entertainment, said in a statement that most details about the new version would be “appropriately shrouded in mystery.” Exactly when the show might appear is not known. Perhaps NBC will wait to see how the most immediate progenitor of the idea, Fox’s revival of “24,” fares this summer. CBS fashioned a hit last summer out of “Under the Dome” and has another such event-style short-run sci-fi series, “Extant,” with Halle Berry, planned for this summer.

headline: At New England Knockout Team Regional, Rules Are Rules
text: At the New England Knockout Team Regional in Cromwell, Conn., this month Jared Lilienstein and Michael Polowan of New York City entered the two-session Wednesday A/B Pairs. In the diagramed deal, they got a tied top, but it cost them first place. How?

Three years after taking over for Larry King, Mr. Morgan has seen the ratings for “Piers Morgan Live” hit some new lows, drawing a fraction of viewers compared with competitors at Fox News and MSNBC.

headline: Vows: A Temporary Separation
text: When Hinda Schuman and Susan Toler separated, Ms. Schuman made a photography series about their breakup. They could only stand eight months apart, however, and are set to wed after 32 years together.

Miller, an Olympian since 1998, was somehow turning back the clock and had made himself the favorite in the opening, and premier, ski racing event of the Sochi Games.

headline: Top Military Body Against Syria’s Assad Is in Chaos, Undermining Fight

headline: Amid the Triumphs, an Argument for Tolerance
text: SOCHI, Russia — The closing ceremony of the Sochi Games on Sunday night was a celebration of everything Russian, and everything that Russia does so well.

headline: Expand Pre-K, Not A.D.H.D.
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — THE writing is on the chalkboard. Over the next few years, America can count on a major expansion of early childhood education. We embrace this trend, but as health policy researchers, we want to raise a major caveat: Unless we’re careful, today’s preschool bandwagon could lead straight to an epidemic of 4- and 5-year-olds wrongfully being told that they have attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

headline: Genetically Modified Babies
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — AN advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration is set to begin two days of meetings tomorrow to consider radical biological procedures that, if successful, would produce genetically modified human beings. This is a dangerous step. These techniques would change every cell in the bodies of children born as a result of their use, and these alterations would be passed down to future generations.

headline: Health Care Horror Hooey
text: Remember the “death tax”? The estate tax is quite literally a millionaire’s tax — a tax that affects only a tiny minority of the population, and is mostly paid by a handful of very wealthy heirs. Nonetheless, right-wingers have successfully convinced many voters that the tax is a cruel burden on ordinary Americans — that all across the nation small businesses and family farms are being broken up to pay crushing estate tax liabilities.

headline: How a Kingpin Above the Law Fell, Incredibly, Without a Shot
text: MAZATLÁN, Mexico — They reacted here with utter disbelief. Joaquín Guzmán Loera, El Chapo, drug kingpin to the world, the Robin Hood of Sinaloa, had been arrested in his home state, in the resort town that is a loyal fief of his empire?

headline: For Detroit, New Stage in Its Race to Recover
text: DETROIT — Labor union leaders said they hated it. Financial creditors said it was lopsided against them. Some community leaders said it favored the banks over ordinary people. And at least one pension fund official called it premature and draconian.

headline: Crime and Punishment and Obama
text: I DOUBT any president has been as well equipped as Barack Obama to appreciate the vicious cycle of American crime and punishment. As a community organizer in Chicago in the 1980s, he would have witnessed the way a system intended to protect the public siphoned off young black men, gave them an advanced education in brutality, and then returned them to the streets unqualified for — and too often, given the barriers to employment faced by those who have done time, disqualified from — anything but a life of more crime. He would have understood that the suffering of victims and the debasing of offenders were often two sides of the same coin.

headline: Let the E.P.A. Do Its Job
text: On Monday, for the third time in seven years, the Supreme Court will consider the scope of the federal government’s power to regulate the emission of greenhouse gases, which are a major contributor to global climate change.

headline: Locked Away in Immigration Jails
text: You can find examples of federal detainees held inexplicably for years without criminal charges or bond hearings much closer to home than Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: New Version of Two-Faced YotaPhone to Have Larger Screens and More Power
text: The Russian start-up Yota Devices will reveal on Monday the next generation of its unusual two-faced YotaPhone at the Mobile World Congress event in Barcelona. The phone stands apart from many of its smartphone peers — which often appear similar to each other — by having a conventional color touchscreen on one side and a low-power electronic paper display filling its other side.

headline: Blast Kills 12 Riding in Van in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 12 people were killed and 16 injured when a bomb went off in northwestern Pakistan on Sunday, according to police officials, as security forces continued to attack militant hide-outs in the country’s tribal regions with airstrikes.

headline: A Second Front in the Privacy Wars
text: More than a year before Edward Snowden exposed the vast reach of government surveillance, President Obama proposed a Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights to protect Americans from the prying eyes of Internet companies, advertisers and other businesses. In a February 2012 report, his administration offered a well-reasoned argument for giving consumers more control over how much and what kind of data companies can collect about them and what businesses can do with that information.

headline: First Companies Give to Fund for Victims of Bangladeshi Factory Collapse
text: ROME — Five global clothing brands and retailers on Sunday became the first contributors to a new fund raising $40 million for victims of the Rana Plaza factory disaster in Bangladesh, and activists are campaigning to pressure other brands to also make donations.

headline: Yankees Add Four Years to Gardner’s Deal
text: TAMPA, Fla. — From the moment the Yankees signed Jacoby Ellsbury on Dec. 7, the speculation began that they would trade Brett Gardner. Who, after all, would need two speedy, leadoff center fielders?

headline: Fed’s Aid in 2008 Crisis Stretched Worldwide
text: WASHINGTON — Tuesday morning, Sept. 16, 2008, was perhaps the darkest time for the United States economy in modern memory — even if nobody knew it quite yet. It was barely 24 hours removed from the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers, and a few hours before the government would rescue the insurer American International Group.

headline: N.B.A.’s 10-Day Contract Is Essentially a Job Tryout
text: The N.B.A. is known for its guaranteed contracts, which stand in stark contrast to the free-for-all in the N.F.L., where a player can generally be terminated anytime. An exception in basketball is the 10-day contract, which serves as a risk-free, on-the-job tryout for a player attempting to make a team’s roster.

headline: As His Fortunes Fell in Ukraine, a President Clung to Illusions
text: KIEV, Ukraine — As his allies deserted him and throngs of people bayed for his blood almost within earshot of his office, President Viktor F. Yanukovych took time out on Friday to celebrate Ukraine’s first gold medal at the Olympic Games in Sochi, Russia. In a message of congratulations to the women’s biathlon relay team, he praised its “power and will to win.”

headline: Pentagon Plans to Shrink Army to Pre-World War II Level
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel plans to shrink the United States Army to its smallest force since before the World War II buildup and eliminate an entire class of Air Force attack jets in a new spending proposal that officials describe as the first Pentagon budget to aggressively push the military off the war footing adopted after the terror attacks of 2001.

headline: Fresh From Prison, a Former Prime Minister Returns to the Political Stage
text: KIEV, Ukraine — For nearly two years, foreign officials pleaded with President Viktor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine to let his archrival, former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, leave prison for medical care abroad, but he refused, convinced that she had just one destination in mind: a return to the political stage.

headline: In the DeMint Era at Heritage, a Shift From Policy to Politics
text: WASHINGTON — Not long after Jim DeMint took over the Heritage Foundation last spring, his team summoned the staff for a meeting unlike any the decorous conservative policy organization had ever convened. Music blared in the auditorium. Policy analysts began with a few awkward jokes and then scampered about in a series of skits that laid out the foundation’s goals.

headline: Power Shift Inspires Joy in Kiev, Fury in East
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Red Communist flags flew on Sunday in front of a massive bust of Lenin in this hardscrabble coal-mining city, a stronghold of pro-Russia sentiment in Ukraine. About 500 yards away, a few hundred pro-democracy activists, harangued by hundreds of counterdemonstrators, laid wreaths for the victims of last week’s bedlam in Kiev at a memorial to one of Ukraine’s most revered figures, the 19th-century poet Taras Shevchenko.

headline: Julian Fellowes on Viewer Criticism and ‘Downton Abbey’s’ Future
text: After a royal audience with King George V and Queen Mary of England, and guest appearances by Shirley MacLaine and Paul Giamatti, the fourth season of “Downton Abbey” came to a conclusion on PBS’s “Masterpiece” on Sunday night. No major characters met their demises, but this year, which dealt with the rape of the servant Anna and the introduction of a jazz singer who pursues a perilous romance with Lady Rose, among other story lines, was hardly free of conflict or controversy.

headline: Stability and Chaos, Hallmarks of Presidential Races, Swap Parties

headline: Miracle-Gro Wants More People to Try Their Hand at Gardening
text: A STAPLE of hardware stores and garden centers for more than six decades, Miracle-Gro — with its descriptive, almost cartoonish name — is so recognizable to consumers that other brands, including AT&T and Hyundai, have featured it in their advertisements. To promote its Mini Countryman, which is much larger than its Cooper model, for example, in 2013 Mini USA produced billboards and print ads in which a giant box of Miracle-Gro blue plant food appeared to have spilled onto a green Cooper and caused a growth spurt.

headline: Despite Stroke, Algerian Leader Says He’ll Run for Re-Election

headline: Nets’ Win Is Ordinary, Though the Night Is Anything But

headline: Deeply Bound to Ukraine, Putin Watches and Waits for Next Move
text: MOSCOW — The sudden collapse of the Kremlin-backed government in Ukraine has for now delivered a profound setback to President Vladimir V. Putin’s strategy to deepen political and economic ties with the country and thus keep it from embracing Europe.

headline: Book Review Byline Tally Shows Gender Disparity

text: There is something very different about the latest $1 billion IBM is throwing at cloud computing. This sum says as much about the way the cloud is changing IBM as it says about the way IBM is pursuing the business of renting software and computing power over the Internet.

headline: Play About Detroit Riots Wins Kennedy Drama Prize
text: Dominique Morisseau’s “Detroit ’67” has won the Edward M. Kennedy Prize for Drama Inspired by American History, Columbia University and Jean Kennedy Smith are expected to announce on Monday. The prize, which was created in 2012 and first awarded last year, was endowed by Ms. Smith to honor her late brother’s legacy and is announced around his birthday, Feb. 22. The award includes a $100,000 cash prize as well as assistance from the Columbia Center for New Media Teaching and Learning at Columbia University Libraries in creating a teaching website that will put the work in historical context, and offer study guides and scholarly discussion.

headline: After a Long Rain Delay, Earnhardt Takes His Second Daytona Title

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 8 P.M. (Investigation Discovery) THE INJUSTICE FILES: SUNDOWN TOWNS By 1936, the practice of forcing African-Americans from all-white communities after the sun set was so prevalent that Victor Green, the Harlem civic leader, wrote the “Negro Motorist Green Book,” a guide to help black travelers avoid places where they might be threatened or even killed. In 1968, the Fair Housing Act, which made it a federal crime to deny equal housing opportunities based on race, creed or national origin, in effect outlawed the existence of these “sundown towns.” But did it eliminate them all? The filmmaker Keith Beauchamp, above, travels the country to find out.

headline: Underneath the Quiet in Kashmir, Youthful Anger Simmers

headline: Bill Thomas, 89, Dies; Editor Guided Los Angeles Times to 9 Pulitzers
text: Bill Thomas, the editor who led The Los Angeles Times from the Watergate years through the presidency of Ronald Reagan, a period in which the paper vastly enlarged its ambition and won nine Pulitzer Prizes, died on Sunday at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Gluten-Free Spaghetti With Baby Broccoli, Mushrooms and Walnuts
text: This week I was really into adding nuts to many of my pasta dishes. They contribute substantial “meaty” texture and wonderful flavor. Baby broccoli is more elegant than regular broccoli, with long wispy florets and thin stems.

headline: Gluten-Free Fettucine With Brussels Sprouts, Lemon and Ricotta
text: Brussels sprouts love a whisper of lemon, which is what the zest provides in this combo. The ricotta becomes creamy when you add a small amount of cooking water from the pasta to it, but you have to serve this right away or the ricotta will stiffen up again. I used gluten free Le Veneziane fettucine made with cornmeal, and thought the color and texture were very good. It only took 5 to 6 minutes to cook.

headline: Gluten-Free Penne With Peas, Ricotta and Tarragon
text: The reason I choose penne for this dish is because I always like the way the peas find their way inside the little tubes. The dish is simple, sweet with tarragon, and very quickly made. You must serve it right away or the ricotta will stiffen.

headline: Facebook Stock Not So Different Than Bitcoin
text: With its extraordinary swoop on WhatsApp last week, Facebook proved its stock is not so different from the crypto-currency of the moment, Bitcoin. They can both be used for certain, specific purposes. Neither is backed by a government. Both depend on vast networks of individuals. And their worth reflects demand, which is based on murky fundamentals. The trick: monetize them while they still have value.

headline: Gluten-Free Spaghetti With Shrimp, Kale and Tomatoes
text: I like to use black kale for this. I blanch it in the pasta cooking water, then I add the chopped blanched leaves to the tomato sauce at the end of cooking, just so they will heat through and soften a little more. I sear the shrimp and make the tomato sauce in the same pan. You can toss shrimp in the tomato sauce or just top each serving with them, which is the way to go if there are vegetarians at the table.

headline: With a Classical Violinist’s Composing Debut, Watch Magazine Adds Music to Its Content

headline: Public Pension Tabs Multiply as States Defer Costs and Hard Choices

Chris Christie of New Jersey overhauled the state’s pension system in 2011, he celebrated it as a bold, bipartisan step toward paying down the state’s costly promises to its retired workers. Some would have to work longer, some would lose inflation adjustments, and both workers and taxpayers would have to pay more into the system.

headline: Natural Big Lies

headline: Huntington’s Conflicts, Fukuyama’s World
text: My Sunday column, on Russian grand strategy and Ukrainian turmoil, doubles as the latest installment in my semi-recurring series dedicated to the idea that ours is still essentially a Francis Fukuyaman world — that is, a world in which the West’s combination of liberal cosmopolitanism and democratic capitalism has no ideological rivals worthy of the name. To elaborate a little on that theme and its significance, let me quote from a Walter Russell Mead essay that ran in the Journal late last week, under the Fukuyama-invoking headline “Putin Knows History Hasn’t Ended”:

headline: Kiss Won’t Play the Rock Hall of Fame Induction
text: The rock band Kiss is about to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and fans of the group have been hoping for a full-scale in-costume reunion of the four players who started the band 40 years ago – Gene Simmons, bass; Paul Stanley, rhythm guitar; Ace Frehley, lead guitar; and Peter Criss, drums. Mr. Frehley and Mr. Criss left and returned several times, and last performed with Kiss a decade ago. But Kiss has continued with other players, including its current guitarist, Tommy Thayer, and drummer, Eric Singer.

headline: Thailand’s Army Chief Cautions Antigovernment Protesters
text: BANGKOK — The head of Thailand’s army, one of the most powerful institutions in the country, appeared to distance himself from the goals of antigovernment protesters in a nationally televised speech on Monday that analysts said was a signal to the Thai public.

headline: Paying the Price for Insider Trading Profits
text: Can a criminal be held responsible for what others gained from his violation? An appeals court answered “yes” when the crime was insider trading and the profits went to a hedge fund rather than directly to the defendant.

headline: ‘How Much Do You Want?’
text: Fast growth entrepreneurs are usually fast talkers, but one of the most valuable lessons that any entrepreneur can learn is when to keep your mouth closed during a negotiation. The hard part is when the other person has learned the same lesson. The hidden rule here is usually this — the one who speaks first loses.

headline: Samsung Unveils Galaxy S5 and Gear Fit, With a Focus on Simplicity

headline: Road-Tripping Through the Wild West, in the Name of Fashion
text: Martin Carvajal and Ben Ferencz, the designers of the men’s clothing and accessories brand FairEnds, live in New York and Missoula, Mont., respectively. This duality shows through in their fun and functional backpacks, bags, hats and shirts — the sort of urbane yet outdoorsy pieces that feel equally at home on Rivington Street or the Ruby River.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Feb. 11-25, 2014
text: The News Quiz took a week of vacation last week, so the 10 questions below cover headline-making events from the last two weeks, from the Olympics to Ukraine to gay rights.

headline: Barcelona Pays $19 Million Tax Related to Neymar Acquisition
text: MADRID — F.C. Barcelona said Monday that it had made a payment of $18.6 million to Spanish tax authorities related to last year’s acquisition of the Brazilian star Neymar in an attempt to settle a legal dispute that has highlighted the opaque and convoluted system of payments used by soccer clubs to sign players.

headline: Why a Fed Governor Bought a Home When He Knew the Market Was Teetering
text: Frederic Mishkin was in a bind. In January 2008, his wife wanted to buy a house, but as we all know now, the housing market was in the midst of a crash. More than one person probably shared similar doubts with friends around the same time, but Mr. Mishkin is a little different. He told his story during a Federal Reserve meeting, as we learned when the minutes were released late last week.

headline: Wall of Riot Police Greets Demonstrators at Sentencing of Moscow Protesters
text: MOSCOW — The riot police officers massed in force on Monday morning outside a courthouse here, well before the judges and the defendants had even arrived, to confront the demonstrators who came to criticize what the authorities have done to political dissent in today’s Russia. The officers erected barriers half a block away and, with blue-and-white police buses parked nearby, formed phalanxes of shields and body armor.

headline: New Italian Premier, in First Speech, Outlines Early Priorities for His Tenure
text: ROME — Making his first appearance before Parliament since becoming prime minister, Matteo Renzi on Monday called for lawmakers to have the courage to make radical change, pledged to push through political and electoral overhauls, and promised bold, innovative measures to revive the moribund economy.

headline: Netflix, Comcast and Net Neutrality
text: A deal announced Sunday between Comcast, the nation’s largest cable and broadband company, and Netflix, the popular video streaming service, raises several troubling questions about the future of the Internet. Under the agreement, Netflix will hook its servers directly to Comcast’s network for an undisclosed fee, cutting out the middlemen that previously connected the companies together.

headline: Ugandan President Discusses Antigay Law
text: President Yoweri Museveni signed into law a controversial bill that introduces lengthy prison sentences for “the promotion or recognition” of homosexual relations.

headline: A Taste You Hate? Just Wait
text: A life breaks down into epochs, with bright dividing lines between them. There’s the period of impotence and innocence before a driver’s license, and the insurance premiums and speeding tickets after. There’s pre-mortgage, when a landlord handles plumbing emergencies, and post-mortgage, when you’re on your soggy own.

headline: Habitat Loss Speeds Up a Kestrel’s Life

headline: How Many Best-Picture Nominees Have You Seen?
text: With blockbusters like “Gravity” and films with more than respectable box office receipts, like “The Wolf of Wall Street,” “American Hustle” and “Captain Phillips,” in the running for best picture, Academy organizers and producers of the Oscars broadcast may be thinking they’re in for a sizable home audience. (Viewership correlates most closely to the box office tally for the nominated films; a year of little-watched indies portends badly for the ratings.) But despite what critics and pundits consider an unusually strong cinematic field, most people have still not seen any of the best picture contenders, according to one recent poll.

Kennedy Jr. and Douglas Kennedy, with their familiar family looks and style, all recorded by a dozen television cameras stationed outside in a biting cold.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: February 21-23, 2014
text: Last month, John Wayne Rogers, 40, escaped first-degree murder charges for shooting his friend to death with an assault rifle after a long drinking session in a Florida hotel room in 2012. After spending two years awaiting trial, a judge granted his Stand Your Ground motion for immunity and ruled that Rogers acted in self-defense. Rogers had testified that the victim, James DeWitt, 34, punched him and threatened his life.
