text: The letter from the landlord said he needed access to the apartments for a couple of weeks to make repairs.

headline: From Buffett, Lessons From His Farm
text: Investors around the world hang on Warren Buffett’s every word, hoping for a scrap of advice from a legendary businessman. Mr. Buffett often dishes out a few morsels of that advice in a letter that coincides with the annual report from his firm, Berkshire Hathaway.

headline: Pope Moves to Reshape Management of Vatican
text: ROME — Pope Francis on Monday announced a major restructuring of the Vatican’s outdated administrative and economic bureaucracy as he established an agency to oversee budgets and financial planning and also created a powerful post of auditor general to guard against fiscal mismanagement.

headline: Blood Pressure Drugs Tied to Risk of Falls
text: Older adults who take blood pressure drugs have a greater risk of serious falls, a new study reports.

headline: Parenting When Even Minimum Wage Is Out of Reach
text: I live in Milwaukee. They just raised the minimum wage here, but I don’t have a job. There are not many options out there. I’m 24 years old, and I have two kids — my son is 4 years old and my daughter is 6.

headline: The Fight for 98 Linden
text: After 23 years of living in their rent-stabilized apartment, Noelia Calero and her family are fighting to stay. The landlord, they say, is using intimidating tactics to push them out.

headline: After Hours | A Digital Deconstruction of Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya”
text: “This Was the End,” an experimental meditation on Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya” at the supercool Long Island City arts space The Chocolate Factory Theater through March 8, begins both mesmerizingly and gratingly. Actors walk and run in and out of the set — a wall of doors of various shapes and sizes, sliding open and closed — while, ingeniously, the same actors do a version of the very same thing in a film projected imperfectly onto it. It’s an eye-popping sight. Meanwhile, a soundscape, chopped up from the Beatles’ “White Album,” assaults you, from speakers fitted close to the audience, half of whom covered their ears. The overall effect is hypnotic and somewhat unbearable. To what end? Is this collage meant to unpack the existential tedium of “Vanya” itself — a play in which characters frustrate us and break our hearts with their doddering romantic and career obsessions and resentments, all the while knowing that nothing will change?

headline: Step 1 Before Red Bulls’ Opener: Remove Foot of Snow
text: Soccer players can be among the most fickle of professional athletes. Things have to be just so, from the cut of their uniforms to the look and feel of their cleats. But what really gets their attention, their extreme, undivided attention, is the condition of the playing surface.

headline: Secrets of the Ages
text: Think too much about your life span and you will never get out of bed in the morning. Once you do, though, all the scientific mysteries of the subject may lie panting on the rug at your feet. Why should your good old faithful dog (avid exerciser, nonsmoker, nondrinker) be condemned to age and die after barely a decade, while you remain firmly in your prime — and the neighbor’s African gray parrot lives loudly on and on?

headline: Monday Motorsports: Dale Earnhardt Jr. Outruns Rain, Crashes and Competition at Daytona
text: Dale Earnhardt Jr. took the victory Sunday in the bruising 2014 running of the prestigious Daytona 500, staying out front much of the second half of a race interrupted for more than six hours by a rain delay.

headline: A Weeknight Fish Chowder Reminiscent of the Shore
text: What’s for Dinner answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: A Mouse Brain to Guide Us, Ear Tubes and Infections, Alan Alda Improvs Science
text: In new efforts to map every nook and neuron of the brain, a mouse is more important than you might think; this one is for the parents out there — a quick primer on how to deal with infections if your child has ear tubes; the actor best known for his role in “M*A*S*H” brings acting techniques into science class.

headline: In a Flood, Ants Really Come Together
text: When the need arises, ants that live in flooded areas can link their bodies together to form buoyant rafts that protect the queen and much of her brood. Now scientists have figured out how they do it.

headline: Help for Endangered Lemurs
text: Lemurs are the most endangered mammal group on the planet. Native to Madagascar, off Africa’s Indian Ocean coast, lemurs have suffered from decades of habitat loss and poaching. If protected in conservation sites managed by local communities, they could see a revival, a group of researchers report in the journal Science.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Stella Jean Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Slow Start for Newly Opened ‘Bridges of Madison County’
text: The new Broadway musical “Bridges of Madison County,” based on a best-selling novel and starring an acclaimed musical theater performer, Kelli O’Hara, opened on Thursday to generally favorable reviews, including some raves. Yet the show is struggling to sell tickets, with a middling gross of $364,888 for eight performances last week, according to box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

headline: Like Columbus, It Floated Here
text: By the time Columbus arrived in the New World in 1492, bottle gourds had already conquered much of the globe. After evolving in Africa, one species, Lagenaria siceraria, made a break for East Asia around 11,000 years ago and eventually took up residence in Polynesia, China, Peru and beyond, earning the title of most widely distributed pre-Columbian domesticated plant.

headline: Harold Ramis, Director, Actor and Alchemist of Comedy, Dies at 69
text: Harold Ramis, a writer, director and actor whose boisterous but sly silliness helped catapult comedies like “Groundhog Day,” “Ghostbusters,” “Animal House” and “Caddyshack” to commercial and critical success, died on Monday in his Chicago-area home. He was 69.

headline: For the Supreme Court, a Case Poses a Puzzle on the E.P.A.’s Authority
text: WASHINGTON — In trying to decide whether the Environmental Protection Agency has the authority under two programs to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from stationary sources like power plants, the Supreme Court on Monday faced what Justice Elena Kagan called “the conundrum here.”

headline: New ‘Sleeping Beauty’ to Mark American Ballet Theater’s 75th Anniversary
text: American Ballet Theater will mark the 75th anniversary of its founding next year with a new production of “The Sleeping Beauty” choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky and based on the production Léon Bakst created for Diaghilev’s Ballets Russes in 1921, the company announced.

headline: Clues to a Very Old Extinction and Pizza for War Zones
text: A homicide trail that had been cold for 252 million years is suddenly warm. A new vaccine can withstand high temperatures, and here comes pizza that doesn’t need a fridge. Even January, it turns out, was warmer than you thought.

headline: Syria War Stirs New U.S. Debate on Cyberattacks
text: WASHINGTON — Not long after the uprising in Syria turned bloody, late in the spring of 2011, the Pentagon and the National Security Agency developed a battle plan that featured a sophisticated cyberattack on the Syrian military and President Bashar al-Assad’s command structure.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Russia, Thailand and South Sudan.

headline: The Secrets of Film Sound
text: Melena Ryzik visits Skywalker Sound and learns how sound designers make movies come to life.

headline: Thomas Is Getting a New Chance to Break Precedent (if Not Silence)
text: WASHINGTON — Here is a good way to get a belly laugh from Justice Clarence Thomas: Suggest to him that the Supreme Court’s decisions should seldom be overruled.

headline: Flappy Bird Copycats Keep on Flapping
text: On Feb. 9, the Western world fell into chaos as Flappy Bird, a highly addictive game, was removed from mobile app stores by Dong Nguyen, an independent developer in Vietnam.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Color-Blocked Fur Coats
text: Last season, Miuccia Prada presented furs printed with hibiscus flowers and the artistic renderings of ladies’ faces in a rainbow of bright colors. This season, the ripples of those statement pieces have hit designers’ collections like a tidal wave, making the multicolored fur coat a must-have item for fall 2014. Although it is a trend we have seen before — especially at Céline, where color-blocked fur has become a signature of sorts — the frequency with which we’re now seeing fur with a graphic quality is making what once seemed like a luxury item feel like a new wardrobe staple. We first saw a version in New York at Altuzarra, where the young designer dressed up a simple, dark fur coat with vibrant colors like Yves Klein blue and tangerine. Then at J. Mendel, the house run by a long line of furriers, bold colors and abstract, latticelike color-blocking offered a fresh and modern take on the brand’s signature material. Finally at Marni in Milan, vertical panels of cobalt, white and crimson made an oversize silhouette seem long and lean — and a fluffy, neutral-colored collar provided the ultimate luxurious top-off.

headline: When Men Get Breast Cancer
text: Breast cancer is not always pink.

headline: Trailer for Ukraine’s Uprising Stars Will Smith and Sylvester Stallone
text: Looking for a way to pay tribute to the courage of protesters in Kiev, who refused to be dislodged from Independence Square over the past three months despite violent attacks from the security forces, a Ukrainian video blogger found the words he needed in dubbed versions of two Hollywood action movies.

headline: Closing Olympics Ceremonies Give NBC a Narrow Win on a Crowded Sunday
text: The final night of the Winter Olympics coverage on NBC was the most-watched event on television Sunday night but the competition was formidable, as “Downton Abbey” posted its best audience total ever for a finale on PBS and “The Walking Dead” on AMC scored its usual enormous rating with younger audiences, doubling the total for the Olympics.

headline: A Chilling Vision of a Television Future and Its Prescient Seer
text: In the closing chapter of “Mad as Hell” — informatively subtitled “The Making of ‘Network’ and the Fateful Vision of the Angriest Man in Movies” — Dave Itzkoff lays out how the American media has become even more Chayefskyian in the decades since Paddy Chayefsky, the angry man in question, wrote his crazed, perceptive, unwieldy, galvanizing satiric fantasia set in the world of network television news.

headline: Nodding to Brahms, but Honoring Stern
text: In 1997, while the great violinist Isaac Stern was still alive, Carnegie Hall named its main listening space the Isaac Stern Auditorium, to commemorate his role in helping to save the building from the wrecking ball in 1960. Stern died in 2001, and what more could Carnegie possibly do to honor his memory?

headline: In a Petipa Program, the Exotic Shares Space With the Classical
text: Nineteenth-century ballet, like much of 19th-century European art, loved the Orient. Ballets set in Turkish harems or Indian temples, with costumes and plots that seemed exotic, were highly popular. Yet, as the dance historian Doug Fullington pointed out in an entertaining and enlightening program at the Guggenheim Museum on Sunday, the actual dancing in these productions was almost all classical ballet.

headline: Musicians Sing for a Cause That’s Their Own
text: In the music industry’s big fights over issues like copyright and royalties, it’s usually the titans — record conglomerates, Silicon Valley giants — that clash. But as individual musicians feel squeezed by the digital revolution, they are beginning to speak out in increasing numbers.

headline: Sounds for the Start of the Day
text: On first listening to Beck’s placid, self-possessed 12th studio album, “Morning Phase,” I did not look him up on Wikipedia to see if he’d broken up with his wife. I was not fully functional: The record’s beauty approaches slowly, floats, surrounds and shuts off external awareness in the brain stem.

headline: Chinese Arts Company Goes Public in Bid to Grow
text: SHANGHAI — The China Poly Group Corporation, a state-run conglomerate that got its start selling weapons to the People’s Liberation Army, has over the past few decades successfully branched into developing real estate, selling sports cars and producing television sitcoms. Now the company’s huge arts and culture division — Poly Culture Group Corporation — is planning an initial public stock offering that could raise up to $330 million and bolster the prospects of the company in the world’s biggest and fastest-growing art and auction market.

headline: Staying on Script, for Now
text: MSNBC turned Ronan Farrow, 26, a handsome celebrity activist, into Chuck Todd.

headline: Developer Is Shot in the Head Outside His Long Island Castle
text: Gary Melius, a well-known Long Island developer and prominent political patron, was shot in the head by a masked gunman on Monday in the parking lot of his opulent Gold Coast estate in Suffolk County, the police said.

headline: Holder Sees Way to Curb Bans on Gay Marriage
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Monday injected the Obama administration into the emotional and politicized debate over the future of state same-sex marriage bans, declaring in an interview that state attorneys general are not obligated to defend laws that they believe are discriminatory.

headline: New Land, New Tongue, New Fame
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Growing up in Beijing as the daughter of a physicist, the writer Yiyun Li seemed destined for a career in science. But she would surreptitiously read from “this big book of Tang dynasty poetry,” she said, while “pretending to do math.” Years later, studying for a Ph.D. in immunology at the University of Iowa, she adopted a similar strategy, reading short stories clipped from The New Yorker as she did lab work.

headline: Two Sisters With Secrets, Desperate for Escape
text: Part Sam Shepard gothic drama, part “Moth Radio Hour” yarn, “My Daughter Keeps Our Hammer,” by Brian Watkins, tells the story of Sarah and Hannah, sisters in their 20s, living with their ailing mother in the farm country of Eaton, Colo., and desperate for a way out.

headline: When in India | Spiritual Healing
text: While North India has no shortage of ashrams, the recently opened Vana, Malsi Estate, located in Dehradun near the foothills of the Himalayas, is taking wellness to new heights. The 31-year-old physics major-turned-organic farmer Veer Singh has spent nearly five years and $155 million building this tranquil spa retreat, which offers everything from a few days of yoga to three weeks of Ayurvedic healing.

headline: The One-Eyed Witness
text: Anyone who has hired a lawyer knows $1,000 doesn’t buy you much. But when Anthony Ray Hinton was on trial for his life in Alabama, that’s the total amount his court-appointed attorney thought he could spend on a key expert witness in firearms evidence. All he could find for that price was an elderly one-eyed man with a degree in civil engineering who was laughed out of court for his inability to answer basic questions.

headline: Customizing a Mash-Up
text: When opera was a much younger art form, star singers could choose which arias they wanted to sing, often swapping in favorite numbers that showed off their voices to best advantage for whatever the lowly composers and librettists had originally written.

headline: Times Minute | Tea Party Challengers
text: Tea Party challengers enter congressional primary races. Also on the Minute, tenants battle for rent-controlled units in New York and the actor Alan Alda talks science.

headline: Times Minute | Tea Party Challengers
text: In the Video

headline: Zebra Mussels: Young and Invasive
text: In contrast to adults whose shells are always firmly attached to substrates like rocks, the larval veliger stages of zebras mussels swim freely in water currents for several weeks.

headline: Science Takes On a Silent Invader
text: Since they arrived in the Great Lakes in the 1980s, two species of mussels the size of pistachios have spread to hundreds of lakes and rivers in 34 states and have done vast economic and ecological damage.

headline: Target Push Into Canada Stumbles
text: OTTAWA — When Canadians crossed the border into the United States on shopping excursions, Target was a prime destination. But when Target crossed the border last year and brought its stores to Canada, the magic somehow vanished.

headline: Harold Ramis's Many Roles
text: The film critic A. O. Scott discusses the career of the actor and director Harold Ramis, who died Monday. He is best known for his impact on comedy.

headline: LinkedIn Goes to China
text: Hoping to greatly increase its presence in one of the world’s great labor markets, LinkedIn has announced the formation of a site dedicated to China.

headline: Jazz at Lincoln Center Season to Include Tributes to Billie Holiday and Wayne Shorter
text: Jazz at Lincoln Center’s 2014-15 season, running from September through next June, connects musical traditions that start with jazz and open out to the Americas in general — North and South, Cuba and the Antilles. The details of the concerts, lectures, workshops and other events on the organization’s premises within the Time Warner Center and elsewhere are to be released Tuesday, with a piece of added news. What was formerly the Allen Room — the amphitheater within Frederick P. Rose Hall, with 50-foot-high glass windows overlooking Columbus Circle — will be renamed the Appel Room, in honor of Robert J. Appel, chairman of Jazz at Lincoln Center’s board, who donated $20 million to the organization earlier this year. (Allen & Co., the financial company for which the room was named in 2004, agreed to give back naming rights to a new donor.)

headline: A Bonus: Some Play on a Trip for Work
text: On a business trip to London last fall, Caroline Michaud took the last flight out of Heathrow Airport to Chicago on a Saturday night so she would have time to visit the National Portrait Gallery, take a run by Buckingham Palace and spin through St. James Park.

headline: Probing the Parliament of Neurons
text: Clay Reid and colleagues are going deep into the mouse brain to decipher the conversations and decisions of neurons.

headline: The Brain’s Inner Language
text: SEATTLE — When Clay Reid decided to leave his job as a professor at Harvard Medical School to become a senior investigator at the Allen Institute for Brain Science in Seattle in 2012, some of his colleagues congratulated him warmly and understood right away why he was making the move.

headline: Regulating the ‘Dark Money’ of Politics
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ukraine as a Bridge
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tarmac Purgatory Ends, but New Trials Appear
text: WALK down memory lane with me to wintertimes in years gone by, when bad weather routinely caused passengers on hundreds of flights to be stranded on airplanes that had pulled away from the gate but then sat idled on tarmacs, neither taking off nor returning to the terminal, for three, five, even 12 hours and more.

headline: Inequality in Our Cities
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Spirituality of A.A.
Needed: A Parole Panel
text: To the Editor:

headline: That Buzz You Hear Is Nascar After Earnhardt’s Big Victory
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — A sport desperate to connect to a new, younger audience took a significant step toward that goal with help from Dale Earnhardt Jr.

headline: Dialogue With the Wealthy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Study Suggests Top N.H.L. Teams May Suffer After Sochi
text: Several playoff contenders — the Chicago Blackhawks, the St. Louis Blues, the Montreal Canadiens, the Anaheim Ducks, the Vancouver Canucks, the Pittsburgh Penguins and the Rangers — sent seven or more players to the Sochi Olympics.

headline: Judge Likely to Dismiss Script Case
text: LOS ANGELES — A federal judge here said she expected to grant summary judgment against a producer who accused Warner Bros. and others of basing the Clint Eastwood baseball film, “Trouble With the Curve,” on a script that belonged to him.

headline: On a Plane, and Learning the Finer Points of Farming
text: I GREW up in the Midwest and didn’t fly much when I was younger. Now, as a consultant and author of “Your Network Is Your Net Worth,” I’m traveling all the time. I find business travel tiring, so I can’t say I love it. But I do love being able to support myself in a nontraditional way.

headline: With Bounce at Buzzer, Nowitzki Deflates Knicks
text: Another Carmelo Anthony gem was wasted Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Equality of Taxes
text: Same-sex married couples will be required to file their federal income tax returns reflecting their married status for the first time.

headline: Steel Industry Feeling Stress as Automakers Turn to Aluminum
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — For nearly a century, Ford’s River Rouge factory and its neighboring steel mill have worked in close harmony to produce some of America’s most popular vehicles, from the Model A to the F-150 pickup truck.

headline: A Mayor in the Middle of Two San Franciscos
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Edwin M. Lee, the mayor of San Francisco, began his career as a lawyer fighting for public housing tenants in the city’s Chinatown and likes to think of himself as a champion for those who are struggling.

headline: For Same-Sex Marrieds, a Tax Season to Look Back
text: Tax season doesn’t usually stir up emotions about the meaning of family and equal rights.

headline: At the Oscars, Bringing Brands to Life
text: WHEN viewers watch ABC on Sunday for coverage of the 86th annual Academy Awards, they will see commercials for more than a dozen organizations or companies like AARP, Coldwell Banker, General Motors, Mars, J. C. Penney and Unilever. Those spots will, however, be only part of the marketing efforts that seek to walk the red carpet with Oscar.

headline: Live Nation Cut Its Losses Last Year
text: The giant concert company Live Nation Entertainment’s revenue rose by 11 percent last year and its net loss narrowed significantly, as attendance grew for country and electronic dance events, the company reported Monday.

headline: Inside the ‘Museum of Corruption’
text: In February 2014, the palatial compound of Viktor Yanukovych, the former president of Ukraine, was opened to the public after he fled Kiev.

headline: Fake Putin Diary!
text: Dear Diary,

headline: TV Networks Ask Supreme Court to Shut Down Aereo
text: Aereo, the start-up that uses tiny antennas to stream the free signals of TV stations to its customers’ Internet-connected devices for a fee, is stealing from the broadcast networks on a giant scale, the broadcasters asserted in a filing with the Supreme Court on Monday.

headline: Ford to Drop Microsoft From Car Systems
text: Ford has found a new software partner to power its in-car entertainment and communications systems, making plans to drop technology from Microsoft in favor of software from BlackBerry.

headline: Governor of Arizona Is Pressed to Veto Bill
text: PHOENIX — As the Arizona Legislature sent a bill to her desk Monday that would grant business owners the right to invoke religion to refuse service to gays and others, Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, faced pressure from many corners to veto the measure, which has cast unwanted national attention on Arizona.

headline: Confessions of a Lifelong Eavesdropper
text: Confession: I eavesdrop. Not only that, I make my students do it.

headline: Supreme Court Declines Tennis Channel Appeal
text: The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an appeal from the Tennis Channel in its dispute with Comcast over placement on the company’s cable channel lineup.

headline: Coverage of Olympic Games Delivers a Win for NBC
text: A network buys the rights to the Olympics to beat its prime-time competition for 17 nights in a row.

headline: Man Charged in Series of Fires at 2 Queens Shopping Centers
text: A 23-year-old man was charged on Monday night in connection with a series of small fires over several days at two shopping centers in Queens, the police said.

headline: Indictments for 28 More in Fraud Case
text: Twenty-eight more people, including retired police officers and firefighters, have been indicted as part of the Manhattan district attorney’s investigation into an extensive scheme to defraud Social Security disability insurance, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Pentagon Officials Say They’re Willing to Assume Risks of a Reduced Army
text: WASHINGTON — In shrinking the United States Army to its smallest size since 1940, Pentagon officials said Monday that they were willing to assume more risk the next time troops are called to war.

headline: ‘The Wild West of Privacy’
text: We are fast approaching a privacy crisis in the United States. Google, Facebook and other big Internet companies collect information about us, which they deploy in the service of advertisers. Big data brokers, like Acxiom, have developed sophisticated tools that allow them to know almost as much about us as we know about ourselves; they then sell that data to all kinds of companies that want to learn everything from our habits to our health, from our sexual orientation to our finances. The digital age has made it easy to collect medical data, which is supposed to be protected under federal law. Huge data breaches at big retailers like Target have made it seem unsafe to use credit cards. And I haven’t even mentioned the Edward Snowden revelations about the massive data collection by the National Security Agency.

headline: Rash Repression in Venezuela
text: PROTESTS have rocked Venezuela in recent weeks, but no one seems to agree on why huge numbers of people have suddenly taken to the streets. Some observers see the demonstrations as a verdict on food and medicine shortages, inflation and economic stagnation. Others see them as the tantrum of a retrograde former elite bent on nullifying the results of the last election. The government, for its part, is sticking to the old script: Venezuela is falling victim to a fascist conspiracy cooked up by American officials who are terrified of its revolutionary aspirations.

headline: Connecticut Plans to Market Health Exchange Expertise
text: WASHINGTON — Connecticut has been so successful in getting people to sign up for health insurance through its online marketplace that it is setting up a consulting business to help other states build and operate websites where people can compare and buy private insurance policies.

headline: The Capture of Chapo Guzmán
text: Many Mexicans may have found it hard to believe that it was really him. That the pudgy little man with the Super Mario mustache being marched into a helicopter by a masked marine with gloved hand firmly on his neck was El Chapo, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the world’s most wanted, most elusive drug lord.

headline: Apple’s Serious Security Issue: Update Your iPhone or iPad Immediately
text: This week, Apple rushed out a patch for its iOS 7 and iOS 6 operating systems to fix a serious security issue. Before I explain further, let me just say this: If you’ve gotten the prompt to update and you haven’t, do it now. If you’re still running older versions of iOS on your iPhone, iPod, or iPad, update now.

headline: A License to Discriminate
text: There are 17 states where it is legal for same-sex couples to marry, and there is no evidence that the accelerating progress toward equality has compromised anyone’s freedom to worship or hold religious beliefs.

headline: Scottish Oil and Gas an Issue in Vote on Independence
text: LONDON — They have disagreed over whether an independent Scotland could retain the British pound as its currency. They have sparred over whether Scotland would remain in the European Union if it votes in September to leave the United Kingdom. And on Monday, two of the most prominent advocates of the arguments for and against Scottish independence — Alex Salmond, Scotland’s first minister, and David Cameron, the British prime minister — turned to another crucial economic issue at stake in the battle: the future of the still-substantial oil and gas reserves in the North Sea.

headline: Prosecutors Talk to Mayor of Fort Lee
text: The mayor of Fort Lee, N.J., met last week with federal prosecutors investigating the closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge in September, his lawyer said on Monday.

headline: Ukraine’s Uncertain Future
text: The venal president of Ukraine is on the run and the bloodshed has stopped, but it is far too early to celebrate or to claim that the West has “won” or that Russia has “lost.” One incontrovertible lesson from the events in Kiev, Ukraine’s capital, is that the deeply divided country will have to contend with dangerous problems that could reverberate beyond its borders.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 25, 2014
text: “The truly distressing thing about these folks leaving is that they’re the ones who know how to negotiate, know how to legislate, know how to get things done.”

headline: Happy Workers, Healthy Bottom Line
text: Are there forms of compensation that are clearly “win-win” – worth more to workers than the cost to employers?

headline: Colorblind Notion Aside, Colleges Grapple With Racial Tension
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — A brochure for the University of Michigan features a vision of multicultural harmony, with a group of students from different racial backgrounds sitting on a verdant lawn, smiling and conversing.

headline: Pension Funds Sue on a Deal Gone Cold
text: Sitting around a table in Baton Rouge, La., in February 2008, a handful of board members of the Firefighters’ Retirement System of Louisiana heard an investment pitch that would later come back to haunt them.

headline: A Dragon Returns, This Time Onstage
text: Fists fly with all the fury an action fan could want. Legs flash from the hip like lightning strikes. Twirling kicks and jabbing arms all but set your own head spinning. The fight sequences in “Kung Fu,” the new play about Bruce Lee by David Henry Hwang, bristle with kinetic drive and an innovative combination of dance and martial arts.

headline: U.S. and Britain Join Forces in Bank Misbehavior Cases
text: It seemed to be a thumb in the eye of the Justice Department. Britain last week criminally charged a former Barclays employee suspected of trying to manipulate global interest rates, even though the authorities in London were aware that the employee had been assisting American prosecutors in a related investigation for more than a year.

headline: Role Reversal
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — There are certain words that pop up time and time again in crosswords. It might be because they’re really common, or it might be because their letters are really helpful in puzzle construction. I tend to think it’s more the latter. That’s why we see fairly specialized words like epee appear in the grid so often.

headline: Two Dolphins’ Paths to a Bullying Scandal
text: Three days after Jonathan Martin checked himself into a South Florida hospital for psychiatric help, he received a string of conciliatory messages from Richie Incognito, his Miami Dolphins teammate and tormentor, who asked about his health and said that he missed him.

headline: @GSElevator Tattletale Exposed (He Was Not in the Goldman Elevator)
text: A three-year parlor game has been taking place on Wall Street to identify the Goldman Sachs employee behind a Twitter account that purports to reveal the uncensored comments overheard in the firm’s elevators.

headline: Bobby Jindal After Meeting With Obama
text: The Louisiana governor accused the president of “waving the white flag” on the American economy.

headline: Israeli Warplanes Strike Near the Border of Syria and Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Israeli warplanes launched two raids near the Syrian-Lebanese border late Monday, according to Lebanon’s National News Agency, raising speculation that Israel might have targeted a weapons convoy to prevent the Syrian government from delivering missiles to its Lebanese ally, Hezbollah.

headline: Rangers’ Darvish a Model of Success for Tanaka
text: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Would you believe that the first batter Yu Darvish faced in live competition this spring was named Tanaka? He was a nonroster infielder, Kensuke Tanaka, and he did not inspire an intense winter bidding war. But as Darvish pitched the first inning of the Texas Rangers’ first intrasquad game on Monday, it was hard to miss the link.

headline: Rodriguez Still Belongs to Union Despite Lawsuit Rancor, Director Says
text: TAMPA, Fla. — During his one season with the Yankees, in 2004, Tony Clark, now the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, was teammates with Alex Rodriguez. It was 10 years ago, a season that ended in excruciating defeat for the Yankees, who were beaten by the Red Sox in the American League Championship Series.

headline: Trimmings, Best of Milan Fashion Week
text: From the Lagerfeld-like bag bug to fast food-reminiscent sunglasses, these are the standout fall 2014 accessories from Fendi, Gucci, Bottega Veneta and more.

headline: Injuries at the Olympics Deplete Several Rosters
text: The most palpable effect of the Olympics on N.H.L. teams’ performance is through injuries. The toll in Sochi was high.

headline: Wary Stance From Obama on Ukraine
text: WASHINGTON — Televisions around the White House were aglow with pictures of Ukrainians in the streets, demanding to be heard and toppling a government aligned with Russia. It was an invigorating moment, and it spurred a president already rethinking his approach to the world.

headline: Young Mets Pitcher Is Quietly on the Rise
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — In the middle of the Mets’ clubhouse here, two of the organization’s brightest pitching prospects have their lockers next to each other. To the left is Noah Syndergaard, a 6-foot-6-inch, 230-pound 21-year-old from Texas, who is hard to miss and has already received much attention and praise this spring.

headline: Simón Díaz, Venezuelan Folk Musician Heard Worldwide, Dies at 85
text: Simón Díaz, one of Venezuela’s most popular singers and comedians who also earned recognition worldwide for his prowess as a player of the cuatro, a guitar-like instrument, died on Feb. 19 at his home in Caracas. He was 85.

headline: De Blasio Answers Critics on Road Safety
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio was questioned by reporters after a television news crew filmed his chauffeur-driven car breaking traffic rules, only days after he announced a street safety campaign.

headline: This Time, de Blasio Confronts S.U.V. Issue Head-On
text: Three days after walking out of a news conference as reporters shouted questions at his back, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday finally fielded inquiries about his motorcade’s caught-on-camera violations of traffic laws — but he could not resist offering reporters some pointed criticism of his own.

headline: Seeking Details on Plan to End Traffic Fatalities
text: Speed humps. Crossing guards. Police officers on patrol just being more alert to lawbreaking drivers around them.

headline: Just Like His Power, Ukrainian Ex-Leader Vanishes Into Thin Air
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Ukraine’s acting government on Monday declared the former president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, a fugitive sought for mass murder, but it seemed at a loss to find the man whose authority had crumbled over the weekend.

headline: In New Home, Policy Group Gets Big Gift
text: WASHINGTON — The American Enterprise Institute — one of the nation’s oldest conservative think tanks, but one that has never had its own home — is getting financial help for its new headquarters in a stately Dupont Circle building from a $20 million donation by Daniel A. D’Aniello, a co-founder and chairman of the private equity firm the Carlyle Group.

headline: A Sudden Demand for No. 98 Jerseys
text: Jason Collins fell asleep Saturday night without a team. On Sunday, he became the Nets’ most publicized player, the first openly gay athlete to play in an N.B.A. game, although one on a 10-day contract.

headline: In Venezuela, Protest Ranks Grow Broader
text: SAN CRISTÓBAL, Venezuela — As dawn broke, the residents of a quiet neighborhood here readied for battle. Some piled rocks to be used as projectiles. Others built barricades. A pair of teenagers made firebombs as the adults looked on.

headline: A Border City on the Edge of the Law
text: MONG LA, Myanmar — The smuggling route into this rebel-run jungle outpost just over the Chinese border begins on the back of a motorcycle that takes passengers through steeply terraced rubber plantations, and skirts the official crossing before ending at an outdoor market where bedraggled prostitutes mingle with Chinese tourists haggling over tiger claws, bear paws and desiccated squares of elephant skin.

headline: This Is Your Conductor Writing: I’m Sorry
text: As the doors opened to the 6:52 a.m. train from New Haven, the single sheets of paper, one on every seat, came quickly into view.

headline: A Lucrative Market in Myanmar
text: Mongla market in Myanmar is best known among Chinese tourists for its large selection of rare and endangered animals.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 24, 2014
Vigilantes, Once Welcome, Frighten Many in Mexico
text: LOMBARDÍA, Mexico — They have been hailed as saviors, vigilantes marching into town with military-style rifles and submachine guns, wearing no uniforms and threatening to whip miscreants as they bring order to this lawless Mexican region known as Tierra Caliente, or hot lands.

headline: What Is a Majority Vote in the State Senate? The Answer Goes Beyond Simple Math
text: ALBANY — There has been a curious question bouncing around certain quarters of the New York State Senate: How many votes, exactly, does it take to pass a bill?

headline: Sri Lanka: U.N. Official Seeks International Inquiry
text: The United Nations’ human rights chief on Monday called for an independent international inquiry into possible war crimes committed during Sri Lanka’s civil war, saying the Sri Lankan government lacks the political will to mount a credible investigation. The United Nations official, Navi Pillay, said “national mechanisms have consistently failed to establish the truth and achieve justice” with respect to the large number of killings and other abuses in the final chapter of the two-decade-long war in 2009 and continuing abuses that include attacks on religious minorities, journalists and human rights activists. She added that an investigation “is fundamentally a question of political will.” Sri Lanka rejected the report. President Mahinda Rajapaksa’s administration called the recommendations “arbitrary, intrusive and of a political nature.”

headline: Mexico: Legal Wrangling Begins Over Drug Kingpin
text: Two days after Mexican marines arrested the drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, questions are being asked about whether he will be tried in Mexico or in the United States. Lawyers for Mr. Guzmán, who was charged Sunday with offenses related to organized crime and cocaine trafficking stemming from a 2009 investigation, are seeking an injunction against extradition. Federal officials in Chicago and New York have said they want to try him in those cities, and he faces additional indictments in Texas and Florida. But Mexico’s interior minister, Miguel Ángel Osorio Chong, said Monday that the government’s security cabinet would “make the most appropriate decision.” Mexico’s ambassador to Washington, Eduardo Medina Mora, said Saturday that Mr. Guzmán should face charges in Mexico first. Mr. Guzmán, who is being held in a high-security prison outside Mexico City, escaped from a Guadalajara prison in 2001 and spent almost 13 years as a fugitive.

headline: In Plan to Dump Contaminated Soil, Classic New Jersey Politics Emerge
text: CARTERET, N.J. — We slip slided, a zoologist, two environmentalists and I, across ice, snow and mud toward a wire fence with a sign: Environmental Investigation Cleanup.

headline: Dark Side of the Moon
text: Keep time while tracking the many lunar phases with spring’s most out-of-this-world watches.

headline: Five Sweet Stops for Paris Fashion Week
text: In 2010, Vogue Paris named the inimitable Irish expat and award-winning cookbook author Trish Deseine one of its 40 “women of the decade.” That they included her alongside icons like Marion Cotillard and Zaha Hadid is a testament to her talent, to be sure, but also a nod to her invaluable contribution to the annals of French cuisine. Deseine’s work, which spans 17 books and a long-running recipe column for French Elle, has succeeded in both lifting the complexity from French home cooking and exhorting fat-free hardliners to consider (and taste) the merits of butter and sugar, which she insists are two of the greatest boons to food.

headline: Remaking Film Comedy With a Straight Face
text: Harold Ramis, who died Monday at 69, made everyone around him look better. A startlingly creative distributor of laughs, he was a master orchestrator who knew how to create conditions for funny people to excel.

headline: Putting Economic Data Into Context
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Newark Stop-and-Frisk Data Is Analyzed
text: A new study about police stop-and-frisk encounters in Newark found that one quarter of police stops ended in an arrest or a summons, about twice as often as they do in New York City.

headline: Apparent Theft at Mt. Gox Shakes Bitcoin World
text: The most prominent Bitcoin exchange appeared to be on the verge of collapse late Monday, raising questions about the future of a volatile marketplace.

headline: Camels Linked to Spread of MERS Virus in People
text: A new study suggests that camels are the major source of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, a viral disease that has sickened 182 people and killed 79 of them since it was first detected in Saudi Arabia in 2012.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SECRETS OF THE VATICAN In February 2013, Pope Benedict XVI resigned, the first pope to do so in nearly 600 years. He left behind a divided Vatican, mired in scandal: a sexual abuse crisis; suspected money laundering and corruption at the Vatican bank; and the leak of internal documents revealing cronyism, power struggles and accusations of blackmail. But has Benedict’s successor, Pope Francis, managed to lift the Roman Catholic church out of crisis? “Frontline” uses undercover footage and interviews with Vatican insiders, abuse victims and whistle-blowers to address that question and others in this 90-minute special, nearly a year in the making. “It is necessary to open the windows of the church, because we need fresh air,” says one of Francis’s closest confidants, Cardinal Óscar Andrés Rodríguez Maradiaga.

headline: Pakistan Bombs Militant Area as Officials Weigh a Wider Offensive
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — The Pakistani military pressed its campaign of airstrikes against militants in the remote tribal regions on Tuesday, reportedly killing at least 30 people, as the national cabinet met to consider a broader military offensive, officials said.

headline: On Twitter, ‘Being Black at the University of Michigan’
text: As my colleague Tanzina Vega reported, there’s a notion in the media and popular culture that millennials are growing up in a colorblind world and “race is a relic of the past.”

headline: Xi Visits Beijing Neighborhood, Lighting Up Social Media
text: Updated, 3:22 a.m. EDT | President Xi Jinping of China continued his campaign to be seen as a warm, down-to-earth leader by taking a stroll Tuesday morning through a Beijing neighborhood that is popular with tourists and locals alike.

headline: A Magazine Cover for a Famously Humble Ambassador
text: Even before he arrived in Beijing, Gary Locke, the United States ambassador, achieved a rare sort of national prominence in China. A 2011 photo of him with his daughter at a Starbucks in the Seattle airport, carrying his own backpack, was widely circulated on Chinese social media sites. Many praised Mr. Locke for his apparent humility — carrying his own bag and trying to pay for his drink with a coupon. Others, including some state media commentators, questioned whether Mr. Locke’s behavior was a carefully calculated display.

headline: An Art Event Incorporates Itself in the Spaces of New Delhi

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | How a Kingpin Above the Law Fell, Incredibly, Without a Shot
text: In “How a Kingpin Above the Law Fell, Incredibly, Without a Shot,” Damien Cave writes about the arrest of Joaquín Guzmán Loera.

text: Suzy Menkes speaks with Antonio Marras about the importance of his Sardinian roots and his new collection inspired by howling wolves.

headline: Reversing Course, Japan Makes Push to Restart Dormant Nuclear Plants
text: TOKYO — The government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe made its biggest push yet to revive Japan’s nuclear energy program on Tuesday, announcing details of a draft plan that designates atomic power as an important long-term electricity source.

text: The gentle sound of lapping waves mingles with woozy notes from a distant steel guitar as a fruity cocktail beckons — paradise, right?

text: KIEV, Ukraine — Struggling to form a new majority coalition in Parliament, and under excruciating pressure because of a looming economic calamity, Ukrainian lawmakers decided Tuesday to delay for two days the naming of an acting prime minister and a provisional government.

headline: Pistorius Trial in Large Part Can Be Aired on Live TV

text: I’d like to thank everyone who took the time to contribute their thoughts on my recent post about shipping costs. Lots of good input there, with a wide range of viewpoints. I showed all of them to my salesmen and we came up with four options:

text: In Milan’s Navigli District, locals embrace vintage clothing and bright colors.

headline: @GSElevator’s Big Reveal
text: @GSELEVATOR EXPOSED  |  For three years, Wall Street has been trying to identify the employee behind the Twitter account @GSElevator, which reported anonymous snippets purportedly overheard in elevators at Goldman Sachs. But it turns out, the tweeter doesn’t work at Goldman and never did, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. In fact, the tweeter is a 34-year-old former bond trader in Texas named John LeFevre.

headline: Britain Arrests Ex-Detainee Freed by U.S.
text: LONDON — The British police said on Tuesday that they had arrested Moazzam Begg, a former detainee at the American prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, along with three other people on suspicion of terrorism offenses related to the war in Syria, where, intelligence officials say, hundreds of British militants have been drawn to the fight against President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Knicks’ Felton Faces Gun Charges
text: The Knicks were grinding their way to another brutal loss in a season full of them Monday night at Madison Square Garden. The game came down to a last-second heave by the Mavericks’ Dirk Nowitzki, which caromed high off the rim before falling through for the winning shot.

headline: In Beijing, Complaints About Smog Grow Louder and Retaliation Grows Swifter
text: Nearly a week into northern China’s latest airpocalypse, the skies over Beijing are murky and acrid with a heavy smog that shrouds the sun. On social media sites, the yellow, choking air has become something of a meme, as residents post depressing photos of their blackened air purifier filters and hazy urban vistas with comments like #nuclearwinter.

text: The most overlooked of knits get asked to the fashion dance.

text: Hyphens cause us no end of confusion, perhaps because the only overarching rule is this: Use them when they are needed and don’t when they aren’t.

headline: Disney Throws Open the Gates to Its Own Digital Movie Service
text: LOS ANGELES — As consumers display increased interest in owning movies digitally, a habit considered crucial to Hollywood’s future, Walt Disney Studios unveiled a service on Tuesday that aimed to make collecting its films easier.

headline: Bonderman Says TPG Is Considering Going Public
text: BERLIN — David Bonderman, the co-founder of the private equity firm TPG Capital, said on Tuesday that his firm was considering going public but had not committed to doing so.

headline: Video: The Ranch Where ‘Star Wars’ Exploded
text: “Before there was a here here, I was here,” said Randy Thom, the director of sound design at Skywalker Sound, part of George Lucas’s Skywalker Ranch complex outside of San Francisco. “It used to be called Sprocket Systems, in the earliest days, and it became Skywalker Sound in the mid ’80s,” said Mr. Thom, who first worked with the company on “The Empire Strikes Back.”

headline: A Pakistani Militant Leader Stirs, Worrying the Indian Government
text: NEW DELHI — When a new administration takes over after national elections in May, one of the first challenges it is likely to face will come from the Kashmir Valley. Adding to the Indian government’s worries about the return of violence in the region, particularly among the youth, is the reappearance of Maulana Masood Azhar, the leader of the Pakistani militant group Jaish-e-Muhammad.

headline: Kravis Says Private Equity Does Poor Job of Discussing Its Benefits
text: BERLIN – Henry Kravis, the co-founder of the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, and other industry leaders think the private equity sector has a bit of an image problem.

text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Ava Smith (left) and after (right) makeup by Gordon Espinet and hair by Sam McKnight.

headline: Cartoons in the Elevator
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The Preschool Parent Interview: An Elevator Pitch for My 2-Year-Old
text: We’d just completed the school tour, and, with six other parents, were being escorted into a boardroom. Jon and I had spent the morning asking endless questions. (Do the ages mix? How do you handle separation? Where’s the coffee? No Danish?) Finally, I thought, we could sit back and listen to the preschool’s spiel, doodling with their branded pads and pencils. But the director, sitting at the head of the long table like a C.E.O., began. “Let’s go around,” she said. “One by one, describe your child in one word. Then, explain why this school is a good fit.” My heart galloped. She was asking us to pitch our kids — in public? Though this environment was contrived (some might say insane), it brought up a question I’d been contemplating: What is the best way to talk about my child?

headline: Feminist Tales, Up to a Point
text: PARIS — The list of important 20th-century female ballet choreographers isn’t long, but Birgit Cullberg, often forgotten today, is certainly on it. Cullberg, for whom the Swedish government formed the eponymous Cullberg Ballet in 1967, was regarded as a major choreographer well into the 1980s. Today, however, her work is almost unknown outside her native country. (Her son, Mats Ek, has achieved far greater renown).

headline: The Sorry State of Campaign Finance in Albany
text: Campaign finance reform is incredibly important, but, frankly, it’s not very sexy. How do you rouse a full-throated rallying cry for a system that could clean up politics by encouraging more people to run for office? It’s not a bleat against new taxes. It’s not a tale of two cities.

headline: Second Act | Once More, With Feeling
text: A historic London recording studio gets reborn as a stylish movie theater while staying true to its rock ‘n’ roll roots.

headline: The Secret to a Bulletproof Antidoping Test?
text: In the lab of Yannis Pitsiladis, a physiologist in Scotland, athletes spend their days injecting synthetic EPO, a popular performance-enhancing drug that tricks bone marrow into churning out more red blood cells, allowing athletes’ bodies to absorb more oxygen. Pitsiladis hasn’t gone rogue. He’s at the forefront of an effort to revolutionize the hunt for dopers in sports by scouring his subjects’ blood cells for a distinctive, long-lasting genetic “fingerprint” left by the drug.

headline: At Private Equity Conference, a Debate Over the Benefits of Going Public
text: BERLIN – The benefits of going public remained a hotly debated topic among private equity leaders as they gathered at SuperReturn International, the private equity gathering in Berlin.

text: CAIRO — An industrialist who rose to prominence during the Mubarak era was named as Egypt’s new prime minister on Tuesday, a day after his predecessor abruptly announced the resignation of the military-backed government that had managed the country since July.

headline: Down the Up Staircase
text: James Surowiecki makes an important point: if you want a society in which everyone has a decent life, you need to construct a society in which everyone has a decent life — not a society in which everyone has a small but equal chance of living the lifestyle of the rich and famous.

headline: ‘Dallas’ Promotion Brings $1.98 Gasoline to Manhattan for a Day
text: In an effort to create publicity for the premiere of the third season of “Dallas,” TNT’s reboot of the 1980s nighttime soap, the network on Monday dressed up a filling station in Manhattan to look as if it were owned by the show’s fictional Ewing family. But the fresh Ewing Energies logos decorating the awning over the fuel pumps were only part of the promotion.

headline: The Read Around: Video of B. J. Novak
text: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Above, the writer and actor B. J. Novak, whose debut collection of fiction is “One More Thing,” talks about the freedom of following ideas wherever they might lead.

headline: Venezuelan Opposition Leader Tweets at the President
text: Updated, 12:40 p.m. | If, on Monday, President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela had something pressing to say to Henrique Capriles, the country’s most prominent opposition leader, he would have to save it for later. Mr. Capriles, after initially indicating that he would attend talks on Monday with Mr. Maduro and other elected officials about the growing unrest in the streets, had a very public change of heart.

headline: Defending Bitcoin, Andreessen Says Mt. Gox Is ‘Like MF Global’
text: The apparent collapse on Monday of Mt. Gox, the most prominent exchange for Bitcoin, spooked many holders of the virtual currency, as they tried to determine whether the problems pointed to larger flaws in the Bitcoin system.

headline: Lloyd Webber’s New Musical to Close in London
text: The theater gods have at long last taken revenge on Andrew Lloyd Webber for the ubiquity of “Cats,” “Phantom of the Opera” and “Evita.” His latest musical, “Stephen Ward,” which opened to mixed reviews in London in December, and has had mediocre ticket sales ever since, will close on March 29, the BBC reported on Tuesday.

text: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC takes over our Instagram account for Milan Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

headline: Repsol in $5 Billion Settlement With Argentina
text: LONDON — Repsol, the Spanish oil company, said Tuesday that it had agreed to a $5 billion compensation deal with Argentina for the seizure of the company’s operations in that country, ending a bitter two-year dispute.

headline: 2 Allies Meet Before 50th Anniversary of Israeli-German Ties
text: JERUSALEM — Israel and Germany began preparations to mark 50 years of diplomatic relations with a joint meeting here on Tuesday between the Israeli government and most of the German cabinet, an event analysts said was both symbolic and a practical reflection of the strong ties between the two countries.

headline: The Goldman Sachs Elevator Stalker Is Revealed — as a Fibber
text: It’s safe to talk on the elevator again at Goldman Sachs. The author of a snarky Twitter feed — @gselevator — has been revealed as John LeFevre, 34, of Texas, described as a former bond executive. As it turns out, he doesn’t work at Goldman and never did.

An excerpt is below, along with links to background on the four other winners of this annual prize, which honors the memory of Senator John Heinz and is given to people improving the human condition and environment through work in areas ranging from poverty alleviation to the arts and sciences.

text: GAITHERSBURG, Md. — The Food and Drug Administration is weighing a fertility procedure that involves combining the genetic material of three people to make a baby free of certain defects, a therapy that critics say is an ethical minefield and could lead to the creation of designer babies.
