text: A villager transporting milk on a horse cart on the outskirts of Jammu city.

headline: Former City Ballet Dancer to Lead Academy in Los Angeles
text: The dancer Jenifer Ringer, who retired this month from New York City Ballet, has been appointed head of the Colburn Dance Academy, a new division of the Colburn School in downtown Los Angeles, The Los Angeles Times has reported.

headline: A Brooklyn Inspiration for ‘Frozen’
text: The Oscar-nominated composers Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez say that in some part, inspiration for the songs they wrote for “Frozen” came from Prospect Park.

headline: Long Island Developer Recovering; Gunman’s Identity Remains Elusive
text: A day after being shot in the head by a masked gunman, Gary Melius, a well-known Long Island developer and prominent political patron, was recovering on Tuesday, and remarkably lucid.

headline: BlackBerry Chief Demurs on Sale of Messenger Service, for Now
text: BlackBerry has had a rough couple of years. But the prospect of a deal for its messaging service, on the heels of Facebook’s blockbuster takeover of WhatsApp, has helped buoy the ailing smartphone maker’s fortunes.

headline: Arguments Against God
text: This is the second in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Louise Antony, a professor of philosophy at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst and the editor of the essay collection “Philosophers Without Gods: Meditations on Atheism and the Secular Life.”

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Milan Women’s Shows
text: A glimpse at what gals are wearing this season.

headline: John Lennon Manuscripts Go to Auction
text: More than 100 John Lennon manuscripts, including short stories, poems and line drawings, most of them produced for the two books Lennon published during his lifetime, “In His Own Write” (1964) and “A Spaniard in the Works” (1965), will be auctioned at Sotheby’s in New York on June 4.

headline: Newcomers in Bidding Fight for Catskills Casino Weigh Site Closer to New York City
text: The battle to build a potentially lucrative $500 million casino resort amid the wooded hills and craggy economy of the Catskills has been a gentlemanly affair, with a half-dozen rivals gently competing for one, if not two state licenses for the region.

headline: At Helmut Lang, a Changing of the Guard
text: The guard has changed at Helmut Lang. The label announced today that its creative directors, the husband-and-wife team Michael and Nicole Colovos, will leave after eight years in the post.

headline: No Bailout for Bitcoin Holders
text: Imagine that the leading stockbroker in a country closed its doors without giving any reason. Its clients would be in a panic and customers of rival firms would be very nervous. That is exactly what has happened to Bitcoin, the leading pseudo-currency.

headline: Lexus Ranked No. 1 on Consumer Reports’ Annual Brand Report Cards
text: For the second year, Lexus, Toyota’s luxury brand, earned the top overall score in the Consumer Reports’ Car Brand Report Cards, the publication announced Tuesday. Honda’s Acura luxury division took second place, and Audi was third.

headline: Study Links Temperature to a Peruvian Glacier’s Growth and Retreat
text: Sitting on a flat volcanic plain 18,000 feet above sea level, the great Quelccaya ice cap of Peru is the largest piece of ice in the tropics. In recent decades, as scientists have watched it melt at an accelerating pace, it has also become a powerful symbol of global warming.

headline: Navalny Is Convicted of Resisting Arrest at Moscow Protest, Despite Video Evidence
text: Updated, 5:31 p.m. | As my colleague Andrew Roth reports from Moscow, the dissident blogger Aleksei A. Navalny was sentenced to seven days in jail on Tuesday after a judge found him guilty of resisting arrest at a protest in Moscow the night before. The conviction of the activist lawyer, despite visual evidence posted on his blog that appeared to show him going peacefully into custody, raised concerns that Mr. Navalny could face a much longer term in jail in one of the other cases filed against him for what he insists are political reasons.

headline: Are the New ‘Golden Age’ TV Shows the New Novels?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Mohsin Hamid discuss whether TV shows like “The Sopranos” and “The Wire” can be compared to the novels of writers like Charles Dickens and Henry James.

headline: California Endangered Species: Plastic Bags
text: LOS ANGELES — On a recent drizzly day, Esha Moya found herself standing outside a grocery store in South Los Angeles, her half-dozen paper bags falling apart in the rain, wishing she had a few small items that had been free and plentiful her entire life but are now banned in this city: plastic shopping bags.

headline: ‘Late Night’ Gets Sunny, and a Family Tree Grows
text: Jimmy Fallon felt the need to explain how a monologue works when he became the new host of “The Tonight Show.” Seth Meyers, 40, who on Monday took Mr. Fallon’s place on “Late Night,” was more relaxed and self-mocking, telling viewers not to expect anything too new. Or, as he put it, “I’m going to shake stuff up and open this thing with a monologue!”

headline: Audra McDonald to Return to Broadway as Billie Holiday
text: The five-time Tony Award winner Audra McDonald will make an unexpected return to Broadway this spring — in time to qualify for the 2014 Tonys — to play Billie Holiday in the musical play “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill,” its producers announced on Tuesday. While the show had been in the works for the 2014-15 theater season, the unusually swift closing of the Broadway play “Bronx Bombers” provided a theater, Circle in the Square, which also happened to suit the intimate nightclub setting of “Lady Day.” Performances will begin March 25 with an opening night of April 13. It is a limited engagement, scheduled to run for 10 weeks, or 70 performances.

headline: Venezuelans Document Unrest
text: The student protests that began just a few weeks ago in Venezuela have swept the country, as my colleague William Neuman reports, evolving into the biggest demonstrations seen since the death of the longtime leader Hugo Chávez last year.

headline: Geithner’s Book Has a Title: ‘Stress Test’
text: For the title of his memoirs, Timothy F. Geithner has employed a somewhat wonky phrase evocative of the financial crisis: “Stress Test.”

headline: Apollo’s Co-Founder Sees Opportunities to Invest in Distressed Debt
text: BERLIN – Despite a frenetic period of sales and spin-offs, Leon Black, the co-founder of Apollo Global Management, said Tuesday that there were still attractive opportunities for private equity firms to invest in distressed debt.

headline: Nissan Recalls 13,500 Frontier Pickups for Potential Fire Hazard
text: Nissan is recalling about 13,500 Frontier pickup trucks from the 2012-14 model years for a possible fire hazard, the automaker said in a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: What’s Happening off the Runway During Paris Fashion Week
text: Paris Fashion Week begins today. And while the fashion set may be feeling the lag of the final leg of shows, the City of Light is geared up to stimulate and pamper wary showgoers when they’re off duty. Here, a guide to surviving (and enjoying) the festivities.

headline: Sri Lanka Denounces Push to Open War Inquiry
text: NEW DELHI — Sri Lanka’s government on Tuesday forcefully rejected a call for an international war crimes investigation into the country’s bloody civil war, adding to tensions with the United Nations’ human rights body.

headline: Aid Group Sees Daunting Obstacles to Health Care for Afghans
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The patients in the four hospitals run by Doctors Without Borders in Afghanistan are the lucky ones, by all accounts, having arrived at well-stocked facilities that maintain international standards with high-quality free care.

headline: Truth and a Prize Emerge From Lies About Hoffman
text: Herding his three younger sons out the door to school on Feb. 5, David Bar Katz was stopped for a moment by his eldest, who was browsing the Internet.

headline: Elliott Raises Bid for Riverbed to $3.3 Billion
text: Updated, 3:48 p.m. |

headline: Orange-Currant Scones
text: Julia Moskin shows how to master the art of making sweet, tender scones with a firm crust and a soft, crumbly texture.

headline: Cédric Charlier: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Paris

headline: In His Words | Stillness in the Move
text: Teju Cole’s new book extols the streets of Lagos, Nigeria, where he spent his youth. Here, he expounds on what’s so great about living in New York.

headline: Tax Overhaul Plan Faces Key Hurdles
text: WASHINGTON — The proposal by the top Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee to overhaul and simplify the nation’s tax code is already coming under scrutiny from fellow Republicans, with at least one party leader, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, saying the plan has no chance.

headline: Sochi Performances That Deserve a Mention, if Not a Medal
text: SOCHI, Russia — The first Winter Olympics by the Black Sea ended Sunday after 98 events, abundant sunshine, occasional fog and one more gold medalist than expected because of a tie in the women’s downhill between Tina Maze and Dominique Gisin.

headline: Biscuits and Scones Share Tender Secrets
text: The American scone is a confection in crisis. Puffy and pale, supersized and supersweet, it has lost its purpose. Is it a muffin? Is it a pastry? Does it exist to be frosted with icing, or spread with jam — or only to crumble into the crevices of car upholstery?

headline: Brazil Real Estate Start-Up Draws U.S. Investment
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Amid continuing concerns about Brazil’s sputtering economy, the Dragoneer Investment Group of San Francisco has made its first investment in an Internet company here, leading a $12.75 million round in VivaReal, an online real estate classifieds start-up, the companies said on Tuesday.

headline: In Ukraine, Both Sides Exploit Jewish History
text: Thanks to extermination and emigration, the Jews of Ukraine, who numbered about 2.7 million at the beginning of the 20th Century, are now down to perhaps 250,000 and falling. But their history is playing an oversized role in the drama of revolution unfolding in Kiev, as both sides exploit them and their memory to gain an upper hand in public opinion.

headline: Justices Rule on Home Searches and Defendants’ Frozen Assets
text: WASHINGTON — In a pair of 6-to-3 decisions, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that the police may sometimes search homes over the objections of one of their residents and that criminal defendants are not entitled to hearings to try to gain access to frozen assets to pay their lawyers.

headline: U.S. Game in Ukraine Is Moved to Cyprus
text: Ukraine’s soccer federation announced Tuesday that it would move a March 5 friendly against the United States men’s national team to Cyprus from the eastern city of Kharkiv. The federation said it had agreed to move the match out of Ukraine, after a request from U.S. Soccer, for safety reasons.

headline: It Remembers, You Fold: Packing-List Apps
text: Can a smartphone help you pack for a vacation?

headline: Cranbury, N.J.: One Town, Many Personalities
text: When the Helstrom family decided to downsize last summer, they moved just nine houses away from the home they had been living in for 10 years in Cranbury. Jane Helstrom said it felt as if they had moved not just to a new neighborhood but to another region of the country, such as from New England to Nebraska.

headline: Rajoy Vows to Cut Taxes, Saying Spain Is Recovering
text: MADRID — Mariano Rajoy, the Spanish prime minister, on Tuesday announced an income-tax cut for low earners and a reduction in social security contributions by employers, citing an economic recovery he said would let Spain shift away from austerity measures.

headline: With ‘Drone to Home’ Service, Netflix Uses Satire Against Amazon
text: Netflix on Tuesday released a satirical video promising “Drone to Home” delivery of DVDs to customers, taking an obvious swipe at Amazon’s plan to deliver items to consumers via small octocopters, a.k.a. drones.

headline: Lucy Kirkwood Wins Blackburn Play Prize
text: The playwright Lucy Kirkwood has won this year’s Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, given “to recognize women who have written works of outstanding quality for the English-speaking theater,” for her play “Chimerica.” The award, which is to be presented by the director Phyllida Lloyd on Tuesday night at a ceremony in London, comes with $25,000 and a signed print by the artist Willem de Kooning.

headline: White House Meeting Turns Into a Lightning Round for Obama and Boehner
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner sat across from each other for an hour on Tuesday in the leather-bound chairs of Mr. Obama’s office and quickly ticked through a remarkably long list of issues.

headline: Bustan Opens on the Upper West Side
text: Headliner

headline: Anthony Vaccarello: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Paris

headline: The Gun Report: February 25, 2014
text: Yesterday, the Supreme Court declined to review two cases involving the rights of those under 21 to own handguns. One case involved a Texas law that bars nearly all 18-, 19- and 20-year-olds from obtaining a handgun permit. The other involved a federal law that prohibits licensed firearm dealers from selling handguns to people under 21, which was instituted in 1968 and aimed at diminishing violent crime. Both appeals were filed by the National Rifle Association.

headline: Share Your Experience With Race on Campus
text: For my article today on racism on college campuses, I spoke with students from around the country about how race is still very much an issue for young Americans despite openness to interracial dating, marriage and friendships. I also read dozens of posts on Twitter and other social media platforms and used Facebook to help find people to interview.

headline: Day After Uganda’s Antigay Law Is Signed, a Tabloid Publishes Names
text: In October 2010, a tabloid newspaper in Uganda called Rolling Stone published a front-page headline: “100 Pictures of Uganda’s Top Homos Leak. Hang Them.”

headline: Considering a New G.M.O.: Baby
text: From Fear of ‘Designer Babies’ as F.D.A. Weighs Fertility Procedure:

headline: G.M. to Expand Small-Car Recall to 1.4 Million Vehicles
text: General Motors will more than double the size of a recall issued this month for an ignition switch defect in some of its small cars, the automaker said in a news release Tuesday. The expansion brings the number of vehicles covered by the recall to nearly 1.4 million in the United States.

headline: Fresh Maine Scallops; Hefty Sandwiches and a Wine Club in Manhattan
text: To Sear: Sea Scallops That Taste Just Like Maine

headline: Starring a (Reluctant) Journalist
text: In the race for the Oscar for best feature documentary, so much attention has been paid to “The Act of Killing” and “The Square” — the first about mass killings in Indonesia, the other about the revolution in Egypt — that a third film about international politics has been overshadowed. But Richard Rowley’s “Dirty Wars” is even more global in its focus, examining clandestine American military operations in places like Afghanistan, Somalia and Yemen.

headline: Creative Writing, via a Workshop or the Big City
text: The four most influential young literary magazines in America, each founded within a few years of the turn of this century, are n + 1, based in Brooklyn; McSweeney’s and its sibling The Believer, both based in San Francisco; and Tin House, based in Portland, Ore. Tell me which you prefer, and I will, more or less, tell you who you are.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Magdalena Frackowiak at Anthony Vaccarello
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Magdalena Frackowiak (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Anthony Turner.

headline: Another Dingell Is Expected to Run for Congress in Michigan
text: WASHINGTON — Debbie Dingell, the wife of Representative John Dingell, the Michigan Democrat and longest-serving member of Congress who announced his retirement on Monday, is expected to announce a bid for her husband’s seat.

headline: In Idaho, Thin Snow Means Fat Tires
text: Snow has been so scant in Idaho this winter that bicycles started showing up in shop windows in the middle of January, and cyclists began booking ski huts during a season when it’s usually backcountry skiers who are seeking accommodations.

headline: Roy Simmons, 57, Lineman Who Later Came Out as Gay, Dies
text: Roy Simmons, a former offensive lineman for the Giants and the Washington Redskins and one of only a handful of N.F.L. players to have said publicly that they were gay — all after their playing careers ended — died Thursday in his apartment in the Bronx. He was 57.

headline: InterMune Lung Drug Is Successful in New Trial
text: A drug being developed to treat a fatal scarring of the lungs has succeeded in an important clinical trial and could become the first medicine to be approved for that disease, known as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

headline: Who Can Consent to a Warrantless Search?
text: Have you ever been in a home the police urgently wanted to search? What if you disagreed with someone under your own roof about whether to let the cops in without a warrant? That’s the position Roxanne Rojas found herself in one October day in 2009, stuck quite literally in between an abusive boyfriend and police officers in the heat of a robbery investigation.

headline: Obesity Rate for Young Children Plummets 43% in a Decade
text: Federal health authorities on Tuesday reported a 43 percent drop in the obesity rate among 2- to 5-year-old children over the past decade, the first broad decline in an epidemic that often leads to lifelong struggles with weight and higher risks for cancer, heart disease and stroke.

headline: Regulators Weigh In on Online Educational Services
text: As school districts around the country increasingly turn to online educational services that can collect and analyze details about how individual students learn, some parents and legislators have been raising questions about whether the personal information collected by such programs is federally protected from being shared or sold by technology vendors.

headline: A Digital Detective
text: Alison Chung followed her lifelong love of solving mysteries to found a forensic technology firm.

headline: Kiev in Chaos: Teaching About the Crisis in Ukraine
text: Updated: March 3, 2014

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Cédric Charlier Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Ladies and Gentlemen, the Polls Are Almost Closed
text: This is it. Soon the equivalent in Oscar circles of the checkered flag  will be waved: at 5 p.m. Pacific Standard Time, voting ends for the 86th Academy Awards. All ballots are due in — the paper versions that some members still prefer, or the online ones, which the majority of the Academy now uses.

headline: Watching TV Without Paying for Cable
text: Q. Is it possible to dump cable and still view my television, even if it is just local channels? I am really tired of paying the cable prices.

headline: An Inside Look at Cooking and Dining in Tel Aviv
text: Six years ago, Tel Aviv tapped into its inner voyeur when it joined the international movement “Houses from Within,” a festival in which residents of some of the city’s most interesting (and opulent) homes fling open their doors and allow the public to visit.

headline: In Performance: Bebe Neuwirth
text: The actress sings “Nowadays” from the Kander and Ebb musical “Chicago,” on Broadway at the Ambassador Theater. She is appearing in the show through March 9.

headline: Mixed Results, but Strong Outlook, for Home Depot and Macy’s
text: Home Depot and Macy’s, two of the country’s biggest retailers, reported mixed earnings for their fourth fiscal quarters on Tuesday, both partly blaming an unusually cold and stormy January for slow sales. Compared with many retailers, however, the companies did fairly well.

headline: Keyboard and Function Keys Returning to BlackBerry Phones
text: Last year, BlackBerry’s vision of the future was an all-touch-screen phone. Now John S. Chen, who became chief executive and executive chairman after that plan’s spectacular failure, is proposing a return to BlackBerry’s past as its path to the future.

headline: Religious Experience and the Modern Self
text: I have a couple of posts coming that aren’t quite direct follow-ups to what I wrote last week about Adam Gopnik’s New Yorker essay on atheism and belief, but deal with issues related to the whole modernity/belief/atheism tangle. For the first one, I wanted to juxtapose two pieces whose intended audiences don’t necessarily overlap that much — a London Review Books essay on Japan and “the ghosts of the tsunami,” and a Grantland career retrospective on the Dutch director Paul Verhoeven, of “Robocop” and “Showgirls” fame.

headline: First Lady Announces After-School Initiative
text: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama on Tuesday introduced a broad, five-year initiative to make after-school programs a healthier, more active environment for millions of children, saying the changes would also help the children’s performance during the other hours of the day.

headline: Unlikely Partners: Rookie Agents and Gay Player
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Joe Barkett loves to play chess, appreciating how the game rewards those who can think four or five steps ahead, an approach he has applied to his fledgling career as a sports agent. Yet for all the well-prepared plans that Barkett made with Cameron Weiss, his business partner and college friend, their unimaginably sudden rise began with a single, serendipitous keystroke.

headline: G.M. Report Shows Recall Investigation Took 10 Years
text: Alan Batey, president of General Motors North America, said Tuesday that the automaker’s nearly decade-long investigation of a defect for which it is now recalling 1.4 million vehicles – and which is related to 13 deaths — “was not as robust as it should have been.” The admission came as the automaker tried to explain to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration why it took so long to recall the vehicles.

headline: In 1930s Britain, an Office Lothario and the Women Who Endure Him
text: In the early 1930s, when the Great Depression had the planet in its grip, the playwright John van Druten could be counted on to provide Broadway audiences with a particular brand of escape: sophisticated modern comedies set amid London’s privileged classes.

headline: Many in China Can Now Have a Second Child, but Say No
text: BEIJING — After three decades of a Chinese policy that limits most families to one child, many families say they will not take advantage of a major change allowing a second child because of the rising cost of child-rearing.

headline: A Good Ratings Night for Another New NBC Late-Night Show
text: NBC’s introduction of its new late-night lineup continued in high gear Monday night as the first edition of the Seth Meyers version of the “Late Night” show opened with strong ratings numbers.

headline: Islamist Militants Blamed for Deadly College Attack in Nigeria
text: LAGOS, Nigeria — After herding the female students into a classroom, Islamist militants from the group Boko Haram fatally burned or shot dozens of male students in an attack late Monday on a state college in northeastern Nigeria, officials said on Tuesday. It was the fourth school assault attributed to the group in less than a year.

headline: Mozilla Hopes to Reduce Smartphone Prices Radically
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Can a cellphone maker produce a smartphone for just $25?

headline: A Respite From the Season and the Scene
text: Lately I’ve been keenly aware of needs I didn’t realize I had, like dress shoes with ice cleats, an age-appropriate ski cap, self-shoveling sidewalks and a car that can hop sideways over snowbanks into empty parking spots. With the first bite of my first course at a new restaurant in Brooklyn called Dover, I knew I’d been missing something else, too.

headline: Credit Suisse Helped U.S. Clients Hide Billions in Assets, Senate Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — An elevator controlled remotely. A bank office referred to by its code name. A sheaf of bank statements hidden in the pages of Sports Illustrated.

headline: The Theater of Faith and Doubt, Love and Pain
text: Craig Lucas has a romantic comedy about a not so funny topic opening on Thursday at the Cherry Lane Theater. “Ode to Joy,” produced by Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, is about addiction. Mr. Lucas, the prolific writer of “Reckless,” “Prelude to a Kiss,” “Longtime Companion” and the musical collaborations “Marry Me a Little” and “The Light in the Piazza,” also directs the new play, his follow-up to “The Lying Lesson” of last season. In an interview, he talked about the tricky art of keeping things light when the truth is hard to hear. Excerpts from the conversation follow.

headline: Frailty, Thy Name Is ...
text: There’s something distinctly unpromising about the Australian comedian Jim Jefferies, or rather, the fictional version of himself he plays on the FXX comedy “Legit”: paunchy, with a peculiar ridge of hair and the hesitant manner of a man expecting disaster.

headline: Battle Over London Market Raises Development Issues
text: LONDON — Trying to renovate a Victorian market and tack on some offices hip enough for Google in the oldest part of this ancient city is not a task for the weak of heart. Just ask Geoff Harris.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Chad and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Chad, Turkey, North Korea and India.

headline: Canadian Firm Buys Tower on Park Avenue
text: A Canadian investment firm has agreed to pay $575 million for a 33-story office tower at Park Avenue and 57th Street in the latest indication of a soaring real estate market spurred by foreign investment.

headline: Apple Issues Fix for Security Problem on Macs
text: Apple has finally issued a security update to its OS X Mavericks software for Macintosh computers, patching a bug that could have let hackers eavesdrop on supposedly encrypted connections and steal everything from usernames and passwords to location data.

headline: The Official, if Possibly Unnecessary, End of Acetaminophen Use During Pregnancy
text: This is the kind of research result that changes behavior.

headline: S.&P., in Lawsuit Defense, Seeks Documents About Obama-Geithner Meetings
text: Updated, 8:25 p.m. | For Timothy F. Geithner, the former Treasury secretary, meetings with President Obama were nothing out of the ordinary.But one such meeting has taken on outsize significance for Standard & Poor’s, the ratings agency that is defending itself against the government’s claims of fraud.

headline: Beauty in the Details
text: LONDON — Watching Elizabeth McGorian and Thomas Whitehead performing the Queen and Cattalabutte in “The Sleeping Beauty” at the Royal Opera House, it’s easy to think, “Only with the Royal Ballet.” The Queen is the loving, solicitous mother of Princess Aurora, the heroine whose finger prick casts the court into a hundred-year sleep; Cattalabutte is the fussy, officious master of ceremonies, whose oversight enrages the fairy Carabosse, causing all the trouble.

headline: Why Most Small-Business Owners Will See Premiums Rise Under A.C.A.
text: A new report from the federal government that says more small employers will see premiums increase than fall under the Affordable Care Act appears to have put the Obama administration on the defensive once again. But the report is remarkable as much for what it reveals about the current state of the small-group market as for how it might look under Obamacare, as the law is commonly known.

headline: You Think You Know Your Neighbors, but ...
text: “The Americans,” which returns Wednesday on FX, has a sly title that suggests how deeply deceptive this thriller is at its core.

headline: A Wasteland, With Aliens
text: “Almost Human,” a cheap-looking amalgam of “Fire in the Sky” (1993) and Philip Kaufman’s vigorous 1978 remake of “Invasion of the Body Snatchers,” should not be confused with the Fox television drama of the same name. That show features quirky writing, confident actors and at least one character who inspires empathy; this project, on the other hand, has clearly diverted too much of its small budget toward special effects.

headline: Stars! Or So They Can Seem
text: Before a recent performance of “iLuminate,” I felt like a schoolgirl who’d stolen an advance copy of the final exam. Having seen the show’s first version six months ago and read its publicity material, I knew what was going to unfold.

headline: Curtain Call | Milan Fashion Week
text: To mark the conclusion of Milan Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.

headline: After Inquiry, SAC Capital Says It Intends to Hire a Trading Monitor
text: Updated, 8:01 p.m. |

headline: Plaza-Saving Efforts Earn Honors for Groups
text: For their efforts to save Peavey Plaza in Minneapolis from the wrecking ball, the Preservation Alliance of Minnesota, the Cultural Landscape Foundation and the Minnesota chapter of Docomomo US have received the Advocacy Award of Excellence, one of three inaugural Modernism in America Awards. Established by Docomomo US, a nonprofit conservation organization dedicated to the modernist movement, the juried awards honor those working to preserve and rehabilitate midcentury architecture and design.

headline: Hiding in the Shadows, Scavenging for Clues in Every Drawer
text: On a widely discussed and admired recent episode of HBO’s “True Detective,” Rust Cohle, played by Matthew McConaughey, escaped from drug dealers, white supremacists and law enforcement through a series of improbable actions. He hid between two scraggly bushes, sneaked beneath a clothesline, paused behind a tree trunk, dashed into the shadowy section of a street and occasionally persuaded his pursuers to give up the chase by beating them into submission. At one point, Cohle waited quietly, gun aloft, against a wall as four armed men burst from a nearby door — only to run in the opposite direction.

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Milan Fashion Week Take Their Bows
text: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Milan Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.

headline: Obama Announces New Manufacturing Hubs
text: The president said two new manufacturing institutes would be located in Chicago and Detroit in an effort to create high-quality jobs.

headline: Morgan Stanley Reaches Agreement With S.E.C. on Mortgage Bonds
text: Morgan Stanley has tentatively agreed to pay $275 million to resolve a federal securities investigation related to subprime mortgage bonds the investment firm underwrote in 2007.

headline: A Buyout Offer That Raises Questions of Board Fairness and Duty
text: If you happen to control a public company and want to buy out the remaining shareholders, avoid the mistakes made by the American Financial Group in its attempt to squeeze out the minority at the National Interstate Corporation.

headline: Choose Your Monetary Adventure, Mt. Gox Edition
text: Bitcoin was, of course, created in part to cater to libertarian dreams – to provide a way to store your wealth where governments can’t steal it through taxation or currency debasement.

headline: Tour’s Director Criticizes New ‘Annie’
text: The $12 million Broadway revival of “Annie” closed last month as a critical disappointment and commercial failure. But it turns out that the musical’s hard-knock life continues.

headline: Knights in Shining Opera, at the Met
text: They did a Haydn opera about a supposed trip to the moon at the Hayden Planetarium, a rare Baroque piece featuring a decadent Roman emperor at a decadent downtown nightclub, and a Daniel Catán opera set in a poisonous garden at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Times Minute | U.S. Colleges and Race
text: Racial tension at United States colleges. Also on the Minute, The National Enquirer settles a libel suit surrounding an actor's death and Disney launches a new movie app.

headline: Argentina Takes Its Debt Case to the U.S. Supreme Court
text: Argentina has now staked the future of its debt, and perhaps its financial fate, with the United States Supreme Court. Yes, you read that right. Argentina wants the nine justices to weigh in on a case involving its obligations to holders of its government bonds and to resolve the mess created by a handful of federal judges.

headline: A View From Iran: ‘Respect Rather Than Sanctions’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lessons From Google, in School and at Work
text: To the Editor:

headline: Study Finds Limited Benefit to Some ‘Medical Homes’
text: You may have heard the term “medical home” to describe a way of organizing doctors’ practices to provide more comprehensive, less costly, patient-friendly treatment. Insurance companies often offer more money to practices that become recognized as medical homes, which use a team approach to coordinate care. States are even looking to medical homes to help save money in their Medicaid programs.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Cédric Charlier’s Side-Swept Locks
text: For the Cédric Charlier runway, the hairstylist Laurent Philippon created a look based on a severe part. Starting above the left eye, he divided the hair all the way back, in a perfect line, to the bottom of the neck — a style inspired by the coifs of film noir heroines and silent-movie stars. To the left of the divide, tousled locks were tucked behind the ear and draped naturally over the shoulder. And on the right, they were pushed forward over the ear for what Philippon described as a “rock ‘n’ roll twist.” “I loaded the hair with Bb.Gel from Bumble and Bumble,” he explained while combing the product through and then ruffling it with his fingers. To finish, he used Bumble and Bumble’s new City Swept spray, which provided “beautiful natural shine.” The texture of this look is in fact quite stiff, but it offers the illusion of soft, wet hair. “I would have left it wet,” Philippon noted, “but we had fur.”

headline: As Rest of Economy Weakens, Chinese Exports Surge
text: GUANGZHOU, China — The vast steel mill here on the south bank of the Pearl River was supposed to have closed more than three years ago, its labyrinth of rusty chutes and sheds bulldozed and its huge cranes with gigantic steel claws dismantled for scrap.

headline: Restaurant Worker Wages
text: To the Editor:

headline: Andrew Silberfein
text: Mr. Silberfein, 49, is the chief executive of Rouse Properties, a publicly traded real estate investment trust based in New York. The company owns and operates 34 malls in 21 states, or around 24.5 million square feet of retail property.

headline: Ukrainian Journalists Launch YanukovychLeaks
text: Viktor Yanukovych may have vanished early Saturday from Ukraine’s presidential palace outside Kiev, but not without a trace. His entourage left behind security-camera images of a hasty flight from the lavish compound, and something else — tens of thousands of apparently incriminating documents that were still floating near a dock at the waterfront residence when journalists and curious spectators arrived.

headline: Bank of America Discloses 2 New Investigations
text: Bank of America said that it was facing two new investigations related to its activities in foreign currency exchange markets and its handling of government-backed mortgages in the United States.

headline: Ukraine’s Crisis, and the Russia Card
text: To the Editor:

headline: Solar Industry Jump-Starts a Revival in California
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Back in 2009, when Danny Kennedy was looking for office space for the fast-growing solar services company he had co-founded, his venture capital investors recommended setting up shop in one of the “Twitterville kinds of areas” south of Market Street in San Francisco.

headline: Abolitionist or Terrorist?
text: FAYETTEVILLE, N.Y. — ON Feb. 15, a group of activists in Charleston, S.C., unveiled a life-size statue of Denmark Vesey, a black abolitionist who was executed in 1822 for leading a failed slave rebellion in the city.

headline: With Syria, Diplomacy Needs Force
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE conventional wisdom about Syria is that nothing can be done. It is said that military action would be either perverse — bringing the jihadists in the opposition to power — or futile, failing to tip the balance against the government of President Bashar al-Assad. Using force, it is argued, would also jeopardize other strategic objectives, like securing a lasting nuclear deal with Syria’s supporter Iran.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: Recent Sale

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Anthony Vacarello Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: U.S. Orders Tests on Rail Shipments of Oil
text: Federal regulators on Tuesday ordered shippers to properly test and classify crude oil from the productive Bakken region before loading it onto freight trains, a move meant to tighten regulatory standards after a spate of derailments and explosions that highlighted the hazards of carrying crude oil on rails.

headline: For Hotels.com’s Campaign, the Answer Was Obvious
text: TO the pantheon of brand mascots that includes the Most Interesting Man in the World, who pitches Dos Equis beer, and the Wisest, who peddles Campbell’s Soup, a website for booking accommodations is hoping to add an advertising character meant to be regarded as the Most Obvious Man in the World.

headline: How the West Can Shape Ukraine
text: Can the U.S. and the E.U. foster democracy without antagonizing Russia?

headline: Trust Eroded, Obama Looks Beyond Karzai
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, apparently resigned to President Hamid Karzai’s refusal to sign a long-term security agreement with the United States before he leaves office, told him in a phone call on Tuesday that he had instructed the Pentagon to begin planning for a complete withdrawal of American troops from Afghanistan by the end of the year.

headline: A Luxury for the Mets: Two Promising Catchers
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — With the 35th overall pick of the 2012 amateur draft, the Mets chose Kevin Plawecki, who was among the top catchers in college baseball. He was polished at the plate and behind it. He could get on base, flash some power and manage his pitchers. He had all the makings of a major league catcher.

headline: A Nonprofit Lender Revives the Hopes of Subprime Borrowers
text: WASHINGTON — About 200 people struggling to become homeowners filled the pews of Plymouth Congregational church on a recent Saturday morning. Some were self-employed, others short on a down payment, many branded by credit problems. Mortgage lenders would have thrown money at them a decade ago. Now, the chastened industry turns them away.

headline: The Bane and the Boon of For-Profit Colleges
text: Marc Jerome, the executive vice president of Monroe College, says his business is being unfairly targeted as corrupt.

headline: Turks Are Glued to a Sensational Drama, This One Political
text: ISTANBUL — Turks have always loved a good soap opera. Years ago the fixation was “Dallas,” and Turks of a certain age still refer to a woman who drinks too much as Sue Ellen, the boozy character on that show. More recently, the Turkish drama “The Magnificent Century,” about palace intrigue and romance in an Ottoman sultan’s harem, became an obsession here and in the Middle East.

headline: Back on His Feet and Leading a New Team
text: Mike Lonergan, then the coach of Vermont, was scouting an A.A.U. tournament several years ago when he noticed Maurice Creek, a 6-foot-5 guard. Creek was on the same team as a player Lonergan was trying to recruit, and as Lonergan watched Creek effortlessly convert jump shots, some thoughts crossed the coach’s mind: He is a really good shooter, but I will never coach him. He is too highly rated.

headline: Nuclear Waste Repository Set to Reopen After Leak
text: Almost two weeks after an unexplained puff of radioactive materials forced the closing of a salt mine in New Mexico that is used to bury nuclear bomb wastes, managers of the mine are planning to send workers back in and are telling nearby residents that their health is safe.

headline: Ivan Nagy, Star of American Ballet Theater, Is Dead at 70
text: Ivan Nagy, a dancer of riveting noble presence who became one of American Ballet Theater’s most popular stars in the 1970s as an acclaimed partner to great ballerinas, died on Saturday in Budapest. He was 70.

headline: Author’s Unmasking Won’t Stop Book
text: In a book proposal recently sent to publishers, the writer known only as @GSElevator — a popular Twitter account consisting of things purportedly overheard inside Goldman Sachs’s elevators — bragged about being aggressively recruited by the bank.

headline: Don’t Just Do Something. Sit There.
text: With Russia growling over the downfall of its ally running Ukraine and still protecting its murderous ally running Syria, there is much talk that we’re returning to the Cold War — and that the Obama team is not up to defending our interests or friends. I beg to differ. I don’t think the Cold War is back; today’s geopolitics are actually so much more interesting than that. And I also don’t think President Obama’s caution is entirely misplaced.

headline: Tentatively, European Union Weighs Its Options on Support for a New Ukraine
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The European Union’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, spent two days here promising unspecific support for a new Ukrainian government but urging it not to break close trading and cultural links with Russia. Ms. Ashton’s deft dance was inevitable — the European Union and the West are not willing or capable of bailing out Ukraine’s economy, especially if Moscow retaliates with new punitive tariffs, higher prices for natural gas and a cutoff of significant ties to Ukrainian factories and businesses.

headline: Long-Suffering Royals Regain Confidence
text: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Dayton Moore has been coming here for eight years as the general manager of the Kansas City Royals, roaming the practice fields on sun-kissed February mornings, watching his prospects and imagining a better tomorrow. Now, he believes, it is here.

headline: Rethinking Our ‘Rights’ to Dangerous Behaviors
text: In the last few years, it’s become increasingly clear that food companies engineer hyperprocessed foods in ways precisely geared to most appeal to our tastes. This technologically advanced engineering is done, of course, with the goal of maximizing profits, regardless of the effects of the resulting foods on consumer health, natural resources, the environment or anything else.

headline: Lincoln and the ‘Cannibals’
text: While America was embroiled in a bloody civil war for its very survival, a little over 5,000 miles away from Washington, in the middle of the South Pacific, the people of the Marquesas Islands were in a struggle of their own over slavery.

headline: De Blasio Says New York Can Add 29,000 Pre-K Seats
text: One of the biggest questions surrounding Mayor Bill de Blasio’s push for a higher income tax to pay for more prekindergarten seats in New York City is whether he could create enough seats to justify the increase.

headline: Clinton Makes Kentucky Appearance
text: The former president spoke at a fund-raiser in Louisville for Alison Lundergan Grimes, a Democratic Senate candidate.

headline: The Education of a Long Island Conservative
text: Who says old politicians can’t reinvent themselves, jettison long-held beliefs and emerge from ideological cocoons, fresh as butterflies?

headline: Ex-President Ventures Where Some Might Not
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — When Alison Lundergan Grimes, Kentucky’s Democratic Senate candidate, welcomed former President Bill Clinton to a fund-raiser here Tuesday, she offered a rendering of recent political history suited for red-state Democrats: Mr. Clinton’s tenure was showered with praise, former President George W. Bush was mildly scorned, and President Obama was implicitly rebuked.

headline: North Korea’s Atrocities
text: The world has long been aware of North Korea’s repression and brutality against its citizens, through the stories of escapees and reports by human rights groups and the State Department. But a study by a special United Nations commission has produced the most authoritative indictment yet.

headline: At Steinbrenner Field, Heisman Winner Is Star Attraction
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees have had encounters with college football stars, including one who played at Florida State University. That was Deion Sanders, nicknamed Prime Time, who signed his minor league contract with a dollar sign for the S in his name, as General Manager Brian Cashman recalled.

headline: Trading Site Failure Stirs Ire and Hope for Bitcoin
text: The apparent collapse of Bitcoin’s best-known and once-dominant trading platform has provoked outrage among its users, but it has also stirred hopes that the way may now be clear for more established players to transform and rein in a largely unregulated market.

headline: A Military Budget to Fit the Times
text: The Pentagon’s proposals to reduce the Army to pre-World War II levels and modify some benefits for troops and retirees may seem unsettling to a nation that prides itself on having the world’s most capable military. But these ideas, part of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s 2015 military budget, reflect a necessary and more prudent realism as America ends 13 years at war.

headline: Christian University Resumes Inquiry in Handling of Sexual Abuse Reports
text: An investigation into Bob Jones University’s handling of sexual abuse complaints will be allowed to resume, the university and investigators said on Tuesday, after the school endured two weeks of criticism for cutting off the inquiry, without explanation, as it neared completion.

headline: An Unfinished Ukraine Palace and a Fugitive Leader’s Folly
text: LASPI, Ukraine — Chased from his sumptuous villa outside the Ukrainian capital and last sighted searching for a sanctuary here on the Crimean Peninsula, Viktor F. Yanukovych, the former president, suffered a final indignity on Tuesday: The masons and electricians he had hired to build a Pharaonic seaside retreat in a historic, old-growth forest decided that he would never pay his bills and started hauling away their equipment and materials.

headline: Christie’s Budget Proposes Sacrifices but No Big Solution to Labor Costs
text: TRENTON — A diminished Gov. Chris Christie sought to reclaim the mantle of fiscal sobriety that helped catapult him to Republican stardom, releasing a budget on Tuesday that called for new sacrifices from public employees, offered a painful payment to New Jersey’s indebted pension system and abandoned his cherished plan to cut the state income tax.

headline: Crude Weapons Help Fuel Unrest in Bastion of Venezuelan Opposition
text: SAN CRISTÓBAL, Venezuela — No one here is hiding the heavy artillery, such as it is. Students camping out on an intersection of this city, which has become a battleground between the authorities and antigovernment protesters, have a variety of homemade weapons — mortars to lob small, noisy explosives, miniature firebombs, slingshots, clubs and nasty-looking things called Miguelitos made from hoses festooned with nails.

headline: Pioneering Aside, Collins Just Tries to Learn Plays
text: LOS ANGELES — Jason Collins was longing for a sense of normalcy Tuesday at Nets practice.

headline: After Career of Firsts in Air Force, G.O.P. Challenger Has a New Mission
text: TUCSON — The Air Force Association’s Cochise Chapter had fallen into a rapt silence as Martha McSally — the first female fighter pilot to fly a combat mission and command a fighter squadron — recounted a tale from her days in the military, the time when what was supposed to be a “routine reconnaissance” mission in Afghanistan went awry.

headline: Parade Marches Backward
text: I have long been opposed to gays marching in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade on Fifth Avenue.

headline: Justice Dept. Informs Inmate of Pre-Arrest Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has informed a former Brooklyn man who is serving a 15-year prison sentence over a terrorism-related conviction that his communications were subjected to surveillance without warrants before his arrest.

headline: Shell Game
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today marks the debut of crossword constructor Ruth B. Margolin, whose first-ever New York Times puzzle has been rated a Wednesday difficulty. Not bad for a newcomer.

headline: El Chapo’s Arrest Unlikely to Break Mexican Cartel
text: To have a crack at an international kingpin, undercover officers from Boston and New Hampshire went from the mountains of northern Mexico through the Caribbean to Spain, where they discovered operatives of the powerful Sinaloa cartel setting up new routes and new markets.

headline: Toxicology Expert Lifts Kerry Kennedy’s Defense
text: WHITE PLAINS — On the second day of Kerry Kennedy’s misdemeanor trial on charges of driving under the influence of a sleeping pill, the prosecution’s pharmaceutical expert said that the drug, a generic version of Ambien, could render users incapable of recognizing that their driving was impaired.

headline: 17 Brokerage Firms Agree to End Analysis Previews
text: Seventeen brokerage firms, including Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Merrill Lynch, have agreed to stop participating in money management surveys aimed at tapping into research analysts’ changing views on companies before those opinions are publicly issued.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 25, 2014
Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 26, 2014
text: “Why does he need a palace every few kilometers? He thought he was a czar.”

headline: The Wilfred Complaint: Salazar et al. v. The Dept. of Education
text: A lawsuit filed in federal court contends that the government should cease collection of loans for students who were falsely certified for enrollment at Wilfred Academy.

headline: Suit Seeks Relief for Trade School Students With Years of Debt but No Career
text: The Wilfred Academy promised her “everything you’ll need for your beauty career.” When she enrolled, Ana Salazar, a single mother of four, then 40, believed it was a ticket out of her minimum wage job as a security guard.

headline: Hired to Fight Pirates, but Doomed by Boredom
text: PORT OF VICTORIA, Seychelles — The night before their lifeless bodies were found inside a cabin on a cargo ship, Jeffrey Reynolds and Mark Kennedy enjoyed the night life here, at tourist haunts called Le Rendez Vous and the Pirates Arms.

headline: Corrections: February 26, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Honorific Streets, Now Cataloged
text: For a brief moment, a woman named Zenita Thompson enjoyed a small dollop of immortality. In 2006, City Councilwoman Letitia James of Brooklyn introduced legislation to rename half of a two-block-long street in Crown Heights, McKeever Place, for Ms. Thompson.

headline: 2 Hollywood Stars on Capitol Hill
text: WASHINGTON — Television and the movies cannot seem to resist juicy Washington settings — “House of Cards” (intrigue!), “Scandal” (high drama!) or maybe “Veep” (zany!) — but on Wednesday, Capitol Hill will provide the background for two Hollywood stars with real-life missions.

headline: Russian Opposition Leaders Get Jail Terms
text: MOSCOW — A municipal court on Tuesday jailed several Russian opposition leaders, including the activist and blogger Aleksei A. Navalny, for resisting arrest during a rally near the Kremlin that ended with more than 400 demonstrators detained by the police.

headline: Lawyers for American Couple Seek Inquiry in Qatar
text: Lawyers for an American couple, held in Qatar for more than a year on charges that they murdered their adopted African daughter by denying her food and water, have formally asked the country’s attorney general to open an investigation into medical evidence used by the prosecution, asserting that it was fabricated.

headline: New Twist Emerges in ’86 Murder of Swedish Premier
text: LONDON — Ever since Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden was gunned down on a Stockholm sidewalk in 1986, theories about his unsolved murder have proliferated, with suspicions that Kurdish separatists or apartheid-era South African hit teams were behind it.

headline: Hong Kong Editor Whose Ouster Stirred Protests Is Slashed
text: Updated, 2:58 a.m. E.D.T.| The former chief editor of a Hong Kong newspaper whose dismissal in January stirred protests about press freedom in the Chinese territory was slashed Wednesday morning, the police said.

headline: New Coalition Takes On India’s Two Biggest Parties
text: NEW DELHI — Eleven political parties, including seven regional parties, formed a coalition on Tuesday in hopes of drawing voters away from India’s two main national parties in the general elections in May.

headline: Britain: Police Error Frees Bombing Suspect
text: A man accused of killing four British soldiers in a bombing in London in 1982 will not face trial because he was mistakenly told that he was not wanted by the police. John Downey, 62, from Ireland, was arrested at Gatwick Airport last year and charged with four counts of murder. A court in London was told that Mr. Downey, who had denied the charges, was one of 187 suspects who were assured that they would not be prosecuted as part of moves to resolve the conflict in Northern Ireland. In a statement issued Tuesday, the Metropolitan Police said that Mr. Downey’s letter was sent incorrectly in 2007 but that it respected a court ruling that he should not face prosecution.

headline: Imperfect Already?
text: The first PATH station platform at the developing World Trade Center hub, for riders to Hoboken, N.J., opened on Tuesday.

headline: Why the I.R.S. Scandal Won’t Go Away
text: In the continuing battle over Republican allegations that the Obama administration pressured the Internal Revenue Service to obstruct Tea Party applications for tax-exempt status, three well-known political figures are among those likely to benefit: Karl Rove and David and Charles Koch.

headline: Optional Seating
text: Object of art? Perch for books or a drink? Bedside table? Chairs this good looking transcend their function through exceptional form.

headline: How to Get Fit in a Few Minutes a Week
text: High-intensity interval training, a type of workout that consists of very brief bouts of very strenuous exercise, has become enormously popular in recent years. A main reason is that although such workouts are draining, they can be both very effective and very short, often lasting only a few minutes.

headline: The Affordable Care Act’s Multiple Taxes
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Word of the Day | cant
text: cant •\ˈkant\• noun and verb

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 11:35 A.M. (Starz Cinema) A SEPARATION (2011) In this Oscar winner for best foreign-language film, a couple (Leila Hatami, above, and Peyman Moadi) must decide whether to leave Iran for the sake of their daughter or stay to care for a parent with dementia. Either option could end their marriage. “It is a rigorously honest movie about the difficulties of being honest, a film that tries to be truthful about the slipperiness of truth,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this drama, written and directed by Asghar Farhadi and starring his daughter, Sarina, as the couple’s child. “It also sketches a portrait — perhaps an unnervingly familiar picture for American audiences — of a society divided by sex, generation, religion and class.”

headline: As Steel Mill Closes, Guangzhou Loses a Piece of Its History
text: Few steel mills in China have as storied a history as the Guangzhou Steel mill. Rival factions during the Cultural Revolution engaged in gun battles in and around the sprawling complex. Local residents say that young men and women hoping to flee China’s poverty and chaos in those days prepared for the all-night swim through shark-infested waters from Shenzhen to Hong Kong by practicing in the murky waters of the Pearl River next to the factory.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 26, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Airbus to Increase A320 Production
text: PARIS — Record demand for new commercial jets drove a 22 percent jump in profit at Airbus Group last year, prompting the European plane maker on Wednesday to announce a 10 percent increase in production of its most popular single-aisle plane.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The ‘Star Quality’ of Jennifer Lawrence
text: In “Being Human Seems Enough,” the Times film critic Manohla Dargis writes an appreciation of the Oscar-nominated actress Jennifer Lawrence.

headline: The Sublime Combination of Butter and Soy
text: Who knows who first mixed soy sauce and butter and discovered the pleasures the combination provides. Try the mixture on warm white rice, a steaming pile of greens or an old sneaker — regardless, the taste is a sublime velvet of sweet and salty, along with a kind of pop the cognoscenti call umami, a fifth taste beyond bitter, sour, salty and sweet. Soy butter provides warmth and luxury, elegance without pomp. It raises recipes to heights almost indescribable in the telling.

headline: Chris Lehane Out-Washingtons Washington
text: On a hot Sacramento morning, Chris Lehane burst into a conference room filled with trial lawyers, lobbyists and one aggrieved mother, and laid out his battle plan: How to force California to raise its 40-year-old ceiling on medical-malpractice awards. Lehane, who is 46, spent six years working in the Clinton White House, battling the ethical scandals that seemed to confront the administration every day — typically by discrediting the accuser or leaking a document to undercut an impending news story critical of the president or the first lady. Now Lehane uses similar strategies — opposition research, attention-grabbing antics, the crafty manipulation of old and new media — for groups like this one, the Consumer Attorneys of California. The campaign to raise the cap on damages for pain and suffering in medical malpractice suits, which was set at $250,000, might have been handled legislatively, but much high-impact law in California is made at the ballot box, in the form of well-publicized voter initiatives. Influencing voters with his own extreme brand of performance politics has become Lehane’s specialty.

headline: Empowering Photographers to Embrace an Uncertain Future
text: With a torrent of images from the mundane to the momentous on social media and online, Susan Meiselas has been thinking about how to empower and excite photographers about an uncertain future. Ms. Meiselas, a member of Magnum, was a guest editor for the latest issue of Aperture magazine, where she highlights how photographers can embrace their new tools to make new choices and start new conversations.“Everyone has a smartphone and everyone’s a photographer,” she told the Lens co-editor James Estrin. “So those who have committed themselves to developing the visual language of photography over these decades have to ask, ‘How can we continue to contribute?’ ”Their conversation has been edited.

headline: Is Your Generation Really ‘Postracial’?
text: According to Urban Dictionary, “postracial” is “a term used to describe a society or time period in which discussions around race and racism have been deemed no longer relevant to current social dynamics. Popularized after the election of Barack Obama to the presidency of the United States of America in 2009.”

headline: Milan Looks
text: Fur, fabrics and fancy dominated the runways during the Italian fashion week.

headline: New York Today: Bundle Up, It’s Almost March
text: Good Wednesday morning to you.

headline: Most Democrats Want Clinton to Run in 2016
text: More than 8 in 10 Democrats say they want Hillary Rodham Clinton to run for president in 2016, showing a level of interest in her that no other potential candidates – Democrat or Republican – come close to matching among their party’s voters, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: ‘I Have Been Told That I’m Different’
text: Alison Chung of Chicago is not wired like most people. This can present challenges socially, but from a business perspective it’s her competitive advantage as the owner of a consulting firm that is essentially a digital detective agency.

headline: Daily Report: As Mt. Gox Falls, Bitcoin Looks to the Future
text: The apparent collapse of Bitcoin’s best-known and once-dominant trading platform has provoked outrage among its users, but it has also stirred hopes that the way may now be clear for more established players to transform and rein in a largely unregulated market, Rachel Abrams and Nathaniel Popper report.

headline: Poll Results
text: The full results of The New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Private Equity Leaders See Opportunities in Europe
text: BERLIN – Private equity leaders expressed optimism on Wednesday about the prospects for investments in Europe as economies recover.

headline: A Silver Lining in Bitcoin’s Stumble
text: BITCOIN’S SILVER LINING  |  The apparent collapse of Mt. Gox, the most prominent Bitcoin exchange, late Monday night naturally stirred outrage and panic. After all, a document circulating widely in the Bitcoin world said the company had lost 744,000 Bitcoins — about 6 percent of Bitcoins in circulation — worth more than $300 million at current exchange rates. But Bitcoin’s latest troubles did little to shake the confidence of many, and indeed, the virtual currency’s stumble may provide just the spark it needs to become a more mature part of the financial system, Nathaniel Popper and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook.

headline: Carlyle’s Co-Founder Says More Private Equity Firms Likely to Go Public
text: BERLIN — David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder of the private equity firm Carlyle Group, said on Wednesday that he believed more private equity firms would seek to go public in the next few years.

headline: In Performance: Bebe Neuwirth of ‘Chicago’
text: Theatergoers who check out Bebe Neuwirth’s return to the Kander and Ebb musical “Chicago,” where she is playing the prison matron “Mama” Morton through March 9, will hear her sing the character’s signature number, “When You’re Good to Mama.” To celebrate her “Chicago” trifecta — Ms. Neuwirth has also played the principal roles of Velma and Roxie — she chose to sing “Nowadays,” a song she describes as “archetypical Kander and Ebb.”

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Jacquemus Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

headline: VSPs of 2010
text: Dan Drezner has an interesting article in Politico that’s framed as a rebuttal to Nick Kristof’s condemnation of irrelevant academics, but is actually much broader. Drezner argues that there are three tribes — money men, political insiders, and academics — each of which has its own strengths and weaknesses, and each of which would be well advised to listen to the others (but doesn’t).

headline: Red Spreads
text: Uh-oh. Chinese equivalents of the TED spread and other gauges of financial stress in the US have widened sharply. The widening in the TED spread was one of the key reasons I was already very scared in late 2007. If past is prologue, we should be very worried about China now.

headline: Now, Nations Mull the Ways to Regulate Bitcoin
text: Authorities around the world are grappling with how to regulate virtual currency in the wake of the implosion of Mt. Gox, a prominent trading platform for Bitcoin.

headline: China Charges Scholar With Inciting Separatism
text: BEIJING — Security officials in China’s far western borderlands have formally arrested a scholar and champion of the country’s ethnic Uighurs on charges of inciting separatism, his lawyer said Wednesday.

headline: Media Report | Big (Bad) Data
text: The buzziest idea in business may be its greatest downfall.

headline: Data Breach Hurts Profit at Target
text: The widespread theft of Target customer data had a significant impact on the company’s profit, which fell more than 40 percent in the fourth quarter, the retailer reported on Wednesday.

headline: A Tough Decision for a Cafe Regular
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Thai Army Reinforces Areas Near Protesters
text: BANGKOK — After two consecutive nights of gunfire in Bangkok’s central business district, the Thai army on Wednesday built sandbag bunkers in upscale neighborhoods and reinforced what officials described as a peacekeeping presence near areas occupied by protesters seeking to overthrow the Thai government.

headline: Feelings, Facts, Food and Genetic Engineering – A Fresh Look
text: Updated, 2:16 p.m. | Please watch and weigh in on this open-minded discussion of the intersection of biotechnology, the environment and the dinner plate at Pace University.

headline: Judge Expedites Men’s Wearhouse Lawsuit
text: A Delaware judge on Tuesday expedited Men’s Wearhouse’s lawsuit against its smaller rival, Jos. A. Bank, in an ugly takeover battle between the men’s suit retailers that is playing out in court.

headline: As Putin Orders Drills in Crimea, Protesters’ Clash Shows Region’s Divide
text: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — With cries of “Allahu akbar,” Arabic for “God is great,” thousands of protesters in the capital of Ukraine’s Crimea region, a tinderbox of ethnic, religious and political divisions, added an Islamic voice on Wednesday to the tumultuous struggle for Ukraine that last weekend drove the president from power and that has pushed Russia and the West into a face-off reminiscent of the Cold War.

headline: Hazardous Duty
text: While Steve Sheinkin was researching his last book, “Bomb: The Race to Build — and Steal — the World’s Most Dangerous Weapon” (later a National Book Award finalist and a Newbery Honor winner), he came across an astounding story from that era. In 1944, in the midst of the Second World War, 50 African-American sailors were tried for mutiny, convicted and sentenced to 15 years hard labor. Their only crime was to refuse to load ammunition.

headline: Veterans at Home, on a Mission of Compassion
text: Rachel Gutierrez was an army sergeant in Iraq, but back home in Phoenix she leads a platoon. At 2:30 in the morning last Oct. 18, members of the 1st Platoon Phoenix   gathered at an all-night McDonalds in a bad neighborhood downtown. Their mission was to comb the streets for chronically homeless veterans (who tend to sleep in groups but scatter during the day) and register them to get housing and other services.

headline: A Queen of What-Ifs
text: Idina Menzel has a blockbuster voice that seems to have a knack for blockbusters. Not only did she star in the original “Rent,” but she also delivered the anthem “Defying Gravity” in the seemingly unstoppable “Wicked.” And while the success of the Disney movie “Frozen” is a result of many factors, the most underrated might be the force with which Ms. Menzel delivers its signal song, “Let It Go,” which does not easily wear out its welcome. (Trust me, as a father of a 5-year-old fan, I have tested this.)

headline: Walking Through Majorca
text: On Foot Holidays, the self-guided walking tours specialist, has introduced a new route — its 21st — to the Spanish island of Majorca.

headline: A New Title for Angela Missoni
text: Soon it will be Dr. Angela Missoni to you.

headline: CreatureCast: A Tale of Two Urchins
text: Many different species do similar things. The pencil sea urchin and green sea urchin, for example, are both grazers in the coastal waters of the Galapagos Islands.

headline: Two Urchins, Similar but Not
text: When does biodiversity matter for the function of ecosystems, and when can we consider different species to be essentially the same? When, for example, is a grazer just a grazer, and when do we need to consider the distinctions between different species of grazers?

headline: Paco de Lucía, Master Flamenco Guitarist, Dies at 66
text: Paco de Lucía, who was born into a musical family and grew up to become one of the world’s greatest guitarists, mastering flamenco music and finding new audiences by blending it with jazz and other genres, died on Wednesday in Mexico. He was 66.

headline: Slalom for Russia as It Seeks to Invest in North Caucasus
text: ARKHYZ, Russia — Just over the mountains from where Russia’s Olympic dream played out this month to a worldwide audience, Aleksei Grebennikov, a copper miner, glided down the bunny slope of a brand-new ski resort on the Abishira-Akhuba mountain ridge.

headline: To Die For
text: It’s no secret that smoking and drinking are terrible for you. Why, then, are designers determined to make vice look so nice?

headline: No Comment Necessary: The Fake Dangers of Marijuana
text: It’s hard finding evidence that you can die from a marijuana overdose—because no one has ever died from a marijuana overdose. Unless, that is, you resort to fake news, as Annapolis Police Chief Michael Pristoop did on Tuesday.

headline: Little Orchestra Society Wants Your Help to Rename Itself
text: What’s in a name? For the Little Orchestra Society, there’s a lot of history — the orchestra was founded in 1947 and has become renowned for its inventive educational concerts, and also, increasingly, for its inventive presentations of new works. But lately, members of the ensemble’s board and management, as well as the conductor James Judd, who became its music director last season, have been worrying that the name doesn’t fully reflect the orchestra’s mission.
