text: 1964: Cassius Clay Beats Liston

headline: The Koch Brothers’ Network
text: The Center for Responsive Politics has put together a chart of what it calls “the Koch brothers’ labyrinthine network of political groups.”

headline: Viktor Yanukovych’s Car Collection Was a Private Automotive History Museum
text: Ever since Viktor F. Yanukovych fled Kiev last week, the world has gotten a good look at the deposed Ukrainian president’s lavish residential complex. Among the zoo, the golf course and the many garish luxury items on the site (notably the fake pirate ship), Mr. Yanukovych kept a collection of automobiles that would make any collector proud.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Viewer Numbers, at Least if Twitter Is Any Guide
text: How many people watched the second season of “House of Cards” on Netflix? Only Netflix knows because the streaming service withholds viewership data in a way that Francis Underwood, the show’s conniving main character, might admire. But if the number of messages on Twitter about “House of Cards” is any clue, the audience for the political thriller may have grown substantially.

headline: Metal Singer Pleads Guilty in Plot to Kill Estranged Wife
text: Tim Lambesis, the singer for the Christian metal band As I Lay Dying, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to trying to hire an undercover sheriff’s deputy to murder his estranged wife, Meggan Lambesis. The singer’s new plea — he had pleaded not guilty in September — brings the case nearly to an end: he will be sentenced, in San Diego County on May 2, nearly a year after his arrest. Until then, The Associated Press reports, the singer, 32, is free on $2 million bond. He faces a nine-year jail term and a $10,000 fine.

headline: App Smart: Creativity
text: Kit Eaton describes three apps that can help in the creative thinking process.

headline: Finding the Right App to Unblock Those Creative Juices
text: Creative thinking is a huge part of a job like mine, but it’s also critical to many types of work — including yours, I’ll bet.

headline: To Pay for Infrastructure Repairs, Obama Seeks Tax Changes
text: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Caught between a gridlocked Congress and a Highway Trust Fund that will soon be broke, President Obama on Wednesday urged lawmakers to overhaul corporate and business taxes to pay for repairing and replacing the nation’s aging roads, rails, bridges and tunnels.

headline: Interview: Randy Thom
text: Randy Thom, the director of sound design at Skywalker Sound, discusses his work.

headline: Prominent Occupations Still Viewed as Male Domains, Study Finds
text: A new report finds that while both men and women say there are not enough women in positions of power in the workplace, a majority of respondents still preferred to cast men in prominent jobs.

headline: Kerry Kennedy Hits Back as Prosecutors Question Story Line at Trial
text: WHITE PLAINS — Did she have the cappuccino and carrots for breakfast before the medication? Or did the medication come first?

headline: Poll Suggests Crushing Loss Awaits India’s Governing Party
text: NEW DELHI — Two months before Indians vote in national elections, a new poll suggests that India’s dominant political party and family may suffer one of their worst defeats in the country’s 67-year history.

headline: Today in Small Business: Online Reviews Matter More Than Most Owners Think
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today?

headline: Clip: 'Lone Survivor'
text: A scene from the film, directed by Peter Berg, with sound editing by Wylie Stateman.

headline: The Ellen DeGeneres Synergy Stop
text: Having an Oscar host with her own talk show is proving to be the very definition of cross-brand promotion. Even before she was chosen to host the broadcast (her second time being the M.C.), Ellen DeGeneres’s daytime program was a popular pit stop for celebrities, but lately it’s served as a synergistic must-stop.

headline: Times Minute | Clinton’s 2016 Numbers
text: Former first lady Hillary Clinton is the popular choice among Democrats in a New York Times/CBS News poll. Also on the Minute, the future for troops in Afghanistan and the growing trend of "phablets."

headline: Times Minute | Clinton’s 2016 Numbers
text: In the Video

headline: Artists on Artists | Shirin Neshat on Kaveh Golestan’s Humanistic Portraiture
text: Since the late ’90s, Shirin Neshat has been lauded for photographs, films and videos that explore the lives of Iranian women. Her first video, “Turbulent” (1998), featured a face-off between a male and a female singer in Islamic Iran, while “Women Without Men,” her 2009 feature film, focuses on the problems experienced by four women during the 1953 coup that brought the last shah to power. More recently, her work has addressed other countries in the Arab Spring, as in “Our House Is on Fire” (at Chelsea’s Rauschenberg Project Space, closing March 1), a group of poignant portraits of ordinary men and women in Cairo, survivors of the Egyptian revolution. “I wanted to humanize the people we think of as the other,” Neshat says.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Paris

headline: 36 Hours in Kyoto, Japan
text: A full 36 hours, 36 days, or even 36 weeks could be spent exploring the thousands of Buddhist temples, Shinto shrines, Zen gardens, palaces, pagodas, parks and walking paths in Kyoto, the former imperial capital of Japan. So it’s little surprise that the most common complaint about the enchanting city is that there are too many tourists, especially during the spring cherry-blossom season. To avoid crowds, consider seeking out local haunts in far-flung neighborhoods, all within reach thanks to an extensive public transport system. You’ll quickly discover that many of Kyoto’s most rewarding attractions can’t be found in any guidebook. At least not yet.

headline: For Merle Haggard, a Boxcar Was Home. Now It Needs Work.
text: OILDALE, Calif. — The tanker trains loaded with crude oil still rattle down the tracks at the end of the alleyway where Merle Haggard, a living legend of country music, grew up in a boxcar that his father transformed into the family home.

headline: Q & A: Making Scones and Biscuits
text: Heather Bertinetti, the pastry chef at the Four Seasons restaurant, and Julia Moskin discussed baking tender biscuits and scones with you, our readers. (The master recipe for both is here.) Their replies to questions and comments from readers are below.

headline: Potential Conflicts Cited For Mortgage Servicer
text: New York State’s top banking regulator said he had new concerns about Ocwen Financial, one of the nation’s largest mortgage servicing companies, creating another regulatory headache for the company.

headline: Image of the Day: February 26
text: Somdev Devvarman, an Indian tennis player, in action at the ATP Dubai Tennis Championships in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

headline: Barnes & Noble Nook Unit Continues to Sputter
text: Barnes & Noble said on Wednesday that it would release a new color tablet later this year, even as losses in its sputtering Nook division continued to weigh down the bookseller in its most recent quarter.

headline: Governor Brewer Promises to ‘Do the Right Thing’ for Arizona
text: Updated, 7:58 p.m. Under pressure from fellow Republicans, civic leaders and business groups, Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona announced Wednesday night that she had vetoed a bill that would have given business owners the right to invoke religion to refuse service to gays and others, as my colleague, Fernanda Santos reported.

headline: The Politics of Large Fowl
text: Gail Collins: David, here in New York we’ve been having a crisis over swans. Can we talk about that today? I don’t think we’ve ever discussed large fowl before.

headline: ‘Journalism Oracle’? What Was I Thinking?
text: I realize now that I may have overpromised. When asked recently to suggest a topic for a speech I will give on Friday to several hundred college journalists at their annual convention, I went with something snappy sounding. My talk is called “Journalism 2020: A Forecast and Guide to the Years Ahead for Young Journalists.”

headline: The Messaging App Wars Are Just Getting Started
text: There are 24 different ways for me to message someone from my phone right now. All for no additional charge beyond my existing cellphone bill.

headline: Clear Channel to Debut ‘iHeartRadio Music Awards’
text: If a hit song fails to win a Grammy, it could always win an American Music Award. Or an MTV Video Music Award. Or a People’s Choice Award. Or a Billboard Music Award. And if it’s a country track, there’s always the Country Music Association Awards and the Academy of Country Music Awards.

headline: How a Nurse Created a Silicon Valley Incubator
text: Jonathan Nelson likens the Silicon Valley organization he started, Hackers and Founders, to something he remembers from childhood, when his family moved to the small town of Anoka, Minn., from Central America. (His parents worked for a nongovernmental organization.) The Nelsons received a welcome basket with information about the community, including where the local supermarket, hardware store, post office and auto mechanic were located.

headline: French Street Artist Taking His Work Onstage at City Ballet
text: JR, the French street artist who specializes in large-scale international projects, is taking his collaboration with New York City Ballet off of the floor and onto the stage.

headline: Do You Know Your Calling?
text: As I am about to enter my fourth year writing about my soccer journey from the United States to Russia to Sweden and back home, I am often struck by the feedback I’ve received. Readers have related how some of what I have written affects them, and their comments have also given me new topics to ponder. They have all led me to consider why I do what I do.

headline: Why Don’t All New Cars Have Rearview Cameras?
text: The Times’s Matthew L. Wald reported recently on the Transportation Department’s enthusiastic embrace of a plan to require all new cars to broadcast their location, speed, direction and other data, and to receive similar data from other cars, so as to warn drivers of impending collisions.

headline: T-Mobile Turns an Industry on Its Ear
text: A rash of consumer-friendliness has broken out across the mobile data industry. Over the last year, the four major carriers — AT&T, Verizon, Sprint and T-Mobile — have cut prices and offered greater flexibility in how they sell their voice, text and broadband services. The industry could be on the verge of an all-out price war.

headline: Bringing the Happy
text: It can probably all be explained by the hat, the indelible success of Pharrell Williams.

headline: In a Retirement, a Loss for Barclays
text: Hans-Joerg Rudloff’s retirement at age 73 comes at an unhelpful time for Barclays.

headline: For ‘Fifty Shades of Grey,’ More Than 100 Million Sold
text: The “Fifty Shades of Grey” erotica series by E L James has sold more than 100 million copies worldwide, its American publisher, Vintage Books, said on Wednesday, a milestone for a trilogy that began as fan fiction and emerged as one of the biggest-selling series in publishing history.

headline: The Lesson of ‘Apocalypse Now’
text: By now you may have gathered that whenever you hear a sound in a movie, it’s not exactly what it seems.

headline: Need to Fund School Programs? Just Sell Your Kids’ Clothes
text: How’s this for a school funding plan?

headline: Easy on All 12 of Our Legs
text: Back when Hugh Kepets left his elevator studio on Gramercy Park for a one-bedroom nearby, he didn’t think twice about moving to a fourth-floor walk-up. “I was a relatively young man at the time and didn’t see the stairs as a problem,” he said.

headline: Water: Teaching About the World’s Most Valuable Substance
text: We travel on it, feed it to our crops, swim in it, pollute it and, yes, drink it. In some parts of the world, countries even fight over it. Water is everywhere, and yet in many places there’s not nearly enough of it to go around.

headline: Possible Troop Withdrawal in Afghanistan
text: The White House press secretary, Jay Carney, said that with the unlikelihood of the signing of a pact known as the B.S.A, the United States would prepare to reduce its force in Afghanistan.

headline: Foreign Exchange Firm Fined in Britain
text: Britain’s Financial Conduct Authority on Wednesday fined the British units of FXCM, a retail foreign exchange trading firm, 4 million pounds forwithholding profits from its clients.

headline: With Games Gone, Will Travelers Still Go to Sochi?
text: On a recent evening in Krasnaya Polyana, Russia, Pat O’Meara sat with his wife and two daughters and watched the American Kaitlyn Farrington snag a gold medal in the women’s halfpipe snowboard event.

text: Molly Wood says bigger may be better when it comes to smartphones.

headline: European Parliament Approves Tough Rules on Electronic Cigarettes
text: PARIS — The European Parliament on Wednesday approved rules for the region’s fast-growing market for electronic cigarettes, regulations that could help set a benchmark for standards around the world.

headline: Former Time Executive to Open Chelsea Art Gallery
text: The contemporary art world is jam-packed these days with collectors from the halls of corporate America, but few of them take their love of art so far as to open a gallery.

headline: New Bill Proposes Auction Royalties for Artists
text: When a collector makes a hefty profit in reselling a contemporary painting or sculpture, the artist rarely benefits. Hoping to change that, three lawmakers introduced legislation on Wednesday that would allow artists to share in those proceeds. The bill proposes that artists receive 5 percent of the price of art that is resold at public auction for more than $5,000. Named the American Royalties Too act (so as to have the catchy abbreviation A.R.T.), the bill is a revised version of legislation that Representative Jerrold Nadler of New York, the ranking Democrat on the Courts, Intellectual Property, and Internet subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee, introduced in 2011.

headline: Rival Protesters Brawl in Crimea
text: Clashes erupt between pro-Russian and pro-Ukrainian demonstrators in Simferopol.

headline: The Picky Eater Plan: 12 Ideas to Take Back the Dinner Table
Mets’ Jon Niese to Have M.R.I. Exam on Throwing Shoulder
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Spring training is where optimism often reigns, while the cold reality of the regular season is still off in the distance somewhere.

headline: Indian Naval Chief Resigns After Submarine Accident
text: NEW DELHI — India’s naval chief resigned on Wednesday after a Russian-made Indian submarine caught fire off the coast of Mumbai, injuring seven officers and leaving two missing. It was the 10th accident involving an Indian warship in seven months.

headline: A Shortage of Caregivers
text: If you want fresh evidence of the caregiving crisis that lies in the not-too-distant future, look no further than the employment projections released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics late last year.

headline: Christie Starts Push to Rein In State’s Labor Costs
text: STIRLING, N.J. — Gov. Chris Christie said on Wednesday that he felt insulated from the burdens of re-election and undistracted by scandal as he embarked on a potentially polarizing public campaign to cut the costs of New Jersey’s public employee benefits.

headline: What You Get for... $1,500,000
text: WOODSTOCK, N.Y.

headline: Some New Art From ‘Calvin and Hobbes’ Creator
text: In putting together “Stripped,” a documentary exploring the art and evolution of newspaper comic strips, Dave Kellett and Fred Schroeder, the co-directors, interviewed more than 70 cartoonists. One of the biggest gets was Bill Watterson, the reclusive creator of “Calvin and Hobbes,” the beloved newspaper strip about a mischievous boy and his stuffed tiger, which ran from 1985 to 1995.

headline: Feeling Blue, but Not Sad in the Navigli District
text: The Navigli district in Milan is known for its graffiti-lined canals, bars and clothing shops. In recent years, the neighborhood has also emerged as a hub for artists, designers and partygoers. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Two Brothers Sentenced in ‘Transformers’ Hong Kong Attack
text: Two brothers who were arrested after a melee on the set of “Transformers 4,” in Hong Kong in October have been sentenced to jail terms, Reuters reported.

headline: David Guttenfelder on the Second Camera
text: David Guttenfelder, chief Asia photographer for The Associated Press, has received enormous attention this year for his extraordinary work on Instagram, primarily because of his shots of every day life in North Korea. Still-life pictures of playing cards and computer work stations, or a brief video of two giggling ice-cream vendors, give Guttenfelder’s followers a rare look inside the Hermit Kingdom.

headline: Rival Protesters Clash in Crimea
text: Scuffles erupted outside the regional Parliament in Crimea as thousands of pro-Russia demonstrators confronted Muslim Crimean Tatars backing the new Ukrainian leadership.

headline: Classical Playlist: Luiza Borac, Alisa Weilerstein, Cédric Tiberghien and More
text: ARTHUR BERGER: ‘Words for Music, Perhaps,’ and Other WorksBoston Modern Orchestra Project, Gil Rose, conductor(BMOP/sound)The American composer Arthur Berger, who died at 91 in 2003, first emerged in the 1940s writing vibrant, pointed Neo-Classical works. Over time he embraced 12-tone techniques, but, in his own distinctive way, retained crystalline Neo-Classical clarity and directness. A recent recording from the conductor Gil Rose and the Boston Modern Orchestra Project presents a diversity of Berger works ranging from “Words for Music, Perhaps” (songs on Yeats poems originally composed in 1940) to the intricately engrossing Diptych: Collage I and Collage II from the 1990s. Mr. Rose has long been a Berger champion. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: ‘Frozen’ Soundtrack Is Back to No. 1
text: Disney’s animated film “Frozen” has been a monster hit at theaters, and its soundtrack has proved a big success, too. Released three months ago, the album returns this week to the top of Billboard’s chart for a fifth time at No. 1 — the most weeks at No. 1 for a soundtrack since “Titanic” was at the top for 16 straight weeks in 1998.

text: Paris

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Damir Doma Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Eyebeam Chooses an Architect for New Brooklyn Home
text: The art and technology center Eyebeam has selected WORK Architecture Company (WORKac) to design its future home in Brooklyn, another addition to the Brooklyn cultural district in Fort Greene.

headline: Federal Judge Strikes Down Texas’ Ban on Same-Sex Marriage
text: HOUSTON — A federal judge in Texas struck down the state’s ban on same-sex marriage on Wednesday, ruling that the laws restricting marriage to a man and a woman violated the United States Constitution and handing gay-rights advocates a major legal victory in one of the nation’s biggest and most conservative states.

headline: New Jersey Criminals, This Time Without the Smirk
text: “The Red Road” is not the television show northern New Jersey needs. It’s bad enough that the six-episode series, beginning Thursday night on SundanceTV, is about violent crime, police corruption, racial tension and mental illness. But what’s worse is that it validates the thinking of anyone who pictures the Garden State as drab and monotonous. At least the Sopranos knew how to have fun.

headline: Conjuring Big-Screen Romance
text: Imagine Alice in Wonderland as a beautiful dreamer besotted with old movies and vintage love songs. That enchanting, slightly unstable creature materialized at Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening in the person of Maude Maggart, a child of show business, whose new show, “The Door Opened,” sprinkled fairy dust into the room. If you inhale too much of it, God help you. But in small amounts, it is an extremely seductive perfume.

headline: Lego Pieces Together a New Act
text: While the thought of 3 million Legos may have parents instinctively rubbing the soles of their feet, executives at the Legoland park in Carlsbad, Calif., are smiling.

headline: From Kepler Data, Astronomers Find Galaxy Filled With More but Smaller Worlds
text: Nearly a year after a pointing system failure ended the main planet-hunting mission of NASA’s Kepler spacecraft, planets continue to pour out of the sky.

headline: The Payments Challenge for Mobile Carriers
text: BARCELONA, Spain – Every cellphone operator is looking for ways to persuade customers to use their smartphones to buy goods online.

headline: After 4-Year Overhaul, Library Is to Reopen in Washington Heights
text: Snowstorm after snowstorm, imbroglio upon imbroglio, Bill de Blasio has had a tough few weeks. However, even an embryonic mayoralty comes with a few ego-salving perquisites, like dedicatory plaques with your name on them.

headline: At Washington Theater, Imagining Scalia
text: Justice Antonin Scalia, meet Justice Antonin Scalia.

headline: A Hedge Fund Manager Says SAC Taint Is Manageable
text: Dmitry Balyasny is one hedge fund owner who isn’t afraid of hiring traders from SAC Capital Advisors as long as they were far away from the “messiness” that engulfed the firm during the federal government’s crackdown on insider trading.

headline: The Madness of War Told in the First Person
text: “You can’t describe it to someone who wasn’t there,” says a Marine who’s served in Iraq, “you can hardly remember how it was yourself because it makes so little sense. And to act like somebody could live and fight for months” there “and not go insane, well, that’s what’s really crazy.”

headline: A Pregnant Worker, Forced to Go on Unpaid Leave, Is Back on the Job
text: As readers of “The Working Life” column know, Floralba Fernandez Espinal was forced out of her job at a thrift store in the Bronx last month because she was pregnant and could no longer do heavy lifting.

headline: Mental Illness Risk Higher for Children of Older Fathers, Study Finds
text: Children born to middle-aged men are more likely than their older siblings to develop any of a range of mental difficulties, including bipolar disorder, autism and schizophrenia, according to the most comprehensive study to date of paternal age and offspring mental health.

headline: The Moment | Endless Sunday
text: A relaxed hippie vibe runs through men’s wear this spring with casual cuts and let-loose prints — a welcome break from the buttoned-up look of workaday clothes.

headline: Brain Trauma Extends to the Soccer Field
text: Chronic traumatic encephalopathy, the degenerative brain disease linked to repeated blows to the head, has been found posthumously in a 29-year-old former soccer player, the strongest indication yet that the condition is not limited to athletes who played sports known for violent collisions, like football and boxing.

headline: Syria Ships Mustard Gas to Port to Be Destroyed
text: GENEVA — After weeks of deepening foreign frustration over missed deadlines and other delays in Syria’s elimination of its chemical weapons, the international mission policing the process reported on Wednesday that Syria had delivered a significant consignment of mustard gas, one of the deadliest toxic agents, to the Syrian port of Latakia to be exported and destroyed.

headline: House Proposal Would Raise Taxes on Private Equity Income
text: The investment profits generated by private equity, long a subject of debate in Washington, would be taxed at a higher rate under a proposal on Wednesday by the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: This month, six novels explore brutality and loss, whether in wartime, friendship, family or matters of the heart.

headline: Cooking Techniques: Mincing Sage
text: Mince sage and other leafy herbs to release their oils.

text: Paris

headline: The Gun Report: February 26, 2014
text: We have written before about gun sales transpiring on Instagram and Reddit, mostly without background checks. Now we can add Facebook, where photos of breastfeeding mothers are censored, but gun sales continue unabated.

headline: Techniques: Filleting a Fish
text: Cut a whole fish into two fillets.

headline: Gay Marriage: Soon Available in Texas
text: Marriage-equality ventured into Texas on Wednesday as U.S. District Judge Orlando Garcia issued a preliminary injunction against the state’s amendment banning same-sex unions.

headline: A General Theory of Obamacare Fiction
text: Conservatives appear to be really upset that liberals are actually taking on the facts in the anti-Obamacare ads they’ve been running. How dare you question whether the people in these ads are giving an accurate picture — they’re suffering!

headline: Supreme Court Permits Investor Lawsuits in Stanford Fraud
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday allowed investors to pursue class-action suits against law firms, insurance brokers and financial services companies that the investors said bore partial responsibility for one of the most brazen frauds in recent history, the $7 billion Ponzi scheme orchestrated by R. Allen Stanford.

headline: Library Renovation Plan Awaits Word From de Blasio
text: As a candidate last summer, Bill de Blasio told Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that New York City should stop financing the ambitious renovation of the Fifth Avenue flagship of the New York Public Library until someone figured out how much it was all going to cost.

headline: Cooking Techniques: Cutting Up a Chicken
text: Cut a whole chicken into eight pieces: two breasts, two legs, two thighs and two wings.

headline: Marvel TV Series to Film in New York
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo helps announce the scheduled filming of a TV series based on Marvel characters in New York.

headline: Justices Rule Against Man Over a Zone for Protests
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday unanimously ruled against an antiwar protester who was convicted of breaking federal law by entering an area set aside for protests near the main entrance to Vandenberg Air Force Base, from which he had been barred.

headline: Pace Picks Yassky, Ex-Taxi Chief, as Its Law School Dean
text: Law school deans are rarely familiar faces, but Pace University is getting one who should be recognizable to anyone who slid into a New York City taxi cab in the past few years.

headline: Pivotal Point Is Seen as More States Consider Legalizing Marijuana
text: A little over a year after Colorado and Washington legalized marijuana, more than half the states, including some in the conservative South, are considering decriminalizing the drug or legalizing it for medical or recreational use. That has set up a watershed year in the battle over whether marijuana should be as available as alcohol.

headline: A Republican’s Tax Overhaul Envisions Big Changes
text: WASHINGTON — Big banks would face a new tax on lending. Taxes paid to state and local governments would no longer be deductible. The earned income credit for low-wage workers would be converted to a more limited deduction on payroll taxes. The mortgage deduction and retirement savings breaks would be curtailed.

headline: Kerry Sees Syrian Retaliation Against Rivals in Talks
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department accused the Syrian government on Wednesday of retaliating against the Syrian opposition’s representatives to the Geneva peace talks by arresting their family members.

headline: Assault Charge for a Top New York City Council Official
text: A high-ranking New York City Council official was arrested at his apartment on the Upper West Side and charged with domestic assault, a police spokesman said on Wednesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, China, Bahrain and India.

headline: Cooking Techniques: Cleaning Mushrooms
text: Clean mushrooms before cooking to remove any traces of dirt.

headline: Blackstone Said to Be Near a Deal to Invest in Versace
text: Versace is in advanced discussions to take on the Blackstone Group as a minority investor, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, in the latest sign that the finance industry’s interest in high fashion shows few signs of abating.

headline: England, Conflicted on Its Place in Europe, Looks to Germany
text: LONDON — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany will address members of both Houses of Parliament, have lunch with Prime Minister David Cameron at 10 Downing Street and then meet Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace for afternoon tea.

headline: Josephine Le Tutour Transforms Backstage at Rochas
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Josephine Le Tutour (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Luigi Murenu.

headline: Test Is Improved Predictor of Fetal Disorders
text: A test that analyzes fetal DNA found in a pregnant woman’s blood proved much more accurate in screening for Down syndrome and another chromosomal disorder than the now-standard blood test, a new study has found. The promising results may change how prenatal screening for genetic diseases is done, though the test is costly and generally not yet covered by insurance for women at low risk.

headline: Performing Beethoven as a Birthright
text: With the technical level of orchestras rising overall in recent decades, we are almost accustomed to hearing precise, incisive performances of Beethoven’s formidable Ninth Symphony. Yet, on Tuesday night, for the first concert of Carnegie Hall’s ambitious three-week festival Vienna: City of Dreams, the conductor Franz Welser-Möst led the illustrious Vienna Philharmonic in an account of Beethoven’s Ninth that had curious moments of shaky playing.

headline: In Ukraine, Naming of Interim Government Gets Mixed Response
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Standing before a crowd of tens of thousands in Independence Square, the center of the three-month civic uprising that ousted President Viktor F. Yanukovych, the lawmakers temporarily controlling Ukraine announced an interim government on Wednesday night to be led by Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, a veteran public official.

headline: England vs. Russia-Netherlands at NEC Bridge Festival
text: The 19th NEC Bridge Festival was held in Yokohama City, Japan, from Feb. 11 to 16. Perhaps for the first time, there were no players from the United States or Canada. The only North American presence was provided by the Daily Bulletin editors, Rich Colker of Wheaton, Md., and Barry Rigal of New York City.

headline: Three Types of Passion Made Flesh
text: LYON, France — The choreographer Rachid Ouramdane isn’t exactly an obvious candidate for a ballet company commission. Working in a contemporary idiom, he has created a number of impressive pieces that reflect on torture, post-traumatic stress, war and occupation, possibly drawing on his French-Algerian background.

headline: An Orchestra Plays Backup Band as a Countertenor Takes Center Stage
text: When the Venice Baroque Orchestra visited Zankel Hall a year ago, it showed off the virtuosity of its individual members and of the group as a whole. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday evening, it served mainly as a backup band — an excellent one, to be sure — for the brilliant French countertenor Philippe Jaroussky.

headline: A Top Financial Prosecutor to Leave
text: The exodus of corporate prosecutors continues.

headline: Ben Affleck Urges Action in the Congo
text: The actor was in Washington D.C. on Wednesday to discuss the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

headline: The Promise and Pitfalls in a Tax Reform Plan
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Bold Lines at Dries Van Noten
text: At Dries Van Noten, the only beauty detail as bold as the graphic designs on the fall/winter 2014 collection was the black stripe the makeup artist Peter Philips painted above the models’ upper lashes. He described the arch as having a certain fluidity, exuding “the feeling of being done in one motion.” Philips used a pigment-heavy M.A.C. Chromacake body paint, which he thinned out with a little water-based mixing medium and applied using a flat Giorgio Armani eye shader brush. The rest of the face was kept bare and muted to keep the focus on the colorful, eye-catching looks.

headline: Ben Affleck Urges Action in Congo
text: The actor discussed the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo at the State Department with Secretary of State John Kerry and former Senator Russ Feingold, the special envoy for the region.

headline: OSHA’s Investigative Report on Daniel Curry’s Accident in ‘Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark’
text: A report by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration on Daniel Curry’s accident on Aug. 15, 2013, during a performance of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.”

headline: Eat Your Spinach and Win the Game, Too
text: Anyone who has ever made a video game with an agenda beyond entertainment has faced the same challenge: How do you hide that agenda to avoid turning off players? Trip Hawkins, the founder of Electronic Arts and other game companies, describes this as making sure “kids are having fun and not smelling the spinach.”

headline: Injured ‘Spider-Man’ Dancer Discusses His Lawsuit
text: It was a stunt that Daniel Curry had performed many times before in the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark”: Plant himself firmly on a hydraulic lift in the pit beneath the stage, then remain steady as he rose a dozen feet to emerge for the start of Act II.

headline: Huawei and ZTE Look to Sell More Smartphones Abroad
text: Huawei and ZTE have a lot in common. They both primarily sell networking equipment, and they both want to be a more powerful force in consumer products like smartphones.

headline: Older Fathers: Assessing the Risks
text: The question of whether a father’s age at a child’s conception puts that child at an increased risk of developing various disorders has intrigued scientists for some time. In the most comprehensive study to date of paternal age and offspring mental health (published in the journal JAMA Psychiatry and reported in The New York Times by Benedict Carey), researchers found that “children born to middle-aged men are more likely than those born to younger fathers to develop any of a range of mental difficulties, including attention deficits, bipolar disorder, autism and schizophrenia.”

headline: Don’t Ask for the Moon, Name-Drop the Stars
text: Say “Now, Voyager” to a binge watcher of Turner Classic Movies or a gay man of a certain age, and you’ll get a knowing smile, a strong opinion and a quotation. (“Don’t let’s ask for the moon. We have the stars.”) Talk to someone not versed in the Bette Davis canon, and you might get a blank stare and something about “Star Trek.”

headline: In Athens, the Last Man Painting
text: ATHENS — Leonardo DiCaprio’s face glowed triumphantly from a large billboard here atop the Athinaion, an old movie theater where “The Wolf of Wall Street” was recently playing. Mr. DiCaprio had just been nominated for an Oscar, and Vasilis Dimitriou had painted him larger than life, with a gleaming gold statuette against a sea of red and black brush strokes.

headline: A Rogue Shoe and Its New Cousins
text: “I feel it.”

headline: Times Minute | News for Likely Parents
text: Two studies provide some good and some bad news for prospective parents. Also on the Minute, clashes in a new area of Ukraine and Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York announces a Marvel deal.

headline: Talent | At Age 70, a Star Is Born
text: More than four decades after releasing her little-heard debut album, the folk singer and lifelong dental hygienist Linda Perhacs takes another shot at greatness.

headline: Times Minute | News for Likely Parents
text: In the Video

headline: Obama Outlines Infrastructure Plans
text: In Minnesota, the president said he planned to fix the nation’s crumbling roads, rails and bridges.

headline: A Voice of Her Own
text: AGE 27.

headline: As Ukraine Crisis Rumbles, Georgian Premier Visits U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Irakli Garibashvili of Georgia met with Secretary of State John Kerry on Wednesday to discuss ways to develop his nation’s economy and reinforce its pro-Western path. But the tumultuous events in Ukraine, and Moscow’s decision to send a message by conducting a surprise military exercise in western Russia, have cast a shadow on the Georgian leader’s visit here.

headline: Flight Suits in Italian Wool
text: Weary business travelers, increasingly inured to the indignities of air travel, take note: J. Crew understands your plight. It has modified its best-selling Ludlow suit with a specially woven three-ply Italian wool to resist rumpling, wrinkling and unsightly creasing. On sale Wednesday, and available in navy, pale gray and charcoal, the suits almost guarantee an upgrade upon arrival.

headline: Kelly Osbourne, From Party Girl to Fashion Sage
text: Kelly Osbourne is certainly no stranger to fame. In fact, it runs in the family.

headline: Police Officer Is Shot in Legs in Brooklyn
text: A first-year New York City police officer was shot in the legs on Wednesday evening in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, by a man he and his partner had just pulled off a bus for failing to pay the fare, the police said.

headline: Four Marvel TV Shows to Film in New York
text: Across the metropolis, weary residents mutter about a tale of two cities, wondering who will bring back the jobs.

headline: No Conflict of Interest Found in Favorable Review of Keystone Pipeline
text: WASHINGTON — A State Department contractor who prepared an environmental analysis of the Keystone XL pipeline did not violate conflict-of-interest rules, even though the contractor had previously done work for TransCanada, the company seeking to build the pipeline, a State Department inspector general’s investigation concluded on Wednesday.

headline: On Safari in Widowhood
text: In Carole Radziwill’s new novel, “The Widow’s Guide to Sex and Dating,” the main character, a woman whose husband died five months earlier, is taken by a friend to the Grill Room at the Four Seasons, a place described as a Serengeti for billionaires.

headline: Disclosing the Fees on Prepaid Debit Cards
text: If you’ve ever shopped for a prepaid debit card, you may have found it difficult to determine just what fees the cards charge and what terms they offer, because the cards vary in the type of information, if any, they disclose.

headline: One Unhappy Guy
text: In a 5,000-word cover article in New York magazine this week, Alec Baldwin took aim at Shia LaBeouf (“a jailhouse mentality”), his former MSNBC colleagues Joe Scarborough (“neither eloquent or funny”) and Rachel Maddow (“a phony who doesn’t have the same passion for truth off-camera that she does on air”) and Anderson Cooper of CNN (“the self-appointed Jack Valenti of gay media culture”). Mr. Baldwin’s admission that “I find myself bitter, defensive, and more misanthropic than I care to admit” didn’t find much disagreement on Twitter.

headline: After a Fire Sale, Time to Reminisce
text: On Wednesday night, the last of 39 Loehmann’s stores closed for business, including four in New York City, where the company got its start in the 1920s. On the heels of Daffy’s and Filene’s Basement, such a demise may indicate a declining middle class, or a retail landscape transformed by the Internet and Goliath-like chains, or some combination. What’s certain is that it is leaving a lot of nostalgic shoppers.

headline: Complete Results: New York Times/CBS News February Poll
text: The nationwide poll was conducted Feb. 19 to 23 by landline and cellphone among 1,644 adults.

headline: G.O.P., Though Deeply Split, Has Election Edge, Poll Shows
text: Republicans are in a stronger position than Democrats for this year’s midterm elections, benefiting from the support of self-described independents, even though the party itself is deeply divided and most Americans agree more with Democratic policy positions, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows.

headline: Views on Voting and the Political Parties
text: How do the Republicans and the Democrats differ? How are they similar? The New York Times and CBS News asked Americans for their views on various issues, their attitudes toward the parties and their opinion of a number of possible presidential candidates.

headline: Beauty News
text: The trend of ordering services on the go through apps like Uber and Seamless has now extended to booking beauty technicians who will visit the location of your choice. These examples are free to download, and the cost of services includes tax and tip.

headline: Power Tools for a Red Carpet Look
text: As Oscar gowns have become more formal, so too has the hair that accompanies them. Gone are the days when actresses would walk the red carpet with their locks tucked under a crocheted cap (Ali MacGraw, 1971), raked into an outlandish Bob Mackie headdress (Cher, 1986) or casually combed (Michelle Pfeiffer, 1990). On Sunday, viewers will see a parade of stylized looks, like Reese Witherspoon’s Veronica Lake waves at the ceremony last year and Emma Watson’s stern bun at the most recent Golden Globes.

headline: Boldface Gems
text: With eight days remaining until Oscar night on Sunday, Pamela Love wasn’t taking any chances. An arrowhead pendant of her design swung like an amulet from her throat; snakes and pentagrams gleamed on her fingers, and a sprinkling of tattoos marked her wrists.

headline: Connected to the Oven via an App
text: In the push to automate home appliances, the oven remains a tough sell. Who hasn’t panicked that they stepped out of the house and accidentally left the oven on? To do so intentionally seems to invite a leap of faith.

headline: Covering All Corners of the Earth
text: Weaving together geology, anthropology and Google Earth imagery, the Dutch designer Roosmarijn Pallandt has developed a series of carpets called Consider This Landscape a Territory. She begins with a bird’s-eye photograph of a rug-making region like northern Portugal, Nepal or Japan, then spends months researching each culture and its traditional rug-making techniques. Finally, she converts the original aerial image into a carpet produced by local artisans from natural materials. For the Flora rug, for example, which will be exhibited at the International Furniture Fair in Milan in April, a half-dozen women in Portugal hand-knotted felted wool yarn, jute and eucalyptus. The Ice carpet was knotted by a Tibetan family using wool from sheep, yak and goats combined with silk. The rugs can be ordered through Ms. Pallandt’s studio, in collaboration with Casalis, a Belgian carpet company. Prices start at about $1,168 per square meter. Information: roosmarijnpallandt.com.

headline: Dick Button Still Cuts a Fine Figure
text: When Dick Button, the figure skating analyst and a two-time Olympic gold medalist, faces a question he doesn’t care to answer, he either pretends he can’t hear it (a legitimate alibi for someone deaf in one ear) or acts as if he’s on a bad cellphone connection. “Hello, hello, HELLO!” he says in his deep broadcaster’s voice.

headline: Matters of Taste
text: Growing up in the African country of Togo, Mansour Ourasanah knew what it was like to be hungry. But he assumed that limited food was a universal misfortune, like a head cold or a broken heart. Eventually he discovered that plenty of food was available for people with money; it was just that his family was poor.

headline: Bamboo Takes a Bow
text: While bamboo is gaining popularity as a sustainable material, it still doesn’t have the status of hardwoods like walnut or oak. But Elora Hardy can envision a day when it will.

headline: An Auction to Feed Others
text: A dining room that can support 4,500 meals a month? That’s what one New York City nonprofit is hoping for when it auctions a roomful of designer furnishings this week to benefit orphans in Nepal.

headline: Is It O.K. to Allow Pets and Their Stuff to Be Seen During Showings?
text: Q. Is it O.K. to leave pets and all their stuff out in my apartment during showings?

headline: Sales at KleinReid, Grace & Favor and Others
text: Some items are on sale at the Shop at the Cooper-Hewitt, while supplies last (the Camel vase by Anton Ginzburg, usually $240, is $168; Credit Card Cutlery by Ineke Hans, usually $10, is $7; London earbuds by Urbanista, usually $69, are $49); 212-849-8355, shop.cooperhewitt.org.

headline: Michael Gross: Goodbye to All This
text: Late in 2004, architectural pickers were working their way through the old Mayflower Hotel on Central Park West between 61st and 62nd Streets, harvesting pedestal sinks, bronze mail-chute boxes and cut-glass chandeliers.

headline: Efforts to Curb Solitary Confinement
Earth, Wind and Fire
text: Evan Fry is known for the quirky, irreverent commercials he creates for companies like Volkswagen, Harley-Davidson and Burger King in his role as an advertising executive. One of the wackiest, directed by Spike Jonze, involved the gleeful annihilation of a Gap store by its employees — Mr. Fry’s answer to the question of how an established brand should announce its reinvention.

headline: Citing Long-Delayed G.M. Recall, Senator Calls for Change in Safety Agency’s Process
text: The 10-year investigation and problematic recall of 1.4 million General Motors cars related to 13 deaths shows that the government’s early-warning reporting system isn’t working, Senator Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat, said on Wednesday in a letter to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Had the system worked better, it might have saved lives, Mr. Markey said in the letter to David Friedman, the acting administrator of the safety agency.

headline: Art Checks in at a London Hotel
text: Guests who check into Room 134 at the Ace Hotel London Shoreditch will find one wall covered with a color photograph by Richard Evans of autumnal countryside. In Room 113, Jonathan Barnbrook has created a large-scale piece inspired by neoclassical Victorian typography, above, while the walls of Suites 533 and 534 are hung with Justine Ashbee’s woven textiles in simple geometric patterns.

headline: The Arizona Test
text: To the Editor:

headline: Antigay Laws in Africa
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yes, Audiobooks Count
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Dries van Noten Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Together in Radioland
text: To the Editor:

headline: James Patterson’s Largess
text: To the Editor:

headline: Three’s a Trend | Warm and Comfortable Winter Wear
text: With cozy head-to-toe knits, designers are fast turning hibernation into a dressing category of its own. In their fall/winter 2014 collections, they’re layering oversize, monochromatic, luxurious separates — sweaters, pants, skirts and tunic dresses — that cradle the body in coziness. The first sighting of the look was in New York at The Row, where the designers Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen redefined our understanding of comfortable luxury with overwhelmingly voluminous knits including a cowl-necked, bell-sleeved sweater paired with a matching skirt. The trend continued at Marc Jacobs, whose neutral collection was filled with plush, nubby matching separates like a ribbed, V-neck long sweater with coordinating leggings and scarf. And at Edun, a sporty ivory tank dress paired with slouchy trousers and sneakers in the same color looked like the ultimate weekend wardrobe. The trend has continued to unfold in London, Milan and, now, Paris. Come fall, accepting unannounced guests at home will have never looked better.

headline: To Save on Defense, Hire Rivals
text: WASHINGTON — RECENT proposals to slash the troop levels of the regular Army illustrate how much pressure the United States government is under to shrink its military budget, even as it revamps and re-equips its forces for future conflicts. To meet all of those goals at the same time, we need to turn to one of the commercial world’s most basic cost-control weapons — competition.

headline: Hard Talk Aside, Little Desire by the West to Leave Afghanistan
text: BRUSSELS — Listening to the Western defense officials gathered at a NATO meeting here on Wednesday, it would be easy to think that the United States and the rest of the international military coalition in Afghanistan have shifted into a full-speed withdrawal from the country by year’s end.

headline: Handset Makers Go Big on Smartphones
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Smartphones are going against one of the long-held rules in portable electronics, that smaller is better.

headline: Events and Sales Starting the Week of Feb. 27
text: Openings

headline: Dodging Queries on Arrest, Felton Looks to Postseason
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Appearing without prepared notes, Raymond Felton took a seat Wednesday afternoon behind a thin yellow divider that, from a distance, could have been misconstrued as police tape. This was the setting for a 53-second statement in which Felton, the Knicks’ starting point guard, declined to address his arrest Tuesday on felony gun charges.

headline: Obama’s Pipeline
text: WASHINGTON — WHEN I was elected to Congress in 2002, George W. Bush was president and big business wrote environmental policy. We all remember Vice President Dick Cheney’s energy task force — a who’s who of mining and oil interests — and the administration’s constant questioning of climate science.

headline: Federal Court Orders YouTube to Take Down Controversial Anti-Islam Video
text: A federal appeals court ordered YouTube to take down a controversial anti-Islam video in an unusual copyright decision that Google, which owns YouTube, said raised questions about freedom of speech.

headline: Arizona Governor Vetoes Bill on Refusal of Service to Gays
text: PHOENIX — Ending a day that cast a glaring national spotlight on Arizona, Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, vetoed a bill on Wednesday that would have given business owners the right to refuse service to gay men, lesbians and other people on religious grounds.

headline: Senate Panel Says Credit Suisse Helped Hide U.S. Assets
text: Senators on both sides of the aisle criticized Credit Suisse at a hearing on Wednesday, saying it helped thousands of Americans hide billions of dollars in assets from United States tax authorities.

headline: Health Law’s Small Co-ops Have Had a Mixed Success So Far
text: The rented offices of HealthyCT, a new insurer in Connecticut, bustle with the energy of a start-up. The sales force takes pride in noting that HealthyCT is a truly local outfit, governed by members, rather than a for-profit behemoth like Anthem, the state’s dominant insurer whose offices are a 10-minute drive away.

headline: Cable Channel Taps Multicultural Roots
text: A FLEDGLING cable channel founded by a filmmaker known for action fare aimed at a multicultural audience is adding to its original programming — and its deals with advertisers — as the annual upfront bazaar for the sale of television commercial time gets underway.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Rochas Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Tesla Plans $5 Billion Battery Factory for Mass-Market Electric Car
text: Tesla Motors said on Wednesday that it planned to invest about $2 billion in a large-scale factory to produce cheaper batteries for a mass-market electric car within three years.

headline: Funds and New Timetable for Offshore Wind Farm in Massachusetts
text: BOSTON — Cape Wind, the much-delayed offshore wind farm project proposed for Nantucket Sound, said Wednesday that it had received a new loan commitment that would allow it to finish its financing this fall and begin producing power by 2016.

headline: U.S. and European Regulators Call Popular Diabetes Drugs Safe
text: A year after beginning investigations of the safety of some of the world’s most popular diabetes drugs, regulators in both the United States and Europe said their own research and reviews of study data indicated little cause for concern.

headline: Kerry Condemns Uganda’s Antigay Law
text: Secretary of State John Kerry on Wednesday condemned the antigay measure signed into law in Uganda this week, saying it is as serious a moral offense as anti-Semitism in 1930s Germany or apartheid in white-led South Africa. “You could be in 1930s Germany or you could be in 1950s, ’60s apartheid South Africa,” Mr. Kerry told reporters. “The signing of this antihomosexuality bill is flat-out morally wrong.” The Uganda law imposes harsh sentences for homosexual acts, including life imprisonment in some cases, according to government officials. Mr. Kerry said the legislation was “bigger than just Uganda” and added that there were 78 other countries in which “you have these laws that are just contrary to human rights and contrary to human nature.”

headline: ‘Tonight’ Starts Well, on YouTube and on TV
text: The traditional television ratings have been impressive for the first week-plus of the new “Tonight” show hosted by Jimmy Fallon, but they do not include what amounts to a giant secondary audience that has gathered online to watch carefully crafted and curated highlights of the show on YouTube and other sites.

headline: Shrugging Off Past Setbacks, Obama Plans Personal Role in Middle East Peace Bid
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, after avoiding a hands-on role in Middle East peacemaking since the setbacks of his first term, plans to plunge back into the effort, his advisers said this week, starting with an urgent appeal to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

headline: Silver Belles at Dries Van Noten
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.Though it was presented in a gilded, chandelier-lined room in the opulent Hôtel de Ville in Paris, Dries Van Noten’s fall/winter collection was anything but Old World in feel. Day-glo corsages were draped atop men’s wear coats, separates sported rave-like colors and drop-waist dresses cast an iridescent sheen. The shoes, like the clothes, were modern, wearable and a touch futuristic. This ankle boot combined solid and metallic-stamped felt with a mirrored-leather heel for a tone-on-tone texture play that elegantly balanced the old and the new.

headline: A Supreme Court Patent Case Comes Down to a War of Adjectives
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday heard arguments in two cases that some technology companies hope will address what they say are abusive and coercive lawsuits brought by “patent trolls,” or companies that buy patents not to use them but to collect royalties and damages.

headline: Keepsakes From Across the Border
text: It was the summer of 1980, and I was 7 years old, when I traveled to America for the first time. I came to Los Angeles with my mom. The trip, which included visits to Disneyland and Sea World and Knott’s Berry Farm, was the reward my parents gave me for finishing first grade with honors. The Mexican middle class has always been as pampering in its affections as aspirational in its customs, and my family was no exception.

headline: Prize Catch for Ukrainians at Boat Harbor: A Soggy Trove of Government Secrets
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The papers were first spotted swirling in the eddies of a boat harbor on the sprawling compound of the former Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, on the outskirts of Kiev. Intrigued, the protesters-turned-security guards who had taken over the grounds found a raft and began fishing the documents out of the water. Later, they recruited a diver to retrieve sunken nylon bags of files from the riverbed.

headline: Plan Offers No Picnic for Union Square Park
text: Oh thank God, finally we will have a place to catch a high-toned meal inside Union Square Park.

headline: Targeting the Johns in Sex Trade
text: CHICAGO — Several police officers are waiting in a hotel room, handcuffs at the ready, when they get the signal. A female undercover officer posing as a prostitute is with a would-be customer in an adjacent room, and she has pushed a secret button indicating that they should charge in to make the arrest.

headline: Rogen Tells Congress of Family’s Struggle With Alzheimer’s
text: Seth Rogen opened his testimony to a Senate panel on Wednesday with a quip.

headline: No Country for Old Mores
text: Arizona’s S.B. 1062, part of the conservative “Jim Queer” crusade to use religious liberty as means of codifying discrimination against people for their sexual identities, once again places conservatives on the wrong side of history and further marginalizes an intolerance-obsessed party during an inclusion-oriented era.

headline: Where Derek Jeter Is, Mark Teixeira Once Was
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Derek Jeter said he was not concerned about his surgically repaired left ankle on the eve of his scheduled Grapefruit League debut Thursday, 501 days after he shattered it.

headline: Fresh Produce Comes to the Bronx via a Veggie Mart on Wheels
text: The old school bus painted with big green and purple leaves pushed through the icy rain to ease alongside Southern Boulevard in the South Bronx. The door swung open with a squeak, revealing a cornucopia of organic eggs, potatoes, onions, garlic, cabbage, apples and turnips piled on the seats.

headline: A New York Observer Article Brings a Spat in Trump’s Orbit
text: Bill Gifford was managing an ice cream shop in Maplewood, N.J., last summer when a customer, Ken Kurson, the editor of The New York Observer, came in with an unorthodox request. He wanted Mr. Gifford, a 28-year-old political science major who was seeking a new job but had almost no journalistic experience, to write an article about the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman.

headline: The State of Arizona
text: Arizona. Wow. How often do you find yourself saying, “Go, entrenched interests of the business community!” Yet here we are.

headline: New York City Council Swiftly Passes Bill to Extend Paid Sick Days
text: The new, more emphatically liberal City Council was in full swing on Wednesday, expanding New York’s law on paid sick leave from the watered-down version passed last year and approving a resolution supporting Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to raise taxes on the wealthy to pay for expanded prekindergarten.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 26, 2014
Cooking Techniques: Frosting a Cake
text: Make sure every bite of cake includes an even amount of frosting.

headline: Fertilizer Limits Sought Near Lake Erie to Fight Spread of Algae
text: A United States-Canadian agency called on Wednesday for swift and sweeping limits on the use of fertilizer around Lake Erie to reduce the amount of phosphorus entering the water and creating a vast blanket of algae each summer, threatening fisheries, tourism and even drinking water.

headline: No Respite on the Court for the Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — As if Raymond Felton weren’t having enough trouble keeping opposing point guards out of the lane, his estranged wife went around him to deliver his gun, unregistered in New York, to the police. Already convicted in the court of public basketball opinion, he’s now been declared guilty by one city tabloid (“Raymond Felon”) of two criminal counts.

headline: Ukraine and the Perils of Division
text: In the violence and chaos of the past week, the question has been raised whether stability might be served by dividing Ukraine, Czechoslovakia-style, into a Ukrainian-speaking northwest and a Russian-speaking southeast?

headline: Rift at Jewish School in Manhattan Over Canceled Plan for Israeli-Palestinian Talk
text: During a presentation on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Peter Beinart, an author and columnist who writes frequently on the topic, suggested to a group of high school students that they invite a particular Columbia University professor to give his views.

headline: Tears and Tissues as Editor Testifies in Phone Hacking Case
text: LONDON — The tabloids Rebekah Brooks once edited might have paid six figures or more for details like those she has been divulging about her personal life during her trial on phone hacking charges: the celebrity husband, the adultery, the infertility, the daughter by a surrogate mother.

headline: From Alabama, Hockey’s Ultimate Travel Team
text: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — The team’s trip earlier this season seemed planned by a crazed travel agent who threw darts at a map. Outbound, fly commercially from Huntsville to Denver, east to Chicago, then to Anchorage. On the return, jet from Anchorage to Seattle, then a stop in Houston before the final trip home. Total miles logged: 8,282.

headline: Liar’s Jackpot
text: An unknown writer becomes famous on Twitter for compiling quotes he didn’t hear from Wall Street co-workers he doesn’t know, in a place he never worked — and wins a lucrative contract to tell all about it, in a real book.

headline: Better Lawyering for the Poor
text: New York State’s chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, is making some innovative changes to the education and training of lawyers as well as to the workings of the court system that bear close watching around the country.

headline: Spike Lee Exchange Highlights Gentrification Debate
text: All of David Crouch’s longtime neighbors on stately Adelphi Street in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, have the same story: the phone calls or the mailings or the knock on the door, week after week, with the same coaxing question and the same shimmering offer.

headline: A Simpler Tax Plan, Not a Better One
text: The Republican tax plan unveiled in the House on Wednesday ensures that there will be no tax reform in the near future. It refuses to ask for greater sacrifice from the rich to bring in desperately needed revenue for rebuilding the country and improving education, which Democrats correctly regard as a huge missed opportunity. Hard-line conservatives, on the other hand, insist that changing the tax code should include slashing revenue, which the proposal avoids.

headline: Peter Rona, 79, Dies; Explorer Found Hot Springs on Ocean Floor
text: Peter A. Rona, an oceanographer who dived into the depths of the world’s seas and surprised his peers by discovering vast mounds spewing hot smoke at the bottom of the icy Atlantic, exciting interests in deep-sea mining and the origins of life on earth, died on Feb. 20 in Plainsboro, N.J. He was 79.

headline: Arizona Governor Vetoes Bill
text: Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, vetoed a bill that would have given business owners the right to refuse service to gay men and lesbians on religious grounds.

headline: Warlords With Dark Pasts Battle in Afghan Election
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Ashraf Ghani, the apparent front-runner in the Afghan presidential race this year, was once unstinting in his opinion of one of the country’s most prominent warlords, Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, calling him a “known killer.”

headline: Chokwe Lumumba, 66, Dies; Activist Who Became Mayor in Mississippi
text: Chokwe Lumumba, a civil rights lawyer who once called for an independent black-majority country in the American Southeast before running for mayor of Jackson, Miss., last year, winning handily, died on Tuesday in Jackson. He was 66.

headline: Mind Cleared, McIlroy Now Is Seeking Staying Power
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Rory McIlroy arrived here a year ago ranked No. 1 in the world after an astonishing ascension that included two major tournament titles, bearing expectations that he would challenge and perhaps even dethrone Tiger Woods as golf’s dominant player.

headline: Neighbors Seek to Prevent Return of Chumley’s to Greenwich Village
text: Jim Miller had looked forward to 2014. He believed it was the year he would finally reopen Chumley’s, the well-known Greenwich Village bar that has been closed since a wall collapsed in 2007.

headline: Anything Goes
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE —#8212; Stanley Newman, the man behind today’s AMAZIN’ crossword, has created a theme set “in a neighborhood bar,” in which four answers together form a sentence you might hear at a local tavern. The sort of place where everybody knows your name — and everyone’s a gossip. Solve the puzzle and you’ll see what I mean.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 19 through Feb. 23 with 1,644 adults throughout the United States. Interviews were in English or Spanish.

headline: Verrazano Bridge Toll Cut Despite High-Level Protest
text: If the Metropolitan Transportation Authority thought it would rubber-stamp a proposed cut in toll rates for the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, Richard Ravitch had other ideas.

headline: Private-Jet Airline Bets on a Thrifty Streak in the Rich
text: PARIS — Alexandre Azoulay would like to tell you something about the rich today: They aren’t so different from you and me.

headline: Contracts for Milk in New York City Schools Are Flagged
text: They are guzzled by the half-pint in schools across New York City each day: cartons of milk labeled low-fat, skim and chocolate, the flashiest among them decorated with cartoons of skateboarding cows.

headline: Service Members Testify to Senate Panel on Sexual Violence
text: WASHINGTON — Former service members who were victims of sexual violence told a Senate panel on Wednesday that military commanders should not be involved in decisions about sexual assault cases. Their views reflected those of Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, who convened the panel to promote a bill she is pushing that she said would help solve the problem.

headline: Turkish Leader Disowns Trials That Helped Him Tame Military
text: ISTANBUL — A series of sensational trials that shook the Turkish military in recent years achieved what many regard as the most important legacy of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s more than a decade in power: sending the army back to its barracks and out of politics.

headline: Rangers Wary of Drop-Off After the Olympics
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Eight years ago, the Rangers went into the Olympic break 20 games above .500. But after goalie Henrik Lundqvist, then a rookie, led Sweden to the gold medal, the Rangers, who had eight other Olympians, struggled. Although they finished with 100 points, they were third in the Atlantic Division and were swept by the Devils in the first round of the playoffs.

headline: Gardner to Oppose Udall, Complicating Democrats’ Senate Hopes
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Cory Gardner, a rising star in the Republican Party, will run for Senate in Colorado, the latest complication to Democrats’ hopes to hold on to a number of Senate seats that had seemed relatively safe.

headline: For Once, Face of Devils Has Little Use for His Mask
text: NEWARK — The Devils have historically had success with a defense-minded team led by strong goaltending.

headline: Civilians Flee as Violence Worsens in South Sudan
text: KILO 10, Sudan — Martha Akuoch survived two offensives in the South Sudanese civil war, but the third pitched battle in the city of Malakal was more than she could take. She packed up and crossed the border into Sudan with her six children.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: A Family of Spies in Danger
text: When we last left Elizabeth (Keri Russell) and Philip (Matthew Rhys) things were a mess. It was nothing you wouldn’t expect from two K.G.B. agents posing as an American couple living in a cul-de-sac outside Reagan-era Washington: Their marriage was in jeopardy. Their mentor had just been murdered. Philip had just “married” the F.B.I. secretary who was feeding him secrets, and their daughter, Paige (Holly Taylor), was starting to suspect that they might be more than simply the hardworking owners of a travel agency. And then Elizabeth was shot in a set-up engineered by the F.B.I. agent Stan (Noah Emmerich) who is also their neighbor, who also needs a haircut. (Yes, it’s the ’80s, but he’s an F.B.I. agent, not an earth science teacher.)

headline: Michigan: Detroit Mayor Details Hopeful Vision
text: Mayor Mike Duggan on Wednesday laid out an ambitious vision for his bankrupt city, promising to buy new ambulances and buses, to create an affordable car insurance program and to urge tougher laws to stop thieves from stealing metal from streetlights and empty houses. For a city that became the nation’s largest to seek bankruptcy protection and for a mayor whose authority is limited by an emergency manager overseeing operations, Mr. Duggan struck a hopeful note in his first State of the City address. “The change has started,” said Mr. Duggan, who took office on Jan. 1. “The change is real. And Detroit is not nearly as far away from turning around as people think.”

headline: For-Profit School Sued Over Lending Practices
text: A federal agency on Wednesday sued ITT Educational Services, a major owner of for-profit colleges and trade schools, alleging predatory lending and other charges. It is the first suit against a for-profit education company by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, created in 2011, the bureau said. The bureau said the company lured students with zero-interest borrowing that had to be repaid after the first year, then pressured them to take new loans with very high fees and interest, knowing that most of them would default. ITT called the claims “without merit.” The company’s ITT Technical Institutes have about 140 campuses and 55,000 students.

headline: Disbelief After Egypt Announces Cures for AIDS and Hepatitis C
text: CAIRO — At a news conference late last week, an Egyptian Army doctor confidently announced that the country’s military had developed a cure for the virus that causes AIDS, as well as hepatitis C, one of Egypt’s gravest public health threats.

headline: Venezuela Accuses Intelligence Officers of Murdering 2
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Seven members of the intelligence service have been charged with murder in the shooting deaths of a demonstrator and a government supporter after a major protest march here, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Russia: Group to Seek House Arrest for Navalny
text: Russia’s powerful Investigative Committee said Wednesday that it would ask a court to put Aleksei A. Navalny, an opposition politician, under house arrest. In a statement, the committee said that Mr. Navalny had violated the terms of a travel ban in a case pending against him by driving outside of Moscow and by defying police officers at a rally on Monday. Mr. Navalny has said that the case against him, in which he stands accused of stealing more than $800,000 from the Russian branch of Yves Rocher, is politically motivated. The Associated Press said he was accused of doing so by charging an excessive price for shipping services. Mr. Navalny came to prominence by publishing online his investigations into government corruption. If approved, house arrest, which in other cases has included a ban on Internet use, could effectively remove Mr. Navalny from public life.

headline: Nigeria: College Attack Death Toll Rises
text: The United Nations reported Wednesday that at least 45 students were killed in the attack by Islamic extremists on a college in Nigeria this week and that the victims were as young as 13. The death toll was higher and the age range of the victims at the Federal Government College of Buni Yadi, in Yobe State, younger than initially reported by the Nigerian authorities. “Many lives were lost,” Manuel Fontaine, Unicef’s regional director for West and Central Africa, said in a statement denouncing the assault, the fourth that has closed a Nigeria school since last June. He said the closings had disrupted the lives of thousands of students, “many of whom have had no access to formal learning for months.” The Islamist group Boko Haram, which has denounced public education in Nigeria as blasphemous, has been blamed for the assaults.

headline: Living With Schizophrenia: Wanting to Connect
text: I still remember the first group therapy session I went to after I got out of the hospital. I was 20 and had been diagnosed as schizophrenic after a road trip that took me from Colorado to the United Nations building in New York City, my mind riddled with notions of good and evil, demons and angels, and a determination to save the world. Now I was in something of a state of shock, having come to understand that amid the delusions and paranoia that swarmed through my head I was, in reality, insane.

headline: The Mammoth Cometh
text: The first time Ben Novak saw a passenger pigeon, he fell to his knees and remained in that position, speechless, for 20 minutes. He was 16. At 13, Novak vowed to devote his life to resurrecting extinct animals. At 14, he saw a photograph of a passenger pigeon in an Audubon Society book and “fell in love.” But he didn’t know that the Science Museum of Minnesota, which he was then visiting with a summer program for North Dakotan high-school students, had them in their collection, so he was shocked when he came across a cabinet containing two stuffed pigeons, a male and a female, mounted in lifelike poses. He was overcome by awe, sadness and the birds’ physical beauty: their bright auburn breasts, slate-gray backs and the dusting of iridescence around their napes that, depending on the light and angle, appeared purple, fuchsia or green. Before his chaperones dragged him out of the room, Novak snapped a photograph with his disposable camera. The flash was too strong, however, and when the film was processed several weeks later, he was haunted to discover that the photograph hadn’t developed. It was blank, just a flash of white light.

headline: Sebastião Salgado: Migrant in a World of Migrants
text: Before he was known as a photographer, Sebastião Salgado was something even more essential to his identity: an émigré. His left-leaning politics and commitment to social justice had led him to flee Brazil in 1969 to study economics in France. There, he found countless other exiles — the lucky ones — who had managed to escape the murderous grip of Latin America’s Operation Condor.

headline: Does Reading a Book Count More Than Listening to One?

headline: Credit Suisse Under Scrutiny

The Senate hearing, the result of a two-year investigation into practices at the bank from 2001 through 2008, followed a scathing report issued on Tuesday by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations that at times read like a legal thriller for its bizarre details on the lengths the bank went to aid Americans in tax evasion.

headline: You’ve Got Meal (a Note, Too)
text: “The Lunchbox,” Ritesh Batra’s debut feature, is a romance that takes place in Mumbai, but its style is more Hollywood than Bollywood, and Old Hollywood at that. Though Mr. Batra and his cinematographer, Michael Simmonds, shot the film on location in the bustling modern city, with a naturalism alien to both American studio-era back-lot fantasies and present-day Indian musical extravaganzas, “The Lunchbox” has the measured pace and Classical restraint of a romance from the ’30s or ’40s. The comedy is more wry than uproarious, the melodrama gently poignant rather than operatic, and the sentimentality just sweet enough to be satisfying rather than bothersome.

headline: The Robber Barons of the For-Profit College Sector
text: Honest, well-run for-profit colleges can be helpful to students who do not qualify for traditional schools. But the robber barons in the for-profit sector represent a menace that requires more federal oversight. They saddle students with crushing debt while furnishing them useless degrees – or no degrees at all. These schools have been known to push students who are eligible for low-cost, federal loans into ruinously priced private loans that have fewer consumer protections and that give borrowers who get in trouble little choice but to default. That in turn makes it difficult for them to find jobs, get credit or rent apartments. And because private student loans are difficult to escape through bankruptcy, the stricken borrower might never recover.

headline: The Fancy Flock of James Bond Films

Where one may find it vaguely interesting that the inimitable character of James Bond was named after a real-life American ornithologist who published a book called “Birds of the West Indies” in 1936 — the author of the popular spy novels, Ian Fleming, was an avid bird-watcher — Simon sees an opportunity. In a two-part exhibition also titled “Birds of the West Indies,” Simon examines the surprising and thought-provoking relationship between the two men.
