headline: Painting on a Radio Canvas
text: LOS ANGELES — Max Maslansky’s talk show on KCHUNG radio is called “Riffin’ ” for a reason. When he invited the artist Danielle Adair to the station’s studio on the edge of Chinatown here, above a sewing-machine-repair shop and an herbalist, they touched on diverse subjects like cherry farming in Michigan and her work in progress: an experimental opera called “Caution Bomb” inspired by the radical educator Rudolf Steiner.

headline: Indian Soldier Kills 5 Members of His Unit in Kashmir
text: NEW DELHI — An Indian soldier killed five fellow soldiers with his service rifle and then committed suicide before dawn on Thursday while on duty at the gate of an army unit in the Indian-administered portion of Kashmir, the army announced.

headline: Exam Finds No Shoulder Problem for Mets’ Jon Niese
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets avoided their first potential calamity of spring training Thursday when pitcher Jon Niese was found to have “no shoulder problems at all” after having a magnetic resonance imaging test in New York, Manager Terry Collins said.

headline: Ukraine Crisis in Maps
text: The latest updates to the current visual survey of the continuing dispute, with maps and satellite imagery showing rebel and military movement.

headline: Balmain: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Why College Supply Matters
text: Most of the debate over America’s stagnant college graduation rates focuses on things that affect demand, like college affordability and the availability of financial aid. We ponder whether high school graduates are prepared for a college education.

headline: PayPal Has the Maturity to Go Out on Its Own
text: PayPal has outgrown the warm embrace of its parent eBay. Ownership by the online merchant provided rich soil for the payment system to thrive. But PayPal is now mature enough to grow faster on its own. The activist investor Carl C. Icahn has a point when he says that splitting eBay in two — as first suggested by Breakingviews in 2008 — would make investors about 15 percent richer.

headline: Proenza Schouler: 2 Americans in Paris
text: PARIS — In a basement on lower Broadway rests the entire Proenza Schouler archive, cataloged, bagged and unvisited. “From 2005 on, we’ve got every single collection,” said Jack McCollough, one half of the New York fashion label. (The earliest collections, from 2002 on, were sold to finance the ones that followed.) “But we never go down there, and we never reference it, really.”

headline: Day After Governor’s Veto, Arizona Takes Up Abortion Clinics
text: PHOENIX — A day after being reprimanded by Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, for failing to heed her call for action on the budget and the state’s child welfare agency, Arizona’s Republican-led House of Representatives promptly took up a new piece of social legislation on Thursday that would permit the surprise inspection of abortion clinics in the state.

headline: A World Tour for Restructuring Enthusiasts
text: Just when the world of restructuring was becoming dull, the world responded with a wave of financial distress. That sounds like bad news for most people, but for the cognoscenti of financial misfortune, it’s like an early Mardi Gras.

headline: Weak-Kneed Democrats Waver on the Minimum Wage
text: This week Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid decided to postpone a vote on raising the minimum wage, in part, it appears, because he does not have enough Democratic support to pass the measure. The holdouts include several Democratic senators from low-wage and mostly southern states who are up for reelection this year. That is pathetic.

headline: A Final Meal for Manzanilla
text: Manzanilla, Yann de Rochefort’s Spanish restaurant on Park Avenue South with the well-known Andalusian chef Dani García, closes tonight after about a year in business. Mr. de Rochefort said that the restaurant was not living up to expectations. “I feel it’s better for me to concentrate on my Boqueria restaurants, which are doing extremely well,” he said.

headline: China’s President Will Lead a New Effort on Cybersecurity
text: SHANGHAI — President Xi Jinping is presiding over a new working group on cybersecurity and information security, China announced on Thursday, a sign that the Communist Party views the issue as one of the country’s most pressing strategic concerns.

headline: The Gun Report: February 27, 2014
text: Here at the Gun Report we often come across careless handling of firearms, which can be deadly, especially when children find and discharge them. But it looks like the A.T.F. is having the same problem.

headline: British Regulator Pursuing Charges Against 3rd Person in Libor Case
text: Britain’s markets regulator issued the third notice in as many weeks that another individual is in its cross-hairs in its wide-ranging investigation into the manipulation of important interest rate benchmarks, including the London Interbank Offer Rate, or Libor.

headline: Study Indicates That Bill Redefining Full-Time Employment Would Have Costs
text: A few weeks ago, we reported on the sudden interest among House Republicans in legislation to rewrite the employer mandate in the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Nina Ricci: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Soggy Government Documents
text: Protesters sorted through documents discovered at the sprawling compound of the former Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovych.

headline: Ginta Lapiņa Transforms Backstage at Nina Ricci
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Ginta Lapina (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Kennedy Case Goes to Jury After Debate Over How Quickly a Sleep Aid Works
text: WHITE PLAINS — In an indignant summation, the prosecutor in the misdemeanor trial of Kerry Kennedy asked the jury Thursday to ignore the defendant’s magnetic background, and convict her for continuing to drive after she became aware she was under the influence of the sleeping pill Zolpidem.

headline: Artists Donate Works for Legal Defense of Man Who Smashed Ai Weiwei Vase
text: MIAMI — A few dozen artists have promised to donate works for an auction to help cover the legal expenses of a colleague who stunned the art world by smashing a vase by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei at the Pérez Art Museum Miami.

headline: Palestinian Found Dead After Standoff With Israelis
text: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian man was found dead in his home in the West Bank town of Bir Zeit on Thursday after a standoff with Israeli forces that had come to arrest him, according to the Israeli military.

headline: A JPMorgan Co-Head of Debt Capital Markets to Take a New Role
text: One of JPMorgan Chase’s heads of debt capital markets, Andrew O’Brien, will take on a broader new role overseeing lending activity across the investment bank, the firm announced in an internal memo on Thursday.

headline: Arizona Democrat Won’t Seek Re-election to House
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Ed Pastor, Democrat of Arizona, announced Thursday that he would not seek re-election this year for a 12th term.

headline: At Abandoned Ukrainian Palace, an Anxious Look Toward the Future
text: NOVI PETRIVTSI, Ukraine — Arthur Pereverziev is just 24, but he has the calm air of command. Thrown early into politics by the tumultuous decade that began with the Orange Revolution in 2004, he was an instrumental member of the civilian group Vidsich, or Repulse, which opposed the presidency of Viktor F. Yanukovych.

headline: Catching Perth’s Wave in Western Australia
text: Conjure up a city embodying all things right about cities. Assuming you lean toward the progressive, I’ll wager your rendering includes the following: multiple parks and waterfronts; spotless subways and free public buses; restaurant menus with organic, locally sourced food and wine; cool bars in heritage buildings; and pop-up everything, from farmers’ markets to cinema and yoga.

headline: Shopping, Sipping and Slurping in Bushwick, Brooklyn
text: Bushwick, a crime-ridden, desolate scene throughout the ‘90s, has recently developed a reputation for its raves, which are marked by pulsing electronic dance music and poker-faced Brooklyn hipsters. Fortunately, Bushwick offers more than a neon-tinted night life, and those more interested in mood lighting than strobe lights need not beware. This neighborhood, where hulking warehouses and graffiti-covered walls still far outnumber trees and grass, is a haven for artists, newly minted college graduates, working-class families and freelancers of all stripes, and this shows in its hangouts, which are often whimsical, generally easier on the wallet than their Manhattan counterparts and, as of late, surprisingly sophisticated.

headline: A Certain Something, Repeated
text: “A Collective Invention: Photographs at Play” at the Morgan Library & Museum is a gimmicky exhibition. That might sound bad, but it’s not. Some gimmicks are better than others. The one animating this show of more than 80 photographs and photo-related objects borrowed from private collectors makes for an entertaining and illuminating experience.

headline: Montana’s Big Sky Resort Gets Bigger
text: Bigger isn’t always better, but when it comes to ski resorts, size offers distinct advantages, from variety of terrain to off-the-beaten-path runs. For years, Vail Mountain has reigned as the nation’s largest ski area, but last fall Big Sky Resort, the understated ski area in southwestern Montana, leapfrogged its better-known competitor with the addition of acreage on a series of adjacent mountains, giving Big Sky boosters new talking points: empty runs.

headline: Rick Owens: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Federal Budget Deficit Falls to Smallest Level Since 2008
text: WASHINGTON — Closing the books on a fiscal year in which the federal budget deficit fell more sharply than in any year since the end of World War II, the Treasury Department reported on Thursday that the deficit for 2013 dropped to $680 billion, from about $1.1 trillion the previous year.

headline: A Discussion About ‘Bright Lights, Big City’
text: This time we outsourced our selection for the Big City Book Club to the writer and satirist Gary Shteyngart. We asked him to pick his favorite book about New York, and he did not demand that we read his own newly published memoir, “Little Failure,” about his upbringing as a Russian émigré in Queens. Instead, he selflessly selected “Bright Lights, Big City,” Jay McInerney’s touchstone novel of the hedonistic ’80s life on the other side of the East River. Join us for the online discussion of the novel with Mr. Shteyngart on Monday, March 10, at 6:30 p.m.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘The Lunchbox’
text: Ritesh Batra, the director of “The Lunchbox,” narrates a scene from his film.

headline: Art Matters | The Resurgence of Robert Mapplethorpe
text: Two high-profile exhibitions are breathing new life into the work of a famous art provocateur. Here, the curator Clarissa Dalrymple, Mapplethorpe’s dear friend, recalls one of his many controversial images.

headline: The ‘Myriopticon’ Game
text: A game captures the “Great Rebellion”

headline: D.C. Insurance Must Cover Treatment for Transgender Residents, Mayor Says
text: WASHINGTON — Health insurance providers in the District of Columbia must cover treatment for those given a diagnosis of gender dysphoria, including gender-reassignment surgeries, Mayor Vincent C. Gray said Thursday.

headline: An Unreliable Hero Aboard a Troubled Flight
text: A satisfying, primitive bluntness distinguishes “Non-Stop,” an action thriller that makes good on its title. In the 1950s, its star might have been Edmond O’Brien, a character actor who landed a few leading roles, including, in “D.O.A.,” as a poisoned man racing against the clock to find his murderer. With escalating clammy desperation he hurtles toward his fate, ticktock, ticktock. Liam Neeson runs a similarly frantic circuit in “Non-Stop,” as an air marshal trying to outwit a villain vowing to knock off a passenger every 20 minutes, ticktock, ticktock.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: male breast cancer, hepatitis C and antifreeze. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: A New Theater for Cirque du Soleil in Mexico
text: Montreal-based Cirque du Soleil has taken its acrobatics-based shows around the world, but put down few permanent roots, notably in Las Vegas, where it produces eight separate shows, and Orlando, where it has one. Now the group is heading south of the border with a new theater under construction on Mexico’s Riviera Maya.

headline: Museums to Display Ensor’s Monumental Drawing
text: RESTORED ‘SAINT ANTHONY’

headline: Growing Crisis in Its Backyard Snares Russia
text: MOSCOW — Despite repeated vows not to interfere or intervene, President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia has now found itself more deeply ensnared than ever in Ukraine’s worsening political crisis, facing appeals to support the country’s ethnic Russians, provide haven for its deposed president and perhaps even undertake a military response. The question is whether he intended it that way.

headline: Brown Seeks Fourth Term as Governor of California
text: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown, already the longest-serving governor in California history, announced Thursday that he would run for an unprecedented fourth term.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘The Lunchbox’
text: In this video, the director Ritesh Batra narrates a scene from his drama about the connection made between a neglected housewife (Nimrat Kaur) and a widowed office worker (Irrfan Khan).

headline: 8 Cities Vie for 2016 Republican Convention
text: No major Republican contenders have announced that they will seek the presidential nomination in 2016, but eight cities are officially in the running to throw the party for the nominee.

headline: De Blasio Seeks to Halt 3 Charter Schools From Moving Into Public Spaces
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio, seeking to curb the influence of outside providers of education, said on Thursday that he would block three charter schools from using space inside New York City public school buildings.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Afghanistan, Syria and Venezuela.

headline: O’Reilly Considers the ‘Downside’ to Having a Woman President
text: It’s only February, 2014, but Bill O’Reilly is already out there campaigning for Hillary Clinton, 2016. That’s not what he intends, of course, because I’m guessing Mrs. Clinton would be the last person Mr. O’Reilly wants to be president.

headline: Text to Text | ‘Huckleberry Finn’ and ‘In Defense of a Loaded Word’
text: “Probably the most offensive word” in the English language. Or, a word that can be used in a “neutral or familiar way and as a friendly term of address.” A word that should never be said. Or, a word that should never be said by white people.

headline: Ask Well: What Helps Motion Sickness?
text: A look at the drugs — some used by astronauts — that can relieve car, sea and space nausea.

headline: Praying for the Home Team in Oklahoma City
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Before the plumes of smoke and the shimmering pyrotechnics, before the two dozen or so dancers gyrating in microscopic shorts and the hip-hop, before the hairy mascot on stilts and the sponsorships — “Tonight’s free throws are brought to you by Hooters!” — there is prayer.

headline: Consumer Reports: Lexus Is No. 1
text: For the second year, Lexus has received the top overall score in the Consumer Reports’ Car Brand Report Cards. Acura took second place, and Audi was third.

text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Matthew Morrison to Star in Weinstein’s ‘Finding Neverland’
text: The theater and television actor Matthew Morrison will join Harvey Weinstein’s first major theater project — the musical “Finding Neverland” — in the role of J.M. Barrie, the creator of Peter Pan, according to two theater executives with knowledge of the casting. Mr. Morrison is now preparing for a developmental workshop of the show in March, which — if all goes well — will be followed by the American premiere in late summer at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., the executives said on Thursday. They spoke on condition of anonymity because the Weinstein Company has yet to officially announce the casting and production plans.

headline: A Dire Economic Forecast Based on New Assumptions
text: The part of the past that you deem most relevant can be critical in determining your outlook for the future. And nowhere is that clearer than in the changing economic forecasts that come out of the Congressional Budget Office.

headline: Hagel Urges Russia to Be 'Transparent'
text: Following NATO talks on Ukraine in Brussels, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel calls on Russia “to respect Ukraine’s sovereignty and avoid provocative actions.”

headline: Klinsmann Invites 24 to U.S. Team’s Camp in Germany
text: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States men’s national soccer team, on Thursday released the 24-man roster that he will take to training camp in Frankfurt. The players are expected to report Sunday.

headline: Discussions of Arizona Governor’s Veto
text: Reaction to Gov. Jan Brewer’s veto of a bill that would have allowed refusal of service to gay men and lesbians.

headline: The Return of the Happy Atheist
text: As promised, a second post occasioned by the Gopnik essay on belief and atheism — this time, focused on the interesting change that’s come over atheism over the last generation or so, during which time the sunny optimism of 18th century irreligion has made a striking comeback. Reading Gopnik’s remarks on the confident, history-is-going-our-way spirit of so much of the new unbelief, I was reminded of a Leszek Kolakowski essay, “Anxiety About God in an Ostensibly Godless Age,” which appeared more than thirty years ago, in 1981, and can be found in a recent collection of his work. Here’s a relevant excerpt, offering a kind of mini-history of Western atheism and its discontents:

headline: Video: Countdown to Oscar Night
text: With just three days to go until the big night, Hollywood is working overtime on preparations, and so are pundits. While the Bagger sorts out her predictions in what has shaped up as a very competitive awards season, The Times media columnist David Carr and co-chief film critic A.O. Scott have surveyed the best-picture field in preparation for a special Oscar-night edition of their show “The Sweet Spot.”

headline: British Spies Said to Intercept Yahoo Webcam Images
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A British intelligence agency collected video webcam images — many of them sexually explicit — from millions of Yahoo users, regardless of whether they were suspected of illegal activity, according to accounts of documents leaked by Edward J. Snowden.

headline: A Storm Washes Away Old Ideas on Wine
text: When Hurricane Sandy sent the East River surging in October 2012, Buzzy O’Keeffe, the owner of the River Café, ordered his staff to open the doors. By letting the water go through his restaurant, which is on a barge at Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn, he believes he saved it from sinking under the weight of the flooding. Even so, the River Café was ravaged.

headline: Alice Herz-Sommer, Who Found Peace in Chopin Amid Holocaust, Dies at 110
text: Throughout her two years in Theresienstadt, through the hunger and cold and death all around her, through the loss of her mother and husband, Alice Herz-Sommer was sustained by a Polish man who had died long before. His name was Frédéric Chopin.

headline: Moving on From Make-Believe
text: When Tyler and I were 27, we packed up a Penske truck with everything we owned and drove cross-country to move in together for the first time in Portland, Ore., 3,000 miles from my family in New York.

headline: Focusing on Its Digital Strategy, Time Inc. Hires Away an Executive From The Atlantic
text: Time Inc. announced on Thursday that it had hired M. Scott Havens, the president of The Atlantic, to spearhead the digital strategy for its magazine brands, including People, Sports Illustrated and Fortune.

headline: Start-Up That Analyzes Twitter for Wall Street Raises Financing
text: Eagle Alpha, a start-up that mines social media and the web for market-related information, is expanding with backing from a handful of individual investors.

headline: Costa Concordia Captain Returns to Ship as Trial Examines Generators
text: ROME — For the first time since the cruise ship Costa Concordia hit a submerged rock and capsized two years ago, killing 32 people, the ship’s captain went back aboard the vessel on Thursday with a team of experts investigating the shipwreck as part of his trial.

headline: A Window-Washing Service on Two Wheels
text: “Dirty windows are bad for business,” said Phil Prado, 50, giving the rationale for his own business: a one-man, two-wheeled window-washing service that has him pedaling around downtown and Midtown Manhattan.

headline: A Farmer’s Breakfast, and Then a Wander
text: When the actor Michael Emerson, 59, walks around Manhattan, it’s not unusual for people to stop him and ask if he’ll pose for a picture. The television shows “Lost” and, currently, “Person of Interest” have made his spiky hair, thick-rimmed glasses and long sideburns a giveaway. He takes it in stride, even on Sunday, which he designates a day of leisure, reserved for meandering, cultural events and time with his wife, the actress Carrie Preston, 46 — who herself is recognized for her roles in “True Blood” and “The Good Wife” — and her extended family. The couple live with their rescue dog, Chumley, 4, near Columbus Circle.

headline: Wryly Nibbling at His Bread and Butter
text: BEIJING — Is there a Chinese word for chutzpah? If there is, the Shanghai artist Xu Zhen, often called the Maurizio Cattelan of China, fits the bill. Combining the roles of artist, curator and chief executive of his own corporation, MadeIn, he has forged a career of pushing buttons, consistently riling audiences with shocking installations though rarely provoking the Chinese government. He is considered the leader of a younger generation of Chinese artists who have disengaged from the Mao-driven paintings of the 1990s in favor of more conceptual projects. Xu Zhen (pronounced shoo-jen) is also the commissioned artist for the sprawling 2014 Armory Show, which opens on Thursday on Piers 92 and 94 in Manhattan with a focus on China.

headline: An App That Makes Recommendations Based on Tastes
text: It is a standard feature of websites to provide recommendations to users based on past activity. On nytimes.com, the “Recommended for You” tab is always at hand. Services like Pandora and Netflix have long suggested music and movies based on algorithms that track users’ preferences.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Truly Glowing Skin at Balmain
text: At Balmain, makeup artist Tom Pecheux focused on creating gorgeous skin. But instead of using makeup to create the illusion of a flawless face, he pampered the models with face massages to help the blood circulate and to suss out an all-natural glow. Pecheux then nourished the skin with Rodin Olio Lusso face oil, for both hydration and luminosity, followed by Estée Lauder’s Revitalizing Supreme and Idealist Pore-Minimizing Skin Refinisher. After this deluxe treatment, Pecheux applied foundation — he advises mixing two hues, especially during transitional seasons — and powder. Eyebrows were teased out to be fuller, “but not bushy, not extravagant, not Frida Kahlo,” he explained, adding that “eyebrows give a woman character.” Overall, it was a spare, natural look. “If your skin looks beautiful, you already look beautiful. After that, everything else is accessory,” Pecheux reasoned. “At Balmain, there is a lot of accessorizing on the body, so you don’t need accessorizing on the face.”

headline: Jos. A. Bank Rejects Latest Men’s Wearhouse Bid, but Agrees to Meet
text: Jos. A. Bank said on Thursday that its board had rejected Men’s Wearhouse‘s newest takeover bid, worth nearly $1.8 billion, but said that it was willing to meet to try and agree on a higher price.

headline: Confused and Enthused at a Sports Bar
text: THE first time I watched a Knicks game on TV with my stepson Simon, he was 7. He came armed with the remote; I came armed with Vogue. A few minutes in, he fixed me with an icy glare. “You’re not watching the game,” he announced. “You’re reading a magazine.”

headline: Superheroes Heading to New York
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Wednesday that four live-action television series based on Daredevil and three other Marvel comic book heroes will be shot in New York City.

headline: Charles Ives’s Workroom, Pencil Shavings Preserved
text: The austere workroom from the 1910s home of the modernist composer Charles Ives in West Redding, Conn., has been transported to Manhattan, complete with pencil shavings, tattered bulletin board postings and a secret stash of alcohol bottles.

headline: The Twins Ran Off? Can I Have Their Share?
text: When I was an editor at The New York Times Book Review not so long ago, we usually discouraged reviewers from mentioning the prizes an author had won, unless those prizes were ambrosial — the National Book Award, the Man Booker, the Yale Series of Younger Poets and so on.

headline: Also on the Menu at Empire Diner: New Memories
text: Amanda Freitag walks to work daily and is still giddy when she opens the door to the Empire Diner. A Chelsea landmark from 1976 until it closed in 2010 (briefly reopening as the Highliner), it is, since Jan. 7, her restaurant now. “I can’t believe it, this is such an iconic space,” Ms. Freitag, the chef and owner, said Tuesday in the redone Tenth Avenue diner that kept some dented metal but added Edison bulbs and gray leather banquettes. “Now to see it come to life, and everybody telling their stories, it’s been great.” A celebrity chef with warmth and whimsy, Ms. Freitag has heard friends and strangers tell of first dates at the former diner turned into marriages with children, and waiters getting grown-up jobs. With twists on staples likes burgers and omelets alongside items like lox and burrata and luxuriously creamy orzo “mac and cheese,” the menu breezily mixes memory and modernity.

headline: ENI Reaches Deal With Statoil for Gas Price Cuts

As a result, ENI agreed to suspend the legal arbitration on the contracts, which began last summer, for 30 days while the two companies try to reach a final agreement.

headline: In Oscar Voting, All Politics Is Local
text: Steve McQueen, director of “12 Years a Slave,” doesn’t storyboard his films, though all have a painterly aesthetic. Mr. McQueen started out as a visual artist. He also doesn’t shot-list, production-speak for cataloging each day’s scenes, preferring to set up and let the camera roam on location.

text: In the Video

headline: White Lies
text: Strange times, crowed too many wise and unwise men over the millenniums. But as the art critic Jerry Saltz wrote in New York magazine last fall, maybe we’re finally at a point where the strangeness of the times is matched by an ability to accept it. In defending the perplexing Kanye West video “Bound 2,” Saltz heralded this as an age of the New Uncanny. The all-American banal-bizarre spectacle of the video (synthetic sunsets; slow-motion galloping stallions; the nippleless ingénue) is “a freakish act of creation and destruction by appropriation,” what Saltz deems “part of a collective cultural fracturing.” Saltz is riffing on Freud’s description of the uncanny as “nothing new or alien, but something familiar and old-established in the mind and which has become alienated from it only through the process of repression.” But maybe we’re not as alienated as we once were, something that occurred to me when beholding another unapologetic, all-encompassing contradiction-celebration: the story-allegory and real-surreal gyre of Helen Oyeyemi’s gloriously unsettling new novel, “Boy, Snow, Bird.”

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Feb. 28-March 6
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: The Reinvention of the Suit
text: From cutoff sleeves to elongated jackets and shorts, traditional men’s wear is taking its cues from the street.

headline: If You Can’t Get Onstage, Go Online
text: In an early episode of the web series “Submissions Only,” created by Kate Wetherhead and Andrew Keenan-Bolger, the struggling actress Penny Reilly, excited to be cast in a workshop production of an important new musical, ends up with such a small part that she’s seated behind a piano where the audience can’t see her. The scene is funny, but the humiliation was real for Ms. Wetherhead, who plays her.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Feb. 28-March 6
text: Kids Food Festival

headline: State of Our Art, According to Whitney
text: WHITNEY Biennials can be daunting, confounding, exhausting and sometimes even outrageous. No matter how the curators organize this sprawling survey of what’s happening in American contemporary art right now, trying to navigate the museumwide exhibition and make sense of it all is a challenge, even for the pros.

headline: Egyptian Military Claims to Cure H.I.V. and Hepatitis C
text: As my colleagues Kareem Fahim and Mayy El Sheikh reported, the Egyptian military made the unlikely announcement last week that after 22 years of secret research it had found a cure to not just one global public health scourge, but two: hepatitis C and H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: Slaking a Thirst for Beers at Craft Breweries
text: On a recent Friday evening in an old factory building in Bristol, people crowded into two back rooms to down pints of beer. It looked like some kind of pop-up party, but it was actually just business as usual at the Firefly Hollow Brewing Company, one of the many new craft breweries to open in Connecticut in the last two years.

headline: Chris Lehane’s Political Theater
text: In this week’s magazine, Adam Nagourney profiles Chris Lehane, a California-based political strategist known for what Nagourney calls “performance politics.”

headline: Google Pays for the Ride
text: Google, which has been at the center of a controversy in San Francisco over tech company shuttles using public infrastructure, is giving $6.8 million to fund a city transit program.

headline: Two Months In, Attracting Crowds
text: MoCA Asian Bistro in Woodbury has been drawing crowds since its opening two months ago. When I called two days ahead for a Friday or Saturday reservation, I was told that none were available, no matter how early or late. I settled for a Saturday night reservation 10 days in the future and was given a choice of 6 or 6:30 p.m.

headline: Buying Real Estate in a Changing Climate
text: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Google Continues With Its Project Ara Modular Smartphone Effort
text: Google might have given up on Motorola after it sold the company to Lenovo last month, but the search giant is still going all-in on its experimental Project Ara phone, which is a modular smartphone.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: The Radical Happiness of Pharrell
text: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss Pharrell Williams and his new album, “G I R L.”

headline: Spare Times for Feb. 28-March 6
text: ‘Darkness & Light: Contemporary Nordic Photography’ (through April 26) It’s not surprising that this show’s 10 photographers, hailing from the lands of the midnight sun, use light in a variety of ways. Their skills are on display at Scandinavia House, 58 Park Avenue, at East 38th Street.

headline: Cervelli and Yankees Teammates Show Support for Protesters in Venezuela
text: About a dozen Yankees, including Francisco Cervelli of Venezuela, became the latest major leaguers to express support for the growing opposition movement in Venezuela by being photographed with the nation’s flag and signs for peace. Ichiro Suzuki and C. C. Sabathia were among the Yankees in the photo, which was posted to Cervelli’s Instagram account.

headline: Asian Cuisine, Easy on the Fusion
text: Sleekly designed Asian fusion restaurants have popped up all over Westchester in recent years with lounge-style lighting, pumping music and menus that are not as much a fusion as they are a gathering of offerings from Japanese, Chinese, Malaysian, Korean and Thai cuisines.

headline: A Small Subset of Texas Voters Who Hold a Lot of Sway
text: In modern-day Texas, the election that matters is usually the Republican primary.

headline: Creative Cuisine, Vibrant Setting
text: The minute you enter Órale Mexican Kitchen in Jersey City, you can see that the person who decorated it has a fine eye for design. Note, in particular, the beautifully lit bottles of Jarritos soda, in colors that reflect their flavors (lime, strawberry, fruit punch, mandarin and grapefruit). After a flight of tequila and a round of guacamole studded with unexpected treats, like cubes of Cabrales blue cheese or juicy pineapple, you know you are in for more than just visual delights.

headline: Luminous Canterbury Pilgrims
text: With monastic masonry shipped in from Europe, an interior filled with liturgical luxe, and its air fragrant with spiritual expectation, the Cloisters, the Metropolitan Museum’s medieval redoubt in Upper Manhattan, is a complete atmospheric package, and one of the city’s great examples of installation art.

headline: Authenticity Is Just Part of an Allure
text: When it comes to Champagne and Roquefort, an appellation d’origine contrôlée, a trade label authenticating a product’s provenance, can be a useful guarantor of quality. But how much do terroir and tradition matter in music? Plenty, according to the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, which continues its New York residence as part of Carnegie Hall’s festival Vienna: City of Dreams.

headline: The Damage That Good Can Inflict
text: Good intentions and billions of promised dollars only go so far. That, certainly, is one of the sobering truths in “Fatal Assistance,” a potent, persuasive and quietly furious documentary that examines how international aid agencies failed Haiti after the catastrophic 2010 earthquake. That disaster, which was followed by other calamities, including a cholera outbreak, left an estimated quarter-million people dead and more than a million temporarily or permanently homeless. People and organizations across the world pledged help, and money started to flood in along with journalists, religious workers, relief groups, Bill Clinton and Sean Penn.

headline: Operas Unfolding at a Different Met
text: As ticket holders for a performance by the Gotham Chamber Opera filed into the Arms and Armor Court at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Wednesday evening, some did a double take when they saw a soldier in modern uniform sitting behind a glass enclosure, rolling a joint.

headline: So Blissfully Nestled in Her Web of Lies
text: The anxious, melancholic drama “Two Lives” is the story of a woman caught up in the toxic backwash of long-ago events that exert a fearful grip on the present. Unholy forces shaped the double life of this woman, Katrine (Juliane Köhler, “Nowhere in Africa”). Happily married and living in Norway, she has a secret past that merges two of the darker chapters of 20th-century European history.

headline: Many Allies, but Perry Lends Name to Few
text: As Republicans poke around for signals on how to vote in crowded primary races — those, that is, who have not taken advantage of early voting — the state’s top elected Republican official is offering little assistance.

headline: The Greatest Story, Retold
text: Adapted from the History channel mini-series “The Bible,” “Son of God” runs through the scriptural greatest hits of the Passion with the reliability of a Sunday reader. It’s a movie that embraces the nearly pedagogical predictability of lines like “Where’s Judas? You seen him?” or “Thomas, stop doubting.”

headline: Finding Poetry in Pairs
text: Kimberly Bartosik’s “You are my heat and glare” begins with a song. You might be in the lobby, waiting for the elevator to the third-floor studio, when you first hear it. Two singers (Gelsey Bell and Dave Ruder), part the crowd and then disappear into the stairwell, their luminous harmonies vanishing with them.

headline: A Juvenile Justice System With Few Checks
text: Carefully assembled and soberly presented, Robert May’s “Kids for Cash” takes a lacerating look at America’s juvenile justice system — the United States is one of only three countries in the world to decline to ratify the United Nations’ Convention on the Rights of the Child — and the perils of its increasing privatization.

headline: If You’d Like to Live, Best Not Look Inside
text: Robert De Niro’s silly pompadour in “The Bag Man” is one sign that this sardonic neo-noir, the first feature directed by David Grovic, has a cheeky sense of itself as something extra clever. Mr. De Niro plays Dragna, whose voluminous hairstyle — reminiscent of Paulie’s ’do on “The Sopranos” — is also a reflection of his inflated ego.

headline: You, Me, Us
text: My husband and I had successful careers in finance before we married. When we had our first child, we agreed that I would quit my job to spend more time with the baby. (We now have two bright toddlers.) But we never agreed how our finances would be managed after I stopped working. Now, he pays the house- and child-related expenses, and I pay my personal expenses from my savings, which will run out at some point. But when investment decisions are required, he calls the shots, even though he asks for my opinion. This often makes me uncomfortable because he is willing to take greater risks than I am. How do you think we should make these decisions?

headline: Truth-Telling in a Medical Setting
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Globalization of Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Child Genius Meets Middle-Age Kid
text: In “With Honors” (1994), Brendan Fraser played a Harvard undergrad. Twenty years later, he goes back to school in Billy Kent’s “HairBrained” as Leo Searly, a 41-year-old failed gambler who decides to enroll at the fictional Whittman College and befriends a 14-year-old classmate.

headline: Tea Party Group, Celebrating Its Fifth Anniversary, Is Happy but Restless
text: WASHINGTON — The list of marquee names on hand was testament to the growing clout of the Tea Party: Rand Paul, Ted Cruz, Mike Lee — all three elected to the Senate thanks to its activist support.

headline: The Crowning Glory
text: Like coats and ties at a ballgame, cornices have pretty much disappeared from contemporary architecture.

headline: Inroads Into Child Obesity
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Military Budget
text: To the Editor:

headline: Curbs on E-Cigarettes
text: To the Editor:

headline: A War of Words: Israel Responds to Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: Eggs Over Easy, With a Side of Weird
text: “I may see dead people,” Odd (Anton Yelchin), the civic-minded hero of “Odd Thomas,” tells us, “but then, by God, I do something about it.” Given that most of the expired souls who crave his attention are crime victims, what he does usually takes the form of hunting down killers.

headline: A Suburban Life Running on Fumes
text: A line of cocaine disappears up a nostril in what turns out to be an apt introduction to a movie about curdled characters seeking empty distractions. But “Chlorine,” Jay Alaimo’s sour tale of suburban greed and marital disappointment, can’t even deliver a temporary high; mired in the blahs, the blues and the midlife crazies, this poor man’s “American Beauty” slowly sucks your will to live.

headline: New Butler Services Buff Luxury Hotels
text: In the race for an increasingly personalized luxury hotel experience, the butler may be the ultimate amenity. Since January, the new Langham, Chicago has employed a rotating staff of eight dedicated butlers for its three club floors.

headline: Humanity, Enhanced, on a Russian Battlefield
text: The credits of “Stalingrad,” a Russian-made 3-D film set during a pivotal battle in World War II, attribute the story to selected chapters from the panoramic novel “Life and Fate” by Vasily Grossman. It’s not the source you might expect for a war movie that uses slow-motion as liberally as a Michael Bay film and that heaves its scream-filled skirmishes onto the arena-size canvas of an Imax screen.

headline: Dove Tells Women to Love Their Armpits
text: AFTER bearing the brunt of jokes about “Bridgegate,” the scandal surrounding the closure of traffic lanes on the George Washington Bridge that aides of Gov. Chris Christie apparently ordered as political payback, New Jersey residents may not laugh along with Dove billboards that will appear in their state.

headline: More Seems to Be Less for Mets at First Base
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — It was not really supposed to be a competition at all.

headline: On a Youth Kick
text: PARIS — Youth is the cause célèbre here. There is a sour sense that the next generation of great designers has yet to come. Figuring out who they are is part of the task of the newly established LVMH Prize. It will offer 300,000 euros (about $412,000) and industry mentorship to the winner of an open contest — provided he or she is younger than 40, with at least two collections already in hand.

headline: Political Party Ends Blockade of NATO Supply Route in Pakistan
text: The opposition politician Imran Khan announced Thursday that his political party, Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, which governs the northwestern Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province, would end its three-month blockade of a NATO supply route. Mr. Khan’s party imposed the blockade in November to protest American drone strikes in Pakistan’s tribal regions. On Thursday, party workers removed a protest camp in Peshawar that was used to stop trucks heading toward the border with Afghanistan. This week, a court in Peshawar ruled that the blockade was illegal. A statement released by Mr. Khan’s party said that “the pressure of the blockade had already resulted in a shift in the Obama administration’s drone policy, and as a result drones had been stopped for the present.”

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Several Bombings Leave Dozens Dead in Iraq
text: At least 38 people were killed and more than 50 were wounded Thursday in a series of bombings in Iraq, three of them in Shiite areas of Baghdad, Iraqi officials said. The deadliest attack killed 24 people when a bomb attached to a motorcycle exploded in a market where motorcycles are sold in the Sadr City area of Baghdad, the police said. Another bomb in Sadr City blew up a bus, killing five people and wounding 14, and a bomb in the Shaab neighborhood destroyed a minibus, killing four people and wounding 13, the police said. At a checkpoint in northern Baghdad, a suicide bomber killed three soldiers and wounded three, and in Tuz Khurmato, north of Baghdad, a blast at a fish restaurant killed two people and wounded 18, security officials said. Also on Thursday, Iraqi security forces carried out operations against militants in Mosul and in Kirkuk and Anbar Provinces, with officials reporting that more than 20 militants were killed.

headline: Brooklyn Communal Cool: The Brand
text: On a recent Tuesday evening, Dickerman Cade Sadler III was in the kitchen making tacos for his roommates, sautéing beef in a frying pan and setting aside a bowl of rice and beans for the vegetarians. In the living room-cum-recording studio, Denitia Odigie was sitting at the drum kit tapping out a beat, her back to the wall papered with old-fashioned damask, while a man who calls himself Sene (his real name is Brian Marc) set up a mike under the glass and bronze chandelier. Standing outside, on the quiet cul-de-sac, two 20-somethings in clunky glasses and knitted beanies braved the freezing winter air to smoke a cigarette.

headline: Evidence of Concealed Jailhouse Deal Raises Questions About a Texas Execution
text: In the 10 years since Texas executed Cameron Todd Willingham after convicting him on charges of setting his house on fire and murdering his three young daughters, family members and death penalty opponents have argued that he was innocent. Now newly discovered evidence suggests that the prosecutor in the case may have concealed a deal with a jailhouse informant whose testimony was a key part of the execution decision.

headline: Met Opera Seeking Concessions in Union Talks
text: The Metropolitan Opera is seeking concessions from its unions, whose contracts are up at the end of July, as it begins a round of labor negotiations that promise to be contentious.

headline: The Cancer Divide
text: As nations across Africa have made remarkable progress against infectious diseases, more people are living long enough to develop cancer.

headline: A Community Center as DMZ in City’s Class War
text: In ordinary times, the opening of a gym in Lower Manhattan might not occasion much reflection, but these, as it happens, are not ordinary times. We are in a moment of class warfare, of punishing the rich for their triumphs of asset management, or so the right labors to convince us. To believe this is to miss the extent to which class warfare is more than a political tool; it is an intimate social reality whose perpetrators come not from the vast aggrieved bottom.

headline: U.S. Moves Toward Atlantic Oil Exploration, Stirring Debate Over Sea Life
text: The Interior Department opened the door on Thursday to the first searches in decades for oil and gas off the Atlantic coast, recommending that undersea seismic surveys proceed, though with a host of safeguards to shield marine life from much of their impact.

headline: The Tenure Pipeline at Harvard Business School
text: Harvard Business School says it wants to improve the gender balance among faculty members, but it is far from that goal without extensive hiring.

headline: British Lawmakers Intensify Focus on Head Injuries
text: LONDON — Spurred by the momentum the issue has gained in the United States, British lawmakers have started their own campaign to highlight the incidence of serious head injuries in sports, calling for a tightening of the rules governing the way that players, coaches, team doctors, professional leagues and parents respond to sports-related concussions.

headline: Bakken Crude, Rolling Through Albany
text: ALBANY — On a clear December morning two years ago, a 600-foot oceangoing oil tanker called the Stena Primorsk left the Port of Albany on its maiden voyage down the Hudson River laden with 279,000 barrels of crude oil. It quickly ran aground on a sandbar.

headline: Ease and Ardor
text: Michel de Montaigne and Samuel Johnson are two of the greatest essayists who ever lived. They tackled similar problems and were fascinated by some of the same perplexities, but they represent different personality types and recommended two different ways to live.

headline: Arizona Bill Allowing Refusal of Service to Gays Stirred Alarm in the G.O.P.
text: When Gov. Rick Scott of Florida was asked early Wednesday whether he supported Arizona legislation that would make it easier for business owners to refuse service to gay people on religious grounds, he demurred, saying he was unfamiliar with the bill. By afternoon, his office issued a statement saying the measure was divisive and should be vetoed.

headline: No Big Deal
text: Everyone knows that the Obama administration’s domestic economic agenda is stalled in the face of scorched-earth opposition from Republicans. And that’s a bad thing: The U.S. economy would be in much better shape if Obama administration proposals like the American Jobs Act had become law.

headline: SeaWorld Questions Ethics of ‘Blackfish’ Investigator
text: LOS ANGELES — SeaWorld Entertainment, which has come under fire after the release of “Blackfish,” a critical documentary about whales in captivity, struck back Thursday at one of its government monitors for her supposed cozy relations with animal-rights activists and involvement in the film.

headline: Cubs Are Working on Winning Soon, if Not Now
text: MESA, Ariz. — The Chicago Cubs devoted 7,500 square feet to the workout facility of their sprawling new spring training complex here. There is also a 120-seat theater and 22 pitching mounds and 16 batting cages. But the gym is the jewel, two stories of weight machines and treadmills and loud music underneath a canopy of red and blue championship banners.

headline: The Mean Streets of New York
text: WITHIN a two-block radius on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, three pedestrians have lost their lives in separate traffic accidents since Jan. 1. Nineteen more have been killed elsewhere in the city since the beginning of the year. Those 22 are just the latest in the city’s epidemic of traffic fatalities. Last year 176 pedestrians were killed by cars and trucks in the city, according to police data, the most since 2008.

headline: When May I Shoot a Student?
text: BOISE, Idaho — TO the chief counsel of the Idaho State Legislature:

headline: Fitness and Redemption
text: Tommy Mickens started a company that teaches fitness to senior citizens, a career move that began after he served 20 years in prison.

headline: Jeter, Held Hitless, Gives Yankees Fans Reason to Celebrate
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Derek Jeter walked to home plate in the first inning Thursday and, before looking out to the mound, said hello to the Pittsburgh Pirates’ new catcher, Chris Stewart, his teammate on the Yankees the last two seasons.

headline: A Call to Give Consumers Their Credit Scores Free
text: In its new role as consumer credit watchdog, the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Thursday urged credit card companies to give customers free copies of their credit scores — crucial pieces of financial information used to evaluate qualifications for mortgages, credit cards and even certain types of insurance and rental apartments.

headline: Driving Down Childhood Obesity
text: There are glimmers of good news in the struggle to control obesity, one of the greatest health risks confronting the United States and other affluent nations. The latest federal report shows a significant reduction in the obesity rate among children ages 2 to 5, a vulnerable period when obesity patterns are often locked in for a lifetime. It is only a modest step in the right direction for a small slice of the population, but it suggests that further gains may be possible with a determined effort.

headline: Of Crime and Punishment, Redemption and Aerobics
text: It was a stinging 9 degrees on a recent Thursday morning when Thomas Mickens bounded into the Rochdale Village Senior Center in Jamaica, Queens. He was 15 minutes early to teach his 8:30 a.m. aerobics class, and his boisterous entrance was met by friendly jabs and laughter from about three dozen enthusiastic older people. The group ranged from 60 to 89 years old, most on the younger side of old age; none relied on walkers and only two had canes.

headline: As Africans Surge to Europe’s Door, Spain Locks Down
text: MELILLA, Spain — It is easy to pick out the new arrivals at the shelter for immigrants here on this tiny patch of Spain in North Africa. One man limps by on crutches with a plaster cast on his ankle. Another has a bandaged arm in a sling. Abbdol Cisse, 19, had stitches on his face.

headline: Thailand at the Brink
text: Political tensions that have long simmered in Thailand have exploded into violence in recent days. Clashes and gunfights between antigovernment protesters and security forces led to several deaths and many more injuries over the weekend. But the country’s elected leaders and the protesters are digging in their heels even as the conflict tears their country apart. The leader of Thailand’s army recently warned that continued violence could lead to a “collapse” of the country.

headline: Business and the Minimum Wage
text: Much of the discussion about the Democratic proposal to raise the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour by 2016 has rightly focused on the workers who will clearly benefit from the move. But what about businesses? How would higher wages affect them?

headline: Events in New Jersey for March 2-8
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: McIlroy Leads With 63, but He Has Company
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Rory McIlroy’s emotions often creep into his game, causing his mind to wander far outside the gallery ropes. But if McIlroy blocks out the noise and channels his talent, he can produce special scores like the 63 he fired to take the Honda Classic lead Thursday.

headline: Nagging, as a Force for Good
text: Lurking strategically in the offices of the Department of Probation in the Bronx, Stephanie Arno positioned herself so that no one could walk out to 161st Street without passing her.

headline: Events in Connecticut for March 2-8
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: The Toys of War
text: Just in time for Christmas 1866, a 30-year-old game creator named Milton Bradley ran an advertisement in Colman’s Rural World, a St. Louis-based publication for farmers. Bradley, a lithographer living in Springfield, Mass., was already well known for inventing “The Checkered Game of Life” in 1860. His 1866 ad promoted his games and amusements as “moral, entertaining, wonderful, and instructive.” Among these wonders was the Myriopticon, a toy panorama containing 22 scenes from the history of the “Rebellion” so recently concluded. The toy evidently caught on, at least for a time. The next year, another Bradley puff described the Myriopticon as “immensely popular with boys,” especially those ages 7 to 12.

headline: Mortgage Servicer’s Ties Raise Regulatory Concern
text: Mortgage servicers collect money from homeowners and distribute those payments to lenders. It’s a fairly boring business, but not to William C. Erbey.

headline: Plan to Redevelop Domino Sugar Factory in Brooklyn Hits Snag: De Blasio
text: For years, the plan to redevelop the Domino Sugar refinery in Williamsburg was viewed in the neighborhood with dread, roundly derided as a line of bulky new buildings that would clog the Brooklyn waterfront.

headline: A Call to Arms on a Vermont Heroin Epidemic
text: RUTLAND, Vt. — Block by block, this city in central Vermont has been fighting a heroin epidemic so entrenched that it has confounded all efforts to combat it.

headline: Events on Long Island for March 2-8
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Credit Card Debt Threatens Turkey’s Economy
text: ISTANBUL — Ozcan Yuksel’s descent into debt began with a stroll down Istiklal Caddesi, a popular Istanbul promenade teeming with shops and restaurants.

headline: Antoine Mason Is Driven to Succeed, Just Like His Father
text: Longtime Knicks fans probably still treasure memories of Anthony Mason, a powerful 6-foot-7, 250-pound forward who willed himself to prominence as a seemingly tireless worker beside Patrick Ewing in the early 1990s. Mason’s son Antoine, a junior guard at Niagara who is the second-leading scorer in Division I with 25.7 points a game, has a less imposing body type. But he is his father’s son in every other way.

headline: A House With a Modified Loan Is a Symbol of Servicers’ Tug of War With Investors
text: A small, run-down house in Uniondale, N.Y., may sum up why bad blood is brewing between some of the biggest players in today’s housing market — and why that tension may hamper the nation’s attempts to recover from years of painful foreclosures and depressed housing values.

headline: Copycat Business Model Generates Genuine Global Success for Start-Up Incubator
text: BERLIN — For Linio, think Amazon for Mexicans. For Zalora, think Zappos for Malaysians. For Easy Taxi, think Uber for Nigerians.

headline: Bin Laden Relative’s Lawyers Claim Mistaken Identity as Trial Nears
text: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, faces a terrorism trial next week in Manhattan. But his lawyers now claim that the authorities have mixed him up with a man with a similar name who is detained at the United States naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Naming of Officials in Ukraine Reflects Homage to Power of the Street
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Oleh Musiy, a prominent doctor who last week coordinated the improvised field hospitals that treated wounded and dying protesters during clashes with the police, is now the health minister of Ukraine, a nation of 46 million people.

headline: Rare Supreme Court Outburst Caught on Even Rarer Videos
text: WASHINGTON — A protest group has posted surreptitious videos prepared inside the Supreme Court during oral arguments, one of them showing an audience member standing to denounce the court’s decision in the Citizens United campaign finance case.

headline: At Council Hearing, Calls for New York to Offer Homeless Children and Families More Aid
text: Members of the City Council pressed the de Blasio administration at a hearing on Thursday to complete a proposal for rental assistance to New York’s homeless and demanded improved services for more than 22,000 children living in city shelters.

headline: Events in Westchester for March 2-8
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: A Caged Wife, Desperately Spinning Her Wheel
text: How can suspense be so enthralling when you know exactly what’s going to happen? You may find yourself asking that question as you dig your fingernails into your palms during the show that opened on Thursday night at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Can’t Hold Their Feelings, or Their Alcohol
text: Something scary, and pretty much irresistible, happens in the first act of “Ode to Joy,” Craig Lucas’s eloquent mess of a play at the Cherry Lane Theater. What occurs is both beautiful and ugly, and ticklingly familiar if you’ve ever bonded with someone in the depths of a shared drunkenness. Or is it heights? Whatever’s going on, it’s intoxicating, in all senses of the word.

headline: Turn Up the Music
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle from Martin Ashwood-Smith may be themeless, but it still has a fair number of references to music.

headline: Timetable Set for Rules on Wheelchair-Accessible Taxicabs
text: Amid concerns that New York City was not moving swiftly enough to make more taxis accessible to the disabled, a federal judge in Manhattan set a timetable on Thursday for the publication of new accessibility rules and a public hearing that is required before they are formally adopted.

headline: A Second Bout of ‘Passion,’ Rawer
text: BERLIN — Bach’s “St. Matthew Passion” is contemplative, a study in suffering and transcendence. His “St. John Passion” is tighter and more angular, a battlefield of action and reaction.

headline: State Department Report Details Suppression of Human Rights Abroad
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department reported Thursday that an increasing number of governments were suppressing political opponents and restricting the freedom of assembly.

headline: Outrage Over Sexist Remarks Turns Into a Political Fund-Raising Tool
text: In the past few months, Republicans have called Wendy Davis, a Democratic candidate for Texas governor, “Abortion Barbie,” likened Alison Lundergan Grimes, a Senate candidate from Kentucky, to an “empty dress,” criticized Hillary Rodham Clinton’s thighs, and referred to a pregnant woman as a “host.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 27, 2014
Post-Filibuster, Obama Faces New Anger Over Judicial Choices
text: WASHINGTON — When Democrats changed Senate rules last year to limit the filibuster against White House nominees, it raised hopes among some liberals that President Obama would use his new power to reshape the federal judiciary. Now, just over three months later, some Democrats and progressive groups are instead trying to stop two of the president’s latest nominees to the federal bench on the grounds that they are too conservative.

headline: Workers at Nuclear Waste Site in New Mexico Inhaled Radioactive Materials
text: WASHINGTON — Thirteen employees who worked the night shift at a nuclear waste burial site in New Mexico after an underground leak are carrying radioactive materials in their bodies, but it is too soon to say how much health risk this poses, Energy Department officials said on Thursday.

headline: For Drivers on Some City Bus Routes, Requesting the $2.50 Fare Can Be Dangerous
text: The crime can seem as innocuous as it is common. Short on cash, a rider slips through the back door of a city bus, skirting the $2.50 fare.

headline: U.S. Prosecutors Interview Christie’s Spokesman
text: One of Gov. Chris Christie’s closest aides was interviewed on Thursday by federal prosecutors seeking to determine whether the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge in September amounted to a crime, the aide’s lawyer said.

headline: Authorities to Seize a Roman Statue in Queens That They Say Was Stolen
text: Federal investigators on Friday plan to seize an ancient Roman sculpture from a Queens warehouse on behalf of Italian officials who say there is evidence the marble statue of a reclining, half-clad woman valued at $4 million was looted from Italy decades ago.

headline: Rangers Still Going Strong (So Are Trade Rumors)
text: Picking up where they left off 20 days ago, the Rangers played their first game after the Olympic break and kept on winning, this time a 2-1 verdict over the defending Stanley Cup champion Chicago Blackhawks. A Rangers team that was streaking in the weeks leading up to the Olympics is streaking still; they are 17-6-1 in their last 24 games.

headline: Missing Out on the Latest Texas Oil Boom, One Town Repurposes Its Leftovers
text: LULING — Down, up. Down, up. Click.

headline: Jim Lange, Genial Host of ‘Dating Game,’ Dies at 81
text: Jim Lange, the original host of “The Dating Game,” the hit TV show that distilled the Swinging Sixties into a potent blend of on-screen matchmaking, jovial innuendo and unstinting Mod aesthetics, died on Tuesday a his home in Mill Valley, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Crimea’s Bloody Past Is a Key to Its Present
text: KIEV, Ukraine — On Thursday, masked gunmen vowing loyalty to Russia seized the Parliament building in Simferopol, the capital of Crimea.

headline: Guitars and Their Different Moods
text: Beverly Maher, the owner of the Guitar Salon, described guitars as being like people, moods and all.

headline: The Young and the Rebellious
text: In the early 1990s, European and American curators and art dealers became aware of African photographs taken in the mid-20th century by the operators of small portrait studios, particularly in Mali. Discovering negatives that had been stored for decades, they went about printing, exhibiting and selling these works, making local photographers like Seydou Keïta and Malick Sidibé international art stars in the process.

headline: No Guitar Is the Same
text: The guitarist Virginia Luque demonstrates the difference in sound between a classic American guitar and one from Britain.

headline: A Place That Plucks Heartstrings
text: On a small, tree-lined street in the West Village, those who know where to look (or those who have made appointments) will find the Guitar Salon, which occupies a parlor-floor apartment in a brownstone built in the 1830s. The only indication of what’s inside is a small black-and-white sign taped next to the buzzer depicting a Bohemian woman in flowing robes plucking at a classical guitar. The guitars are too quiet to be heard from the street.

headline: Dale Gardner, Astronaut Who Helped Corral Wayward Satellites, Dies at 65
text: Dale A. Gardner, an astronaut who helped lead the first salvage operation in space, steering a jet-propelled backpack to corral two wayward satellites and bring them aboard the space shuttle Discovery, all while orbiting 224 miles above Earth, died on Feb. 19 in Colorado Springs. He was 65.

headline: One More Collapse for the Crumbling Knicks
text: MIAMI — Nobody needed Carmelo Anthony to confirm what everyone already knew. But given his uncertain future with the Knicks, his saying it only added to the angst that has gnawed at this team for months.

headline: Nearly Everything Changes (Except the Red Plaid Shirt)
text: There are people in this world who believe the universe is out to get them. And audiences at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn come to know one of the nicest in “The Other Josh Cohen,” that precious rarity, an original low-budget musical with a life-affirming message and songs worth remembering.

headline: South Africa’s Creative Uprising
text: It may be far-flung, but the tip of Africa has been quietly asserting itself as a significant new hub of design talent. And the founders of Southern Guild, a Cape Town-based collective, are doing their part to make sure that the rest of the world notices.

headline: How the Medical Establishment Got the Treasury’s Keys
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: U.S. Militant, Hidden, Spurs Drone Debate
text: WASHINGTON — He is known as Abdullah al-Shami, an Arabic name meaning Abdullah the Syrian. But his nom de guerre masks a reality: He was born in the United States, and the United States is now deciding whether to kill him.

headline: Irish Musicians to Play ‘Danny Boy’ and Much More
text: When Sharon Corr,  a singer-songwriter, appears at the Y.M.C.A. Boulton Center for the Performing Arts in Bay Shore on March 16, she will include a number of traditional Irish songs — “really lovely ones,” including “Cooley’s Reel” and “Mna Na hEireann,” she said during a recent phone interview from Los Angeles, where she was doing a show late last month. Ms. Corr, of Dublin, will also perform songs intended to appeal to fans who don’t automatically associate her name with her heritage.

headline: With Moments of Tenderness and ‘Ungrandmotherliness’
text: When her doorbell rings in the middle of the night, Vera Joseph doesn’t hear it at first. She isn’t wearing her hearing aid. When she communicates with the person on the other side of the door (Leo, her 21-year-old grandson), he can’t understand her because she doesn’t have her teeth in. Vera, one of the two central characters in Amy Herzog’s play “4000 Miles,” which had its opening night on Wednesday at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, may not seem like the firebrand midcentury American Communist she used to be, but no one should see her as a stereotypical little 91-year-old lady either.

headline: A Parting Shot at U.S. Ambassador, Inspired by Mao
text: The departing United States ambassador, Gary F. Locke, gave a farewell news conference in Beijing on Thursday, at which he praised the deepening economic ties between the world’s two biggest economies and urged China and Japan to cool down escalating tensions over a territorial dispute.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 9 P.M. (13) JAZZ AND THE PHILHARMONIC In this concert inspired by Jazz at the Philharmonic, a four-decade series of performances produced by Norman Granz starting in 1944, four arts organizations — the National YoungArts Foundation, the Phillip and Patricia Frost School of Music at the University of Miami, the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts of Miami-Dade County, and Jazz Roots: A Larry Rosen Jazz Series — join forces to spotlight YoungArts alumni and mentors. Performers include the vocalist Bobby McFerrin (above), the pianist Chick Corea, the pianist and composer Dave Grusin, the trumpeter Terence Blanchard, the violinist Mark O’Connor, the opera bass-baritione Eric Owens, the classical pianist Elizabeth Joy Roe, the choreographer and dancer Desmond Richardson, the pianist Shelly Berg, and the Henry Mancini Institute Orchestra, conducted by Scott Flavin. In Karen Goodman and Kirk Simon’s “Becoming an Artist,” at 10:30, Bill T. Jones, Frank Gehry, Mikhail Baryshnikov, Raúl Esparza, John Guare, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Mr. Owens, Rosie Perez, Robert Redford, James Rosenquist and Kathleen Turner discuss the art of the mentor and their roles within YoungArts.

headline: You’ve Got Meal (a Note, Too)
text: “‘The Lunchbox,’ Ritesh Batra’s debut feature, is a romance that takes place in Mumbai, but its style is more Hollywood than Bollywood, and Old Hollywood at that,” A.O. Scott of The New York Times wrote in his movie review.

headline: Crash That Kills Schoolgirls Highlights Thai Road Dangers
text: BANGKOK — A week after the release of a study concluding that Thailand has the world’s second-highest road fatality rate, a bus carrying schoolgirls on a class trip to the beach collided with a truck on a provincial highway early Friday, killing 15 people and providing a grim corroboration of the study’s findings.

headline: Special Night for Collins, and a Win for the Nets
text: DENVER — Jason Collins trotted onto the court with 8 minutes 2 seconds left in the fourth quarter Thursday night, the way he had done many times during his 13-year N.B.A. career.

headline: Ousted Ukrainian Leader, Reappearing in Russia, Says, ‘Nobody Deposed Me’
text: ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia — Viktor F. Yanukovych, the ousted president of Ukraine, appealed for calm on Friday and rejected separatism or forcible intervention from abroad, even by Russia, where he has taken refuge.

headline: With Military Moves Seen in Ukraine, Obama Warns Russia
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s fragile new government accused Russia of trying to provoke a military conflict by invading the Crimea region on Friday, while in Washington President Obama issued a stern warning to the Kremlin about respecting Ukraine’s sovereignty, in an effort to preclude a full-scale military escalation.

headline: Crackdown on Baby Trafficking Zeros In on Websites
text: The Chinese police have broken up four online baby-selling rings and rescued 382 infants in an operation aimed at curbing a trend toward highly organized, Internet-based baby trafficking, news media outlets in Beijing reported Friday.

headline: ‘Somebody That Nobody Thought I Could Be’
text: When someone on the Academy Awards broadcast on Sunday announces the nominees for best documentary short subject, a lot of viewers will head to the kitchen to refill the Cheetos bowl.

headline: Do You Pay Attention to Nutrition Labels on Food?
text: Nutrition labels weren’t required on packaged foods in the United States until the 1990s. Now they are a familiar sight that many of us take for granted — or even ignore.

headline: Invincible Looks on City Streets
text: One afternoon in 1983, the photographer Amy Arbus spotted a woman walking down St. Marks Place in Manhattan wearing a stained overcoat and using a bowling ball bag as an improvised purse. Ms. Arbus photographed the woman, Madonna Ciccone, who mentioned that she was still wearing her pajamas. Yet Ms. Arbus noted that she was also wearing makeup.

headline: Euro Zone Inflation Stays Low; Joblessness Remains High
text: PARIS — Inflation in the euro zone remained stuck at a very low level in February, while the jobless rate was unchanged in January, official reports showed on Friday, providing the European Central Bank with crucial data before its monetary policy meeting next week.

headline: British Airways Parent Returns to Profitability
text: PARIS — International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways, said Friday that it swung to a net profit last year, reaping the gains of deep cost-cutting and heavy job reductions at its money-losing Spanish unit, Iberia.

headline: New York Today: Seeking the Homeless
text: Good ice-cold Friday to you. The mercury is in the teens. The wind chill is near zero.

headline: The End of the ‘Developing World’
text: BILL GATES, in his foundation’s annual letter, declared that “the terms ‘developing countries’ and ‘developed countries’ have outlived their usefulness.” He’s right. If we want to understand the modern global economy, we need a better vocabulary.

headline: A Conversation With: Kalvakuntla Taraka Rama Rao, Telangana Leader
text: Kalvakuntla Taraka Rama Rao, an Andhra Pradesh assembly legislator and senior leader of the Telangana Rashtra Samithi party, is the son of Kalvakuntla Chandrasekhar Rao, the party’s president, who is also considered the architect and driving force behind the successful petition for a separate Telangana state, which will be carved out of Andhra Pradesh.

headline: What You Learn in Your 40s
text: PARIS — IF all goes according to plan, I’ll turn 44 soon after this column appears. So far in my adult life, I’ve never managed to grasp a decade’s main point until long after it was over. It turns out that I wasn’t supposed to spend my 20s frantically looking for a husband; I should have been building my career and enjoying my last gasp of freedom. I then spent my 30s ruminating on grievances accumulated in my 20s.

headline: Court Orders House Arrest, and No Internet, for Fierce Critic of Putin
text: MOSCOW — Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s leading opposition figure, was placed under house arrest on Friday and ordered not to use the Internet or telephone for two months, thus removing President Vladimir V. Putin’s fiercest critic from public life.

headline: North Dakota Leads on the Road to Recovery
text: SIX years after the recession began, the United States has yet to return to where it was by any of three measures of economic activity: jobs, highway miles driven or house prices. That makes this business cycle unique among recent cycles — within four years of the recessions that began in 1981, 1990 and 2001, each of those indicators was up substantially.

text: Ukraine’s ousted president, Viktor Yanukovych, made his first public appearance in a week on Friday, telling journalists in the Russian city of Rostov-on-Don that he remains in office, as our colleague Steven Lee Myers reports.

The Tokyo-based exchange halted trading earlier this week.

headline: Daily Report: Mt. Gox, Having Lost Essentially All Bitcoins, Files for Bankruptcy
text: Mt. Gox, the troubled exchange for the virtual currency Bitcoin, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers’ coins, essentially all of them, in a hacking attack, Hiroko Tabuchi reports from Tokyo.

I will also become a distinguished scholar at the Graduate Center’s Luxembourg Income Study Center. You can read all about it in the Graduate Center’s announcement.

headline: Japan to Revisit Apology to Wartime Sex Slaves

headline: Listen Up | Will Owen Pallett Win an Academy Award This Sunday?
text: “It’s been a really crazy, busy week,” Owen Pallett exclaimed as he returned Tuesday from Haiti, where he was performing with his frequent collaborators, Arcade Fire. A maverick virtuoso of the violin, as well as an in-demand composer and arranger, Pallett is now back in Los Angeles to attend a “private, Oscar-y dinner” with the likes of Burt Bacharach, Randy Newman and John Williams. The event is tied to his recent Academy Award nomination for best original score, which Pallett shares with Arcade Fire for their work on the soundtrack to Spike Jonze’s acclaimed film “Her.” “I’m going to get a haircut,” he said. “I don’t know how else to prep to meet my big hero, Burt Bacharach. It’s kind of strange and disorienting, all that’s happening. It’s not something I’ve been thirsting for my entire life.”

Those in Philadelphia are in luck: At Little Nonna’s, a cozy restaurant that opened in September in Center City, the family-style “Sunday gravy” is served every night of the week.

headline: On the Beach, on the Cheap, in Mozambique
text: An hour up the sand from the little beach town of Tofo, perched on a peninsula jutting off the southern coast of Mozambique on a bay of gently surfable Indian Ocean waves, I met five children who had never heard of pizza.

headline: Fast Acquittal for Kennedy, Whose Name Put Prosecutors in Bind
text: WHITE PLAINS — After nearly 20 months of celebrity theater and an incalculable amount of effort and courtroom expense, the misdemeanor trial of Kerry Kennedy ended on Friday in breakneck fashion, as jurors took one hour to find her not guilty of driving under the influence of a drug: a sleeping pill that she said she took by accident.

text: The psychedelic folk singer Linda Perhacs discusses her hiatus; a little stubble goes a long way; the Meh List takes on the Oscars.
