headline: Nursing-Home Pitfalls
text: I am an advocate for nursing-home residents. A new technique to control the wandering of dementia patients involves placing black floor mats in front of unsafe areas, such as outside exits. Due to a fear of falling, persons with dementia will not walk on dark spaces on the floor (they tend to see them as holes). This is an alternative to antipsychotic drugs and lockdown units. Since this technique uses fear and a disability to guide behavior, but with the intent of safety, is it ethical? LISA MARIE HAYES, HOUSTON

headline: The Brilliant, Unnerving Meta-Marketing of ‘The Lego Movie’
text: Princess Leia and Harry Potter are dining in the eat-in kitchen of their midcentury modern home, sunshine bouncing off the white floors and refracting through the enormous aquarium that separates the kitchen from the den. “I need more pink tiles for my dining room!” their neighbor Hermione calls from her rainbow-colored split-level ranch home next door, which boasts three patios and two hot tubs.

headline: The Last, Disposable Action Hero
text: When the screenwriter David Hayter conceived the idea for “Wolves,” his directorial debut, he wanted to make a coming-of-age drama that he describes as “ ‘Twilight’ with a bit more bite to it — and without abstinence.” His script focused on a high-school football-star-slash-werewolf who skips town after his parents are gruesomely murdered and eventually comes to blows with a man-eating alpha dog. Hayter just needed to find the perfect young werewolf, and he settled on a relatively unknown actor named Lucas Till as the lead. “I thought of Lucas because I felt this movie was about a kid on the verge of adulthood,” said Hayter, who also wrote the screenplays for “Watchmen” and “X-Men.” “And this is the story that takes him over the brink.”

headline: Battle of the Kites
text: There is perhaps no event more anticipated in Gujarat, a state in India’s northwest, than the International Kite Festival every January. Residents prepare for months, making kites in bright colors, using elaborate designs that have been passed down for generations. On the main day of the festival, people get up before dawn to fly their kites from rooftops and, with any luck, cut down competing kites. (Some kite strings have been dipped in an emulsion that includes finely ground glass.) When a participant successfully downs another kite, a small trumpet sounds a victory blast. The festival, which is celebrated at the end of the mild Indian winter, when daytime temperatures hover in the 80s, is tied to a traditional day on the Hindu calendar that marks the change of seasons. “Flying a kite brings good luck and good fortune in the new year,” says Tobias Hutzler, who captured images of the festival. “They are sending wishes into the air.” Julie Bosman

headline: ‘The Bachelor’ Host Chris Harrison: ‘I Know Why You’re All Single’
text: You’ve been hosting “The Bachelor” and “The Bachelorette” for a combined 27 seasons. Are you surprised how long the show has lasted? Absolutely. It started back in 2002, when there was hardly any reality television. “Survivor” had just started. My hope and dream was that “The Bachelor” would last one or two nights on network TV, so I might meet somebody in the network and then I could get a real job.

headline: Who Made That Antiperspirant?
text: The week after Christmas in 1916, a dermatologist in Illinois published a cure for sweating. An abundance of perspiration — or “hyperhidrosis,” as doctors call it — could lead to emotional pain and discomfort, and “the knowledge that an unpleasant odor clings to one makes the sensitive person dread to meet others.” In an era in which some patients were dosed with X-rays for their sweating, Arthur W. Stillians offered something seemingly revolutionary: the under-arm application of an aluminum-chloride cream three times over the course of a week. “In 20 cases in which I have used this lotion, it has never failed to give relief,” he claimed in a prestigious medical journal.

headline: Thousands of Bill Clinton White House Papers Released
text: WASHINGTON — She wooed Republicans in Congress while bristling at the national news media. She aspired to be a pioneer of women’s rights around the world while running a full-blown war room on health care at home. She was, in her staff’s view, often too defensive, too removed in public.

headline: Need Help on Your Ballot?

But as the Bagger writes here, it’s been “an unusually competitive Oscar race for best picture, with even the most-seasoned pundits, the kind who can spot the leader weeks out, changing their minds in the days before Sunday’s show, pleading confusion.”

headline: Ditch the Snow Shovel
text: As heavy, wet snow blanketed New York City last month and then quickly turned to slush, the sidewalks in front of some luxury apartment buildings remained pristine. As if by magic, snowflakes melted as they touched the ground in front of these upscale addresses, releasing a faint vapor that hung momentarily in the bitter cold before vanishing altogether, thanks to what is turning out to be the ultimate amenity in an unrelenting winter: heated sidewalks.

text: Hosting the Academy Awards ceremony can bring glory or infamy. After missteps in recent years, Oscars producers are returning to safer middle ground with the selection of Ellen DeGeneres.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Husband-Hunting in the Raj’
text: This week, Alida Becker and Nick Reding.

headline: Writers on the Left
text: LILLIAN HELLMAN

headline: Using Skype to Build a Business
text: In October 2012, David Greenberg was operating a thriving tutoring business, Parliament Tutors, when Hurricane Sandy hit. Suddenly, Mr. Greenberg started getting emails from tutors saying they were unable to meet with clients who had already purchased packages for the SAT, which was just two weeks away.

headline: Paperback Row
text: AFTER THE MUSIC STOPPED: The Financial Crisis, the Response, and the Work Ahead,  by Alan S. Blinder. (Penguin, $17.) This comprehensive history of the 2008 meltdown, one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2013, says that it was the result of a “perfect storm” of events, from the bursting of the housing bubble to the financial implosion that followed the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers. Blinder, a former Fed vice chairman, is critical of both the Bush and Obama administrations, but he also praises them for taking steps to save the country from falling into a serious depression.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: BARK: Stories,  by Lorrie Moore. (Knopf, $24.95.) The uncrowded format of Moore’s first collection in 16 years allows each story the chance it deserves for leisurely appreciation and lets the reader savor just what makes her work unique.

headline: Inside the List
text: Building Blocks: There’s a sweet moment in “All Joy and No Fun,” Jennifer Senior’s smart new look at modern parenting (it’s at No. 16 after three weeks on the hardcover nonfiction list), in which Clint Holder, one of the fathers Senior shadowed, shows his older son how to assemble a Lego ice-cream truck. “Here, let me help,” he says: “You put this thing on the back of it.” Watching him snap the pieces together, Senior observes that Clint “plumps with life, like a diabetic who’s finally been handed a sucking candy.” Then he notices her noticing him, and offers a sheepish-sounding explanation: “I’m biased about Legos,” he says. “They’re what I played with when I was little.” The scene will resonate with anybody who’s watched “The Lego Movie” — half of America, in other words — which likewise features a father passionate about his Lego creations. (The movie’s success has spilled over onto the best-seller list; a junior novelization, “Lego, the Lego Movie,” remains at No. 3 in its fifth week on the children’s middle-grade list.)

headline: Sparks of Life
text: The heroine of Marcel Theroux’s previous novel, “Far North,” was an intrepid survivor named Makepeace who scavenged books from the ruins of a post-­apocalyptic Manhattan, but showed little interest in actually reading them. “A person is always better than a book,” she reasoned.

headline: Madness Most Discreet
text: Near the end of Kem Nunn’s crafty new novel, the title character, a 49-year-old San Francisco psychiatrist named Eldon Chance, confesses to feeling a persistent sense of “vertigo, attributable no doubt to the sudden, simultaneous rush of so many large ideas.” That diagnosis, like so many of Dr. Chance’s, is both entirely plausible and hilariously wrong.

headline: Passages to India
text: In 1671, the East India Company sent 20 single women to Bombay, each supplied with an allowance of £300, a new set of clothing and a simple directive — to find a company-approved mate within a year. “In those early days,” Anne de Courcy remarks, “marriage was often undertaken with the sort of rapidity usually confined to spotting a business opportunity and pouncing on it.” But as she follows the long history of what came to be known as the fishing fleet, which supplied a steady cargo of potential brides to generations of expats, it seems clear that the official coupling of a man and a woman in British India, despite an often hastily applied gloss of romance, continued to be conducted in distinctly commercial style. By the 19th century, potential wives were paying a bond of £200 for the privilege of sailing off to a strange land to ally themselves with a virtual stranger. And pity the poor soul who — despite a ratio of three or four men to every woman, inspiring tales of proposals offered at funerals and engagements announced as husbands lay dying — failed to drag the humblest prospect to the altar. Put on a ship back to England, she would now be dismissed as one of the “Returned Empties.”

headline: The Unvanquished
text: In 2011, writing in the Book Review about a memoir by Binyavanga Wainaina, ­Alexandra Fuller opened with a marvelous plea: “Harried reader, I’ll save you precious time. Skip this review and head directly to the bookstore.”

headline: Five Years Later, an Over-the-Top Wall Street Blog Returns
text: Like many in the fall of 2008, Amit Chatwani was done. Lehman Brothers had collapsed, the government had bailed out the American International Group, and the financial system was in chaos.

headline: Days of the Dead
text: “On our mountain only boys were born,” Ladydi Garcia Martínez tells us in the opening pages of Jennifer Clement’s new novel, “Prayers for the Stolen,” “and some of them turned into girls around the age of 11.” Rather than a tale of transgender magic realism, however, this is the story of a young Mexican girl who grows up in a rural mountain community in the Pacific state of Guerrero — “a land of red insects and women” — not far from Acapulco. Although named after Diana, Princess of Wales — the “saint for betrayed women” — Ladydi is called “Boy” by her mother, Rita. Turning girls into boys — or at least making them ugly — is a matter of survival on the mountain. Girls get short haircuts at the “ugly parlor”; Ladydi even colors her teeth with black and yellow markers to make them look rotted. “All the drug traffickers had to do was hear that there was a pretty girl around,” she says, “and they’d sweep onto our lands in black Escalades and carry the girl off.”

headline: A Body in the Snow
text: The violent murder of a young innocent underpins Andrea Portes’s second novel, “Bury This.” Beth Krause is the victim in a 1978 case that is revitalized in 2003, when a group of film students starts to make a documentary of her life. The question posed by one of them is: “If 25 years can discover the Internet, the cellphone, this thing the iPod, can 25 years discover the secret of a girl murdered, abandoned, by the side of the road?” But the question at the heart of “Bury This” isn’t about the possibilities brought by advances in forensic science but about the possibilities of language in the face of the ugliest truths.

headline: Willkommen
text: Among the trophies of the Second World War captured by Allied intelligence agents were Nazi scientists and their research on biological and chemical weapons. In a classified memorandum titled “Exploitation of German Scientists in Science and Technology in the United States,” the Joint Chiefs of Staff described these men as “chosen, rare minds whose continuing intellectual productivity we wish to use.” Such intellectual spoils were not to fall into Soviet hands. In 1945, Operation Overcast (renamed Operation Paperclip for the paper clips attached to the dossiers of the most “troublesome cases”) began. More than 1,600 Germans were secretly recruited to develop armaments “at a feverish and paranoid pace that came to define the Cold War.”

headline: Bleak Houses
text: If anyone can make you root for the murderer, it’s Denise Mina, whose defiantly unsentimental novels are less concerned with personal guilt than with the social evils that create criminals and the predators who nurture them. THE RED ROAD (Little, Brown, $26), as fierce a story as any Mina has written, opens in 1997 with a shocking double murder in a seedy section of Glasgow. The murderer gives up without a fight, and that, you’d think, should be that — except for the fact that the killer, Rose Wilson, is a 14-year-old prostitute (“looking 16, feeling 12”) and one of the men she stabbed to death was the pimp who had hired her out to service eight men.

headline: Girlfish
text: Alice Hoffman has always celebrated the marvelousness of what’s real in the world, even as she creates the distinctive atmosphere of uncanniness and magical potential that looms over her fiction. Her devoted readers expect melodramatic stories imbued with the atmosphere of folk tales. Omens and portents are her stock in trade. Feminist themes and generous amounts of Renaissance Faire-style potted history make her storytelling all the more suggestive. Eerie and powerful acts of nature signify undercurrents of mood the way irregular minor chords in the background music tell us how to feel during ominous scenes at the movies. Lost in a dark forest of one kind or another, Hoffman’s characters have a heightened awareness of the hidden meanings that surround them as they struggle toward the light.

headline: There Goes the Judge
text: Poor Judge Crater. Famous for decades after his mysterious disappearance in 1930, he’s mostly forgotten today, long ago replaced in the cultural consciousness (and joke book) by Jimmy Hoffa. But good crime stories don’t stay buried, and Ariel Lawhon’s new novel, “The Wife, the Maid, and the Mistress,” digs up the case of the so-called Missingest Man in New York and feasts on its bones.

headline: Strong, Silent Types
text: Short-story collections might be divided into two groups. One is the hodgepodge, the mixtape, the gathering together of stray parts from here and there. D. W. Wilson’s “Once You Break a Knuckle” keeps a rarer company — the collection in which the stories are in conversation, and together form a world to be explored not linearly but sideways, more than once, through previously unexplored corridors and secret passageways hiding in plain sight. These books, by design, are echo chambers of empathy. The world is large, they seem to say, and it is full of other people whose lives are as important to themselves as mine is to me and yours is to you. Look around.

headline: In Our Pages: March 1
text: 1914: Disease Follows Snowfall

headline: Director of Boston’s Museum of Fine Arts to Retire
text: After 19 years as director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Malcolm Rogers said on Thursday that he plans to retire as soon as the board has named a successor.

headline: Just Say Nein
text: Joachim Fest’s fascinating memoir about what it was like to come of age during the years of the Third Reich is unusual because its central character is not the author but the author’s remarkable father. Johannes Fest was the middle-class headmaster of a primary school in suburban Berlin, a pious Catholic and father of five, a cultural conservative who revered Goethe and Kant, and a loyal German patriot — “a dyed-in-the-wool Prussian,” in Fest’s words — the kind of person who might have been expected to become an active supporter of Adolf Hitler and the National Socialists. In a foreword by Herbert Arnold (a professor emeritus of German studies at Wesleyan University who has also supplied informative notes throughout the text), the elder Fest is described as “tailor-made for a career” with the Nazis. And yet some quirk in his personality made him a fierce Weimar republican, ready to sacrifice himself, even his family, to principles he knew to be right even as everyone around him was yielding to mass hysteria. “Not I,” a best seller in Germany when it appeared in 2006, the year of the author’s death at age 79, is a memorable tale of lonely courage, stoic endurance, self-imposed hardship and a life lived amid ubiquitous, all-­encompassing danger: “Even ­innocent-sounding remarks could be life-and-death matters.” It reminds us that simple human decency is possible even in the most trying of ­circumstances.

headline: A reading of “Dear Spring” by Charles Simic
text: The Pulitzer Prize-winning poet reads his ode to spring.

headline: Raf Simons Designs a Dynamic Dior
text: PARIS — Taut tailoring, but for a feminine body — that was the message at Dior, where the designer Raf Simons reached down to his deep men’s wear fashion roots and made his collection bloom for the French house.

headline: Times Minute | Yanukovych Emerges
text: Viktor F. Yanukovych, the ousted Ukrainian president, made his first public appearance since disappearing a week ago. Also on the Minute, challenges for Oscar hosts and the origin of antiperspirants.

headline: Now May Be a Good Time to Bail Out of Frequent-Flier Programs
text: Fly one mile, get one frequent-flier mile in return.

headline: Times Minute | Yanukovych Emerges
text: In the Video

headline: Oscar Hosts and the Academy’s Dilemma
text: As host of the Oscars and of her own daytime talk show, Ellen DeGeneres has been making the most of cross-promotional opportunities this awards season. That sets her apart from the typical Academy M.C., but in other ways she represents a safe choice for the organization, which may have felt gun-shy after turns by Seth MacFarlane and James Franco. Here’s the Times’s chief television critic, Alessandra Stanley, explaining the Academy’s thinking when it comes to choosing Oscar hosts over the years.

headline: Paris Fall 2014: Elements | Texture
text: A thematic visual diary of Paris Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.

headline: Talking Talent | Around the World with Chelsea Handler
text: The best-selling author Chelsea Handler, host of E!’s corrosively hilarious late-night talk show “Chelsea Lately,” is back with a collection of travel essays titled “Uganda Be Kidding Me” (Grand Central Publishing, out March 4). In it, Handler recalls injuring herself (sometimes) and drinking too much (often) while laughing her way across the globe (always) alongside her merry pack of female travel companions. With her beloved brand of self-deprecating wit, she takes the reader from a safari in South Africa to a weekend of skiing in the Swiss Alps — chronicling every airport nightmare and downright dirty encounter along the way. Here, she discusses the process of writing the book, as well as “ugly babies,” her “lesbian roommate” and the delicate art of comedy.

headline: Wendy Whelan’s Renovated Rental
text: The New York City Ballet principal Wendy Whelan lives with her husband, David Michalek, on a skinny stretch of the Upper West Side that’s known among insiders as the dance belt. Since coming to Manhattan from Louisville more than 30 years ago to train at the School of American Ballet, Ms. Whelan has moved from rental to rental but has never moved out of the neighborhood.

headline: Facts & Figures: Interracial Marriage vs. Same-Sex Marriage
text: First year Gallup found that a majority of Americans thought same-sex marriage should be legal: 2011

headline: Yanukovych Speaks Out After Ouster
text: Viktor F. Yanukovich appeared in public for the first time since he was ousted as Ukraine's president. He spoke in Russian and said he will not give up the fight for his country's future.

headline: At the RSA Security Conference, Things Get Testy and Then They Get Awkward
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It was hard to avoid the shadow of Edward J. Snowden at the annual RSA security conference this week.

headline: A Blockbuster Landed in Their Laps
text: Marvel Entertainment has a history of entrusting its superhero blockbusters to offbeat directors, but the brothers Russo may take the cape.

headline: The Envelopes Please
text: Other than best picture, what is the most important Oscar category?

headline: What’s It All About?
text: Father-daughter memoirs have an inherent appeal, especially when the father and daughter are on an almost preposterous quest. There’s such a quest in “Trespassing on Einstein’s Lawn”: to uncover the nature of reality. It all began when Warren Gefter, a radiologist “prone to posing Zen-koan-like questions,” asked his 15-year-old daughter, Amanda, over dinner at a Chinese restaurant near their home just outside Philadelphia: “How would you define nothing?”

headline: Big Ticket | Cityscape Views for $12 Million
text: A sponsor unit at 737 Park Avenue, an Art Deco-style brick-and-limestone apartment building acquired by Macklowe Properties and the CIM Group in 2011 and since converted to 60 luxury condominiums, sold for $12,057,366.08 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The monthly carrying costs are $6,720.68.

headline: Yanukovych Speaks Out After Ouster
text: Viktor F. Yanukovych appeared in public for the first time since he was ousted as Ukraine’s president. He spoke in Russian and said he would not give up the fight for his country’s future.

headline: Fed Searches for a New Method of Offering Guidance
text: Updated, 10:25 p.m. | The Federal Reserve is struggling to redefine the central element of its economic stimulus campaign, its plans for short-term interest rates.

headline: Image of the Day: February 28
text: Virat Kohli, an Indian cricketer, being bowled out during a one-day international match between India and Sri Lanka at Fatullah, Bangladesh.

headline: In Miami Beach, a Concierge for Daytime Activities
text: Miami may be known for its pulsing night life but the Surfcomber is hoping to shake things up a bit. The 186-room hotel in Miami Beach recently created a “director of daylife” position with the purpose of helping guests maximize their time before the sun sets.

headline: A Scorecard on Jos. A. Bank’s Latest Moves
text: “I wish I knew how to quit you.”

headline: Highlights From the Clinton Documents
text: The National Archives made public on Friday afternoon a trove of secret documents detailing the inner workings of Bill Clinton’s White House, a disclosure of acute interest not just to the history of one presidency but to the prospects of another. Thousands of pages of internal memos and papers offered insights into Mr. Clinton’s decisions, as well as the role his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, may have played in shaping them. Times reporters posted standout passages and analysis below.

headline: Geneva Motor Show to Showcase Extreme Opulence
text: Green can be found in many hues at an auto show: green, as in environmentally friendly; green, as in the color of envy over all the new cars. But at the Geneva auto show, green is really about the color of money.

headline: Kosovo Gets a Real Game, if It Can Assemble a Team
text: After six years of rejection, cajoling, schmoozing, direct action and, finally, acceptance, Eroll Salihu is at last organizing a game that counts.

headline: Back to Basics on Corporate Apologies
text: Lawrence S. Spiegel is a partner in the government enforcement and white-collar crime group of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom in New York and general counsel of the firm.

headline: Nick Bollettieri’s Age: 82. His Vision for Tennis Talent: 20/20.
text: BRADENTON, Fla. — The first surprise upon arrival was to see Nick Bollettieri wearing a shirt.

headline: Will Someone Please Make a Better Online Calendar?
text: Over the last few days I’ve been using a promising new calendar program called Magneto. The app was created by a start-up whose founders have put a lot of thought into how people use online calendars, and it addresses several shortcomings found in other digital organizers.

headline: Plans for a Restaurant in Union Square Park Move Ahead
text: After years of legal battles, a plan to open a seasonal restaurant in the recently restored neo-Classical arch and colonnade that anchors the north end of Union Square Park is back on track. Barring any other bureaucratic roadblock, the restaurant, to be named the Pavilion, would open in June.

headline: Hard Life for a von Trier Woman, Again
text: Fifteen years ago, Catherine Deneuve reflected in her journal on filming the unorthodox musical “Dancer in the Dark” (2000) with Björk and the director Lars von Trier. Tensions ran high on the demanding shoot. But despite fierce creative differences and psychological stress on all sides, Björk saw her feature-acting debut, as a single mother going blind who faces the death penalty, to its conclusion. And Ms. Deneuve couldn’t figure out why.

headline: GrubHub Files for an I.P.O.
text: GrubHub is already well known to the masses of office workers who rely on the company’s online food ordering services. Now it is hoping that investors are just as eager for what on its plate.

headline: Sonia Rykiel: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Ash Spill Shows How Watchdog Was Defanged
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — Last June, state employees in charge of stopping water pollution were given updated marching orders on behalf of North Carolina’s new Republican governor and conservative lawmakers.

headline: Aftermath of Coal Ash Pond Rupture
text: An animated graphic by the Center for Energy, Environment and Sustainability at Wake Forest University shows the aftermath of the coal ash pond rupture at Duke Energy’s Dan River Steam Station.

headline: Casting Shadows on a Fanciful World
text: Imagine you could pry off the back of Wes Anderson’s head as if it were a vintage TV set and rummage around inside. What would you find there? A mind like a junk drawer crammed with kite string, Swiss Army knives and remote-controlled toys, or one that springs open as neatly as a well-organized tackle box? A memory palace assembled ad hoc from brownstone apartments, underground caves and submarine compartments, or a diligently designed, continuously flowing and elegant old Alpine resort?

headline: Butternut Squash With Polenta
text: Cooked together slowly, squash and polenta serve as a sweet and silky bed for caramelized onions and savory sausage.

headline: Toronto’s Ethnic Buffet
text: When I tell my friends in Toronto how much I love their city, they often say, “Really?” I always assume they imagine I’m just trying to be gracious, or perhaps — with characteristic Canadian modesty — they’re reluctant to acknowledge how easy their city is to love. But they also have a great deal of justifiable civic pride, and a clear sense of why Toronto is such a special and unusual place to live and visit. There’s more to this understated city than many people might realize.

headline: Christian Dior: Fall 2014 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Polenta’s Journey From Fancy to Familiar
text: When polenta first hit the food scene in the United States, it was the kind of delicacy that graced the likes of only Italian specialty food shops and high-end restaurants.

headline: Finding a Setting That Captures a Scene
text: Wes Anderson’s films are best known for their eccentric characters and rigorously whimsical tone. But just as distinctively captured are their settings. Think of the colors and textures of the Indian landscapes in “The Darjeeling Limited,” for example, or the lovingly rendered Mediterranean locations in “The Life Aquatic With Steve Zissou.”

headline: The Pasta Is Gluten-Free
text: Every so often I like to do a small roundup of gluten-free pasta products, to see if there is anything new and noteworthy on the market. This week was a good time to do it, as I’m in New York staying with my sister Melodie, who is gluten-intolerant. Melodie used to eat a lot of rice pasta until she became concerned with reports about arsenic in rice. It is cold in New York and we are mourning the death of our 95-year-old mother, and this calls for comfort food. So I went shopping for gluten-free pasta that was not made primarily with rice flour, and put my purchases to good use.

headline: For Coke, Challenge Is Staying Relevant
text: Can this brand be saved?

headline: Apollo Chief Questions Effort to Limit Banks’ Exposure to Buyout Deals
text: Leon D. Black, the head of Apollo Global Management, questioned the wisdom of a regulatory effort to limit the ability of banks to finance risky buyout deals.

headline: A Maelstrom of Fraud Without Early Warning
text: Not for the first time, Citigroup has stepped into a mess – and by extension besmirched the financial industry. Not that Citigroup committed a crime, or colluded to set foreign exchange rates or Libor prices, say. Rather, the bank is the victim of fraud in Mexico that could cost it much as $400 million. The problem is that the lender has been cheated out of the cash in one of the most basic businesses in banking. That should worry Citigroup’s rivals, too.

headline: Putin's Foe Placed Under House Arrest
text: A Russian court placed the opposition leader Aleksei Navalny under house arrest. Mr. Navalny, a critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, said the ruling was baseless.

headline: Deadly Bus Crash in Thailand
text: Watch scenes from a deadly bus crash in the eastern Prachin Buri province of Thailand.

headline: Popcast: The Radical Happiness of Pharrell
text: This week, Jon Caramanica and I examine the producer, songwriter and singer Pharrell Williams, whose radically airy, upbeat second solo album, “G I R L,” is to be released next week in a modified version of a Beyoncé-style sudden drop. (It will arrive two days after his performance on the Academy Awards telecast.)

headline: In Kentucky, a Family at the Center of the Earth
text: Jerry Bransford remembers the short day trips his family used to make to Mammoth Cave, half an hour away from their home in Glasgow, Ky. His father would tell him stories about how his family first came to know the cave as slaves but eventually became famous guides, starting a legacy that would last four generations. He grew up wanting to feel what it would be like to walk in the shoes of these men, whose renown had faded with time.

headline: Wheelies: The Legal Navigation Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Countering Israel Boycotts, With Glamour
text: WASHINGTON — Scarlett Johansson politely declined an invitation to speak to the 14,000 people gathering here Sunday for the annual meeting of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac, as the nation’s most powerful pro-Israel lobbying group is known.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Bulkier Brows, Harry Brant’s Runway Moment and Dries Van Noten’s Curator Cameo
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: ‘A Trip to Mammoth Cave, Ky.’
text: In 1864, James Fowler Rusling, a Union soldier and abolitionist, published a pamphlet recounting his experiences in the cave as well as an interview he conducted with Materson Bransford, the slave who served as his guide.

headline: Pictures of the Year: Finding Stories Everywhere
text: Barbara Davidson of the Los Angeles Times was named newspaper photographer of the year in the 2013 Pictures of the Year International competition. Daniel Berehulak of Reportage by Getty Images took the title of freelance/agency photographer of the year. Most of the images in Mr. Berehulak’s winning portfolio were made on assignment for the New York Times. Pictures of the Year International is a program of the Donald W. Reynolds Journalism Institute at the Missouri School of Journalism.

text: The prolific writer reads his poem.

text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Fatal Assistance."

headline: You Can Look, but You Can’t Check In
text: While “The Grand Budapest Hotel” is busy with smaller design elements, one of its most striking designs is the hotel itself. Outfitted in shades of pink and purple and situated atop a hill, the hotel is grandiose and picturesque. It also happens to be nine feet tall. For wide shots of the hotel, the director Wes Anderson and his team decided to use a handmade miniature model.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The White Album
text: The popularity of white outerwear this winter has been a perfect match for this particularly snowy season.

headline: Look & Listen Music Festival to Spread to Brooklyn
text: Organizers of the Look & Listen Festival, which makes a point of presenting an eclectic slate of new music concerts in galleries and other spaces where the performers and audiences are surrounded by contemporary visual art, said on Friday that it will offer performances in Brooklyn for the first time since it was founded in 2002. As in past years, the festival is short – this year’s runs for a week and includes four concerts – but each program includes two or three ensembles or soloists, an arrangement more typical in pop than in classical music.

headline: In Performance: Mark Padmore
text: The tenor Mark Padmore performs the prologue from Britten’s “Billy Budd.”

headline: Saying Thank You in 45 Seconds
text: One of the more influential cultural mainstays to emerge from Hollywood in the last 50 years may be the most maligned: the Oscar acceptance speech. Though often mocked, these high-stakes odes to self-regard, faux humility, stress management and careful planning (or lack thereof) are actually extremely revealing, even career defining. And their impact extends far beyond Oscar night. What happens in Hollywood doesn’t stay in Hollywood but shapes every award celebration, from the most valuable player of the office softball team to the best apple pie at the bake-off.

headline: Rice University to Demolish Former Museum Building
text: Rice University in Houston plans to demolish its Martel Center building, originally the Rice Museum, which was built by John and Dominique de Menil, the university confirmed on Friday.

headline: Gauging the Tax Impact of Investments Options and Living in New Jersey
text: JIMMY FALLON has brought “The Tonight Show” back to New York City, and in return for leaving California, the show’s owner, NBCUniversal, is receiving a tax credit that amounts to about $20 million a year.

headline: Rain in California Brings Relief, and New Problems
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s not quite a month of Sundays — or even a perfect game pitched in the seventh game of a World Series — but something rather extraordinary happened across California on Friday.

headline: Surge in Stocks Helps Norway Oil Fund’s Profit Soar
text: Norway’s giant oil fund said on Friday that it earned 15.9 percent, or about $115 billion, on its investments last year, profiting from big bets on American and European stocks that offset losses in government bonds from around the world.

headline: What Faces Can’t Tell Us
text: CAN you detect someone’s emotional state just by looking at his face?

headline: Book Review Podcast: Commercial Coupling
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Alida Becker reviews Anne de Courcy’s “The Fishing Fleet: Husband-Hunting in the Raj.” Ms. Becker writes:

headline: Did Inflation Phobia Cause the Great Recession?
text: We now know that many key people at the Fed spent 2008, the year of financial doom, obsessing about inflation, which wasn’t a threat at all. This is not good; what’s even not-gooder is that, as David Glasner and others have pointed out, the central bankers who got this so completely wrong remain in positions of great influence, and show no sign of having rethought their views.

headline: Why the Bank Leverage Ratio Is Important
text: Mayra Rodríguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a New York-based capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm. She is also a faculty member at Financial Markets World.

text: Paris

headline: The Gun Report: February 28, 2014
text: • With a bill allowing students and staff to carry guns on Idaho’s college campuses making its way through the state legislature, Greg Hampikian, a professor of biology and criminal justice at Boise State University, asks today in a Times Op-Ed, “When may I shoot a student?” The column, styled as a letter to the state legislature, continued, “Now that we’ll all be packing heat, I would like legal instruction in the rules of classroom engagement. … If I am working out a long equation on the board and several students try to correct me using their laser sights, am I allowed to fire a warning shot?”

headline: Movie Review: 'The Lunchbox'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Lunchbox."

headline: Balancing Act
text: The latest Range Rover Sport has found a nice compromise between handling on-pavement and off-road performance.

text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Non-Stop."

text: The 2014 Land Rover Range Rover Sport might be a better mountain climber than slalom runner, but don't roll your eyes at the "sport" badge on this S.U.V.

headline: Save for Retirement First, the Children’s Education Second
text: A HALF-DOZEN years ago, Brian Appelbaum’s savings plan was focused mainly on his own retirement. But now he is married and the father of two young children.

headline: A Stylist for Whom ‘Nice’ Is Not an Insult
text: “It could be a shoe moment,” said Jeanann Williams, a fashion stylist.

headline: An All-Terrain Hero Shifts Priorities
text: Many see Range Rovers as dignified transportation for the upper crust. Picture Queen Elizabeth II peering over the steering wheel of this talisman of British gentry, perhaps returning to Balmoral Castle, the royal family’s summer retreat in Scotland, from a grouse shoot.

headline: Oscars in Party Mode, a Few Days Early
text: LOS ANGELES – With Oscar Sunday comes Oscar Party Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. Oh and Saturday, too. The flurry of congratulatory activity leading up to the big show includes cocktails, galas, benefits and celebrations old and new.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Lanvin Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Why Republicans Don’t Want to Acknowledge the Falling Deficit
text: An important budget memo was issued this week celebrating just how far the deficit had fallen over the last five years. But in one of the incongruities that define the political moment, the memo was issued by a Democrat, Senator Patty Murray of Washington, chairwoman of the Budget Committee, not a Republican.

headline: Raising the Bar on Prices and Amenities
text: Just a few layers of lath and plaster can stand between two homes in New York City, and still, people may never meet their neighbors. But for apartment dwellers in a crop of new rental towers, it may be hard to remain strangers.

headline: The Best of the Week’s eBay Barbs
text: Carl C. Icahn and eBay executives might not be debating on CNBC anytime soon, but the verbal war between the activist investor and the e-commerce behemoth intensified this week all the same.

headline: A Purpose Beyond Profit
text: For years, I’ve listened to chief executives of large companies pay dutiful lip service to concepts like corporate social responsibility, investing in the communities they operate in, treating employees as their most precious asset and living their values. Mostly, it comes off as so much canned public posturing — boxes to be checked off, rather than any sort of deep commitment.

headline: Wine on Wheels
text: How often have cyclists wished for a bike basket that could securely hold a bottle of wine and two wineglasses for the duration of their ride? Probably not that often, though with the current proliferation of bike tours taking visitors closer to both nature and alcohol, they may soon be in high demand.

headline: Protesters Say They’ll End Blockades in Bangkok
text: BANGKOK — In what appeared to be a major retreat by the movement to overthrow the Thai government, protesters on Friday said they were abandoning their campaign to shut down Bangkok and would dismantle their blockades of major intersections set up in January.

headline: A Shakespearean Mash-Up With Scintillations of Sorcery
text: A few years back, Peter Gelb, in one of his most daft and delightful strokes as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, hatched the notion of creating a full-scale Baroque-style pastiche opera, scavenging arias and instrumental numbers from a variety of Baroque sources. The resulting odd beast of a work — “The Enchanted Island,” “devised and written” (the Met’s words) by Jeremy Sams and ever so loosely based on Shakespeare’s “The Tempest” and “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” — stirred considerable curiosity.

headline: An Alien March Madness: Is There Life in Space?
text: It’s not an invasion from space, but it is an invasion about space.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, South Sudan and Nigeria.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: This week’s On the Market in the Region properties include a renovated five-bedroom Tudor in New Rochelle, N.Y., and six-bedroom home in Old Tappan, N.J., featuring artistic floor and wall treatments.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s On the Market in New York City properties include an Upper East Side Co-op in a Beaux-Arts building; a Garment District condo in a former clothing factory; and Lefferts Manor townhouse built in 1910.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Curating Inspiration
text: The designer gives Suzy Menkes a tour of his exhibition, "Dries Van Noten: Inspirations," at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris.

headline: Cate Blanchett’s Fashion Sense
text: Ms. Blanchett, who is nominated for a best actress Oscar, commands respect on both the silver screen and the red carpet.

headline: Insulted by Don Rickles and Thrilled About It
text: LOS ANGELES – Philomena Lee was not the only party-hopper on Thursday night. The Bagger and Martin Scorsese made the rounds too though, sadly, not together.

headline: NJOY, E-Cigarette Maker, Receives Funding Valuing It at $1 Billion
text: Even as electronic cigarettes draw the scrutiny of regulators around the world, investors are seeing potential in the fledgling industry.

headline: A Romance That Shocked in Another Era
text: Characters keep talking about Manhattan’s falling snow in the Keen Company’s polished revival of Paddy Chayefsky’s “Middle of the Night,” now at the Clurman Theater. Sometimes it’s invigorating, inspiring them to walk for blocks; sometimes it wears them down like the attrition of age. And sometimes it’s a metaphor for the familial reaction to this play’s love that dare not speak its name: a May-December romance.

headline: An Argument to Turn to Jesus Before the Bar
text: When Kim S. Phipps was leading the search for a new president of the Council for Christian Colleges and Universities, she called Edward O. Blews Jr. and said, “Ed, this is God, and she is calling you to the C.C.C.U. presidency.”

headline: Ugly? It’s a Crowd Pleaser Now
text: PHILADELPHIA — Look at a new car that you think is preposterous. Chances are good that 50 years from now, when few like it remain, it will attract a crowd of admirers on the street.

headline: Growing Into Its Looks
text: With styling that was once dismissed as garish, Chris Rossi’s Lincoln Continental Mark V now draws a crowd of admirers wherever it goes.

headline: The How and Why of Dal
text: I went to my local Indian grocery the other day looking for dal, but I couldn’t decide which dal to buy. There were so many kinds to choose from, all enticing — bright orange massour dal, canary yellow chana dal, ivory hued urad dal and straw-colored moong dal, among others. In the end, I bought 10 one-pound packages, each a different color.

headline: After 15 Years, Reunited and Restored
text: Have you ever lost a car? Of course you have — at the airport or in a snow bank, or maybe your roommate, spouse, mom or dad took off with it. And let’s not forget the rented silver Altima you parked at the mall the week before Christmas.

headline: CCTV Shows Crimean Parliament Takeover
text: Footage from security cameras showed the moment armed men seized Simferopol’s Parliament building in Ukraine’s Crimea region.

headline: (Supreme) Court TV and the Magically Disappearing Protest
text: Let’s set aside for the moment the perennial debate over whether the Supreme Court should (yes) or will (someday, surely) join the other branches of government and televise its proceedings. Instead let’s consider the Court’s odd and counterproductive handling of the incident captured on the dramatic, unprecedented secret video that appeared on YouTube yesterday afternoon.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The White Album
text: The popularity of white outerwear this winter has been a perfect match for a particularly snowy season. A surprise, since white coats are perhaps the greatest luxury of fashion because of their need for constant cleaning. Many women wore white or off-white fur-side-out shearling coats (bottom row), though one woman preferred the leather side out, coated in gold. There were white hooded jackets, white marabou-trimmed mules and even a white Marie Antoinette wig. High school students from San Antonio made snowmen, complete with a white topper with a large brim, which they made by rolling snow along a wood banister at Bryant Park.

headline: Photo: Authorities Seize $4 Million Statue in Queens
text: Officials on Friday seized a Roman statue valued at $4 million on behalf of Italian officials who say it was looted. As Tom Mashberg reported on Thursday:

headline: Week in Pictures for Feb. 28
text: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes a cemetery on Staten Island, a new PATH station platform at the World Trade Center hub, and a memorial for Ukrainian protesters in the East Village.

headline: A Designer’s Palm Beach Jumble Sale
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — They came from all over, seeking a fragment of Lilly Pulitzer’s life and a souvenir of a woman they called an icon. Will Bannister and his wife, Leslie, came from Fort Worth, Tex.; Brandon and Cheryl Forbes Plunkett from Nashville; and Eva Cox from Cleveland, where she had built up a kitty especially for an auction of property from the Pulitzer estate.

headline: Comfy in Any Costume

headline: Graydon Carter, the Last Impresario
text: On a recent chilly Monday afternoon, Graydon Carter, the Vanity Fair editor and host of a party that for two decades has been the hottest ticket in Hollywood on Oscars night, perched on a tan modernist sofa in his vast 22nd-floor corner office at 4 Times Square, looking like a Hirschfeld sketch of himself. His Buddha-like belly bulged from a blue bespoke jacket; his trademark swoop of silver hair, which by now seems to function as an alternate logo for Vanity Fair, looked like a curvilinear roof by Saarinen.

headline: Almodóvar’s World, Spun With (What Else?) Passion
text: Have you ever considered how the splashy, sultry films of Pedro Almodóvar might translate into dance? Jomar Mesquita, the artistic director of Mimulus Cia de Dança, offers his interpretation in “Dolores,” an evening-length work heavier on atmosphere than on linear story, which opened at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Dior Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: A Spiritual Adviser’s Help Is Twisted as He’s Tormented
text: In the tradition of thrillers about unassuming acquaintances who turn out to be deadly (“Misery,” “Fatal Attraction”) comes “Repentance,” a movie of modest means that nevertheless offers a fairly cohesive story and at least one standout performance. It may underplay an idea laden with potential, but at least that notion is present.

headline: Heavy Rains Pound Southern California
text: A second winter storm this week swept into California, bringing more rain than this drought-hit state has had in months.

headline: Cleaning Out Rauschenberg’s Attic: Places in the Sun for His Late Work
text: The artist Robert Rauschenberg hated repeating himself, art-wise, and said that his works, as an honest reflection of his life, were “really just evidence that I’m still paying attention.”

text: Secretary of State John Kerry called Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, to express concerns over military activity in Crimea that could further inflame tensions in Ukraine.

headline: Side Road to Success Wins Matthew McConaughey Admiration

Their conversation turned to Mr. McConaughey and his Oscar-nominated role as an AIDS patient in “Dallas Buyers Club.”

text: President Obama said any intervention militarily in Ukraine would be “deeply destabilizing.”

headline: In Paris, Oscar Viewing Becomes a Challenge
text: PARIS — During Paris Fashion Week, which runs through Wednesday, there has been a wave of anxiety among fashion editors that doesn’t have anything to do with traffic jams or running late to a show. Editors have been flummoxed in trying to figure out how they’re going to watch the Academy Awards telecast on Sunday, which begins after 2 a.m. here.

text: Stephen A. Schwarzman is raking in the rewards of a hugely successful year for the Blackstone Group.

text: Venezuela protests continue amid the start of a long Carnival weekend. Also on the Minute, start-ups that copy their way to success and the rise of practical robots.

headline: Under Cover: How Do You Light a Woolly Mammoth?
text: When Joanna Milter, the magazine’s deputy photo editor, contacted the Royal BC Museum in Victoria, Canada, about photographing its replica woolly mammoth for this week’s cover story, a museum staff person warned her that the shoot would be, and we quote, “a lighting challenge.”

text: From Michelle Obama to Michael Moore to Marlon Brando (or not Marlon Brando), the Oscars have a long political history, explains Sam Tanenhaus of The Times.

text: At the 19th NEC Bridge Festival in Yokohama City, Japan, two weeks ago, the teams that did not qualify for the quarterfinals of the NEC Cup played in a subsidiary Swiss Team event.

headline: Another Light Shines Through
text: The guitarist and songwriter Bryce Dessner is best known as a member of the indie-rock band the National. Lately, though, he has spread his wings as a classical composer. Lest you jump to unwarranted conclusions, understand that Mr. Dessner has long created a quirky strain of chamber music with another group, Clogs, and that the Kronos Quartet has championed his compositions. On Friday, Mr. Dessner celebrates the release of “St. Carolyn by the Sea,” his debut album of orchestral music for Deutsche Grammophon, with a concert by Ensemble LPR, Le Poisson Rouge’s house chamber orchestra. The program includes Mr. Dessner’s “Lachrimae” and another piece from his CD, a suite from the Radiohead guitarist Jonny Greenwood’s score for “There Will Be Blood.” André de Ridder, who conducts the Copenhagen Philharmonic on Mr. Dessner’s album, makes his New York debut with this concert. (8 p.m., Le Poisson Rouge, 158 Bleecker Street, near Thompson Street, Greenwich Village; lepoissonrouge.com.)

headline: New Variations on Standard Jazz
text: The young tenor saxophonist Aaron Burnett, originally from Chicago, can play a ballad standard with feeling, and then head into an improvisation with wide intervals and split-tone effects.

headline: New Season at That Motel
text: We knew going into “Bates Motel” that young Norman Bates (Freddie Highmore) was going to be an odd duck and that his mother, Norma (Vera Farmiga), was likely to have some odd ideas about child rearing. What we didn’t know was that the whole danged town is a little unhinged.

headline: From Beach to Bathroom
text: As a soloist with New York City Ballet, Tom Gold often seemed an amiable dancer, and some of his good-natured personality may be creeping into his ballets now that he has become a choreographer.

headline: ‘Family Guy’ Guy as Astrobiology Guy
text: WASHINGTON — When some of the nation’s brightest minds gathered here at the Library of Congress to celebrate Carl Sagan, the pioneering astrobiologist, the first guest speaker was someone with no professional background in science.

headline: A Hometown, Amplified
text: Last summer, the Italian Conceptual artist Rudolf Stingel created something of a sensation in Venice when he covered most of the public spaces — the majestic atrium and two floors — of the 18th-century Palazzo Grassi with a digitally printed, predominantly red Ottoman carpet over which he sparingly hung a combination of abstract and Photo-Realist paintings. Mr. Stingel, who is known for continuously expanding his repertoire, has recently been immersing himself in landscapes. In 2010, the Neue Nationalgalerie in Berlin showed some of his earliest attempts. Now, from Tuesday through April 12, eight of his new photo-based landscapes will be shown at the Gagosian Gallery, 522 West 21st Street, in Chelsea.

headline: It Takes a Funeral: So Much Angst
text: Patrice Chéreau was a creature of the theater. But he had a parallel career as a moviemaker, which the Film Society of Lincoln Center is honoring in the series Patrice Chéreau: The Love That Dares. If nothing he did for the screen had the genre-shaking impact of his stage work — his 1976 “Ring” cycle at Bayreuth helped usher in an era of Regietheater, or director’s theater — he did raise eyebrows with the sexually explicit “Intimacy” (2001), starring all of Mark Rylance, the corseted Olivia in the “Twelfth Night” that just ended its Broadway run. “Intimacy” was much discussed for how much it showed and how real or not the sex was, though what’s most real — and naked — is the emotional life of Mr. Rylance’s character. “Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train” (1998) only seems more buttoned up. As a train hurtles toward Limoges and a funeral, Mr. Chéreau plunges us into a world of interlocking relationships, of sex, desire, despondency. The style is distinctly cinematic, but the emotion verges on operatic. (Through Wednesday; filmlinc.com.)

headline: Let Them Wear Crowns
text: PARIS — The royal court of Undercover arrived here Wednesday night. Jun Takahashi’s show had the pomp and circumstance of an uncanny jubilee. It left some of the most indelible images seen so far this Fashion Week.
